HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
China Says Banking System Faces a Sweeping Overhaul

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 16

 BODY:
At the heart of the financial crisis in Asia is a badly kept secret: many bank loans throughout the region are based on a personal or political relationship between banker and borrower.
Cronyism is widespread in Asian business, and in China -- as much as anywhere -- friendship and position can outweigh the law. But crisis can open the way for change. 
 Today, the governor of China's central bank disclosed a sweeping reorganization of the banking system aimed at making it more professional and less political, an undertaking that reflects the desire of Chinese leaders to keep Asia's financial crisis from engulfing them as well.
Dai Xianglong, who heads the People's Bank of China, said that curing the nation's epidemic of bad debt would require a different system of supervising state banks, one modeled on the Federal Reserve in the United States.
"We have to insure that commercial banks will operate according to law, and not be open to interference by any organization or individual," Mr. Dai told a news conference.
Yet the plans Mr. Dai outlined involve such a deep shift in business practice and philosophy that it is highly questionable how much real change can be achieved. Coming just as China is undergoing a wrenching shift from a planned to a market economy, the financial overhaul may also be more difficult at a time when China faces falling investment and slowing economic growth.
Mr. Dai argued this juncture was precisely the time for a bold reorientation, and he pledged to complete the job in just three years, mirroring the Government's plans to sell the bulk of the state-owned enterprises by the end of 2000.
"Just as state-owned enterprises are the key to enterprise reform, the central bank is key to financial reform," Mr. Dai said.
Under the plans he outlined, the central bank would eliminate its main branches in each of China's 30 provinces and replace them with regional headquarters along the lines of the Federal Reserve system. Doing so, Mr. Dai said, would help prevent the local authorities from forcing local banks to finance favored projects, even when they made no sense financially.
A Chinese bank official said the reorganization was likely to centralize financial decision-making power under the control of Zhu Rongji, the Deputy Prime Minister whose authority over economic affairs often puts him at odds with provincial-level officials. Closing so many local bank offices would also mean at least 20,000 layoffs, the official said.
"The idea is that regional bank heads will outrank provincial governors, and won't have to listen to them," said the bank official, who said he supported Mr. Zhu's plans and spoke on condition of anonymity.
One of the modern mysteries of China's financial system, and biggest burden, is the question of how many loans to money-losing enterprises will ever be repaid.
Mr. Dai said today that 20 percent to 25 percent of all loans in China were overdue, but he argued that only 5 percent to 6 percent were actually unrecoverable, a figure that sounds optimistic. Yet even he seemed to acknowledge that China's statistics were incomplete.
"You can argue about whether this 5-6 percent is accurate or not," Mr. Dai said. "But I don't want to hear anyone repeating those rumors that it is 25-30 or even 40 percent. That would be irresponsible."
Even the lower estimate, however, requires a sizable amount of cash if China's banks are to remain solvent. Mr. Dai said the central bank would allocate more than $6 billion to cover unpaid loans in 1998, and another $7 to 8.5 billion in 1999 and 2000.
For many ordinary people in China, a major question of the day is whether the central bank will devalue the currency, the yuan, which will help China's exports but could cause higher inflation. Today, Mr. Dai insisted that the need for financial stability still outweighed the possible benefits of a devaluation. He said China would not devalue its currency this year.
Mr. Dai also expressed support for the determination of Hong Kong to keep its currency's value linked to the dollar, even if doing so drove up interest rates and damaged the stock and property markets.
"Of course China would like to see the stock market and inflation rate remain stable as well," Mr. Dai said. "But compared with these aims, stabilizing the exchange rate is more important."
Mr. Dai described the collapse of Peregrine Investments Holdings, a Hong Kong investment bank that led the market for Chinese share offerings there, as "very regrettable." But he said it would not affect China's plans to list shares of more mainland companies in Hong Kong.
Over all, Mr. Dai offered a relatively optimistic picture for China's economy this year, predicting growth would exceed 8 percent. Growth last year was 8.8 percent. He also said the country's foreign exchange reserves totaled $139.9 billion at the end of 1997.

HEADLINE: Journal;
The 2 Tim McVeighs

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
Here's a scenario that could be out of Kafka, or at least Alfred Hitchcock -- except that it's really happening and hasn't been sold to Hollywood. Yet. Its protagonist is Timothy McVeigh -- not that Timothy McVeigh, but a 36-year-old sailor who, through bad luck, not genealogy, found himself with the same name as the biggest mass murderer in American history.
And that's the good news. Last fall, while on duty as the senior enlisted man on a nuclear submarine, he exchanged America Online E-mail with a civilian Navy employee with whom he was organizing a Christmas charity toy drive for kids back at his Honolulu base. His good deed did not go unpunished. His correspondent checked out his "member profile" -- the autobiographical sketch any AOL member can voluntarily post on line -- and discovered that Mr. McVeigh had listed his marital status as "gay." She promptly notified the Navy that it just might have a declared homosexual in its midst. 
 But if the Navy wanted to dismiss the sailor for having violated "Don't ask, don't tell," it had no case. The AOL profile identified this "gay" man as only Tim of Honolulu, with no last name. According to subsequent sworn testimony, a Navy investigator solved this problem simply by asking AOL over the phone for Tim's identity -- and promptly got an answer. Once back on shore, Mr. McVeigh was put under investigation and then ordered discharged, three years short of his pension. Merry Christmas!
The sailor is fighting back in court, however, and in the virtual court of Internet opinion, where his case has been raging for the past week. By the time real judges weigh in he could be easily the second most famous Timothy McVeigh in history. If the Navy investigator did pursue Mr. McVeigh's cyberidentity without either identifying himself or obtaining a court order, it's a likely violation of the Electronic Communications Privacy Act. If AOL did blithely unmask one of its 10 million members (many of whom use anonymous screen names), it too is in legal jeopardy -- and will face a meltdown of consumer confidence that will dwarf its past P.R. disasters over service outage.
So far the Navy is defending its snooping and AOL is pleading innocent. Mr. McVeigh, for his part, has pointedly never declared that he is gay, noting that AOL member profiles routinely fib and fictionalize. His aggressive legal tactics have already sent Government lawyers scrambling; his discharge has been delayed until next Wednesday. By the time he's done, Mr. McVeigh may be the poster boy for the whole country's growing concerns about all kinds of cyberspying.
He may also prove to be the man who finally brings home the absurdity and bigotry of "Don't ask, don't tell." Mr. McVeigh is as clear-cut a victim of a witch hunt as could be imagined, and that witch hunt could expand exponentially if the military wants to add on-line fishing to its invasion of service members' privacy. Multitudes of military personnel identify themselves as gay on the Internet, rank and base often included.
Even if Mr. McVeigh were to prove one such gay sailor, what has he done wrong? He has served his country for 17 years with a spotless record, earning four Good Conduct Medals and the Navy Commendation Medal, among other decorations; his performance reviews cite him as an "outstanding role model" and a leader in crew training on equal-opportunity issues.
Contrast that record with the other Timothy McVeigh's. In his Army stint before, during and after the Persian Gulf war, the Oklahoma bomber was known for fomenting racial polarization by slurring his black peers and assigning them the dirtiest tasks in the motor pool. He openly trafficked in anti-Semitic and racist literature and participated in the activities of off-base organizations toying with armed resistance to the Government. In a published letter to a newspaper editor, he argued that it might be necessary to "shed blood" to achieve his political aims.
What does it say about American fairness and justice -- let alone our priorities in national security -- that the military looked the other way at that Timothy McVeigh's ostentatious public psychosis while it torments the second, exemplary Timothy McVeigh for the "crime" of having a private life that should be nobody's business but his own?

LENGTH: 485 words

HEADLINE: Taking Leave of the Census

 BODY:
The resignation of the Census Bureau's Director, Martha Farnsworth Riche, does not bode well for hopes that the 2000 Census will be more accurate than the flawed effort in 1990. Ms. Riche, a respected professional demographer, says she has accomplished her goal of redesigning the census process, but regrettably she will not see the difficult task to completion. Her departure robs the agency of the leadership needed to resist political efforts to hijack the census.
Ms. Riche has had to battle fierce political opposition from Republicans on the use of statistical sampling to supplement the traditional head count in the upcoming census. The 1990 Census, which did not use sampling, was the most costly in history and yet missed 10 million Americans and counted 6 million twice or in the wrong place, according to analyses by the National Academy of Sciences. That is because census counts depend entirely on locating people at specific addresses. New immigrants, those in shared housing, migrant workers, the homeless, the poor and young people tend to be undercounted. As these populations grow, particularly in larger cities, the traditional counting approach has become less and less accurate. 
 Professional statisticians and economists, including experts convened by the National Academy, have said that taking a sampling of those who do not return their census forms by mail and using that sample to estimate the uncounted population would be far more accurate than sending field workers out to make fruitless door-to-door counts. Ms. Riche has been a sensible proponent of this plan.
But Republicans have fought sampling because they believe that the missing millions could turn out to be minorities living in areas that vote Democratic, possibly giving Democrats an advantage since census figures are used to draw state and Federal legislative districts. In a compromise deal hammered out between the White House and Republican leaders last November, the Census Bureau was allowed to go forward with a small dress rehearsal using both sampling and traditional counting techniques this year. In exchange, House Speaker Newt Gingrich will be allowed to use government money to bring a lawsuit to stop the use of sampling in the actual census in 2000.
Ms. Riche's departure could leave the Census Bureau without a guiding force when the sampling battle resumes in Congress after this testing period. It appears unlikely that the Republicans will approve a nominee to the post who supports sampling. Yet Ms. Riche bluntly says there is probably no one in the professional community who thinks an accurate census can be taken without sampling. The Administration may decide to shy away from a confirmation battle by naming an acting director to the agency instead. The politics that drives this debate now threatens to undermine what should be a politically neutral government task.

HEADLINE: Comptroller of the Currency Plans to Leave

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The Comptroller of the Currency, who regulates nationally chartered banks, told President Clinton this week that he planned to leave office on April 4, when his five-year term expires.
"I am proud of what we have been able to achieve," the regulator, Eugene A. Ludwig, wrote, citing his involvement with other regulators in easing the credit shortage that hurt the economies of New England and other areas after the 1990-91 recession. 
 He also prodded banks to increase their lending in poor communities and noted that such lending had increased to $43 billion annually from $3 billion before 1993.
If a successor has not been confirmed before April 4, the agency's chief counsel, Julie Williams, will become acting comptroller.

HEADLINE: Clinton and 3 Baltic Leaders Sign Charter

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
President Clinton signed a charter of partnership today with the Presidents of the three Baltic countries, once among the "captive nations" under Soviet rule, and pledged American support for their aspirations to join NATO.
"This charter of partnership underscores how far your nations have come," Mr. Clinton said in the White House East Room to Presidents Lennart Meri of Estonia, Guntis Ulmanis of Latvia and Algirdas Brazauskas of Lithuania. 
 "Almost exactly seven years ago today, Baltic citizens were facing down tanks in the struggle to reclaim their independence," Mr. Clinton said. "Today your democracies have taken root."
The charter does not guarantee NATO membership but offers Washington's explicit support for the Baltic nations' efforts to join. "America is determined," Mr. Clinton said, "to create the conditions under which Estonia, Lithuania and Latvia can one day walk through that door."
America's security is tied to Europe, Mr. Clinton said, "and Europe will never be fully secure if Baltic security is in doubt."
The charter says the United States has "a real, profound and enduring" interest in the security and independence of the three countries and their integration into organizations like the European Union and the World Trade Organization.
Without pledging the United States to the defense of the Baltic countries, the charter embodies a moral and political commitment to their independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity and sets up a Partnership Commission to promote democracy and market reforms.
America's NATO allies, wary of alienating Moscow by extending NATO membership into the former Soviet Union, insisted that the charter also reflect NATO's ultimate responsibility, as a collective alliance, for choosing new members.
"Membership must not be just in the interests of the Baltic states," a senior NATO country official said. "It must serve the overall strategic interests of the alliance."
President Ulmanis of Latvia said today: "This charter will serve as a key for the next century. It makes us allies."
In another action today, Mr. Clinton, for the fourth time, renewed his waiver of a provision in the Helms-Burton Act that tightens American sanctions on Cuba and allows American citizens to sue foreign companies doing business from properties that were expropriated from American companies by the Castro Government.
The United States has been under increasing pressure from allies to end its decades-old embargo on Cuba. Pope John Paul II, who visits Cuba next week, has chided Washington for the hardship its policies impose on the Cuban people, and European and Canadian allies have criticized the legislation.
The Soviets annexed the Baltic nations after overrunning them in 1940, but Washington never recognized the annexation. "For 50 years," Mr. Clinton said today, "Lithuanian, Latvian and Estonian Americans kept alive the dream of Baltic freedom." Mr. Brazauskas's recently elected successor as Lithuanian President, Valdas Adamkus, fled Soviet rule as a teen-ager and came to the United States, retiring in 1996 as a top administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency's Chicago region.
"With its bipartisan support for a nonrecognition policy, America was a true friend of the Baltics in a time of need, acting as a beacon of hope throughout the long, dark and cold years of the Soviet occupation," President Meri of Estonia said today.
"NATO enlargement to the Baltics will be the next big project of the alliance," he said, and the "real test of post-Madrid security thinking," he added, referring to the NATO summit meeting last July in which the alliance agreed to admit Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic.
The Senate is expected to vote on that expansion this spring. Baltic membership would be much more contentious, and American officials have told the Baltic nations not to expect to be part of a second expansion in 1999. They have also been urged to do everything possible to solidify and stabilize their relations with Russia and to treat ethnic Russians within their boundaries with care and respect.
Russia's reaction to this charter has been "surprisingly low-key," American officials say. Moscow has urged the Baltic nations to adopt Finland's neutral stand, outside NATO, but the Baltic countries have rejected any limitation on their freedom to join any European security or cooperative organization.
The United States is urging the European Union to take in the Baltic nations as rapidly as possible to provide another form of "soft security," and Estonia is believed to be first in line for possible membership in the union before the turn of the century.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Decline as Outlook for Asia Seems to Improve

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell sharply yesterday as the near-term outlook for Asia seemed to improve, the stock market rallied and there were new signs that the economy was strong as 1997 ended.
The yield on the 30-year bond, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, rose to 5.80 percent, from 5.74 percent Thursday, as the price fell 1 point, to 104 17/32. The yield on the 10-year note rose to 5.53 percent from 5.46, and the yields on shorter-term government securities also moved higher. Trading ended at 2 P.M. ahead of Martin Luther King Jr. Day on Monday. 
 If this pullback in yields holds, it could be disappointing for consumers who had seen mortgage interest rates fall to four-year lows earlier this week but hoped for further declines. According to The Bank Rate Monitor, the average rate nationally on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage dropped to 6.87 percent this week while the rate on a 15-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 6.49 percent.
But since hitting recent lows on Monday, the yield on the 30-year bond has jumped from 5.69 percent and the 10-year yield, which is the key rate for mortgages, has risen from 5.36 percent.
Robert Heady, the publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, said that if yields held at yesterday's level, mortgage rates should rise a little when he does his weekly survey on Wednesday. Mr. Heady says that rates are so low now that if all other aspects of the mortgage are favorable it is probably better to lock in a rate than "to play Las Vegas."
Analysts and traders, however, think that the selloff yesterday was just a blip in a trend that should continue to push interest rates lower.
"To me today's movement simply shows that the market got a little ahead of itself," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, said, "We started the week way over the top." But, he added, "this does not mean we are not going to have any more rally." He said that the shortened trading day and Monday's holiday added to selling as traders worked to leave themselves less exposed over the long weekend.
The bond market got its big assist last week from the apparent worsening in the outlook for Asia as the Government of Indonesia seemed unwilling to put into effect the economic measures required as part of its $40 billion international bailout. Much of the buying, traders said, was from foreigners seeking a haven in the American market.
But this week the outlook changed, with President Suharto of Indonesia signing a new accord with the International Monetary Fund on Thursday. The fall of the dollar this week against the yen indicated that some of this foreign buying might be reversing.
Asian stock markets also rebounded, including a 6.11 percent surge in Japan and a 6.89 percent jump in Indonesia yesterday. But this optimism could reverse quickly. The selloff in Asia in the first week of the year followed a December where things were looking better.
Mr. Fine said that investors had pushed long-term yields to near 30-year lows and short-term yields to below the Federal Reserve's 5.5 percent target for the overnight Federal funds rate because they see low inflation continuing and they expect the drag from Asia to slow growth here and curb prices even further.
But he said that some investors might also be betting that the Asian drag on the American economy would force the Federal Reserve to cut its short-term interest rate target soon. That hope, he said, may be being reassessed right now, a fact reflected by the jump in the yield of the two-year note, which fell as low as 5.02 percent during trading Monday but ended yesterday at 5.33 percent.
One reason for this, Mr. Fine said, is that the economy has not yet shown any significant sign of slowing from the nearly 4 percent pace of growth last year, although a slowdown is the consensus for 1998.
The Federal Reserve's report on December industrial production yesterday showed a jump of five-tenths of a percent last month and an increase of 5 percent for the year, the strongest performance since 1994. The report showed that American factories were operating at the highest capacity since September 1995.
At the same time, people who have seen the early January University of Michigan consumer sentiment index said it had jumped to 104, compared with a final December reading of 102.1. The Michigan report is released only to subscribers.

HEADLINE: San Simeon Resort Plan Rejected

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The California Coastal Commission has rejected a plan that would have let the Hearst Corporation build a 650-room resort on land surrounding Hearst Castle State Park at San Simeon, instead approving a scaled-down 375-room project that the company contends would be economically unfeasible.
The Hearst proposal, for land the company owns, was part of a broader coastal plan by San Luis Obispo County that the commission unanimously rejected late Thursday. That plan now goes back to the county, which has six months to respond, and Hearst has vowed to fight on for a the bigger project. 
 Environmental groups were bitterly opposed to the Hearst plan, which includes a proposal for a 27-hole golf course and a dude ranch, saying it would waste scarce water, block ocean views and impede public access to one of the last stretches of undeveloped coastline in the state. Some local groups supported the plan as a spur to economic development.
The coastal commission staff had rejected the plan as too big, and after a daylong hearing that drew hundreds of people in San Luis Obispo, the commission agreed by a vote of 9 to 3 that the project should go forward only if it was greatly scaled down and the golf course eliminated.
If the county and the commission cannot reach agreement on a new coastal plan for the region, the current plan, passed in the early 1980's, remains in effect. That zoning plan would allow for the bigger resort, but commission staff members and environmental groups say that changes in environmental standards and growth in the region since then make it unlikely that Hearst could ever obtain the necessary permits from the commission to build the resort.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Surge in Asian Stocks Buoys Markets in Europe and U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Asia led the way. Then came Europe and the United States.
Global stock markets rallied yesterday after the Japanese Government backed a plan that many investors believe will stimulate its economy and help ease concerns about the Asia crisis. 
 Although much of Asia remains mired in financial and economic problems, optimism sent stock prices soaring in Japan, Hong Kong and elsewhere in the region.
The Nikkei 225 average, the main Japanese stock index, jumped 6.1 percent to its highest level in nearly a month. The Hang Seng index in Hong Kong, one of the bellwether stock indexes in the Pacific Rim, gained nearly 4 percent.
Those gains helped push stock prices higher in much of Europe, and later in the United States.
"Asia drove stock prices today," H. Vernon Winters, the chief investment officer at Mellon Private Asset Management in Boston, said. "You saw it span across the world, from Asia to Europe and then here."
It has been that way for some time now. Events in Asia set the tone for trading in the rest of the world.
Many of the world's largest governments and the International Monetary Fund have mobilized to contain the damage from Asia's currency and financial crisis, which began in Thailand last summer and spread. But much of the world is bracing for a slowdown that could hurt corporate profits and stock prices.
While the United States economy remains robust, bullish investors have been in retreat for months, while bearish types forecast the end of one of the greatest bull markets of all time.
What impact the Asian crisis will have on United States profits remains unclear. But this week at least, strong earnings from several technology companies helped the market recover from a sharp selloff last week.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 7,753.55 yesterday, up 61.78 for the day. For the week, the blue-chip average rose 173.13 points points, or 2.3 percent, recovering about half its loss the week before, the worst weekly setback since 1989.
Broader measures also gained yesterday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 10.78, to 961.51, and the Nasdaq composite gained 15.82, to 1,562.88.
The market may have been lifted by more evidence that the United States economy remains strong. The Government said industrial production rose in December for the 14th consecutive month and factories operated at their highest rate since September 1995.
Many on Wall Street believe that the strength of the American economy will cushion corporations affected by slower growth abroad.
But investors still do not know how to interpret events in Asia. For seven months now, the Dow average and other stock market indexes have advanced little. The Dow accumulated most of 1997's spectacular overall gain during the first half of the year.
"If you go back to July, that's where we got the first news about Thailand," Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal Lyon & Ross, said. "And since then, we've been whipped around."
The main fear is that earnings will suffer as exports to Asia decline and cheaper imports from Asia force American companies to lower prices, cutting profit margins.
Barbara Marcin, a strategist at Citibank Global Asset Management, said that until investors get through fourth-quarter earnings and have more guidance on Asia's impact, it will be difficult for the market to advance. Even then, she said, prospects for a strong 1998 are doubtful.
"We might see a 5 or 10 percent gain in the stock market this year, she said. "But after three spectacular years, you're probably not going to get another stellar year."

HEADLINE: Congeniality And Unease As Wall St. Addresses Race

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
There was something for everyone at this week's Wall Street conference organized by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and his Rainbow/PUSH coalition.
The meeting -- with its star-studded cast that included President Clinton and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve -- offered Mr. Jackson and his organization an opportunity to generate headlines again while raising tough questions about why black Americans and other minorities have had so little access to investment capital, financial training and well-paying jobs. 
 And with affirmative action under increasing assault in the political arena and in the courts, business may actually be a friendlier forum these days for Mr. Jackson to practice his patented blend of uplift and agitation. Hobnobbing with the country's financial titans did not hurt Mr. Jackson's image, either.
"You raised my stock, thank you very much," Mr. Jackson half-jokingly told Mr. Greenspan after the Fed chairman addressed the conference. He did more than that. The meeting also provided Mr. Jackson and Rainbow/PUSH with an opportunity to raise tens of thousands of dollars from Wall Street's bulging pockets.
Mr. Jackson would not say exactly how much money had been raised by this week's event, although he said that the event's sponsors, which included big Wall Street firms like Merrill Lynch and the Salomon Smith Barney subsidiary of Travelers Group, had provided $400,000 "in round figures" to help cover the cost.
Rainbow/PUSH also held a fund-raiser Thursday night on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, with about 450 guests paying $500 each for dinner and entertainment by the singer Roberta Flack. Mr. Jackson declined to say how much that event had raised, explaining that not all the costs had been calculated. He also raised money yesterday at a $350-a-head luncheon.
But beyond the coffers filled, is anything likely to change as a result of the sessions, which combined 1960's-style consciousness-raising with a hardheaded 1990's focus on the bottom line?
For the middle-aged white men who run most Wall Street firms, the two-day gathering at the World Trade Center in downtown Manhattan that ended late yesterday offered an opportunity to pay lip service to minority hiring and to wear their hearts on their sleeves before a basically sympathetic audience.
After all, critics said, Wall Street has plenty of explaining to do: Blacks now account for no more than 600 of the country's 90,000 brokers, according to Tony Chapelle, publisher of Securities Pro newsletter, which reports on blacks on Wall Street. The percentage of employees in the securities industry who are black has dropped from 10.6 percent in 1990 to 8.4 percent in 1996. And nearly three out of five blacks on Wall Street are employed as office and clerical workers, according to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
The conference exposed a clear divide on Wall Street. In general, firms with lots of ordinary customers seemed to take the conference more seriously. Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover both contributed to the event, officials said, and senior executives from each firm attended.
But firms that deal little with the investing public, like Lehman Brothers, seemed less involved. William Ahearn, a Lehman spokesman, said this week that the firm had "at least one person attending," but was not supporting the event with a donation or providing speakers for any of the industry panels.
Asked what he had achieved at the conference, Mr. Jackson gave a discursive answer, setting out the grim economic history of the country's black population. "For 250 years blacks were listed as commodities," he said.
"There are these definable, quantifiable gaps in our economy," he said, adding that the conference had helped to draw attention to "the investment gap, the education gap and the trade gap in our economy."
"Wall Street stands to gain if it closes the gap," he said.
In interviews, Mr. Jackson and his staff insisted yesterday that they would continue to keep a close eye on Wall Street, and that their newfound closeness with the securities industry would be characterized by "tough love," combining friendship and criticism.
At some firms, Mr. Jackson's carrot approach appears to be having some effect. James Dimon, the chairman and chief executive of Salomon Smith Barney, has told managers for the last two years that they will be rewarded financially if they succeed in hiring good minority and women candidates, according to Gordon McAndrew, a spokesman for the firm.
But the stick may prove even more effective. Smith Barney settled a class action suit brought by women and minority employees in part by pledging to do more to safeguard their rights. A resolution to a similar suit brought against Merrill Lynch is currently being negotiated.
Mr. Jackson, when asked about the cases, replied with a broad statement offering few specific suggestions.
As for the black business leaders among the 650 people in attendance, the meeting was a chance to do more than exchange business cards. "It's bringing people together to focus on the task at hand," said Kenneth I. Tatum of Mitchell & Titus L.L.P., an accounting and consulting firm. That task, he said, is to "insure that minorities get to share opportunities" in fast-growth sectors of the economy like finance, software and high technology.

HEADLINE: Happy Days Are Here Again (At Least Until After Fall)

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, and two of his top aides braved a sleet storm in Washington on Thursday morning, traveling to Capitol Hill to pay a call on Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, with whom President Clinton has had an often testy relationship.
On Wednesday, the President and Mr. Gephardt appeared together smiling at a White House photo opportunity. On Saturday, Mr. Gephardt and his wife, Jane, will have a private dinner with Al and Tipper Gore at the Vice President's mansion. Mr. Gephardt, an expected challenger to Mr. Gore for the 2000 Democratic Presidential nomination, will presumably check his weapons at the gate. 
 Mr. Clinton, Mr. Gore and Mr. Gephardt, all making nice? What's going on?
Ordinarily such contacts between Government leaders of the same party to discuss political and legislative strategy would be of little moment. But Mr. Clinton's relations with his fellow Democrats have never been quite ordinary.
Just last month, Mr. Gephardt, speaking for many of his Democratic colleagues in Congress, accused the President of conducting a Government of timid ideas and neglecting the nation's major challenges.
"We need a Democratic Party that is a movement for change and a movement for values, and not a money machine," Mr. Gephardt said at Harvard on Dec. 2, in an address that infuriated the White House.
Mr. Gephardt's speech marked a new low in a relationship that had already veered from mutual suspicion to open hostility. It was delivered three weeks after House Democrats had dealt Mr. Clinton a humiliating defeat over a measure that would have expanded his ability to negotiate trade agreements.
But today all appears rosy between Mr. Clinton and his fellow Democrats, as they join arms in public displays of unity on a political agenda for the coming year.
"The love fest continues," said a senior Democratic Congressional aide.
"Just one big happy family," chirped a top White House official.
Has this marriage been saved?
Perhaps -- for now.
There are a number of reasons for the new civility among Democrats, including a realization that division and pre-Presidential-campaign jockeying would hurt the party's efforts to regain the House in the elections this year.
The White House has made concerted efforts to appease Mr. Gephardt, both on a personal level and in policy proposals intended to appeal to Democratic officials and voters.
In recent weeks, Mr. Clinton has announced initiatives that sound much like traditional Democratic something-for-everyone interest-group politics: more spending on child day care for working mothers, expansion of Medicare to younger beneficiaries, a big school-construction program and a plan to train thousands more teachers, endorsement of Jesse Jackson's plea to Wall Street to hire more women and members of minority groups, a $5 billion program of grants and tax credits to address global warming and a $4 billion package for workers displaced by foreign trade.
"If you look at what Mr. Gephardt said in his speech, he was raising many of the issues that are beginning to be addressed in the President's agenda," said Laura Nichols, Mr. Gephardt's director of communications.
White House officials dispute that the President's proposals were intended to cater to Mr. Gephardt and the liberal wing of the Democratic Party. The ideas, they say, were entirely consistent with what they call Mr. Clinton's fiscally responsible "new Democrat" philosophy.
"The Gephardt speech was a catalyst for everyone realizing that it was in all of our interests to find things we can work together on," said John Podesta, deputy White House chief of staff.
"That speech obviously rubbed us the wrong way," Mr. Podesta added, "but the President said that if we work together there are a number of things we can accomplish, like electing more Democrats to the House and Senate. After that, most of the tension melted away."
Still, a reservoir of mistrust remains among many Democrats.
Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, said Mr. Clinton's embarrassment on the "fast track" trade legislation "got the President's attention."
"His post-fast-track speeches have been terrific," Mr. Rangel said. "He's starting to address the problems of Americans who are outside the economic loop."
But, Mr. Rangel said, he is not entirely convinced that Mr. Clinton is committed to pursuing policies that will help the Congressman's urban constituents.
Richard Bond, former Republican national chairman, said the White House had panicked after Mr. Gephardt's Harvard speech, concerned that Presidential politics would undermine Mr. Clinton's ability to pursue any agenda in 1998.
"The post-Clinton wars were about to seriously break out," Mr. Bond said. "But Clinton has now bought himself some time by making nice with Gephardt in social terms and making nice with the left wing of the Democratic Party in policy terms by these extensions of the dependency culture that they favor."
White House realists expect the truce to be only temporary, lasting until perhaps the day after the November elections.
And if the Democrats lose seats in Congress or statehouses -- a common off-year experience of the party that holds the White House -- lesser officeholders are sure to blame the President, as they did after the Republican sweep of 1994.
Even if the marriage hangs together through the year, said one senior White House political aide, "things will get a lot more complicated in 1999."

HEADLINE: Texas Tobacco Deal Is Approved

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 16

 BODY:
A Federal judge today approved a $15.3 billion deal that settles a lawsuit by Texas against the tobacco industry for by far the greatest settlement the industry has reached with a state.
The money, to be paid over 25 years, includes an initial $725 million and another $264 million to fund state research and anti-smoking initiatives for youths, according to the industry. Earlier figures that placed the value of the settlement at about $14.5 billion failed to include the upfront payments of about $725 million. 
 The settlement is subject to change, depending on inflation and sales volume.
Lawyers for cigarette companies and the state met with Judge David Folsom of Federal District Court in Texarkana, Tex., for about six hours today to put the finishing touches on a deal reached on Thursday.
"We have a settlement," said Ron Dusek, a spokesman for the Texas Attorney General, Dan Morales. "It is done."
Judge Folsom is expected to sign the documents on Tuesday.
One issue that appeared to remain unresolved was how much money the lawyers who negotiated the deal for the state would receive. The state on Friday filed four motions asking the judge to arbitrate the fees. The lawyers had been promised a 15 percent cut of a jury award.
The deal is by far the largest of the three settlements the industry has made with states, coming close to the combined $14.4 billion negotiated with Florida and Mississippi last year.
Texas had sued eight tobacco companies and three trade groups for reimbursement of about $8.6 billion in Medicaid money spent on Texans' smoking-related illnesses dating to 1968. With damages, the lawsuit grew to more than $14 billion.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Indonesian Currency Continues Slide Despite I.M.F. Deal

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund got virtually everything it wanted from President Suharto. Yet today, one day after he reluctantly agreed to a major restructuring of Indonesia's economy, its weakened currency resumed sliding.
The international marketplace, which has become the de facto arbiter of Indonesia's economic policies, still seemed dissatisfied. The risks and uncertainties, several financial analysts said, remained too great. 
 The currency ended the day at 8,450 rupiah to the dollar -- 6.5 percent lower than when the economic package was announced. Earlier today it dipped as low as 9,000 to the dollar, near the level that had set off panic buying last week.
That panic has eased, but confidence in the long-term future does not yet appear restored.
Even Robert E. Rubin, the United States Treasury Secretary, acknowledged today that the I.M.F.-backed reform packages for Asia offer no guarantees of success. He also offered no predictions on how long the crisis would last. "I don't have a crystal ball," he said in an interview on "The Newshour With Jim Lehrer" on public television in the United States.
Crippling private debt is still dragging down Indonesia's economy. Its political future remains tenuous and potentially chaotic.
"I'm sure the I.M.F. and the World Bank stood up from the table rubbing their hands with glee: this was their wish list," said Daragh Maher, an Indonesia specialist with ING Barings in Singapore. "But at the end of the day, Indonesia has a chronic foreign debt problem, and there was nothing offered in the package that would suggest that that would be any easier to manage."
Indonesia's stock market rose 6.9 percent today, but it was not a reliable indicator of confidence. The market is now so thinly traded that small movements can have a disproportionate effect.
If the rupiah's value erodes further, the country's burden of about $65 billion in dollar-denominated foreign debt would keep swelling, pushing more companies toward default and slowing the economy still more.
It is as if the formerly fast-growing nation of 200 million people, one of Southeast Asia's "tiger economies," was under "a billion pounds of weight," said Rajeev Malik, an economist for Jardine Fleming in Singapore. "It will certainly have a difficult time behaving like a tiger."
Worries were compounded by an impending fuel-price rise caused by Mr. Suharto's agreement to end subsidies, and by new predictions contained in the Thursday agreement of zero growth and 20 percent inflation.
Mr. Suharto received encouragement from the United States, which along with other nations had pressed him to agree to the I.M.F.'s terms.
President Clinton telephoned him a second time, and Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, who was in Jakarta earlier this week, said the announcement had increased Indonesia's stability.
Success in restoring the country's economic health is crucial now to Mr. Suharto's political future.
The crisis has intensified dissatisfaction with his 32-year rule, and the political tension is rising in advance of his expected reanointment as President in March.
Even as public demands for his resignation have increased over the last week, Mr. Suharto has made no provision for an orderly transfer of power. Even if he stays on, investors are likely to remain nervous.
At the same time, the country is bracing for social unrest as the economic slowdown, along with the newly announced austerity measures, lead to rising prices and joblessness.
For many Indonesians, who, like Kremlinologists, have become expert in reading their enigmatic leader's moods, Mr. Suharto failed to restore confidence in his leadership.
"This is an old fox," said one Indonesian political analyst who spoke on condition of anonymity. "If he's in a corner, he says to everyone, 'Yes.' Then when he's out of the corner he goes back to doing everything his own way."
For four months, after agreeing to a $40 billion rescue package organized by the I.M.F., Mr. Suharto dodged and ducked, resisting prescriptions that attacked the heart of his family's financial empire and his grip on the country's economy.
But with the tumbling currency causing panic in the streets and his back against the wall as the New Year began, Mr. Suharto capitulated to the I.M.F. He agreed to dismantle monopolies, halt inefficient projects, release the market from price controls, lift trade restrictions and reduce the national budget.
"It's quite impressive," said Donald Emmerson, an Indonesia expert and professor of political science at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, who was in Jakarta today. "One has to be encouraged but still skeptical about follow-through. I think the markets are saying, 'Show me the money.' "

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Optimistic Signs in Japan
Global stock markets rallied yesterday after the Japanese Government backed a plan that many investors believed would stimulate its economy and help ease concerns about the Asia crisis. 

 The Nikkei 225 average, the main Japanese stock index, jumped 6.1 percent to its highest level in nearly a month. That helped spread some optimism to other parts of Asia as well as Europe and the United States, where the Dow Jones industrial average finished the week with a 2.3 percent gain, recovering about half its losses a week earlier. Page D4.
 
Japan's governing party proposed accounting changes that would allow banks to vastly increase their dwindling capital and enable them to grant more loans. D3.
 
Adam Smith Goes to Asia
Among the humbled tiger economies of Asia, the form of capitalism that emphasized government planning and long-term relationships is now viewed as the problem, not the solution. Businesses are reluctantly adopting elements of the free-market, Adam Smith brand of capitalism practiced in the United States, despite its harsh consequences of layoffs and bankruptcies. A1.
 
China's central bank governor disclosed a sweeping reorganization of the banking system to make it more professional and help insulate the nation from financial upheavals in neighboring Asian countries. The overhaul resembles the Federal Reserve system in the United States. D3.
 
Fed Data Depict Industrial Vibrance
Industrial production increased half a percent in December, the 14th consecutive monthly gain, and factories operated at their highest level since September 1995, the Federal Reserve said. The data reinforced a view that the United States can withstand any harm from Asia's crisis. D16.
 
Bond prices fell sharply on the new signs of U.S. economic strength, the apparent improvement in Asia's outlook and the rally in stocks. The 30-year Treasury yield rose to 5.80 percent from 5.74. D4.
 
Deal Seen for Movie Theater Chain
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., one of the biggest investment firms that specialize in buying other companies, is said to be in talks to buy Regal Cinemas Inc. for more than $1 billion. It would be the firm's second acquisition in the movie theater business in two months. D4.
 
Less Swagger at Microsoft
The clash between Microsoft and the Justice Department has battered the confidence of the software giant. Microsoft employees say they are tired of having their integrity questioned every day. "How did Microsoft become more hated than the Government?" asked a former employee. A1.
 
Clash Seen on Car Standard Two nonprofit safety groups have decided to oppose a proposal that Federal regulators abandon the side-impact standard for a new standard introduced in Europe. Auto makers have asked for the change, saying that it would make it easier and cheaper for them to design and build cars that are more similar on both sides of the Atlantic. A10.
 
7-Up's Story Gets Lemon-Lime Twist
Hoping to improve 7-Up's perenially low ranking in soft-drink sales, its parent, Cadbury Schweppes, has injected more lemon-lime flavoring, the first formula change since the soda was introduced in 1929. D2.
 
Salomon Executive Departs
John G. Macfarlane, who played a central role in rescuing Salomon Brothers after a Treasury-bidding scandal in the early 1990's, is leaving Salomon Smith Barney Inc. to become chief operating officer of Tudor Investment, a big hedge fund. D4.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Haircut Time

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin better hurt somebody fast. Citibank would do. Or maybe his old partners at Goldman Sachs. Or maybe his old competitors at J. P. Morgan. Or better yet, all of them. But he better hurt somebody, fast.
Because if Mr. Rubin can't show that as part of the U.S.-led I.M.F. bailout of Korea, Indonesia and Thailand, the U.S., European and Japanese banks that lent these countries money won't also pay a price for their mistakes, he can forget about getting any more money out of Congress for the I.M.F. Forget it. Congress returns next week, and you can already hear the tom-toms beating: "No More Money For The I.M.F. Let The Asians Go Bust." 
 Mr. Rubin needs to do two things if he wants to save U.S. funding for the $40 billion I.M.F. bailout: He needs to speak to America and draw blood on Wall Street. He needs to explain to Americans precisely why the Asian bailout is valid. And he needs to make sure that any American bank that was involved in loans to Asia, and now wants to share in the I.M.F. bailout, takes a haircut. And I'm not just talking about a trim.
So far the Clinton team has failed miserably to make a convincing argument as to why the U.S. should make its overdue deposit to the I.M.F. -- $17.9 billion -- and why this won't end up as welfare for Asian tycoons and U.S. bankers. (Most Americans don't even realize that the I.M.F. is a credit union for countries. The U.S. doesn't "give" the I.M.F. anything. The U.S. deposits funds in the I.M.F. bank, and the I.M.F. pays the U.S. interest and then lends money to troubled economies.)
Consider Korea. Korea's private banks borrowed $92 billion from foreign banks. Those foreign banks are saying to Korea that they will extend the loans, to get the Koreans past the short-term debt crunch so they don't have to declare bankruptcy, but only on the condition that the Korean Government take over responsibility for that bank debt and pay it back with even higher interest over the long term. An I.M.F. loan now gives Korea the cushion to take the deal.
Opponents of such a workout argue that Korea is much better off letting private companies go bust and having them bought out or restructured by more prudent and efficient managers, and that the world is better off letting the foreign banks also get burned so they will be less reckless in the future. Those are not ridiculous arguments.
What U.S. officials mumble in response are two arguments. One is that the collapse of huge economies like South Korea or Indonesia could present a real national security problem for the U.S. Maybe.
The more compelling argument is the domino theory -- that if huge economies like Korea, Thailand and Indonesia are allowed to just go bankrupt, they will take down other emerging markets, from Asia to Latin America, and likely drag down Japan. And if the world's second-largest economy goes down, that will seriously impact U.S. interest rates and markets. And it won't just be Billionaire Bob who takes a hit, but also Joe Sixpack's pension fund, mutual fund and, maybe, job. Millions of workers in developing countries would also be ruined.
This domino argument may be exaggerated, but testing it by seeing what would happen if the Asian tigers were left to melt down would be the greatest roll of the dice of the post-cold-war era. It is reasonable that the U.S. Treasury Secretary wouldn't want to take that risk.
So what to do? The U.S. must insist that it will contribute to an I.M.F. bailout only if both borrowers and lenders being bailed out receive no more than 75 cents on the dollar for any money invested and lost. The U.S. also has to use its influence to try to insure that, in restructuring a country's debts, that country is not forced to pay exorbitant additional interest. The worst thing would be that the I.M.F. bails out a country and Western banks profit even more from their own mistakes.
It's a fine line. People need to be hurt, so they think twice in the future. But not killed, if there is a chance they can recover and grow again.
An I.M.F. bailout that makes reckless banks and investors whole again will never fly. An I.M.F. bailout that punishes both reckless banks and investors, but still leaves them some space and buys them some time to make real business and governance reforms, is both good economics and good politics.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Horse Tracks Need Help In New Jersey, Panel Says

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 16

 BODY:
After a year's study, a commission on New Jersey's slumping horse-racing industry urged the state government today to pump $25 million to $50 million a year into racetrack purses and to soften betting regulations so residents can place wagers by telephone, via the Internet or in a few new upscale off-track betting parlors.
The commission's report and recommendations were silent on the introduction of slot machines at the state's five tracks. And before the 19-member panel voted on the report in Trenton, it narrowly rebuffed two 11th-hour amendments to add slot machines to the list of proposed ways to lure more fans to the tracks. A coalition of panel members from the Whitman administration and two representatives of Atlantic City casinos, Donald J. Trump and Herbert R.Wolfe, the chief executive of the Atlantic City Showboat Casino Hotel, defeated the slot machine appeal. 
 Representatives of horse breeders and owners and three of the panel's four state legislators voted for the slots. The votes were 11 to 7 and 10 to 8. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman created the panel, the Racing Industry Study Commission, in December 1996 to explore ways to stop this decade's steep slide in betting and attendance, improve the quality of horses and races, and find ways to lure horse players back from Atlantic City casinos, the state lottery and tracks in Delaware, which introduced slot machines two years ago, and in Pennsylvania, which allows phone betting. Besides those problems, the panel's final report said the track faced possible increased competition for the gambling dollar from New York, noting that Gov. George E. Pataki is talking about allowing slot machines at New York tracks and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's administration is entertaining notions about a casino on Governors Island.
The report stressed that New Jersey's best answer to the competition in its neighboring states was higher purses for the owners of the top finishers in each race. It called higher purses the "pivotal economic component of the entire sport," saying they guaranteed better horses racing each day and more financially stable breeding farms.
The report offered no suggestions on the source of its proposed annual state subsidy of $25 million to $50 million. Panel officials said they were leaving it up to the Governor and the Legislature to find the money. Copies of the report went to both.
Governor Whitman's office had no immediate reaction to any of the recommendations. Gene Herman, a spokesman for the Governor, said the administration wanted to study them before commenting.
As for the proposals for phone and off-track betting, it will be several months before those ideas become reality, if at all. The types of gambling allowed on horse races are restricted by the State Constitution. Before the Legislature can consider them, voters must first approve them in a statewide referendum. Commission officials said such a vote could not come before next November. If voters accept them, they must then win legislative approval.
The commission's report criticized the restrictions and urged the Legislature to loosen them. Commission officials complained that the Legislature alone can change both the way the state lottery and casinos are run. But, they said, tracks suffer unfairly because of the requirements for statewide referendums on phone and off-track betting.
The report noted that New York State allows phone betting at its tracks and New Jersey horse players use the system, taking their dollar away from New Jersey's tracks.
The state's tracks have suffered from the outside competition. Total attendance last year, through November, was 2.7 million, down 1.1 million from the same 11-month period in 1993. In those same four years, on-track betting has fallen to $450 million from $831 million, the New Jersey Racing Commission said.
The commission questioned whether all five tracks could survive, especially the Atlantic City Racetrack and Garden State Park in Cherry Hill. It suggested using them as off-track betting theaters that would be operated by track owners and feature restaurants and other amenities. Southern New Jersey legislators, however, are expected to oppose any attempts to close Garden State Park. The slot machines at Delaware's tracks have pumped about $30 million a year into the tracks' purses in the last two years ago, the commission said.
But the commission rejected them for New Jersey. The panel's chairman, Candace Straight, a member of the state agency that operates the state's two biggest and busiest tracks, the Meadowlands and Monmouth Park, said the panel was not convinced that slot machines would increase on-track betting. In addition, she said, the commission did not believe that New Jersey voters or members of the Legislature favored expansion of casino-style gambling beyond Atlantic City.
The amendment rejected today by the 11-7 vote had recommended that the slots be introduced immediately. The one, rejected by the 10-8 vote, had proposed introducing slot machines to New Jersey's tracks if New York State permitted them at Aqueduct or Belmont. The sponsor, Senator Richard J. Codey, Democrat of West Orange, said slots at either track would leave New Jersey's tracks at a distinct disadvantage.
"If that became the case," he siad, "you could set off a bomb in the Meadowlands and not injure anyone because no one would be there."

HEADLINE: U.S. Can't Find Buyer for Jets Thailand Can No Longer Afford

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Thailand's effort to back out of a contract to buy eight American-made F/A-18 fighter jets has run into a big problem: The United States does not want them back and is not likely to find anyone else to buy them any time soon.
At a meeting today with Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen, Thailand's Prime Minister, Chuan Leekpai, formally asked the United States to keep the F/A-18's or find another country willing to pick up the $392 million bill, a defense official traveling with Mr. Cohen said. 
 But that is easier said than done.
Despite assurances by Mr. Cohen that he would do all he could to help, the United States cannot just buy back the fighters, since this particular type of F/A-18 is made for export only, meaning the planes are incompatible with those already in the American arsenal.
Moreover, the defense official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said it would be virtually impossible to find another buyer in time for Thailand to keep to its contract with the planes' manufacturer, Boeing Co., which includes a $100 million installment in March.
The few countries that have shown interest in buying F/A-18's in the past, like Malaysia, are suffering from the same economic turmoil that has forced Thailand to reconsider its purchase.
After his meeting with Mr. Chuan, who also serves as Defense Minister, Mr. Cohen announced that he would send a team of defense officials to Thailand in the next week to 10 days to begin talks about what to do next. Despite the Thai request, however, he suggested the solution would involve negotiations with Boeing to simply extend payment.
"We're talking to contractors, as I mentioned, to find ways in which perhaps payments could be spread out, payments deferred, ways in which we could accommodate their security needs while also recognizing their economic difficulties," Mr. Cohen said at a news conference at the Defense Ministry.
A Boeing official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said in a telephone interview that Boeing was prepared to support the United States in its talks with Thailand. But since Thailand technically purchased the planes directly from the United States and not Boeing, the official said, the matter remained one for the two Governments to settle.
If the Pentagon went ahead with Thailand's request, the United States could end up essentially negotiating against itself.
Mr. Cohen's visit today -- part of his 12-day, 7-nation tour of Asia -- was intended to shore up the United States' military and strategic ties with Thailand, which have been strained at times in recent years. But as the difficulties with the F/A-18's have showed, much of his mission has been overshadowed by the economic crises sweeping Southeast Asia.
"We know you are currently experiencing difficulties," Mr. Cohen said at the start of a meeting with the Foreign Minister, Surin Pitsuwan. "But we hope we can provide assistance and support in a variety of ways."
The F/A-18's are due to be delivered over eight months starting in early 1999.
Thailand has already paid $72 million of the $392 million price, but with the value of its currency collapsing by half since last summer and its spending constrained by the International Monetary Fund's $17 billion bailout, it has been hard pressed to pay for it and a host of other, smaller weapons purchases.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
A Grateful Paterno Promises $3.5 Million to Penn State

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

 BODY:
In a dramatic reversal of the economic relationship between universities and high-profile football coaches, Joe Paterno of Penn State, and his wife, Sue, have pledged $3.5 million to the school that has employed him since 1950.
The gift will pay for scholarships, faculty positions and the construction of an interfaith spiritual center and a sports hall of fame on the State College, Pa., campus. 
 "To the best of our knowledge, no college coach, at any university at any time in history, has made a gift at this level of generosity," said Graham B. Spanier, the university president.
Paterno, who turned 71 last month, said he and his wife had discussed making a major donation for 25 years.
"I make more money than I should make," he said. "They let me work, so, thanks."
The Paternos contributed $420,000 in past years toward construction of a library, a library acquisitions fund and the endowment of scholarships for minority students.
Their latest gift will endow professorships in the university libraries and the College of the Liberal Arts; a graduate fellowship and undergraduate scholarship in the School of Architecture and Landscape Architecture, plus a fellowship and a scholarship in the classics in the College of the Liberal Arts.
The spiritual center is planned as an extension of an existing chapel. The hall of fame will be built between Beaver Stadium and the Bryce Jordan Center.
"I find it truly remarkable that the Paternos would take a substantial portion of their life savings and return it to the university," Dr. Spanier said.
"Money has never been important to us," Sue Paterno said. "Material things have never been important to us. What is important to us is what the future of the world will be."
Sue Paterno had laughed and described the family as being "in the red." Joe Paterno sounded like someone who needed to hold a job for the next few years.
The Nittany Lions' coach, whose 298 victories are the most among active major college coaches, laughed at the idea.
"You hit that right on the head," Paterno said.
"The president is requiring it," Dr. Spanier said.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-5
 
Turkey's Largest Party Is Banned by High Court
Turkey's highest court placed an immediate ban on the country's largest political party, finding it had a subversive agenda and was working to replace the nation's secular order with a rule based on Islam. A1 

America Under Attack in Iran
Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's spiritual leader, gave a fiery sermon full of venom toward the United States. To cheering crowds, he ruled out any dialogue with the "Great Satan." A1
 
Inspectors Leave Baghdad
William Scott Ritter, Jr., the American weapons inspector, left Iraq with his team. They had been blocked from working since Tuesday by the Government of Saddam Hussein, an action that brought about another confrontation with the United Nations. Richard Butler, the director of the special commission charged with disarming Iraq, left for Baghdad. A5
 
Thailand Backs Away From Jets
Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai formally asked the United States to keep eight American-made F/A-18 warplanes that Thailand had contracted for or find another country willing to pay the $392 million that they cost. Thailand's currency has collapsed by half since last summer and its spending has been constrained by the I.M.F. Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said he would do what he could, but buyers seem scarce and the planes were built to export specifications. A5
 
Russian Reformers Lose Clout
Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin announced changes in the official duties of two Deputy Prime Ministers, Anatoly Chubais and Boris Nemtsov, both considered reformers. Mr. Chubais was removed from overseeing government media policy, but would retain considerable sway on economic policy. Mr. Chernomyrdin said he would assume oversight of the fuel and energy sectors from Mr. Nemtsov, a likely presidential contender who would be left with the politically unpopular issues of pension and housing reform. A4
 
Clinton Signs Baltic Charter
President Clinton signed a charter of partnership with the Presidents of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and pledged support for those nations' aspirations to join NATO. The charter does not commit the United States to defend the Baltic nations, but embodies a moral and political commitment to their independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity. Washington never recognized the three nations' annexation by the Soviet Union. A4
 
Eavesdropping in Germany
Germany's Parliament decided to permit the police to bug private homes for the first time since the Nazi era. Previously, the postwar Constitution protected private homes from all forms of eavesdropping except in exceptional circumstances relating to crime and terrorism. The change is meant to combat organized crime and money laundering. A4
 
NATIONAL A6-10, A14
 
Some Who Seek Abortions Find the Politics Abstract
Many young women who have chosen to have abortions say the procedure is used too casually, as a sloppily recurring form of birth control, rather than as the result of a careful personal decision. Most of those interviewed seemed to regard the fight over abortion as a remote historical phenomenon, and a surprising number said they did not consider themselves "pro-choice." A1
 
Anti-Abortion Effort Fails
The Republican National Committee rejected a proposal to withhold money from candidates who do not oppose late-term abortion. A9
 
Repercussions at Microsoft
There is a clear sense in Redmond, Wash., that Microsoft, the world's most powerful software corporation, has lost some of its swagger in its ongoing legal battle with the Justice Department. The courtroom tactics, blunders and air of defiance have provided much more than drinking-fountain fodder in the Seattle area, where the enormous wealth created by Microsoft has transformed the region. And there is considerable concern that the ride may be over. A1
