HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Crisis Pushing Asian Capitalism Closer to U.S.-Style Free Market

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Sitting in his office just off the factory floor, a week's stubble on his face and weariness in his eyes, Kim Jung Ju watches his workers carefully, figuring out whom he might lay off next.
"Now the bottom line is everything," Mr. Kim says mournfully, and he complains that the relationships that were the underpinning of Korean-style capitalism are dying quickly. "Before, companies that had done business with us for a decade would help us out in times of trouble. But no more." 
 So the customers of Mr. Kim's clothing factory are breaking the rules of the game by squeezing him and curbing orders. And he reacts by breaking the rules again and laying off one-third of his 130 employees.
That is the harsh reality of free-market capitalism, and it might be unremarkable in the United States. But this is Asia, where in the past some nations followed a different economic model, emphasizing not markets but rather Government planning and long-term relationships.
That version of capitalism, particularly the variety developed by Japan and adopted by South Korea, is now widely regarded as a problem rather than a solution. For the present at least, the Asian financial crisis is driving Governments and businesses alike toward a more open, market-oriented, laissez-faire version of capitalism, the kind championed by the United States.
While many aspects of East Asia's community ethos will remain, Asian officials and scholars suggest that the region's economies may emerge from the financial crisis looking a bit more like the American economy. In other words, they would be more open to imports and foreign investment, less curtailed by strict regulations, less dominated by Government planning and more ruthless about laying off workers.
"Everybody has been liberating markets to take advantage of globalization and the world economy," said Jusuf Wanandi, chairman of a policy research center in Jakarta, Indonesia. "So we are all moving more to the American model."
Still, as Mr. Wanandi noted, this does not mean that Asian countries will adopt the free model outright. Many Asians are still not on friendly terms with the market forces that over the last few months have demolished their economies, and they worry that an excess of markets will threaten a way of life and community ethos.
While the changes under way seem breathtaking to a laid-off Korean worker, they still leave the region looking -- to Western eyes -- far more Asian than American. Western commentators have been saying for generations that Asians are becoming "more like us," and while in one sense they were right, that does not mean that convergence lies ahead.
In any case, the change in the mood in Asia is striking because Japanese-style capitalism was perhaps the most formidable rival to neoclassical free-market capitalism as a model for other countries. Japanese officials vigorously urged other Asian nations to adopt the Japanese approach to capitalism, even sponsoring a 1993 World Bank report that was supposed to give the Japanese methods the seal of legitimacy. The report did not quite do that, but it was not as critical of state intervention as an earlier World Bank report.
To be sure, Asia as a whole never adopted a single economic model. Hong Kong was traditionally a paragon of laissez-faire capitalism. On the other hand, Japan and South Korea relied on a very similar system of industrial planning, huge inter-linked conglomerates, lifetime jobs in big companies, export assistance and protected domestic industries.
Taiwan, Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia were somewhere in-between, but all borrowed in part from the Japanese development model. Bureaucrats in all those countries sometimes seemed to think that they were better at allocating capital and goods than markets were.
"How can you go hunting without a target?" Naohiro Amaya, the late former top Japanese trade official and leading theorist of the Japanese model, was quoted as saying in 1988. "When you go hunting, you have to shoot at a target. But your neoclassical school of economics says you can fire in all directions at once, and the 'market' will insure you hit the target. Well, we don't accept that line of reasoning, and our economic model will probably be stronger in the future, and have a greater demonstration effect for developing countries, than either the American model, which has become weak and less relevant, or the Soviet central-command model."
The wheel may turn again, but for now there are no more boasts about the superiority of the Japanese-Korean model.
"Other Asian markets should take note and move their economies more in the direction of free market logic and away from government and bureaucratic intervention and centralized monopolistic industrial power blocs," warned the Chosun Ilbo, South Korea's leading newspaper. "If Asians have been arrogant, soaked in snobbish and boastful attitudes, then now is the time to realize their limitations and show a degree of humility and repentance."
These days, both Japan and Korea are trying to dismantle regulations and bureaucratic controls over the economy. "Economies are all going the American way, and that's a major trend today," Makoto Kuroda, a former top Japanese trade official and managing director of Mitsubishi Corporation, said.
 
Some Trends Under Way in Past
Still, Mr. Kuroda noted that there are countercurrents as well, and in any case the trend away from bureaucratic intervention is not a completely new one.
In Japan, the Government has been losing its ability to manipulate the economy, and layoffs have become more common in the last few years. Regulation is diminishing, and imports have risen, and those trends have been visible in South Korea and other Asian countries.
The Asian financial crisis has dramatically accelerated this process. While Asia has had crises in the past, like the oil crisis of 1973-74, that were in some ways more severe than the present one, those were external shocks. In contrast, this crisis seems more of a collapse from within, especially with Japan's long stagnation since 1990, and the problems raise fundamental questions about whether a new strategy is necessary.
"The model is now clear," said Lee Hong Koo, a member of the South Korean National Assembly and a former Prime Minister. "It's not Japan. It's the West."
"The current crisis has convinced almost all people that that the old style doesn't work," Mr. Lee added. "We will adjust ourselves rapidly to the new requirements, which means we will fashion ourselves more like the West, like the U.S. and European model."
Mr. Lee and others emphasize that they do not see the collapse of their development strategy as a defeat for Asia. On the contrary, they hope that freer markets may give the region a new dynamism.
"If we faithfully implement the reforms we agreed on with the I.M.F., we will emerge with a stronger economic foundation, and we will be poised to overtake Japan," said You Jong Keun, a top economic adviser to President-elect Kim Dae Jung of South Korea.
 
Several Changes Are Predicted
In the real world, a shift to a new model is never quite so clear-cut as it sounds, but in general the changes that diplomats and business executives are talking about are these:
*Governments may control economies less than before. The Finance Ministry in Korea no longer tells the banks whom to lend to, and the Finance Ministry in Japan has lost its capacity to determine the fate of banks and securities houses. As a result, despite official Japanese assurances that no big bank would be allowed to fail, one did in the fall.
*Labor markets may become a bit more flexible, and unemployment rates will rise. Lifetime employment and rigid seniority will tend to be less important, and layoffs will increase. This has been happening for years but will accelerate. South Korea's unemployment rate is expected to quadruple this year to 10 percent.
*Relationships in general may tend to become less important. The huge families of linked companies -- called keiretsu in Japan and chaebol in South Korea, where the ship-building arm buys its cars from the linked auto company and its beer from the linked brewery -- is gradually giving way to a more open system in which business is allocated not by loyalty but by price. Already, business groups in both countries are for the first time allowing affiliates to collapse, and Asia's great home-grown champion of relationship finance, Peregrine Securities in Hong Kong, collapsed this month.
*Companies may make less effort to build market share and more effort to make money. Japanese banks and South Korean chaebol alike are being ordered to disclose more accurate and useful financial information, and everyone is paying more attention to credit-worthiness.
 
Transition Apparent In Seoul Already
These changes are matters of degree, and even modest change will take time. But in Chung Youn Goo's small clothing factory in Seoul, the transition is already apparent. Mr. Chung has laid off a third of his work force, rather than keep them on in hopes for a rebound, as he would have done in the old days, and he is now scrutinizing data as much as cultivating relationships.
"Our methods of doing business have changed a lot," Mr. Chung said as he sat at a small table near the factory floor. "We put a lot more emphasis on making sure that we have confidence in the companies we deal with. For companies listed on the stock exchange, for example, we conduct a thorough review of their financial standing, because now even the big companies can go belly up very quickly."
The crisis is so recent that the changes in the way of doing business are tentative, and many still have not fully taken effect. But in South Korea, the chaebol have been forced to accept substantial changes by the markets and by President-elect Kim, who unlike other recent presidents owes the chaebol nothing.
On Thursday, the chaebol jointly promised to adopt Western accounting standards, to bring outsiders into their boards of directors and to reduce the cross-guarantees that subsidiaries make to honor one another's debts. They also pledged to reduce their debt-equity ratios to bring them closer to Western standards.
These measures are important because the top 30 chaebol account for nearly two-thirds of South Korea's economic output. That was the result of preferential treatment -- the Government ordered banks to lend to the chaebol, for instance -- and the ratio is expected to drop as South Korea becomes more market-oriented.
To be sure, while executives find themselves forced to embrace the market, that is not to say they find it a pretty sight. Dong Hwa International, a trading company, did some deals with the United States a few years ago, and its executives were angered when the American company promptly cut costs by dispensing with Dong Hwa and contacting the Korean end company directly.
That was shrewd but unethical, Dong Hwa executives say. Still, they see such moves as the way of the future.
"I think the Korean economy will look more like America's, because all parties here are trying to cut costs, cutting out third parties, cutting out middlemen," lamented Kim Jin Hyung, an executive of Dong Hwa.
 
Resembling America Only a Bit More
Yet Asia is not suddenly going to look like America. One way of looking at it is that young Japanese, Taiwanese, Koreans, Chinese and Thais already wear Western clothes, eat American hamburgers, watch American movies and listen to American music. Within a few years, they are much more likely also to face the risk of layoffs, and to change jobs with American-style casualness.
All this will make Asia's labor markets, finance and industry resemble America's a bit more, but Americans do not become more group-oriented or respectful of their parents when they put on a Sony Walkman.
Japan is still the country that is most hesitant about rapid change toward a more market-driven system, with Japanese wary of the brutality of market mechanisms. The old system protected a way of life that is often inefficient -- with the tiny rice shops and futon-makers that charge ludicrous prices -- but that is also central to the ethos of Japan. A more efficient, market-driven system may mean better prices and more supermarkets, but the fear is that it will also lead to alienation, crime and an end to the civility that is the most outstanding feature of daily Japanese life.
The result is a profound ambivalence that has Japan tip-toeing toward a freer market system but still aghast at the layoffs and turbulence that a radical economic restructuring will require.
"Markets are riddled with defects," the Yomiuri Shimbun, the largest circulation newspaper in Japan, complained in an editorial. "Markets widen the rich-poor gap and raise unemployment, putting the nation's entire social fabric at risk."
Yet the newspaper acknowledged, just a bit sadly, that "the move toward markets has reached the point of no return."

HEADLINE: Tough Sanctions Can Halt Trafficking in Humans;
Why Russians Leave

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Traffickers' New Cargo: Naive Slavic Women" (front page, Jan. 11): 
 While it is true that unemployment rates (as high as 95 percent for women in some parts of Russia) are driving women out of the country, it is not the only reason why women are desperate to leave Russia.
Most women who do find employment are forced to work menial jobs. On average, they make half as much as men. Fifty-five percent of households headed by single mothers have incomes below the poverty level. In some cases, women who have answered job listings have been told they will have to sleep with their employers and follow a dress code of miniskirts and tight shirts.
Because of poor economic conditions, violence against women is also on the rise. Every fifth murder is someone killed by a spouse, and the majority of victims are women. Victims of domestic violence and rape have little recourse; domestic abuse is considered a "family affair." Instead of labeling as "naive" the women who leave in hopes of something better for themselves, you should consider the problem as it really is: a serious human rights issue.
 
SARAH HYMOWITZ
West Orange, N.J., Jan. 12, 1998

HEADLINE: TURKS' HIGH COURT ORDERS DISBANDING OF ISLAMIC PARTY

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Turkey's highest court placed an immediate ban on the country's largest political party today, ruling that it harbored a subversive agenda and was working to replace the nation's secular order with one based on Islam.
"This court has decided to close the Welfare Party because of evidence confirming its actions against the principles of the secular republic," Ahmet Necdet Sezer, Chief Judge of the Constitutional Court, said in announcing the ruling. 
 The court also ruled that seven leaders of the party would be barred from political activity for five years. Among them is the party leader, Necmettin Erbakan, 71, who was Prime Minister from June 1996 until June 1997. Six, including Mr. Erbakan, are currently members of Parliament, and the seventh is a mayor.
Today, Mr. Erbakan urged his supporters to remain calm and ignore "provocateurs who might want to take advantage of this situation." He said he would appeal the decision to the European Court of Human Rights.
A leading young figure in the party, Abdullah Gul, called the decision "a shadow on Turkish democracy."
"We are the mainstream and backbone of this country," Mr. Gul said. "A large part of the population supports us. In a democratic society, this group must be represented. We will have another political party."
Some Turkish secularists hailed the decision, but many foreigners, including those who consider themselves friends of Turkey, said it would hinder the country's efforts to portray itself as a fully functioning democracy.
The United States and several countries in the European Union had urged the Government to do whatever was possible to prevent a decision like the one handed down today. After the ruling was announced, the British Embassy in Ankara issued a statement saying, "We are concerned with the implications for democratic pluralism and freedom of expression, and will be discussing the closure of Welfare urgently with our E.U. partners."
There have also been predictions that the decision could radicalize at least some supporters of political Islam and perhaps even drive them to violence. In anticipation of a violent reaction, the police in Ankara and Istanbul strengthened patrols around mosques and Welfare Party offices, but no disturbances were reported today. Friday prayers proceeded normally.
In making its decision, the court acted under a series of laws, including one that prohibits efforts "to change the secular character of the Turkish Republic" and another that bans political parties from seeking political advantage "through the use or misuse of religion or religious beliefs."
Turkey's Constitution defines secularism as one of the nation's basic principles and forbids repeal, or even discussion of repealing, that definition.
Military commanders and other secularists say these restrictions are necessary to preserve what they describe as the world's only Muslim democracy. Others believe that they limit voters' rights to choose the future they want for their country and themselves.
Today's ruling was based in part on public statements by Welfare Party leaders that the prosecutor submitted as proof of what he called the party's subversive agenda.
Among the statements were Mr. Erbakan's assertion that democracy "is not an end but a means for us." The court also heard a tape of another Welfare Party leader, Oguzhan Asilturk, saying, "The order we shall bring has a big difference, as big as mountains, from the secularist and democratic order. Ours is on the mountaintop, and democracy is in the abyss."
The party did not deny that such statements had been made, but it said it could not be responsible for the public statements of "all our four million members."
There has been talk of starting a new party from the ashes of the Welfare Party or adopting a minor party, but politicians say no firm decision has been made. In its waning days, the party took the precaution of divesting itself of cars and other material assets, giving them to prominent members for fear that the assets might be seized by the Government. The ruling did not include any freezing of party assets.
Some news commentators predicted that today's decision would marginalize pro-Islamic forces and usher in an era of political stability. Others asserted that former Welfare leaders would portray themselves as outsiders victimized by an undemocratic attack and that any new party they formed could turn out to be even stronger than Welfare was.
The prosecutor who presented the case against Welfare, Vural Savas, said any new Islamic-oriented party "will be subjected to investigation on whether it is a continuation of the banned party."
Mr. Savas said Welfare leaders were working to "destroy the Turkish Republic" and "establish a state based on religious principles."
"The assumption that political parties cannot be closed in democratic regimes is not correct," Mr. Savas asserted. "The Turkish Constitution accepts the understanding of 'combative democracy,' which permits the closure of political parties if their programs or activities threaten the existence of the state."
In a 275-page reply, the Welfare Party called Mr. Savas "prejudiced and intolerant of everything related to Islam" and described his charges as baseless and demagogic.
"It is also a sociological fact that closing a party does not and cannot change the minds of people," the party asserted in its defense. "People can only change their thoughts if they are given better alternatives."
Welfare emerged as a significant political force in the late 1980's, when it began winning control of local governments. Its success in smaller communities led voters to give it control of several large cities, including Istanbul and Ankara. In the 1995 national election, it won 21 percent of the vote, more than any other party. It holds 150 of the 550 seats in Parliament.
Although the party has been dissolved, officeholders elected under its banner will retain their positions but will be considered independent of party affiliation.
Within weeks after the Welfare-led Government took office in June 1996, it began taking steps that angered the secular establishment. Mr. Erbakan made official visits to Iran and Libya, effusively embracing their leaders. He received leaders of Muslim brotherhoods, dressed in traditional robes that are anathema to secularists here, for a religious dinner at his official residence.
Later he began placing Islamic allies in important bureaucratic posts and encouraging families to send their children to religious schools and women to wear head scarves. He announced plans to build a mosque in Taksim Square, the secular heart of Istanbul, and Cankaya, the section of Ankara where the Presidential Palace is located.
These and other steps alarmed top military leaders, who consider themselves the ultimate guardians of Turkish secularism. Supported by allies in the press, they began portraying Mr. Erbakan as a deceitful plotter whose secret agenda was to turn Turkey into an Islamic state.
For their part, Welfare leaders insisted that they were acting within democratic rules. In their written defense before the Constitutional Court, they declared that they were "against any sort of religious or political fanaticism" and "on the side of pluralist democracy, reconciliation and tolerance."
Military commanders scoffed at such assertions, calling them part of Welfare's duplicity. They finally brought down the Government with a series of "briefings" for the press, business figures, judges and bureaucrats in which they portrayed Welfare as hostile to all that Turks should hold dear. Mr. Erbakan, understanding that he could not govern in the face of such direct opposition from the military, stepped down on June 18.
One American scholar who has closely studied the Welfare Party, Jenny B. White of Boston University, wrote before today's ban that the party's "ultimate direction is still unclear."
"Despite Welfare's pragmatism and modern image, there is concern that more radical religious zealots are riding into power on its coattails," Ms. White wrote. "Erbakan may be the head of an Islamist political party, but many Turks wonder what the rest of the body looks like."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Washington Criticizes Ruling
 WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (By The New York Times) -- The United States criticized Turkey's courts today for banning the Welfare Party, saying the decision "damages confidence in Turkey's democratic, multiparty system."
The State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said the United States would not interfere in the internal affairs of its NATO allies or support any particular political party.
John Shattuck, the Assistant Secretary of State for human rights, will go forward with a planned visit to Turkey next month despite the ruling, Mr. Rubin said, adding, "One of the things that he will obviously make clear is that Americans, as a democracy, will have difficulty understanding and reconciling this action with our concept of democracy."
"Despite this troubling development of this banning of the party," Mr. Rubin concluded, "we do have confidence in Turkey's future as a democracy, and our view is that the challenges that Turkey faces will be resolved by more democracy rather than less."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 26, 1998, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Jan. 17 about a Turkish supreme court ruling banning the country's largest political party attributed a quotation incompletely. The observations by Jenny B. White, an American scholar of Turkey who wrote that the ideological trend of the banned party was unclear, appeared first in Current History magazine.

HEADLINE: Word & Image;
To Whom It May Concern

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
A "committee of concerned journalists" wants my signature on a "Statement of Concern." It says that technology, economics and "our relationship with the public" have produced a crisis "pulling journalism from its traditional moorings." Because I, too, feel intimidated by quirky computers, greedy stockholders and fickle readers, I reach for my pen.
Then I read on: "Many journalists feel a sense of lost purpose. There is even doubt about the meaning of news, doubt evident when serious journalistic organizations drift toward opinion, infotainment and sensation out of balance with the news." 
 Now I must reflect. Yes, I have had doubts about the meaning of news. But my doubts gave me purpose; as an editor, I was well paid to entertain them. With less than 200,000 words in the weekday Times to encompass the world, deciding what's news and what isn't proved to be a fascinating struggle. I never resolved my doubts because my definition of news became highly volatile, of little practical help.
My only verity is that news must be new. News is not a rendering of reality, only a quest for novelty.
Novel for whom? Here the trouble starts. To an audience of 8-year-olds, the multiplication table might qualify as news. In The Times, which assumes readers to be at least 12, math gets ink only when it solves Fermat's last theorem. Embedded in the minds of all journalists is the image of a prototypical consumer of their news.
I defined my readers by geography and ideology as well as chronology. I wrote and edited with a bias for the home team, the Yanks in the cold war and the Yankees in the World Series. But when New York quarreled with New Jersey or the Yankees played the Mets, I became neutral; I qualified for Victor Navasky's taunt that The Times preaches "the ideology of the center, which includes a denial that it has an ideology."
Besides being new and fitfully neutral, my news needs to be important or interesting, preferably both. This leads into a realm that the Committee of the Concerned might disparage as mere opinion. For example, given the autobiographical nature of most Woody Allen films, I bet that his latest marriage, though it surely qualifies as "infotainment," will turn out to be important to his art. For me, therefore, his romance is news. So are Seymour Hersh's "sensations" about J.F.K.'s promiscuities. Though they are not particularly new or very interesting, they strike me as important -- for publishing if not politics. They seem bound finally to exhaust the public's appetite for Kennediana.
The truth is that journalists who assemble a newspaper, magazine, book or newscast cut the cloth to suit their audience, and they are often only guessing about its size and shape. A paper catering heavily to investors in Mobil and Texaco will give extensive coverage to the White House visit of President Nazarbayev of oil-rich Kazakhstan. But the newscasts that labor to hold the audiences assembled by Sally Jessy Raphael and Jerry Springer will skip the Kazakhs and go heavy on Allen and Kennedy, with all the Mia and Marilyn footage they can find. And they could all point to the news in the "responsible" New York Times to validate their choices.
So I sheathe my pen to read further into the "Statement of Concern." It already bears nearly 500 names, but the signers share no attribute beyond their proclaimed concern. They favor a dozen public forums, financed by the Pew Charitable Trusts, "to clarify the purpose and principles that distinguish our profession." Although another branch of Pew propagandizes for something called "civic journalism," the Concerned Committee promises to avoid "solutions" and "codes of conduct." It will not place owners "at odds with" reporters, or journalism with "business." It seeks only to articulate what journalism "stands for."
Concerned now about the vagueness of this concern, I attend one of the committee's forums: "Can Journalism Be Impartial?" Man from The Times says being fair means applying judgment without passing judgment. Clever. Fellow from local TV says he hires consultants to appraise the quality of his news. Lazy. Washington Post critic says journalists are "salvationists" who want to fix the world by trashing the status quo. Cliche. A liberal Congressman says mistrust of government makes the media conservative, and a conservative columnist says Republicans and Christians feel ill served by a too-liberal media. This is when Navasky mocks the center and I conclude that many readers really favor bias so long as its their own.
Regretfully, I decide not to sign. I cannot find meaning in principles until I know the purposes to which they will be put. How do I know what anyone is for until I know what they're against? My greatest concerns concern something, and somebody.
In considering the state of communication in our culture, I am concerned that the conspiratorial nostrums of Oliver Stone and Seymour Hersh pollute the air we all breathe. I am concerned that the public's perception of "the media" now includes Jerry Springer, Sally Jessy Raphael and other enemies of civilized discourse. I am concerned that the murder, mayhem and medicine that pass for news on local television -- including stations owned by The New York Times Company -- are pushing all journalism into trashy territory. I am concerned that the owners of many media companies are starving their news departments, which should certainly put them "at odds with" conscientious reporters and editors, and vice versa.
Dear Concerned Ones: You cannot define our "responsibilities and aspirations" if you do not point to good and bad media practice, cite cases, name names. Be concerned not with what journalism "stands for" but with the good and evil that it does, day in, day out. Give the Pew money not to high-minded panelists but to abject practitioners ready to confess their failures and frustrations. Hire more critics to publicize our errors, libels and neglects, to do unto us what we do unto others. And pension off my generation of committee creatures, tiresome pleaders for the mythical good old days.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Spain's Freest Spirit Gives Maturity a Try

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
AT 46, PEDRO ALMODOVAR IS NO longer the overgrown kid he was back in the early 1980's when he sprang from the thick of Madrid's anything-goes night life, armed with a hand-held camera, to record the intoxication of Spain's post-Franco freedoms.
Funny, outrageous, sexy, even kinky, his early movies had plots that veered off at random angles. Culminating with the wackily exuberant "Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown," which won him international acclaim and an Academy Award nomination in 1988, they were a reflection of their author's disheveled, carefree life. 
 "My first films coincided with a moment of absolute, vital explosion in this city," said Mr. Almodovar, whose hair is more neatly shorn than in his wilder days but still stands up on end, giving him the look of a startled teen-ager. "Madrid in the beginning of the 1980's was probably the most joyful, the most fun, most permissive city in the world. It was really the rebirth of the city after such a horrible period as the Franco regime. If there was something characteristic about Madrid, about the culture of Madrid that I belonged to, it was its night life. That was my university, and the university for many others."
Mr. Almodovar, the most visible exponent of "la movida," as the cultural ferment in Madrid after Franco's death in 1975 was known, had arrived in the capital in the 1960's, a teen-ager escaping from the stifling, strictly Roman Catholic environment of the region La Mancha. In the spirit of the times, he tried a bit of everything: he created comic strips, performed in a drag act, sang in a rock band and worked for the telephone company, filming his first experimental movie on weekends.
Sitting recently in a modest office at his production house, El Deseo, surrounded by film posters, books and a few odd, kitschy mementos, Mr. Almodovar was ready to admit that he had grown up, if belatedly. And his 12th film, "Live Flesh," which opened on Friday in New York, is, in fact, a reflection of the adult in him, with a more sober look at love and passion and even a sidelong glance at the yearning for children and family.
Based very loosely on a novel by the British mystery writer Ruth Rendell, "Live Flesh" is the story of five characters -- two women and three men -- whose lives are linked by a shooting in 1990 and the accompanying elements of revenge, desire and jealousy that reach into the next several years. This is a typical mix for Mr. Almodovar, but unlike his more freewheeling films, "Live Flesh" stays on a fairly tight track as its plot unfolds.
In this movie, as in most of Mr. Almodovar's others, Madrid itself is a major protagonist. But this time, the city -- like the director -- has lost its glitzy surface. The Madrid of "Live Flesh" is not the highly colored, highly stylized skyline seen beyond the penthouse in "Women on the Verge"; it's a gritty place of forgotten shantytowns and kindergartens for needy children.
In Europe, critics have hailed "Live Flesh," which opened in the fall under its Spanish title "Carne Tremula," as a welcome departure from the director's old formulas. "The protagonist of the 'movida' has learned how to structure both his stories and his emotions," concluded a review in the Italian newspaper Il Mesaggero.
"I am not sure where he is going," said Angel Fernandez-Santos, a film critic for El Pais, the Spanish newspaper with the largest circulation, in an interview. "but I think Almodovar is entering his period of maturity. He is starting to show complete command of the art form. The earlier films were interesting, but they had little mistakes. In 'Live Flesh,' the whole puzzle fits together."
Mr. Almodovar hates putting labels on his work, but he admits that both "Live Flesh" and his 1995 movie, "The Flower of My Secret," about a romance-fiction writer with a bad marriage who starts writing under her real name, are departures. "In the last two films, I was attracted to narratives that were much more austere and sober," he said, "but that was because that suited those stories best."
He paused briefly, then made an offhand confession. "It also may be," he said with a smile, "that I am saturated by myself, by the things that I have done in the past."
Two of the characters in "Live Flesh" are trapped in a love that is violent and self-destructive, always a subject of fascination for Mr. Almodovar. But the main protagonists are two attractive young people, Victor (Liberto Rabal) and Elena (Francesca Neri), who experience a more innocent, albeit very complicated, romance.
At the start of the film, Victor's birth, on the night in 1970 when the Franco regime declared a state of emergency, is shown, in the back of a bus on a grim, empty Madrid street. By the end of the movie, Elena is about to give birth to their child in the back seat of a taxi as it drives through brightly lighted downtown streets that are buzzing with shoppers. These two nativity scenes serve as bookends, not only for the movie's interlocking love stories but also for the country's historical trajectory over the last quarter-century. And it is here that Mr. Almodovar returns again to reaffirm, and celebrate anew, the meaning of freedom.
"THE TWO PROTAGONISTS in this case have a happy ending because the happiness is the realization that the human being who is about to be born will be born in a better country," he said. "All my movies have a political commentary imbedded in them, and that is the freedom that the characters enjoy."
"I truly think this is the only country where I would have been able to do the things that I have done," he added. "I don't think I could have done them in England, France or the U.S. This is a free country where I can work in complete freedom. And in Spain, we hold on to our freedom like children clutching their most precious teddy bear."
But for Spanish audiences, Mr. Almodovar has dropped an ominous note into the narrative: the voice heard on the radio announcing the state of emergency belongs to Manuel Fraga Iribarne, the president of the Galicia provincial government who was Franco's minister of information and went on to become the grand old man of the conservative party that rules Spain today.
"There is a ghost on the horizon, and that upsets me like it upsets many Spanish people," said Mr. Almodovar. "I think it is impossible for Spain to go back to that awful past, but we are not so far from it either. That voice on the radio is still a live voice; it belongs to an active politician who in fact created the party that is now in power."
Mr. Almodovar's relationship to his native country is fraught with ambiguity. He is treated like a superstar -- the premieres of his films are always top social and cultural events in Madrid -- but his peers have yet to vote him a Goya prize, Spain's top cinematic award.
"THERE IS A KIND OF tradition here," he said, when asked about the absence of "Live Flesh" from this year's list of Goya nominees. "There is a huge hostility against me that is demonstrated every year at this time. I was too successful here and outside Spain. It is a question of envy."
Although he remains committed to the city he calls home, Mr. Almodovar laments Spain's eagerness to join ranks with its northern European partners. He thinks this policy has spawned a deadly homogenization, forcing Madrid to trade in some of its Spanishness -- its late hours and its siesta, for example -- for the sterility of, say, Oslo.
The Madrid in "Live Flesh," he says, could be any city. "I wanted to show a contradiction, both architectural and social, a contradiction which is very alive, very expressive and very unjust, the kind of thing you see in every big city today."
There are also economic pressures peculiar to the 1990's that have changed his beloved city, by putting a premium on competition at the expense of creativity. "Young people now are very preoccupied with the market, which is natural," said Mr. Almodovar, still a hedonist at heart. "But I remember in the early 80's, everything we did we did for pleasure, because we liked to, for the joy of doing it. Now people are not doing that, and it is a pity. Because, when you are starting out, that is when you need to do exactly what you want, with no responsibility."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2915 words

HEADLINE: Seven Unsung Novels Crying to Be Filmed

BYLINE: By MARGO JEFFERSON 

 BODY:
HAD I THE WINGS OF A dove, I would certainly consider flying away from the decorous sameness of the classics now being made into movies and television specials.
So much Henry James, so very much Jane Austen. And look, all three of the Brontes this time around. Then more Wharton, another "Tom Jones" (six hours this time) and heading our way is a BBC cable channel replete with the old standards. 
 Not that they haven't or won't yield their pleasures. But why this insistence on trafficking only in the sanctioned classics when it comes to pre-20th-century fiction? Filmmakers aren't remotely shy about using any piece of contemporary fiction, however cheap. And film history has taught us that many of the best movies are made from minor and shrewdly trashy work.
Recently, I read a group of thoroughly gripping, not yet canonized American novels that could make first-rate movies. They have strong stories, complicated characters, plenty of room for visual drama, and a mass of social and sexual complications (brutal to subtle) that usually make only the briefest appearance in "great books" movies.
Serious producers and directors say they are desperate for stories with depth and complexity. Screenwriters say their skills are the equal of novelists'. Why aren't they clamoring for the rights to this kind of interesting -- no, more than interesting -- rich, startling literature?
These novels are set in America, in the troubled, violent years between the late-19th century and the onset of World War I. The best-known of the writers is William Dean Howells, usually called the father of American realism. The others, several of whom he championed, are: Harold Frederic, Charles W. Chesnutt, Abraham Cahan, Anzia Yezierska and David Graham Phillips.
Four of them were journalists; Yezierska did menial labor and settlement house work; Chesnutt was a lawyer and court stenographer. And, yes, their jobs took them away from their fiction, but it exposed them to facts of American life that were passing other novelists by.
The interesting thing about what we call minor or second-level fiction can work to a filmmaker's advantage. This fiction doesn't have the unity of structure and language that the masterworks offer. It keeps in all sorts of material that major writers make it their business to refine or get rid of: subplots that keep appearing and disappearing, compulsive asides and expostulations; whole lectures on various topics. And yes, this does mean readers have to live with a surfeit of period attitudes and literary devices. But it also means they get the benefit of a less strictly edited sensibility. These novelists are like archivists, giving us much fuller access to the records, conscious and unconscious, of the age.
This is fiction from an America coming to terms with -- and coming undone by -- the consequences of industrialization, the Civil War and Reconstruction, immigration, the clash of old and new beliefs, be they religious, scientific or political, and, as one of the authors puts it, "the sex relations between men and women." Rebellion, repression; economic need or social habit; love, lust and pure hatred: these are some of the relations that earnest little phrase covers.
As for relations between the races, plenty of people who called themselves pure Nordics considered blacks a sub-species, Jews, Italians and Irish Catholics inferior races and the poor either or both. Each group responded in its own way; each had to make a life in the meantime. The relations among them was a drama you could find playing anywhere, any day of the week, as tragedy, farce or ethnic vaudeville.
Against this backdrop, individual stories and passions fight for our attention. And when it comes to passions -- money, power and what can only be called a sense of one's spiritual worth count as much as sex. Every one of these books takes on the hurly-burly of American life in a way that Wharton and James, for all their mastery, could not have done and did not want to do.
All of these books are in print, and represent just a sampling of the possibilities.
 
Anglo-Saxon Tales as Yet Untold
"A Modern Instance," William Dean Howells, 1882.
As the editor of The Atlantic Monthly, Howells was highly respected and highly respectable. But when he saw the respectable turning vicious and corrupt, he took it on with quiet implacability.
This book's deliberately restrained title conceals a truly horrifying portrait of a socially appropriate, emotionally murderous marriage. Bartley Hubbard is a good-looking New England newspaperman whose self-satisfaction registers as bonhomie in youth and greedy fatuousness in middle age. His wife, Marcia Gaylord, is single-mindedly possessive of him: what is first excused as the romanticism of a young woman about to fulfill her destiny as wife and mother is in fact the deformed obsession of a woman never trained or encouraged to put her mind and heart anywhere else.
Howells follows their move from a small town in Maine to Boston, the big city where they must establish themselves. Bartley thrives -- or thinks he does -- in a claque of breezy, cynical journalists. Marcia never quite gets the mixture of the pragmatic and pious that marks Boston society.
Socially, they keep being shuttled between the middle class and the lower fringes of the upper class. There are plenty of well-done characters -- shrewdly greedy newspaper publishers, repressed, high-minded young men and restless, socially confined young women; heiresses who like taking up charity cases and the lawyers who safeguard their money as they do so. Of course, there is a love triangle -- all torment and self-denial.
But in the end everything comes back to Bartley and Marcia. They are pitiable, they are monstrous, they are totally recognizable: your sympathies and your loathing keep switching from one to the other. Howells's first inspiration for the novel was "Medea." But this being a modern instance of a tragic misalliance, it is divorce that promises a revenge as awful and final as murder.
 
"The Damnation of Theron Ware," Harold Frederic, 1896.
Robert Duvall (who plays a Pentecostal preacher in his current film "The Apostle"), said recently that it is amazing we have so few movies about religion, given how it pervades just about every part of American life. In "Theron Ware," religion dictates people's social, economic and sexual destinies. And having done that, it threatens more souls than it could ever save.
Frederic was a militant realist as a novelist. But in "Theron Ware" his exacting journalist's eye and ear joined forces with the uncanny to create an upstate New York version of the otherworldly terrors and temptations that drive stories from "Faust" to "The Turn of the Screw."
Theron Ware is a young, pleasing and ambitious minister who finds himself assigned to a church in upstate New York. He arrives with his sensible wife and soon discovers he is expected to follow the spiritual and economic dictates of a group of Methodist church fathers who are hard-nosed businessmen six days a week and hard-nosed evangelicals on the seventh.
When he meets his first (that's right, his first) Irish Catholics, he is unsettled but thrilled: they might as well be sorcerers and goddesses leading him into forbidden but exquisite rites and mysteries. A worldly priest; a free-thinking scientist; a wealthy young woman who proclaims herself more pagan than Christian and has talks with the priest that are easier and more intimate than Theron has ever had with his wife. All of this makes him desperate to join their world without having to surrender the rewards of his own. Faith, eros and greed are at war inside him.
And how modern it all is too: the Methodist tent meetings with their tele-evangelist fervor; the Roman Catholic priest suggesting that the church leaven public implacability with private adaptability. And the three women in Theron's life, each needing a certain degree of masculine protection, each trying to see that it doesn't quash their private needs or pleasures. (The most successful of these is Sister Soulsby, a Methodist fund raiser and soul saver whose methods anticipate the best tricks of 20th-century advertising and pop psychology.)
As for Theron, small wonder that with his gift for mesmerizing crowds, his love of admiration and his flexible belief system, he comes to realize that the Senate might suit him better than the pulpit.
 
Racial and Ethnic Dramas in Which the Differences Within a Minority Group Matter at Least as Much as That Group's Relation to the Majority
"The House Behind the Cedars" (1900) and "The Marrow of Tradition" (1901), Charles W. Chesnutt.
Chesnutt's post-Reconstruction South is a treacherous postwar zone filled with brutish and byzantine rituals. (Among the brutish: lynchings. Among the byzantine: a longstanding network of cross-race family and social relations.)
Chesnutt's novels are about tensions, alliances and eruptions of physical or emotional violence on both sides of the color line. Among whites, the clash is usually between old manners and new money; among blacks, it's how a small elite (those with education and professions) and a large group of workers and servants balance class distinctions against racial unity.
And of course there is the third group, the mulattoes, who have the choice of passing for white or designating themselves Negroes or, at their peril, trying to do both. Chesnutt himself looked like a white man and chose to live (in the terminology of his times) as a colored man. With his law background, he found characters and events as much a question of manipulation as of anything we could call truth.
"The House Behind the Cedars" is the tale of a gifted and attractive brother and sister who decide to pass and establish themselves in the best class of whites South Carolina has to offer.
Rena, the sister, makes a brilliant match, which is exactly what her calculating brother has intended. But the engagement is soon threatened, first by her own ambivalence, then by a series of miscalculations, shifting loyalties and full-stop treacheries. The novel itself is a kind of mulatto -- it cannot stay on either side of a tonal or genre line. You could call it an ironic melodrama; you could call it a farcical tragedy.
"The Marrow of Tradition" is a compressed epic and a political thriller. It is set in one town and spans two generations of whites and blacks whose blood and fortunes are entwined. The author surrounds these families with characters who are constantly negotiating their positions on the racial, social and moral scale. (Duplicity can be a game as well as a necessity.) There is a romantic subplot, naturally. And there are moments of grisly comedy that make you feel you are witnessing a minstrel show from hell.
As for the political thriller aspect, its factual base was a race riot that took place in Wilmington, N.C., in 1898. (Chesnutt knew some of the survivors.) In the interests of stripping Negroes of as many rights as possible, a group of white aristocrats joins forces with the newly empowered whites they dismissed as trash before the war, while a few more liberal whites watch, turn away and hope for the best.
There is no one response in the Negro community -- how could there be? Some of the professionals advocate reason and caution; others preach radical defiance. And the working class is split, too, between blacks eager to answer violence with violence and blacks eager to believe that if they just go about their business quietly, it will blow over and leave them unharmed. The novel ends with the riot (it is harrowing), and a quiet aftermath that leaves questions of justice and reconciliation painfully dangling.
 
 "The Rise of David Levinsky," Abraham Cahan, 1917.
As Neal Gabler made clear in "An Empire of Their Own: How the Jews Invented Hollywood," inventing it didn't mean they should put their own life stories on the screen if they wanted to attract a mass audience. But the journalist and novelist Abraham Cahan, with a history much like theirs, could put a similar story into a book.
David Levinsky is a Russian Jew -- part of a vast group of Russian Jews who immigrated to New York in the 1880's. Orphaned and penniless, he settles on the Lower East Side, where every newcomer is sneered at as a greenhorn by anyone who has been in America even a few months longer. But he makes his way up, step by step, mishap by mishap, plan by plan: from street peddler to small manufacturer to millionaire power broker in the ever-expanding business of mass-produced women's clothing.
The business of America is business, said Calvin Coolidge, and that means that business should be (and too rarely is) a great subject for American drama. Not to mention all the social details that accompany a financial rise.
There are the embarrassments: David eating in an expensive restaurant for the first time and not knowing which piece of silverware to use. And the triumphs, as the callow youth who once lusted hopelessly after his landlord's wife and considered marrying a factory girl who earned more than he, becomes a desirable match for the daughters of the best Russian-Jewish families in the city.
And the revenge, for as some of the people who once condescended to him, German Jew and WASP, end up working -- or hoping to work -- for him.
 
Stories of Women Who Are Not Unduly Victimized, Unrealistically Triumphant or Predictably Punished, and Whose Fates We Do Not Know in Advance From Having Already Read the Book or Seen the Movie
"Salome of the Tenements," Anzia Yezierska, 1923.
Yezierska's Jewish immigrant women hurl themselves into the drama of assimilation and self-fulfillment, feeling the pull and the oppressiveness of the world they come from and the one they long for.
Her first book, "Hungry Hearts," was made into a 1920 movie, but New York was where she needed to be to write and she returned from Hollywood a year later. Her best-known novel, "Bread Givers" (1925), has been called "a struggle between a father of the Old World and a daughter of the New."
The wittier, worldlier "Salome" could be called "a struggle between a woman of the New World and a man of the Old," but this time, the Old World man is an old New York WASP and the New World woman is a first-generation American Jew.
Unexpectedly -- it turns out to be a romantic comedy -- Yezierska channels her social conscience into mockery and lets her heroine be the chief mocker. She gives us a sly and very practical happy ending. But a few turns of the plot, and we could have a painful drama on our hands.
"Salome" unfolds on the Lower East Side in the early 1900's. Wealthy philanthropists devoted to the settlement house movement make plans to eradicate poverty and to erase the more unsettling signs of foreignness found among the immigrant poor.
Sonya Vrunsky is poor, smart and beautiful. She hates being patronized and she craves the pleasure that money does buy. When the Yiddish newspaper she works for sends her off to interview a philanthropist, she decides she will marry him. (This is no wild fantasy: Yezierska based her story on such a marriage and on her own relations -- professional, but emotionally tempestuous -- with the philosopher John Dewey.)
Manipulating here, charming there, Sonya wins her millionaire. Together at last, day after day, with the differences that first thrilled them (her vitality, his rectitude) threatening to turn into maddening sociological cliches. Sonya has entered Edith Whartonland: Can she manage to stay there and, if so, can she bear it?
 
"Susan Lenox: Her Fall and Rise," David Graham Phillips, 1917.
Ah, the sensational Susan Lenox, whose life takes two volumes to unfold, and who has thus far been given a wholly inadequate 1931 vehicle that starred Greta Garbo.
When we first meet Susan she is a fresh young thing living with small-thinking relations in a small Indiana town. The only stain on her reputation is the fact that she was born out of wedlock, but it marks her like a scarlet letter once she is accused of being fast with the local rich boy.
Her relatives marry her off to a coarse local farmer; she takes refuge on a showboat with a theater company and never stops moving. She goes from Cincinnati to New York City to Paris. She goes back and forth among tenements, hotels and theaters. She goes from being a street prostitute to a kept woman to an independent woman and from impassive disgust to lust and love.
Phillips was murdered by a man who resented his portrayal of women as blighted by the conventions of society. The world of Susan Lenox is described with a muckraking journalist's lethal precision, from the tenement bed she shares with two other women to how she adjusts her makeup when she is streetwalking. But the story would not work if it weren't such a grand melodrama: Phillips turns melodrama into high-style emotional muckraking.
Classic novels and the films they inspire strive to give us a complete emotional and social world. We are right to love them for that, when so many contemporary films settle for a gripping sequence of events and emotional effects. But constantly drawing on the same books and writers is playing it much too safe.
What are we so afraid of? Is it that we still don't know about whole chunks of our past? Or is it that we still don't want to look?

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 3-Building Complex for S.I. Corporate Center;
Offices and Hotel, Next to Wetlands

 BODY:
Ground will be broken next month for a 65,000-square-foot, three-story office building in the Bloomfield section of Staten Island. It will be the first component in a $19 million, five-building complex in Staten Island Corporate Park.
The centerpiece of the 12-acre campus will be a 60,000-square-foot, six-story hotel and conference center with 175 rooms and a banquet hall for 1,200. It also will include an 85,000-square-foot, three-story office building with an 8,000-square-foot day-care center, as well as two free-standing 6,000-square-foot restaurants. 
 The developer is Richard Nicotra, owner/franchiser of 300 fast-food outlets including Everything Yogurt, who purchased 24 acres for $2 million last spring from the city's Economic Development Corporation; he later bought two additional acres from the city. Ten acres of the property will be preserved as wetlands.
The original concept called for a 16-acre campus with three two-story buildings with three restaurants and a free-standing day-care center, said Mr. Nicotra. But the campus has been reduced to devote four acres to vegetation characteristic of a maritime oak forest and containing Nantucket juneberry plants, "the rarest plant ever to grow in New York City," according to Richard Lynch, head of the Sweetbay Magnolia Bioreserve Conservancy, a year-old environmental group.
Construction of the hotel and conference center is scheduled to begin in August. A walking trail, pond and visitors' center with information on plant life are to be part of the wetland area.
Vito Fossella Sr., president of the Staten Island concern Land Planning and Engineering Consultants P.C., designed the project.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
New State Code to Ease Rehabilitation-Project Costs

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
EARLIER this month New Jersey put in place a set of rules to govern the rehabilitation of existing buildings. State officials say they could bolster economic development and the production of moderately priced housing, especially in cities.
New Jersey is the first state to design a separate code of standards to encourage renovation projects, which accounted for about half of the $6 billion in construction activity in the state last year. The new code, which became effective Jan. 5, is aimed at establishing a more efficient and cost-effective way for property owners to restore their structures without compromising their safety. There are 2.3 million residences and 500,000 commercial buildings in the state. 
 The regulations were drafted in response to criticism that current renovation requirements, governed under the state's construction code for new buildings, often add unnecessary costs. In many cases, owners were required to upgrade older structures to new construction specifications when the renovation exceeded 50 percent of the overall value of the property, or if there was any change in its use.
The Division of Codes and Standards in the Department of Community Affairs, which oversees housing, developed the new standards over the last two years with input from the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University in New Brunswick and a 30-member advisory board. The board was made up of local code officials, developers, architects, preservationists and advocates of housing for low- and moderate-income people.
State officials estimate that the new code could reduce the overall cost of a rehabilitation project by 4 to 40 percent, depending on the amount and type of work and the age, size and planned use of the building. Based on a 15 percent saving, the state's annual production of low- and moderate-income housing units could rise by 450 units to 3,450, according to the Affordable Housing Network of Trenton, which lobbied for the rehabilitation code.
The concept also sits well with the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, which is pushing rehabilitation standards as a provision in the national construction codes that states would have the option of accepting. Its standards, published last February, are modeled on earlier draft proposals for New Jersey's new code.
Jane M. Kenny, Commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs, said the new code removed a regulatory barrier to the recycling of older buildings and "adds a kind of predictability to the process." The hope, she said, is that developers will shift their attention from new construction in the suburbs to rehabilitation projects in the state's urban centers, where much of the old building stock stands.
Further supporting such a shift was a bill signed by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman on Jan. 7 that provides incentives to builders to redevelop sites contaminated by industrial pollution. The incentives include tax breaks, equal to three-fourths of the cost of cleaning a site and an exemption from new clean-up costs once a project is approved by the state Department of Environmental Protection.
"These are powerful new tools for urban redevelopment," said Commissioner Kenny.
"Developers shied away from older buildings and cities because it was felt that development was just too difficult," said Arthur J. Maurice, vice president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association in Trenton. "These two state actions will help change that mindset."
Basically, the new code sets up more flexible standards for rehabilitation based on safety risks, what the building will be used for and the extent of the work. A building being changed from a private residence to a public use -- say a restaurant -- would have to meet more stringent safety requirements than a building where no change of use is intended. In that case, safety improvements would be dictated by the extent of the renovation.
THE new code also permits alternative safety methods, including the installation of a sprinkler system instead of the reconfiguration of a building for an additional exit. It also includes a separate section dealing with historic structures.
The lack of clearly defined costs in fixing older buildings has until now discouraged rehabilitation projects because "if the return on investment is unpredictable the investment usually is not made," said William M. Connolly, director of the Division of Codes and Standards at the Department of Community Affairs.
He said the new code divided rehabilitation work into four categories -- repair, renovation, alteration and reconstruction -- and provided a detailed list of the code requirements needed to accomplish that work, making it easier and less costly in the process.
To illustrate the point, he gave the example of a 41-unit apartment complex on Academy Street in Trenton that was rehabilitated for low- and moderate-income housing under the old code. Under the new standards, he said, the cost of $90,000 per unit under the old standards could have been reduced by about $4,000.
He explained that under the new code old party and exterior walls that are not as fire resistant as most new ones -- but are not a safety hazard -- do not have to be ripped out, resulting in savings of $1,400 per unit. In addition, the old stairwells do not have to be widened from their original 32 inches to the 38-inch minimum needed for new construction, saving another $1,400 a unit. And by putting in a more advanced fire-alarm system instead of the required fire sprinklers costs could be reduced by $1,200 a unit.
No one argues with the goal of the new code. But there are mixed feelings about how effectively it will be implemented.
"After more government grants, the second best way to reduce rehabilitation costs is to adjust the code," said David Dubrow, president of Dubrow Construction Corporation, based in Newark. "But it depends on how much red tape is still involved and how local code officials interpret the new code."
Mr. Dubrow said he would wait to see how the code works and if the promised savings amount to even 20 percent he would probably do more renovations like the one his company is now doing in Orange. That project involves the conversion of an old 40,000-square-foot furniture factory on Scotland Road to 19 high-ceilinged condominiums.
Housing advocates -- including the Affordable Housing Network -- are more optismistic. "The new code is a dramatic improvement," said Diane Sterner, executive director of the network. "Reducing renovation costs allows public subsidies to be stretched farther and, in turn, more projects will get done."
William C. Asdal, who runs a remodeling company bearing his name in Chester that concentrates on rehabilitation projects, added: "Buildings on the fringe of economic viability now become viable and worthy of restoration."
The new code gives homeowners as well as developers "a common-sense way" of looking at older buildings, he said. Mr. Asdal intends to utilize the new standards to build a 600-square-foot addition to his 2,230-square-foot 18th-century stone house in Chester. He estimates that he will save $15,000, or 20 percent, of the overall cost of the project, which will start in March.
In another project under the new code, a former 1920's garage at 30 Greenwood Avenue in the Mill Hill historic district of Trenton that sat vacant for two decades is to be reborn as a private residence. John D. S. Hatch of Clarke Caton Hintz and W. David Henderson of Atlantis Historic Properties, local architects, will restore the 2,000-square-foot, two-story garage and add a third 630-square-foot floor for its owner, Roland Pott, who bought the building last year for $15,500. The cost of the renovation, to begin next month, is $100,000.
By applying the new code, the existing stairwells and corridors, which are narrower than those allowed in new construction, will not have to be widened, nor will the rear and side windows have to be blocked in, Mr. Hatch said. Under the previous regulations, he explained, firewalls would have been required because the windows are close to other properties.
Without the windows "parts of the building would have been unpleasant and unusable and there was a possibility the owner would not have gone ahead with the project," he added.
Now, Mr. Hatch said, the owner will save $10,000 to $20,000 and a boarded-up building will be reused.

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
A Sports Arena in Hoboken?

 BODY:
What do you think of a proposal to move the Devils from the Meadowlands to an arena that would be built above the Hoboken train station?
 
No Room for More Cars
 My family's been in Hoboken since about 1870 and I also grew up there, leaving in 1982. Two of the biggest reasons for my departure were the lack of parking and the difficulty of getting back into Hoboken whenever I left it, which was daily. To assume that everyone attending all events at the new facility would arrive on public transportation is illogical. Ticket holders will try to drive into town, further clogging already narrow, crowded streets.
 
PAM ROLAND
West Orange
 
Let Them Ride PATH
 The owner, John McMullen, wants a new arena that has luxury boxes. How are "luxury" people going to get there? Can you imagine telling a client, "Here are some Devils-Flyers tickets, use the company suite, and here are some PATH passes to get there"? These people use limos.
New Jersey Transit and PATH will be expected to alter their schedules for game nights. Temporary service adjustments like that will cost money for additional buses and trains, and overtime.
 
K.C. JACKSON
Teaneck
 
A Future White Elephant
When the shipping and manufacturing industries left, the only thing sparing Hoboken from the fate of its shabbier neighbors was an influx of artists and then young professionals. This has become in some ways a Frankenstein's monster, with an entire economy revolving around entertaining and housing these people. The proposed arena is simply a larger version of the many schemes we've seen in the chase for a highly sought-out clientele, while many other aspects of the town have been neglected. Hoboken's cachet will not last forever. The proposed arena -- built over a historically significant station that should be restored, not obscured -- could become a gigantic white elephant.
 
ROBERT LACKEY
Hoboken
 
Luxury Parking
 With parking being at a premium in Hoboken, it sounds like a parking space might cost more that the luxury suite.
 
DEE HICKMAN
Hillsborough
 
Build Schools Instead
Building all these arenas disturbs me because the nation needs schools. There is never any money to build schools but always money for sporting events. What's wrong with this picture?
 
CAROL KARAM
Morganville
