HEADLINE: Teaching Adults to Read

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: UNION

 BODY:
ONE night a week, for several weeks now, 13 people have been meeting in the second-floor activities room of the public library here. The group includes a nurse and a retired nurse, a college student and a financial expert, a receptionist for a pharmaceutical company and a manager for the State Department of Labor, a retired clerk and an unemployed paralegal.
Despite their varied backgrounds and age differences, they have a common bond: they love to read with a passion, and they hope to help others who can't. 
 They are literacy volunteers.
And after finishing this 6-week, 18-hour course, they will be asked to commit at least an hour and a half once a week for the next year to tutor someone in basic literacy or in English as a second language.
"You're a guide, not a dictator," Liela Bernstein told them. A reading specialist and retired high school teacher, Ms. Bernstein is a tutor trainer for the Union County affiliate of the Literacy Volunteers of America. During the first lesson she gave on a rainy January night that might have deterred less dedicated people, she touched on the relationship of mutual trust and respect that develops between tutor and student.
"It's a cooperative effort," she said. "They want relevant lessons to their lives and goals."
Between 40 million and 44 million adult Americans are functionally illiterate, unable to locate an intersection on a street map or fill out a simple form, according to a survey released by the United States Department of Education in 1993. Another 40 million are at a second level, said the report by the Educational Testing Service in Princeton, meaning they have difficulty answering questions about facts in a newspaper article.
In New Jersey, 20 to 23 percent of adults in the state, roughly 1.2 million to 1.4 million people, were at the first level, while 23 to 28 percent performed at the next level of proficiency.
"New Jersey mirrors the national survey," says Margery Oppenheimer, executive director of the New Jersey branch of the Literacy Volunteers. A list of the 26 affiliates, which operate in 20 of New Jersey's 21 counties, appears on this page. (The only county without a program is Warren.)
In the 1996-97 school year, Literacy Volunteers programs in New Jersey provided tutoring in basic literacy skills or in English as a second language to 5,915 people. But with only 4,386 volunteer tutors, the total waiting list of those seeking help stood at 1,410 in late June.
Although it is the largest statewide provider of volunteer-based adult literacy services, the Literacy Volunteers of America is not alone in offering such courses. Programs are also offered by a variety of state agencies and private organizations.
A joint task force of the State Commission on Higher Education and the State Employment and Training Commission has found no fewer than seven state agencies operating 17 programs at a cost of $36 million annually.
In a report scheduled for release in several weeks, the task force also found there were other state programs addressing literacy, but not as a primary focus.
"That means $36 million is a conservative figure," said Martine Hammond-Paludan, executive director of the State Commission on Higher Education and a member of the task force. "The general conclusion of the task force is, if we're going to advance employability and self-sufficiency and improve accountability among the many literacy programs, including improvement of efficiency, there needs to be much better coordination of these efforts."
The State Department of Education has the most programs. It provides money to, or supports with Federal money, 56 adult high schools offering literacy courses and high school degrees to 10,000 students annually; 46 evening schools serving 3,000 foreign-born students; 22 volunteer literacy programs helping 3,000 adults, and 35 adult basic-skills programs providing basic literacy and other services to 35,000 adults. The total price tag: about $21.5 million.
The need for such programs is evident. New Jersey ranks fifth in the nation in foreign-born residents, who make up 13 percent of the state's population, said Ms. Hammond-Paludan. The 1993 illiteracy survey found that 34 percent of the people at level one were foreign born.
In addition, 25 percent of residents 25 and older lack a high school diploma or a Graduate Equivalency Degree and 17,000 students dropped out of public school from 1994 to 1996, she said.
Henry Plotkin, executive director of the State Employment and Training Commission, said people with limited reading and writing skills used to be able to get good jobs in manufacturing but no longer can.
"That's really changed," he said. "It's been a steady evolution for a while to an economy where there is more of a direct correlation between skills and income than at any time in American history."
 
Opening a Book And a Bigger World
High school was difficult for Ada Jimenez, a single mother who lives in Jersey City. When she was 17, she left it to have a baby and found it impossible to return.
Two years ago, she learned about the Jersey City Free Public Library Literacy Program conducted by the Literacy Volunteers.
"I wanted to better myself," says Ms. Jimenez, now 32. "I wanted to be a better reader. I wanted to be able to read to my daughter."
When she started classes, her reading skill was "very low" and she was unable to write a letter. "I was really sad," she says.
"I stuck with it," she recalls. "It wasn't easy. It was very hard. It requires a lot of time. If you're working and a parent, there are a lot of sacrifices you have to make. You have to want it bad."
Aside from improving her literacy skills, Ms. Jimenez went to beauty school during the day and earned a certificate in cosmetology, managed to get her G.E.D. by going to an adult school at night and even obtained a driver's license.
"You know what it is when you can read?" she asks. "It's like the whole world is open to you. You can read maps. You're able to travel."
Now she is taking a computer typing course and working on her resume. She dreams of attending college and even of owning her own business. In the meantime, she wants to increase her reading skills.
"Imagine yourself blind, and one day you're able to see, and you can pick up any book and read it," she says. "It's great. There's so much to learn."
Herman Wilcher, 77, of Plainfield decided about five years ago that he was tired of depending on relatives to help him pay bills by check and do other personal business. So he signed up with the Union County Literacy Volunteers. A native of Savannah, Ga., he moved to New Jersey 33 years ago and briefly ran a sandwich shop in East Orange before taking a job as a porter at A.T.&T.
"I didn't want too many people outside to know I couldn't read and write," Mr. Wilcher says. "It was certainly embarrassing to me."
When he started, he could barely read the alphabet. Now he is reading at about a seventh-grade level. He voted for the first time, does his own banking, can read food labels when he shops and is planning to write a family history.
"I feel so good about it, I can't even explain how I do feel about it," he says. And, he adds: "I can put down things on paper today and look at it tomorrow. I don't have to keep everything in my head."
John Shaw, 37, a custodian at Becton Regional High School in East Rutherford, had a high school diploma but could not read. He would ask co-workers to spell words for him, took an oral exam to pass his boiler test and, when confronted with menus, usually ordered hamburgers.
After studying with the Hackensack affiliate of the Literacy Volunteers for 10 years, he can read signs, menus and newspapers with less difficulty. And he is experiencing the sheer joy of reading books.
"I feel good about myself," he says. "Now when you get yourself hooked on a book, you want to pick up the book every minute you have and read it."
 
Lesson Plans For Real Life
"We got the bus. It was yellow and red. We went to the park. The children played ball. We ate hot dogs. It was a good day."
This story is one that Laurie Glinka gives to people who apply for literacy classes. By asking them questions about it and by using other tests, she can determine how well they read, listen and comprehend.
As program coordinator for the Union County affiliate of Literacy Volunteers of America, she matches students with tutors -- some of 43,400 volunteers nationwide in the Literacy Volunteers, who in 1996 tried to help 67,886 students. The Union County office is one of 400 affiliates in 44 states in the organization founded in Syracuse in 1962.
In doing her assessments of students, she grades them from non-reader to fifth-grade level. Most of Union County's 220 students fall into the mid-second grade to mid-third grade level in reading, she says.
Once students are matched with tutors in confidential sessions that often take place in libraries, the students set their own goals.
Long-term goals, like getting a job, are broken down into short-term goals like learning how to read classified ads or a training manual. Tutors are told they should use students' life experience to teach them, so every lesson plan is different: how to read a prescription bottle, or a note sent home from school.
"The steps give them a sense of accomplishment," says Ms. Glinka, a mother of three who has worked as a manager of a fast-food restaurant, an aide to the elderly, and a bartender.
Karen Paardecamp, who operates a financial and computer consulting company, deCamp Consultants, donated a room in her office in Linden to serve as headquarters for the Union County Literacy Volunteers.
Ms. Paardecamp, who is the literacy group's treasurer and serves on its board, said she became more focused on the literacy issue when she realized it was becoming more difficult to hire qualified employees.
"I myself have a slight dyslexia problem that I've always struggled with," she says.
Although the affiliates are similar, there are variations. The Jersey City Free Public Library Literacy Program, for instance, has a family literacy project in which parents and children meet together to improve reading skills. It also has a computer lab that allows students temporarily without tutors to help teach themselves to read.
"Many people are fearful of computers, and working on them gives them a sense of self-worth and of being in touch with today's technology," says Carol Bloch, the Jersey City executive director.
Each student's skills are reassessed periodically. It may take one person a year to move up one grade level and another only six months. Each progresses at his or her own pace, and much depends on the tutor.
In addressing a class of fledgling tutors, Liela Bernstein said three qualities would make them effective: patience, understanding and creativity. And, she added, "You have to be interested in everything they have to say."
 
Tutor of the Year, And Other Rewards
Some tutors stick with the program for years; others fade away after their year's commitment. To recognize those who have excelled over time, the New Jersey office of the Literacy Volunteers chooses a tutor of the year, honored at a special ceremony each spring.
Now holding the title is Fran Pellmar, a 77-year-old woman from Edison with a background in accounting. She helped run her husband's store in Rahway for 18 years.
Ten years ago, she joined the Middlesex County literacy volunteers and became a tutor in English as a second language.
"I'll tell you, frankly, I've always felt that life has to have meaning, and we only go through this route once," she says. "And I want my life to make some kind of small difference."
But why literacy?
"Because language is very important to me," says Mrs. Pellmar. She was born on the lower East Side of Manhattan, the daughter of immigrants from Poland. "English is my second language," she says. "When I was a child, I spoke only Yiddish.
The reasons for tutoring vary, but all come back to wanting to share the gift of reading and to contribute to society.
"I love to read," says Elaine Gross, a nurse from Summit and a tutor in training in Ms. Bernstein's class. "And the thought of not having that enjoyment is just too sad to imagine."
Bonnie Anderson, a school librarian who is on the board of the Union County affiliate, says people have helped her in her life and she wants to return the favor.
"It took my student three weeks to learn to read a calendar," Ms. Anderson says. "He worked so hard every day at home that when he finally read the calendar for this first time, I cried."
Ms. Bloch worked for years in health care but found her niche as a literacy tutor.
"This is the most important thing I've ever done," Ms. Bloch says, "because I'm helping to change someone's life forever."
In her 10 years of tutoring, Mrs. Pellmar has probably changed the lives of at least 60 students, but she, too, has been changed.
"I've made a lot a friends," she said. "Everyone I've tutored feels close to me, and they feel that through me they're being introduced to American society."
"Working with these immigrants has meant a real lot to me personally because students I tutor, whether in conversation groups or one on one, introduce me to a culture that I was not familiar with, and I'm privileged to be able to learn about them."
Being honored as tutor of the year pleased her, she says, but that wasn't the real reward connected with her work.
What was?
"Just the doing," she says.
 
Where Teachers and Students Meet
 
The organization Literacy Volunteers of America offers programs throughout New Jersey. HEADLINE: Q[A]
Bonds, School Bonds: He Sells Them

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:

WHO -- Rafael Perez, 39, of Teaneck, executive director of the New Jersey Educational Facilities Authority for three years.
 
HIS AGENCY'S JOB -- The authority, little known outside the circle of higher education, was created in 1966 to help public and private colleges and universities sell bonds for capital construction projects, including building classrooms and dormitories. 

WHAT MAY CHANGE -- The Department of Education, the authority and some legislators would like to expand the scope of the authority's activities so it could handle bond sales for construction projects for elementary and high schools. Legislation is expected to be introduced to give the authority this added responsibility.
 
WHY DO THIS? -- Governor Whitman has said more than $2 billion is needed to renovate or replace school buildings and equipment in the 28 poorest districts in the state, which the state Supreme Court, in its Abbott v. Burke decisions, said must be brought up to the same educational standards as the richest districts in the state. The Department of Education estimates that the average age of school buildings in those districts is 56 years. Classrooms are overcrowded, and classes are sometimes held in converted closets or gymnasiums. These schools need new heating systems, as well as computer equipment. To address this, school districts will have to sell bonds to undertake large capital construction projects.
 
WHAT THE AGENCY CAN DO -- "We want to demystify the process of selling bonds," said Mr. Perez, who spent 10 years as a lawyer specializing in public finance. "A school board might sell bonds once every 10 or 20 years. We go to the bond market every month, so we have the expertise needed, and we have more leverage in hiring bond counsels and financial advisers. This frees the school district from going it alone in the bond market. The authority has never defaulted on bonds, so on Wall Street and in the market, we have a reputation and we can sell bonds at a lower interest rate and save schools money."
 
HOW THE AGENCY WORKS -- The authority sells tax-exempt bonds for a school and gives the proceeds to the school for a construction project. The school then repays the authority, which pays the bondholders. The authority does not provide money to guarantee the bonds. The authority, based in Plainsboro, has 11 members and is part of the Treasury Department.
 
WHY INVOLVE THE STATE? -- "Bonds are not always used for the work they are intended for. In the case of the special-needs school districts, the state is paying the debt service on the bonds and taxpayers are providing the money to repay the bond holders. The authority can see that the money is used efficiently and is used for the purpose that was intended."
 
TRACK RECORD -- "In the last three years since I have been here, the authority has sold $1 billion in bonds for colleges and universities. Most of the money has been for new technology, for athletic facilities and for housing," said Mr. Perez, whose salary is $99,000 a year. Since its creation, the authority has been involved in 237 bond sales for the state's colleges and universities. KAREN DeMASTERS

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:

Burning Desires To Enter Hot Business
 Jumping into the cigar craze, two entrepreneurs have founded a cigar production and distribution company, Tsar Cigars, that specializes in oddly sized and shaped cigars. 
 Arthur Metz, chief executive officer, and Danny Lipis, president, began distributing cigars from their office at 450 Park Avenue South, near 30th Street, at the end of November. Their staff of 14 has moved about 600 boxes of cigars so far. They have their own brands, Tsar I and Tsar II, which have several sub-brands. The Petite Perfecto, in the Tsar I line, tapers off on both ends, like a narrow spinning top. The Tsar II line includes short, slender models.
Mr. Metz said he helps compose the blends of Dominican and Sumatran tobaccos. "I grew up in a home where there wasn't a room without a cigar burning," he said. "If you're raised in a butcher's house, you know what the cuts are, and if you're raised in a cigar smoker's house, you know the difference between what's right and what's not."
 
Dissonance Can Be Found Amid Loud Bars on West Side
Upper West Side watering holes can become loud and boisterous, especially on "frat bar row" on Amsterdam Avenue in the 90's. A mellow new lounge on Columbus Avenue called North may be an alternative.
On Christmas Day, Matthew Paratore and Michael Bondanza opened North, at 483 Columbus Avenue between 83d and 84th Streets. Customers can sink into plush cherry colored couches and seats spread over 850 square feet and relax to recorded salsa and blues murmuring through loudspeakers.
"Its a 30's-and-over crowd," said Mr. Paratore, a former tailor. "We bring in straight and gay, black and white, men and women 30 to 70 years old."
Mr. Paratore, who says he started smoking cigars at age 13, is especially proud of the humidor that holds about 150 boxes of cigars for sale and consumption on premises. "But don't worry," he said. "It's not smoky. We have a really efficient ventilation system."
 
Necessity Is the Mother Of Massa's Cafe Harborside
The city told Dominick Massa he would have to turn an old cafeteria for longshoremen on his property into a restaurant as a condition for renewing his long-term lease of 1.2 million square feet in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, so he opened Massa's Cafe Harborside last month.
In a sparsely populated waterfront area, Mr. Massa hosts about 100 manufacturers and distributors (everything from tiles and furniture to soup and nuts) employing about 1,000 people.
Mr. Massa's grandfather and uncle used the cafeteria, at 1 43d Street, between First Avenue and the bay, for lunch when they worked at the old Bush Terminal commodities distribution station. "When I was 5, I remember my mother asked me to bring my grandfather the lunch pail he'd forgotten that morning," said Mr. Massa, who is 52. "The cafeteria was a smoke-filled room with hundreds of people eating around white porcelain tables."
The new restaurant sells Italian food at $10 to $22 an entree under a 50-foot-high vaulted ceiling that glows under spotlights at dinner time. Mr. Massa's son, Michael, is the chef.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mitsubishi Mirage;
Out of the Shadows, an Eye-Opener

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
MITSUBISHI is known in America for the Montero, its tough, midsized sport utility. The company ubiquitously advertises the Diamante as an alternative to entry-level luxury sedans like the Lexus ES 300. Its Galant has a solid if not broad following in the market for midsize sedans. And while they are beginning to show their age, Mitsubishi's affordable Eclipse and more-macho-than-thou 3000GT sports car still appeal to real road warriors.
All of which leaves the Mitsubishi Mirage, the company's Japanese-made subcompact, to fend for itself. And that's a shame, for both the Mirage coupe and sedan are handsomely finished, exceptionally agile little cars with reasonable price tags. 
 Start with the coupe. Restyled for 1997, it remains a sleek little package that stands out in a field of budget coupes like the Dodge Neon, Chevrolet Cavalier and Ford Escort.
The very basic $11,250 DE model comes with a 1.5-liter, 92-horsepower four-cylinder engine and modest accouterments: cup holders, vanity mirror, radio-cassette player. For $3,500 more, Mitsubishi gets serious: The fancier LS come with a strikingly smooth and peppy 1.8-liter four cylinder that delivers 113 horses. The LS also has air-conditioning; nicer upholstery; a height-adjustable driver's seat; a split, fold-down rear seat; tilt steering wheel, and larger, 14-inch wheels with grippier tires.
Add $744 for power windows, locks and side-view mirrors, cruise control and intermittent wipers. Tack on $793 for a power sunroof and $732 for anti-lock brakes.
Mitsubishi would be happy to include a four-speed automatic transmission, too, for $720. But on this car, the automatic would be a waste. For one thing, the five-speed manual gearbox is a silky delight, right up there in quality with the best from Honda. For another, the LS coupe begs to be driven hard. Indeed, it handles like a kinder, gentler Acura Integra, my own standard for drivability in the less-than-$20,000 class.
The sporty feel of the LS coupe is all the more remarkable in light of the car's high marks for comfort and convenience. The dashboard readouts and controls are models of clarity. And thanks to the height adjustment, the front bucket seats are a cut above the economy-class competition. The tight, tight, tight back seat is best reserved for children -- or, better, folded down for extra cargo space.
The sedan version shares engines with the coupe, but seemingly little else. The coupe shouts, "Drive me," but the more conservative sheet metal and subdued interior of the sedan whisper, "Trust me." Mitsubishi's promotional material makes much of the sedan's passing resemblance to the "chiseled look" of the Diamante. The overall impact, though, is generic Japanese subcompact.
A pretty face isn't everything, however, and the Mirage sedan delivers plenty of what most small-car buyers care about. The cabin has a clean, airy feel; the front seats handle relatively large frames. Back-seat and trunk room are adequate, though not up to the standard of the Mazda Protege. Engine, road and wind noise are nicely suppressed at highway cruising speed.
The price gap between the base DE (smaller engine, fewer amenities) and the LS sedan is just $940, which makes the latter a relative bargain at $13,720. And guessing, surely correctly, that hardly anyone would opt for an LS without air-conditioning, Mitsubishi offers a $1,600 "value package" that also includes power windows, locks and mirrors; cruise control; 14-inch wheels, and a split, folding rear seat.
The LS four-door that I drove came with the four-speed automatic ($680 on the sedan), a model for an economy-car transmission. Under normal throttle, upshifts were almost imperceptible and the transmission betrayed no tendency to hunt for gears on long hills. While Mitsubishi says the automatic adapts the shift points to the style of driving, I never noticed much difference.
The real joy of the Mirage sedan -- what makes it stand out in a field full of no-fuss, no-muss people movers -- is the first-rate handling. A sophisticated four-wheel independent suspension, combined with neutral steering and plenty of road feel, gives you the confidence to toss this sedan around. Indeed, equipped with the stick shift (for better control and acceleration) and the value package, the Mirage LS represents serious value in the pocket-rocket class.
Solid subcompacts can be had for less (think Saturn SL, Hyundai Accent, Ford Escort). A couple thousand dollars more buys extra room or more power (Honda Civic EX, Volkswagen Jetta GL). But the Mirage, coupe or sedan, stands out as a car built for drivers yearning to have fun on a budget.
 
INSIDE TRACK: Subcompacts for the inner child.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Aimee Picchi, Peter Dodds

 BODY:
Aimee Elizabeth Picchi, a television reporter, was married yesterday to Peter Sheridan Dodds, a graduate student. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.
Ms. Picchi, 27, who is keeping her name, covers software and Internet companies for Bloomberg News in Boston. She graduated from the Eastman School of Music. She is a daughter of Nancy and Bernard J. Picchi of Bernardsville, N.J. Her father is a managing director of research and a stock strategist at Lehman Brothers in New York. Her mother is the Internet coordinator at the Bernardsville Public Library. 
 Mr. Dodds, 28, is a doctoral candidate in applied mathematics and geophysics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he is a Fulbright Scholar. He received bachelor's degrees in electrical engineering and science and a master's in science, all from the University of Melbourne in Australia.
He is a son of Kathleen and Ken Dodds of Nhill, Australia, where they operate a cereal farm. They also teach. The bridegroom's mother is a home economics teacher at Nhill High School, and his father is a lecturer in economics, business and computer science at the Longerenong College of the University of Melbourne at Horsham.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: THROGS NECK;
Graduating to the High Seas

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
Edward Micola and a few of his friends spent a recent Thursday night reminiscing about their past and speculating about their future. All three graduated from college in 1996 and have landed good jobs. One is a social worker at New York University. Another, who majored in sculpture, does graphic design for J. Crew.
But Mr. Micola, 23 and a graduate of the State University of New York's Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, is doing something entirely different. At 4 P.M. on a weekday, while his friends might be fighting drowsiness with cups of coffee at their desks, he could be anywhere in the Atlantic as the third officer on the Chesapeake City, an 880-foot oil tanker. 
 "There's thousands and thousands of miles of ocean and it's all yours," he said. "I'd never seen skies like that. So many stars. In the Persian Gulf, I'd jog in the morning around the deck. There were a lot of dolphins, sea turtles, the occasional whale. I'm breathing in that air being out there and feeling very much alive."
And, with an annual salary of $58,000, he says he is feeling very secure.
On Jan. 8, 31 graduates of the Maritime College in Throgs Neck received diplomas; 125 or so more are scheduled to graduate in May.
Warren Engle of Green Bank, N.J., is looking for a job as a third mate on a tugboat in the region. "Something small to start out with," he said. Greg Banas of Lackawanna, N.Y., said he wanted to sail the Great Lakes and then go into the marine insurance business.
Others join the Navy or the Coast Guard, run casino ships on the Mississippi or become engineers.
Just about everyone who graduates from this SUNY branch who wants a job can get one, said Richard L. Miranda, a college spokesman. "Believe it or not, it's almost a guarantee," he said.
Still, while seafaring jobs are growing worldwide, they are declining in the United States, said Richard T. du Moulin, chairman of Intertanko, a trade group for the tanking industry.
But employees with specialized knowledge are in demand, here and abroad, he said. After the catastrophic Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1989, stringent new safety regulations have been adopted. And graduates of the six maritime colleges in the country receive intensive training in the new rules.
Graduates of the Bronx college receive an average starting salary of $35,000, Mr. Miranda said. Those who work at sea usually alternate three or four months on duty with an equal number of months on break at home.
For Mr. Micola, this has added up to long days of labor and adventure. On Jan. 9, he was planning to catch a flight to Kuwait to the ship. "I don't want to sit behind a desk," he said. "I don't want a two-week vacation. I'm young. This is what I want to do now." BARBARA STEWART

HEADLINE: OFF THE RACK;
Can You Crush The Millennium Bug?

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK 

 BODY:
IF the Asian financial crisis and roller-coaster markets haven't given you enough post-holiday worries, you can always turn your attention to the year 2000 computer crisis.
In fact, you should. Less than two years away, a pervasive computer glitch will fully kick in just as the ball drops in Times Square on Jan. 1, 2000. The so-called millennium bug could prove very risky for your personal finances. 
 In its February issue, Money magazine offers an article by Andrea Rock and Tripp Reynolds that examines the issue from the point of view of consumers and investors. It is a scary picture.
As has been amply reported, many computer programs and operating systems use only two digits to recognize years. When 2000 rolls around, the final two digits will be read as the year 1900, in effect starting the 20th century anew. Huge amounts of data and records -- including those for stock and pension accounts -- could be lost or corrupted.
Money points out that problems are already cropping up: Credit cards with an expiration date in 2000 or later have confounded computerized cash register systems in some retail stores, and appointments made for January 2000 shut down a computer network that handles patient schedules at three hospitals and 75 clinics in Pennsylvania.
Money says the problem has become a crisis in part because many companies and governments have procrastinated, counting on a "silver bullet" solution. Now they are realizing that the bug must be fixed chip by chip and line by line of computer code.
According to the magazine, Standish Group International, a consulting firm in Dennis, Mass., has estimated that United States companies will spend $440 billion fixing their cases of the millennium bug.
What's an individual consumer and investor to do? Among other suggestions, Money recommends the following:
* Find out whether your bank has fixed the problem. If you cannot get assurances by the end of this year, shift your money to a national bank, where the Fed is likely to give top priority for bailouts if problems occur.
* Watch your credit cards. If you have one with an expiration date beyond 1999, it may not work or may create problems. Be sure to carry at least one card with an earlier expiration date.
* Make sure your insurance company, especially if it is a small one, has dealt with the problem. Otherwise, you could find a policy canceled by a computer confused about dates.
* Test your computer and the programs you use. All Apple Macintoshes will accept the date change. Most PC's made after 1995 are supposed to, but you won't know for sure until you test. Testing programs can be downloaded free from several Internet sites, including Survive 2000 (www.sbhs.com) and YMark 2000 (www.nstl.com).
 
MUTUAL ATTRACTION Many of February's personal-finance magazines present their mutual fund picks for 1998. Because of differing criteria and categories, the selections have little in common; some are just mind-numbing lists of rankings in which a reader can see how a particular fund has performed.
Smart Money takes a different, and perhaps more useful, approach. It picks six funds that it likes for 1998 and then provides an update on how its 1997 selections performed. No fund appears on both lists, which may give pause to investors who make fund choices for the long term.
The picks for 1998 are: Baron Asset, Fidelity Select Developing Communications, Franklin Global Health Care, MFS Emerging Growth, Nicholas Limited Edition and T. Rowe Price Science and Technology. Gains for the 1997 choices, from Nov. 29, 1996, to Dec. 5, 1997, ranged from 21.06 percent for Janus Worldwide to 39.04 percent for Legg Mason Value Prime -- compared with 32.38 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
Mutual Funds magazine, in its section titled "The Undiscovered Fund," profiles a small fund, Delaware Aggressive Growth, which was taken over last April by Gerald Frey, a former money manager at Morgan Grenfell Capital Management. From January through April last year, the fund lost 22 percent. In the third quarter it soared 36 percent and for the year through Dec. 5 -- the period covered by the magazine -- it gained 47 percent. From Dec. 5 through Friday, though, the fund was down nearly 13 percent. As the numbers indicate, it is a volatile fund that may not be for the faint of heart.
 
INSIDE TRACK February's Individual Investor magazine has three articles that examine the strategy of buying shares in companies in which officers, or insiders, are also loading up on the stock -- under the theory that executives know more than analysts about their companies' prospects.
 
SHORT-CIRCUITED In Worth's February issue, Jim Rogers argues that so-called circuit breakers, which temporarily suspend stock trading when the market falls too fast, mainly benefit Wall Street insiders: They are the only ones with a clue as to what's going on during these timeouts. They are aware, for example, of imbalances of buy and sell orders for a particular stock during the pause. In the case of an imbalance of sell orders, the insiders know how far the stock is likely to fall when trading resumes -- "and therefore the exact point at which they can safely begin to buy," he writes. Meanwhile, he adds, "we're in the dark."
 
BITS AND PIECES Kiplinger's February issue looks at the considerable risk of investing in Russia. . . . In its November issue, Money strongly recommended dumping AT&T stock at $45.25 a share; on Friday, AT&T shares closed at $65.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Just Refinanced That Mortgage? Maybe It's Time to Do It Again

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
ALL it the re-refinancing boom.
Propelled by a precipitous drop in long-term interest rates to near-record lows in recent weeks, another wave of mortgage refinancings is rolling through the nation, only a few years after the last one crested. This one is characterized by many homeowners seeking cheaper rates for a second time or looking to lock in for a longer term. 
 Mike Dixon, for instance, vice president for finance at the Heartland Institute, an economic research group in Chicago, has refinanced his home twice since September alone. Mr. Dixon bought his home in River Forest, Ill., in 1995 for $250,000. He put 5 percent down and financed the rest at a 8.125 percent rate, fixed for five years, then adjusted annually for 25 years.
He refinanced in September at a 7.625 rate, under the same terms as the first mortgage. Then, earlier this month Mr. Dixon re-refinanced into a 7.25 percent, 30-year fixed-rate loan.
Indeed, it seems in the current environment, many homeowners can save money by refinancing, provided they stay in the home for a reasonable time.
"Refinancing is something that everyone is talking about now," Mr. Dixon said. "And they are not only looking for lower rates, but they are looking to lock in rates instead of having these hybrids."
His decision was easier to make because prepayment penalties -- which penalize some people who refinance -- are not allowed in Illinois. Moreover, brokers in the state pay closing costs, so while interest rates are slightly higher rate, the out-of-pocket costs are less. He said the only inconvenience was having to finance two escrow accounts during the process.
Mr. Dixon was also able to drop his private mortgage insurance because his home had swiftly appreciated; that, along with an additional $5,000 he paid into the loan, gave him more than 20 percent equity, the point at which the insurance is no longer required.
It also brought the new mortgage amount down to $221,750, low enough for Mr. Dixon to get a so-called conforming loan, rather than one at the slightly higher rate for "jumbo" mortgages.
With these moves, Mr. Dixon has seen his monthly payment fall from $2,500 in 1995 to $2,250 in September to $2,150 today -- a drop of $350 in five months.
"People can flip a couple times a year here," he said. "In fact, if rates drop another half-point, I may refinance again into a 15-year mortgage."
Mr. Dixon is not alone in his desire to refinance. Keith T. Gumbinger, a vice president with HSH Associates, a mortgage analyst in Butler, N.J., said that most first-time refinancings in the current swell had been for people who had bought their homes in recent years, or who couldn't refinance earlier because of low equity levels or tight lending standards. Many other borrowers who are refinancing, he said, have probably done so once before in the last decade.
Mr. Gumbinger noted, though, that the recent surge is nowhere near the tsunami in 1992 and 1993, when 30-year fixed-rate mortgages dipped below 7 percent for the first time in more than a quarter-century and some adjustable-rate mortgages had initial rates as low as 3 percent.
Back then, more than 70 percent of all new mortgages were refinancings. As of Thursday, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, a trade group in Washington, 59.9 percent of current mortgage applications were refinancings, up 11.5 percentage points from the previous week and the highest since Oct. 22, 1993.
The current figure is more than double the level a year ago and could rise further if rates stay low or continue to decline. As of Thursday, the average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was 7.01 percent, according to HSH Associates -- slightly above the 6.83 percent of Oct. 15, 1993, which in turn was the lowest since 1965.
Most of the refinancing activity has been into 30-year fixed-rate loans. Rates on one-year adjustables have not fallen as sharply, and many homeowners who took them out in recent years have found that they are now paying higher rates than they would for a 30-year fixed-rate loan.
As of Thursday, the average adjustable rate, according to HSH Associates, was 5.69 percent, just over one and a half percentage points above its all-time low of 4.15 percent on Oct. 29, 1993. These are teaser rates, though; after the first year, they often rise to the rate of the one-year Treasury security plus two to two-and-a-half percentage points.
In this climate, brokers say, buyers are sharply recasting their expectations of what constitutes a proper mortgage rate. "Eight percent used to be considered a good rate but today the 6 7/8 percent rate is incredible, like manna from heaven," said Ellen Bitton, the president of Park Avenue Mortgage Group, a mortgage broker in Manhattan.
Deciding whether to refinance can be complicated. For starters, many rules of thumb have become outdated.
The old formula was called "2-2-2," meaning refinancing was practical if borrowers had been in a home at least two years, intended to stay at least two more years and refinanced at a rate at least two points lower than their current mortgage rate. But that applied when people were refinancing from one fixed-rate loan into another fixed-rate loan and when refinancing fees were high.
So when is the rate difference wide enough? Neil Bader, chief executive of the Skyscraper Mortgage Company, another mortgage broker in Manhattan, suggests that a drop in rates of even half a percentage point can justify refinancing, if the attendant costs are wrapped into the loan or are paid for by the broker, as Mr. Dixon's was. Such loans are sometimes called "zero-cost" refinancings; in exchange for about three-eighths of a percentage point in the rate, all other fees are paid.
Not considering fees, the savings can be substantial even when rates drop just a little.
"Consider, for instance, a homeowner with an existing mortgage of $200,000," Mr. Bader said. "At a mortgage rate of 7.25 percent, the monthly payment is $1,364. At a refinanced rate of 7 percent, just a quarter-percent lower, the monthly payment would be $1,330, a savings of $34 per month."
Even the calendar is lending support to the refinancing impulse. Banks are more aggressive in their lending at the start of a year, Mr. Bader said, because their internal quotas of how many loans they need to make in the year have not yet been filled, as they often are at year's end.
"This is a compelling time to refinance," he said. "For the first time in over two years, no-points fixed-rate mortgages are available under 7 percent. Prior to this, fixed-rate mortgages under 7 percent were available only if the buyer was willing to pay points."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mike and Toietta Dixon have refinanced the mortgage on their suburban Chicago home twice since September, causing their monthly payments to fall a total of $350. (Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Taking the Plunge"
Refinancing is again a hot topic for homeowners, many of whom took advantage of the last spate of low interest rates earlier in the 1990's to reduce their mortgage costs. The best way to determine whether to refinance is to do the math and compare the costs of a new deal with the potential savings. (Source: HSH Associates)

LENGTH: 2802 words

HEADLINE: Now, Big Blue Is at Your Service

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
IT was the way the new, improved I.B.M. was supposed to work. In September 1996, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the company's chairman, lured a handful of corporate chief executives to a daylong strategy seminar. During a discussion of research collaboration among companies in different fields, Robert B. Shapiro, the chairman of Monsanto, wondered aloud whether his pharmaceutical and agricultural-products company could use any I.B.M. technology in its genetics research.
Within weeks, a SWAT team of I.B.M. executives was dispatched to Monsanto's headquarters in St. Louis, armed with tantalizing discoveries from I.B.M.'s labs that could be used to help map the gene structure of seeds and human cells. Once in the door, the I.B.M. salesmen looked for other opportunities. Lo and behold, a year later, Monsanto signed a 10-year deal worth hundreds of millions of dollars to I.B.M. 
 But the contract wasn't for computers or for software. And gene research was the smallest part.
Instead, the agreement called for I.B.M. to run Monsanto's mainframe computer system, to install and maintain its 20,000 personal computers, to operate the network that links its facilities and to write new application programs for the company. Having gotten its foot in Monsanto's door, I.B.M. showed its stuff -- and its stuff these days is services.
Competing with everyone from Electronic Data Systems, the computer-services giant, to accounting firms to the teen-agers who set up Web sites for small businesses, I.B.M. has grown in a few short years into the world's largest provider of technology services. It advises clients on technology strategy, helps them prepare for disasters, trains their employees and even gets them onto the Internet.
The services business was started in 1990, three years before Mr. Gerstner was hired. But it played right into his strategic gamble that the way to revive the tottering company was to capitalize on what others saw as I.B.M.'s handicap: its sheer size.
He quickly pulled back from the strategy of his predecessor, John F. Akers, to divide I.B.M. into smaller, more nimble units, perhaps in preparation for spinning them off. Rather, Mr. Gerstner decided, I.B.M. would offer its traditional big customers one-stop shopping for computer products, from microchips to mainframes. And services would be the glue that bound all the hardware together.
While Mr. Gerstner has stabilized the other parts of I.B.M., the unit now called I.B.M. Global Services has been the engine of growth. Its revenue rose from $2.1 billion in 1990 to $19 billion last year, with increases exceeding 25 percent annually. That is now one-fourth of the company's sales, more than from mainframe computers or any other product line. And services now account for half of I.B.M.'s 240,000 employees.
"It's not just the fastest-growing piece of I.B.M.; services have become the soul of I.B.M.," said Laura Conigliaro, an analyst for Goldman, Sachs & Company. "I.B.M. got to where it is today by offering its customers excellent service, solutions and support, but had largely given them away free." Now it charges.
Services may be the soul of I.B.M., but they aren't always a godsend. Profits represent a meager 10 percent of sales, far less than for its other businesses.
In addition, some analysts say I.B.M. lags behind its competitors in some hot areas, notably writing application programs and helping companies farm out business functions like purchasing and payroll.
"I.B.M. has a history of being very good in services that surround its product line," like mainframes, said John M. Whiteside, a former top I.B.M. services executive who is now the chief executive of Servicenet, which runs computer networks for companies. "The question is, can they produce a set of services for the next decade that embraces the hardware and software of all vendors?"
Meantime, with E.D.S. recovering from a two-year slump and new entrants crowding the computer-services field, competition is heating up even as Asia's economic turmoil shrinks its prospects as a market.
AND now, I.B.M. faces a new challenge: the departure of Dennie M. Welsh.
While Mr. Gerstner can take credit for nurturing I.B.M.'s services business, the initiative is largely the creation of Mr. Welsh, the Tennessee-born engineer who ran I.B.M.'s contracts for NASA during the Apollo and space shuttle programs. Mr. Welsh persuaded I.B.M.'s management to tap into its experience in running big computer systems for the Government and go head to head with E.D.S. in the market for operating corporate computer systems. He then nursed the services business through several tough early years with a mix of personal enthusiasm and his ability to navigate the complex corporate structure.
"Dennie Welch was a lone wolf crying out and pursuing the business, and no one was paying too much attention to him," said Stephen T. McClellan, a computer-services analyst at Merrill Lynch. "He has surprised a lot of skeptics in moving I.B.M. beyond the hardware and software business."
Two weeks ago, Mr. Welsh said he would take a leave of absence to fight an immune disorder so rare that the company says it has no name. He was replaced by Samuel J. Palmisano, his deputy in the early years of the services business who went on to run I.B.M.'s personal computer division. Mr. Palmisano, 46, is among the most prominent of a generation of younger I.B.M. executives seen as potential successors to Mr. Gerstner, who just signed a second five-year contract.
Still, Mr. Palmisano will have a difficult time sustaining the momentum. After all, I.B.M., which eliminated nearly 200,000 jobs in the early 1990's, is hiring 18,000 new people into its services division each year.
"Sam's challenge is simply growth," Mr. Welsh said recently of his successor. "We have been growing this thing at 20 percent or more for some time. Statistics don't allow that to continue forever."
In many ways, the dynamics of the services business are the delightful opposite of the treadmill that forces hardware manufacturers to run faster and faster to sell ever more powerful machines at ever lower prices.
Once companies buy these improved machines, they have to program them, maintain them, update them and train employees to use them. For I.B.M., the computers are the razors it sells to reel in captive customers, and the services are the blades that the users must buy again and again. It is the same logic that prompted General Electric to build a business servicing the jet engines it manufactures.
The scope of I.B.M.'s services offerings can be seen by traveling to Boulder, Colo., and prowling the enclosed walkways that connect the low buildings at the company's 493-acre site nestled in snow-covered mountains, one of nine such operations around the world.
The command center is one of those showy rooms, modeled after NASA's Mission Control, in which dozens of hushed technicians scurry about under a glowing wall of giant television screens, pausing occasionally to tap at computer terminals. They are busy performing I.B.M.'s classic, and biggest, technology service, in which it undertakes big, computerized functions like accounting and inventory-management for clients. This outsourcing business took off in the recession of the early 1990's, when companies were searching for ways to cut costs. Some even got an initial financial kick, because I.B.M. and E.D.S. bought their computers and hired their data processors in return for 10-year contracts.
While downsizing and layoffs no longer land an executive on the cover of a business magazine, "strategic partnerships" and sticking to "core competencies" often do. So the Boulder operation does more than save clients money. Monsanto wasn't looking simply for mainframe outsourcing; it wanted a partnership with a single company for research, programming and computer operations. "We are looking for fewer, more substantial relationships," said Patrick J. Fortune, the company's chief information officer.
Other parts of the Boulder center knit such relationships together. Through a tunnel from the command center is the computer room, where the I.B.M. mainframes that handle much of the large-scale data crunching have the appearance of the black obelisk in the movie "2001: A Space Odyssey."
Snaking into the computer room are enough telephone lines to keep a town chatting. I.B.M. has built one of the largest data networks in the world, with links to more than 100 countries. Not only does this network connect I.B.M.'s far-flung data centers to its corporate customers, it has also turned into a major product in its own right. Companies use the network to connect electronically to their suppliers, for example. And, increasingly, I.B.M. helps companies like Merrill Lynch hook their customers to the Internet.
Nearby is a vast facility that offers an eerie "Twilight Zone" sense that something is amiss. There are rooms and rooms filled with desks, telephones and computers, but not a person is to be seen. This is a new, $34 million disaster-recovery center, which will spring to life the next time a hurricane, earthquake or terrorist act disrupts a client's operations.
I.B.M. keeps copies of clients' computer data, so its machines can stand in for theirs. And I.B.M. employees will answer customers' phones until they send their own staffs to Boulder.
Another building houses hundreds of work stations, but unlike the disaster station, it is buzzing with earnest young techies. This is the fastest-growing part of I.B.M.'s service business: the workers operate help lines for stumped computer users at corporations across the country.
Fifteen years after I.B.M. introduced corporate America to PC's, it has become clear that the cost of buying them is only the tip of the financial iceberg of maintaining them and training employees to use them. And beyond the cost is the confusion. These days, many big companies don't even know how many PC's they have or what programs are on them. And that makes it difficult to upgrade the machines' software or track down bugs.
SO, increasingly, corporations are paying companies like I.B.M. as much as $250 a month per user to take these problems off their hands. "We can take control of your PC and tell you that your printer is out of paper," said David Graves, a systems developer. "Then we can tell you where in the closet the spare paper is stored."
Elsewhere at Boulder, and at many other sites around the world, are armies of consultants, programmers, repair technicians and specialists in such fields as updating computers to handle dates in the year 2000 and beyond.
The glitz and scope of the Boulder facility are a far cry from the seat-of-the-pants operation Mr. Welsh and a few other executives cobbled together in 1990. "We got started when I.B.M. was at its worst," Mr. Palmisano recalled, referring to the company's slide into red ink in 1991. "And we needed capital to start up and to hire a lot of people, but we had to earn our way every day."
Then, when the operation opened, nobody was interested. "I was 4 percent of my sales plan in 1993," said Daniel R. Colby, one of the first sales executives Mr. Welsh recruited. "It was real touch-and-go whether we were in the right business."
The company made some whopping mistakes. When a key phone line supporting Amtrak's reservation system was cut, it turned out that I.B.M. had never installed a planned backup. As a result, the railroad's phones were dead for half a day. But in classic I.B.M. fashion, it shipped in so many shock troops so quickly to fix the problem that it was able to repair its relationship with Amtrak.
Other customers were not so understanding. Some, like First Tennessee Bank, abandoned I.B.M. altogether. And several customers that stayed were money-losers, because I.B.M. had won its early contracts with below-market bids.
Lessons were learned, however. As I.B.M. figured out what its real costs were, and as it grew bigger and more efficient, it stopped the kamikaze bidding. As for the unhappy customers, it placated them by writing into their contracts the exact service level they could expect. It promised to fix problems within an hour or a day, depending on how much they were willing to pay. If that is spelled out, I.B.M. says, there's less room for complaining later.
I.B.M. also had to explain to customers that the squads of systems engineers who for years had helped set up new mainframes and keep them humming would now be sending bills for their services. But because this unbundling of services helped I.B.M. lower its computer prices, the complaints were muted.
The company has had to navigate through the potential conflict between providing the best services and promoting its own hardware and software. At a client's request, I.B.M. will buy and operate computers made by Hewlett-Packard or Sun Microsystems and use software from Microsoft or Oracle.
Competitors are quick to note that I.B.M. technicians' advice might not be completely objective, since they are obviously tempted to denigrate rivals' products and pitch their own. And Mr. Welsh made no bones about the fact that whenever he could, he pushed computers made by I.B.M. and software from its Lotus subsidiary. Indeed, I.B.M.'s services unit has turned into one of the company's biggest customers for hardware.
The business began to hum in 1995, when I.B.M. posted $12.7 billion in services revenue, edging past E.D.S. to become the world's largest computer services company two years ahead of Mr. Welsh's master plan.
"They have done a great job in building mass in the service business and a very good job in persuading the market that I.B.M. is a credible player," said Gary J. Fernandes, vice chairman of E.D.S. "We were lured into a false sense of security by the long record of success we had."
Now, Mr. Gerstner is pushing I.B.M.'s services business with a huge marketing campaign built around the Internet. Once companies dip their toes into the on-line waters -- what I.B.M. calls "e-business" -- they will realize they will also need to improve the rest of their systems to keep up, the theory goes. Linking big, complicated systems to one another plays right into I.B.M.'s strengths, the company figures.
"In my old life at the I.B.M. P.C. company," Mr. Palmisano said, "we wanted to put customer support and ordering on line, but we had to get daily information on our parts available from the warehouses of our suppliers. To do that you have to upgrade your entire system."
When other companies go through the same exercise, he said, "a lot of people are just going to say: 'You run all this for me. I just want to take the orders when they come in and be done with it.' "
SMALL businesses are another vast untapped market that Mr. Gerstner has declared a priority. There are millions of them, representing nearly half of the technology spending in the country. And many are hopelessly perplexed by their computers. I.B.M is using the expertise it gained in running its corporate personal-computer help desks to offer scaled-down versions of the same service.
For example, it has just introduced a series of prepaid service cards, which look like telephone cards and are sold in shrink-wrapped packages by computer dealers. One, which costs $200, entitles the holder to call I.B.M. five times for help on any of dozens of software programs.
The company is selling another card -- this one for $25 a computer, with a minimum of five machines -- that is good for one disaster-recovery mission by I.B.M., complete with air-shipped delivery of a new computer and use of a nearby I.B.M. office, if needed.
Similarly, I.B.M. is about to test a mass-marketed training and consulting package aimed at helping small businesses to use the Internet. For fees of $1,000 to $5,000, customers will get the right to a certain number of seminars delivered over the Internet, written material and the ability to get answers to some questions by electronic mail.
Actually, I.B.M.'s small-business product line starts at prices as low as $25 a month for a service that lets companies put their own home page on the World Wide Web.
Why would Big Blue bother with anything that small? For the same reason it was interested in joining Monsanto in genetics research: Once a customer whets its appetite at $25 a month, it is often just a matter of time before it wants a fancier Internet site that can take credit cards. Funny, I.B.M. has just the thing. Just buy a $15,000 I.B.M. server with the $5,000 I.B.M. Net.Commerce software. Need to design your site and get all of this hooked together? Perhaps a $50,000 I.B.M. Smooth Start service package will do.
Well, at least that's the way the new, improved I.B.M. is supposed to work.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
What $13 Million Buys Besides an Hour of TV

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
SO NBC agreed last week to pay $13 million an episode to hold onto television's most popular show, "E.R.," thereby pumping life into the network for at least another year. The deal-makers were congratulating themselves about all the zeroes before the decimal point. The cast was looking forward to one big payday after another.
But in today's economy, just how much money is $13 million? 
 The seemingly stratospheric payout that Warner Brothers demanded -- and got -- for "E.R." is the same as the value of Visa credit card transactions charged in the 60 minutes that the show is on the air (and in every other hour, around the clock).
But the going rate for "E.R." is still well below the national debt. "It used to be about $13 million a second," said Douglas Durst, the real estate developer who operates the national debt clock on the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan. "It's now around $6 million a second."
Real emergency room doctors can make $13 million last longer than the "E.R." doctors. The budget for the 34-bed emergency room at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn for a full year is almost the same as for a single episode of "E.R."
At Maimonedes, $13 million covers only what Dr. Steven J. Davidson, the hospital's chairman of emergency medicine, classifies as direct expenses. Every emergency room has indirect expenses -- "heat and light and having a building and having somebody from respiratory making sure there's oxygen in the hospital's oxygen system, and that there's a supply cart up there and the floors have been washed and waxed." JAMES BARRON

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Good Product. Sound Plans. No Sure Thing.

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
AMERICA'S love of innovation runs deep. More than a century ago, Ralph Waldo Emerson earnestly proclaimed that anyone who invented a better mousetrap would find the world beating a path to his door.
For a dose of reality though, consider the tale of Doumar Products Inc. and un-du, its adhesive neutralizer. 
 There is no question that un-du is the sticker world's version of a better mousetrap. The product can not only remove oil-based labels, stickers, price tags, bumper stickers, masking tape and gum, but it can also make a sealed envelope temporarily transparent so you can confirm whether you really signed that check.
Buyers who managed to find Doumar's low-budget booth amid more than 2,000 others at the International Housewares Show here last week broke into smiles as Mark Foley, the company's marketing director, used un-du to separate Duct Tape from single-ply toilet paper without damaging either. The delight became amazement when Mr. Foley then demonstrated that after allowing a few seconds for the un-du to evaporate, the tape was once again sticky.
"Everyone's awed," said Carlos Sanginesi, owner of Golden Oil International, a wood-polish maker. He had a difficult time competing for attention at his adjacent booth.
Still, after two years of market tests, trade shows, appearances on QVC's home shopping programs and repeated rounds of money raising, Doumar is only now creeping toward commercial success. There have been brushes with financial collapse and fears that larger competitors were about to introduce copycat products, which would have forced Doumar into legal battles it could ill afford.
"We've got a great product, lines of credit from the bank, manufacturing capacity and marketing reps -- and we're struggling," said Gary Reichling, Doumar's chief executive and president. "I don't see how entrepreneurs operating out of a garage without such a great product do it."
How entrepreneurship works -- or flops -- has never been a more crucial economic question. Downsizing has created legions of experienced executives and workers who are looking for employment and opportunity in new ventures. Small businesses are often cited as the major job creators in the economy, but it is new small businesses that account for most of the gains, according to Robert Premus, a former economist for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress who recently set up an entrepreneurial studies program at Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio.
And innovation, while clearly the riskiest form of entrepreneurship, may also be the key to long-term economic growth.
"There are 600,000 to 700,000 new businesses created each year, and an educated guess would be that well under 20 percent have a new product or something distinctive," said Paul Reynolds, a professor at Babson College in Wellesley, Mass., who is coordinator for a consortium of 27 universities, foundations and Government agencies interested in research on entrepreneurs.
"Each invention may only affect daily life a little," he said, "but these things have a cumulative impact that sets the United States apart from other countries."
As Wright State recognized, no self-respecting business school can today ignore the intense interest of business students in such activity. Harvard Business School says that in a recent survey, more than half of its 24,000 graduates classified themselves as entrepreneurs.
And the enthusiasm is not limited to America.
"It's a foregone conclusion worldwide now that if you want your economy to grow, you have to encourage entrepreneurship," said Jerry White, director of the Caruth Institute of Entrepreneurship at Southern Methodist University in Dallas.
One of Professor White's favorite role models for would-be entrepreneurs is his 36-year-old former student, Mr. Reichling, who grew up on a South Dakota dairy farm and studied accounting at his state university. Mr. Reichling and a friend moved to Dallas 10 years ago with $800 between them. They had so little experience with big cities that they did not realize they needed jobs before landlords would rent to them. They slept in their Chevette the first week.
Mr. Reichling soon got work as a $7-an-hour clerk filing waste reports for Dixico, a packaging company that made snack-food bags for companies like Frito-Lay and Keebler. By 1993, he had become a certified public accountant, earned an M.B.A. at Southern Methodist, risen to chief financial officer of Dixico, married and bought a modest home in the suburb of Mesquite.
That year, Bell Packaging, Dixico's Indiana-based parent, decided to sell the company. Mr. Reichling was offered a substantial raise, a better title and the use of a Lincoln Town Car. Instead, he and a partner engineered a risky, $2 million leveraged buyout of a Dixico subsidiary that had piled up $600,000 in losses the previous nine months.
Mr. Reichling invested everything he owned, outside of a small bit of equity in his home. But the gamble paid off when he and his partner quickly restored the company to profitability. They sold it to Huntsman Chemical in 1995 for an undisclosed sum, which, Mr. Reichling says, "left me a millionaire."
Professor White calls the turnaround "an expert piece of entrepreneurship" and uses it as a case study.
But that episode was just a warm-up for the challenge of starting Doumar. The fledgling company was created in November 1995 by two Minnesotans -- Mark Foley, a former salesman of liquor, apparel, chocolate and medical equipment who was looking for a new line of work, and Douglas Farley, a real estate agent. They were dazzled by the response among Minneapolis secretaries and others for whom Mr. Foley had demonstrated un-du after he had been sent samples by its inventor, his father, Charles Foley.
With just $6,000 in capital -- and Mark Foley went into debt, at that, to come up with his share -- Doumar acquired the rights to distribute un-du for two years. But the new company clearly needed more money to grow. That was when Warren Garden, a lawyer who had helped the partners incorporate, introduced them to Mr. Reichling, who had been investing some of his new wealth in a variety of fledgling businesses -- acting, in entrepreneurial argot, as a financial "angel."
ANGELS are the black hole of entrepreneurship research. No one knows how much capital such private investors put up annually, but the consensus is that it is far in excess of the contribution of the $43.5 billion professional venture capital industry. The angels' money, contacts and management advice come at the crucial stage when businesses are too new to get the attention of the venture capital firms, according to Charles Heller, director of the Dingman Center for Entrepreneurship at the University of Maryland.
Mr. Reichling loved un-du but was appalled by the holes in Doumar's business plan. He invested $75,000 in the spring of 1996 on the understanding that Doumar would negotiate permanent distribution rights. He also wanted it to take over manufacturing and control of the patent from Un-du Inc., a venture that Charles Foley had cobbled together with acquaintances in North Carolina in the hope that they would commercialize un-du.
That year was consumed in raising new money, negotiating the Un-du Inc. buyout terms, designing more sophisticated packaging, building a network of sales representatives and courting buyers at shows. There were highs, like winning "best new product" at the Business Product Industry Association show here in June 1996. Mr. Reichling completed the transition from angel to full-time chief executive in September, partly because he felt he owed it to friends and relatives who had invested at his suggestion.
In November, Reading China and Glass, a kitchen and dining room superstore chain based in Newark, Del., placed the first major retail order. Still, the year ended with just $38,000 in revenue and $400,000 in expenses.
"We went through much more money than we thought we would," Mr. Reichling said.
Last year, the tightrope moved much higher. Revenue reached about $800,000, thanks to growing retail orders and a series of appearances on QVC -- including a 10-minute segment last month featuring Mark Foley that resulted in the sale of 30,000 bottles. But the company also invested heavily, moving manufacturing to Texas, expanding production capacity, installing computer and phone systems and hiring more employees.
There were times when the company tottered perilously. In the course of the move, thousands of poorly capped bottles of un-du evaporated. Everyone pitched in to refill them by hand -- and had the blisters to prove it. Local investors and relatives, including Mr. Reichling's parents, both in their 80's, were sometimes recruited as weekend or evening labor to help meet rush orders.
To stay afloat, Doumar's executives twice took pay cuts. Even so, Mr. Reichling had to set up a compensation pecking order. The first to be paid were vendors and hourly workers; then Mr. Foley, who is divorced but has child support payments to make and almost no savings; then Brendan Bauer, the director of operations, whose wife works as a teacher, and finally Mr. Reichling. Pay levels were restored last fall, but December was the first month when everyone was paid on schedule.
Doumar could have made life easier for itself by accepting more money from angels, which was readily available. But Mr. Reichling was reluctant to further dilute the holdings of the early investors like Mr. Foley.
Mr. Reichling is currently the largest shareholder, with more than 30 percent of the company.
Mr. Foley said he was down to 12 percent but, he added, "I know the sacrifices will pay off down the road."
But new bumps always seem to emerge. For instance, when Doumar finally began attracting orders last year from a few nationwide retailers like Walgreens and Staples, it discovered that they routinely demanded 90 days to pay. That squeezes cash reserves at Doumar, which must pay its suppliers up to two months sooner.
Perhaps most discouraging, many retailers who love un-du tell Doumar that they will not place orders until the company has the money to advertise it widely. Others flatly refuse to order from a company with only one product.
THE costs of any wrong move are certain to grow because, as last week's housewares show underscored, potentially tough competitors have started to emerge.
The biggest concern has been the Magic American Corporation, a Cleveland-based maker of specialty cleaners with $30 million in annual revenues and well-established distribution capacity. Six months ago, Magic American served notice that it was paying attention, instigating an investigation by the Consumer Product Safety Commission of Doumar's labeling of the flammable product.
Mr. Reichling said the Federal agency ended up concluding that there was no problem, but the episode was an unexpected, nerve-fraying diversion. Then, buyers told Doumar late last year that Magic American was hinting that it would soon have a cut-price version of un-du under its popular GooGone brand.
At Magic American's booth at the housewares show, Doumar executives encountered the new GooGone "Sticker Lifter" for the first time. They were dismayed that the package resembled un-du's, but the products differ enough that it was difficult to see what Doumar could do about it.
GooGone clearly uses a different, slower-acting solvent that does not preserve the adhesive on the tape or label being removed. Nor does it leave all surfaces stain-free, as un-do does. It comes with a plastic lifting tool, but unlike the one covered by Doumar's patent, Magic American's tool is not attached to the bottle.
"We think the separate tool and the slower action give us more flexibility," said Alan Zeilinger, Magic American's president, who diplomatically praised Doumar for "expanding the category."
The arrival of competitors steps up the pressure on Doumar to quickly take the un-du name national -- and even international -- to help establish it as the clear leader in adhesive removers. If un-du can become a strong brand name, Doumar has a much better chance of adding other products, including stain and odor removers, to its business, even it they are not unique. Only then would it become an attractive supplier for giants like Wal-Mart and Home Depot.
Expanding too rapidly has, of course, led to spectacular debacles, even for famous entrepreneurs. Raising capital without giving away control and most of the profits to investors is one challenge. Attracting the right managers is even tougher, according to those who have studied the field.
But the more frequent, if less visible, error is expanding too slowly, according to Lloyd E. Shefsky, a lawyer who represented entrepreneurs for 25 years. Mr. Shefsky wrote "Entrepreneurs Are Made Not Born" (McGraw-Hill, 1994) and now teaches at Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management.
"Survival without huge success is the most common outcome," he said.
The signs are mounting that the issue for un-du is shifting from whether it will survive to how big a success it will be.
"It's been flying off the shelves," said Kimberly Nathan, the buyer for Reading China who gave Doumar its first big break.
But Mr. Reichling remains cautious.
"Every step," he said, "has been tougher than we expected."
