SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1096 words

HEADLINE: The World: Indonesia's Economic Crisis;
The World Looks at Bali and Sees Krakatoa

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia

 BODY:
WHEN Krakatoa blew apart in 1883 in one of the world's most cataclysmic explosions, it took three months before the first evidence of the eruption off Java was visible in America, in the form of brilliant sunsets created by volcanic ash circling the globe.
When the rupiah, Indonesia's currency, melted down 10 days ago, it took only minutes to feel the reverberations. Currencies and stock markets dropped throughout Asia, and Wall Street took a shellacking. Within hours, President Clinton was on the phone to Asia's longest-serving leader, Suharto, telling him he had only days to get his economic act together. 
 And by the middle of last week, it was hard to move through this steamy capital -- where cement-mixers, loose chickens and tycoons in soon-to-be-repossessed Rolls Royces coexist in a perpetual traffic jam -- without running into delegations of foreign officials in mid-damage control. There was Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, on a whirlwind tour of seven reeling Asian capitals to build "market confidence." There was Defense Secretary William Cohen, telling the Indonesians "we are here in good times and in bad," and the director general of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, dishing out prescriptions for turning bad times into good. (The last plan, his aides acknowledged in a confidential memorandum, may have helped make the bad times worse.)
And that doesn't count the flood of Asian prime ministers, finance ministers, and global economists who came to examine the wreckage, like aircraft engineers looking to prevent the next crash.
But does it really make sense for the world to quiver at the prospect of collapse in a country whose gross domestic product is roughly comparable to the combined annual revenues of Walmart and Exxon -- something in the low $200-billion range? Ten years ago, a meltdown of the Indonesian currency market would barely have warranted two paragraphs on page 17 of the business section. Since then Indonesia has grown and the globe has shrunk. But has it shrunk that much? Probably not.
 
Overreacting?
"There could be an element of overreaction to all this," one senior Western finance official conceded, saying that theories about small markets setting off Krakatoa-sized explosions in faraway lands "might be getting a little overblown."
If Indonesia ignored the world's advice about how to reform its economy, he suggested, it's possible there would be no global contagion. It is just possible that the country might simply find itself cut off from the world economy -- the archipelago version of a black hole that no investor or international banker would get near, except, naturally, for long weekends in Bali.
Still, no one -- especially in Washington -- is eager to let Indonesia sink and see what happens, lest they discover that those annoying globalists are right, and that Jakarta's pain quickly becomes Tokyo's, and Tokyo's becomes New York's.
They are not that adventurous because six months into the Asian crisis people still have a hard time figuring out how an astounding variety of disparate problems -- bad debt in Jakarta, unyielding labor unions in Seoul, uncomprehending politicians in Tokyo, shaky banking systems everywhere -- are mixing together to produce a financial crisis that refuses to end.
In the absence of a real understanding of what is happening, the I.M.F. is prescribing traditional solutions: austerity, high interest rates, opening markets wider. But those do not address the problems of a crushing debt and deepening recession, which may explain why even after the I.M.F. has acted, currencies have continued to drop. There are no magic bullets.
Indonesia is an example of how the Asian crisis has become the ultimate game of three-dimensional checkers, where a false move in a distant corner of the board has a jarring way of affecting all the moves in the middle of the board. And in this case, the middle of the board is occupied by China, Japan and the United States.
But that alone doesn't explain the worry about Indonesia. Sure, its economy is promising, but it's hardly Japan or Korea. There's oil just offshore, sneaker factories and a smattering of medium-tech manufacturing. And it has a lot of problems (which investors were happy enough to overlook when the place was growing at 7 percent a year): It is run by an aging authoritarian who cut deals for his family and friends (many of which the I.M.F. wants broken up); it is a country of legendary corruption, and now there is fear on the streets that when the inevitable political transition begins chaos could ensue. Oh, and its companies borrowed at least $65 billion overseas -- maybe much more -- that they cannot pay back now that the rupiah has plunged 70 percent.
A bad scene, but is it America's problem? By itself, probably not. But Mr. Cohen was here out of fear that if Indonesia destabilizes, so does all Southeast Asia. And Mr. Summers was here because he has learned how quickly a loss of confidence in a nation or a currency can turn an outflow of funds into a panic.
And then there are all the odd linkages among nations that did not exist a decade ago. South Korea, which has problems of its own, has more than 300 companies here, and huge loans to Indonesian enterprises that are now going bust. As those loans go bad, Korea's banks and conglomerates suffer; and when Korea worsens, so does Japan. When less powerful currencies fall, pressure grows in places like Japan and China to let their currencies weaken. Otherwise, for example, Chinese sneakers will not retain their cost advantage over Indonesian sneakers. It is the kind of cycle that seems like it will never end (until one day it switches directions).
 
A Confidence Problem
"I have been impressed by the fact that this is a regional problem as well as a problem in individual countries," Mr. Summers said from South Korea on Friday. "Sound policies in any one country is conducive to confidence that benefits other countries as well."
In fact, while confidence is mildly contagious, the loss of it can be highly contagious. Investors who see a panic in Indonesia have a lot easier time convincing themselves that Malaysia, or Tokyo, is next. So America spent the week holding Mr. Suharto's hand for the same reason Hong Kong is killing its chickens: Because no one will buy if they think there is even a remote chance of catching something deadly.
It may not be rational, but it's a very human response, whether you are on Java, in Hong Kong or in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: The Nation: U.S. v. Microsoft FAQ;
Court Is Not Where They'd Like to Go Today

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
MICROSOFT and the Justice Department were at each others' throats again last week. The venue was a United States District Court in Washington, where a Microsoft programming maven and a Government software expert testified on the fine points of Internet browsers and operating system software.
Hardly the stuff of Court TV, but the case has become an antitrust soap opera. Why? And what is at stake? If the case were an Internet site, the basic questions would be addressed in a FAQ file, shorthand for frequently asked questions (pronounced "fack"). Here then is a FAQ file for, as the suit reads, "United States of America v. Microsoft Corporation." 
 Why is the Government going after Microsoft?
The Justice Department filed a suit last October alleging that Microsoft was violating its 1995 consent decree. In that pact, the company agreed to alter its licensing contracts slightly to avoid Government antitrust charges. But the Justice Department now alleges that Microsoft is breaking that agreement by forcing personal computer makers to load its Internet Explorer browser onto their machines as a condition of licensing the Windows 95 operating system, which is the industry standard. The antitrust decree prohibits Microsoft from tying one of its products to another in its licensing deals with PC makers.
So isn't this a simple case and Microsoft is guilty as charged?
The Justice Department says yes. But Microsoft says no because the same section of the consent decree that prohibits tying one product to another also says that the provision "shall not be construed to prohibit Microsoft from developing integrated products." Microsoft contends that Explorer and Windows are not separate products but a single, integrated product. Explorer, the company says, is a "feature" of Windows.
How important is the consent-decree case?
At first, it appeared to be a wrist-slap suit, but the stakes have risen over the last month. On Dec. 11, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ordered Microsoft to stop forcing PC makers to install Explorer along with its Windows software. It was a temporary setback for Microsoft, and mainly a moral victory for its rival in the browser market, Netscape Communications Corporation. After all, Microsoft gives away Explorer free, so few PC makers, if any, would likely take the unbundled option -- Windows without Explorer.
Microsoft's reply to the judge's order was swift and firm. Saying it could not unbundle Explorer and Windows, Microsoft called the judge's order "senseless." It proposed two unattractive unbundled options -- an outdated version of Windows or a new one that had been ruined by yanking out Explorer.
The Justice Department called Microsoft's response "arrogant" and filed a contempt of court motion. To many in the industry, the company's combative tactics have made it seem a bully. Even its executives admit the company's hard-line stance has tarnished its good name, but they insist their uncompromising approach is based on principle, not pique.
What is the principle?
Microsoft says that only the company should determine what goes into its operating system -- the master control program that serves as the central nervous system of a computer. Any slippage from that principle is a step down the road to what Nathan Myhrvold, Microsoft's chief technology officer, colorfully describes as "the Federal Bureau of Operating Systems."
The bedrock issue in the consent-decree case, says Steven Ballmer, an executive vice president, "is really the fundamental right to innovate."
The Government replies that it has no intention of meddling with software-design decisions; the real issues in the case are less about technology than about the abuse of market power by a dominant company.
Do antitrust laws that date from the 19th-century robber barons really apply to the high-tech industries of today?
The Government believes that they do. "The overarching principles of the use of market power and the abuse of market power are consistent," said Joel I. Klein, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's antitrust division. "The current laws are applicable to new circumstances and new markets like computer software."
Beyond the consent-decree suit, The Government is also weighing an antitrust suit against Microsoft under the Sherman Act of 1890, but it is as yet undecided about bringing the broader case challenging Microsoft's business practices.
But isn't the lesson of the I.B.M. case that the Government and courts move too slowly to keep up with the computer industry?
In 1982, the Reagan Administration announced that it was dropping the Government's antitrust case against I.B.M., which ran for 13 years. The real force that broke I.B.M.'s iron grip on the industry was its own sluggishness in coping with innovations like the microchip and upstarts like Microsoft.
The I.B.M. case has been for the Justice Department what the Vietnam War was for the Pentagon, a humbling experience that has shaped policy ever since. If they bring a Sherman suit against Microsoft, Justice officials insist, it will be sharply focused, in keeping with Mr. Klein's belief that modern antitrust enforcement should limit itself to "surgical intervention."
What should antitrust policy toward Microsoft be?
That's a truly complex issue that probably will be debated for years. Robert E. Hall, a professor of economics at Stanford University, has thought a lot about the subject. A respected mainstream economist who is often mentioned as a candidate for a Nobel prize, Mr. Hall was an adviser to the Justice Department when the consent decree was negotiated and eventually approved in August 1995.
Mr. Hall argues for the benefits of constant scrutiny of Microsoft, given its dominance of a vital industry, but he also argues for careful enforcement. "The big problem in this field is the risk that the cure is worse than the disease," he said.
Practices to prevent, he says, include contracts with outside software developers that stop them from working with Microsoft rivals or licensing deals that exclude competitors. "The challenge is to hold the door open for the next Microsoft," he said, "so there is no way for Microsoft to hold onto its position except to develop great software."

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By PATRICK J. LYONS 

 BODY:

ASIAN TURMOIL, PART I
Try, Try Again
Nothing is simple with Indonesia. The International Monetary Fund thought it had a deal in October to bail out the country and put it on a more austere path. Then came a 1998 budget that imposed austerity on everyone but the Government and the well connected. High-level visitors flocked to Jakarta to explain to the Suharto Government that this just wouldn't do. On Monday, Version 1.1 of the deal had Indonesia pledging to behave and getting a few concessions on budget surpluses and bank closings. (The latter, the I.M.F. acknowledged, had clearly backfired.) But once again the deal was threatened by rear-guard actions to spare the vast business empires of President Suharto's family and friends from the bitter economic pill. Progressively bigger wigs -- including President Clinton and Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director -- weighed in. On Thursday, President Suharto finally agreed to Version 2.0, with its long list of stringent particulars and much less wriggle room. 

ASIAN TURMOIL, PART II
Turning a Corner
Though the two are both experiencing currency crises, South Korea is proving as different from Indonesia as kimchi from cloves. The Seoul stock market staged an impressive revival last week. The benchmark Kospi Composite index has recovered more than half the ground it lost after the global equity selloff last October, and is up 31 percent so far in 1998. Negotiations with foreign banks to refinance the country's debt seemed to be making calm, steady progress, though some smaller American banks have complained of undue pressure from their big money-center competitors, who had been given normally confidential details of the little guys' loans by the Federal Reserve.
 
ASIAN TURMOIL, PART III
Mercantilism Redux
Consensus has it that the only way back to prosperity and a decent credit rating for most of the stricken Asian nations is to throttle back on imports while exporting like mad, preferably to the United States. The Philippines took the concept to heart last week, killing a $600 million Boeing jetliner order on Friday, as did Thailand, which reported for December the biggest trade surplus in its history. Detroit worried very publicly about the new cost advantage for Asian rivals; each of the Big Three told analysts to expect heavy rebates and discounts on cars and mini-vans in 1998 to combat cheaper imports.
 
U.S. v. MICROSOFT
Down and Dirty
Microsoft's battle with the Federal Government is shaping up as an epic mud-wrestling match -- with some of the gooey brown stuff splattering on the referee. In hearings before United States District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, the Justice Department said Microsoft was thumbing its nose at the judge's Dec. 11 order to stop forcing manufacturers to install its Internet browser software in any computer that ships with the Windows 95 operating system. Microsoft retorted that the Hobson's choice it is offering manufacturers -- broken Windows, obsolete Windows or bundled Windows -- was exactly what the judge's order required, so the judge had better be careful what he orders. Contempt, said the Government. Aw, whadda you know anyway? said Microsoft. Judge Jackson said he would rule on the contempt charge next week; a three-judge panel will hear Microsoft's appeal of the Dec. 11 order sometime in March.
 
EARNINGS
Scattering the Chips
Go figure. Motorola, the No. 2 chip maker, reports a strong fourth quarter, with profits up a third from a year earlier even after a biggish one-time write-off, but Wall Street expected even better, so the stock slides. A day later, Intel, the Hertz to Motorola's Avis, chalks up a so-so fourth quarter with profits off a touch, but investors are delighted and push up the whole technology sector. The reason may lie in Asia, where Motorola says it's smarting but Intel isn't overly worried. Apple Computer, Sun Microsystems, Digital Equipment and Unisys all reported positive quarters.
 
DEALS
Cleaning Out the Attic
A company once known as an aggressive acquirer announced plans to shed some pieces that don't quite fit anymore. Viacom inherited the Simon & Schuster book publishing businesses when it took over Paramount Communications in 1994. Now Viacom wants to unload all but the trade book division, even though selling so soon may expose the company to a stiff tax hit on the $4 billion to $4.5 billion in expected proceeds. Another formerly busy buyer, Dun & Bradstreet, subdivided into three pieces last year; now one of the pieces, Cognizant, will itself be divided, into Nielsen Media Research and a health care information business.
 
THE TUBE
Fetching a Fortune
Whether on the gridiron or in the trauma ward, mobs of telegenic young adults rushing heroically about wearing similar clothing is what brings in the big television money. The latest rights auctions for pro football broadcasts ended with Fox retaining the National Conference games on Sunday afternoons, CBS outbidding the incumbent NBC for the American Conference, ABC holding onto "Monday Night Football" and ESPN squeezing out TNT to take the whole Sunday night cable package. The league's total take: $2.2 billion a year, about double the current rate. A day later, stung by its football loss and the imminent demise of "Seinfeld," NBC threw about $13 million an episode at Warner Brothers to keep the hospital drama "E.R.," its top-rated series, for another three years; it had been paying only $2 million per.
 
PRICES
Flat-Lining
As with Generalissimo Franco in the old comedy bit, so too with inflation: The latest bulletins say it is still dead. The Labor Department reported that consumer prices crept up a paltry one-tenth of 1 percent in December and 1.7 percent in all of 1997, a snail's pace not witnessed since 1986. Leave out the volatile food and energy components, and the last time prices were this flat, John Glenn was an astronaut.
(Hmmm . . .) Omens were mixed: According to separate Government reports, the cost of imports fell sharply in December, signaling little chance that inflation will revive next year and adding ectoplasm to the specter of possible deflation, but retail sales made a strong showing in the month, signaling the opposite.
 
MARKETS
Easy Terms
Stock markets have no monopoly on exuberance. Treasury bond yields plumbed some historic lows at midweek before ratcheting up slightly by Friday, especially on the longer maturities, as investors looked for safety and predictable returns in an earnings season made puzzling by the spotty effects of Asian economic turmoil. Analysts say home mortgage rates, which most lenders peg to Treasury yields, are now low enough to spur a new wave of refinancings. Article, page 8.
 
GEEKS WANTED
Short Supply
Never mind medicine, law or pro sports, kids. If you can sling code, you can work anywhere. Demand for computer programmers is far outstripping the supply of new computer science graduates each year, pushing companies to desperate measures to find and keep the talent they need. Recruiters are cold-calling every phone extension at rival software companies, chasing new graduates with distantly related degrees in math or engineering and flying in programmers from overseas to fill the cubicles. Hardest to find are people with a clue about how to fix the year 2000 problem, since it entails conversance with obsolete programming languages and a willingness to fill long days with mind-numbing detail work. The Federal Aviation Administration is among those struggling to tame the problem in time: I.B.M. says the old 3083 mainframes handling some crucial air traffic control tasks won't be safe to use after Dec. 31, 1999.

HEADLINE: Pope and Castro Set a Visit to Befit Gambling Men

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: ROME, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Most papal trips -- and Pope John Paul II so far has made 80 outside Italy -- are choreographed, scripted and ultimately predictable. But there are others that for both the Pope and his hosts, are a historical roll of the dice, with consequences no one can foresee.
John Paul's 1979 trip to his native Poland was one such gamble. Another will be next week, when the 77-year-old Pope travels to Cuba to be greeted by Fidel Castro, the 71-year-old Communist revolutionary who has finally decided to risk letting the leader of the Roman Catholic Church into his isolated island nation.
The encounter of those two aging but vital leaders, representing powerful and conflicting world views, is sure to be one of those snapshots that will lurch history forward, no matter what they say to each other when they meet Thursday afternoon in the Palace of the Revolution in Havana.
The Pope's trip, which will be covered by some 3,000 journalists from all over the world, has already brought more attention to Cuba than most other events since the Castro revolution of 1959. That in itself means a lot to Mr. Castro, who is clearly looking to the Pope to rescue him from the pariah status imposed by the United States. During the five-day trip, the Pope, a consistent critic of the use of economic sanctions as a political weapon, is sure to add his voice again to the world's almost unanimous opposition to the American embargo of Cuba.
But beyond the impact of the images, some of which are sure to be stunning, few experts know what to predict.
"My impression after being there is that no one really knows anything," said Msgr. Lorenzo Albacete, a Puerto Rican-born instructor at St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers, who just returned from a visit to Cuba. "I talked to a lot of people -- in the church and in the Government -- and everyone is walking around without a clear idea of what they are about to get into."
Even the Pope's health is again an issue of suspense, despite the Vatican's reassuring statements. Pope John Paul, who is believed to suffer from a form of Parkinson's disease, appeared close to collapse on Jan. 11 during a baptism ceremony in the Sistine Chapel.
But few who know the Pope doubt that he at least knows what he wants as he travels to Cuba on Wednesday.
According to Tad Szulc, a journalist and author who has often met with both leaders, the Pope's "basic concept is that something has to be done to allow a peaceful evolution, or a transition in Cuba which will happen sooner or later, whether because of biology or pressure." Mr. Szulc added: "The Pope has enough sense not to go to Cuba for the hell of it. I think he has reason to believe that Castro is ready to enter into a deal."
For Mr. Castro, who has until now been able to stamp out any dissent in Cuba, there is a risk in allowing another leader to share his stage.
"What is going to happen," Monsignor Albacete said, "is a space opening in a society that has never opened before, to an outsider with a comprehensive and strong world view different from the one that has controlled every public space in Cuba for 38 years. It will be like someone coming from Mars."
For the Vatican, there is a risk that the concessions Mr. Castro makes to his visitor and the Catholic Church will be only cosmetic, but still flashy enough to impress world opinion -- like last month's one-time-only Christmas holiday or the recent televised address by Jaime Cardinal Ortega of Havana.
If there are high expectations that the visit will bring lasting change to Mr. Castro's single-party state, they come in large part from the Pope's own track record. His trip to Poland in 1979 was a key episode in a chain of events that, 10 years later, brought about the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe. In other countries with repressive governments, the Pope's visit has prodded the local authorities into making concessions.
As the sole authority for Christianity's largest church, the Pope brings to any visit an institutional weight unrivaled among religious leaders. But there is also the personality and charisma of this Pope, who after 19 years on the throne of St. Peter has become a world-class master of the media and a formidable diplomat.
In meetings with those who might be considered his adversaries, the Pope has typically succeeded in inspiring respect -- even awe -- and establishing trust. Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski of Poland recalled in his book that as the last Communist Prime Minister in 1983, he was moved "beyond all reason" when he met the Pope. "For me, it was a deep personal experience," he said.
In his memoirs, the last Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, described being struck, at his first private audience with John Paul in December 1989, by how similar some of their views were.
"This means we must also have something common 'at the source' in our ideas," Mr. Gorbachev said he told the anti-Communist Pope.
Even Mr. Castro, whose faith in Communism remains unshaken, left his first meeting with the Pope at the Vatican last year sounding more like the Catholic schoolboy he had once been than the atheist revolutionary he became.
"For me, it is a miracle I was able to meet the Pope," he told reporters after his half-hour private conservation in the Vatican in November 1996.
And yet Cuba, one of the last Communist states left in the world, may prove too much even for the Pope's artful lobbying or his public appeal. Cuba is not Poland. Its Catholicism is not so deep, or so interwoven with national identity. Nor is the Pope Cuban, which means he does not bring with him the intense personal and patriotic commitment that is on display during his Polish trips.
And to Cuban exiles like Zoe Valdes, a 35-year-old novelist who lives in Paris, there is the danger that any positive effects of the visit will be whittled away by the Government.
"Internationally," she said, "there will be people who will find things have changed. But within Cuba there will still be repression."
For the Vatican, one goal for the trip is intensely parochial, to gain solid ground for the church in Cuba as it emerges from a long period of marginalization. "The main concern of the church is to obtain some kind of legal existence," Monsignor Albacete said. "Everything else is a hope."
The Cuban people's reaction to the Pope's presence among them is one of the greatest unknowns. Monsignor Albacete said he was struck by people's profound ignorance about the church and the Pope himself.
"Bishops told me that when they walk the streets of Havana, people come up to them and ask them if they are the Pope," he said.
Ms. Valdes said that although many Cubans might be ready to hear the Pope's message, the question would be its meaning to them, given Cuba's dire economic situation.
"This may shake people up -- it might make them think," she said. "But there are a lot of people in Cuba who, given a choice between thinking and finding food for their families, will choose to focus on food."
 
Castro Praises Pope
 HAVANA, Jan. 17 (Reuters) -- President Castro issued a warm welcome for Pope John Paul today, describing him as a man of talent and intelligence and "a historic figure of our epoch."
 In a six-hour speech on state television that began Friday evening and stretched into today, the Cuban leader heaped praise on the Pope, who arrives on Wednesday. He urged Cubans to fill public squares for the four outdoor Masses that the pope will preside over and insisted that the Pope has much in common with the Cuban Government's thinking in terms of condemning the world's social injustices.
 "He's done all his criticisms of Communism," he said. "Now he's criticizing capitalism."

LENGTH: 1910 words

HEADLINE: Sudden Weakness Aside, Suharto Looks to Outlast Economic Crisis

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Jan. 17

 BODY:
For 32 years, Asia's longest-serving leader, President Suharto of Indonesia, has bent this sprawling, fractious and astoundingly diverse nation to his will.
While he has sometimes been questioned, his control has never been seriously challenged. He has never hesitated to use force, favoritism or political manipulation. But in the last decade, it has been Indonesia's remarkable prosperity -- built partly on a cascade of foreign investment -- that has cemented his control. 
 Suddenly in the last few months this longtime military commander and genius of political survival has encountered a force beyond his control: the world financial markets, which in a stroke have brought his country's currency and its $225 billion economy to the brink of collapse.
"This is something he cannot shoot, he cannot put in jail, he cannot close down like our newspaper," said Jusuf Wanandi, director of the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a leading Indonesian policy institute.
On Thursday, under pressure from the markets and leaders around the world, Mr. Suharto appeared to capitulate. He signed a document allowing the International Monetary Fund to direct minute details of his country's daily life, from the price of gasoline to the marketing of plywood and cloves. And he agreed, on paper at least, to break up the cartels that have made his family and loyalists millionaires.
Sensing his sudden weakness, longtime opponents of Mr. Suharto, who is 76, have boldly called for him to step down. Even some of the country's elite have gently suggested that after so many years he should not have to endure the "burden" of guiding the country through a painful economic recovery.
For the United States, the simultaneous emergence of an economic crisis and significant political opposition to Mr. Suharto's continued rule poses a major diplomatic challenge. To quiet the markets -- and keep Indonesia's problems from worsening the rest of Asia's -- Washington is looking for stability. Any suggestion that the world's fourth-most-populous nation, and the biggest military power among Southeast Asian nations, might fall into political chaos would undo Washington's efforts to contain the Asian financial crisis.
At the same time, the United States has been pressing for years for a more open political system in Indonesia, one that would inevitably challenge Mr. Suharto's one-man rule. So all week long here, American officials visiting Jakarta have been performing a delicate pirouette, trying to endorse Mr. Suharto's new commitment to market economics, without seeming to prop up Mr. Suharto himself.
 
Market Economics And State Control
But while Mr. Suharto's future seems suddenly in play, it is far from sure that Indonesia's economic crisis marks the beginning of the end of his long rule. He has placed himself at the center of the I.M.F.'s new restructuring program, and he has been widely expected to seek and receive parliamentary approval two months from now for a seventh term.
"Washington is concerned about supporting Indonesia," a senior United States official said after a week of intensive contacts with Mr. Suharto that included two long telephone calls between the Indonesian leader and President Clinton. "And Suharto just happens to be the leader of Indonesia at the moment."
One of the many mysteries in this chaotic capital is whether Mr. Suharto is truly committed to a radical restructuring of the country's economy, as he says, or whether he is simply uttering the phrases that the markets want to hear.
It is a sign of the new mood here that one of the country's leading newspapers, The Jakarta Post, warned on Friday that the Suharto Government might again defy I.M.F. strictures that loosen its control.
"The risk of a recurrence of corruption, collusion and market distortions is indeed quite big," the newspaper said, "with the children and close relatives of so many top officials, provincial leaders, high military officers and retired generals quite active in business."
The newspaper issued a direct challenge to Mr. Suharto almost unheard of in past years: "The writing is already on the wall: reform now or collapse."
Since Mr. Suharto took over from the nation's founder, Sukarno, in a violent transition that is estimated to have killed half-a-million people, he has managed the economy the way he has managed the country: by presidential decree. Huge projects, from dams to power plants, needed presidential blessing -- and often a partner with close ties to the President. But Mr. Suharto always understood that without foreign trade, relatively liberal investment rules to attract foreigners, and a sharing of the nation's wealth, his command could be imperiled.
Exploiting high oil prices in the 1970's and early 80's, he used the country's huge oil and gas revenue to help pull the nation up from poverty. For the first time, almost all Indonesian children went to elementary school, and by the mid-1980's the country grew enough rice that it no longer had to import it and other staple foods.
 
Crisis and Images Of I.M.F. Domination
But there was still an uneasy blend of market economics, favoritism for Suharto cronies, and state control over key industries. Price supports for key products kept farmers happy, and fuel was subsidized for everyone. Unions have been repressed, but minimum wages have risen regularly to keep the peace -- perhaps too regularly for some economists, undercutting some of the country's competitive advantage.
"The astounding thing," one banker who has lived here for years said this week, "is that he kept the juggling act up for so long. But he understood that rising incomes was part of his political insurance policy."
By the mid-1990's, though, foreign investment began pouring into Indonesia so fast that it was no longer wisely managed. The country's borrowings soared, and banks proliferated -- most of them virtually unregulated. The World Bank, in a generally upbeat study in May 1997, warned that the property market -- especially in Jakarta, where the skyline is filled with half-completed office towers -- was out of control, and that "a reversal could hit Indonesia's still-weak banking sector and be the trigger for an economic downturn."
That is exactly what happened. Thailand's economic collapse led investors around the world to reassess the risks in Indonesia. Soon, the money reversed direction, and the currency crashed. Mr. Suharto turned to the I.M.F. in October for a bailout package worth more than $40 billion, including a $3 billion pledge from the United States. But he did little to enforce its terms, and when he introduced a budget this month that seemed to ignore some of the fund's economic targets, the markets responded with wrath.
With the currency, the rupiah, down 70 percent since last summer, companies with collective overseas debts of at least $65 billion have simply stopped making payments. The new I.M.F. plan does nothing to restructure that debt, which is one reason the currency is still falling.
Today all major economic activity here seems frozen. Exporters cannot borrow the letters of credit they need to get raw materials from abroad. So factories are slowing down. Even the state-owned airline, Garuda, doesn't have the cash to make lease payments on its fleet. A country that counted on 7 percent annual growth now will be lucky if its economy does not shrink. And the social cushion that growth created -- already under strain because of unemployment and a widening income gap -- is eroding as capital leaves the country.
"Everything has collapsed," a 27-year-old advertising worker who identified himself only by his first name, Doli, at a McDonald's in Jakarta. "Up until recently, everyone said that the "fundamentals" of the Indonesian economy were strong," he said, dismissing that thought with a quick epithet.
But Doli's anger was directed primarily at Michel Camdessus, the director general of the I.M.F.
Pointing to a newspaper photo of Mr. Camdessus, arms folded and standing over Mr. Suharto during the signing on Thursday, he said: "That picture says it all. Maybe in the West its O.K. to stand that way, but for us, it's an act of intimidation. That photo tells us that Indonesia is under the thumb of the I.M.F."
Indonesians say it is not "people power" that threatens Mr. Suharto's authority, but "shopping power."
As long as there were more motorbikes in the villages and more cars in the cities, popular discontent was rarely more than an irritant to the President. But the prospect of 20 percent inflation, the end of subsidies, and possible food shortages has set off panic buying and rioting.
Muslim leaders -- Indonesia has more Muslims than any other country -- retired generals and former ministers have joined the calls for a Presidential transition.
 
Scarier Fate: Suharto, Or His Replacement?
The problem is that many people are as worried about a future without Mr. Suharto as they are about a future under his continued rule.
"If Suharto is out, people say, 'Good, we'll have a change,' " said Meri Pengistu, a leading economist. "But we don't know what we're going to get in his place. That's what's so scary."
Mr. Suharto has assured that no potential successor will emerge from his shadow, shuffling vice presidents over the years, and declining to anoint younger politicians.
Whenever the opposition has become too vocal, it has been quashed. Last year, when Megawati Sukarnoputri began to draw large crowds as the leader of one of the two sanctioned non-governmental parties, the Government engineered her ouster from her party, making her ineligible to stand for the Presidency.
A People's Consultative Assembly is to meet in March when Mr. Suharto's sixth five-year term ends. He is expected to choose to stay on, and the assembly is expected to agree. In five previous elections, he has been the sole candidate of all three government-sanctioned parties.
But with Mr. Suharto's health, longevity and political power in question, there is new attention to his choice for vice president -- his potential successor. When the transition finally comes, the next leader will almost certainly be drawn from within the existing power structure, probably from the military, which still dominates Indonesia's politics.
The list of names shifts over time, gauged by the smiles or favors or golfing afternoons shared with the President. Now a new calculus has emerged to chart their popularity: the possible reactions on the fluctuating currency markets.
"If it is Habibi," said a political scientist, naming a businessman and Minister of Technology who is a leading contender in the vice presidential sweepstakes, "the rupiah will fall to 10,000," from its current level of about 8,500 to the dollar. "If it is Hartono," the Information Minister, "it will be 15,000. If it is Harmoko it will be 20,000," he said of the Speaker of the House.
"And if it is Tutut," he concluded, using the nickname of Suharto's powerful eldest daughter, Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana, "all the way down to 30,000."
In the end, there is not likely to be a true successor to Mr. Suharto. Whoever follows him will not come close to dominating every corner of the nation's life as Mr. Suharto has for three decades. The politics of Indonesia makes that highly unlikely; the new dominance of external market forces makes it virtually impossible.

HEADLINE: HUSSEIN DELIVERS A NEW ULTIMATUM ON U.N. INSPECTORS

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 17

 BODY:
President Saddam Hussein threatened today to expel all United Nations arms inspectors from Iraq in six months if his Government is not cleared of suspicions about its weapons programs and if the sanctions that have devastated the country's economy are not lifted.
His threat came in a speech marking the seventh anniversary of the start of the Persian Gulf war. He spoke two days before the chief United Nations arms inspector, Richard Butler, is to arrive in Baghdad for critical talks on a new standoff over weapons inspections. 
 Iraq has claimed regularly since 1991 that it has accounted for all its weapons of mass destruction, but evidence found by United Nations inspectors has shown otherwise time and again.
The United States and some other nations fear that Iraq may still have biological and chemical weapons. If inspections are not completed in six months, and Mr. Hussein carries through on his threat to end them then, the Clinton Administration will be under tremendous pressure to act, even though military attacks would be unpopular in many capitals, especially in the Middle East.
In his speech, which lasted nearly an hour, Mr. Hussein quoted the Koran and Old Testament prophets recognized by Muslims to portray himself as the fearless defender of Arabs and all poor nations against the "American tyrant." He said the Iraqi people and their leaders were "determined to launch a great jihad" -- a holy war -- to get the sanctions lifted.
But he also made a plea for a new approach to the impasse with the United Nations. He renewed calls for talks to circumvent the United States, which has held out for the strictest Iraqi accountability. He said that since the "American" disarmament plan had failed, other avenues should be tried.
Mr. Hussein couched his threat in an endorsement of a November recommendation by the Iraqi National Assembly that Iraq cease cooperating with the inspections ordered by the Security Council as part of the 1991 cease-fire. The recommendation is now before the Revolutionary Command Council, the highest-ranking Government body in Iraq.
The day began with the wailing of air-raid sirens as a reminder of the start of the Persian Gulf war in 1991. Mr. Hussein said he was aiming his speech, shown on tape on television this morning, to a new generation of Iraqis, "who may still have to shed blood and be martyrs." He seamlessly rewrote the history of Jan. 17, 1991, by leaving out what had caused the war: his army's occupation of Kuwait five months earlier.
"On that day at 2:30 in the morning," he said, "the Americans invaded. Bombs and rockets fell on Baghdad." Iraq won that war, he said -- still calling it "the mother of all battles" -- because "Iraq refused to comply and surrender."
Mr. Hussein hurled epithets at the United States, calling Washington at various points "neo-imperialist," "flesh-mongering" and "leprous." The speech was simultaneously interpreted in English for the benefit of international television networks.
"The United States is full of treachery against all nations and all people," Mr. Hussein said, adding a warning to Latin Americans and Southeast Asians that their financial problems are a manifestation of the American conspiracy to "rule all four corners of the world."
In this very personalized Government, officials seemed to have little or no advance knowledge of the President's remarks. On Friday night, some did not know exactly when the speech would be delivered, and learned the time from network television crews gathered here to await Mr. Butler's arrival Monday.
Mr. Butler is expected to press the Iraqis for access to forbidden sites and to discuss Baghdad's repeated charges that the arms inspection teams have too many Americans.
This week, one group of experts could not carry out its full list of inspections because Iraq objected to the presence of the team leader, Scott Ritter, an American, and to the relatively large number of Americans in the group. The team left on Friday, a day ahead of schedule.
Other teams looking for evidence of biological, chemical and nuclear weapons as well as violations of import-export controls have been able to continue their work.
This round of inspections resumed after a crisis in the fall, when Mr. Hussein expelled American inspectors, and the United Nations withdrew the rest of the teams until Iraq agreed to everyone's return.
After the speech today, Mr. Butler is likely to add to his agenda the issue of a time frame for completing inspections, Iraqi and United Nations officials say. Mr. Butler was in Bahrain today on the way to Baghdad, where he has meetings scheduled for Monday and Tuesday.
American and other officials have for years blamed Iraq for their delays in declaring it free of weapons of mass destruction -- biological, chemical and nuclear, as well as prohibited long-range missile systems. They say Baghdad first lied about its arsenal, then tried to conceal it when investigators began to accumulate evidence.
Lately, the Iraqis have been putting many suspect sites off-limits, even though this has further stalled efforts to complete the investigation.
Iraq began that crisis by invading Kuwait on Aug. 2, 1990, a day after talks failed to resolve the two countries' disputes. These involved their common border, Iraqi debts to Kuwait and Iraqi accusations that Kuwait was pumping more oil than allowed under agreements in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
Four days later, the United Nations Security Council imposed an embargo on commerce with Iraq, but it allowed the Iraqis to continue buying medical supplies and food.
The American-led war that finally pushed Iraq from Kuwait -- with the participation of troops from 30 countries -- did not begin until more than five months later, after high-level diplomatic missions had failed to persuade Mr. Hussein to withdraw.
The war began with an air campaign against Iraq, and the ground offensive that freed Kuwait followed on Feb. 23. President Bush declared victory on Feb. 28, and on March 3 Iraq agreed to a cease-fire on American terms.
A month later, the Security Council formally set the requirements to be met by Iraq. Foremost among them was the agreement to eliminate weapons of mass destruction in exchange for the lifting of the economic sanctions imposed in 1990. Both Baghdad and the United Nations Special Commission created to disarm Iraq expected the process to last only a few months.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Envoy's Rebuttal
 WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (Reuters) -- Bill Richardson, the United States representative at the United Nations, said today that there was no chance of sanctions' being lifted unless Mr. Hussein allowed unfettered access to weapons sites. Mr. Richardson told CBS television that the Iraqi President was "dreaming" if he thought sanctions would be removed before Iraq complied with all Security Council resolutions and allowed "full and unfettered access to all sites of weapons of mass destruction."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Why Cubs Got Beck For a Bargain Price

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
In a world of ever-escalating salaries, Rod Beck may as well apply for welfare. Beck will pitch for the Chicago Cubs next season for $3.5 million, only $250,000 more than his 1997 wages.
Not that Beck needs any sympathy at that rate, but his experience as a free agent was not what top-flight closers have come to expect. It raised more questions than anything else, the primary one being why, with closers moving hither and yon in a game of musical relief pitchers, did Beck settle for a one-year contract with a relatively meager salary? 
 "It ended up being one of those things where teams that could afford a closer didn't really need one and teams that needed a closer couldn't afford one," said Rick Thurman, Beck's agent.
But Beck's status, economically and geographically, might have been different if the Cleveland Indians had done what Thurman said they told him they were going to do.
"We feel like we had been misled by Hart," Thurman said.
He referred to John Hart, the Indians' general manager. Hart was out of town and not available for comment, his secretary said.
"John and I spent all day Christmas, from 6 in the morning until 11 at night, working on a deal," Thurman said. "We finished it, but it was contingent upon them moving Mesa. Hart claimed he knew that he had two deals he could consummate within 24 to 48 hours."
Jose Mesa has been the Indians' closer the past three seasons. Last year, though, he began the season on trial on rape charges -- he was acquitted -- and ended it by squandering a 2-1 lead in the seventh game of the World Series. The Indians, who began talking with Thurman well before Christmas, clearly had thoughts of making a change.
"We had a deal that was a little over $12 million for three years with an option for a fourth year," Thurman said. "The total package with very makable incentives was worth about $20 million over four years."
But, the agent said, no deal for Mesa was forthcoming. Hart had been negotiating with the Cubs and the Colorado Rockies, but nothing definitive developed. More than 72 hours later, the following Monday, Thurman said, he had a message on his voice mail from Dan O'Dowd, Hart's assistant, saying "they were having a hard time moving Mesa."
"We tried to get hold of Hart for quite a while," Thurman said, but the Indians' general manager did not call back immediately. "When he did, about a week later," Thurman said, "he told us the deals he thought he had out there weren't there. The deals just never happened. He wasn't as close as he said."
That episode was the final blow for Beck. One of the most effective closers of the past five years, the 29-year-old right-hander felt the first sting when the Giants acquired Roberto Hernandez, another established closer, from the Chicago White Sox last July 31.
"At that point we needed every able arm we could get," Brian Sabean, the Giants' general manager, said, explaining the deal. But he also said, "Rod had had his ups and downs."
Beck, who earned 37 saves in 45 opportunities, felt burned again after the season when the Giants offered him less than $4 million a year for two years.
"Quite frankly," Sabean said, "it was dismissed out of hand. He wanted more years for a lot of money." Thurman called it "a token offer."
In the last five years, Beck has earned 181 saves. Only Randy Myers (188) and Dennis Eckersley (186) have more. But Beck has raised concerns in some baseball quarters with his increasing size and his decreasing velocity. No longer able to throw the ball past hitters, he relies more on finesse. Managers and general managers are often suspicious of closers whose ability is finesse, not speed.
But the Giants were nevertheless prepared to retain Beck, unless they made him an offer they knew he could refuse.
His weight (listed at 236 but heavier)?
"That was never really a concern for us," Sabean said, "because he was so durable. He never had arm troubles. It never got in the way of his pitching."
His velocity (down to 88 to 89 miles an hour from 94)?
"It's not uncommon for someone who has pitched as much as he has," Sabean said. "He has control and savvy and the ability to get hitters out."
But when the Giants traded for Hernandez, it created doubt in at least some baseball minds and very likely scared off some potential suitors.
The Cubs needed an established closer and got one without overpaying, or even paying the going rate. The Toronto Blue Jays gave Myers $18 million for three years. The Tampa Bay Devil Rays lured Hernandez for $22.5 million over four years. The Giants, who did not want to bid against the Devil Rays for Hernandez, traded for Robb Nen and will pay him $14.5 million over the next three years.
Beck and the Cubs have a mutual option for a second season at a $5.5 million salary, but he can leave after the 1998 season. "By taking a one-year deal with Chicago," Thurman said, "we allowed ourselves the flexibility to be a free agent next year, and if he stays, he'll be paid the market rate."
 
A Partnership Splits
 Tony La Russa and Dennis Eckersley have worked for the same team for the past 10 years and in the same city for the past 13. Now, as the 43-year-old Eckersley pitches himself closer to retirement, they will be separated by teams, cities and leagues. Eckersley has opted to play in his backyard with the Boston Red Sox.
"It was totally his decision," said La Russa, the St. Louis Cardinals manager. "When the season was nearing an end, we made it clear we would be interested in having him back. It's been the same situation the last three, four years with me and Eck. We talk, kind of gauge to see if he's lost his appetite to work out and compete. He let us know he wanted to pitch in '98, but it was obvious that the two years in St. Louis, where his family wasn't with him at all, were very difficult. When the season was over, he said it was very difficult. If there was interest in Boston, it would make sense for him."
Eckersley, No. 2 in career saves behind Lee Smith, has earned 386 of his 389 saves for La Russa, who altered his career in 1987 by converting him into a reliever in Oakland. Eckersley had three saves for Cleveland in his first two seasons in the major leagues when he occasionally relieved.
Is La Russa ready for life without Eck? "That thought has crossed my mind a lot of times," the manager said. "I've had good fortune to have that lead and push the Eckersley button. I've never taken it for granted. It shakes me up some not to have him."
 
Playoff Changes Possible
 The widespread criticism of the playoff format has been heard. The executive council has acted to make two significant changes in the system. Approval by owners and players will enable them to be put into effect next October.
Change one: Instead of predetermining which division champions will play each other and which will play the wild-card team, the three division winners will be ranked by won-lost record. The team with the best record will play the wild-card team unless the two are in the same division. If they are, the team with the best record will play the first-place team with the worst of the three records.
Change two: Instead of a 2-3 split in the first-round schedule, the team with the better record in one pairing and the division champion in the other will play the first two games and the fifth game at home. In the league championship series, the team with the better record will get Games 1, 2 , 6 and 7, unless it's the wild-card entry.
If this format had been in effect last October, the first-round National League pairings would have been the same, Atlanta and Houston, San Francisco and Florida. The Braves would also have had the first two home games, just as they did in their three-game sweep. The other series would have started in San Francisco instead of Florida, meaning the Marlins would have to have won the first two games on the road to duplicate their three-game sweep.
The league series would have been scheduled exactly as it was.
The American League pairings, on the other hand, would have been switched, the Yankees playing Seattle and Baltimore playing Cleveland. The wild-card Yankees would have had to play the first two games in Seattle, which the Orioles did, winning both.

HEADLINE: Tax Credit for Natural-Gas Fuel Could Mean Cleaner Air for South Bronx

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

 BODY:
More than 10,000 trucks make deliveries every day in the industrial South Bronx, their exhaust fumes contributing to some of the most polluted air in the city. It is a neighborhood where rates of asthma and other respiratory illnesses are the worst in the city, but residents' complaints have long taken a back seat to the area's economic desperation. Any solution that might drive away the trucks, and precious jobs, was no solution at all.
Now, however, legislation enacted in Albany and proposals circulating at city agencies, in the Borough President's office and in Washington, are raising hopes that businesses in the Bronx and throughout the city will soon begin converting hundreds of trucks from diesel and gasoline engines to cleaner-burning compressed natural gas. 
 A little-noticed state law that took effect Jan. 1 provides a powerful economic incentive for companies to convert their fleets to natural gas: a tax credit that would refund 60 percent of the cost of the conversion. The law also addresses the problem of where to refuel the vehicles, since there are only 20 such natural-gas stations in the city and only one in the Bronx. It establishes another tax credit, this one refunding 50 percent of the cost of building a natural-gas fuel station.
Richard Kassel, a senior lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental advocacy group, said the new law vaulted New York from a laggard to one of the most progressive states in encouraging the use of alternative fuels.
"It's one of the best, which makes sense because of the air quality problems here and because of the population density," he said. "And the more incentives that are provided, the more successful it's going to be."
Over the last several years, efforts to promote alternative fuels in New York have produced some natural-gas-powered buses, garbage trucks, postal and utility-company trucks, and, most recently, about 150 taxicabs in a heavily subsidized experiment. Yet finding a commercial truck with a "clean" engine was about as hard as finding a place to refuel it in the five boroughs.
Indeed, movement to natural-gas engines is hobbled by a chicken-and-egg dilemma, experts say: Until many such vehicles are on the roads, it will not make business sense to open filling stations for them, and prices will remain high. But without the widespread availability of fuel, at low prices, few vehicle owners will make the switch.
All of which explains why environmentalists were overjoyed in August when the State Legislature enacted the natural-gas tax credits.
Suddenly, change is afoot.
The gas companies are stepping up their marketing efforts, and local businesses that handle conversions from diesel or gasoline to natural gas say they have begun to get calls from potential customers, instead of the other way around.
Robert Meeker, president of Clean Vehicle Systems of Staten Island, said he was already negotiating with a liquor distributor in the city for an order of 10 new trucks and with a beer distributor for another 20. "We're getting a lot of response from small fleets that are looking to do the right thing," he said.
But others say the new law will not be enough. David Vandor, a Tarrytown consultant to fleet owners, said that even with the tax credits, companies could actually lose money because natural gas is no cheaper than gasoline and is slightly more expensive than diesel fuel. He estimated that a company with about 20 trucks would spend $2,952 a year on diesel fuel, but $3,585 for natural gas.
A number of enticements are being considered by government officials, any one or two of which could tip the scales in favor of natural gas, Mr. Vandor said:
*The New York City Department of Transportation is considering creating "green zones" in lower and midtown Manhattan, where curb parking would be restricted to trucks using alternative fuels. An executive at United Parcel Service, which operates 10 natural gas-powered vans in Manhattan, said U.P.S. would be eager to convert more vans if it meant cutting down on the $1 million in parking tickets it now receives annually in Manhattan.
*E-Z Pass discounts, now under consideration for nighttime truck traffic, could be extended to natural-gas-powered vehicles at any hour.
*Registration fees could be reduced for alternative-fuel vehicles.
*Taxes on sales of natural gas could be reduced or eliminated.
In the South Bronx, meanwhile, politicians well schooled in the health dangers of truck exhaust for their constituents -- the asthma rate is 12 times the national average, for example -- are not waiting for new incentives to materialize. Borough President Fernando Ferrer and Congressman Jose E. Serrano are collaborating on a bill that would add Federal tax credits, on top of the new state incentives, for conversions to natural-gas vehicles by businesses in "empowerment zones." The South Bronx empowerment zone, a Federally designated poor urban area that receives special Federal grants and tax credits, includes the Port Morris Industrial Park and the 24-hour Hunts Point Market, as well as more than a dozen waste-transfer and recycling stations.
The bill being drafted by Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Serrano would extend the tax breaks to out-of-town companies whose trucks make regular trips to and from an empowerment zone.
Carlos Padilla, president of the South Bronx Clean Air Coalition, said the idea presented a delicious irony -- a borough turning the other cheek.
"For so long, the rest of the city has put their dumps over here, whenever it benefited them," he said. "Now, when the hotels and restaurants in Manhattan get their food from Hunts Point, it'll be delivered in cleaner vehicles. The Bronx is doing the rest of the city a favor."

HEADLINE: U.S. IS REVIEWING BAN ON THE SALE OF ARMS TO CHINA

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 17

 BODY:
On the eve of his trip to Asia this week, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen pressed the Clinton Administration to let an American arms maker sell spare parts to China, despite a ban on sales of military equipment imposed after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989, Administration officials say.
Mr. Cohen did not advocate a general lifting of the sanctions, the officials said, but rather suggested making an exception in the case of Sikorsky Aircraft of Stratford, Conn., the maker of Black Hawk helicopters. 
 Sikorsky, which sold 24 unarmed Black Hawks to China's military in 1984, has been lobbying the Administration to allow it to sell China replacement engines and other parts, arguing that these should no longer be considered military equipment prohibited by the Tiananmen sanctions.
In internal discussions leading up to Mr. Cohen's three-and-a-half-day visit here, which began this evening, the Administration rejected the idea as premature, and Mr. Cohen agreed to support that decision, the officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The officials said, though, that the Administration was considering ways to improve relations with China, and that easing the sanctions was among them. That raised the prospect that at least some of the sanctions could be lifted, possibly in time for President Clinton's visit to China later this year, although officials emphasized that no decisions had been reached.
One official said a decision at this time to lift, even slightly, the sanctions on any equipment that would be used by the Chinese Army would provoke too great an outcry on Capitol Hill and elsewhere, and overshadow whatever benefits the United States received in exchange.
"That's a whole lot of heat to take for some spare parts," the official said.
Mr. Cohen declined through his spokesman, Kenneth H. Bacon, to talk about his discussion of the sanctions, saying the Administration's internal deliberations should remain private.
In an interview with reporters during his 12-day tour of Asia, Mr. Cohen said China had to do more to improve human rights, among other things, before the United States could lift any sanctions. But he also made it clear that the sanctions, now nearly a decade old, would not go on indefinitely.
Asked about the possibility of lifting them, he said, "Sometime in the future it may be possible, but I don't foresee it at this particular time."
Nonetheless, Mr. Cohen's willingness to consider an exception to the sanctions underscored the extent to which he is prepared to find ways to improve relations with China in general and its military in particular.
During his visit here, which will include meetings with senior Chinese military leaders and President Jiang Zemin, Mr. Cohen hopes to take steps to increase contacts and build confidence between the American and Chinese militaries.
On Monday, he and China's Minister of Defense, Chi Haotian, are scheduled to sign a document called the Military Maritime Consultation Agreement. The agreement -- essentially a set of rules governing contacts between the countries' navies -- is meant to avoid unintended clashes on the open seas.
Earlier this week, Mr. Chi said exchanges of military officers, among other steps, were already easing tensions, according to the official newspaper China Daily. Those tensions reached a fever pitch when China held provocative military exercises in the Taiwan Strait in March 1996 and the United States responded by sending two aircraft carriers to the region.
There are already signs of improvements. On Friday, an American C-17 cargo plane from Japan flew into Beijing carrying 40 tons of clothing, medicine and other relief supplies for victims of the earthquake that killed 50 people and left thousands without homes in northern Hebei Province, north of Beijing.
Mr. Cohen's visit to China is part of the Administration's efforts to improve relations between the countries. Mr. Cohen is the first Cabinet member to visit Beijing since Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang met in Washington in October.
While Administration officials describe a gradual improvement in relations, profound differences remain, and one of the greatest, as far as the Chinese are concerned, is the sanctions.
After the Tiananmen massacre, the Bush Administration imposed an array of sanctions on China, prohibiting investments and trade with its Communist Government, although commercial activity continued. Congress enacted many of the sanctions into law.
The massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators interrupted what had been a small but growing trade in military equipment. Through the 1980's, the United States had, largely in secret, exchanged equipment and intelligence with China as a counterbalance to the Soviet Union.
Sikorsky's sale of 24 of the Army's S-70C Black Hawk helicopters in 1984 was China's first major purchase of American military hardware. Before being delivered to China, the helicopters were stripped of their weaponry, though they were still classified as military equipment because of their advanced motors and avionics, which were made by General Electric.
At the time, the sale totaled $150 million, including spare parts and technical training. Now, nearly 14 years later, the helicopters need repair, and both the Chinese Government and Sikorsky, which is owned by United Technologies Corporation, have been lobbying the Administration to waive the Tiananmen sanctions enough to allow spare parts to go through.
"Spare parts are vital to the operation of any fleet of vehicles," said a spokesman for Sikorsky, William Tuttle. Mr. Tuttle said that with advances in technology since the helicopters were purchased, the replacement engines and other parts needed for the Black Hawks were no longer considered military hardware, even though they are still covered by the sanctions. He declined to discuss the costs of the equipment.
Sikorsky's case had received support in the Pentagon and in Congress, particularly, Mr. Tuttle said, from Connecticut lawmakers like Representative James H. Maloney of the Fifth District and Senator Christopher J. Dodd, both Democrats.
Sikorsky's case also received a hearing from Mr. Cohen. "He was in the 'Gee, isn't there something we can do about this' camp," one Administration official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Under the law, Mr. Clinton could authorize a waiver allowing the sale to go forward without lifting the sanctions generally.
A senior official said the matter remained under review, but added that it was more likely that the Administration would first consider lifting other sanctions, like those on underwriting American companies or enhancing economic development.
The official said Sikorsky's case, like others involving trade with Chinese companies, many of which are state-owned, would almost certainly provoke a firestorm. All the more so since the helicopters are used by China's Army, offically called the People's Liberation Army, although primarily for transport and search-and-rescue missions, the official said.
"It's really a domestic political issue," the senior official said. "How would we answer the critics who say we're arming the P.L.A.?"
A major part of Mr. Cohen's visit will be devoted to finding ways to increase cooperation with China's military, which remains wary of the United States' presence in the region, particularly American support for Taiwan.
"I think we have to take out relationship step by step and not rush it," Mr. Cohen said in an interview today.

HEADLINE: Montana Has Mountains Like Switzerland and Wants Numbered Accounts

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: BILLINGS, Mont.

 BODY:
When people think of Montana, what comes to mind are trophy trout, no daytime speed limit and the occasional mountain hermit. That is all well and good, but state officials would like to project something entirely new: the last best place for rich foreigners to hide their money.
In December, Montana completed regulations on a new law that makes it the first state to open its doors as an offshore banking haven, allowing special depositories for wealthy overseas clients seeking privacy and protection for their money. 
 And from Roundup to Big Timber, hard-luck towns are now dreaming of getting a piece of the action that they hope will make Montana the Switzerland of the Rockies or the Grand Cayman of the North.
Skeptics say it is a pie-in-the-Big-Sky idea, one that will attract more laundering of overseas drug and mob money than it will generate in clean currency. But the optimists in the state capital Helena say the new law could eventually earn enough money to replace all state taxes.
Just as states not long ago crossed the once forbidden line of getting revenue from assorted games of chance, what Montana is trying might simply be the next logical step for tax-phobic state legislators.
Some state lawmakers call it the ideal tax, one paid by somebody other than residents and voters. The state would get its revenue from a fee paid by people for the privilege of hiding their money. And though it sounds to critics like a naive reach for easy money, Montana officials say they have not just fallen off the global currency turnip truck. They spent two years studying the issue and are convinced it is a potential revenue gusher.
"There's never been anything like this in North America," said State Senator Mike Sprague, a Republican who sponsored the bill that was passed overwhelmingly by the state's Republican-dominated Legislature and signed into law last fall.
"There is about $3 trillion in money in these kinds of accounts, mostly in Switzerland or the Grand Caymans," Mr. Sprague said. "You figure if we could only get a fraction of that amount, say $75 billion, and from that generate a billion dollars in fees -- that would take care of the entire state share of the budget."
Whether depositors would actually choose to hide their money in Hungry Horse instead of St. Moritz is another question. "People have been calling," Mr. Sprague said, "and not all of them think we're nuts."
The State Commerce Department, which is helping to set up the depositories and would screen and regulate them, said there had been at least 70 inquiries from people wishing to be chartered to accept the overseas accounts. More than 30 potential depositors have also expressed interest, the department said.
"A man called just the other day and asked where he could send his $30 million check," said Vivian Manuel, a spokeswoman for the department. Thus far, there is no place to stash money, gold or stock certificates in the state. But state officials expect to begin chartering institutions or individuals soon.
The rules are fairly simple. Depositors cannot be United States citizens or convicted felons. They must deposit at least $200,000.
In turn, Montana promises a measure of privacy found in no other state -- based on language in the State Constitution -- and the political stability of the United States. International treaties would still apply, of course, so Montana's status as a tax haven would be limited. Still, Montana officials say interest is high because there are so few options for safe sanctuaries.
"We've got the most stable political environment in the world, the most stable currency and, in this state, the strictest privacy and confidentiality laws," said Peter Blouke, director of the State Department of Commerce.
His department's projections for state revenue, about $12 million a year, are much more modest than those expressed by Mr. Sprague. The money would come from a 1.5 percent fee for every depositor. Mr. Blouke shares the view of political leaders here that the state has something to offer that more traditional money hideaways do not.
"We have a very small bureaucracy," he said.
But Federal officials worry about criminal money making its way into the state. And given that the staff in Helena is small and inexperienced in regulating international money, Federal officials say the state will be no match for people who are wise to the ways of hiding tainted money. They also say there is an inherent conflict of interest in having one small state bureaucracy both promote and regulate the depositories.
"The whole thrust of banking in recent years is to know your customer," said Raymond W. Kelly, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for Enforcement. "Well, it's very hard to know your customers in these kinds of offshore arrangements."
The Federal Government, Mr. Kelly said, has little regulatory oversight of Montana's new depositories, beyond the requirement that cash in excess of $10,000 brought into the country must be reported.
Many questions remain unanswered about Montana's venture into offshore banking, Mr. Kelly said, including concerns about people fleeing taxes, liens or fines in other countries. "We're going to be watching this very carefully," he said.
But state officials are not worried. They envision investors from Asia fleeing the uncertainty and financial collapse of recent months and dumping their assets in Montana.
"We would become one option for people who need a portion of their assets to be totally secure and always available," Mr. Blouke said.
With a stagnant population and a somewhat flat economy tied to mining, agriculture and tourism, Montana has struggled in recent years to balance its budget. The state has no sales tax and relies on revenues from income and property taxes.
Some political leaders compare the offshore plan to what Nevada did earlier in this century when it became a mecca for easy divorce and casino gambling.
And if the plan fails in Montana, the state is out only about $18,000, the cost of studying how to set itself up as an offshore banking haven.
"We may be a little naive," Mr. Sprague said. "But for the price of a good used pickup truck, what can we lose?"
