HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
With the All-Star Game and the Olympics, the N.H.L. Tries to Extend Its Global Reach

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 17

 BODY:
When the 19-year-old Wayne Gretzky played in his first National Hockey League All-Star game 18 years ago as a member of the Clarence Campbell Conference team, the opposing Prince of Wales Conference had a 51-year-old right wing named Gordie Howe. Gretzky was a young star in his rookie N.H.L. season. Howe was an old star in his final season. But they had one thing in common: Both were Canadian, as were the overwhelming majority of All-Star participants and N.H.L. players in general.
On Sunday, eight days away from his 37th birthday, Gretzky will again grace the midseason showcase when his team representing North America plays a team representing the rest of the world. Among Gretzky's Canadian- and American-born teammates and his European opponents will be more than a few whose early childhood memories include watching Gretzky dominate the sport in the first decade of his brilliant career. They, like many fans, must appreciate that Gretzky is still among the elite of his profession. 
 "Maybe I'm getting younger as I'm getting older," a smiling Gretzky said after a recent multipoint performance.
Still effective in many games, Gretzky has 12 goals and 33 assists for 45 points in 47 games with the Rangers, his fourth N.H.L. team. Every point sets a new record, as his statistics have eclipsed those of Howe and everyone else. To put the Gretzky era into perspective, consider the hockey world of his first All-Star appearance. It was early February of 1980, just weeks before the United States upset the Soviet Union and went on to win the gold medal at the Winter Olympic Games in Lake Placid. Back then, it would have seemed preposterous to predict that N.H.L. professionals would some day play in the Olympics. And it would have seemed ludicrous to suggest that Russian stars would someday be on display in the N.H.L. All-Star Game.
But as the best professionals prepare to represent their nations in the Olympics next month in Japan, eight Russians will suit up on Sunday for the N.H.L. All-Star team that represents Europe. They will skate alongside four players from Sweden, four from Finland, three from the Czech Republic, two from Slovakia, one from Germany and one from Latvia.
The new format was created this season to stoke the flames of rivalry that have cooled since the end of the Cold War and the breakup of the Soviet Union. Gretzky and just about every other player involved said the change is welcome because the high-scoring, low-intensity All-Star games of the recent past have been less than mid-season classics.
"I think this is a good change," Gretzky said. "We needed something to spice up the All-Star game. Those 10-8 scores are not what our game is all about."
It is also part of a larger format, a three-day extravaganza that promotes a growing sport in many ways. On Friday night, the women's teams representing the United States and Canada played before more than 14,000 fans in General Motors Place. Canada won by 2-1 amid waving flags and shaking signs. One of them said: "Trounce the States at Nagano." At the conclusion of the game, many of the Canadian players stood at attention and sang along as the national anthem, 'O, Canada,' was played.
On Saturday night, the N.H.L. players will conduct the skills competition and the old-timers will play an exhibition. In the hallways of the hotels and public buildings, there are booths and exhibits for corporate sponsors. A special honored guest is Willie O'Ree, who became the league's first black player on Jan. 18, 1958. This season, nine black athletes have appeared in N.H.L. games, the most ever.
The host city, with its beautiful mountainous vistas and mild winter climate, has a large Asian population and sits on the Pacific rim. It is an appropriate location as many of these All-Stars look westward toward the east and the competition in Nagano next month. One player likely to gain a following in Japan is Canada's Paul Kariya, a Vancouver native who plays for the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim. One of the most talented and charismatic players in the N.H.L., Kariya is of Japanese descent on his father's side.
The N.H.L. of Gretzky's rookie season had only a handful of players born in the United States or Europe. But the league this season is 61.4 per cent Canadian, 16.1 per cent American and 6 per cent Russian. Players from Sweden make up 5 per cent of the rosters and so do those from the Czech Republic.
In that league rosters are 77.5 per cent North American, it is significant that Europeans make up a disproportionate percentage of the top scorers. Of the top 20 players in total points, 9 are from Europe. Sweden's Peter Forsberg, of the Colorado Avalanche, is first in total points with 59. Steve Yzerman, captain of the Stanley Cup champion Detroit Red Wings and a member of Team Canada for the Olympics, said Friday that he noticed this trend recently.
"Does it concern me? No," Yzerman said, repeating a question. "I actually counted that the other day. Europeans dominate it, I think, but there are four or five Canadians and four or five Americans. As the Wayne Gretzky and Mark Messier era is . . . "
He paused, and then rephrased his thought.
"It seems to go in cycles," Yzerman said. "There will be Canadian players coming along. You're always going to have the European players up there now. And the Americans are there to stay as well. And that's something that everybody has to get used to."
The changes of the last two decades have concerned some Canadians. The influx of European talent and the movement of franchises from Canada to the American Sun Belt causes some here to fear that Canadians are losing control of "our game." But from a marketing standpoint, the mix of nations and cultures is ideal for a sport trying to increase its exposure to a world market. Russia's Igor Larionov, who plays for Detroit, recently noted: "The N.H.L. is no longer just a domestic league." Gretzky, asked about the economic upside to the involvement with the Olympics, said:
"For the National Hockey League, as far as merchandising and marketing the sport worldwide, it's a win-win situation."

HEADLINE: Educator Joseph Murphy, 64, Former Chancellor of CUNY

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE

 BODY:
Joseph S. Murphy, the son of a labor organizer and a champion of the working class who rose to become Chancellor of the City University of New York, died in an automobile accident near Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, yesterday. He was 64.
It was not clear last night what Mr. Murphy, who had a long history of humanitarian and educational work in the East African country, was doing in Ethiopia. 
 Known for his genial manner and visceral sympathy for the plight of students, Mr. Murphy was able to rebuild and even extend academic programs during his tenure as CUNY Chancellor from 1982 to 1990, despite the system's financial woes.
Mr. Murphy, who learned to speak Yiddish from his mother, a PolishJew, and Gaelic from his father, an Irish longshoreman, was a political scientist and author of two books.
He was known for his ability to combine a practical knowledge of politics with an enduring commitment to the poor and the working class. Highlights of his tenure as Chancellor included the introduction of child care services for working students and the expansion of adult literacy and collaborative programs with the public schools. He also started a summer remedial course that taught basic skills to incoming freshmen, and a $1.5 billion capital construction program to modernize 13 of the university's 20 campuses.
In an effort to make the administration more reflective of student enrollment, he sought out members of minority groups for top positions. In an editorial marking Mr. Murphy's retirement, The New York Times stated that his "legacy of competence and commitment sets a worthy standard for his successor."
Born in Newark, New Jersey, in 1933, Mr. Murphy attended the University of Colorado and received his bachelor's degree from Olivet College in Michigan in 1955. A recipient of a Woodrow Wilson Fellowship and others, Mr. Murphy received his doctorate from Brandeis University in 1961 and was an assistant professor at Brandeis until 1965.
Mr. Murphy served as director of the Peace Corps' Virgin Island Training Center in St. Croix from 1965 to 1966; as assistant Office Secretary in the Department of Health Education and Welfare in Washington from from 1966 to 1967; as an Associate Director of the Job Corps in the Office of Economic Opportunity in Washington from 1967 to 1968, and as director of Peace Corps operations in Ethiopia from 1968 to 1970.
He then returned to the United State and held a series of academic posts that eventually led him to head CUNY, the nation's third largest public university.
Mr. Murphy served as the Vice Chancellor for Higher Education for the state of New Jersey from 1970 to 1971. He was president of Queens College from 1971 to 1977 and president of Bennington University in Vermont from 1977 to 1982 until he was named Chancellor of CUNY.
Mr. Murphy had continued teaching at CUNY since his retirement as Chancellor and had served at a number of posts in Africa. He worked as an election observer in Ethiopia in 1992 and as a consultant for the Constitutional Commission in Addis Ababa in 1993. Mr. Murphy had also served as a member of the board of YIVO Institute for Jewish Research since 1993 and the UNESCO Global Project since 1992.
Mr. Murphy is survived by his wife Susan Crile, and his children from a previous marriage Lisa, Susanne, and Peter.

HEADLINE: THE BOATING REPORT;
Preparing to Race in Key West, and Beyond

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

 BODY:
Russell Coutts was driving to a boatyard in Auckland, New Zealand, last Wednesday to spend the day testing sails on the water. En route, he decided to return a phone call from the United States.
The sound of shuffling noises emanated from his cellular phone during the call; Coutts was shifting things off the front seat of his car to make room for Brad Butterworth, his team's tactician. Politely, he apologized for the interruption. The phone conversation ended in about 10 minutes, but the two yachtsmen kept driving. Fifteen minutes later, the American's phone rang again in the United States. Unknown to Coutts, the redial button on his cell phone had been switched on. 
 The car noise had been replaced with the screeching sound of a mainsail going up its track, lines flopping on deck and Kiwi crew members chattering like old pals at a men's club. It was a bit of serendipity, an opportunity to listen in like a sea gull on a stanchion to the skipper and the team that had won the America's Cup so resoundingly in 1995. But alas, the talk was mostly garble.
The next best place to tune in to Coutts and his crew will be in Florida during the GMC Yukon Key West Race Week, the next stop on Coutts's international agenda. Talk about jet lag: this week Auckland, next week Key West for the start tomorrow of the five-day grand prix competition.
"Key West is one of the top regattas in the world in terms of being competitive and seeing who's out there," the 38-year-old Coutts said from Auckland. "It's necessary to be there and to see the new technology."
Key West is one of three major events on the water right now, including the Whitbread Round the World Race, which restarts on Jan. 31 from Auckland, and the New York to San Francisco Race, which began yesterday from New York.
The Key West regatta expects more than 260 boats and 4,000 sailors to compete on three courses. The boats are divided among 18 classes, many of which are rated as one-designs such as the Corel 45, the Farr 40, the Melges 36 and the Mumm 30.
Other boats race under handicap rules such as the International Measurement System and the Performance Handicap Racing Fleet. Tom Whidden, chief executive officer of North Sails, and a former tactician for Dennis Conner, said that regardless of boat choice, the sport of yachting is on the rebound.
"I attribute a lot of that to the economy," Whidden said. "But I also attribute it to the fact that sailing is a sport that endures. People went away from it for a variety of reasons. But it seems like a lot of the players are coming back."
Part of the draw may be the ever-increasing fascination with one-design sailboats. But growing hype about the 1999-2000 America's Cup races also seems to be having its effect. Of the eight One Design 48 yachts expected to compete in Key West, five will field mostly America's Cup crews. Among the possible 1999 America's Cup skippers on site will be John Kolius, Dawn Riley, Jeff Madrigali, Chris Law, Ed Baird and Buddy Melges.
Coutts will sail as helmsman of Numbers, a 49-foot Jim Taylor design. The boat, which was overall winner in the I.M.S. division last year, has been a trend setter. At the Admiral's Cup regatta in England last summer, Coutts's team showed up with an unconventional mast shape -- chubby at the base and tapered at the top.
Other I.M.S. owners tried to copy the new style in hopes of reaping a credit advantage under the rating rule. But the modification was ultimately seen by I.M.S. rule-makers as a loophole, which they then tried to eliminate. Coutts said that the mast still is a rule-beater, but other sailors feel the change left them with an expensive but useless adaptation.
"The I.M.S. people take all the heat for it when something like that happens," Whidden said, "but people should have realized it."
The alternative is campaigning with a one-design sailboat, which cannot be modified. But even that plan is bringing on signs of caution.
"I think one-design sailboats are great," Coutts said. "I've been sailing them all my life and grew up sailing dinghies.
"But it's beginning to look like there are too many one-design fleets. The fun of those boats is to bring together large fleets. But when designers keep coming up with new boats, people move on to the next design, and you end up with a whole lot of smaller fleets."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Numbers, with Russell Coutts at the helm, will be a favorite at Key West Race Week. Coutts's team planned to make the trip from New Zealand. (Daniel Forster)

HEADLINE: THEATER;
In 'Ragtime,' a Cast From American History

BYLINE: By ANDREA STEVENS 

 BODY:
WHEN THE MUSICAL "RAGTIME" OPENS TONIGHT, inaugurating the new Ford Center for the Performing Arts, there will be a crowd of familiar names in the character list: Booker T. Washington, Emma Goldman, Houdini, Admiral Peary. These and other figures from early in America's 20th century will flicker in and out of the show, based on E. L. Doctorow's best-selling 1975 novel of the same name.
In fact, the lives of these influential men and women will intertwine with those of three fictional families, as depicted in the musical's book by Terrence McNally: the prosperous white WASP's of New Rochelle, N.Y. (Father, Mother, Mother's Younger Brother and the Little Boy); the enterprising black musician, the woman he loves and their son (Coalhouse Walker Jr., Sarah and Little Coalhouse), and the Jewish immigrant father and young daughter seeking sanctuary in the new world (Tateh and the Little Girl). The clash of races, classes and ideas, the extremes of poverty and wealth, the intense industrialization -- all are set against the period's new rhythm that signaled a new era: ragtime. 
 With a score by Stephen Flaherty and Lynn Ahrens and a cast that includes Brian Stokes Mitchell, Peter Friedman, Marin Mazzie, Audra McDonald, Mark Jacoby and Judy Kaye under the direction of Frank Galati, the musical attempts to portray the creation of modern America nearly a century ago.
Among the many supporting characters, nine historical figures stand out. Here are the actors who portray them and the real individuals (insets) on whom they were based. ANDREA STEVENS
 
Harry Houdini
(1874-1926)
(portrayed by Jim Corti)
 Born in Budapest, Erich Weiss, who took his stage name from the 19th-century French conjurer Houdin, was an American vaudeville headliner and celebrated escape artist who toured Europe and Australia. In "Ragtime," he performs in Atlantic City before an audience that includes the Little Boy. His trick is to extricate himself from a box in which he is imprisoned and manacled, a hopeful metaphor, perhaps, for many poor immigrants.
 
Admiral Robert E. Peary
(1856-1920)
(Rod Campbell)
 For decades, the certainty that Peary had been the first person to reach the North Pole was as solid as Arctic ice. Then last year came a 20-year study by Robert M. Bryce that said neither the admiral nor his rival, Frederick Cook, had accomplished the feat. Defenders of both explorers dispute the conclusions of "Cook and Peary: The Polar Controversy, Resolved," but "Ragtime" does not take sides. In the musical, Father embarks with the explorer from New York Harbor, leaving Mother in charge at home. It is a turning point for Mother and ultimately affects the lives of all three families depicted in the show.
 
Emma Goldman
(1869-1940)
(Judy Kaye)
 Goldman, who was born in Lithuania and immigrated to America in 1886, saw labor conditions first-hand in her adopted country while working in clothing factories in Rochester. An anarchist and a galvanizing public speaker, she was arrested and ultimately deported after speaking publicly in favor of birth control and, in 1917, for obstructing the draft. As the tempo of American industrialization increased, she campaigned for the rights of the working class. In the musical, Younger Brother is inspired by her.
 
Stanford White
(1853-1906)
(Kevin Bogue)
 A passionate lover of beauty in all its guises, White was a partner in the influential architectural firm of McKim, Mead & White. The Century Club and Washington Square Arch are among the firm's existing structures in New York that display White's particular interest in decorative elements. Another of these was Evelyn Nesbit. White, a hedonist drawn to very young women, was married when the affair began. In the musical, the Nesbit character cheerfully sings the song "The Crime of the Century," describing how White met his destiny at the hands of her husband, Harry K. Thaw. The year was 1906. There were 94 more to go.
 
Evelyn Nesbit
(1885-1967)
(Lynnette Perry)
 The former Floradora Girl became the mistress of the architect Stanford White when she was 16. Titillating details of their love life became public once her husband murdered White. Nesbit, it turned out, had amused White by swinging naked on a red velvet seat suspended from the ceiling. Eager for a stage career, even if it meant trading on her own notoriety, Nesbit rode a swing in her vaudeville act and later inspired the 1955 movie "The Girl in the Red Velvet Swing." In "Ragtime," Younger Brother, not surprisingly, becomes enamored of her.
 
Harry K. Thaw
(1871-1947)
(Colton Green)
 When Thaw died at 76, his obituary in The New York Times noted that he had inspired a new term, "dementia Americana." Vain, extravagantly rich and prone to jealousy, he brooded on the fact that his wife, Evelyn Nesbit, whom he married in 1905, had once been the mistress of the celebrated architect Stanford White. In 1906, after a performance of "Mam'zelle Champagne" on the roof of the old Madison Square Garden (which White had designed), Thaw, in the presence of his wife and the audience, drew a revolver and shot White, who had been sitting at a table watching the show. Ultimately acquitted, Thaw spent some years in an insane asylum.
 
Henry Ford
(1863-1947)
(Larry Daggett)
 By cutting production costs, adapting the assembly line to automobile manufacture and designing a standardized car, Ford's company became the largest automobile producer in the world. No lover of unions, Ford resisted them in his factories until 1941. The Model T, which Ford himself designed in 1908, plays a crucial part in the musical, once it is bought and driven onstage by the ragtime musician Coalhouse Walker. Would the industrialist have cared that the Broadway show inaugurating a theater named after his company portrays him as ruthless?
 
J. P. Morgan
(1837-1913)
(Mike O'Carroll)
 Morgan built his father's banking enterprise into a financial, industrial and railroad empire, at one point saving the United States Government from bankruptcy by arranging a loan. He was a renowned art collector who kept many of his expensive purchases in the Pierpont Morgan Library in Manhattan, which did not open to the public until after his death. The building is the setting for a major confrontation in "Ragtime" among Coalhouse Walker, Booker T. Washington, Younger Brother and Father.
 
Booker T. Washington
(1856-1915)
(Tommy Hollis)
 The son of a slave, Washington put himself through school after the Civil War by working, among other places, in the Virginia coal mines. In 1881 he was appointed the first president of an industrial school in Tuskegee, Ala., and turned it into the famous Tuskegee Institute. He was criticized in his lifetime by many prominent blacks for putting education and economic parity ahead of social equality. A recurring figure in "Ragtime," he speaks intensely about the country's racial problems.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 1, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A picture on Jan. 18 with an article about historical figures portrayed in the musical "Ragtime" was published in error. The inset in a segment on the financier J. P. Morgan showed Morgan's son, Jack, also known as J. P. Morgan Jr., not Morgan himself.

HEADLINE: Social Security Fantasy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Representative Jerrold Nadler (letter, Jan. 13) argues that the projected Social Security trust fund shortfall will be reduced from 2.2 percent to 1.5 percent of taxable payroll merely by assuming that the economy will continue to grow at close to the 2.5 percent average annual rate of the past 25 years. 
 However, economic growth is a function of both growth in output per worker (productivity) and growth in the number of workers (labor force). With birth rates in the United States barely at the replacement level, labor force growth will slow sharply in the coming decades, eventually dropping to almost zero unless immigration policies are radically liberalized. Therefore, productivity growth would have to rise even beyond the historic peak levels of the 1950's and 1960's in order to sustain the overall economic growth rates that Mr. Nadler posits for the next century.
Thus, the pleasant prospect of just growing our way out of the Social Security financing gap is remote, and it should not beguile our political leaders into deferring the heavy lifting needed to restore the system's solvency.
 
DAVID BELKIN
New York, Jan. 15, 1998
The writer is an economist.

HEADLINE: Video World Is Smitten by a Gun-Toting, Tomb-Raiding Sex Symbol

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Her name is Lara Croft, and she seems to be everywhere.
Her image is popping up in magazines, on television and computer screens, even on pinup posters like the one in the current issue of PC Games magazine, which shows her reclining in a bikini, a handgun resting suggestively on her hip. 
 There's talk about a movie offer, a modeling contract and perhaps even a marketing deal that might some day have her hawking clothes and soft drinks.
And she's not even real. Ms. Croft is a digitized female image from one of the hottest-selling video games of the year, Tomb Raider 2, which is published by Eidos Interactive, based in London.
But that has not stopped Ms. Croft -- whose tanned, voluptuous cyberframe is the equivalent of 34-24-34 -- from becoming a popular female icon. She is a far cry from Betty Boop, and she is no Barbie doll. She is more like a female Indiana Jones, but pumped up, vertically and horizontally, in the fashion of the 1990's.
Her fans say she is gritty, sexy, sassy, smart and, well, virtually real. And that's exactly what her British creators were hoping for.
"It's really a strange phenomenon because people talk about her as if she's a real person," said Cindy Church, a spokeswoman for Eidos. "A lot of people who play video games fantasize about her."
Unsure of just how to portray the silicon icon, Ms. Church went on, "She's not overly sexual," then paused. "O.K., she is physically sexual, but she has a personality behind her."
Because of those attributes, Eidos executives are being flooded with gifts and presents for the silicon princess. There are flowers, Christmas gifts, even vows from young boys and men. "People all over the world have sent in their pictures," said Tricia Gray at the Eidos office in San Francisco. "She's had dozens of marriage proposals and all these cheesy letters."
Indeed, in Britain, only the bubbly Spice Girls are said to be more popular. And in the United States, her Indiana Jones-like video exploits are being sold in large quantities to game players who are well into their 30's.
Ms. Croft's first game, Tomb Raider, was released in November 1996 and sold about 3.5 million copies worldwide. Tomb Raider 2, which came out last November, has sold several million, according to Eidos.
As a result, just about every game and computer magazine wants to reprint Ms. Croft's sexy image. There are even entire World Wide Web sites devoted to her and sites created by individuals who even take the liberty of posing the digital Ms. Croft in the nude.
"The most obvious reason Lara Croft is so popular is that 99.5 percent of the gaming population is young men," says Steve Klett, editor of PC Games magazine, which has Ms. Croft gracing its cover this month. "And it doesn't hurt that she's so outrageously proportioned."
Indeed, the craze surrounding Ms. Croft (there is also an on-line newspaper dedicated to chronicling her life) might be yet another sign that technological advances in human imagery are creating lifelike portraits that further blur the line between reality and fantasy.
Devoted fans, who see a three-dimensional image and hear a real British voice projecting out of their computer speakers, have dubbed Ms. Croft a "cyberbabe" and the "silicon chick."
And to bolster such realism, Ms. Croft has her own biography and a rebellious past. Born into an aristocratic family in Wimbledon, England, Ms. Croft -- whose given age is 29 -- grew up in a world of private tutors, boarding schools and a Swiss finishing school.
But on a skiing trip to the Himalayas, her plane crashed. Ms. Croft, who was the sole survivor, soon realized that she could not stand the "suffocating atmosphere of the upper-class British society" and preferred a new adventurous life. Thus she began searching for ancient artifacts and fighting villains and a zoo of animals, like tigers and wolves.
But her creators say that Ms. Croft's future is not about slaying dragons but winning eyeballs. "The digital Lara is going to sign a modeling contract with a big agency," Ms. Church boasts. "She'll become a supermodel, like Naomi Campbell and Linda Evangelista."
Even her creators think she's real.

HEADLINE: MEDIA: BROADCASTING;
Last week's deals proved that the networks can't live without high-rated programs.

BYLINE: By Bill Carter 

DATELINE: PASADENA, Calif.

 BODY:
AT the end of the week of spending extravagantly, the networks rested -- and wondered what they had wrought.
With a few causal strokes of a pen last week, each of the four broadcast networks spent more money on programming than they had ever spent before -- three for N.F.L. football, one for television's most popular entertainment program, "E.R." 
 Every price set a record. The commitments added up to more than $8 billion for ABC, more than $4 billion for Fox, $4 billion exactly for CBS and just under $900 million for NBC.
For Don Ohlmeyer, the president of NBC's West Coast division, the binge spending that began 1998 will force the networks, who have coped with dwindling audiences for nearly two decades, to approach their business in entirely new ways.
"This business has changed more in the past 24 months than it changed in the previous 24 years," he said. "And the companies that are going to succeed are the companies that can successfully reinvent themselves. Whether that's in programming. Whether that's in ways that they sell advertising. Whether that's in ways they generate revenue."
But that reinvention will have to come quickly to help pay the tab for last week's excesses.
And even though it was spending the least, NBC had the most questions to answer. The network absorbed the loss of Sunday afternoon football after a 34-year run just two weeks after learning that it would lose its most successful program of the last decade, "Seinfeld," at the end of the season.
NBC's decision to spend a previously undreamed of total of $13 million for each episode to retain rights to "E.R." was certainly related to the loss of "Seinfeld."
"Clearly, you don't want to lose both 'Seinfeld' and 'E.R.,' " Mr. Ohlmeyer said.
But paying that enormous price for "E.R." on top of the disappearance of "Seinfeld" -- means NBC's two biggest profit-centers will be wiped out next season.
Add that to widespread predictions that the three other networks face the serious prospect of losses over their N.F.L. contracts if the national economy encounters even a lull in its current bullet-train run, and you have a plot-line for the next great television disaster movie.
"The I.R.S. makes the determination that if once every five years you make a profit, you're a business," Mr. Ohlmeyer said. "If not, you're a hobby. We don't want to be a hobby."
This is the current state of commentary on a business that was once jokingly called a license to print money. How did it come to this?
As Mr. Ohlmeyer put it, "In today's environment, you are what you program."
Last week proved that the networks simply can not live without high-rated programming. If they do not have it, they must buy it. The result, of course, is that those with the desirable programming enjoy overwhelming leverage over those who need it. It's a seller's market.
The need for programming that attracts mass audiences has only grown with the number of viewing choices. "As audiences get smaller and smaller at the networks and there are more of these tiny networks running around, I think what's left becomes extremely valuable," said Robert C. Wright, the president of NBC.
With all this competition, network television's ability to command the kind of mass audiences that drive their advertising revenues dwindled. And even though the few hit shows left that can has command a mass audience are also suffering a ratings decline, their value is increasing.
"We have an anomaly in mass-media enterprises," said Robert Broder, a prominent agent in the television business, who heads the firm Broder, Kurland, Webb, Uffner. "Because of fractionalization, programs that are at the highest level are more valuable in a down market than they were in an up market, even when they are performing less well in absolute terms."
Football was clearly deemed Must-Have TV, at virtually any price. NBC executives said in interviews that they could not value beyond $300 million a year the American Football Conference package they abandoned to CBS for a price of $500 million.
Of course, NBC had been all too willing to pay more than $500 million to wrest away "Monday Night Football" from ABC because it would have instantly helped shore up NBC's prime-time program lineup.
The football negotiations also helped drive NBC to secure "E.R." before it could be bid into the ionosphere by another network. Mr. Ohlmeyer said he was "deathly afraid that we would get 'Monday Night Football' and we'd have a crazed ABC out there."
ABC might have been just crazed enough to pay, say, $20 million an episode for "E.R."
"E.R." now costs about $2 million an episode. At $13 million, Mr. Ohlmeyer emphasized NBC "will not lose money."
But will it make any? Maybe, if NBC can come up some creative way to attract more revenue, like keeping more of the commercial time that used to be sold by NBC's stations, or perhaps shoving the 11 P.M. local news back by one minute on Thursday nights so more commercial time can be squeezed into the highly-rated "E.R."
The other networks are talking about similarly elaborate strategies to maximize their revenues from football.
Mr. Wright, ruefully describing the out-of-control negotiating process, likened the networks to participants at a kind of wild, drunken party.
"Everybody's too happy, everybody looks too good, people who never smoke cigarettes are now smoking cigars, people are making promises to each other," Mr. Wright said.
"And the next morning you have to wake up and face the reality."

HEADLINE: A Classified Advertising Free-for-All

BYLINE: By ERIC HUBLER 

 BODY:
For more than two decades, consumers around the world in search of widgets, wombats or wives have turned to their local free-ads papers -- and have often got what they wished.
For almost as long, newspaper publishers have considered free-ads papers minor pests -- if they even knew about them. Though they look like tabloid newspapers, these papers have more in common with fliers for a swap meet or a yard sale than with a traditional newspaper. 
 But, while these papers have been flying under the radar of everyone but their devoted readers for years, the format, invented by a self-described hippie, has become so profitable that papers are being snapped up by multinationals or expanding into chains in their own right.
The free-ads paper is not, itself, free; that's its doppelganger, the "shopper," typified by the Harmon and Pennysaver papers given out at supermarkets. Rather, it is the ads that are free, an abhorrent notion to most publishers. By letting individuals place free classifieds, then charging them $1 or $2 to buy the paper at a newsstand or at a news box, free-ads publishers turn the classified ads themselves into content around which advertising can be sold to businesses.
One prominent player, the London-based Loot Group, takes in $52 million annually from its 14 British and Irish editions, 55 percent from the cover price and 45 percent from display ads, according to its managing director, Heidi Bergemann.
What has really helped fuel the growth of the papers is an Amsterdam-based trade organization called the Free Ads Paper International Association, or Fapia, which represents about a third of the world's free-ads papers. The group's 80 member publishers put out titles in 140 cities, with circulations ranging from 6,000 to 450,000.
The publications are not as big a phenomenon in the United States, but they are published in cities like Los Angeles, Las Vegas, Nev., Indianapolis and Charleston, S.C., though not all are members of the association.
Readers attracted to the idea of getting something for nothing are people like Peter Hoffman, a Manhattan private investigator who is so hooked on Loot's year-old New York edition that he has his electronic scheduler remind him of the deadline each Monday. The paper is published on Wednesday. So far he has sold a camera, a couch and the boxes he used in a recent move. Now he is trying to unload an Amtrak ticket. "It's like a permanent yard sale for me," Mr. Hoffman said. "I never got rid of so much junk in my life."
In addition to providing technical support and setting standards (members may not, for example, publish ads relating to drugs, weapons, prostitution or pedophilia), Fapia is a trade association with a twist, Ms. Bergemann said.
With the aid of a coupon developed by the organization, a reader of any member paper may submit an ad for free publication in any other paper (though if the ad goes to multiple papers it costs a few dollars). This allows lonely hearts in Milan to read the plaintive wishes of their counterparts in Tokyo or New York.
Although the exchange ads account for only 1 percent of the membership's total weekly volume of four million ads ("Nobody's going to fly to Paris to buy a used fridge," Ms. Bergemann said) the 40,000 international ads certainly add color, creating a mosaic of the state of the economy and the human psyche worldwide. Some recent ads from Loot's New York edition include:
*SOS, I'm looking for kind space people who can heal me. I'm troubled with strange disease (Japan).
*A white male, 28, is looking for marriage w American lady and move to Hollywood to become famous movie stars (Belgium).
*Russian woman 30, Lidia, w son, lonely, sks a man for relationship, more, what are you interested, sorry, I don't speak English.
*We both, 29 and 28, gay guys, very cute, search you 2 lesbians for marriage, we are from Munich, Germany.
A recent edition of London's Loot, the chain's flagship paper, filled 96 tabloid-size pages. It included ads for selling or swapping everything from cameras to cars and vacation homes to fitness equipment. It also had 11 pages of personal ads, almost all from people seeking relationships.
And in a small section titled "Message noticeboard," ads ranged from the poetic ("Cramped is this life at home, dusty indeed its spheres, life gone forth is wide open") to the cryptic ("suits you") to the polemical ("Politics is the shadow cast upon society by big business.").
The first free-ads paper, Buy and Sell Press in Vancouver, British Columbia, remains solely owned by its founder, Mike Abbott, who thought the enterprise would foster social interaction and create a kind of people's capitalism.
The idea was copied elsewhere in western Canada and California in the 1970's. It skipped much of the rest of North America but flowered in Europe.
In gratitude, the free-ads association made Mr. Abbott its honorary president. "They owe me millions, those blokes," he said. "Some of these papers have changed hands for hundreds of millions of dollars since 1985," when the association was founded.
Mr. Abbott will not spell out his own profit, but he says the industry's arithmetic is as simple as it is sweet: a well-run paper sells two copies for every ad it carries, has a circulation of 25,000 to 30,000 per million of population, and enjoys a profit of 20 percent.
Corporate interest in the format is clear. Consider the fate of one of Buy and Sell's earliest imitators, the Recycler. Born in a phone conversation, during which Mr. Abbott casually advised an admirer to start a free-ads paper in Los Angeles, the Recycler now has 10 regional editions, plus 35 other papers of various formats, and is majority-owned by a Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette investment fund.
The big buyout story, though, is Secondamano. Founded in Milan in the late 1970's, it mushroomed to eight cities in Italy, one in Switzerland, and 11 in Russia and Kazakhstan. The ex-Soviet papers turned out to be the jewels of the free-ads world -- the Moscow edition, like Loot's London flagship, went from a weekly to a daily to handle the volume -- and caught the eye of Paris-based Hebdo Mag International (now a unit of the Cendant Corporation).
Hebdo, though best known for its paid-advertising titles like Wheels 'n Deals, already owned, co-owned or was about to own free-ads papers in Paris, Warsaw, Budapest, Amsterdam, Puerto Rico and Buenos Aires. Hebdo acquired Secondamano last January, making it easily the largest free-ads publisher. Cendant does not break out revenues by operating division, and Hebdo officials declined to specify what the company paid for its acquisitions.
The format's strongest endorsement comes from an American newspaper that bucked traditions and says it has benefited as a result. That newspaper, The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette, now gives away more than a million ads a year, and revenue from business classifieds attracted by the liveliness of the individual ads continues to rise.
The paper began its give-away practice shortly after The Arkansas Democrat bought the assets of its competitor, The Arkansas Gazette, in 1991. At the time, The Democrat was already running free classifieds.
Paul Smith, the general manager of The Democrat-Gazette, said that the free ads "created new readers because people who were interested in something would start to buy our paper even if they subscribed to the other, because we might on a typical day have 300 pet ads while the other would have 15."
Mr. Smith said that although some other newspapers offered free classifieds for inexpensive items, his was the only one that offered a true free-for-all. So why don't more dailies do likewise? "It sounds kind of bizarre," Mr. Smith concedes. "I think a lot of people are afraid to step out and take a chance."

HEADLINE: Taking In the Sites;
Internet Can Help Sort Out Economic Turmoil in Asia

BYLINE: By SREENATH SREENIVASAN 

 BODY:
The economic crisis in Asia has generated a great deal of interest in news about the region, and many people are increasingly turning to the World Wide Web for timely information.
As in most recent crises, the turmoil in Asia highlights the best of the Internet (global reach, firsthand sources, instant access) and the worst (irrelevant search results, selective updates, repetitive data, inaccurate rumors). As with most subjects, it is best to have a map and some experts to help you out. 
 "The Web has been most useful for keeping track of the crisis," said Nouriel Roubini, a professor of international economics at the Stern School of Business at New York University. "The amount of data and information available is quite impressive."
Professor Roubini maintains a site for his class that even people without an M.B.A. will find helpful in learning about the crisis. What the site lacks in fancy design it makes up in analysis, extensive links and a detailed chronology. The main question his site tries to answer: "What caused Asia's economic and currency crisis and its global contagion?"
Even economists who suffer from information overload can find the Web has a purpose when it comes to the crisis. "You are going to pick up a wider range of perspectives with the Internet than with other systems," said Ronald R. Reuss, chief economist for Piper Jaffray, a brokerage firm based in Minneapolis. He uses the Web mainly to supplement the more sophisticated information resources -- like Bloomberg News and Reuters -- he has at his disposal.
Rajiv J. Chaudhri, a former Goldman, Sachs semiconductor analyst and now president of Digital Century Capital, a technology hedge fund, keeps a close eye on the events in Asia. "For me, the Web is a very important research tool," he said. "I need to know what is happening there because it impacts a lot of technology companies here." His Web visits include English-language papers published in Asia.
Several news sites, both here and abroad, offer good starting points. For example, The New York Times on the Web has a section on its site dedicated to the topic. It has articles dating back to December as well as opinion articles and forums in which visitors can discuss the crisis.
The search engine Yahoo offers a collection of the latest news items relating to the situation. An on-line news agency based in London called Out There News has a handy country-by-country guide so you can see that despite being called the "Asian financial crisis," it has not yet affected the entire continent.
Several Asia-based news sites worth visiting are linked from the Times site. Also, check out the site of The Far Eastern Economic Review, the Hong Kong-based publication owned by Dow Jones & Company, which provides coverage of different sectors of the economy. Articles from The Asian Wall Street Journal are available on The Wall Street Journal's Web site -- for a fee.
To go beyond the headlines, some sites provide tools to analyze the data. Indonesia Net Exchange carries stock quotes, research reports and links to listed companies and the Jakarta Stock Exchange. And Bloomberg's site offers some resources that are accessible without paying the $1,200 a month for a dedicated terminal. For instance, an on-line calculator gives rates for more than 215 currencies. So visitors can find out how the Malaysian ringgit is doing against the South Korean won or even the Cape Verde escudo.
To learn about how the crisis is affecting the United States, a site called the Dismal Scientist, which bills itself as the "Web's authoritative source for economic information," has a section dealing with the effect of the crisis on different regions of the country.
The sites of the international organizations that are such crucial players all have Web sites, but they vary in usefulness.
The International Monetary Fund site has a section called "I.M.F. Bailouts: Truth and Fiction" that answers critics unhappy with the assistance packages provided to South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand. The World Bank basically has an archive of news releases and statements by its top executives on the crisis. The Bank for International Settlements, a sort of central bank for the world's central banks, has comprehensive reports on the assets and liabilities of banks of the affected countries.
Getting worthwhile information from the pertinent institutions in Asia is difficult because the sites do not have easy-to-find sections on the subject at hand. A visit to the Asian Development Bank in Manila, the Bank of Thailand in Bangkok or the South Korean Ministry of Finance and Economy in Seoul yields little that is current or that has been updated in recent days.
For another perspective on the situation in Asia, check out The International Workers Bulletin, the journal of the World Socialist Web site. It addresses "the urgent need for a revolutionary socialist response to the crisis of the world capitalist system," and has a series of articles about the consequences of the situation for workers.
Asia Online, a site on the Asian Buying Consortium, has a forum specifically to discuss "Asian market rumors" where advice is freely offered by other Web surfers.
The difficulties in Asia are sure to be a major topic at the annual World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. The conference attracts some of the biggest names in business and government, and its Web site may be worth keeping an eye on when the conference starts on Jan. 29.

HEADLINE: 'Titanic' Wins Top Golden Globe Award

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: BEVERLY HILLS, Jan. 18

 BODY:
In an evening that was expected to pit the big guns of expensive Hollywood dramas against the depth of small, independently produced works, an array of big and small films took Golden Globe awards here tonight, with "Titanic," a $200 million costume drama, winning as top film drama but several smaller movies taking most other awards.
"Does this prove once and for all that size matters?" asked James Cameron, who also won a Golden Globe as best director for "Titanic." 
 But the award for best dramatic actor went to a man who has been absent from films for years, Peter Fonda, well known for his iconic role in the 1960's film "Easy Rider." He won the award for his part as a quiet, courageous beekeeper in "Ulee's Gold," a small-budget film.
"God, it's good to be back," said Mr. Fonda, in accepting his trophy, and then added, "I wish my dad were here tonight," referring to the legendary Henry Fonda.
Judi Dench won for best dramatic actress for her role as Queen Victoria in "Mrs. Brown." And the award for best screenplay went to two first-timers, Ben Affleck and Matt Damon, who originally wrote what became "Good Will Hunting" while undergraduates. The film, a stirring tale of how a tough orphan from the streets of South Boston comes to terms with the abuse he suffered as a child, love and his inexplicable facility as a mathematical genius, was another small-budget drama that is expected to be a strong contender at the Oscars.
The closest thing to a sweep in the evening was scored by "As Good as It Gets," a dark, odd comedy about an intensely neurotic novelist falling in love with a salty waitress. The film, a large-budget studio movie directed and co-written by James L. Brooks, won as best musical or comedy. Its stars, Jack Nicholson (who also appeared with Mr. Fonda in "Easy Rider") and Helen Hunt, won for best actor and actress in the category. Although the awards, given by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, have raised questions because the association is little recognized and has fewer than 100 voting members, they are seen as harbingers of the more popular Oscars given in the spring. As such, they gave little hint of how the voting might go at that time, but did provide Hollywood an opportunity to do something it clearly enjoys, party.
The mood was relaxed and festive, but few people appeared to be enjoying themselves more than the cast of "The Full Monty," an independent film about a group of unemployed workers in Sheffield, England, who decide to put on a striptease performance.
Wearing big smiles as they sauntered down the red carpet before the show, the film's cast members were asked at one point how they got here. The Beatles-like reply: "By aeroplane." The light moment captured the sense of the evening, one of the few that mixes television and movie personalities.
Among the more popular choices of the evening was Burt Reynolds, who has had many ups and downs in his long career and who won as best supporting actor for his role as the paternalistic pornographic filmmaker in "Boogie Nights." The best supporting actress trophy went to Kim Basinger, who played a big-hearted call girl in "L.A. Confidential."
In the realm of the small screen, the award for best television mini-series or movie went to "George Wallace," which starred Gary Sinise and was produced for TNT.
But the best actor in a mini-series or movie for television went to Ving Rhames, who until now has generally had modest roles but put in both a lighthearted and powerful performance as the boxing promoter Don King in "Don King: Only in America," for HBO.
Then, in one of the most strikingly anti-Hollywood gestures of the evening, Mr. Rhames, tears streaming down his face, called the actor Jack Lemmon to the stage (a nominee for his part in "12 Angry Men") and gave his trophy to Mr. Lemmon.
"I knew Don King was a character," a stunned Mr. Lemmon commented, "but I didn't know you were crazy."
The best supporting actress in a television mini-series or movie went to Alfre Woodard for the HBO film "Miss Evers' Boys," for which she won an Emmy award.
"Ally McBeal," one of the few new shows to receive nominations, won as best television comedy. Calista Flockhart, the star of the show, won for best actress in a comedy. The award for best actor in a comedy went to Michael J. Fox, in "Spin City."
The best television dramatic series went, for the second consecutive year, to "The X-Files," the occasionally bizarre, conspiratorial show about two F.B.I. agents chasing -- always with straight faces -- everything from aliens to mutants.
The award for best actress in a television drama went to Christine Lahti in "Chicago Hope." She delivered the most amusing moment when she failed to rush to the stage, bringing a long span of ad libbing until she finally showed up and reported, "You know, I was in the bathroom, Mom."
Anthony Edwards won for best actor in a television drama for his role in "E.R."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Cameron, winner of best director, for "Titanic." (Associated Press)(pg. E3)

HEADLINE: ALBANY IS FAULTED FOR NOT PREPARING TO MEET RECESSION

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 18

 BODY:
For some time, it has seemed that all the fiscal news from here was good. The state is running a big budget surplus for the third year in a row. Gov. George E. Pataki boasts that he has slowed the upward spiral of spending and that the state's emergency reserve fund is larger than ever.
Yet financial experts on Wall Street, in academia and elsewhere warn that while most other states have used the healthy economy of the last seven years to get their financial affairs in order, New York remains woefully ill prepared to survive another recession like the one that struck in the early 1990's. When the next downturn hits, they predict, New York may be forced to swallow the same bitter medicine it did the last time: deep spending cuts, reneging on promised tax cuts, even tax increases. 
 "In terms of its ability to weather a recession, I would say New York is in a three-way tie for last place with California and Louisiana," said Renee A. Boicourt, managing director for state ratings at Moody's Investors Service. Moody's and Standard & Poor's, the two major bond rating agencies, give New York the second-lowest credit rating of any state, ahead of only Louisiana, a reflection of their view of the state's long-term fiscal health.
As the Governor prepares to release his election-year budget on Tuesday, there is no question that New York's condition is better now than it was a few years ago. Independent fiscal monitors give credit to Mr. Pataki, saying he has been more fiscally responsible than his predecessor, Mario M. Cuomo, and to a Wall Street boom that has raised the incomes of traders and investors, swelling payments of state income tax.
But the same experts suggest that the stock market's largess has papered over serious problems, some recent, some a legacy accumulated over decades.
*The state owes $33 billion, far more than any other state and the fifth-highest per capita amount. It spends more than $2 billion a year just to make payments on that debt.
*New York's unemployment insurance fund ranks dead last among the states, with a balance large enough to cover just one month's worth of claims, according to the Federal Department of Labor. To reach the national average of 20 months, New York would need to pour billions of dollars into the fund.
*The $67.4 billion budget enacted last year included huge new tax cuts and education programs that will cost $6 billion a year by 2002, with no plan to pay for them.
The Governor and leaders of the Legislature insist that continued economic growth and management of spending will keep the state solvent. In fact, the Democratic Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, often accuses Mr. Pataki of an excess of caution, claiming that there is more money available than the Governor lets on.
"We have fought to make sure that the budgets we put together here were based on conservative revenue estimates," said Donna Arduin, Mr. Pataki's first deputy budget director. "We have managed spending very carefully, and the result has been growing surpluses every year."
She noted that skeptics were wrong in saying the state would be unable to absorb the 25 percent income tax cut enacted from 1995 through last year.
But Andrew Rein, senior research associate at the Citizens Budget Commission, said that achievement was possible only on the back of a historic performance by the stock market. "The state acts like that's going to go on forever, and it can't," he said.
Tom Carroll, president of Change-NY, a conservative anti-tax group, said the state's current fiscal condition had an unsettling parallel in the 1980's. "There was a fantastic run-up in the stock market, just like there is now, and the state was increasing spending," he said. "And then, as it always does, the cycle turned, the market dropped, we had a recession and suddenly the state had a huge deficit. The tax cuts that were scheduled were postponed, there were cuts in programs, cuts in school aid."
All indications are that, as in most election years, lawmakers will adopt a budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1 that will please voters, but not fiscal watchdogs. The Republican majority leader of the Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, has called for more tax cuts, and Mr. Pataki, a Republican, has said that he, too, will seek tax cuts. Mr. Silver wants a major increase in education spending.
And aides to the Governor say that with the state awash in cash, Mr. Pataki will show no appetite for the kind of spending cuts he once advocated. Indeed, he has already indicated that he will propose large increases in spending for education and road repairs.
Economists warn that New York's good times have not been broad-based enough to create the underlying strength to withstand a recession in good shape. Rather, they say, the state's prosperity has stemmed largely from a single industry, the financial markets, and much of the state's economy remains weak.
The last recession was longer and much deeper in New York than in the country as a whole, and the recovery has been less hearty. Mr. Pataki is fond of saying that the state's employment growth now ranks sixth in the nation, but he is speaking of the raw number of jobs. In percentage terms, New York remains near the bottom: over the three years Mr. Pataki has been in office, employment in the state has grown 3 percent, compared with 7 percent nationally.
"New York is particularly vulnerable to an economic downturn because the recovery we've had has been precarious," said Jennifer McCormick, an analyst at the Fiscal Policy Institute, an Albany-based research group that is financed by unions and foundations. "We're at the mercy of one industry."
The recession of 1990-91 hit state governments hard, forcing budget cuts and tax increases, and many states have made changes to prevent a repeat of that experience.
"A lot of states have really been aggressive about using the economic growth of the last several years to build up their reserve funds and to change their budget practices," said Corinna Eckl fiscal program director for the National Conference of State Legislatures in Denver.
In the last few years, several states have used surpluses to pay off debts early; in the last year, California and Connecticut retired major obligations. But New York actually increased its indebtedness with the $1.75 billion environmental bond act championed by the Governor in 1996, and with smaller borrowings buried in its budgets.
New York has had large cushions recently -- a surplus of almost $1.5 billion last year, and one projected to top that this year -- partly because Mr. Pataki has intentionally underestimated revenues. And the current year's budget sets aside $530 million to meet future obligations, a step that fiscal monitors call an almost unheard-of bit of prudence.
But New York lacks the mechanisms that many states have to enforce such caution. Ms. Eckl said that at least eight states have laws prohibiting them from spending more than a certain fraction -- usually 95 to 98 percent -- of the money that becomes available each year, with the rest set aside until the following year.
"A lot of states also require that the budget projections remain balanced three or four years out," she said, "so that if you increase spending or cut taxes, you have to balance it into the future, on paper, at least." In New York, by contrast, even the administration's own budget projections routinely show multibillion-dollar deficits in future years.
Like most states, New York has a "rainy day" fund that can be touched only in a bona fide emergency. But New York's fund, at $335 million, holds less than 1 percent of the state's $35 billion general fund, compared with a national average of almost 3 percent, according to the National Association of State Budget Officers. New Jersey and Connecticut, with much smaller budgets, have emergency funds almost as large as New York's.
Where some states have laws requiring deposits into those funds, New York does not, and in fact, its law limits deposits to 0.2 percent of the general fund each year. Mr. Pataki has made the maximum deposit, about $65 million, in each of his three years. Aides to the Governor say he will propose raising that limit to 0.5 percent.
The most obvious sign of New York's problems, its chronically late budgets, is viewed by fiscal monitors as more a symptom of trouble than an ill in itself. But even there, the rules that enforce discipline elsewhere -- the most Draconian rule, forcing government to shut down if the budget is not on time, is law in 23 states, according to Ms. Eckl -- are lacking here.
In Mr. Pataki's first two years in office, he proposed, along with income tax reductions, deep cuts in education, health care and welfare spending. A result was consecutive budgets that kept most state spending flat. (About one-third of the budget comes from the Federal Government for programs like Medicaid, and that portion continued to grow.)
Fiscal monitors generally hailed that record as a welcome change. But the current budget, adopted last summer, increased spending 5 percent.
"Spending is once again growing faster than inflation," said Mr. Rein, of the Citizens Budget Commission. "And we are very skeptical of their ability to keep the promises for the future that were enacted into law."
Those promises include $2.1 billion a year in state tax cuts, $2.7 billion a year in aid to local governments to pay for property tax cuts, and $1.2 billion in new education programs, a total of $6 billion a year in commitments to be phased in over four years.
Mr. Carroll, of Change-NY, called the spending plan irresponsible. "There is no one who is bigger tax cut fans than we are," he said, "but you simply can't cut taxes and increase spending at the same time. The math doesn't work."

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
But There Is No Peace

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Cut through Benjamin Netanyahu's talk, and the reality is plain. The present Government of Israel is not interested in making peace with the Palestinians.
That is so for a simple reason. There is and always has been only one way to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict: land for peace. And the Netanyahu Government has now made clear that it has no intention of withdrawing from enough of the land Israel occupies in the West Bank to make a deal imaginable. 
 Last week the Netanyahu Cabinet resolved that Israel must retain permanent control of all Jewish settlement areas in the West Bank, routes for future highways, security zones on the borders and "enveloping Jerusalem," water and other "infrastructure," and "historic sites sacred to the Jewish people." Israel Radio estimated that this would leave 60 percent of the West Bank under Israeli control.
The Cabinet position mocks United Nations Resolution 242, with its call for withdrawal from occupied territories to "secure and recognized" borders. The framers of the resolution and other statesmen read it to allow at most minor border adjustments.
Moreover, the part of the West Bank the Netanyahu Government would allot to Palestinians would be cut up into little islands: bantustans without economic or political viability. No conceivable Palestinian leader would consider such a proposition.
The Cabinet declaration followed another demarche by the Netanyahu Government: a list of politically impossible conditions that the Palestinian Authority must fulfill before Israel carries out its commitment to make further interim withdrawals from the West Bank.
One demand, for example, was that the Authority hand over Palestinians accused of terrorism to Israel. Yasir Arafat would probably be overthrown if he did that. Prime Minister Netanyahu would not turn over to the Palestinian Authority Israelis arrested for killing Palestinians. Israel's law forbids extradition of its citizens to any other country.
Another demand was that the Palestinian Authority suppress "hostile propaganda" by, among others, journalists and preachers. Would Mr. Netanyahu silence Israelis hostile to the Palestinians? Would he silence religious extremists of the kind who called Yitzhak Rabin a traitor for signing the Oslo Agreement?
Under the heading of "reciprocity," Mr. Netanyahu demanded that the Palestinian Authority take tougher security measures against terrorism. But as Henry Siegman of the Council on Foreign Relations pointed out in an analysis for The Boston Globe, Israeli Government officials negotiated a detailed security protocol with the Authority -- and Mr. Netanyahu rejected it.
Mr. Netanyahu's actions show that he is trying to do two things at the same time. For the sake of relations with the United States, he wants to keep alive the illusion that he is ready for peace negotiations. But he wants to assure his Government coalition, further to the right since David Levy's departure, that the idea of negotiations is going nowhere.
That poses a formidable challenge to President Clinton. He and his advisers know what Mr. Netanyahu is up to. What should he say when the Prime Minister visits him this week?
Bill Clinton is as warm a friend as Israel has had in the White House. He believes, as did his predecessors, that the long-term interest of Israel lies in peace with the Palestinians, not in unending conflict.
And an American interest is at stake, too. The United States has been, for good reasons, Israel's great supporter. It is the only power that can bring about the peace Israelis need. To allow ourselves to be diddled by Mr. Netanyahu's tactics would be humiliating not only to President Clinton but to this country.
In the circumstances, the wise course is for President Clinton to speak the truth out loud. If the Netanyahu position ends the hope of useful negotiations at this time, it is better to say so than to go on sending missions and pretending. Pretending can only delegitimize the idea of peace.
It will hardly be easy for the President. Prime Minister Netanyahu is a master of the glib, and he will be telling American audiences that he is all for peace. We shall see whether Mr. Clinton has the will to confront him with reality.

HEADLINE: Joseph Murphy, 64, Professor And Ex-Chancellor of CUNY

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
Joseph S. Murphy, the son of a labor organizer and a champion of the working class who became Chancellor of the City University of New York, died in an automobile accident near Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Saturday. He was 64.
Dr. Murphy, whose doctorate was in political science, had just begun a visit to Ethiopia, during the break between CUNY's fall and spring semesters, to carry out research relating to courses in political science that he was teaching at CUNY. He had a long history of humanitarian and educational work in Ethiopia. 
 At his death he held the title of University Professor at CUNY, and was teaching graduate courses in political science at its Graduate School and University Center. He was also teaching political science courses in CUNY's worker education programs, whose students are mostly labor union members who have jobs during the day.
Known for his genial manner and visceral sympathy for the plight of students, Dr. Murphy was able to rebuild and even extend academic programs during his tenure as CUNY Chancellor from 1982 to 1990, despite the system's financial woes.
Dr. Murphy, who learned to speak Yiddish from his mother, a Polish Jew, and Gaelic from his father, an Irish longshoreman, was a political scientist and the author of two books, "The Theory of Universals in Eighteenth Century British Empiricism" (1961) and "Political Theory: A Conceptual Analysis" (1968).
He was known for his ability to combine a practical knowledge of politics with an enduring commitment to the poor and the working class. Highlights of his tenure as Chancellor included the introduction of child care services for working students and the expansion of adult literacy and collaborative programs with the public schools.
He also started a summer remedial course that taught basic skills to incoming freshmen, and a $1.5 billion capital construction program to modernize 13 of the university's 20 campuses.
In an effort to make the administration more reflective of student enrollment, he sought out members of minority groups for top positions. In an editorial marking Dr. Murphy's retirement, The New York Times stated that his "legacy of competence and commitment sets a worthy standard for his successor."
His special interests as a political scientist and an activist included the influence of the American labor movement and the American intellectual left on politics and intellectual life in the United States, including the formation of economic policy.
Born in Newark in 1933, Dr. Murphy attended the University of Colorado and received his bachelor's degree from Olivet College in Michigan in 1955. A recipient of a Woodrow Wilson Fellowship and others, Dr. Murphy received his doctorate from Brandeis University in 1961 and was an assistant professor at Brandeis until 1965.
Dr. Murphy served as director of the Peace Corps' Virgin Island Training Center on St. Croix from 1965 to 1966; as assistant office secretary in the Department of Health Education and Welfare in Washington from 1966 to 1967; as an associate director of the Job Corps in the Office of Economic Opportunity in Washington in 1967 and 1968, and as director of Peace Corps operations in Ethiopia from 1968 to 1970.
He then returned to the United States and held a series of academic posts that eventually led him to head CUNY, the nation's third largest public university.
Dr. Murphy was the Vice Chancellor for Higher Education for the State of New Jersey from 1970 to 1971. He was president of Queens College from 1971 to 1977 and president of Bennington University in Vermont from 1977 to 1982, when he was named Chancellor of CUNY.
Dr. Murphy held a number of posts in Africa. He worked as an election observer in Ethiopia in 1992 and as a consultant for the Constitutional Commission in Addis Ababa in 1993. He had also been a member of the board of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research since 1993 and of the UNESCO Global Project since 1992.
Dr. Murphy is survived by his wife, Susan Crile; his children from a previous marriage, Lisa, of Des Moines, Susanne, of Manhattan, and Peter, of Queens; five grandchildren, and his mother, Doris Murphy of the Bronx.

HEADLINE: Proud to Be the Towns That Taste Forgot;
Wildwoods Stop Lamenting Cheap, Tacky Motels and Start Promoting Them

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: WILDWOOD, N.J., Jan. 16

 BODY:
The last campaign to try to lure the tourists back here promoted the size of the island's beaches, which are so wide that patrols regularly rescue bathers overcome by heat exhaustion as they trudge to and from the water's edge.
Before that, the Mayor of Wildwood, convinced that Atlantic City, 30 miles north, was to blame for a faltering tourist season, decided to fight fire with fire: he brought in Chief Larry Snake of the Delaware tribe of western Oklahoma, who declared a two-and-a-half acre parking lot sacred ancestral land in the failed hopes of turning it into a casino. 
 Now, the answer is the epitome of tackiness.
The newest, most ambitious promotional idea ever unleashed on this barrier island holding the towns of Wildwood, North Wildwood and Wildwood Crest capitalizes on its having the largest collection of screaming, kitschy 50's and 60's motels on five square miles.
More than 250 motels operate here, competing for attention with signs as loud as a chorus of kazoos. They give the Wildwoods a Twilight Zonelike feel of a place trapped in another era, and for the longest time, they have been blamed for keeping the island from reaching its full tourist potential. But lately, with the 20th century slipping away, there has been a definite shift in attitude.
The motels (as well as the island's aluminum diners and fluorescent boardwalk buildings) are beginning to acquire the historic cachet of original Levittown Cape Cods. Architects and design students from all over marvel at them. Historians write about them. Photographers and artists study their smallest details. The question, now, is how to make tourists want to flock to them.
To Steven Izenour, a professor of architecture at the University of Pennsylvania's Graduate School of Fine Arts, the answer is plain: "Turn up the volume." He and nine students, in collaboration with professors and students from the Yale University School of Architecture, have unveiled the first half of a yearlong study for promoting the Wildwoods by exploiting the candy-colored, flat-roofed, low-rent parking garage-like commercial architecture -- especially the neon signs, plastic palm trees and kidney-shaped pools.
"Wildwood has the greatest treasure trove of 50's and 60's commercial architecture I've ever seen in one place," he said, after a two-hour public presentation of the plan here the other day. "It can be a counter-Disney. The kind of ad hoc funkiness of a place like Wildwood is what makes it so interesting. The more you have Disney, the more you need Wildwood."
The plan, endorsed by city officials, motel owners and just about everyone else who has seen it, plots the resurrection of Wildwood by such notions as making the motels' huge signs twice as big, making the plastic palm trees taller, adding loud, vintage commercial signs to the tops of buildings and painting buildings lots of bright colors.
This isn't the first time someone has suggested promoting the island's gaudiness. A few years ago, a local group began tours of what it called the island's "doo-wop" architecture. (The tours were canceled for lack of interest, but "doo-wop" has stuck.) The Doo-Wop Preservation League, where the plan was presented, is dedicated to celebrating the anticlassic buildings that some people have advocated tearing down. But the Ivy League plan goes further, by suggesting that the aging motels do need some sprucing up.
To one motel owner, Lester Katsanis, that is an idea whose time is long overdue. "We've already done $25,000 in improvements," said Dr. Katsanis, a chemist who bought the Quebec Motel 12 years ago. "We've always said there is no place like Wildwood. We've got the cleanest water, the biggest beaches and the motels that are museums of Americana. People love them."
Still, he and Tony Totah, a marine biologist who owns a five-unit apartment complex, said a tourist plan should mention some natural wonders here as well. "We've got all kinds of marine life in our waters," Mr. Totah said. "We have whales, dolphins, seals, turtles. It's great to focus on the motels, but Wildwood is great in lots of ways."
Wildwood's Mayor, Fred Wager, also wanted a wider focus of interest. "I think it's a great thing," he said of the study. "And I think there's a lot of culture here. We're creating historic districts all over. We have the cleanest, safest beach in the country. And we have more rides on our boardwalk than Disney World."
There is a peculiar habit here of comparing Wildwood with Disney at every turn, though the town is more reminiscent of pre-casino Atlantic City. It is, in every way, a summer place. Most of the stores -- and motels -- are closed until May, and more than a quarter of the population is currently unemployed. Buildings are boarded, streets are empty and seagulls waddle around with no fear of cars or people.
Ke Feng, a 24-year-old architect from Beijing on a one-year visa to study at the University of Pennsylvania, was, like many young people, utterly smitten with the anti-Disney neon of motels like the Lollipop and the Stardust. "I've only been in this country since September," he said. "I found the architecture in Wildwood very interesting. It's very different from China."
He had the unenviable task of studying the island's traffic patterns and improving the parking lots. He created, among other things, a two-tier garage painted in black and yellow diagonal stripes with huge billboards on top, changing rooms and bathrooms in lots near the beaches.
But could this be done? Mr. Izenour, who will work with Mr. Ke and a group of Yale students and colleagues on the second half of the project, has made a career of creating comprehensive studies for communities. "We did one in Atlantic City when the casinos were approved," he said. "It was completely ignored.
"But this time," he added, opening his hand to show a stack of business cards from interested parties, "this time, I think at least some of it is going to happen."

Long-suffering Wildwood, N.J., five square miles of screaming neon from the 50's and 60's, is saying: Forget the Donald. Go for the Cleavers. Bigger plastic palms. Louder colors. Vintage signs.
