HEADLINE: This Term, a New Dynamic for Whitman and Legislature

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
When Christine Todd Whitman was sworn into office as Governor four years ago, she demanded immediate legislative action on her bold campaign pledge to cut state income taxes. Most lawmakers, cowed by her defeat of an incumbent governor, overcame their skepticism and went along with her plan.
But as Mrs. Whitman begins her second and final term on Tuesday, she can no longer issue edicts and expect her fellow Republicans in the Legislature to fall in line. Republicans control both houses, but her narrow re-election victory has tipped the balance of power toward them. And they have hinted that they are prepared to set the state's agenda for the next four years if she does not have the vision to formulate one for them. 
 Nevertheless, Mrs. Whitman said in an interview last week that she was undaunted by the challenges of being a lame-duck governor, and she dismissed the view that her political clout had been diminished.
"I got elected, and that is the bottom line," she said. "Everybody else has this thing about 'close election victory.' I really don't think it matters. I am the only Republican to carry the state of New Jersey since 1985. I have done it twice now. And this is not a state given to Republicans. Would I have loved to have won bigger? Of course."
She also said she did not care what the pundits have to say about a decline in her "national standing." She points out that the number of speaking requests from Republican Party leaders and candidates across the country has not declined.
Even before her narrow victory, Mrs. Whitman's decision to veto legislation banning a type of late-term abortion diminished her chances of winning her party's nomination for national office. The State Legislature overrode her veto last month.
Just a few days ago, the Republican National Committee considered a resolution to bar party support for anyone opposed to such a ban. Knowing she has become a popular target for more conservative members of her own party, Mrs. Whitman chose not to lobby against the resolution, which ultimately failed.
"At this point, it is better if I don't, because I tend to be a lightning rod for people on the other side," she said. "And to me, it is much more important that the party not do this for emotional reasons. It is the wrong thing to do to start setting litmus tests."
In her inaugural address, Mrs. Whitman said she would call for more preservation of open space and unveil plans to help bolster the state's ailing cities.
She has already shown a willingness to tackle unpopular issues.
In her annual address to the Legislature last week, she proposed requiring municipalities to seek voter approval for property tax increases above the rate of inflation. She called for an end to tenure for school principals and for sweeping changes in the civil service system. On auto insurance, she did not offer a specific plan, but set a March 30 deadline to sign legislation into law to reduce rates.
In her most politically contentious move, she also called for a referendum on merging some of the state's 616 school districts. She said New Jerseyans would have to give up some local control over public schools if they wanted to reduce the cost of public education, which makes up about two-thirds of local property tax bills. "Let's have the discussion," she said. "Let's not play games with the people."
While Republican legislative leaders offered broad praise for her ideas last week, they have already begun to question her proposals, particularly the forced merging of school districts.
Mrs. Whitman said she was not surprised by that reaction. "Those are not things that are going to come easily," she said. "They will take some time to get done because they are fairly major. But I am used to hearing naysayers."
Complicating Mrs. Whitman's ability to set the legislative agenda in the next four years could be the political ambitions of the two top Republican leaders. Both Assembly Speaker Jack Collins and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco are said to be considering a bid for the Republican gubernatorial nomination in 2001.
Mr. DiFrancesco wasted no time last week offering his own vision for the next four years. At the swearing-in ceremony for members of the Senate, he delivered a speech that focused on improving the state's transportation system, to which Mrs. Whitman has paid scant attention.
Yet despite the talk of the potential for conflict, Mr. DiFrancesco and Mr. Collins insist they each have a good working relationship with the Governor. They point out that the Legislature has already begun to play a larger role, shaping state policy in the final two years of Mrs. Whitman's first term.
"As of this moment, I don't think that it has changed very much," Mr. DiFrancesco said of the Governor's relationship with the Legislature. "She seems a little more relaxed. The way that we get along is that we talk. We have worked very closely together and we will continue to work closely together."
Stephen Salmore, a political consultant to Republican candidates and a visiting political science professor at Drew University, said that Mrs. Whitman's biggest challenge would be cajoling lawmakers to support her agenda. "She comes in without the enthusiasm and expectations that she did four years ago," he said. "And no one owes her anything."
He said he believed that Mrs. Whitman laid out interesting proposals in her speech last week. "But the reaction from lawmakers was tepid," he said. "I think the reaction reflects the skepticism about whether she will really push for her ideas."
Mrs. Whitman said she was prepared to do what it took to get the job done. "I am going to continue to speak out," she said. "I don't have to aggressively jam down everyone's throat all the good things that have happened. On the other hand, you want people to know what we have done."

HEADLINE: WAVE OF MERGERS IS RECASTING FACE OF BUSINESS IN U.S.

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Not since a wave of industrial takeovers created the great oil, steel and auto companies at the beginning of the century has corporate America been reshaped by a sweep of merger activity as broad as the one taking place today.
Last year alone, a record $1 trillion in mergers took place involving American companies, a pace almost unrivaled in business history. 
 Practically every industry in America has been affected -- from telecommunications to banking and from aerospace to accounting. The strength of this trend is shown by the fact that the total dollar value of the mergers in 1997 was about 50 percent higher than those in 1996, itself a record year. Companies are combining to create new entities on a scale larger than anything before, reflecting a growing belief among Government regulators, and many business executives, that big business is not necessarily bad.
"This is an astonishing merger wave," said Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, which regulates mergers. "We haven't seen anything like this in quite some time. More and more deals we see really should be judged on a global market scale, not just on national or local markets. Mergers go through now that would have been challenged just 10 years ago because competition now comes from all corners of the world."
"I do not believe that size alone is a basis to challenge a merger transaction," he added.
Propelling this trend are several factors: An end to the cold war has ushered in a new era of political stability and expanding capitalism, opening new markets in Europe and Asia. As a result, American companies have had to strengthen themselves to exploit new opportunities abroad and to fend off increasingly aggressive overseas competitors. This all comes at a time when a surging stock market and bargain-basement interest rates make financing these transactions easy.
Most of the mergers in the United States have involved domestic corporations. But there have also been an increasing number of deals between American and overseas companies. And a similar wave of mergers is taking place abroad, with European and Asian companies seeking dominant roles in the global economy.
Indeed, when some companies in an industry merge, others come under pressure to do the same to remain competitive.
What is happening at the end of the 20th century is a reprise of the industrial upheavals that took place at the beginning of the century, when more than two dozen auto companies merged in 1908 to create the General Motors Corporation and when the financier J. P. Morgan paid $1.4 billion in 1901 to acquire Carnegie Steel and dozens of others and created the United States Steel Corporation.
The U. S. Steel combination set a record that remained unbroken for more than half a century. Today, billion-dollar deals are far more common. In 1997, there were 156 mergers of $1 billion or more involving American companies -- a number 60 percent higher than the figure from just a year earlier, when 97 mergers exceeded $1 billion, according to the Securities Data Company, a research concern in Newark.
In the last three years, more than 27,600 companies joined hands, completing more mergers than in the entire decade of the 1980's, once considered the high point for mergers.
"The whole private sector of our economy has undergone a truly unbelievable transformation," said Richard L. Huber, chief executive of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, which became the nation's largest managed health care company through mergers, including the $8.9 billion acquisition of U. S. Healthcare in 1996. "Companies have decided to go for size. They've made a decision to go for big scale or fall back and be a niche player. There is no middle ground."
As a result, many industries are finding themselves with fewer but bigger companies, each one usually taking a bigger market share. For example, mergers have reduced the number of large military contractors to three -- the Boeing Company, the Raytheon Company and the Lockheed Martin Corporation, which itself was created from five companies and is pursuing a sixth.
Federal regulators have seen a doubling in the number of Hart-Scott-Rodino filings -- which are required for all proposed mergers exceeding $15 million -- in the last five years, to 3,700 for the Government's 1997 fiscal year, which ended on Sept. 30.
The economic turmoil in Asia has not yet dampened the trend. Since the Asian problems intensified in October, merger filings with the Government have steadily increased each month, said Connie Robinson, director of merger enforcement at the Justice Department. In fact, in the opening days of 1998, the telecommunications industry continued its hot streak with AT&T's $11.3 billion offer for Teleport Communications Group and SBC Communications' $4.4 billion offer for Southern New England Telecommunications.
The rationale behind today's mergers is different from what motivated the merger barons at the beginning of the 20th century. It is also different from the motivation of the hostile takeover artists who roiled corporate America in the 1980's. And, of course, it could all come to an end if the stock market falls and interest rates climb.
While the 20th century opened with a wave of industrial consolidation aimed at forming domestic monopolies, today's mergers are driven by a desire to gain global reach.
In the 1980's, meanwhile, many takeovers were hostile deals that were heavily financed by debt and were based on breaking up corporations and selling their parts. Today's mergers, however, are usually aimed at building companies and are financed primarily with corporate stock, not borrowed money.
As such, many acquiring corporations have benefited from the surging American stock market, raising the value of the shares that are used as currency in acquisitions.
American corporations now realize that after nearly a decade of reorganizing and downsizing, they cannot wring much more profitability through cost cuts and layoffs, so many are joining forces to remain industrial leaders.
"All the cost-cutting and downsizing that took place in the early 1990's, for which business was so soundly criticized, is finally paying off," said Robert Cotter, co-head of mergers at Salomon Smith Barney. "Now that these companies have rid themselves of excess costs and debt, they've got a lot of capital to invest."
Meanwhile, cold war uncertainties have been replaced around the world with a desire to achieve a rising standard of living -- which opens markets for American products, services and expertise.
"In the 1980's, people talked about globalism but weren't acting globally," said Anthony Magro, head of the merger department at Bear, Stearns & Company. "Now they are. American business used to ask, 'What is wrong with us?' But Europe goes into a slump. Japan goes into a slump. Capitalism wins and the cold war ends. There is American business left standing alone with a rising stock market and the world appearing to be its oyster."
An example of how these factors came together is the $6.9 billion takeover of the Fort Howard Corporation, a paper company, by James River, a former competitor, creating the Fort James Corporation, now the nation's No. 2 consumer paper company. The deal brings together complementary product lines, Fort Howard's superior manufacturing lines and James River's marketing prowess to better take on the bigger Kimberly-Clark and Procter & Gamble.
"This is a merger of coequals who are better off together than apart," said Miles Marsh, Fort James's chief executive. "It pushes us forward in that grand opportunity that lies ahead of us called worldwide growth."
The biggest deal of 1997 was the $36.5 billion takeover bid for MCI Communications by Worldcom Inc., based in Jackson, Miss. That deal, which is subject to approval by the Justice Department, was the latest in more than $100 billion of deals since the telecommunications industry was deregulated in 1996.
In the last five years, there have been 2,492 mergers worth more than $200 billion among commercial banks; 1,435 deals worth $162 billion in radio and television, and 5,114 deals worth $110 billion in the insurance industry, according to Securities Data.
Other areas with heavy merger activity in the last five years are health services, with $107 billion in deals; investment brokers, $104 billion; utilities, $100 billion; oil and gas refining, $96 billion, and hotels and casinos, $84 billion.
So far, little concern has been expressed in Washington. The Government has shifted its antitrust policy from well-known rules that restricted big mergers to a more flexible economic analysis that allows more big companies to unite. Still, not all deals pass muster.
The F.T.C., for instance, halted a proposed $4 billion merger last year between Office Depot Inc. and Staples Inc., the nation's two largest office supply retailers. While the move surprised many, Mr. Pitofsky of the F.T.C. said the deal was rejected because evidence showed that consumers in areas where there was only one office superstore paid higher prices than consumers in areas with competition.
By contrast, the Government cleared Boeing's $15 billion acquisition of the commercial aircraft manufacturer McDonnell Douglas because the Government found that airlines said it made no difference whether the two combined.
Besides, Boeing faces a formidable worldwide competitor in Airbus, the European consortium, and the McDonnell Douglas acquisition reflects a global strategy.
"We have very flexible guidelines," Ms. Robinson of the Justice Department said. "Bigness in and of itself doesn't tell me much. I want to know about the market, the players and what competition exists to judge."
How long this merger pace can continue is anyone's guess. A falling stock market could end it. Should worldwide economic growth slow, the demand for American goods and services could be dampened. And, some companies may simply have so much internal trouble digesting mergers that any hunger for further acquisitions will vanish.
"What could derail this?" asked Steven Heller, head of global mergers at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "An upward movement in interest rates, a downdraft in the stock market, a worldwide credit crunch, an industrial recession. If those things happened, we could see a change. Or it could be something that just comes out of the blue."

HEADLINE: Pataki Seeks Aid For Drivers

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 18

 BODY:
The budget proposal that Gov. George E. Pataki plans to present on Tuesday will contain a few election-year treats for New York State's drivers.
Offering a glimpse of his 1998-99 budget proposal, Mr. Pataki said today that he would call for more money to repair the state's roads and bridges, as well as a significant cut in the fee people pay to register their cars. 
 The Governor said his plan would provide an additional $200 million over the next two years to a $12.7 billion program that the Legislature approved in 1995 to repair roads and bridges across the state by the year 2000.
His proposal would increase the amount of money the state plans to spend on such repair projects to $1.7 billion from $1.6 billion in both 1998 and 1999. He said the plan would create an additional 3,500 jobs in areas like construction and make traveling easier for drivers and passengers on New York roads.
"These additional projects will further improve the safety of New York's roads and bridges while also providing a boost to the economic expansion that is currently taking place in New York," Mr. Pataki said in a statement.
The Governor said his budget would also call for a $13, or 25 percent, cut in the $54 fee that drivers pay every two years to register their cars. That would save New Yorkers $50 million. If approved by the Legislature, the fee reduction would start in July.
"Whether it's through tax cuts or fee reductions, I am committed to putting more money back in the pockets of hard-working New Yorkers," Mr. Pataki said. "The $50 million fee reduction will make owning and driving a car less expensive for millions of middle-class New Yorkers."

HEADLINE: Critics Say Rockefeller Drug Laws Pack the Prisons, Force Plea Deals and Hit Small-Timers the Hardest

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
In the 25 years since New York enacted some of the toughest drug laws in the country, drug dealers, prosecutors and defense lawyers have increasingly found ways of working around the laws or using them in a manner never intended, softening the goal of putting away hardened drug traffickers, say many people involved in drug cases.
The laws, pushed through the Legislature in 1973 by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, have come under periodic attack by critics who say they have clogged the state's prisons without making a dent in the problem of illegal drugs. The echoes of that debate surfaced again last month, when Gov. George E. Pataki commuted the prison sentences of three people serving long mandatory sentences for nonviolent drug crimes. 
 Mr. Pataki granted similar clemencies in the past, and in 1995 he called for changing the Rockefeller drug laws to allow more nonviolent offenders to avoid long jail terms. But such proposals have gone nowhere, in part because politicians are so wary of being labeled as soft on crime.
The Rockefeller laws, which require sentences as high as 15 years to life, have packed the state's prisons with tens of thousands of drug felons and added hundreds of millions of dollars to annual prison expenses. But rather than imprison major drug dealers for long periods, some prosecutors and defense lawyers say, the laws have instead hit more low-level couriers and addicts selling to support their habits, because more of them are arrested.
Over the years, most dealers have learned how to avoid a long stretch in prison by having an addict or even a child carry the drugs for them. As a result, the mandatory minimums have often hit amateurs like Angela Thompson, who was convicted at age 17 of selling two ounces of cocaine to an undercover police officer at the behest of her drug-dealing uncle. She served more than 8 years of a 15-year minimum sentence before being granted clemency by Governor Pataki last month.
But prosecutors have also found that they can wield the laws as a powerful weapon to force low-level or middle-level dealers who are arrested to trade information implicating accomplices or higher-ups, in exchange for lesser sentences.
"There is no question they've made prosecution easier," said Robert H. Silbering, who retired last month after working since 1991 as New York City's special narcotics prosecutor. "If you didn't have the Rockefeller drug laws, you'd probably have a greater number of drug cases going to trial, and you might have gridlock in the courts."
As a result, however, those with no useful information to trade or with little savvy about manipulating the system seem to absorb the full brunt of the law.
"The serf has often ended up with a far worse sentence than the boss, because the serf didn't know anybody to give up," said Charles D. Adler, a Manhattan defense lawyer who has pressed for alternative sentencing. He recalled defending a client caught carrying narcotics for her boyfriend, who was a professional drug dealer. The boyfriend cooperated and got lifetime probation. She got 15 years in prison.
Defense lawyers have sometimes tried to avoid the laws' tough penalties by steering clients into Federal court, whenever a claim can be made for Federal jurisdiction, because the sentences there are relatively less Draconian.
Lloyd Epstein, a lawyer who practices in both Federal and state courts, gave a stark example of the discrepancy between sentences in the two systems. He represented a Venezuelan courier who swallowed some cocaine-filled condoms before flying to New York. The courier became ill after leaving the airport and required emergency surgery to remove the cocaine. After recovering, the smuggler faced a minimum of 15 years in a New York prison, which Mr. Epstein plea-bargained down to 6 years under a less punitive category of the law covering a smaller quantity of drugs.
"If he'd gotten sick inside the airport," Mr. Epstein said, "he could have gotten only 18 months under Federal law."
All 50 states have some form of mandatory sentences. New York's basic Rockefeller drug law compels state judges to mete out a sentence ranging from 15 years to life to anyone convicted of selling two ounces, or possessing four ounces, of an illegal drug like heroin or cocaine. The law sets shorter mandatory sentences for possession or sale of smaller amounts.
In fact, statistics suggest that few defendants receive the maximum sentence because so many plead guilty to a lesser offense. During the first nine months of 1997, only 585 of the 10,062 indictments returned in drug felony cases were for felonies requiring a sentence of 15 years to life.
But that number includes minor figures who insist on going to trial and are then convicted, leaving the judge with no alternative but to impose the mandatory sentence. In one such earlier case, Anthony Papa, a radio repairman, got 15 years to life for carrying four and a half ounces of cocaine. He served more than 11 years in Sing Sing before he was granted clemency by Governor Pataki and released last January.
A second law requires long prison terms for former inmates who served a drug felony sentence and then commit another felony within 10 years. This law has locked up more people than the first law, Mr. Adler said, because a defendant who pleads guilty to a lesser crime in return for a lighter sentence becomes a convicted felon and faces mandatory prison time for the next offense, even if it is unrelated to or less serious than the first.
As of a year ago, almost a third of New York State's nearly 70,000 inmates were locked up for nonviolent drug crimes at an annual cost of more than $600 million. They included 8,760 drug felons incarcerated at an annual cost of more than $260 million under the first law, according to the Correctional Association of New York, an advocacy group trying to improve prison conditions. In addition, 13,075 drug offenders were incarcerated under the second-felony offender law, at an annual cost of more than $390 million. (There is some overlap between the categories.)
Yet some police investigators and street researchers report that hard drugs are more widely available in New York now than they were 25 years ago. One reason is that a new pusher is always ready to take over the sales of an arrested pusher. "What the Rockefeller laws set out to do has simply not been accomplished," said Stephanie Herman, a drug researcher at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice.
State Senator Catherine M. Abate, a Manhattan Democrat, said the Rockefeller law's greatest weakness is that it "does not distinguish between a kingpin and a drug mule." Last January, she joined State Senator Dale M. Volker, a Republican, in sponsoring legislation giving judges discretion to impose a lesser sentence if the offense was confined to a single incident and unconnected to broader drug trafficking. The bill has languished.
Because locking up each inmate costs the state about $30,000 a year, critics say it would be cheaper to put nonviolent addicts into treatment programs. "My constituents don't want drug dealers on the street and neither do I," said Daniel L. Feldman, the chairman of the Corrections Committee in the State Assembly. "But there's nothing dumber than what we're doing now."
Efforts to change the laws have fallen victim to state politics, say some legislators and officials close to Governor Pataki. Because Democrats who control the Assembly are more interested in modifying the law, Republicans who dominate the Senate would like to squeeze Democratic concessions on other legislation. Some upstate Republicans also do not want the laws changed because they have brought new prisons, and new jobs, to their economically depressed constituencies.
But while politicians continue to debate the laws, almost everyone else has learned to live with them. Mr. Epstein, who has represented hundreds of drug defendants, said, "Dealers work around New York's laws by having a low-level employee, often an addict, hold the drugs, so the dealer can walk free."
Marc Mauer, director of the Sentencing Project, a prison reform group based in Washington, said some dealers have children carry the drugs because they are not subject to mandatory minimums.
One addict who is now in a drug treatment program said that when he could no longer afford to buy crack cocaine, he jumped at the chance to get his drugs free. He took on the risky job of holding the stash of crack for a Bronx street dealer, so if the police swooped in, the dealer could avoid a long stretch in prison. "I ended up selling for them," he said. "I held it."
District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens has viewed the Rockefeller drug laws from several perspectives.
As a lobbyist for New York City in Albany when the laws were enacted, he warned that they would overwhelm the prisons. Later as a judge, he bridled at restrictions on his ability to impose sentences. Now as Queens District Attorney, he said, the same laws make it easier to combat drug trafficking. Despite his frustration as a judge, he said: "I wonder where we'd be today if we didn't have the Rockefeller drug laws. Perhaps we'd be worse off."
Even so, Mr. Brown said, "I think in the long run we would have been better off if we took the money and used it for prevention, treatment and education."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (94%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (79%);

HEADLINE: Essay;
Gravy Trains Don't Run on Time

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The great lesson of the financial meltdown of Asian autocracies is this: Freedom is indivisible. Economic freedom cannot exist without political freedom.
For decades, Asian dictators claimed that they had perfected a higher form of capitalism. Those in power would determine which entrepreneurs would succeed, and these -- related by blood or bound by kickback to the politicians -- would maintain position by perpetuating the dynasty. 
 The world was assured by such philosophers as Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew that a concern for individual liberty was merely a "decadent Western value," and that Asians had discovered that a one-party state with a strong ruler could better provide the stability for growth.
In that Singapore model, taken up throughout Asia, society's order took precedence over individual freedom. Petty crime was crushed along with political opposition.
Western executives who hated the rigors of competition in a free market were pleased to invest in what seemed to be a sure-thing society. The greasing of government palms -- without the scrutiny of a free press or the restraint of independent judiciaries -- was advertised as a newly stable form of capitalism.
Growth-befuddled bureaucrats at the World Bank joined compilers of economic-freedom indexes to endorse such state-controlled commerce. They justified the secret dealing by peddling the notion that such license to do business among power elites would someday lead to political freedom.
It led to collapse. The waves of panic in Asia today, likely to be followed by despair and class resentment, show how wrong these fake capitalists were. The outstretched hand of local politics is no match for the invisible hand of the global market.
The dictatorial model, driven by mutual back-scratching of elites rather than a profit motive open to all, rewarded despotism and nepotism at the expense of efficiency and transparency. Now eyes are opening all over the world to the realization that the gravy train does not run on time.
Communism, socialism, fascism and "crony capitalism" not only interfere with the free flow of capital to the best producer, but also deny the consumer the right to decide which products succeed. Once again autocrats and their acolytes are learning that government's business in business is to protect competition in business.
Consider Indonesia: The Suharto family, until the recent plunge of the rupiah, was probably richer than Bill Gates. International banks were imprudently lending the President's favored companies as much as desired for patently unproductive uses.
But American politicians and investors cannot tut-tut at Suharto predations without hypocrisy because many were buying into that vaunted "model." One flagrant example is how the Riady family, tightly tied into Suharto's deals, bought influence with candidate Clinton, parlaying that advertisable White House connection into politico-economic deals in Indonesia and China.
Small wonder, then, that before Congress approves the $43 billion bailout of Indonesia through the I.M.F., Suharto will be expected to produce James Riady and Arief "James Riady sent me" Wiriadinata, to testify in the U.S. about the campaign and business activities of the longtime Riady employee John Huang, as well as those of "the two Marks" -- Middleton and Grobmyer -- friends and fund-raisers for the Clintons who showed such an interest in Indonesia.
Infectious dealing among people in power and people with money is not an Asian virus; it is a global virus. The yearning for human freedom that undergirds democratic capitalism and produces stable prosperity is not a Western value, but a universal value.
Taiwan, the Philippines, South Korea, Thailand and even Japan show signs of grasping this; Indonesia's Suharto, fearful of a successor who will track down and recover stolen billions, will sign anything; Vietnam, Malaysia and the powerful Lee family of Singapore still don't get it.
The question about the shakeout in Asia is not whether its resourceful, democratizing nations will recover; they will. The question is whether the political leaders and crony capitalists of Russia and China will get the message, gained at such pain, that there can be no stable prosperity without political freedom.

HEADLINE: Budget Heroes Include Bush and Gorbachev

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Who should get credit for the fact that the Federal budget is now virtually balanced?
Economists and budget experts trying to answer that question have offered some predictable and some unusual suggestions as they celebrate the possible demise of the deficit. 
 Among those entitled to take credit, they said, is President Clinton, as well as President George Bush, who agreed to the first big deficit-reduction package, and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who has continually encouraged such efforts.
The experts also gave credit to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Kremlin leader who presided over the collapse of the Soviet Union. The end of the cold war allowed the United States to cut military spending, and those cuts have been indispensable to progress on balancing the budget.
Plainly, the political parties had a role, though not so grand as they will say in this fall's elections.
Republicans have waged a 17-year campaign to shrink the Government and rein in domestic spending and have tirelessly preached the gospel of fiscal responsibility even as they were voting for tax cuts that increased the deficit. Democrats have historically preferred deficit-reduction bills that emphasized raising taxes but have recently been willing to vote for measures that curbed the growth of spending as well.
While politicians relish the prospect of a balanced budget, few take credit for the specific steps that produced it. Republicans do not brag about the laws that raised taxes in 1990 and 1993. Democrats do not boast about having cut the growth of veterans' benefits, farm subsidies and Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals.
The strong American economy has generated a torrent of new tax revenue and sharply reduced the demand for food stamps and public assistance. But in retracing the steps to a balanced budget, experts also cite factors not found in economics textbooks -- factors like Ross Perot and dumb luck.
James C. Miller 3d, who was President Ronald Reagan's budget director from 1985 to 1988, said "the entrepreneurial spirit of the American people," which has sustained seven years of economic growth, was another important reason for the prospect of a balanced budget.
Martha H. Phillips, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a bipartisan group that lobbies for a balanced budget, said: "The economy gets an A plus. The economy and the taxpayers have to get the bulk of the credit."
In the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30, the Federal budget deficit was $22 billion, down from the record of $290 billion in 1992, and the Congressional Budget Office said recently that the budget was likely to be "essentially balanced" for the next 10 years if current policies remained unchanged. Individual income tax payments soared 12 percent last year, to $737 billion.
Robert D. Reischauer, who was director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1989 to 1995, said, "The situation we are in right now is a result of a very strong economy, wise fiscal policy adopted in 1990 and 1993, enlightened monetary policy over the last seven years and a substantial dash of good luck."
Rudolph G. Penner, the director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1983 to 1987, said: "Monetary policy has been extraordinarily skillful in recent years. But we've also been extraordinarily lucky. There haven't been any adverse shocks to the economy."
Mr. Perot, who ran as an independent in the 1992 Presidential race and as the candidate of the new Reform Party in 1996, also gets some credit. His televised talks drew attention to the fact that the Federal Government was running big deficits.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a former coordinator of economic policy for Mr. Clinton, said Mr. Perot, like the Concord Coalition, had contributed to "a drumbeat to reverse the nation's unsustainable fiscal course." And Leon E. Panetta, Mr. Clinton's first budget director, who later became the White House chief of staff, said Mr. Perot had laid "important groundwork for Clinton's willingness to say the time had come to take on this issue."
After Mr. Clinton became President in 1993 and Congress rejected his request for new spending to stimulate the economy, he worked assiduously for the comprehensive legislation to reduce the deficit that was adopted in 1993. It passed by tiny margins: 218 to 216 in the House and 51 to 50 in the Senate, where Vice President Al Gore broke a tie. No Republican in either chamber voted for the measure, which relied heavily on tax increases that affected people with higher incomes.
Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, who became Speaker two years later, said in 1993 that the bill would lead to "a job-killing recession." Another Republican, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, who is now the House majority leader, described the measure as "a recipe for disaster."
But the President says the bill laid a foundation for the subsequent economic boom.
Ms. Tyson said: "For a decade and a half, Republicans had talked about fiscal responsibility. It took a Democratic President working with a Democratic Congress to translate those words into action."
Democrats and some nonpartisan experts say Mr. Bush and his budget director, Richard G. Darman, deserved more credit than they had received.
Mr. Bush won the White House in 1988 with a promise of "no new taxes," and he lost his bid for re-election in part because he broke that pledge when he accepted new taxes as part of a big deficit-reduction bill in 1990.
In a recent interview, former Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who headed the Ways and Means Committee in 1990, said: "George Bush had as much to do with reaching out to balance the budget as anybody I know. He finally recognized that there would have to be revenue increases."
Calculations by Mr. Reischauer, using data from the Congressional Budget Office, suggest that the 1990 bill was the largest deficit-reduction package to date, about 20 percent bigger than the 1993 measure and more than four times as big as the one approved last year.
Mr. Panetta, who was chairman of the House Budget Committee in 1990, said in an interview last week: "George Bush's willingness to sit down and negotiate that agreement was an important first step in reducing the deficit. He paid a political price, but it was the right thing to do."
A solid majority of Congressional Republicans voted against the 1990 bill, and Mr. Bush later said his support for the tax increase was a major mistake. The savings achieved by that law, signed by Mr. Bush in November 1990, were initially swamped by a recession that began in July 1990 and ended in March 1991.
The 1990 law was important not only because it cut spending and raised taxes, but also because it imposed fiscal discipline on Congress through new budget rules. The rules, though seemingly arcane, have proved effective.
For example, the 1990 law established enforceable limits on certain types of Federal spending, which account for about one-third of the budget. The law also required Congress to pay for any tax cuts or legislative changes that increase the cost of entitlement programs like Social Security. This "pay as you go" requirement has discouraged Congress from creating new entitlements.
Moreover, Mr. Darman persuaded Congress to impose new controls on Government loans and loan-guarantee programs. As a result, lawmakers must confront and acknowledge the potential future costs of such commitments.
In the last few years the Federal Government has also benefited from a reduction in the growth of medical spending. Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for poor people, grew more than 25 percent a year in 1991 and 1992, when states were using creative schemes to tap the Treasury. But the growth of Medicaid was less than 4 percent a year in 1996 and 1997.
The growth of Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, has slowed to a lesser degree.
A decline in the number of people receiving and food stamps has also made it easier for Federal officials to balance the budget.
The strong economy has produced jobs for hundreds of thousands of welfare recipients. Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for Republicans on the House Ways and Means Committee, said: "Another factor is even more significant. The 1996 welfare law, with its work requirements, sent new signals about what society expects of welfare recipients."
Federal actions to reduce the deficit appear to have strengthened the economy, even as the strong economy has made it easier for Washington to balance the budget.
Ms. Tyson said the President's commitment to reducing the deficit had been "a significant factor in the better-than-expected performance of the economy."
When the Government borrows less money, interest rates tend to be lower, and private industry can borrow more easily. The cycle reinforces itself. Declining Federal deficits have contributed to economic growth, which generated more revenue for the Treasury, which reduced the deficit further.
Such fiscal restraint became easier after the cold war. From its peak in 1989, military spending has declined by one-third, after adjusting for inflation. Russians hold Mr. Gorbachev responsible for economic chaos and other troubles there. But he is, in Mr. Reischauer's view, "an unsung hero" of America's agonizing struggle to balance its budget.

HEADLINE: Hot and Dirty Jobs End; So Does a Way of Life

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: DOLOMITE, Ala., Jan. 17

 BODY:
Looking into the glowing mouth of the coke ovens, a man could almost imagine what hell is like.
Until Thursday, when the ovens cooled for good, Gary Roberts labored 13 years in the 130-degree heat of the Koppers Industries coke plant in this blue-collar enclave of rusty mills and frayed houses near Birmingham. 
 His skin blistered and his mind sometimes melted into black, and at times he wondered whether he would catch fire as he and 300 others turned the raw coal into the volatile noxious fuel used to produce steel.
"I've had my clothes start smoking," said Mr. Roberts, 44. "My son's hard hat melted on his head."
Then, every payday, Mr. Roberts would peek into the pay envelope and glimpse a bit of heaven. He made $14 to $17 an hour till the fire winked out, until the plant shut down in the midst of what many have called a great American economic recovery. All 300 people are out of work.
Now Mr. Roberts, who abused his body every workday for one of the best paychecks in American labor, puzzles over the prosperity that everyone is talking about. He said he heard about it on television, read about it in newspapers, "and I figure they're talking about somebody else."
Dolomite, these days, is an island of despair, a place of uncertainty in a time when Americans talk about spending money with confidence.
Hard industry like steel mills and the industries that support them have been dying here for three decades.
The remaining plants tend to rely more on machines and less on the flesh-and-blood power that poured the steel and burned the coke. Coke plants like Koppers, besieged by the Environmental Protection Agency for abuses and facing uncertain demands for their product, have just closed their doors.
It does not make the men who worked there feel any better to hear that McDonald's is hiring. When people refer to the closing of Koppers as an end of their way of life, it is more than a blue-collar cliche from the bitterness over lost work.
"It's disheartening," said Mr. Roberts, one of a handful of workers staying on for a few weeks to shut the plant, which opened in 1912. "It was good money." And to earn it, he said, "it took a special breed of man."
It is, say people who work in steel and steel-related industries, the hardest, dirtiest work in a hard and dirty field. At Koppers, bosses took job applicants through the plant before interviewing them, so they could see smut-covered workers breathing through respirators to spare them from poison gases that are a byproduct of the process, so they could feel the heat from furnaces burning at 2,100 degrees.
"At least half of them would just keep walking," said Daniel Hundley, who was a carpenter before the lure of steady paychecks brought him into the coke plant. "You ever jump in a black car on a hot summer day," one with all the windows rolled up? Mr. Hundley asked. "It's a lot like that, 24 hours a day."
The good thing about the plant, one of a few left in the Birmingham area, was that a man always felt that he had earned his pay, said Mr. Hundley, 35. In an odd way, the real pain caused by the work made losing the work harder to take. It was as if the fact that they had survived it, day after day, year after year, bound men and their labor closer.
They will talk about it as if they were describing a live thing that always had them by the throat and then, in the next breath, talk about how much they will miss it.
It was common, the workers said, to see a man sag and collapse, and they knew that the man would not be back for at least three days. It took that long, Mr. Hundley said, for a man to get his head cleared, to get to thinking right again. The workers called it "running hot," like a car engine when the radiator overheats.
"You wear thermal underwear, even in the summer, to keep the heat off you," Mr. Hundley said. "It will hurt you. You wear wooden shoes. If you wear rubber, it will absorb the heat and burn the bottoms of your shoes. I've seen people carried off in ambulances. I've run hot before, and seen little pink elephants. I couldn't figure out where I was."
Mr. Roberts, who worked at a United States Steel coke plant before moving to Koppers, always thought about just walking away, but how does a man abandon $17 an hour, especially a man with no college, no real technical training beyond what he learned in the glow of the ovens?
"I would have liked to have changed fields," Mr. Roberts said, "because I was tired of abusing my body. But this is all I know."
His father retired from a coke plant. Three uncles worked in steel plants. But that was a long time ago, when the evening skies seemed to burn orange from the smokestacks of the mills, and the smut hung over Birmingham skies like a black veil. The air smelled strong, like tar. People down here like to say that it smelled like money.
Mr. Hundley grew up in Pleasant Grove, just north of here. He was a boy in the 1960's, when Birmingham was called "the Pittsburgh of the South."
"All the smokestacks were blowing, people were working," he said. "U.S. Steel would dump its slag after the day was done."
The slag, waste product from the smelting, piled up in what seemed like mountains to the boys his age.
In 1970, 26,400 people worked in steel and steel-related industries in the four counties surrounding Birmingham, according to state figures.
Mr. Roberts and his wife, Mary Ann, raised three children, and the paychecks were regular as a courthouse clock. Makers of coke in Birmingham even exported it to Japan.
In 1980, as the economy shrank, foreign competition loomed and demand plunged. The number of people in steel-related jobs fell to 10,500.
"I got laid off, and I thought it was the end of the world," Mr. Roberts said, but he found a job at another plant, at Koppers. "I figured to retire from there."
A college became Birmingham's new economic mainstay. The University of Alabama at Birmingham's medical school became one of the best in the country.
Wolverine-brand work boots gave way to alligator shoes. The skies cleared. Steel never recovered.
By 1990, the industry had 10,700 jobs. In 1996, the industry had 10,300 directly linked to steel. Steel mills here imported coke from Japan, Mr. Roberts said.
"I wonder if it's that same coke we sent them," he said.
Now the skeletons of the mills stick up like old bones.
"It's a great big graveyard, in a way," Mr. Hundley said.
But if the economy is so good, why not retrain for jobs that are increasing? Like workers in hard industry all over the country, Mr. Roberts and Mr. Hundley know that the jobs politicians talk about are either highly technical ones or those in the low-paying service industry.
Mr. Hundley will retrain for a year at a school in Florida to learn how to repair boat engines and hopes that Federal money will pay for it. But the Federal Jobs Training Partnership Act requires him to train in the state where he worked.
As often happens in Alabama, where Federal programs are concerned, there is a breakdown. Although millions of dollars are available for retraining, the state has only two employees to begin the program.
"The ones I feel the sorriest for are the ones who have been there the longest," Mr. Hundley said. "They haven't learned the skills to do anything else. You take a man 50 years old, it's hard for him to jump into a college and do well."
Mr. Roberts would rather find work in an industry that he knows, even if the sweat does rain off him. But even in his own industry, things have changed too much.
"Nowadays you've got to be a pedigreed dog," he said. "They want a paper on you, saying you can do the work, and it doesn't matter whether you really can."

And to earn it, he said, "it took a special breed of man." (Photographs by Justin Webster for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Housing Hope Of Mentally Ill Is Fading Away

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
NUBY BATCHELOR is more than willing to talk about his past and its long bleak stretches. But he cannot quite join the pieces together. At one point, he says, he was an Army combat instructor. Sometime later, he became a violent alcholic.
He has spent many years, in his words, "in and out of psych wards," and for a period, or perhaps for several different periods, he slept on a park bench in Harlem. He knows that he is not well. 
 These days, he lives in a tiny, meticulously neat apartment in lower Manhattan, filled with electronic equipment he built from kits. He says he is "very, very lucky."
The apartment is a product of a 1990 agreement between Mario M. Cuomo, then the Governor, and David N. Dinkins, then the Mayor, known as New York/New York. Under the accord to provide supportive housing, the two agreed to work together to confront what anyone who walked the city streets at the time could see was the growing problem of the homeless mentally ill.
Both advocates who worked on the original agreement and officials of the current city administration concur that New York/ New York has been effective. In fact, it is one of the rare programs to be initiated in the Dinkins years that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has embraced.
The problem is that the agreement has now lapsed and there is a real chance that it will not be renewed. It took close cooperation between the state and the city to put New York/New York together in the first place, a kind of cooperation that was always unusual and these days is in particularly short supply. (Some advocates for the mentally ill report that the staffs of Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Giuliani are on such bad terms that they often ask the advocates to act as intermediaries.)
Though it could still be resurrected, there will be no provision for financing a new agreement in the budget that the Governor is to release tomorrow.
"New York/New York is one of the great unsung policy success stories," said Julie Sandorf, founder of the Corporation for Supportive Housing. "It not only makes good sense societally, but it's also good economics. And now it's over. I don't get it."
UNDER the New York/New York accord, the city and the state agreed to split the cost of building or refurbishing about 3,000 units of supportive housing where the homeless mentally ill could live and receive on-site counseling.
The program has been expensive. No one has calculated the exact cost, but it is safe to say it has run to hundreds of millions of dollars. But consider the alternatives. It costs roughly $20,000 a year to house someone in a city shelter and $113,000 in a psychiatric hospital. By contrast, it costs roughly $12,000 a year to house a mentally ill person in supportive housing.
Advocates for the mentally ill say that in the absence of a second New York/New York agreement, the city can expect a recurrence of the same dismal conditions that led to New York/New York I -- crowded shelters and a rising number of mentally ill homeless living on the streets. Over the next few years, the state plans to cut its psychiatric hospitals' capacity even further, by nearly 2,000 beds. And already, statistics on homelessness in the city suggest some potentially ominous trends.
After declining for several years, the number of homeless single adults in New York City shelters has begun to climb. Perhaps even more seriously, the proportion of shelter residents who are effectively permanent has been increasing, meaning fewer beds for those who need shelter during a temporary stretch of hard luck.
Clearly mindful of the dangers of repeating history -- and being saddled with the cost of caring for patients the state has deinstitutionalized -- city officials have in recent weeks started to press publicly for a new New York/New York agreement.
"New York/New York I has been a resounding success," Gordon Campbell, the city's Commissioner of Homeless Services, said. "We are committed to development of New York/New York II."
State officials have been pointedly noncommittal. Publicly, they say they are trying to determine whether a second agreement would be cost effective. Privately, they accuse city officials of grandstanding.
"They're not saying how much they are willing to spend and they want us to commit to a number," one state official said.
In the meantime, every month the city finds about 200 people who could be moved into New York/New York housing -- were any available.

HEADLINE: Cuba and the Church Continue To Maneuver Over Pope's Visit

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Jan. 18

 BODY:
With Pope John Paul II scheduled to begin his long-awaited visit to Cuba in just three days, the Cuban Government and the Roman Catholic Church here are locked in behind-the-scenes maneuvering that ultimately will determine to what degree the political impact of the trip is muted or enhanced.
In public, those involved continue to say that the Pope's visit is "purely pastoral" in purpose and that all is proceeding in harmony. 
 And using the newspapers, television and radio stations that Fidel Castro has controlled since 1959, the Cuban President has in recent days sought to portray the Pope as an ally in a struggle against American imperialism.
"We want to see a full house," Mr. Castro said during a five-and-a-half-hour national television appearance that ended early Saturday, adding that he plans to attend a Mass at the Plaza de la Revolucion here on Jan. 25. Cubans should attend "out of courtesy, out of politeness to the visitor," he said, and cautioned, "No one should be shouting 'vivas' at any leader of the revolution."
But at the same time, the Cuban Government has erected obstacles that make it difficult for the church authorities to take their case to Cuba's 11 million people themselves.
Working quietly, the church has been trying to expand the limited space available to it in a one-party state that was officially atheist for 30 years, until 1992. As part of the extensive negotiations that followed the first meeting between John Paul and Mr. Castro, at the Vatican in November 1996, the Cuban church has already secured an increase in visas granted to foreign clergy. It is also pressing for regular access to the state news media and permission to offer religious instruction in schools.
Mr. Castro has sought the papal visit, diplomats and religious leaders here suggested, because he is confident that he can direct its packaging and presentation in a direction that suits his political goals.
They said the Vatican and the Cuban Government have an implicit understanding that the Pope will reiterate the church's longstanding criticisms of the American economic embargo of Cuba and what one senior Cuban official called "the vulgar materialism" of the West.
Referring to the newspaper of Cuba's Communist Party, Mr. Castro said in his televised remarks over the weekend that some of John Paul's speeches read as if they were written by "a journalist from Granma, although of course I am not going to accuse the Pope of being a Communist." The Pope, he added is "a big headache for the unipolar hegemonism of the United States" and "of imperialism, because he is not a man who can be manipulated."
For that reason, it is not correct to classify the Polish-born Pope as the "angel of death for socialism, Communism and revolution," Mr. Castro continued, adding, "He was not the General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union."
Mr. Castro also said, "Instead of a meeting between an angel and the devil, wouldn't it be better to think of a meeting between two angels who are friends of the poor?"
Taking their cue from their leader, other Cuban officials have also spoken with admiration of the Pope and the church's social mission. Ricardo Alarcon, for instance, a former Foreign Minister who is now Speaker of Parliament, has referred to the Pope by such titles as "His Holiness" or "The Holy Father" and dismissed the religious persecutions of the past as a mere "misunderstanding."
At the level of individual churches, though, the situation is far more complicated. Churchgoers, whose numbers have risen rapidly during the "special period" of economic austerity that began with the collapse of the Soviet Union, still complain of official repression of the sort that occurred in the Havana neighborhood of Miramar on Saturday.
Youngsters enrolled in catechism groups at Santa Rita de Casia Church were happily pasting small posters proclaiming the arrival of "the messenger of love and hope" onto trees and poles there.
A police officer on a motorcycle, wearing an imposing helmet and sunglasses, approached them and ordered them to stop. "You know, there's a directive of the party forbidding this," he said sternly.
The adult supervising the children asked, "How can that be if the President himself said on television last night that it's all right, and he is the secretary general of the party?"
"Well, I don't know anything about that," the police officer replied. "All I know is that I've told various other groups to stop, and nobody else has given me any back talk. So it's best that you stop now, because if you don't, people are just going to get upset and tear those posters down."
With that, the children returned to their church as an adult stayed behind. A few minutes later, a man in civilian clothes arrived and told the policeman to let the postering resume. But when a separate group headed out from the church in another direction, it too was rebuffed, this time by a different policeman.
Earlier this month, the Madrid newspaper El Pais reported that church officials had found a bugging device in a house where the Pope is scheduled to stay during his five day-visit, which begins on Wednesday. Cuban officials have denied the report, and Vatican and Cuban church officials declined comment.
As evidence of some easing of restrictions, on the other hand, Jaime Cardinal Ortega last week delivered a half-hour address on state television about the visit, marking the first time since Mr. Castro came to power that a Cuban Cardinal has been permitted to speak to the nation through the mass media. Later, officials said broadcasts of the Pope's Masses here, the subject of more than a year of negotiations, would take place.
In his address, Cardinal Ortega described the Pope not as an anti-Communist first and foremost but as a nationalist whose patriotic pride was wounded by the Soviet occupation of Poland after World War II. Mr. Castro picked up on that theme in his remarks this weekend, drawing an implicit parallel to his own resistance to the dominance of the United States here before 1959.
But despite Mr. Castro's conciliatory words, church officials say that what they really want is regular access to the state media. In its absence, parishes have organized missions that have quietly gone door to door to explain the Pope's role in the church and his background.
The deacon of a small parish church in Regla, a working-class suburb, said that "after all these years, a lot of people know nothing at all" about Catholic teachings. "We have had to explain everything from the beginning, starting with what is the function of a Pope," he added.
Ultimately, diplomats here said, both the Pope and Cardinal Ortega aspire to a much more visible and prominent role for the church here. The precise dimensions of that role have not been made clear, but the church's desire to use the Pope's visit as a springboard are obvious.
In a recent pastoral letter, the Cuban Conference of Bishops declared, "The action of the church in society is not limited to the free exercise of worship." Cardinal Ortega told the Cuban church publication Verdad y Esperanza that the main challenge facing the church after the Pope's departure would be "a dialogue with the state that has yet to start seriously, and which did not advance during the year of preparation for the papal visit."
A Latin American diplomat here put it this way: "The state reserves all power to itself, so there is an institutional vacuum at a time when Cuban society has begun to worry who might guide or broker a transition after Fidel Castro. The church is the sole entity with both the independence and the credibility to allow it to possibly play such a role."
For the moment though, the average Cuban can only watch and wait as church and state jockey. As a group of residents of downtown Havana waited in line today outside a butcher shop across the street from a church, they were asked if they expected the Pope's visit to result in immediate, concrete changes.
"That would be a miracle," one woman said with a laugh. "And as Cubans, though we have learned to hope for miracles, we cannot bring ourselves to believe in miracles."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: 'Year of Woman' Senators In Tough Re-election Races

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 18

 BODY:
The opulent banquet room in the Chicago Hilton and Towers was brimming with Democrats, their $500 gate fees entitling them to an open bar, a roster of spunky speeches and the chance to fatten the re-election campaign coffers of Senator Carol Moseley-Braun.
Sharing the stage with Vice President Al Gore and Senator Richard J. Durbin, among others, Senator Moseley-Braun addressed the crowd. 
 "There's just no question in my mind but that I could not do this without you," she told them, smiling gratefully. "I couldn't continue to put up with the battles and the fights and the troubles and the trials and the raising the money and all the rest of it that I know everybody in this room knows about."
The "troubles and the trials" were taken by many at the fund-raising reception last Tuesday to be an oblique reference to a string of episodes that have stung the Senator in her time in office, raising questions about her judgment on issues including campaign finances, her choice of staff and a secretive trip to Nigeria to meet that country's dictator.
As Ms. Moseley-Braun wages her battle for re-election this year, things are quite different from the way they were in her blockbuster senatorial campaign in 1992. Then, Ms. Moseley-Braun sprang from the obscurity of the Recorder of Deeds office in Cook County, marshaled the anger of female voters in both parties over the male monopoly in Congress, unseated a veteran Democrat and cruised to victory over a Republican rival to become the first African-American woman elected to the United States Senate.
Her stunning success, along with that of other female candidates, gave 1992 the label Year of the Woman. Now, many view Ms. Moseley-Braun as one of the most vulnerable senators, unlikely to maintain the support of the white suburban women who helped elect her last time. And analysts say she will have to work to shore up her base of support by showing her effectiveness as a senator. The challenge for her, experts say, is to dispel the negative images of her first years.
But she is not the only woman facing a re-election fight. Two other Senators elected in 1992, Barbara Boxer of California and Patty Murray of Washington, are also believed to be in for a battle, a surprising turn in a year when a strong economy and relative social and political calm are expected to make re-election easy for most incumbents.
"All three of them are considered vulnerable," said Susan J. Carroll, research associate for the Center for the American Woman and Politics at Rutgers University. "Carol Moseley-Braun has got all these ethical questions. Murray has got performance questions. Boxer, they will paint her as a liberal, that's probably the rap against her. And they all come from states that can go either way."
In addition, two of the three Democrats are being challenged by Republican women.
Ms. Murray's only opponent so far is Linda Smith, a United States Representative known for aggressive campaigning and conservative views. In Illinois, two Republicans are vying for Ms. Moseley-Braun's seat: State Senator Peter Fitzgerald, a millionaire conservative, and Loleta Didrickson, the State Comptroller, who has the backing of Republican leaders like Bob Dole and Jim Edgar, the popular Governor.
The shape of these races, political experts say, tells a lot about the status of women in politics these days, a picture that is much more complicated than it was six years ago, when women flowed into elected office in record numbers, picking up 19 House seats and 4 Senate seats.
 
Post-Anita Hill, And on Their Own
Several things have changed.
"Women voters are no longer surprised to see names like their own on the ballot," said Anita Perez Ferguson, president of the National Women's Political Caucus, a group that recruits women to run for office.
"There is one clear negative difference," said Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster. "In 1992, gender was an issue and it clearly worked to women's advantage. They represented change, they represented the people that the Senate Judiciary Committee talked down to" when Anita Hill testified at the Supreme Court confirmation hearings for Clarence Thomas in 1991. "Those kind of macro-forces don't exist this year," Ms. Lake said.
Women running for re-election are perceived more as incumbents than as women, experts say, with the advantages of fund-raising connections and the potential disadvantages of records that can be criticized.
At the same time, the pool of seasoned female politicians has deepened in recent years as more women are encouraged to try to make the jump from state legislatures to national office. The matchups are smarter, the candidates are tougher, the contests more sophisticated.
"A lot of these women come from elected positions or appointed positions in the state," Ms. Ferguson said. "That is the farm team. They know the ropes. They know what's expected. They know how to run a campaign."
More women are running against women, especially since Republicans are making an effort to recruit candidates in hopes of closing the gender gap that exists between the G.O.P. and the Democrats. In Michigan, Republican women are running for 3 of the 10 seats held by Democrats, and one of the women, Susan Grimes Munsell, a former state representative, hopes to unseat a female incumbent, Debbie Stabenow.
The effect of all this has been a complicated splatter pattern of female candidates. Since 1992, there have been only modest increases in the number of women winning primaries or national office. Women make up only 11 percent of the 535 members of Congress -- 50 in the House and 9 in the Senate -- and 22 percent of state legislators. The only office where they come close to parity is lieutenant governor, where 18 of the 42 states with that position have voted women in, often as demographic or ideological counterweights.
Yet, the maturation of female candidates has led some women with high-profile track records to take on or at least consider major challenges: Geraldine A. Ferraro hopes to unseat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in New York, and Senator Dianne Feinstein is considering a race for governor in California.
 
More Hoping To Be Governors
In a significant change this year, a record number of women, possibly 16, are expected to declare their candidacy for governor, historically a harder office for women to win than a seat in either house of Congress.
"Voters draw the line between executive characteristics and legislative characteristics, and typically the electorate through the 80's did not see women as the executive," Ms. Ferguson said. "Now, the woman boss in your office is becoming much more common."
In Hawaii, Linda Crockett Lingle, the Mayor of Maui, is considered a strong contender for the Republican nomination for Governor. In Connecticut, Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, a Democrat, is trying to defeat Gov. John G. Rowland. And in Iowa, a state with no women in national elected office, Lieut. Gov. Joy Corning, a moderate Republican, is running for Governor.
"The question comes up every day: can a woman win?" said Ms. Corning's campaign manager, Will Lynch. "That was one of the contributing factors in Joy's decision to run. If women in her position aren't out there bumping up against the glass ceiling, when are we going to knock it down?"
Female officeholders still have the benefit of being perceived as less partisan and more conciliatory, but they suffer from being seen as softer on economic issues and crime. And some women running for office, particularly Republicans, said they continue to face more basic hurdles, even if a woman has held the seat.
Marylin Shannon, a Republican State Senator in Oregon running for Congress against Darlene Hooley, a Democrat, said she did not believe all her state's voters had come to accept women in high office. She said a woman once walked up to her and several campaign volunteers at a McDonald's and announced that she would never vote for a woman. Ms. Shannon said she is frequently introduced as a state representative instead of as a senator. "Then they'll apologize profusely," she said. "But they think the Senate is for men."
In the United States Senate, Democrats acknowledge that the women who were swept into office in 1992 are among the most embattled senators up for re-election.
"I don't know if it has anything to do with them being women," said Michael Tucker, a spokesman for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. "I wondered about that myself. I can tell you this much: I'm glad and we're certainly fortunate from a party standpoint that it is our women who are in the toughest fights. These women are driven. Nobody will outwork them."
Senator Murray's biggest challenge, analysts say, is conveying to voters what she has achieved in office. Mr. Tucker cited Ms. Murray's advocacy of environmental issues and pension protection as positive examples of her effectiveness. In addition, Mr. Tucker said that Democrats believed Ms. Murray's 1992 nickname, the "mom in tennis shoes," was still an image voters responded to well, and many Democrats hope that the staunch conservatism of Ms. Murray's opponent, Representative Smith, will make her unappealing to moderate voters.
In California, Senator Boxer may have been given a small lift when Mayor Susan Golding of San Diego, a moderate Republican, dropped out of the race this month. A recent state poll showed Ms. Boxer far ahead of her Republican opponents but falling short of winning support from 50 percent of the voters.
 
Incumbent Has Work Cut Out for Her
In Senator Moseley-Braun's case, a poll last summer showed that only a third of the voters wanted her re-elected. But supporters are banking on voters forgetting the missteps of her first term and focusing on her work on issues like schools and urban environmental problems.
With the help of party leaders, Ms. Moseley-Braun managed to ward off a primary challenge. Her campaign is finally in the black after five years of paying off debts. The Senator has also been paying legal bills estimated at more than $100,000 for a Federal Election Commission investigation into hotel and travel expenses charged to a campaign debit card used by her and the man who was her campaign manager and fiance, Kgosie Matthews. The commission dropped the investigation last year, saying the reputed violations were not as serious as those in other cases before the commission, that staff time was scarce and that the statute of limitations may have run out.
Ms. Moseley-Braun said her strategy this time will have little to do with the fact that she is a woman.
"It's not about me, it's about the job that I've done," she said in an interview. "Those questions are gender-neutral. I'm just going to put my credentials before the people and suggest to them that it's a good idea to rehire me for this job."
Some analysts say Ms. Moseley-Braun, Illinois's senior Senator, has her work cut out for her.
"She has to not only repair the damage that was done with voters in terms of restoring confidence," said John Pelissero, a political science professor at Loyola University here. "She has to also point to a record of real accomplishment. In many voters' minds, the accomplishments of Carol Moseley-Braun are a little fuzzy."
