HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Cuban and Papal Officials Maneuver on Coming Visit
Days before the arrival of Pope John Paul II, Vatican and Cuban officials are locked in behind-the-scenes maneuvering that could determine the visit's political impact. Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, has used the state-run media to portray the Pope as an ally against American imperialism. The Church, meanwhile, has been negotiating to gain greater access to the island's media to make its case itself. A1
 
Pope Names 22 New Cardinals
Francis Eugene George, the Archbishop of Chicago, was one of 22 new cardinals named by Pope John Paul II, and one of 2 Americans. The other American was James Francis Stafford, the Archbishop Emeritus of Denver. This Pope has now named 106 out of the current 123 cardinals, who will choose future popes from among their ranks. A8 

A Call to Arms in Iraq
The Government of President Saddam Hussein called on Iraqis to report for military training and said it was ready for a "holy war" against the sanctions imposed by the United Nations until Iraq gives up its most destructive arms. Richard Butler, chief of the United Nations inspection commission, is due in Baghdad today to discuss the current standoff over weapons inspections. A3
 
Iraqi Diplomat Killed in Jordan
Unidentified assailants slit the throats of eight people, including a Iraqi top diplomat and several Iraqi businessmen, at a villa in the Jordanian capital of Amman, officials said. The lone survivor was a cook who was severely injured. A3
 
No Figure on West Bank Land
The Israeli Cabinet decided not to set a figure for the percentage of land to be included in the next Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank in advance of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's meeting with President Clinton in Washington this week. A3
 
U.S. Accused of Leaks to I.R.A.
Raymond G. H. Seitz, a former American Ambassador to Britain, has accused the Clinton Administration of having leaked British intelligence on Northern Ireland to the Irish Republican Army. In a book to be published next week, Mr. Seitz called the American Ambassador to Ireland, Jean Kennedy Smith, "an ardent I.R.A. apologist. " He also lamented the issuing of a visa to Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein. A6
 
Splinter Groups Worry Belfast
Several renegade groups have the capacity, and apparently the intention, to wreak havoc in Northern Ireland in an effort to subvert the peace talks aimed at ending almost 30 years of sectarian strife there, British intelligence officials said. A Protestant group, the Loyalist Volunteer Force, on Sunday claimed its fourth killing since late December. That group, and a Catholic splinter group, the Irish National Liberation Army, are considered the factions most likely to carry out attacks. A6
 
NATIONAL A10-13
 
Female Incumbents Vulnerable This Year
The stunning success of Senator Carol Moseley-Braun of Illinois, along with that of other female candidates, gave 1992 the label "Year of the Woman." Now, many view Ms. Moseley-Braun as one of the most vulnerable senators, and she is not the only woman facing a tough re-election fight. Two other Senators elected in 1992, Barbara Boxer of California and Patty Murray of Washington, are also believed to be in for a battle in a year when re-election is expected to be easy for most incumbents. A1
 
Women Assaulted in Guatemala
Five American students from a college in Maryland on an educational tour of Guatemala were sexually assaulted on Friday after their bus was ambushed by four gunmen, officials said. After 90 minutes the gunmen left and the bus continued on to Guatemala City. A spokesman for the U.S. Embassy said that Guatemalan authorities had two people in custody. A1
 
Urgency in Cloning Debate
Dr. Richard Seed, the Illinois physicist who bolted into the news this month by declaring that he intended to open a cloning clinic, may be an inadvertent ally to Representative Vernon J. Ehlers of Michigan, whose legislation to ban human cloning remained stuck in Congress. A11
 
Number of Inmates Rising
Despite a decline in the crime rate over the past five years, the number of inmates in the nation's jails and prisons rose again in 1997, according to a study by the Justice Department. This raises a series of troublesome questions, experts said, including whether the United States is relying too heavily on prison sentences to combat drugs. A10
 
Jones Team Looks for Pattern
Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones said that the sexual misconduct case against President Clinton would try to establish a pattern of licentious behavior toward other women by Mr. Clinton. White House strategists said Mr. Clinton finished the Saturday deposition in a mood of high confidence after weighing for himself the challenge posed by the Jones team. A12
 
History Weighs on Memphis
In the 30 years since an assassin killed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in Memphis, the city has struggled to live down the long-term impact of that moment. The symbols of the history and the challenge were everywhere on Saturday: on one side of downtown were meetings on race relations and a party to honor Dr. King's birthday, and on the other, a Ku Klux Klan rally that resulted in tear gas being used to disperse anti-Klan marchers. A13
 
Lott Opposes Medicare Plan
The majority leader of the Senate, Trent Lott of Mississippi, came out against President Clinton's proposal to allow hundreds of thousands of early retirees, laid off workers and uninsured Americans who are nearing retirement age to buy into Medicare. A13
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
New York Unprepared For Downturn, Experts Say
New York State is running a big budget surplus for the third year in a row. Gov. George E. Pataki boasts that he has slowed the upward spiral of spending and that the state's emergency reserve fund is larger than ever. Yet financial experts warn that while most states have used the healthy economy of the last seven years to get their financial affairs in order, New York remains woefully ill prepared to survive another recession. A1
 
Placing Older Students
A school like Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx offers lessons on what might happen if the system put in place Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's idea of requiring students who stay beyond five years to complete their education at night or weekend schools. Officials at Roosevelt, which was once one of the worst schools in the state but is now rebounding, say the very fact that some of those older, longtime students are close to graduating with ambition testifies to the hope the school offers them. B1
 
New Hope in '75 Death Case
Investigators say they have renewed hope that the mystery of Martha Moxley's death 22 years ago can be solved. They are awaiting the results of DNA tests not available two decades ago and are contemplating a new investigation of the case, in which the 15-year-old girl was found beaten to death with a golf club near her family's home in Greenwich, Conn. B6
 
ARTS E1-16
 
Plath Widower Ends His Silence
The poet Ted Hughes has decided to break his long silence about his life with Sylvia Plath, who killed herself 35 years ago after he left her for another woman. Mr. Hughes is publishing a collection of poems about his relationship with Plath, titled "Birthday Letters," which describes the couple's meeting, their tempestuous marriage and Plath's increasing obsession with her dead father and, finally, with death itself. A1
 
OBITUARIES A15
 
Joseph S. Murphy
The champion of the working class who rose to become Chancellor of the City University of New York was 64. Mr. Murphy, the son of a labor organizer, was able to rebuild and even extend academic programs while CUNY chancellor despite the system's financial woes. A15
 
Alexander M. Selinger
The Italian-born, Czech-reared businessman who operated the Eclair Bakery at 141 West 72d Street for more than 50 years was 91. From the moment Mr. Selinger opened the Eclair in 1939 to the day he sold it in 1993, memory -- of happier times, of the coffee houses of Austria and Hungary -- was what the Eclair experience was about. A15
 
BUSINESS DAY D1-8
 
Merger Fever Sweeps U.S.
Corporate America is being reshaped by a wave of merger activity not seen since industrial takeovers created the great oil, steel and auto companies at the beginning of the century. Last year alone, a record $1 trillion in mergers took place involving American companies. A1
 
Univision Success Story
Univision Communications, the nation's largest Spanish-language television network, has had stunning success in reaching the rapidly growing Hispanic population of the United States. Now more companies are waking up to the potential in the Spanish television market. D1
 
Nomura Officials Arrested
Two former officials of the Nomura Securities Company of Japan and a director of Japan's public highway corporation were arrested on bribery charges. The two executives offered roughly $25,000 in bribes to the highway official in exchange for help in becoming the lead underwriter for the highway corporation's foreign bonds. (AP)

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 1688 words

HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: At Princeton, A Sense Of Where They Are;
The Tigers Thrive In a Special System

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
The players on perhaps the most precise and definitely the most unusual college basketball team in the nation are sitting at school desks inside a musty room waiting to oppose Yale on a January night. A curtain surrounds the Princeton Tigers to supposedly muffle the sounds of students on rowing machines as Coach Bill Carmody lectures his squad.
But Carmody is not distracted in this strange setting. His voice is passionate and his eyes are excitable as he hovers over the players. 
 Carmody knows he has a wonderful group of athletes, maybe as special as any since Bill Bradley was the big man on campus more than three decades ago, and he knows his players should squash Yale.
So Carmody peers into their anxious faces and reminds them of who they are, and who they can become.
"Each time you go out there, you want to show this is the product of your hard work," Carmody tells them. "It's such a special time for you. There are 35-year-old guys who play basketball every weekend and wish they could be where you are."
He continues: "Enjoy it, but whatever you do is what people are going to remember you by. When you're 25, you don't want to think back that we didn't play well against Yale. Why not remember playing 15 straight games where we were great?
"This is a special time," he tells his players. "Don't let it go by."
Over the next 40 minutes, Princeton did not. While the Tigers (13-1) were not as dominant as they have often been in losing only to then No. 1 North Carolina and achieving a No. 12 ranking, they never trailed while winning, 69-58.
On this night, they won by scoring all but a few of their points on layups, 3-pointers or free throws. They won by being patient and unselfish in a system Princeton has singularly employed since its former coach Pete Carril walked onto campus in 1967. They won by using a quick and underrated defense. And they won in an athletic manner that makes these Tigers quite special.
"I don't buy into that Ivy League, nonscholarship stuff," said Niagara Coach Jack Armstrong, whose team lost to Princeton, 61-52, in the ECAC Holiday Festival final.
"That's ridiculous," Armstrong said. "These guys can play."
 
The System Is Simpler Than It Appears to Be
As Carmody fiddles with the remote control while reviewing the Yale game in his office, he keeps insisting that Princeton's system of choreographed zigs and zags is simple.
Carmody has a summer basketball camp and said that teen-agers are fearful of trying the offense, but they grin as if Michael Jordan were their new roommate after they understand and run it after three days of practices.
The Tigers start three seniors and two juniors; they are savvy and skilled, and that is apparent as they unleash their offensive sets.
All five players are moving. Cutting hard. Setting screens. Searching for the trusty backdoor play. Holding the ball high and making crisp passes. Staying properly spaced, with center Steve Goodrich above the key to direct the flow and keep the middle open. They want layups or 3-point attempts and patiently move from option to option until the search is successful.
Usually, they get their threes.
After Goodrich faked a backdoor pass and gave up the ball on the second possession against Yale, he used a screen set by James Mastaglio at the free-throw line to nail the first of Princeton's 11 3-pointers. The basket came off the 12th pass of the possession and destroyed 34 seconds of seemingly sound man-to-man defense by Yale.
Usually, they get their layups. Midway through the first half, Mitch Henderson passed to Goodrich above the key. Goodrich faked handing the ball back to Henderson, a signal for a play, and Henderson veered right to screen Emerson Whitley, Gabe Lewullis's defender. Whitley anticipated it and shifted right to prevent a 3-pointer because Lewullis makes 44 percent from that range.
That opened the backdoor. Lewullis darted to his right and snared Goodrich's pass a stride from the basket for the prettiest of Princeton's 14 layups.
The backdoor is Princeton's signature, the play that Goodrich and Lewullis combined on to shock U.C.L.A., the defending champions, in the first round of the 1996 National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.
However, they do not even practice it. It is simply within the system.
"I hate when people tell me this is hard to do," Carmody said. "You can do this at any level and any school."
 
The Team Is Smart And Hard-Nosed
Goodrich, a 6-foot-10-inch senior, is the most critical player in Princeton's system because he is a point center who comes out high in the offense and leaves the pivot open for cutting.
He barely shot 3-pointers in high school, but has made 42 percent from beyond the arc. Yale Coach Dick Kuchen has praised him as one of the two top passing centers in the country. Since Princeton does not have a true inside attack and essentially starts Goodrich and four interchangeable guards, his versatility around the perimeter is integral.
"It's five guys working together," Carmody said, "but the center is the most important."
If Goodrich is not nabbing another assist, then it is Henderson, the feisty guard who is such an impressive athlete he was drafted by the Yankees as an outfielder. The 6-1 Henderson has an assist-to-turnover ratio of 2 to 1, a superb statistic because his left-handed bounce passes off the dribble, which could squeeze through closing subway doors, often glide between two befuddled defenders.
"He's the toughest guy on the team in every way," Carmody said.
Brian Earl looks like he might shave once a month, but he can be an assassin. He also leads the team in scoring, averaging 14.2 points a game.
When Yale twice trimmed the deficit to 7 points in the second half, Earl played Superman. The guard faked a 3-pointer and drove around two defenders for a layup. Then he sank a 3-pointer after Goodrich feigned a backdoor pass to Nate Walton.
Earl's effort was particularly inspiring because the economics major had slept just one hour the previous night while finishing a paper for the course "Mechanical Aerospace Engineering."
"It's not as hard as it sounds," said Earl, whose older brother, Dan, is the starting point guard at Penn State. "Really, it isn't."
With his crew cut and rugged approach, Lewullis looks as if he belongs at a military academy. Actually, he fits snugly at Princeton, where he is the elite 3-point shooter and showed it by making four against Yale. Mastaglio is an adept passer and capable defender who takes the fewest shots among the starters.
"We have smart players who are very good athletes," said Carmody, the second-year head coach who started as an assistant in 1982. "We used to hang around the Wake Forests and North Carolinas for 33, 34 minutes. Now we can win those games."
 
They're Just as Precise On the Defensive End
Everyone adores Princeton's unusual offense, but they play such persistent man to man and box out so strongly for rebounds that Armstrong has shown his Niagara players videotapes of the Tigers on defense as instructional tools. Princeton, the kings at securing wide-open jumpers, rarely allows opponents to get clean looks, which is why the Tigers limit them to 42 percent from the field and under 50 points a game.
After Princeton used a fullcourt press at the start of the game, the Bulldogs turned the ball over five times on their next six possessions against the man to man and never really recovered. When the Bulldogs chiseled the deficit to 56-49 with seven minutes left, the Tigers shut them out for five minutes.
"They're doing what they're supposed to be doing," Kuchen said. It was a simple statement that said a lot.
 
As They Dream of a Title, Others Try to Stop Them
Can Princeton be stopped? According to other coaches, it can be done.
Throttle the shooters. Obviously, it is not easy. Earl, Goodrich and Lewullis are the top gunners, so try to force shots from Henderson, who has made 19 percent from 3-point range, or Mastaglio, who has made 32 percent. Niagara tried that, but Mastaglio had a season-high 18 points and Henderson still sank three 3-pointers. He has made three more in 13 other games.
Get them into foul trouble. The starters average between 32 and 36 minutes a game and, on average, score 50.9 of Princeton's 62.1 points. Henderson missed 17 minutes against Yale with foul trouble, and the Tigers survived. They might not be so fortunate against a superior team. Regardless, Carmody is not concerned about depth.
"I'm not putting someone in there thinking that if I give him minutes, he'll be better later in the year," Carmody said. "We have hard practices. I'll see it in practice."
Switch defenses. The worst thing to do against the Tigers is to let them get too comfortable in their system, so it is essential to vary the defenses and at least make them prove how smart they are. Yale began with a man to man, switched to a 1-3-1, a 1-2-2 and a matchup zone and used fullcourt pressure, without one approach having continuous success.
"I love it when teams go to zones," said Carmody, talking like a coach who knows that his zone offense provides four scoring options. "We kill zones."
Carmody was a coach without a team as he sat in his office last week. Princeton, which does not give athletic scholarships, is in the middle of a 15-day hiatus from games and formal practices because of exams.
"All I do is put out basketballs for guys who want to shoot for an hour as a study break," he said.
The lack of activity should have given Carmody more time to dream. How far can the Tigers advance this season? Carmody claimed he does not think about the possibility of a national championship. It might sound strange to envision the Tigers using their array of cuts, screens and backdoors, their endless barrage of 3-pointers and even their athleticism to challenge for a title, but it should not. Not in this special season.
"I would like to go as far as we can," Carmody said. "If we're fortunate enough to get a bid to the N.C.A.A.'s, I want us to go as far as we can. We're trying to do that."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Strong Job Gains Made In December and in 1997

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
More than 13,400 new jobs were created in New Jersey last month, making 1997 the best year for new employment since 1988, according to a report released on Friday by state officials.
Over all, 78,100 new jobs were created last year, bringing the total number of jobs in New Jersey to 3.75 million, a record high, said the report by the State Department of Labor. 
 The report also found that New Jersey's unemployment rate in December was below 5 percent for the second month in a row. Before November, the unemployment rate had not dipped below 5 percent since June 1990, according to the report.

HEADLINE: Studies of Schizophrenia Vindicate Psychotherapy

BYLINE: By DENISE GRADY 

 BODY:
WHEN a man with schizophrenia requested psychotherapy recently in addition to his antipsychotic medication, he was told that his health maintenance organization would allow only six sessions. "The insurer said there was no evidence that psychotherapy helps people with schizophrenia," said Gerard Hogarty, a researcher and professor of psychiatry at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine.
The story is all too familiar to therapists. The notion behind it is that people with schizophrenia are either too sick to be reached by psychotherapy or, thanks to medication, too well to need it. 
 But Professor Hogarty and his research team have shown that schizophrenic patients taking medication can be helped further by a certain type of psychotherapy. In two studies published in November in The American Journal of Psychiatry, the group showed that a three-year course of the treatment, which they developed and named personal therapy, was extremely helpful to many patients in preventing relapses and improving social adjustment.
Dr. Wayne Fenton, medical director of Chestnut Lodge Hospital in Rockville, Md., who was an author of an editorial accompanying the results of the studies, said they provided the first scientific proof that psychotherapy can help people with schizophrenia. "Because of this, people can no longer argue that psychotherapy for schizophrenia is not effective," Dr. Fenton said. "One might say there is no excuse anymore not to provide needed care."
Although antipsychotic drugs are unmatched in their power to halt the hallucinations and delusions that characterize schizophrenia, they do not erase all signs of illness.
"People are better, but not well," Professor Hogarty said. Despite medication, many patients still have difficulties with memory, attention, problem solving and relating to other people. Relapses are common, often because patients quit taking their medication, but sometimes even when they stick with it. Only 10 percent to 30 percent of the two million Americans with schizophrenia are employed. "There's no drug out there to teach you how to get along with anybody, or how to get a job and keep one," Professor Hogarty said.
Dr. George T. Niederehe, head of the adult and geriatric psychosocial treatment research program at the National Institute of Mental Health, said, "Many of the people we talk about as the homeless are persons with these kinds of mental health problems."
Dr. Niederehe and other experts praised the study. "It's a major advance," said Dr. William T. Carpenter Jr., director of the Maryland Psychiatric Research Center in Baltimore. Dr. Carpenter, who was not associated with the study, said that personal therapy appeared to be the most beneficial treatment developed since the first antipsychotic drugs were introduced in the 1950's.
The treatment of schizophrenia has had a contentious history. When it became clear during the 1960's that antipsychotic drugs worked far better than psychotherapy for most patients, doctors began to question whether psychotherapy was of any use for people with schizophrenia. There are about 400 different types of psychotherapy, Professor Hogarty said, and studies in the last 30 years have been contradictory, with some finding psychotherapy helpful in treating schizophrenia and others calling it useless or even harmful.
By the mid-1980's, psychotherapy had such a bad reputation among experts in schizophrenia that a proposal to study anything by that name would have been "an invitation to unemployment," Professor Hogarty said. The climate inspired him and his colleagues to call the techniques they developed something else: personal therapy.
Their treatment differs radically from the Freudian psychoanalysis that many people think of as psychotherapy. "We're not looking into suppressed thoughts about Mama," Professor Hogarty said. "It's more in the here and now."
Personal therapy is based on the idea that people with schizophrenia are born with brain abnormalities that make them especially vulnerable to emotional stress. Overwhelming stress, often from dealings with other people, can lead to anxiety and depression, which may in turn spiral down into psychosis.
In personal therapy, the therapist tries initially to help patients recognize stress and manage it in order to avoid relapses of schizophrenia. The treatment program is tailored to each patient's needs, and patients progress at their own pace. Eventually, they may reach a stage where they are ready for counseling to help them get along better with other people and to minimize stressful encounters.
Professor Hogarty's study included 151 patients, 97 living with their families and 54 living independently. Most were in their 20's or 30's, and all took antipsychotic medication. Each was assigned to a group that received personal therapy two to four times a month for three years, or, for comparison, family therapy, personal and family therapy, or supportive therapy in which patients were given the opportunity to talk with a therapist and seek help during crises.
In the patients who lived with relatives, only a quarter who received personal therapy alone had relapses, as opposed to half of those who had the other kinds of therapy. Only two quit personal therapy, but 13 dropped out of the other programs.
But in patients living on their own, more receiving personal therapy had relapses than those getting supportive treatment: about half relapsed, as opposed to slightly more than a third of the others. Four left personal therapy, and five left supportive therapy. The researchers said they suspected that personal therapy failed in that group because many of the patients were struggling to find housing, food and clothing, and the treatment may have been too demanding for them.
But in another area, social adjustment, both groups of patients benefited from personal therapy. Personal relationships and work performance improved. Most important, they continued to get better over time, while benefits from the other types of therapy tended to reach a plateau after a year. Had the study gone on, Professor Hogarty said, the patients in personal therapy might have continued to improve even further.
He and his team have devised another treatment that they are now testing, called cognitive enhancement therapy. It involves computer programs aimed at helping patients improve problem-solving skills, and group sessions designed to heighten the ability to act wisely in social situations. Patients like it, and Professor Hogarty thinks the treatment may ultimately prove even more helpful than personal therapy.
Despite the value of personal therapy, other researchers and Professor Hogarty himself said they doubted it would come into widespread use. It is expensive and time-consuming, and would require extensive retraining of therapists.
Nonetheless, Professor Hogarty said, in the long run personal therapy might prove cost effective, because by preventing relapses it can keep patients out of the hospital, which is the most expensive form of care. The treatment may also get them back in the work force. "You get what you pay for," he said. "If you want to pay something more, the lives of these patients can improve substantially."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Asian Financial Crisis Begins to Affect European Economy

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Asia's financial crisis is starting to affect Europe, slowing down exports of everything from heavy machinery to telephones and worsening what were already gloomy prospects for reducing joblessness this year.
Though the ultimate magnitude of Asia's impact remains a guessing game, the trouble signs have been proliferating and analysts are hastily trimming back predictions of economic growth that they made as recently as Christmas. 
 The problems come at a bad time. Booming exports have been the only bright spot in Germany and France, Europe's two biggest economies, and government leaders there have been counting on exports to fuel the first solid economic growth in years.
A slowdown of economic growth is also likely to add to unemployment, which is more than twice as high as in the United States and running at record levels in Germany and France. Joblessness is the biggest political problem for both Lionel Jospin, the Socialist Prime Minister of France, who was forced to use riot police last week to subdue protests by unemployed workers, and Helmut Kohl, the Chancellor of the right-of-center German Government.
To the surprise of most economists, the ranks of Germany's unemployed jumped by 200,000 people last month, to 4.5 million, or 11.8 percent.
Economists said European companies were being hit in at least two ways. The first was through reduced exports to Asian countries, because the devaluation of their currencies had abruptly eliminated much of their buying power, and the slowdown had already led several Asian countries to put off planned development projects. Still, Southeast Asia accounts for less than 5 percent of European exports.
The second and potentially more serious impact is in the form of price pressure. Because Asian currencies have been devalued so sharply, products from countries like South Korea are far more competitive in world markets. That makes it difficult for European or American companies to raise prices, at home or abroad, and is likely to dampen the appetite for investment and spending.
The impact has already shown up at some companies.
A.B.B. Asea Brown Boveri, the Swiss-Swedish engineering conglomerate, said last week that about $560 million in export orders from Southeast Asia had been delayed and could be canceled.
Deutsche Telekom A.G., Germany's dominant telephone company, added $412 million to its provisions on Friday to cover possible losses on investments in Southeast Asia. Deutsche Telekom owns stakes in telecommunication companies in Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines.
Airbus Industrie, the Paris-based aircraft consortium, was trying to collect money from the Indonesian airline Garuda for three airplanes it had ordered. Airbus officials said that Garuda had paid for and received six of nine aircraft that it ordered several years ago. But in December, Garuda failed to come up with $8 million in payments on the three planes that remain to be delivered.
Meanwhile, Moody's Investor Service lowered its credit rating on Friday for two big French banks and issued warnings on seven other European banks. All of these banks have big portfolios of Asian loans, though several say that their potential losses are small if not negligible and that the warnings are unnecessary.
Beyond anecdotal evidence, economists say there are statistical signs that the effects of the Asian crisis are spreading. Salomon Smith Barney has trimmed its growth estimate for the 11 European countries that are expected to take part in the single currency next year, from about 3 percent to 2.6 percent.
Analysts said Germany could feel the biggest impact, because it has always been a big exporter of heavy machinery and capital equipment -- precisely the kind used in big government-sponsored development projects that Asian countries are now delaying or canceling.
The first hint of trouble came earlier this month, when the German Government reported that the volume of foreign orders for German goods had declined substantially for the second consecutive month. After soaring more than 20 percent through last August, as a surge in the American dollar made German products far cheaper in many markets, foreign orders declined by 3.7 percent in October and 2.9 percent in November.
UBS Securities, in a report headlined "Asia Bites," revised its economic forecast for Germany, predicting that exports and profitability in general will be hurt by the Asian crisis. "Undoubtedly, Germany's share in global exports will suffer," said Ralf Kugelstadt, a UBS economist in Frankfurt.
The Asian troubles are not expected to derail the plan for a single European currency, the euro, which is to be introduced on Jan. 1, 1999. Under the Maastricht Treaty, countries are to be admitted largely on the basis of whether they met certain fiscal standards during 1997. Based on what is known about results during 1997, most economists and government officials now assume that 11 countries will join the euro club next year.
But the crisis in Asia could add to problems, like unemployment, that were already made worse by the preparation for the adoption of the euro. European countries have endured painful cuts in government spending and increases in taxes to meet the strict requirements for participating in the euro, and slower economic growth could easily turn the euro into a highly unpopular political issue.

LENGTH: 767 words

HEADLINE: U.N. Envoy, In Baghdad, Hints Teams Could Alter

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The United Nations chief arms inspector for Iraq, Richard Butler, said here today that he might at some point be willing to take a second look at the composition of inspection teams, some of which the Iraqis have complained have too many Americans.
"We choose the best that we can," he said, adding that experts were recruited from around the world to form teams tailored to certain sites and problems. "Maybe in the future, we'll make a double take and look at their nationalities. But only after we look at their qualifications." 
 Before talks that began today, Mr. Butler acknowledged that relations with Saddam Hussein were again at a crisis point but offered Iraq a few crumbs of hope for quicker action toward lifting sanctions.
President Hussein threatened on Saturday to throw all United Nations inspectors out of the country within six months if the sanctions against Iraq's oil sales were not lifted.
As Mr. Butler was arriving today, Iraqis staged a funeral for 70 children said by the Government to have died because the embargo deprived them of food and medicine.
Nevertheless, Mr. Butler said Iraq's threat to end cooperation with the United Nations made "no practical sense."
"The idea of an arbitrary, a priori deadline is something that simply won't work," he said this evening before the first of two rounds of meetings with Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz. "This work can be done quite quickly with full Iraqi cooperation," he added. But, he insisted, "it will end when it ends."
United Nations officials said there would be no public statements about the talks until they were concluded.
Critics of continued sanctions have asked that, at the very least, the United Nations Special Commission begin closing files one by one, to induce Iraq to cooperate more fully.
Once a file on a subject is closed, intrusive and abrupt inspections give way to a long-range monitoring system like those that accompany arms control treaties.
Addressing Iraqi protests on this issue, Mr. Butler, who heads the Special Commission, said that two groups of technical experts would soon meet to explore the possibility of closing files. One is to review the documents on special warheads capable of delivering chemical and biological weapons, and the other is to study evidence that Iraq produced the deadly nerve gas known as VX.
These reviews, however, have proved a two-edged sword. When experts were asked last year to review Iraq's claims of having accounted for all biological weapons and production sites, they called the claims "not remotely credible."
In December, Iraq again declared itself free of germ warfare.
"We don't agree," Mr. Butler said. "We don't agree, not because we are suspicious people, but because disarmament can't be decided on the basis of declaration alone. It has to be verifiable."
Mr. Butler repeated Security Council calls for unfettered access to all suspect sites. He said there was Council agreement on that point.
He was repeatedly questioned about William Scott Ritter Jr., the former United States marine whose team was barred for two days from inspections. Mr. Ritter left Baghdad on Friday, a day ahead of schedule.
"I'm going to get tired soon of the personalization stuff," Mr. Butler said in exasperated tones. "I mean, it really has to stop. I've said over and over again: the man in question is a professional. He is not a spy. He works for the United Nations. I don't want to have to say it again."
Mr. Butler said that Mr. Ritter had been asked to look for evidence of germ warfare testing on inmates during a prison visit last week, but only as part of a "subset" of questions about the prison. In a letter to the Security Council last week, Iraq's representative to the United Nations, Nizar Hamdoon, listed the search for evidence of germ warfare as one grievance against Mr. Ritter.
"I was stunned when the Iraqi permanent representative put that into the public arena," Mr. Butler said, adding that he had intended not to publicize these long-held suspicions because he knew Iraq would be sensitive about them.
Mr. Butler called the Iraqi fixation on Mr. Ritter a diversion from the real issue, which was that Mr. Ritter's team had special expertise in concealment.
"This is not a subject with which Iraq feels comfortable," he said. "The closer we get to the end, the closer we get to the last pieces that have been 'concealed' -- quote, unquote -- of course that makes it tougher."
"The last lap of this race may be the hardest lap," he said. "But we've got to run it. Otherwise, Lord knows what will happen."

HEADLINE: Starwood Says It Has Arranged Financing for ITT Acquisition

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
Starwood Hotels and Resorts Trust has obtained more than $7 billion in financing that will allow it to complete its $10.2 billion acquisition of the ITT Corporation, a hotel and casino company, Starwood's chairman and chief executive, Barry S. Sternlicht, said yesterday.
"The deal will not unravel," Mr. Sternlicht said in an interview, calling the financing "the largest of its type ever done for a real estate transaction." 
 Another casino company, Circus Enterprises, which has been the subject of takeover speculation, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Clyde T. Turner, had resigned.
The Starwood financing, which is being provided by nine financial institutions led by Bankers Trust and Chase Manhattan Bank, will be used to pay as much as $3 billion in cash needed for the cash-and-stock acquisition. The remainder of the funds will be used to refinance some debt, provide working capital and finance other acquisitions.
There had been some speculation in the market that the financing was proving difficult. But Paul Keung, a hotel analyst with Deutsche Morgen Grenfell, said the loan was never in doubt. Rather, the issue was what interest rate the company would obtain because it is highly leveraged.
Mr. Sternlicht acknowledged that the financing "was more difficult than anticipated" because Japanese banks, burdened by bad debts, were reluctant to lend money. No Japanese banks are among the nine participants in the credit package. As for the terms, he said the "end pricing is in line with what we expected."
The package consists of a five-year loan, a revolving credit line and a bridge loan to be paid back within one year through the sale of noncore businesses. Last month, Starwood agreed to sell ITT's telephone directory business for $2.1 billion. Mr. Sternlicht said the company planned to sell ITT's educational services business and perhaps some hotels in areas where Starwood and ITT own properties near one another.
Starwood, based in Phoenix, won a bitter battle in November with the Hilton Hotels Corporation to acquire ITT, which owns the Sheraton hotel chain and Caesars casinos. Starwood's ability to outbid Hilton stemmed in part from the higher stock valuation it has as a real estate investment trust, or REIT, which carries certain tax advantages.
Since then, there has been anticipation that other casino companies might be acquired by REITs. On Friday, Crescent Real Estate Equities, a REIT, agreed to buy Station Casinos Inc. for $635 million in stock. REIT's such as Vornado Realty Trust and Patriot American Hospitality Inc. are said to have been looking at casinos.
Circus Circus has been at the center of such rumors. The company's stock, which fell more than 40 percent last year as it was hurt by a glut of hotel rooms in Las Vegas, Nev., has in the last month climbed from about $20 to close at $25.50 on Friday.
The company has not commented on the rumors.
Circus said the chief operating officer, Michael S. Ensign, would assume Mr. Turner's posts in addition to his own. Circus also said it would take a charge of 8 cents a share in the fourth quarter to settle Mr. Turner's employment contract.

HEADLINE: Merger by 2 Russian Tycoons Creates an Oil Colossus

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Two of Russia's most powerful tycoons merged their oil companies today, creating a politically potent enterprise with control over one of the world's largest oil reserves.
The move, the largest merger in the brief history of Russian capitalism, was immediately blessed by Russia's Prime Minister, who spent much of his own career in the country's state-owned energy industry. 
 It brings together Mikhail Khodorkovsky, a former Communist youth official turned banker who now chairs the Yukos oil company, and Boris A. Berezovsky, a former national security aide whose business empire includes the Sibneft oil company.
The new oil company, Yuksi, is the world's 11th largest oil producer. And the merger gives it the opportunity to grow even bigger. Russia's state oil company, Rosneft, will be sold at auction later this year, and Yuksi will be in position to make a competitive bid, provided that it attracts a Western partner.
"The objective of this combination is to create a world-scale and world-class integrated oil company with strategically located operations throughout Russia," Mr. Khodorkovsky said.
The politics of today's move, however, are as intriguing as the economics. Russia is enmeshed in a tumultuous debate over what type of capitalist system it should have: a free market with genuine competition or "crony capitalism," dominated by a small group of wealthy financiers and businessmen with inside influence.
The merger represents a long-expected consolidation of Russia's vast oil industry, but it also strengthens the role of Mr. Berezovsky, a leading member of Russia's small oligarchy and a bitter opponent of the Government's leading economic reformers, Boris Nemtsov and Anatoly B. Chubais.
The reformers angered Mr. Berezovsky when they sought to end insider deals in the Government's privatization auctions. They have come under a withering assault ever since by newspapers controlled by Mr. Berezovsky and his allies.
Mr. Berezovky has never detailed his relationship with Sibneft. Mr. Khodorkovsky, however, said today that Mr. Berezovsky would become one of the major shareholders in Yuksi because of his interest in Sibneft.
Today's move is part of a broader shakeout among Russian oil companies, as powerful companies gobble up their smaller competitors.
The two companies being merged into Yuksi produced 1.3 million barrels a day in 1997. That was 22 percent of Russia's crude oil production and substantially more than Lukoil, which has now been displaced as Russia's biggest oil company. And Mr. Khodorkovsky said the new concern hoped to boost production to 2 million barrels a day over the next several years.
The merger, which is expected to take a year or more to complete, will encompass four oil-producing fields, five refineries and some of the world's largest proven oil reserves. Mr. Khodorkovsky will head the new company, which will be 60 percent owned by Yukos and 40 percent owned by Sibneft.
Analysts say the production puts the company behind only Royal Dutch/Shell and Exxon among publicly traded companies. But Yuksi is 11th overall in terms of oil production.
A key question, however, is whether the merger will create a more efficient company that can attract Western partners and compete in the global marketplace, or a huge politically well-connected -- but mismanaged -- corporation.
Both Yukos and Sibneft have repeatedly been accused of compensating for poor management and cash-flow problems by stripping assets from their subsidiaries. Stock analysts and brokers here -- including Creditanstalt and Brunswick Brokerage -- have issued reports warning that minority shareholders in Yukos- and Sibneft-controlled subsidiaries are at risk.
Mr. Khodorkovsky denied the charges today and said he was prepared to have his handling of subsidiaries examined by "international banks and legal companies -- but impartial banks, not banks that represent the interests of the opposite side."
The origins of today's merger go back several months to when Mr. Khodorkovsky and Mr. Berezovky were discussing a joint bid for the state oil company, Rosneft.
The 33-year-old Mr. Khodorkovsky had risen from being an official in the Komsomol, the Communist youth organization, to found Menatep bank. He made a fortune trading in currency, commodities and oil and expanded into metallurgy, chemicals and light industry. But more recently he has set his sights on becoming an oil baron.
Despite his current efforts to court a Western partner, Mr. Khodorkovsky's relations with Western oil companies have not always been harmonious.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Japanese Stocks Help Lift Yen As Traders Gain Confidence

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A rise in Japanese stocks helped lift the yen against the dollar in currency trading yesterday.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues, which surged 6.11 percent, closed yesterday up 215.59 points, or 1.34 percent, at 16,262.04. Today, the Nikkei rose another 104.49 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent. 
 The recent gains in the Japanese stock market have bolstered traders' confidence that the Japanese Government is taking concrete steps to salvage the sagging economy.
"There is investor confidence that this crisis will be overcome," said Dennis Heidt, a trader at Banque Paribas.
During Asian trading, currency traders were initially buoyed by a weekend report in the newspaper Asahi Shimbun that a top Japanese Cabinet official had told United States officials that Japan would take additional steps by April to salvage the ailing Japanese economy.
Traders bought up yen until the report was later denied, slowing the rally in the yen.
In Germany, the mark was hurt by a weekend magazine report that quoted Germany's top central banker as saying he doubted that Italy would join Europe's initial conversion to a single currency in 1999. Italy had been seen as getting its house in order to meet the stringent criteria for joining the currency union. The Bundesbank later denied that its president, Hans Tietmeyer, had made the remark.
In early trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 128.88 yen, down from 129.30 yen on Friday. The dollar also traded at 1.8363 marks, up from 1.8336 marks. The pound was quoted at $1.6385, up from $1.6335.
With financial markets in the United States closed yesterday for Martin Luther King Jr. Day, trading was thin. Most trading in New York ended by 10 A.M., as London wound up its day. "By early morning, everything that had to be done was done," said a foreign exchange strategist for I.D.E.A. Inc. in New York.
In addition to Japan's market, other Asian markets were sharply higher yesterday. Hong Kong stocks rose 500.38 points, or 5.62 percent. In South Korea, stocks gained 32.86 points, or 6.63 percent.
The gains in Asia gave a lift to European markets. In London, stocks retreated a bit after reaching a 15-week high. The Financial Times Stock Exchange index closed up 10.5 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, at 5,273.6.

HEADLINE: Clinton Plan to Widen Medicare Can't Pay for Itself, Experts Say

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Insurance experts say they doubt that President Clinton's proposal to open Medicare to people 55 to 64 years old would pay for itself, because, they say, sicker and costlier patients would be the ones most likely to sign up for the new coverage.
In the last two weeks, Mr. Clinton and other Administration officials have repeatedly described the proposal as fiscally responsible and "self-financing." They insist that the new beneficiaries would pay the entire cost, so that there would be no need for Federal subsidies, no risk to the Medicare trust fund and no cost to current beneficiaries. 
 But Robert J. Myers, who was chief actuary of the Social Security Administration for 23 years; William F. Bluhm, vice president of the American Academy of Actuaries, and Julia T. Philips, a health actuary who works for the Minnesota Insurance Commissioner, said in interviews that they doubted that Mr. Clinton's plan would pay for itself at the premium rates he has proposed.
Roland E. King, chief actuary of the Medicare program from 1978 to 1994, voiced similar doubts.
Consumer advocates and health policy analysts praised Mr. Clinton for highlighting the insurance needs of people 55 to 64. But they said Federal subsidies, to help pay the cost of Medicare coverage for some members of that group, might be necessary and would be justified.
Senator John H. Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican who for years has advocated Federal efforts to broaden health insurance coverage, expressed the skepticism of many on Capitol Hill that the proposal would pay for itself as Mr. Clinton contends.
"I don't believe that at all," the Senator said.
Mr. Myers, who is widely respected by actuaries and members of Congress, predicted that relatively few people would buy Medicare coverage under the President's proposal, and he said, "The ones who take it would be the high-cost cases."
As a result, "it will be almost impossible to establish an adequate premium rate," Mr. Myers said, "one that would involve no additional cost to the Medicare system or to the Government."
In a separate interview today, Ms. Philips said: "It's practically certain that the premiums will not cover the costs. It's unlikely to be self-supporting."
Even some people who support Mr. Clinton's proposal have questions about the adequacy of the premiums in the long run. Asked if the new program would be self-financing, Robert E. McGarrah Jr., a health policy expert at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said, "I really don't see how it could be."
White House officials have thoroughly analyzed the Medicare proposal from the perspective of health policy and politics alike but are still wrestling with some financial questions.
Chris Jennings, a White House aide who coordinates health policy, said he could not explain exactly how the premiums had been computed. Mr. Jennings, repeatedly asked for details in the last two weeks, said today that he still did not have "anything on paper."
Rahm I. Emanuel, a senior adviser to the President, said:
"The Republicans want to talk numbers. We will talk about individual real-life stories. And we will keep pounding the Republicans until Congress approves our proposal."
Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, people 62 to 64 could buy full Medicare coverage -- both hospital care and doctors' services -- for a premium of $300 a month. That, according to the White House, is "the average cost of insuring Americans in this age range."
In developing its proposal, the Administration assumed that people seeking such coverage would be somewhat sicker than the average and would have health costs above the norm for people 62 to 64. Mr. Clinton said the extra costs could be fully offset by requiring these people to pay a surcharge on the standard premium after they reach the age of 65.
"Participants would pay an additional monthly payment, estimated at $10 to $20, for each year that they buy into the Medicare program," Mr. Clinton said. The current premium -- for Part B, covering doctors' services and other outpatient care -- is $43.80 a month.
Mr. Clinton said the extra premium would "cover the extra costs of sicker participants."
But Mr. King, the former chief actuary for Medicare, said people who enrolled early, being sicker than average, would have higher mortality rates and might not survive long enough to pay back the cost of the care they received before reaching 65.
The greater tendency of sick people to buy health insurance is known among insurance experts as adverse selection. The people voluntarily buying coverage are more likely to need costly medical care than the people who pass up the opportunity.
Administration officials and their allies in Congress say this is a manageable problem. If the premiums are too low to cover the cost of expanding Medicare, they say, the Government can simply raise the premiums.
That approach seems plausible, but insurance experts say they doubt that it will work.
"If you raise the rates, healthier people leave the program, and you lose money," Ms. Philips said. "The average claims per person go up. You raise the rates again to try to stop the losses. Relatively healthier people leave. The people who stay in the program are those who know or expect that they will be using the benefits."
Mr. Bluhm said that even a modest amount of "adverse selection" could undermine the finances of an insurance program, because 20 percent of the subscribers typically account for 80 percent of the costs. He described adverse selection as "the annoying tendency people have to do what's best for themselves." It can be a major problem for Medicare, because just 5 percent of elderly beneficiaries account for more than half of all Medicare spending on the elderly.
In a report to Congress last year, the President's Council of Economic Advisers said, "Adverse selection is a potentially serious problem for many types of insurance markets." It explained the vicious circle this way: "Those who expect to incur losses are more likely to buy insurance than those who do not. This raises average expenses per beneficiary and forces insurance companies to raise premiums. Higher premiums discourage people with lower risks from buying insurance."
There are many examples of this circumstance. Under a 1986 law, workers who lose their jobs can usually keep their health insurance for 18 months if they pay the full premium paid by the employer and active workers, plus 2 percent. People who take advantage of this option often need health care, and the cost of their medical claims is about 50 percent higher than that of active workers, according to annual surveys by Charles D. Spencer & Associates, a publisher of employee benefits data.
William S. Custer, an associate professor of risk management and insurance at Georgia State University in Atlanta, said:
"You've got to be realistic. This is not going to be self-financing in the way the Administration describes it. You are trying to reach a very vulnerable population, and it's unrealistic to expect that these beneficiaries will, as a group, be able to pay for their own coverage when you consider the effects of adverse selection. You will have to rely on another tax source, either the payroll tax or general revenues."
About half the states have established programs to provide health insurance to people with medical problems who cannot obtain or afford coverage in the private market.
Ryland B. Musick, director of the Florida program, known as the Florida Comprehensive Health Association, said he doubted that the proposed expansion of Medicare would pay for itself.
"There are some healthy folks in that category under 65," Mr. Musick said, "but many others are medically uninsurable. It will be a challenge to break even without a subsidy. If it requires a subsidy, it would be an excellent investment."

LENGTH: 935 words

HEADLINE: Pataki Urges $3 Billion Plan For Campuses, Doubling Total

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 19

 BODY:
As he prepared to release his election-year budget on Tuesday, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed doubling state spending on campus improvements in the state and city university systems, with a $3 billion, five-year capital program.
The plan marks a stark turnabout from Mr. Pataki's first three years in office, when he cut state support for public colleges, raised tuition and reduced aid to poor students. The reversal is made possible by a healthy economy and a prolonged boom on Wall Street that have given the state a budget surplus three years running. 
 Aides to the Governor said today that the state's surplus would reach $1.8 billion by the end of the fiscal year on March 31, the largest surplus in state history. That has enabled Mr. Pataki to enter his re-election campaign doling out state money to popular programs and proposing tax cuts, and to avoid the politically divisive spending cuts that marked the first half of his term.
In the $69 billion budget he is to propose on Tuesday, the Governor will seek to spread much of the state's new wealth to education, one of the programs most favored by voters and one that Mr. Pataki often sought to cut in previous years. Over the weekend, he said he would seek an increase of more than 4 percent in state aid to primary and secondary schools, the largest rise proposed by a governor since the 1980's. If history is any guide, the Legislature will demand -- and the final budget will contain -- more for schools and universities than in the Governor's proposal.
Mr. Pataki's office released details of his capital program for higher education today but would not say what the 1998-99 budget would hold for operating aid to the universities or tuition assistance for the poor.
In the City University, Queens College would get the biggest benefits in the first year, the only year for which the Governor specified which projects would be financed. The campus would get $28 million to renovate Powdermaker Hall, the main academic building, and $15 million for an AIDS research center to be headed by Prof. Luc Montagnier, a discoverer of the AIDS virus, who was hired last year from the Pasteur Institute in Paris.
The State University at Stony Brook would be another big winner, with $17 million for renovation of its engineering building and $10 million for a sports stadium.
University officials praised the plan,which follows a decade of austerity. The plan was first reported today in Newsday. "The university is extremely pleased about the plan," said Jay Hershenson, vice chancellor of the City University. "It helps CUNY campuses in all of the five boroughs, and significantly enhances the teaching, learning and research environment."
In recent years, the state has spent about $250 million a year on capital improvements for public two-year and four-year colleges and graduate schools. The plan announced today would increase that to $515 million a year for five years, and the state universities would be called on to raise an additional $85 million a year on their own -- through hospital operations, donations and other efforts -- for a total of $600 million a year.
Of the $515 million a year in direct state aid, $315 million would go to the 65-campus State University system and $200 million to the 19-campus City University system, roughly the same proportion as in the past. All the state money would be raised through the sale of bonds -- totaling almost $2.6 billion -- despite criticism from fiscal monitors that the state is already too deeply in debt.
Most of the money would go to renovate buildings that are in disrepair. More than $60 million a year would go for technology like wiring classrooms for computers.
"The Governor recognizes that investment in education is important to the success of its students," said Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's communications director.
Officials in both systems said the Governor adhered closely to the universities' own lists of top priorities in assigning money to specific projects.
But in 1995 and 1996, Mr. Pataki pushed through cuts in the operating budgets of the two systems and a $750-a-year increase in tuition at four-year colleges, a rise of 28 to 31 percent. Even last year, with a state surplus like this year's, he proposed more cuts and tuition increases, but the Legislature refused.
"It's an election year, after all, and this will help deflect criticism of his track record on higher education," Blair Horner, a lobbyist for the New York Public Interest Research Group, said of the Governor's plan.
Mr. Horner, whose group lobbies for more money for higher education, said some of the state's surplus should be used to reverse cuts in operating aid that began during the last recession. "We applaud the Governor's proposal to invest in brick and mortar," he said. "We hope that he and the Legislature will also invest in flesh and blood, by reducing tuition and increasing financial aid."
The average cost of full-time enrollment at one of New York's public colleges has tripled in the last decade. Public college tuition in New York is the 12th highest of any state, according to the Federal Department of Education. Four-year college tuition is $3,200 a year in the city system and $3,400 a year in the state system, and students typically pay an additional $500 annually in fees.
The first-year projects Mr. Pataki proposed include $22 million for Brooklyn College to build the West Quad section of the campus, $12 million to renovate Shepard Hall at City College and financing for a classroom building at Baruch College.

HEADLINE: Faith in a Moral Motive for Work;
The Man Who Redesigned Welfare in Wisconsin Is Coming

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

 BODY:
Some teen-agers doodle away the hours drawing race cars or basketball plays. As a high school student in the late 1960's, Jason A. Turner used to draft plans for factories that would put welfare recipients to work.
"I just did it -- not for class," he once said, describing the passion for workfare programs that gripped him early in life. "One of the things that sustained me was I believed I had a solution: 'Hey, listen guys, this is it!' " 
 Among those now lending an ear is Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who named Mr. Turner on Jan. 7 to run the City Human Resources Administration. The move brings one of the nation's most zealous supporters of work requirements to the city where they may meet their toughest test.
At 44, Mr. Turner is a burly, affable, self-effacing man with an unusual sense of mission and more street smarts than the average welfare theorist. An Ivy League graduate from a boarding-school background, he has been a political appointee in the Reagan and Bush Administrations and an architect of Wisconsin's ambitious work program. But he also did college stints as a taxi driver in Houston, and he once sought his fortune as a low-income landlord, only to lose a three-year battle with the neighborhood's crack dealers.
What he has not done is run a program as big as the one he now inherits. New York City has about 10 times as many welfare recipients as Milwaukee, Wisconsin's largest city.
The design of his policies -- as well as his own famously long hours -- make it clear that Mr. Turner views work as more than just an economic necessity. His welfare theories are grounded in the faith that work morally transforms those who perform it, rich and poor alike. "Work is one's own gift to others, and when you sever that relationship with your fellow man, you're doing more than just harm to yourself economically," he said in an interview last spring. "You're doing spiritual harm."
In announcing Mr. Turner's appointment, the Mayor praised his work in Wisconsin, where he helped design a program striking in both its generosity and toughness. It offers welfare recipients extensive child care, job-placement services and, if needed, a community service job.
But it also tolerates virtually no exemptions and it punishes those who fail to comply by withdrawing all cash support.
It remains unclear how much of that vision Mr. Turner hopes to transport to New York City, where unemployment is higher, unions are stronger, the bureaucracy is more unwieldy and the ideological enemies of work programs are more numerous. Untested as a large-scale administrator, Mr. Turner will preside over an agency with 14,000 employees and a $5.8 billion budget at the same time he seeks to transform its institutional culture. And much of his success will depend on creating a relationship with Mayor Giuliani, a man he met only recently.
It is a sign of the challenges -- and the potential for missteps -- that neither Mr. Giuliani nor Mr. Turner would comment last week on their plans. But in his State of the City address last week, the Mayor outlined a welfare vision that sounded much like the Wisconsin program. "We will establish a universal work requirement for everyone receiving benefits," he said. "Other than for severe disabilities, there will be few exceptions."
Mr. Turner's appointment drew high praise from conservative supporters of work programs. "Jason is the most effective welfare reformer in the country," said Robert Rector of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research organization in Washington. Mr. Rector went on to say, however, that "the alignment of forces against reform are much stronger in New York than they are in Wisconsin."
In interviews last year, Mr. Turner said he first grew interested in welfare as a junior high school student, after reading a magazine story on fraud. As the son of a prosperous advertising executive in Darien, Conn., he said, "it just hadn't occurred to me that there were whole classes of people who didn't work, and who basically existed on government charity."
His faith in the work ethic stemmed partly from his maternal grandfather, a Princeton-educated banker who lost his job in the Depression but went on to support his family as a door-to-door brush salesman. Mr. Turner briefly flirted with liberalism as a student at Columbia University. (He voted for George S. McGovern for President in 1972.) But his concern about social order reawakened after he was twice robbed at gunpoint while driving a cab on college vacations.
After working on the 1980 Reagan campaign, Mr. Turner landed an appointment as a junior Federal housing official. Unable to gain an audience for his welfare ideas, he left in 1985 and sank his retirement savings into several small apartment buildings in Washington, only to lose everything.
Mr. Turner returned to government in 1989 as a senior Federal welfare official, but found little support for bold action inside the Bush Administration. Out of office after the 1992 election, he surprised friends by accepting a second-tier bureaucratic appointment in Wisconsin because he was convinced that Gov. Tommy G. Thompson would make sweeping changes.
The program Mr. Turner helped build is distinguished by two features. One is its uncompromising insistence on work. Unlike many states, Wisconsin offers no period of temporary cash aid in which recipients can pursue training or sort out life crises. From the start, virtually everyone is expected to work 30 hours a week -- either with a private employer, or in a community service job if private work cannot be found.
In addition, Mr. Turner established an unusual system of bureaucratic competition. He required county governments to meet specified goals, including caseload reduction, or face bids from private contractors.
Beyond his role as a policy architect, Mr. Turner was also known as a tenacious policy implementer. At one point, his responsibilities included overseeing the work program in Milwaukee. When working in his state policy office in Madison, he sometimes stayed so late that he slept on the floor rather than commute 80 miles to his Milwaukee home. (Mr. Turner and his wife, Angie, now have four young children, including year-old twin boys and a month-old daughter.)
The criticism of Mr. Turner, like the praise, centers on his relentless emphasis on work. In his drive to impose new work rules last year, he set up a computer system short on record-keeping safeguards. As a result, thousands of recipients in Milwaukee temporarily lost their benefits, even while showing up to work.
And while the Wisconsin plan has been praised for its investments in job development and child care, it tends to assume that those services are all that is needed.
So far, the Wisconsin system has given only limited thought to recipients who, for whatever reason, fail to hold the jobs. Some have alcohol or drug problems. Some have mental health problems. Others are tangled in violent relationships at home. In a work-or-else system, some clearly fall through the cracks.
"We're expecting a lot of people who just don't have their lives together to get a job," said Anne Arnesen, the director of the Wisconsin Council on Children and Families, an advocacy group in Madison. "It's hurting women who are not ready for the workplace."
Since imposing work requirements, Wisconsin has seen its caseloads fall nearly 70 percent, with only modest rises in homelessness or other measures of social distress. But as in New York, there is no reliable information on what happens to recipients after they leave the rolls.
In New York, Mr. Turner will face larger challenges on every front. With about 246,000 families on the rolls, New York City has a caseload six times that of Wisconsin. Its unemployment rate is 8.7 percent, compared with 3.4 percent in Wisconsin. And so far Mr. Turner has succeeded as a behind-the-scenes mechanic, not a public spokesman. He has never held the top bureaucratic job.
What's more, the political environment in New York is much more contentious than it is in Wisconsin. Advocacy groups are more deeply opposed to work requirements, especially for women with young children. And New York's conservatives have not shown Governor Thompson's willingness to invest money.
Mr. Giuliani's work program already includes about 32,000 participants, making it by far the largest in the country. Merely by establishing such a sizable program, the Mayor exceeded conventional expectations. But about three-quarters of its participants are single adults, and Mr. Turner will now confront the tougher problems of women with children.
In an interview last summer, Mr. Turner worried about the competence of big-city bureaucracies, and he said New York posed a special challenge. "New York has real ideological warfare and has had for years," he said. "Where there's real hard and fast lines drawn, it makes it real hard to define and run a program. It takes the wind out of your sails at the implementation level."
He did praise Mr. Giuliani, before meeting him, for "being able to get a big work program up and running." But he also worried that the New York City program was "reaching the end of the easy enrollment" and predicted "they can't go further" without a major new effort. That was before he understood that the major new effort would be his.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jason A. Turner, named to run the City Human Resources Administration. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)
