HEADLINE: First Stop a Tough One For Panel on Gambling

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 16

 BODY:
The Atlantic City Rescue Mission, a huge, modern building that sits amid run-down houses just a few blocks from the Boardwalk, offers a look at the good and bad of the gambling boom that has swept the country over the past 20 years.
Many of the more than 3,000 people who come to the mission each year looking for food and shelter are gamblers who failed to quit before their luck and money ran out. 
 On the other hand, the mission has no trouble accommodating all comers, nongamblers included, thanks to the casinos.
Last year, the Trump Taj Mahal and the Trump Marina gave $294,000 in food to the mission. In 1996, Bally's casino helped pay down the mortgage on the mission's nine-year-old building by donating $866,000. And last year alone, the city's 12 casinos contributed more than $1 million to the mission.
"If the casinos weren't here," said Barry K. Durman, the mission's chief executive, "you wouldn't need a mission this size. And if the casinos weren't supporting us, we wouldn't be able to serve the number of people we serve."
On Wednesday, gambling experts, casino officials and reporters will descend on the mission in one of the first stops for the National Gambling Impact Study Commission, a panel appointed by President Clinton and Congress to examine the social and economic consequences of legalized gambling in the United States. With the $40 billion-a-year gaming industry facing its closest scrutiny ever, gambling's advocates and opponents alike are converging on this city, vying for the attention of the nine-member commission during the two-day meeting.
"Everyone wants us to see Atlantic City through their eyes," said Kay Coles James, the chairwoman of the commission. "I suspect that no one on either side is going to be entirely happy with how we do it."
There is no Federal oversight of gambling operations, other than those on Indian reservations. But since the commission was formed several months ago, gambling interests have been fearful that the commission could recommend Federal regulations, increased taxes and other measures to control the continued growth of their industry.
The legislation that led to the commission's formation was pushed by Representative Frank R. Wolf, Republican of Virginia, and at first called for the study of the "negative" effects of gambling. Pro-gaming forces, however, lobbied to have the language changed to make it a study of the "social and economic impacts" of the industry. Still, gambling proponents, who have lined up powerful Washington lobbyists, have repeatedly expressed their concern that the industry will not get an impartial review.
"There have been a series of things during the life of the commission that create the impression that rather than going down the middle and examining things, they're going to skew things in favor of those who are opposed to gambling," said Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., chief executive of the American Gaming Association, the industry's trade group.
The commission plans to visit other major gambling centers throughout the year and has until June 1999 to complete its work and issue a report to the President and Congress.
In the days leading to the meeting, the lobbying has been intense and the complaining about the commission's approach has been at a high pitch. Hoping to show off some of the things that gambling revenues have helped pay for -- his city's new $83 million senior high school and its 4,800 new housing units -- Atlantic City's Mayor, James Whelan, invited the commissioners to take a bus tour of the city. Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey, a Democrat who is one of the casino industry's strongest allies in Washington, offered to take the commission members to dinner to discuss the economic development projects under way in the city.
Despite these efforts, when the commission released its agenda for the meeting earlier this month, the proponents of gambling cried foul.
Other than their two days of presentations from government officials, and testimony from the public and experts on pathological gambling, the panel members had scheduled visits to only the rescue mission, a shop that pays cash for jewelry and the Trump Taj Mahal.
"I was furious," Mr. Torricelli said. "I wanted them to see that Atlantic City is not a finished project and that it is on a launching pad. From the new high school to the housing, none of this would have happened without gaming."
The commission, Mr. Torricelli said, "should have never existed, but since it was created we have to make the best of a bad situation."
Much of the criticism over the commission's objectivity has been directed at its chairwoman, Mrs. James, who is a religious conservative, a former Bush Administration official and the dean of the school of government at Regent University, the Virginia institution started by the Christian Coalition's founder, Pat Robertson.
Mrs. James's first choice as the commission's full-time executive director, James Kilgore, was forced to withdraw last summer after gambling advocates learned that he had declared his opposition to gambling when he ran for Virginia Attorney General. Mrs. James had assured the panel that Mr. Kilgore had never taken a position on gambling. Nancy Mohr Kennedy was subsequently chosen to direct the commission's staff and its $4 million budget.
Then last fall, when Mrs. James hired a research director, Timothy Kelly, she came under attack again because Mr. Kelly, commissioner of Virginia's mental health department, had done past research work as a consultant for the Family Research Council, a conservative group.
The selection of Mr. Kelly, Mrs. James said in a recent interview, was based solely on his ability as a researcher.
"There has been an entire litany of criticisms to the point that I've wondered if it's an attempt to discredit me and the commission so that at the end of the day you can discredit the report," she said.
In recent days, after further discussions with Atlantic City officials, Mrs. James decided to add the Mayor's bus tour to the agenda.
"There is no predisposition to slant our visit in any way," she said. "Any objective observer, looking at how we're going to spend our time in Atlantic City, would have to determine that it is a very fair and balanced approach."
The commission's makeup is actually balanced, with some people who are considered pro-gambling, some who are opposed to it and some who have no strong prior positions on the issue.
Its members include J. Terrence Lanni, the chairman and chief executive of MGM Grand, the casino and hotel company based in Nevada. At least two or three other members are viewed as likely proponents of the industry. Because of her religious conservatism, Mrs. James is believed to be opposed to gambling, although she has insisted that she plans to approach the study without bias. James C. Dobson, founder of Focus on the Family, is considered one of the staunchest gambling foes on the commission.
Gambling opponents have their own concerns about the commission, worrying that the financial muscle and political influence of the casino industry could unduly influence it.
"People on our side are saying the deck is stacked against us because people like Lanni are on the commission," said Tom Grey, the executive director of the National Coalition Against Gambling Expansion.
Mr. Grey, who is clearly enjoying all the anxiety that the commission has created in the industry, said the constant complaints from casino proponents suggested that the industry was not a harmless form of entertainment, as its executives contend.
"Never have I seen such tough people whine and complain so much," Mr. Grey said in a telephone interview. "If this is such a great product like they say it is, then they've got a national commission to show it off to."
On Wednesday night, the commission is to hear testimony from over 100 people. The first eight speakers are members of Gamblers Anonymous. And on Thursday, the commission will hear from experts on compulsive gambling, a problem that casinos acknowledge but contend has been exaggerated by opponents.
"I think it could be more than just an abstract discussion of the problem," said Leo T. McCarthy, the former Lieutenant Governor of California and a member of the commission. "Some useful statistics could come from this testimony."
And Mr. Durman, the executive director of the rescue mission, knows that people on both sides hope to score points in their tour on Wednesday. He is putting the finishing touches on a report and survey that he expects to hand out, which will reveal what percentage of his clients seek help from the mission as a result of gambling.
He is also expecting to get the dirty, tattered carpet in the family lounge replaced before the tour. A new roll of carpet was donated by Caesars Palace.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Asia Troubles Affecting Boeing Orders

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The Boeing Company may have to delay deliveries of jetliners to Malaysian Airline System Bhd. and Philippine Airlines Inc., as Asian airlines struggle to pay for orders made before the region's financial crisis.
Executives of Boeing, the world's biggest aircraft maker, will probably meet this week with Malaysian Airline executives, a Boeing spokesman, Mark Hooper, said. Malaysian Airline is seeking to change a schedule that would have it take delivery of 19 aircraft by 2001, the state news agency reported, citing an interview with the airline's chairman. 
 Seattle-based Boeing is in discussions with Philippine Airlines, which has seven aircraft on order, according to a Boeing spokeswoman, Carie Cable. All seven are 747-400 jumbo jets and together would cost a total of $1.18 billion at official prices, though discounts are nearly always given.
Last week, Philippine Airlines said it had canceled plans to buy four 747-400's.
Asian airlines make up about 30 percent of Boeing's order backlog. The devaluation of Asian currencies is making it harder for countries to pay for new aircraft and to forecast the need for jets.
Boeing said no airline had canceled any orders because of the Asian crisis, though as many as 60 airplane deliveries may be delayed in the next three years.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Albright Defends Bailout Role by U.S.

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The Secretary of State, Madeleine Albright, denied today that the United States was surrendering too much money and power to the International Monetary Fund.
In an interview, she emphasized the major role the United States plays in I.M.F. decision-making and rejected critics who say that United States-backed I.M.F. rescue packages for Asian economies in financial crisis are "bailing out Wall Street." 
 "We are a major part of the I.M.F." and have substantial voting power under the institution's weighted voting system, Ms. Albright said.
Bailouts for Asia's battered economies have brought debate in Washington over President Clinton's economic priorities and the issue of whether the United States is surrendering too much to the I.M.F.
During the interview at the State Department, Ms. Albright asserted that countries receiving bailouts -- South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand -- "have a strong resource base and they need to be allowed to have some breathing space to get themselves back on their feet."
Without such assistance, the crisis would continue with potentially negative consequences for the United States economy, she said.

HEADLINE: Japan and U.S. Draw Closer to Agreement to Liberalize Air Travel

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
United States and Japanese negotiators have agreed on the broad outlines of a deal that would greatly increase the number of flights between the two countries and liberalize travel across the Pacific, airline executives and officials in the Clinton Administration said yesterday.
But the two sides, which open a new round of talks today in Washington, still face a number of outstanding issues that could make a final agreement in the long-running trade dispute elusive. 
 "You never know what happens in a negotiation," said a senior administration official who insisted on anonymity. "But things are closer than they have ever been."
While the Japanese must still agree on a few key issues, the Administration also faces opposition from members of Congress who feel that the proposed agreement does not go far enough. Last week, Senator Jesse Helms, the powerful chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, urged the Clinton Administration not to conclude a deal before he held hearings on Feb. 12, because the proposed agreement falls short of so-called "open skies," or a full-scale liberalization of air traffic between the two nations.
Mr. Helms said that at a time when the United States was urging Asian countries to deregulate their economies to resolve the region's economic crisis, settling for less than open skies with Japan would send the wrong signal.
But Administration officials countered that they would not agree to any deal that did not significantly liberalize air service to Japan, and they felt confident that they could win over Mr. Helms and other critics. An agreement does not require Senate ratification.
"If this thing gels, it will be a substantial deregulation of the trans-Pacific market," the senior Administration official said. "Will it be total? No. But it will be substantial."
Most of the major American airlines appear to be supporting the proposed agreement with the exception of the Northwest Airlines Corporation, which has the strongest presence in Japan of any American airline and has lobbied strongly against anything short of full liberalization.
"This agreement will transform air transportation as we know it," Gerald Greenwald, the chairman and chief executive of United Airlines, said last week. "It will allow the airline industry to provide convenient access to virtually every major city in the world for the first time."
Japanese airlines long resisted air service liberalization because they feared that they would quickly be overshadowed by American carriers, which are more efficient. But the Japanese have also complained about the unfairness of a bilateral air services deal signed in the aftermath of World War II that gave American airlines more access to Japan than Japanese carriers have to the United States.
Under the terms of the proposed deal, Northwest, United Airlines and the Federal Express Corporation -- the three carriers that currently have the most rights to fly to Japan -- would receive virtually unlimited access to the country. That would allow United, which can now fly only six times a week from its hub in Chicago to Tokyo, to more than double that number and give Federal Express the right to fly cargo from Japan to other destinations in Asia.
In addition, about 90 new flights a week to Tokyo and Osaka would be divided among American Airlines, Delta Air Lines Inc. and Continental Airlines -- which currently are allowed only a few flights to Japan -- as well as to two airlines that currently do not fly to Japan, most likely US Airways and T.W.A.
In exchange, All Nippon Airways, Japan's second-largest airline, would receive unlimited rights to fly to the United States, joining Japan Airlines.
The biggest dispute holding up the agreement is Japan's resistance to allowing American carriers to team up with other airlines, both foreign and domestic, to offer flights to Japan and on to other destinations in Asia. Such so-called code-sharing would allow an American carrier to sell a ticket, say, to Singapore by flying a passenger to Tokyo and then transferring the passenger to a Singapore Airlines flight.
Critics say that the proposed deal does not challenge the Japanese Government's power to control ticket prices, which protects its relatively inefficient airlines by preventing the American carriers from competing by offering lower prices. They also say that the American negotiators have given All Nippon Airways unfettered access to the United States without insuring that American carriers will receive space to land at Tokyo's crowded Narita Airport.
The 90 new flights a week were created only after Federal Express agreed to lend some of the landing slots it was not using to commercial carriers until a second runway is completed at Narita, which could be several years away. And because the slots were designed for cargo planes, the landings and takeoffs are scheduled for early in the morning or late at night, inconvenient times for commercial passengers.
Chris Chiames, a spokesman for American Airlines, said that the Federal Express slots could be traded for more convenient times.

HEADLINE: New Baldness Drug Is Older Product at a Premium Price

BYLINE: By DAVID J. MORROW 

 BODY:
Kenneth Scovotti, a balding 55-year-old manager of a New York City gasoline station, has spent $15,000 for five hair transplants the last four years. So he was elated to learn about Propecia, Merck & Company's new hair-growth drug.
"Whether it works or not, I was determined to try it," Mr. Scovotti said. "The only problem is that it's expensive for a pill." 
 In the week or so since Propecia arrived in America's pharmacies, thousands of men have rushed to doctors' offices for prescriptions. Once at the pharmacy, though, they get a dose of cold reality: Merck is selling Propecia for three times the price, per milligram, that it charges for another of its products that uses the same active ingredient, Proscar, a treatment for enlarged prostates.
Marketing an existing drug under a second name is not new, but raising the price is. Merck defends the premium, citing added research costs.
Still, that math is fast creating a black market for Propecia, even over the Internet, and prompting many balding men to try a home science project and possibly commit insurance fraud. Because one Proscar tablet equals five daily doses of Propecia, users persuade doctors to write them prescriptions for the prostate drug and then slice the pills into five parts.
Propecia costs about $50 for a month's supply, or $250 for five months. A bottle of Proscar tablets, which, after dissection, would also last five months, costs about $70, or $14 a month. By contrast, Rogaine -- Propecia's over-the-counter competitor -- costs about $30 a month.
Proscar tablets are covered by most insurance policies; Propecia usually is not -- not even by Merck's employee health plans. Men who get Proscar tablets and dice them may pay nothing for the pills once the insurer picks up the tab, but the practice could be illegal.
"This is definite fraud," said Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University. "A person's insurance policy is worried about their prostate and has allowed money to pay for that, not to foot the bill for hair to grow on their heads."
Merck executives, meanwhile, are frowning heavily over splitting pills. "We don't recommend that people try to divide Proscar tablets to create a dose of Propecia," said Raymond V. Gilmartin, Merck's chairman and chief executive.
"For one thing, there's the precision involved; Propecia is one milligram of finasteride," Mr. Gilmartin said of the active ingredient. "It's hard to split a pill and come away with exactly that amount."
The price issue has not, of course, caught Merck officials by surprise. To counter the inevitable resistance, Merck is allowing consumers to receive a $10 rebate by buying three bottles in what is called a Propak and is rolling out a discount plan for repeat users.
Merck has rolled out the special deals because the stakes are so high. Between 2000 and 2002, three of Merck's big drugs -- those with yearly sales of $1 billion or more -- will lose patent protection, opening the door for generic versions. To offset an inevitable erosion in revenue, Merck is rolling out five new drugs, including Propecia, that could become billion-dollar sellers.
The company's patent woes, though, are merely a backdrop to the more intricate problem of Propecia's pricing. Glaxo Wellcome, for example, sold bupropion as the antidepressant Wellbutrin for years but spun it off recently as Zyban, a drug to help people quit smoking. The price stayed the same.
Why weren't Propecia users as fortunate? Some Wall Street analysts say Merck had no choice. Merck officials insist that Propecia did not share Proscar's research budget but ran up its own bill, estimated at $450 million.
Even so, the additional markup on Propecia is so great that Merck could recoup its research and development expenses quickly. If 1.35 million men were to use Propecia for just a year, the windfall would total some $450 million.
"There's a myth about Propecia," said Wendy Dixon, vice president for specialty and new-product marketing at Merck. "A lot of stories have said that men in the Proscar studies came back with hair, and that's how we got Propecia. They were two totally different products with two separate clinical studies."
Not only does Merck have to recover Propecia's research expenses, the company is also at greater risk of coming up empty-handed. Propecia users, after all, are not sick, so they can stop taking the drug at any time.
Merck's only remedy is a heavy ad campaign, scheduled to begin later this year. Analysts expect no expense to be spared, which will further swell Propecia's overhead.
"One way or another, consumers are going to pay," said Neil Sweig, an analyst with Southeast Research Partners. "Merck will spend at least $50 million this year promoting Propecia and maybe even $100 million if they believe they need ads to stimulate more sales. With Zyban, you lose the customer once they stop smoking. With Propecia, you can keep them forever, but you'll lose them quick if they get discouraged and quit."
Despite a potential market of 33 million American men who have pattern baldness, putting Propecia in a lot of medicine cabinets will not be easy. Dr. Marc Avram, director of the cosmetic surgical unit at New York Hospital, gets 5 to 10 calls a day from men interested in Propecia, but many later decide against taking it.
"For a lot of men, the cost is the deciding factor," Dr. Avram said. "It takes anywhere from three to six months to see any results, and if you quit, you lose the hair that you've grown. Other men are afraid of some of the possible side effects."
Propecia can cause birth defects and should not be used by women. The Propak box has a warning that women should not even hold a broken or crushed Propecia tablet. The drug also carries a slight risk of impotence, lasting as long as it is used.
What may be especially problematic, however, is the psychological element. Apparently, no one is immune to being sensitive on the topic of balding. Asked whether he plans to use Propecia, Mr. Gilmartin, who is clearly losing his hair, said he was thinking about it. When, exactly? "That's personal," he said.
It is too early to gauge the success of Merck's repeat-buyer plan, but analysts are enthusiastic. With a Propak, users can buy a three-month supply and receive a $10 rebate. They can also sign up for the Perks Program, enabling repeat Propak buyers to receive $20 rebates for two future purchases.
"We're pushing the Propak because hair grows slowly, usually between three and six months," said Tom Casola, executive director of Merck's dermatology marketing group. "We want them to stay tied to the product until they see it work."
In the meantime, American TV viewers should prepare for a lot of hair commercials. This month, Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. unleashed an $80 million ad budget to promote extra-strength Rogaine, a topical liquid applied twice daily. Kenneth Vargha, director of marketing for Pharmacia & Upjohn's consumer health care division, said the timing was a coincidence but that he was confident of winning any hair war.
The first hurdle for Merck might be the Internet market. On the Usenet news group alt.baldspot last week, a user in Italy was offering to send Proscar tablets to the United States for just $63 a bottle, or $12.60 for a month's supply of Propecia.
But is hair all it is cracked up to be? "Before people get caught up in Propecia or any hair-replacement treatment," Dr. Avram said, "it might be best for them to consider what they'd look like when they really lose their hair. There's no doubt that it changes someone's looks. But sometimes, the change may be for the better."

HEADLINE: St. Paul to Pay $2.8 Billion For USF&G

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
The St. Paul Companies, one of the nation's largest insurers of corporations, said yesterday that it was acquiring a large competitor, USF& G, for about $2.8 billion in stock, in one of the largest insurance mergers in recent years.
St. Paul, whose chief executive, Douglas W. Leatherdale, will head the combined companies, is also assuming about $700 million in USF& G debt. 
 Mr. Leatherdale and Norman P. Blake Jr., the chief executive of USF& G, said in a joint interview that the merger would yield greater market share and geographic reach for the combined company.
"This is a real reinforcement of the businesses we are strong in," Mr. Blake said.
Both companies are major players in the fields of construction and medical malpractice insurance. St. Paul also has a presence in insuring technology concerns, such as computer companies, and USF& G is a leader in insuring banks, brokerage firms and other financial institutions, as well as municipalities and universities.
"USF& G is strong in the South and Northeast," Mr. Leatherdale said, "and that complements our strength in the Midwest."
Dozens of insurance companies have merged in the last few years. And as larger companies have emerged, many of the remaining companies have sought partners to make sure that they were not squeezed out of the market and to gain economies of scale.
"We think there is an opportunity to take significant cost out of the merged operations," Mr. Leatherdale said.
He estimated that the combined work force of 16,500, including 6,500 USF& G employees and 10,000 at St. Paul, would be reduced over the next 18 months by 1,500 to 2,000.
All together, savings in operating expenses are expected to run to $150 million, Mr. Blake said. St. Paul also expects to take a charge of $300 to $500 million for restructuring related to the merger.
The executives said that they expected the merger to add immediately to the earnings of the combined company, which is to keep the St. Paul name.
Rob Meyers, a managing director at J&H Marsh & McLennan, the world's largest insurance brokerage, said both companies were "very solid."
Gloria Vogel, an insurance analyst at Advest Inc., a brokerage firm based in Hartford, agreed. But she said it would have been difficult for USF& G to survive on its own as competition increased.
"They just weren't efficient enough," she said. "They weren't bleeding. But over the long term they would have been forced to partner with somebody."
Ms. Vogel said that because St. Paul's expertise lies almost exclusively in commercial insurance, the hardest part of the consolidation might be the absorption of USF& G's business in life and home coverage.
The headquarters of the combined companies will be in St. Paul, where the St. Paul Companies are based. But the executives said that the merged company would continue to have significant operations in Baltimore, where USF& G is based.
The purchase price is based on an exchange ratio for USF& G's 111 million shares that could vary based on the price of St. Paul shares during a 20-day period leading up to a USF& G shareholder meeting at which the deal will be considered.
St. Paul agreed to pay about $22 each for USF& G's shares if St. Paul shares trade between $74 and $78 during that period. USF& G shares closed on Friday at $21.4375. St. Paul's roughly 91 million shares closed at $78.125 on Friday.
If St. Paul's stock rises above $78 during that period, USF& G shareholders will share in the increase, though the price will fall if St. Paul shares fall below $74. The deal is expected to close in midsummer.
Mr. Blake said he made the first overture toward St. Paul to initiate the merger. But Mr. Leatherdale said he had been looking for just such an opportunity.
"We think the combined company is going to have a very large presence in the industry," Mr. Leatherdale said.
St. Paul reported revenue of $4.3 billion last year, nearly all from commerical insurance. About 70 percent of USF& G's business is commercial. The rest is in such lines as insurance for automobiles and homes. Of the more than 1,000 companies selling property and casualty insurance in the United States, St. Paul has been ranked 15th and USF& G, 23d. Together, they will form the country's eighth-largest property and casualty insurer, with assets of more than $36 billion and estimated revenue from premiums of $7 billion.

HEADLINE: Congressional Fact-Finding in Saipan: They Came. They Saw. They Golfed.

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
At least five members of Congress and dozens of Congressional aides have traveled a grueling 9,000 miles, crossed nine time zones and endured serious jet lag, all in the name of diligent fact finding.
Their destination: Saipan, a volcanic island and capital of the Northern Marianas, a chain of 14 islands in the western Pacific that is a commonwealth of the United States. The islands, which are about 3,500 miles west of Hawaii, boast crystalline lagoons, balmy climes, championship golf courses and, for the free-market minded, relaxed wage and immigration rules. 
 The bills for the journeys, which can run as high as $5,500 for one person for one week, were paid by the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, which is trying hard to keep its exemption from Federal minimum wage and immigration laws.
"You have people coming here who, before they came on the trip, couldn't find Saipan on the map and have no direct responsibility over it, no history of involvement," said Representative George Miller of California, the ranking Democrat on the House Resources Committee who is a vocal critic of the commonwealth's low wages and labor policies. "It's just a pure and simple lobbying job."
For the past year and a half, the office of the commonwealth's Governor has conducted an ambitious public relations campaign, paying millions of dollars for fact-finding trips and in fees to Washington lobbyists, particularly the law firm of Preston, Gates, Ellis & Rouvelas Meeds.
What sets this lobbying strategy apart from others is the success that the Marianas government has had in convincing Congressional Republicans that Democrats are wrong in pushing a bill that would raise wages and curtail immigration there.
Over the New Year's holiday, Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority whip who has been a staunch supporter of the commonwealth's policies, made the trip to Micronesia with his wife, his daughter and three aides. He stayed for five work-filled days but also found time to play two rounds of golf on a pristine seaside golf course. Upon his return, Mr. DeLay proclaimed the Democrats' legislation dead.
The government-paid trips, first reported by Roll Call, the Capitol Hill newspaper, have become especially popular in the last year, when the former Governor of the Northern Marianas, Froilan Tenorio, sensed a threat from the Clinton Administration to the islands' status quo. The Administration has described the laws as exploitative to workers.
Called to action, the Washington lobbyists hired by the commonwealth got to work. They extended invitations to nearly all members of Congress and their aides, as well as to officials of conservative research centers and newspaper editorial writers, to "educate" them about the Northern Marianas, said Jack Abramoff, the Preston, Gates lobbyist who arranged the trips. As many as 80 Congressional staff members, most of them Republicans who espouse free-market beliefs and dislike Democratic labor policies, have visited the island courtesy of the government.
"They don't have a Congressman or a delegate to the United States," Mr. Abramoff said. "It's the farthest territory from the United States. Nobody knew anything about it. And the Federal bureaucracy, which for so long had a paternalistic and almost colonialist rule over these guys, said let's make a move on their economy."
After World War I, Japan controlled Saipan and the Northern Marianas under a League of Nations mandate. Saipan, which was the site of a Japanese air base in World War II, was seized by United States forces in July 1944 after a three-week battle in which 3,400 Americans and 27,000 Japanese were killed. The island, 13 miles long and about 5 miles wide, then became a base for air attacks on the Japanese home islands.
Saipan and the other Northern Marianas voted to become a commonwealth in 1975. To help stimulate industry, the United States agreed to exempt it from Federal minimum wage and immigration laws.
Now Democrats say the exemption should be revoked. Most of the garment factories are not owned by American citizens. The workers hail mostly from China, Bangladesh and the Philippines, brought in for one or two years and paid $3.05 an hour, compared with $5.15 in the United States. So many workers have arrived -- 35,000 -- that they outnumber Saipan's permanent residents.
To the Democrats' chagrin, the clothing can be shipped to the United States with labels that say "Made in the U.S.A. With Imported Fabric," because Saipan is American soil. Earlier this week the bipartisan United States Commission on Immigration Reform deplored what it described as systematic labor and human-rights violations relating to the treatment of workers there.
But Congressional visitors on Government-paid trips return home with a rosier picture of the islands, said Allen Stayman, an Interior Department official and critic of commonwealth policies.
Saipan is "essentially being taken over by Asian garment interests who are exploiting it for their own greed," said Mr. Stayman.
At least five members of Congress have made government-paid trips to Saipan in the past year and a half, but the island's most illustrious Congressional visitor was Mr. DeLay, the Texas Republican, who came at the invitation of the former Governor, Mr. Tenorio. Mr. DeLay's trip was arranged by Mr. Abramoff, a friend who, along with his wife, contributed $4,000 to Mr. DeLay's 1998 re-election campaign.
To be sure, Mr. DeLay's official itinerary was chock full of meetings. He met with the former Governor and the new Governor, Pedro P. Tenorio, a relative of his predecessor. Mr. DeLay sat down with members of the legislature and with the Roman Catholic Bishop of Saipan, who touched on human rights.
But there was time for regaling and relaxing, too.
Mr. DeLay was honored and entertained every evening. One reception was given by a Hong Kong businessman, Willie Tan, who agreed in 1992 to pay $9 million in back wages for his companies' failure to pay garment workers overtime.
And Mr. DeLay, an avid golfer, twice played on one of Saipan's finest golf courses, the Lao Lao Bay Golf Resort. He and his family also visited Managaha Island, a 10-acre island in the lagoon that is known for its snorkeling.
When he returned to Washington, Mr. DeLay spoke glowingly of the commonwealth's economic policies and renewed his vow to block legislation that would tinker with its wage and immigration policies.
Mr. DeLay's press secretary, John P. Feehery, who accompanied him, said the Congressman wanted to see for himself whether Saipan's purported sweatshop conditions were as outrageous as the Democrats say.
" 'Tis the season to cry junket," Mr. Feehery said. "He would not travel 30 hours for some fun in the sun. That's not what he's about."
By and large, Republicans maintain that Mr. Stayman and other Democrats are simply doing the bidding of American labor unions. Saipan's policy, they say, has been fruitful and effective at making the islands increasingly self-sufficient.
It is an opinion they have honed during their visits to the Marianas.
Representative Phil English, Republican of Pennsylvania, just returned from his own trip to Saipan, where he represented Congressional Republicans at the new Governor's inauguration.
Other guests of the Marianas government have included Representatives Dana Rohrabacher, who later gave a complimentary speech about the commonwealth on the House floor, and Brian P. Bilbray, both California Republicans. Mr. Rohrabacher took his fiancee along, and Mr. Bilbray took his wife.
Because the commonwealth is the equivalent of a state government, the Congressmen did not have to disclose the trips in the same way as those paid for by private businesses. At least four Democrats have made the trip, but the Marianas government did not pay the expenses of three of them. Mr. Miller, who introduced legislation to change the wage and immigrations laws, visited the island this week. His expenses were paid for by taxpayers because he traveled on committee business.
The same will apply for Representative Don Young, the Alaska Republican who leads the Resources Committee, which has jurisdiction over the commonwealth, and 10 members of the panel, who plan to visit Saipan in February. But one of Mr. Young's aides took a trip there earlier this month, paid for by the commonwealth.
Some members of Congress are distancing themselves from the Pacific voyages.
"You can't make a decision here in Washington that affects the Northern Marianas with your head stuck in the sand," said Ken Johnson, press secretary for Representative W. J. (Billy) Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who decided this week not to take the February trip.
"That said," Mr. Johnson continued, "there have been instances where staff members have been shielded from seeing and talking to people who would be able to shed some light on what is happening over there. You're only going to see what they want you to see."

HEADLINE: 3 Years After War, Ecuador and Peru Agree to Peace Talks

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Ecuador and Peru, which went to war three years ago over a border dispute, signed an agreement here today creating a timetable that they said would lead to a peace treaty.
Four commissions are to be established to tackle the main areas of contention between the countries. One will deal with the most thorny issue: demarcation of the border. The other commissions will focus on matters including trade and navigation, security and confidence-building measures. 
 The accord was signed here in an atmosphere of friendliness that contrasted with the past belligerence between the two Andean countries.
Last year, after President Abdala Bucaram of Ecuador visited Peru, the Ecuadorean Congress debated charging him with treason. The visit was high on the list of sins cited when Mr. Bucaram was impeached soon after his return and removed from office. Congress chose Fabian Alarcon to replace him.
The brief war between Ecuador and Peru erupted in January 1995, around the anniversary of the Rio Protocol, a 1942 peace treaty in which Ecuador, defeated in battle, ceded half of its territory. Though it signed the treaty, Ecuador has never accepted its terms, and the maps that its schoolchildren are given show Ecuador's borders encroaching far into Peruvian territory.
Speaking before the signing, Foreign Minister Luiz Felipe Lampreia of Brazil pledged that a Treaty of Free Trade and Navigation, part of the 1942 pact, would finally be put into effect. It would guarantee Ecuador "unrestricted, free, continuous and perpetual" access to the Amazon Basin and the river's northern tributaries, Mr. Lampreia said.
Edgar Teran, the former Ecuadorean Ambassador to Washington who is the lead negotiator for his country, said he believed that today's agreement, which provides for geographers and legal experts on the commissions to weigh the border claims of each side, would lead to a "final solution of the problems between Ecuador and Peru."
His Peruvian counterpart, Fernando de Trazegnies, said, "It's important that we enter the 21st century with a 21st-century mentality," adding that the two countries faced the "common enemies" of underdevelopment and poverty.
The Rio Protocol set the border between Ecuador and Peru and laid out a host of other elements -- until now, largely ignored -- to promote trade and cooperation. The Rio Protocol named Brazil, the United States, Chile and Argentina as guarantor nations.
The guarantors now hope that economic and development incentives in the border region will give the two sides a common stake in promoting trade instead of border wrangles.
"It's an incredible turning point," said Luigi Einaudi, a retired United States ambassador who is heading the Washington delegation.
While neither Mr. de Trazegnies nor Mr. Teran would say what specifically led them to expect success in negotiations now, other diplomats close to the talks said several favorable elements had converged.
With Peru having recently purchased MiG-29 fighter jets and Sukhoi bombers, Ecuador and other countries feared that an arms buildup in Peru could lead to hostilities, a diplomat from one of the guarantor nations said. Some said they feared that President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru might turn to a show of military strength to bolster his flagging popularity as presidential elections approach in 2000.

2d Border Dispute Ends
 TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Jan. 19 (Reuters) -- Honduras and El Salvador today formally ended a long and bitter border dispute that once led the two nations into war, resolving vexing problems of nationality and property ownership for thousands of farmers in the mountainous territory.
The two countries agreed to mark 151.5 miles of border physically within a year. The other 80.6 miles are already marked.
The border dispute led to the so-called Soccer War of 1969, a 100-hour shooting war halted by the Organization of American States. Five thousand people died then, and periodic tension had arisen despite a 1980 peace treaty and a 1992 World Court ruling that tried to work out the differences.

HEADLINE: Franks Is Planning Race to Oppose Dodd for His Senate Seat

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Gary A. Franks, a Connecticut Republican who lost his seat in the House of Representatives two years ago, is beginning a race for the Senate seat of Christopher J. Dodd, the three-term Democratic incumbent and former general chairman of the Democratic National Committee.
Mr. Franks is scheduled to make his formal announcement on Tuesday afternoon in his hometown of Waterbury, and he already has started to stake out staunchly conservative positions. In an interview this evening, the 44-year-old Mr. Franks said he supported a flat tax, a balanced-budget amendment, an end to racial preferences in affirmative action, and vouchers that would pay for children to attend parochial schools. 
 "I'm running for the U. S. Senate because I believe that Connecticut needs a representative in Washington committed to a limited Federal Government, lower taxes and economic prosperity," Mr. Franks said, asserting that the differences between him and Mr. Dodd were "vast." Mr. Franks said he had never voted for a tax increase while Mr. Dodd has voted for "countless number of tax hikes."
Mr. Franks's bid for the Senate is an attempt to recover the luster that he once had as a rising star in the Republican Party. He gained prominence in 1990, when he was the first black Republican elected to the House in nearly 50 years and quickly became a regular on the political talk-show circuit on issues relating to race.
But after three terms in Congress, Mr. Franks lost a run for re-election to James Maloney, 46 percent to 52 percent. Mr. Franks was sharply attacked by organized labor for initially opposing the minimum-wage increase and then defeated in the Clinton landslide.
The Senate race would appear to be an uphill contest for Mr. Franks. Mr. Dodd is popular in Connecticut and already has a sizable fund-raising lead. Marvin Fast, a spokesman for Mr. Dodd, said the Senator had raised more than $2 million by the last public filing date six months ago. Mr. Franks said today that he had raised about $500,000.
A poll released in December by The Hartford Courant and the University of Connecticut Institute for Social Inquiry showed that in a matchup between the two men, 55 percent preferred Mr. Dodd, to 20 percent for Mr. Franks. The poll of 500 randomly selected Connecticut residents has a margin of error of plus or minus five percentage points.
Today, Mr. Franks dismissed the poll, noting that his own survey showed a slightly smaller margin. "Obviously, I have a lot of work to do," he said, adding that he expected to receive strong Republican backing. He has already been endorsed by Gov. John G. Rowland, the state's top Republican, and it appears that he will face no challenge for the party's nomination.
Mr. Franks said many of the state's prominent politicians, including former Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Governor Rowland and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, had lost elections before staging triumphant campaigns for statewide office.
Mr. Fast, Mr. Dodd's spokesman, declined to comment on Mr. Franks's campaign. "There'll be a time and season for politics," he said, "but right now, Senator Dodd is focused on working for the people of Connecticut."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Just a Nonartist in the Art World, but Endlessly Seen and Cited

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
In the tradition of the painter's painter or the poet's poet, M. C. Escher is the nonartist's nonartist. The space-twisting, mind-bending images of this Dutch printmaker rank among the 20th century's most popular.
They have been widely disseminated through unlimited editions, posters, T-shirts and album covers and are regularly found in college dormitories, bookstores, computer labs and mathematicians' offices. Benoit B. Mandelbrot, the inventor of fractal geometry, has listed Escher's art among his inspirations. Douglas R. Hofstadter, the author of the best seller "Godel, Escher, Bach," discussed the different uses that the mathematician, artist and composer of the title made of elaborate structures and repetition. 
 Not surprisingly, the small, informative survey of 77 prints and drawings that the National Gallery has mounted on the centenary of Escher's birth (he died in 1972 at the age of 73) has been drawing large crowds, twice the average attendance for a show of this size.
But it hasn't caused a ripple in the worlds of art and art history, where Escher's work tends to be viewed, at best, as art for beginners, an esthetic first love, like the poetry of Khalil Gibran or Pachelbel's Canon, that is soon outgrown. It may even be news in those quarters that the National Gallery has the largest collection of Escher material outside the Netherlands. (How? In the 1970's, Cornelius V. S. Roosevelt, grandson of Theodore and an Escher devotee in the extreme, gave it 200 prints and drawings, which doubled its holdings in the artist's work, along with 24 scrapbooks on Escher's career and an archive of letters by, to and about Escher.)
The National Gallery show (through April 27) is full of Escherian thrills and conundrums conveyed with workmanlike virtuosity, usually in lithograph or woodcut: impossible architectural structures; staircases that go up and down at the same time; elaborate vistas with three or four vanishing points, and patterns of flat, interlocking animal forms that evolve into animate creatures and then revert to flat pattern. The show begins with early efforts like "Self-Portrait in a Chair," a slightly moody woodcut made in 1920, when he was 22, which shows the seated artist from a steeply pitched mouse-eye view. It culminates in "Metamorphosis III," a 23-foot-long color woodcut completed in 1968 that reviews the manipulations of form and pattern basic to Escher's vocabulary. In this work, these unfold in a procession of seamless transformations, as in a passage where a hexagonal grid mutates into an increasingly realistic honeycomb that releases a battalion of bees that flatten and merge with an approaching school of white fish before shape-shifting into black birds. Each transition triggers a little rush of excitement, the kind you get from a chord change in your favorite pop song.
As these two works attest, Escher started out in a place very different from where he ended up. His development had two phases -- from 1918 to 1937 and from 1937 to 1972 -- and is best described as a process of mind winning out over matter as he turned to abstraction and away from the real world.
Born in Leeuwarden, the Netherlands, in 1898, Escher backed into his life's work. As a child he drew incessantly and was an outstandingly poor student. Frustrated, his father, a hydraulic engineer, sent him to the School for Architecture and Decorative Art in Haarlem when he was 19 to study architecture. Those plans were thwarted within a few days of Escher's arrival when Samuel Jesserun de Mesquita, a teacher of graphic techniques, advised him to switch to the graphic arts.
Escher perfected his drawing and printmaking skills under the watchful eye of de Mesquita. They seem to have formed a close relationship. Escher kept a photograph of his teacher pinned to a cupboard in his studio for the rest of his life and remained in touch with him until early 1944, when de Mesquita and his family, Portuguese Jews, were deported from Haarlem and died in a German concentration camp.
De Mesquita had an unusually clear view of Escher's limitations, writing in an evaluation that "he is too tight, too literary-philosophical, a young man too lacking in caprice, too little an artist."
During the first 15 years of his career, Escher found his optical thrills in the real world, which he depicted from extreme angles or in uncanny reflections. In the manner of Durer and the artists he influenced (Jan van Eyck, for example), Escher depicted himself reflected in a convex mirror, as well as in mirrored spheres and vessels. "Still Life with Mirror," a striking merger of reality and illusion, shows the doors and stoops along one of Rome's cool, stony streets reflected in a dresser mirror, where it almost looks like a painting.
The reality that Escher seemed to love most was the landscape and architecture of Italy, where he lived from 1922 to 1935. (During this time he met and married a Swiss artist named Jetta Umiker and started a family.) He devoted much of his energy to capturing the precipitous slopes and precariously clustered towns of the Amalfi coast and the mountains of Abruzzi and Calabria, spending summers drawing and winters converting the drawings to prints.
Although they look generic, like illustrations for a travel book, these landscapes are also extremely appealing, suffused with a sense of unhurried pleasure and rendered with meticulous care. (One of Escher's stacked-up towns depicted in red and white, crops up near the end of "Metamorphosis III," where it changes into a stack of isometric cubes.)
 
Making a Transition To the Impossible
 In addition to showing Escher at his best (least tight, most capricious), the Italian landscapes may also have helped trigger his second phase. Looking at some of them, it's easy to imagine that Escher studied the spatial complexities of pinnacled town and vertiginous country with such concentration that his eyes started playing tricks -- tricks that later sharpened into his impossible architecture.
In a lithograph of the coastal town of Corte, for example, the road leading up to the charming jumble of houses, streets and churches makes a hairpin turn; it's difficult to tell which side of the turn slants upward, which downward. This effect is far more extreme in late works like "Relativity" of 1953, with its up-down staircases and shifting orientations. A similar transition from real to artificial is indicated in "Still Life and Street," a brilliant woodcut from 1937 in which a windowsill merges with the street below so that a covered bowl on the sill suddenly appears to be monumental, the size of a fountain. (The image's tight regiments of parallel lines may remind some viewers of Sol LeWitt's wall drawings.)
Two other experiences contributed to Escher's withdrawal into increasingly fictive, confounding mindscapes. One was largely positive: in the early 1920's and again in 1936, he visited the Alhambra, where he studied and drew the pulsating patterns of the Islamic tilework and became fascinated with "the regular division of a plane," as he called it, a principle that would determine much of his later work. The other was not positive at all: in 1935, uneasy with the Fascist Government of Mussolini, Escher took leave of his beloved Italy with its inspiring landscape and soothing climate. For two years he and his family lived in Switzerland, which he quickly came to hate for its "horrible white misery of snow," then moved to Belgium and, finally, in 1941, to the Netherlands.
The work from his second phase may express a more distinct, individual vision, but of what? Some images cleverly illustrate geometric or spatial puzzles, like "The "Waterfall," where a medieval viaduct has three levels in which the water flows from one to the next in a continuous circuit. (It is based on the visual trick known as the tribar, a three-sided form whose corners appear to be right angles, which was published in 1958 by the physicist Roger Penrose.) Less illusionistic are the regularly divided planes or periodic images: the teasing patterns of interlocking elements that first seem to be abstract, but are actually cleverly nested living creatures that repeat in contrasting colors.
Occasionally human but usually animal, these creatures include fish, birds, flying fish, horses, gorgons and lizards. When organized on a grid, the interlocking images ceaselessly alternate between positive and negative, foreground and background; when spiraling, as in the many works using head-to-tail fish, the repeating, diminishing forms create a dizzying recession.
The momentary dazzle of Escher's mature works can give you a sharper understanding of how the eye and mind connect and conflict, sometimes at the same time, in the act of visual perception. But the effect is more Czerny than Bach, a mechanical knowledge stemming from perceptual exercises.
The viewer is presented with little more than a reasonable facsimile of the art experience, one that is challenging without being demanding, magical without being genuinely mysterious, that tickles the mind without genuinely stirring the emotions.
Escher's originality pertains largely to science and mathematics. Working intuitively and empirically, he was able to create computerlike complexities without computers and arrive at designs that illustrated mathematical principles that he often did not know about and said he could not understand when they were explained.
Esthetically, he was regressive with a vengeance, much in the way that Andrew Wyeth is, and his personality seems similarly isolated, disdainful of the art of his time and smugly modest. While Escher sometimes said that he saw himself less as an artist than as an artisan or graphic artist, he also said that while other artists pursued beauty in their work, his goal was "to awaken wonder in the minds of my viewers."
 
Moving Inward To an Ugly World
 Even Escher's intellectual originality came at a price: loss of connection with life in its imperfect, worldly form. His work not only moves inward in terms of its emphasis on abstract principles, it moves inward emotionally too, to a dark, sealed-off sphere that is perfectly ordered but also grimly joyless, sometimes ugly and, when the human figure is involved, clearly misanthropic.
Basically, all of Escher's humans are clones, identical anonymous characters moving in regimentation through space or across surfaces. Even when dressed as medieval peasants, as in the marching figures of "Belvedere," they suggest androids. Elsewhere they are elves or gnomes, most disturbingly in "Encounter," where an interlocking pattern of skulking white and black men (the latter with beaks that are a design solution, but nasty nonetheless) breaks apart and the figures circle in opposite directions, as if enacting a ritual dance.
Looking at these conforming, carefully controlled figures, one wonders if Fascism, which Escher detested, hadn't also contaminated his art, inadvertently becoming a subject buried deep beneath the surface but sometimes breaking through it.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Architecture Doesn't Stop At 96th Street

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
THE chorus girls on Broadway stood still as statues, but they made Michael Adams's eyes dance. He craned his neck to behold the slender, bare-chested figures that flanked the windows on the old Hamilton Theater on West 146th Street.
"They look like burlesque queens from Ziegfeld's Follies," Mr. Adams said. "Incredible. On the front of the building the keystones over the windows have comedic masks. It always struck me how in these vaudeville houses they decided there would never be any tragedy, so they just put up the mask of comedy." 
 Tragedy, it turns out, wears a dust mask. Work crews were converting the lobby of this once-grand vaudeville house and movie theater in Hamilton Heights into a department store. The walls had been stripped down to the brick, where white outlines were a ghostly reminder of mirrored arches. One man sorted through a pile of clothing scattered among the plaster and paint chips, ignoring the chipped cherub that hovered above on a frieze.
This raises complicated questions for Mr. Adams, a preservationist and architectural historian devoted to protecting Harlem's physical riches. An active business beats an empty, gated storefront in an area that needs more investment. But why is there no corresponding investment in protecting and landmarking the elegant structures that graced these neighborhoods, some of which have been covered with gaudy siding or slathered with stucco?
While well-organized advocates rally elsewhere in the city to protect their treasures, Mr. Adams said that only 7.5 percent of Manhattan's landmarked buildings are above 96th Street.
"We're not against economic development, but why is it necessary to destroy something irreplaceable?" Mr. Adams asked. "In SoHo or TriBeCa, those features are used to attract people. Here, it's thrown in the Dumpster like it's trash."
Or scavenged and sold to those downtown stores that recycle bits of buildings in exchange for chunks of your wallet. On 149th Street, Mr. Adams pointed to the half-peeled copper dome of a synagogue that had been turned into a Christian church. Hammered-copper lions' heads once graced the dome, but they were swiped ages ago. On the facade, cinder blocks covered what had once been windows.
"I was looking at a book on urban artifacts and there was no mention of Harlem in the index," Mr. Adams said. "But in caption after caption, you see fireplace mantels or doorways that used to be in Harlem."
It was enough to drive him to seek the esthetic haven of Ann Dobson's apartment. She has lived since 1956 in a stately building on Riverside Drive and 150th Street that had once been home to Marian Anderson and Ralph Ellison. Ms. Dobson's nine-room apartment features leaded windows with stained-glass details, impeccable floors and sweeping river views.
HE and Ms. Dobson, a friend, commiserated over the demise of the Hamilton Theater, which she used to visit for first-run movies. That era seemed distant, a reminder of the time when apartments like hers were common, before landlords cut them up to house the thousands of immigrants that settled into upper Manhattan. Now she sometimes feels it's too painful to walk down Broadway and confront the memories stirred by aging or covered-up facades. She takes some comfort in the efforts of Mr. Adams and some of her longtime neighbors.
"This is part of our history," she said. "When I go to other cities in Europe, I see all these places that are 500 years old being used, still being viable. We won't have anything in this city over 100 years old if we keep on tearing it down."
Mr. Adams said he hoped to prod city officials into protecting the interior of the Hamilton Theater, which has already survived years of use as a soda and beer warehouse. He is also pushing to extend the boundaries of the Hamilton Heights Historic District, among other concerns.
He knows that a lot of the new arrivals in the uptown neighborhoods may be more preoccupied with paying the rent than preserving worn-out architectural details, but he is optimistic that proposed Federal legislation offering tax credits for landmarked buildings may help some banks and investors become involved.
He insists that Harlem's past doesn't have to vanish with present progress.
"So many different groups of people have seen this area as the destination of their dreams," he said. "You have this rich cultural and architectural heritage, like the synagogue that is now a church. This layering of culture on top of culture is like an illustration of what America is about."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Bonds Fail to Hold Gains on More Signs of Asian Stability

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices surrendered early gains to finish lower yesterday.
Stability on many Asian markets as well as a rally in stocks weighed down the bond market. Bonds were also dragged down by the expected sale of a $1.4 billion bond issue by Israel, which drew money away from Treasury securities, as well as word of large selling by a hedge fund. 
 The price of the 30-year bond dropped about 15/16, to 104 2/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction to its price, rose to 5.84 percent, from 5.80 percent on Friday -- the highest since 5.92 percent on Dec. 31. The Treasury market was closed on Monday for Martin Luther King Jr. Day.
Traders said the market received a fleeting lift from comments by the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, Edward G. Boehne. Speaking before the Main Line Chamber of Commerce in Berwyn, Pa. Mr. Boehne said the risk of deflation was not particularly significant and that he expected inflation to remain around 2 percent.
Traders said the supply of corporate debt coming to market by issuers taking advantage of low interest rates hurt the longer maturities yesterday, particularly as it came on light trading volume. GovPx, a bond pricing service, said trading was about 10 percent lighter than an average Tuesday in the first quarter last year.
The debt offering by Israel will be priced today through Lehman Brothers. The offering has a face amount of $3 billion with proceeds expected to total $1.4 billion. Traders say the maturities will run from 2002 to 2027.
At yesterday's regular weekly Treasury bill auction the outcome was in line with expectations. The average rate for a three-month bill was 4.980 percent, up from 4.965 percent the previous week. The average rate for the six-month bill was 4.995 percent, up from 4.910 percent.
The Treasury market continues to feel the impact of events in Asia. The turmoil in many countries is expected to help slow economic growth in the United States and may prompt the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates. At the same time, the turmoil is driving foreign investors into the relative safety of United States securities.
"It's getting a little old to keep talking about the Asian crisis and its impact on U.S. Treasuries, but that's the story we're stuck with for the foreseeable future," said Dave Shabelman, a Treasury market analyst with Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco.
Following are the results of yesterday's weekly Treasury auction of new three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Trusts Are Making Strides as Investors in New York Buildings

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
During the early part of this decade, Lawrence H. Feldman, chairman of what was then called Feldman Equities, was anguishing over missed opportunities. He could see that there were Manhattan buildings that could benefit from his upgrading formula available at attractive prices.
But nobody was eager to finance a purchase in a market where vacancies were increasing and rents were falling. 
 "In the early 90's we were frustrated because we couldn't buy the assets we wanted," Mr. Feldman said at a recent real estate conference at Baruch College.
Today, access to capital is much less of a problem. Mr. Feldman is chairman of Tower Realty Trust, which sold more than $350 million in shares to the public last October and has a $200 million line of credit from Merrill Lynch & Company to go shopping with.
Tower is a real estate investment trust, a tax-sheltered company that invests in and holds real estate. REIT's (pronounced REETS) have been a major factor in national real estate markets for most of the 90's, acquiring tens of billions of dollars of assets like suburban shopping centers, office buildings and residential structures.
But until last year, they had been largely absent in New York, which industry executives say was due in part to a state capital gains tax that has since been eliminated and to the sheer size of the properties in Manhattan. Because Manhattan skyscrapers sell for scores or even hundreds of millions of dollars, such an investment would have represented too large a portion of a REIT's assets. But now that some REIT's have grown so large, even a Manhattan building is a relatively small part of its portfolio.
That changed last year. Vornado Realty Trust of Saddle Brook, N.J., acquired many of the properties owned by the Mendik Company and went on a buying spree that included the $420 million 1 Penn Plaza building, which occupies the block bounded by Seventh and Eighth Avenues and 34th and 33d Streets.
In addition, another Manhattan-oriented company, S. L. Green Real Estate, formed a REIT and sold shares, as did Boston Properties, which is controlled by Mortimer Zuckerman. Financial experts say they expect the trend to continue, with privately held real estate increasingly transferred to public ownership. Still, REIT's are a small factor in the city, with Mr. Feldman estimating that they own no more than 45 of the about 1,200 major commercial buildings in New York.
"There are great opportunities in Manhattan office properties," W. Blake Baird of the investment firm of Morgan Stanley said. "We are going to see the recapitalization of assets in New York City and Manhattan. It will be a major change."
Mr. Feldman said his new status would not change the company, other than to give it a greater ability to move quickly when opportunity knocks. "We are real estate developers," he said. "We buy distressed properties and upgrade them." He said that with the national economy strong and most real estate values recovered from the lows of the early 90's, the last bargains are in the concentrated office canyons known as central business districts, like midtown and downtown Manhattan.
Central business districts, he said, are "the last recovery zone." In New York, he added, "downtown is the last place you can buy below replacement costs."
Steven L. Green, the chairman of S. L. Green, said the REIT structure should be more stable and better for tenants than private ownership. "If you have 85 to 90 percent debt, you don't have the money to make improvements and do other things to make tenants happy when the market goes down," he said. As a result of its public offering, he said , his company has only 12 percent debt and is not inclined to go above 30 percent, leaving a substantial cushion to the downturn that history suggests is inevitable sometime in the future.
"Tenants are better off in REIT-owned buildings," Mr. Green said. "Brokers will put tenants in buildings with stable ownership," he said, because tenants typically blame their brokers if problems occur with a new landlord.
Not everyone holds this view. Anthony Downs, a real estate specialist and senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, contends that because managers of publicly owned REIT's want to continuously improve earnings and dividend payouts, they have an incentive to reduce or defer capital spending. "Over time, this could reduce the quality of the nation's inventory of commercial properties if a large fraction of them become owned by public REIT's," he wrote in the current issue of Wharton Real Estate Review.
Nevertheless, David Csontos, a managing director of Insignia Capital Advisers, said REIT's were inherently more stable than private companies because it costs them less to borrow money. Insignia is an affiliate of Insignia Financial Group, which also owns the Edward S. Gordon brokerage and management company in New York.
Mr. Csontos said REIT's could borrow for as much as 3 percentage points less than a private developer or owner, giving them a powerful advantage. But, he said, private companies, which do not have the burden of the detailed reporting requirements of a public company, will probably continue to develop new properties. "At the end of the day, the world will probably be divided into developers and landlords, with the REIT's as landlords," he said.
One of the powerful attractions of the REIT form of ownership is that it offers partnerships that own portfolios of property -- partnerships that are typically owned by families, some of whose members have reached retirement age -- a means of shifting to a more liquid form of ownership, without having to pay capital gains taxes. Scott Rechler, president of Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, said becoming a real estate investment trust enabled the company to liquidate partnerships established by his grandfather more than 40 years ago.

HEADLINE: Princeton Will Liberalize Its Financial-Aid Formulas

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
In a step indicative of the competition among top universities for middle- and lower-income students, Princeton University is liberalizing its financial aid policies, changing many loans to outright grants and altering its formula for calculating a family's ability to pay college bills.
The plan, expected to be approved by the board of trustees on Saturday, eliminates loans for students whose families earn less than $40,000 a year, turning them into grants. It also increases the share of grants over loans to students from families earning $40,000 to $57,500. 
 Jeremiah P. Ostriker, Princeton's provost, said this change would benefit some 115 to 170 students, or about 10 to 15 percent of the next incoming class.
An additional measure, which is engendering much comment, is a plan to stop including home equity in calculating the assets of families earning less than $90,000 a year. For families earning more than that but still qualifying for some financial aid, one-half or one-quarter of home equity will be considered among their assets. Mr. Ostriker said 30 to 35 percent of the incoming class would benefit from that measure.
Princeton officials say the plan will ultimately cost the university some $6 million a year after being fully phased in over the next four years. The college faces growing competition for middle-class students from state universities whose tuition, room and board costs are substantially below those of Princeton.
Jesse Cheng, 21, a senior from San Marino, Calif., said: "When I was choosing whether or not to come to Princeton, the decision was between here and a state school. If Princeton had cost as much as a state school, there would have been no need to debate in my mind whether I should go or not."
The cost of tuition, room and board next fall at Princeton is expected to be $30,531, rising above $30,000 for the first time.
Under the new plan, a student from a family earning $50,000 a year with savings of $15,000 and home equity of $60,000 would benefit from an increase in grant aid of $1,500 a year, according to university calculations.
A student from a family earning $85,000 annually with savings of $40,000 and home equity of $110,000 would gain an additional $2,700 a year, the calculations showed.
The cost of higher education has been a growing topic of concern nationally as tuition increases have far outstripped inflation and average family income.
"The interesting question is whether there will be a cascading effect from this," said Michael S. McPherson, president of Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn., an economist who has frequently written on the cost of higher education. "Very few schools have the resources of Princeton, so their responses are likely to be more targeted and limited than Princeton's."
Other educational economists agreed, saying Princeton's plan might affect its direct competitors in the Ivy League but not many others.
B. Jay Cooper, director of public relations at Yale University, said that he was sure other schools would look at the Princeton plan for competitive reasons but that its impact was still unclear.
Some economists raised questions about the home equity portion of the plan, saying it was politically appealing but economically dubious to remove it from asset calculations.
"Any economist will tell you that an asset is an asset is an asset," said Hal F. Higginbotham, vice president for student assistance services at the College Board. "Home equity is a very emotional and politically charged asset, however, because America's favorite way to save has been home equity."
Princeton officials said that 43 percent of their approximately 4,600 students received financial aid and that the median income of such recipients' families was $70,000.
Justin Mulaire, a 21-year-old senior mathematics major from Stamford, Conn., and a member of the student-faculty committee that created the new plan, said that the university was likely to run a budget deficit in the short term partly because of this program but that the decision to go ahead with it was evidence of the commitment to student aid.

HEADLINE: Rising Fear of Lawsuits Is Threatening Programs of Study Abroad

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
In the aftermath of the rapes of five American college students in Guatemala last Friday, proponents of study-abroad programs in countries of Latin America and the Middle East, where there have long been safety warnings, now have a new enemy: lawsuits.
There is a growing movement to hold universities liable for the safety of their students studying overseas. At risk may be the popular courses themselves. 
 "We are afraid programs that are extremely thoughtful and quite safe won't be supported by institutions because they're afraid of the threat of lawsuits," said Len Clark, provost of Earlham College in Richmond, Ind.
The fears arise as more American students study in increasingly diverse destinations. Two-thirds of the 89,000 students who study overseas still go to Western Europe, according to the Institute of International Education, which is based in New York. But the number of students who went to Latin America in 1996 increased 18 percent over the previous year. In Africa, the increase was 10 percent, and in Asia it was 5 percent.
The issue of liability has become a big concern as students travel to riskier destinations. Mary Davidson, assistant director of the United States office of the American University in Cairo, said that when 58 foreigners were killed in Luxor, Egypt, last November, many American colleges that send students to the American University canceled.
"Was that responsible behavior?" Ms. Davidson asked. "I think many acted on the advice of their institution's legal counsel. Was it responsible in terms of the educational goals of the students and faculty? I'd debate that."
In the latest withdrawal, Spring Arbor College in Michigan announced yesterday that a group of 16 students and 2 faculty members was being brought home early from Guatemala as a result of the attack there. The students had decided to stay, but the college president overruled them.
Separate lawsuits against two American programs are being closely watched as they go to trial this year. In one, an Earlham student who says she was raped in April 1996 by her host father in Tokyo is suing the college for $3 million. In the other, the families of four students killed in a bus crash in India in March 1996 are suing the Semester at Sea program for an undisclosed amount.
Courts have already said colleges and universities are legally responsible for some injuries that befall students on campus. But whether that applies overseas, and to what sorts of injuries, has not been decided.
"In many cases people didn't think there was liability involved, or they didn't want to go after a university -- it's not your traditional target of lawsuits," said Robert Aalberts, a professor of legal studies at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas. "I think they were living on borrowed time until big things happened, and now they have."
For Michael Conn, a 19-year-old sophomore at Brandeis University, safety still means Western Europe. Mr. Conn plans to go to France, not Africa, next year because he believes it is the safest place to study French.
