HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
G.M. is poking around Asia looking for good deals or alliances with beaten-down auto makers.

BYLINE: By Robyn Meredith 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
GENERAL MOTORS is kicking the tires of auto companies in Asia.
Fire-sale prices from the crash of Asian currencies along with eased trade restrictions are rekindling a long-running desire by American auto companies to capture more of the Asian market. 
"This may be the global garage sale of a lifetime," said Joseph S. Phillippi, an auto analyst at Lehman Brothers.
G.M. has been the most aggressive of the American auto makers. It has been talking with two large Korean auto makers, the Daewoo Motor Corporation and Kia Motors, along with other auto or auto parts makers about a variety of options, said Michael G. Meyerand, a G.E. spokesman.
"We're clearly getting more aggressive on it because there's more opportunity," said Donald T. Sullivan, president of G.M.'s Asian and Pacific operations. "We're looking at selectively possibly taking pieces" in East Asian auto makers, he said.
To a lesser extent, the Ford Motor Company has been exploring deals in Asia. "We've been there," said John M. Devine, Ford's chief financial officer. "We're watching everything."
The Chrysler Corporation has remained on the sidelines so far, focusing instead on expansion in South America. "We're a little more cautious than our competition" about the opportunities in Asia, said Thomas T. Stallkamp, Chrysler's president.
Long before the current economic troubles, G.M. and Ford each developed a strategy to capture 10 percent of the Asia-Pacific market during the next decade. Only a year ago, those goals looked wildly optimistic.
But instead of starting from scratch with new factories, the auto companies now have an opportunity to catch up quickly with the Japanese in these markets by buying Asian auto makers or forming strategic alliances with local manufacturers.
Asian auto or auto parts makers were not interested in such combinations just a short time ago. But now some are bankrupt, many are short of cash and most are increasingly worried about their home markets as consumers shun showrooms. In dollar terms, these companies look relatively cheap to Americans after the plunge in local currencies.
Besides, American auto companies have been hoarding cash to withstand the next recession in the United States. Any of the Big Three could spend up to several billion dollars and still barely thin bulging wallets, Wall Street analysts said. At the end of the third quarter, G.M. had $14.6 billion in cash and marketable securities, while Ford had $19.3 billion and the Chrysler Corporation had $7.6 billion.
Indeed, the Asian slowdown could be a blessing for the big American auto makers. As they began building factories in the region in the last few years, analysts became increasingly worried about overcapacity, pointing to the Asian companies that were racing to build assembly lines. Kia and Hyundai, which now face dwindling demand for cars at home, have been able to sell their cars at a heavy discount in the United States because of the declining value of the Korean currency -- a Hyundai Accent sells for $8,500 in the United States, far below the price of a Ford Escort.
By buying into these Asian auto makers, the Big Three could stem production and prevent them from depressing prices worldwide. "What you basically should do if you're G.M. or Ford is you buy a plant and then you blow it up just to make a statement about all the excess capacity there," Mr. Phillippi said.
Several obstacles remain, however, for American auto makers. The region remains in financial chaos, which could lead to political instability. In addition, the potential takeover targets are generally awash in debt.
The Big Three companies are expected to resist acquiring big liabilities. That means that before any deals can be struck, the banks that lent to troubled Asian auto makers will probably have to swallow hard and write down the debt.
And sorting out various ownership rights in Asian companies is complex. "We have to look at can you even extract something from the mess that's already over there -- especially in Korea with the conglomerates," Mr. Stallkamp said.
Furthermore, in the short term, the American auto makers might not fare much better than the Asian auto makers struggling to move cars out of their showrooms. G.M. and Ford may scale back their factory plans for Thailand this year, and Chrysler has lowered its sales projections for Asia.
"If you want to be successful in Asia, you'd better be prepared to be there for the long term," Mr. Sullivan of G.M. said.
Rather than buy Asian companies outright, G.M. may forge partnerships. "You don't have to own everything or have 99 percent control of everything to take advantage of it," Mr. Sullivan said.
Ford already has a stake in Kia, the troubled Korean auto maker, but has not considered taking it over, said Alexander J. Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive. "We haven't been deeply involved in how Kia is restructured," he said. "Our interest really is to protect our 9.5 percent share." Ford also owns 33 percent of Mazda, which holds 7.5 percent more of Kia.
In the last few years, Chrysler has held back in Asia because of the difficulties of doing business in countries with heavy restrictions on imports and other policies that favor local auto makers.
But the International Monetary Fund has recently made some progress in persuading Asian leaders to drop protectionist policies. As part of its bailout package, South Korea agreed to drop certain trade barriers. And after months of resistance, President Suharto of Indonesia agreed as part of a far-reaching deal with the I.M.F. to drop tax breaks for a national car program run by his son.
G.M. responded on Friday by saying that it would make new investments in Indonesia. Earlier this month, G.M. bought out the 40 percent stake owned by President Suharto's half-brother, Bapak Probosutedjo, in General Motors Buana Indonesia, which builds Blazer sport utility vehicles there. "The purchase reflects G.M.'s commitment to Indonesia and its confidence in the long-term prospects of the automotive industry here," G.M. said in a statement.

HEADLINE: Pope vs. Embargo: Still a Sharp Divide in U.S.

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Pope John Paul II will soon add his voice to a growing chorus calling for an end to the United States' economic embargo against Cuba. But the debate that he will be joining is an old one, and opinions in the White House and Congress are deeply entrenched.
After arriving in Cuba on Wednesday, the Pope is expected to denounce the 37-year-old embargo, as he has denounced embargoes in the past. When he does, he will join what one ardently anti-Castro member of Congress, Representatove Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Florida Republican, calls an "unholy alliance": 600 business groups and 140 religious and human-rights organizations asking the Clinton Administration to ease up on the sanctions. 
 The embargo's opponents -- strange bedfellows including the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the National Council of Churches, the National Association of Manufacturers and the American Friends Services Committee -- say the embargo has starved the Cuban people of food and ideas, but failed to change President Fidel Castro.
"Economic embargoes don't work, period," said John Howard, director of international policy and programs at the Chamber of Commerce. "We believe the best way to open up the Cuban regime is to open it up to the American system."
They hope that the papal visit may compel American political leaders to think again about isolating Cuba.
"This is a landmark event," said Representative Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, the ranking Democrat on the House International Relations Committee. "It's got an awful lot of people thinking. The Pope's approach is the exact opposite of the American Government's. The Pope is trying to engage the Cuban people. The U.S. policy is to isolate the Cuban people. The contrast is apparent.
"The real national interest to the United States is to see a peaceful transition after Castro," Mr. Hamilton said. "And the question is whether the embargo contributes to that or not."
Ever since the Cuban revolution in 1959, the White House has used many means -- including failed coups and assassination plots in the early 1960's -- to topple Mr. Castro. The embargo remains Washington's most powerful weapon "to bring pressure to bear on Cuba to change its form of government," in the words of the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry.
Jose Cardenas, Washington director of the Cuban-American National Foundation, a prominent anti-Castro group, described the embargo as "the primary nonviolent policy option for influencing change in Cuba."
So far, nothing suggests that Washington would sheath that weapon.
The Administration says "fundamental change" must come to Cuba before the embargo ends; no such change is in sight. Mr. McCurry said today that the White House would be watching "the aftermath of the trip and the policies pursued by the Government of Cuba, which would be the serious criteria that one could use to evaluate prospects for change in Cuba."
In Congress, Castro's many opponents have shaped the Administration's Cuban policies. Republican leaders and many Democrats, especially those representing communities of Cuban exiles in Florida and New Jersey, are committed to the embargo and unwilling to compromise. They have blocked a bill that would allow Cuba to buy American food and medicine, embargoed in 1992. They say American policy will change only when Cuba's politics do.
"The Pope's visit won't have any effect" on American policy, Ms. Ros-Lehtinen said. "The Pope's visit won't result in any more support for legislation to do away with the embargo. The greedy businessmen, the Chamber of Commerce, won't do away with the embargo. The real embargo is the embargo Castro has on people's freedom."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Possible Merger of Drug Makers Causes Late Stock Rally

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
For Wall Street, bigger seems to be better.
The possible merger of two pharmaceutical companies, which would be the largest corporate coupling ever, caused a late rally in stocks yesterday. 
 Word of the merger talks, between SmithKline Beecham and American Home Products, lifted the stocks of many drug companies as investors took the discussions as a sign that the industry might consolidate further.
The American Stock Exchange's 15-company pharmaceutical index rose 5.1 percent yesterday. The index is up 8.8 percent this year, making it one of the year's best-performing stock indexes.
The news also fueled a larger rally, which pushed the Dow Jones industrial average up almost 120 points as broader market indexes also gained more than 1 percent.
If SmithKline Beecham was to buy American Home Products, the deal would surpass the largest corporate combination to date, Worldcom's planned $37 billion purchase of MCI Communications, and would create one of the world's largest health care companies.
"It underscores that there's still financial deals to be done," said Andrew Brooks, a vice president in charge of equity trading at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore.
American Home Products' stock, which closed at 94 1/4, is trading at the lofty level of about 28 times estimated 1997 earnings. At such a price, "if it's a value to the people who run these companies, then there's value for shareholders," said Steven Goldman, chief market strategist at Weeden & Company, in Greenwich, Conn., explaining why investors pushed up the stock 13 9/16 points.
Gathering steam from the drug stock rally, broad market indexes sailed higher. In its initial day of trading after the stock market's first observance of the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.5 percent, or 119.57 points, to 7,873.12. Last week the blue-chip index rose 173 points.
The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index gained 17.09 points, or 1.8 percent, to 978.60 yesterday. And the Nasdaq composite index rose 1.7 percent, to 1,590.14, a 27.26-point gain.
Calmer markets in Asia provided a favorable backdrop for the market's surge. After posting strong gains on Monday, equity markets in Indonesia, Hong Kong, South Korea and Japan were modestly higher.
The lack of any new financial routs from that region, as well as a round of strong fourth-quarter earnings reports from American companies, heartened investors and sent buyers back into the market yesterday afternoon, analysts said.
The telephone equipment maker Lucent Technologies and the investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, as well as Continental, Northwest and America West airlines, all reported earnings that topped analysts' expectations, while companies like Lockheed Martin, Johnson & Johnson, Pfizer and Paine Webber Group posted earnings in line with forecasts.
But some financial services companies -- including Merrill Lynch and multinational banks like Citibank, J. P. Morgan and Chase Manhattan -- took a hit as Asia's market turmoil cut into earnings. Such earnings reports reminded investors that Asia's woes could still affect the future earnings of American companies, some analysts said.
"The full impact of the events in Southeast Asia has not hit some of these companies," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer at John Hancock Funds in Boston.
"The worst of the crisis has not fully been realized," he said, adding that he still expected investment banks and multinational banks, as well as some technology concerns, to see earnings crimped because of the Asian crisis.
Mr. Freedman anticipates that retail stocks, health care and some technology issues, as well as regional United States banks, will do well because of their limited exposure to the Southeast Asian economy. However, banks with a big international presence may continue to suffer.
In December, analysts' forecasts of fourth-quarter earnings growth for the companies in the S.& P. 500 index fell from more than 13 percent to about 8 percent, Thomas Galvin, chief equity strategist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, told investors in a recent market comment. However, forecasts for the first quarter and all of 1998 are still too high, he said.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
With corporate hotel rates on the rise, the search is on for good rooms that don't break budgets.

BYLINE: By Paul Burnham Finney 

 BODY:
WITH American Express estimating that corporate hotel rates will escalate around 15 percent this year, business travelers are trolling for good budget hotel rooms -- and finding them aplenty.
"Brand new economy hotels are going up every day," said Randy Smith, president of Smith Travel Research, a hotel consulting firm. "Some major companies are asking their travelers to downgrade to brands like Hampton, Fairfield and Comfort Inns and the newer Wingate Inns and Sleep Inns. That's where you can get the best value for your money -- at around $45 a night or sometimes as low as $30. The chains are providing some of the amenities -- TV's, dual phones, coffee makers -- you used to find only in midpriced hotels." 
 The hotel market niche that is making the biggest economy-size waves these days is for longer-term guests, such as employees in training programs, engineering projects and corporate relocations.
Among the classiest of the longer-stay hotels are Marriott International's Residence Inns. But the fastest-growing chain of this newer breed -- with a plain vanilla name -- is Extended Stay America Inc., which was started by the entrepreneur H. Wayne Huizenga, the chairman of Republic Industries, who is building a nationwide network of auto sales outlets and whose holdings include Alamo Rent-A-Car and National Car Rental. At $4 to $5 million each, plus last April's acquisition of Studio Plus Hotels, he has peppered 35 states coast to coast with some 200 hotels in just three years.
All the rooms have a queen-size bed, recliner chair, a computer port, free local calls and voice mail, remote TV, fax delivery, a coffee maker and a tiny kitchen with a stove top, microwave and refrigerator.
Rates range from about $300 to $400 a week at the Studio Plus Hotels to around $200 to $300 at Extended Stay America efficiency studios. Any of those numbers would cover roughly one night at many luxury hotels.
"Some 85 percent of the guests are business travelers," said a spokeswoman, Mariesa Capelli.
The nice twist for those on a tight budget is that many of these longer-stay chains are just as available for single nights as they are for longer periods. For example, the Monday through Friday rates at Extended Stay America in Akron, Ohio, are $44 daily and $209 weekly; in Torrance, Calif., $59 daily and $289 weekly.
But staffing is almost nil. "There's just a front desk, limited maid service and less turnover," Mr. Smith said. "That's where longer-stay hotels save on costs. There's no interaction with guests a lot of the time -- but then many travelers don't need that."
 
Super Bowl Entertaining
If you're bracketing this week's Super Bowl Sunday with some business entertaining in San Diego before and after the game, here are some first-rate restaurant candidates: the clubby Grant Grill in the landmark U.S. Grant Hotel; the Celadon for Thai food in a pretty setting; the opulent Le Fontainebleau, with a Continental menu, in the Westgate Hotel; the formal Top of the Market upstairs and casual Fish Market downstairs on North Harbor Drive for seafood and bay views; the cheerful Cafe Pacifica, also featuring fish, in a mission-style house in the Old Town section, and, nearby, the Old Town Mexican for margaritas and mariachi bands.
Across the Bay Bridge are two dining standouts at water's edge: Marius, with a Provence-inspired chef, in the Coronado Island Marriott and the Azzura Point, specializing in Pacific Rim dishes, in the Loews Coronado Bay Resort.
Up the coast, close to the corporate area called Silicon Beach, are several popular hotel restaurants: the Whaling Bar and Sky Room in La Jolla's venerable La Valencia Hotel; the sleek Cafe Japengo, highly rated by Zagat's survey participants, next to the Hyatt Regency La Jolla, and -- for golf buffs -- the Torreyana Grille at the Sheraton Grande Torrey Pines.
Meeting a business contact for breakfast? Squeeze into the Hob Nob Hill, San Diego's hottest coffee shop, near Balboa Park.
 
Electronic Ticket Agent
Until electronic ticketing acts more like an airline ticket agent, it will attract only a limited number of users. That's why American Express and Continental Airlines may be getting somewhere by having several thousand business fliers test a new "smart card" imbedded with personal preferences and other information . After inserting it in an equally smart Continental card reader, complete with a touch screen and prompts, travelers can switch to an earlier or later flight, upgrade to first class if they're a Gold Elite-level member, change seat assignments, confirm One Pass numbers for mileage credits and obtain boarding passes and receipts.
 
Hot Button
At most of ITT Sheraton's 205 foreign hotels, guests can now use AT&T's direct service on room phones by pressing one button or a three-number combination when calling the United States or 200 other countries.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A European Inquiry on Accounting Mergers

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Giant mergers proposed by four of the Big Six accounting firms encountered a potentially serious roadblock today, when the European Commission's top antitrust official announced that he would conduct investigations of both deals.
The announcement in Brussels, by Karel van Miert, signaled the growing concern among European officials that the two proposed mergers could damage competition and perhaps undermine the integrity of the independent auditors. 
 The mergers would immediately reduce the field of worldwide auditing and accounting firms from the Big Six to a Big Four.
The first deal would combine Price Waterhouse with Coopers & Lybrand to create a firm with $13 billion in revenue and 8,500 partners. The second would merge KPMG Peat Marwick with Ernst & Young, to create a firm with revenue of $15 billion and 11,712 partners.
Expressing "serious concerns," Mr. van Miert said he would look into the mergers simultaneously. His announcement starts a process that lasts about four months and has often led to demands by the European Commission, the European Union's administrative arm, for significant changes. A few mergers have been blocked.
Opposition to the accounting firm deals has been steadily increasing in Europe. The Bank of England and the British Financial Services Authority, a regulatory body, have said the mergers could decrease competition among auditors who verify corporate financial results.
Securities regulators have also raised concern that the mergers could blur consulting work and auditing, causing firms to become so dependent on consulting fees that they allow corporate clients to influence the auditors who review their books.
In November, the International Organization of Securities Commissions, an association of stock market regulators, expressed concern about the reduced number of accounting firms and their "increasing reliance on revenues from consulting and other nonaudit services."
KPMG had tried to address some of the criticism by proposing that accounting firms submit to regulatory supervision of the links between consulting and auditing practices. But that idea was assailed by most other accounting firms, which defend the current self-regulatory system.
European lawyers have also objected to the mergers, fearing that the big accounting firms are taking away their business. In most European countries, accounting firms operate in-house legal firms.
Corporations have been quiet about the proposed mergers. But some may also be worried about how four huge firms can avoid conflicts when performing services for rival companies.
Although all four accounting firms are based in the United States, they are also prominent in Europe, as well, and subject to European Commission regulations.
None of them would comment on the announcement today, saying that they had not received formal notification from commission regulators.
Mr. van Miert has a record of imposing his will. Last year, he forced the Boeing Company to drop a prized marketing practice as a condition for approving its acquisition of McDonnell Douglas. And he has challenged major mergers and alliances throughout Europe.
In announcing his intentions today at a news conference in Brussels, he offered no details about the questions he intends to pursue. But his agency, which is called the Ministry of Competition, only undertakes a full-scale merger review after finding potential problems during an initial, monthlong review.
The United States Department of Justice and Congress are also looking into the proposed accounting mergers. The office of Senator Mike DeWine, Republican of Ohio and chairman of the Senate subcommittee that examines antitrust and competition issues, said today that the panel planned to review the consequences of the proposed deals for American companies.
"There is always a concern when you see a decrease in competition in any industry," said Charles Boesel, a spokesman for Senator DeWine.
A long investigation could present problems for the four accounting firms. KPMG and Ernst & Young are running competitive advertising and marketing campaigns, and the longer they have to wait, the longer they must spend money trying to capture market share from each other.

HEADLINE: 2 Buyout Firms Make Deal To Acquire Regal Cinemas

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON and GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
The movie theater business has captivated two of the nation's largest and savviest leveraged buyout firms, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, which will join forces to form the world's largest chain of movie theaters. But their agreement, announced yesterday, raises the prices for theaters to a level that many in the business called hard to justify at a time when a multiplex building binge has already given the nation too many screens.
The two firms agreed to buy Regal Cinemas Inc., the nation's second-largest chain, for $1.2 billion in cash, or about $31 a share, and the assumption of $290 million in debt. They plan to combine Regal Cinemas with the United Artists Theater Group, which Hicks, Muse agreed in November to buy for $300 million and the assumption of $550 in debt, and with Act III Cinemas, which Kohlberg Kravis bought last month for $323 million and the assumption of $338 million in debt. 
 The result would be a company with 5,347 screens at 727 theaters in 35 states -- or about 17 percent of the nation's screens now, or 20 percent by the end of 1999 under current building plans. Carmike Cinemas Inc., with more than 2,700 screens, is the leader now.
While Kohlberg Kravis and Hicks, Muse see major gains in a combination from cutting overhead and expenses and from building huge megaplex theaters, analysts and industry executives question whether the combined chain could realize enough economies to justify the price. The buyers of the Regal Cinemas, which is based in Knoxville, Tenn., are paying about 13 times last year's cash flow, while buyers of other theater chains generally pay a price that is about 7 times cash flow. (Cash flow is earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization.) And theater chains continue to face added pressure from new forms of home entertainment.
"The business has stable demand and overcapacity," said Christopher Dixon, a media analyst with Paine Webber. "So unless Hicks, Muse gets more negotiating power with the film studios, it is a tough deal. And other theater chains, including Cineplex and Carmike, thought they could get better terms as they got bigger and they didn't."
Clifton S. Robbins, a Kohlberg Kravis general partner, said that while he did not expect better terms from the studios, the combined company could drive harder bargains with other suppliers. Regal Cinemas is growing so rapidly, he said, that the purchase price represents only 8.8 times this year's projected cash flow.
But in a business that is building theaters faster than it is filling them, Regal Cinemas, with 2,333 screens, is among the most ambitious, with plans to add 300 screens this year and 300 next year. Its shares fell from more than $36 at midyear to the mid-$20's in December as analysts questioned whether it was growing too rapidly. Bouncing back up last week on reports that it was in talks with Kohlberg Kravis, Regal Cinemas closed yesterday at $29.4375, down 81.25 cents.
Kohlberg Kravis and Hicks, Muse said their transactions would have a total value of $3 billion, including about $600 million from each of the buyout firms, $100 million from management and the rest in debt.
John R. Muse, chief operating officer of Hicks, Muse, said that rather than worsening the glut, Regal's new theaters -- with sharply rising stadium seating and concessions going well beyond popcorn and soda -- often replace the older, smaller theaters that still predominate in some areas. "Dallas probably has more stadium seating than any area in the country, but Boston doesn't have any yet," Mr. Muse said.
With theaters spread across the Southeast, Midwest and Northeast, and some expansion on the West Coast, Regal Cinemas has aimed at midsize cities and growing suburbs. Unlike many other chains, "We've built our theaters where the population is moving," said Michael L. Campbell, chief executive of Regal Cinemas, who will become chief of the combined company.
Lewis Corman, who served as chief operating officer of Tri-Star Pictures when it bought Loews Theaters in 1986, said that consolidating theater circuits without screens in the same market has only limited value. "You can save on central overhead," he said. "But the terms with theater owners will not necessarily get better because the circuits need the studios just as much as the studios need the theaters." Studios usually take 90 percent of ticket revenues when films open, scaling back closer to 50 percent by the end of their runs.
As for theater concessions, already a major profit source for the chains, Mr. Corman expects few further savings because the gross margin is already about 84 percent. Mr. Campbell of Regal said his chain already enjoyed margins of 88 percent, but planned to bring its new partners up to that mark.
The firms said they had no plans to raise ticket prices.
While the theater industry remains fragmented, the latest combination would go a long way to determining its future course. The question a year from now, said Joseph R. Zimmel, a Goldman, Sachs & Company managing director who advised Regal Cinemas, "will be whether this galvanizes the industry in the sense of taking it from a mom-and-pop type of business to a professionally managed industry."

HEADLINE: A House Chief Limits Uses of Any Surplus

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The chief tax writer in the House laid out a plan today to apportion any Federal budget surpluses equally between reducing the national debt and cutting taxes, saying he wanted to shrink the Government and keep any fiscal windfall out of the hands of those politicians who would spend it.
In making his proposal, the lawmaker, Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, sought to advance a new strategy among conservatives in their campaign against the size and the influence of the Federal Government even as the new world of budget prosperity takes from them the argument that huge budget deficits demand austerity. 
 With the deficits all but gone, everyone from President Clinton to some of Mr. Archer's Republican colleagues have started talking about what they want the Government to do now, from building highways to improving child care to expanding health insurance.
At a news conference today, Mr. Archer, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, responded with the proposal that half of any surplus be taken off the table before it could be spent, earmarked for reduction of the Federal Government's $5 trillion debt.
Mr. Archer said forecasts from the Congressional Budget Office suggested that Congress could comfortably pay off $200 billion of the debt over the next 10 years and cut taxes by the same amount without any risk of creating new budget deficits.
That Mr. Archer, one of his party's most ardent tax cutters, would give equal billing to paying down the national debt reflects the economic and political appeal of cleaning up the accumulated financial mess left by decades of deficit spending.
Economists generally agree that paying down the debt would help reduce interest rates, spur private investment and improve the nation's growth rate as it prepares for its next fiscal challenge: paying for the retirement needs of the huge baby-boom generation starting around 2010. Polls show that voters also give high priority to reducing the debt.
"I believe a balanced budget must lead to a smaller, less-taxing Government, letting people keep more of what they earn, easing their financial burdens, freeing them to invest in themselves and their communities," Mr. Archer said. "But for some in Washington, balancing the budget is just an excuse to bring back the era of big government as they unleash the hounds of higher spending."
Democrats said Mr. Archer was jumping the gun by pushing for tax cuts before a surplus was in hand.
"As a majority of Americans have indicated, they want a Government that is responsive and prudent, not a Government that spends money it does not yet have," said Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the senior Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Archer has considerable control over the agenda on taxes in the House, but his approach is sure to run head-on into calls from members of both parties for new spending.
Representative Bud Shuster, the Pennsylvania Republican who heads the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, is leading a bipartisan push for a surge in spending on roads, bridges and mass transit.
Speaker Newt Gringrich has identified the Pentagon and scientific research as in need of increased spending.
And President Clinton has proposed new initiatives on health insurance and child care.
Mr. Archer said he wanted to find a way of reducing taxes across the board, perhaps by expanding to higher income levels the 15 percent tax bracket, which currently rises to 28 percent for income above some $40,100 for couples filing jointly and $24,000 for single filers.
Mr. Archer said he would also consider exempting the first $400 of interest and dividend income. And he promised to take up the issue of the so-called marriage penalty, the provision in the tax code that produces a tax bill for many two-income couples higher than what they would pay if they were not married.
With Republicans and Democrats alike offering new tax proposals almost daily in the run-up to the opening of the new Congressional session next week, Mr. Archer's condemnation of the current tax code was echoed today by Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader.
Mr. Gephardt, who has long promoted his own plan to cut taxes for many low- and middle-income people, said in a speech in San Francisco that his proposal would now incorporate a provision to eliminate the marriage penalty, suggesting the issue's broad political appeal.
Mr. Gephardt said his plan would reduce the tax bill for 62 percent of taxpayers. He would eliminate nearly all deductions, credits, exemptions and adjustments except the mortgage interest deduction and the exclusion from taxation of employer-provided health insurance.
Mr. Gephardt's plan is intended to keep Federal tax revenues at their current level. But Mr. Archer said his plan would be based on a goal of driving the nation's overall tax bill substantially lower.
Federal revenues this year are running at 19.9 percent of the nation's total economic output, the highest rate since World War II, driven in part by investors who are cashing in large capital gains from the booming stock market. Mr. Archer said he would seek to cap Federal taxes at 19 percent of economic output within the next decade. Such a cap would amount to a $70 billion tax cut.

HEADLINE: Number on Welfare Rolls Dips Below 10 Million

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
The number of people on Federal welfare rolls has dropped below 10 million for the first time in more than 25 years, Clinton Administration officials said today.
Fewer than 4 percent of Americans are now on welfare, the smallest proportion since 1970, the Government reported. 
 The President's Council of Economic Advisers says that more than 40 percent of the decline is attributable to growth of the economy. More than 30 percent results from changes in Federal and state welfare policies and laws, the council said. The remainder is ascribed to other factors, including more aggressive collection of child support.
Rahm I. Emanuel, a senior adviser to President Clinton, said today: "For the first time since 1971, the number of people on welfare is below 10 million. This is a milestone that's based on the reforms that have altered the welfare system to reflect the priority of work and responsibility."
Mr. Emanuel, a strong proponent of the 1996 welfare law, said: "The children of these families whose parents are now working are connected to the mainstream culture, which is built around work. That's a qualitative difference in their lives that can never be measured."
The welfare rolls have been declining for several years. The number of people receiving cash assistance has dropped 29 percent since President Clinton took office and is now far below the peak of 14.4 million recorded in March 1994.
To the surprise of Federal officials and members of Congress, the decline has been accelerating. In January 1997, there were 11.4 million people on welfare, 2.8 million fewer than in January 1993. In the next seven months, from January to August 1997, the rolls declined by about 1.4 million.
Melissa T. Skolfield, a spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Human Services, said tonight: "In August 1997, the most recent month for which we have figures available, there were 9,995,000 people on welfare. That's a drop of more than 2.2 million since the welfare law was signed in August 1996. The number is at its lowest point since February 1971, when it was 9,952,000."
Officials say the decline in welfare rolls results in part from Federal waivers allowing states to experiment with new welfare policies and from the 1996 law, which established stringent work requirements.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 565 words

HEADLINE: A Budget to Run On

 BODY:
Taking advantage of the continuing boom on Wall Street, Gov. George Pataki has unveiled an election-year budget for New York State with enough programs to please nearly everyone. The only hitch is that it ignores fiscal prudence.
The proposed $71.9 billion budget reverses course after three years of attempts to trim state support for schools, higher education, welfare and health programs. In fact, aggregate spending from state funds would rise 8.5 percent, a boost reminiscent of the palmy Cuomo years. The budget is thus certain to enhance the Governor's re-election chances among those hit by cuts in the past. 
 But the budget does nothing to improve the state's precarious fiscal health. Once again, Mr. Pataki projects bigger multibillion-dollar deficits down the road, the main reason for the state's dismal credit rating. Figuring out how to finance these gaps will be the first headache to be faced by the next governor, whether it is Mr. Pataki or someone else. The deficits arise primarily from the exploding cost of tax cuts enacted last year, particularly the new program to subsidize local property tax cuts. If an economic downturn recurs, the state would have to cut spending or rescind tax cuts.
Like President Clinton, who recently unveiled the first balanced Federal budget in a generation, Mr. Pataki has reaped the benefits of prosperity. The current fiscal year will end March 31 with a record $1.8 billion surplus. Mr. Pataki would use much of that surplus to pay for sports stadiums and other pork-barrel projects that were approved by the Legislature last summer. That is throwing good money into a lot of dubious places. But since the Legislature originally intended to finance the projects by borrowing, Mr. Pataki's use of the surplus for this purpose can be viewed as a better alternative in a bad situation. Even so, his budget would drive borrowing by the state to a record $36 billion, mostly because of highway construction, prisons and higher-education spending.
The Governor's decision to avoid using the surplus to grant new tax cuts is prudent. He would simply accelerate by a year cuts that were already enacted, a move that would not worsen budget deficits in subsequent years. He now needs to persuade the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, to avoid his usual move to add still more tax cuts without paying for them. Mr. Bruno was generally supportive of the budget yesterday, declaring that "happy days are here again" for Republicans.
New York City would benefit, as the budget makes good on the Governor's promise last year to increase the proportion of state spending that goes to city schools. Since the accelerated property tax relief will go mostly to districts in the suburbs and upstate, the Legislature may well want to improve the school aid formulas even further. There may also be a need to increase help for drug treatment programs, children's services, school construction and programs to help welfare recipients find and hold jobs.
More politically significant than Mr. Bruno's reaction to the budget was the generally supportive reaction from the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver. The Democrats are certain to try to rearrange Mr. Pataki's priorities, but probably only on the margins. This was a budget designed to please the constituents of both parties in the coming year while ignoring the long-term peril.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INTERNATIONAL A3-8
 
Little Progress in Meeting Of Clinton and Netanyahu
President Clinton presented Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with a plan for the phased Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank. But Mr. Netanyahu made clear that Israeli redeployment would depend on Palestinian compliance with Israeli demands. A1 

After a private meeting with Mr. Netanyahu, the Rev. Jerry Falwell said he would mobilize evangelical churches to oppose giving more territory to the Palestinians. A1

Papal Visit to Cuba
Pope John Paul II was to arrive in Cuba today, and he will find a capital transformed by the presence of more than 3,000 journalists. A1
 
The Pope will encounter a Roman Catholic Church short of staff and vastly weakened by Fidel Castro's rule, but one unified and determined to push for a greater role in Cuban society. A8
 
The Pope is expected to denounce the United States' 37-year embargo of Cuba, in a call unlikely to influence the White House. A8
 
No Ordinary Date in Germany
A German scholar, Christian Gerlach, has published an article asserting that Hitler made a personal decision to put to death German Jews and all other European Jews under Nazi occupation. Mr. Gerlach based his claim on a notation by Heinrich Himmler, the SS chief, that was found in Soviet archives. A4
 
Korean Labor Shows Flexibility

President Suharto of Indonesia gave a strong hint that his choice for his next Vice President and potential successor was a longtime aide, Bacharuddin Jusuf Habibie, 61, a German-trained aeronautical engineer with unorthodox economic views who holds the post of Minister of Research and Technology. HEADLINE: With Pope Due, the Cubans Wrest Dollars From Heaven

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Jan. 20

 BODY:
At the Hotel Habana Libre, Dan Rather and his CBS News team are already ensconced on the 16th floor, while Ted Koppel and the "Nightline" staff are down on the 12th. Peter Jennings flew in Monday night, Tom Brokaw is expected today, and even Martha Stewart is coming in her role as a regular contributor to "CBS This Morning."
On the eve of Pope John Paul II's five-day visit to Cuba, Havana is a city transformed. 
 An army of reporters and television crews from the United States and more than 50 other countries has invaded the Cuban capital, throwing its slow-paced routine into overdrive and poking about without interference into nearly every corner and crevice of this normally restrictive society.
For the Cuban Government, especially the ministries and state companies that are providing services for the papal visit, the influx has already yielded a financial windfall. In a country that has operated under Communism for nearly 40 years, the law of supply and demand is suddenly being applied with a vengeance, resulting in what one travel agent called "Super Bowl prices" for everything from hotel rooms to satellite links.
Until Friday, a double room at the seafront Hotel Nacional was $105 a night and could be booked through almost any travel agent outside the United States, where the economic embargo against Cuba limits such commercial contacts.
Now, the same room costs $285 a night, and independent travel agents in Mexico, Canada and elsewhere complain they have been squeezed out of bookings by Cuban agencies that have links to the Cuban military.
The Government has imposed a series of creative new charges on equipment and supplies.
Want to bring in a satellite telephone? The Ministry of Communications is demanding a $1,000 "licensing fee" per telephone, plus $500 for each week the phone is in use.
Each of the four main American networks has at least 100 people here and they will likely end up having spent at least $1 million apiece once all their bills are paid. Their single biggest cost is a $100,000 "host TV fee" that Cuban state television is charging each of them for the live video feed of the Pope's activities, which normally is provided free or at minimal cost.
"We tried to negotiate some of these costs, but there wasn't much room for movement," said Phil Alongi, an NBC News producer who handled his network's contacts with the Cuban authorities. "It's their place and they have you."
Even after prices are agreed upon and bills are paid, arrangements may be subject to attempts at revision. Two American television executives said that Cuban customs officials informed them that the duties paid for a shipment of equipment earlier in the month were off by a decimal point: instead of being $5,000, the "corrected" bill was actually $50,000.
"Havana has become a three-ring circus," Chris Gillette of A.P. Television said this morning, as dozens of reporters jostled their way through the lobby of the Habana Libre, known as the Hilton until Fidel Castro's revolution put Cuba off-limits for all but a handful of Americans. "I have been coming here for years, and I have never, ever seen the place like this."
El Morro, the fortress and lighthouse that is Havana's most famous landmark, has become the backdrop to the set where CBS will be broadcasting its nightly news this week.
Cameramen in shorts roam the cobblestoned streets and plazas of Old Havana, drawing gapes and friendly japes from residents whose exposure to foreigners 10 years ago was limited to Russians and their allies.
All told, Cuban officials said, more than 3,000 reporters representing 460 foreign news organizations, including four reporters and one photographer from The New York Times,have already been granted credentials for the papal visit, "some of them from the most unlikely publications you could imagine," said Frank Gonzalez, director of the Government's International Press Center. Of that total, Americans make up the largest group, with more than 1,300 correspondents, editors, camera operators and other personnel accredited.
One notable absence, however, is Jose Diaz-Balart, the Cuban-American co-host of CBS's "This Morning" program. Though he is Mr. Castro's nephew by marriage, Mr. Diaz-Balart and his family, led by his brother, the Republican Congressman Lincoln Diaz-Balart of Miami, have long been fierce and outspoken critics of Mr. Castro and his Government, which regularly castigates them as leaders of what is known in official jargon here as "the Miami exile mafia."
It is hard to imagine an atmosphere further removed from Connecticut gentility than the socialist austerity of Cuba, but Martha Stewart is here nonetheless.
Al Ortiz, a CBS News vice president, said that she had been brought down to "try to bring some added slice of life or flavor to our coverage" and that "our hard news coverage is in no way affected" by her presence.
"There's a lot to say about life style down here," Mr. Ortiz added. "She is not going to do superficial, feel-good stuff, but will make an honest attempt to look at how people live here" with reports about, for example, paladares, the small private restaurants Cubans are now allowed to operate.
Since beginning a drive earlier this decade to encourage tourism, Cuba has grown used to receiving European and Canadian visitors on inexpensive package tours.
But the arrival of a phalanx of journalists on expense accounts has meant a welcome injection of hard currency not just for paladares, but also for hotels, taxi drivers and shops, especially those selling cigars and rum.
"In my whole life, I've never seen so many rich foreigners on the streets of Havana at the same time," exulted Xiomara Lopez Pedraza, a handicrafts vendor at a market in the Vedado area, where most of the hotels lodging reporters are located. "Too bad the Pope can't come to Cuba every year."
Although some reporters and producers are bridling at the price gouging, many praise the performance of other sectors of the Cuban bureaucracy, especially the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Requests for interviews are being answered promptly, reporters are actually being encouraged to wander wherever they want, and many Americans have been granted visas that allow them to stay for 30 days instead of one week, the usual pattern.
Among major American news organizations, only The Miami Herald, which Cuba's state security apparatus regards as a Cuban exile mouthpiece, has been denied all requests for visas for its reporters. Visas were also denied to a Newsweek reporter who once wrote about young people injecting themselves with the AIDS virus and a reporter from The St. Petersburg Times who wrote a long piece about the re-emergence of prostitution here.
One European diplomat with long experience here estimates that thanks to the new licenses and higher prices, the papal visit will generate a profit of at least $25 million for the Cuban Government. "This is a one-time opportunity, and they are determined to make the best of it," he said.
At a Monday news conference here, Jose Luis Rodriguez, Minister of the Economy and Planning, declined to estimate how much money the Cuban Government is likely to make from the event. "This has not been looked at as a business venture, so we haven't made a calculation," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Pope is to start a five-day visit to Cuba today and the heavy presence of the foreign press is fattening the country's finances. Transportation in the city ranges from pedicabs to American cars from the 1940's and 50's. (Reuters)(pg. A8)

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Revenge on the Nerds

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
I figured things were way out of perspective in the Other Washington when I heard that Bill Gates had put an inscription from "The Great Gatsby" around the domed ceiling of the library in his new $100 million pad: "He had come a long way to this blue lawn and his dream must have seemed so close that he could hardly fail to grasp it."
Bill Gates was obviously unaware of the magnitude of the truth that he had unwittingly admitted. 
 When he read about the blue lawn, he must have imagined computers with glowing blue screens stretching to infinity. And he must certainly have liked the proximity of the words "dream" and "grasp."
With a judge who is likely soon to hold Microsoft in contempt for petulantly defying an order designed to give its rivals any chance, Mr. Gates's dream may at last have exceeded his grasp. The Justice Department never came down on Gatsby.
This Washington has disabused that Washington of its arrogant presumption that what's good for Microsoft is good for America. This Washington has stripped that Washington of its image as warm, tender, flannel-and-soyburger pioneers of the new economy, and properly pegged Microsoft as an egomaniacal, dangerous giant that has cut off the air supply of competitors in a bid to control cyberspace.
"The only thing the robber barons did that Bill Gates hasn't done is use dynamite against their competitors," Gary Reback, a Silicon Valley antitrust lawyer, told John Heilemann of The New Yorker.
The disheveled college dropout who used to get adoring headlines like "A Regular Guy Who's a Legend: Bill Gates Puts a New Face on the American Dream" now looks like a spoiled rich brat. When they treated the Justice Department and the judge with the same contempt they treat competitors with, the masters of the virtual universe got hit with a grim truth: People hate Microsoft even more than they hate the Government.
Mr. Gates has gone from Horatio Alger similes to virus similes. Frederick Warren-Boulton, another antitrust expert, told The New Yorker: "Gates is like smallpox. You have to go in there and you have to nail it. If you leave it lying around, it will just come back."
When asked who they thought had done more good for the future of America, Bill Gates or Bill Clinton, more Americans chose Mr. Clinton. (Even though portfolio-obsessed Americans would still rather have their children grow up to be more like Mr. Gates than Mr. Clinton, by 47 to 24 percent.)
As Jacob Weisberg plaintively wrote in Slate, Microsoft's on-line magazine: "A few months ago, everyone I met seemed to think that working for Microsoft was a pretty cool thing to do. Now, strangers treat us like we work for Philip Morris."
The Times's Timothy Egan explored the angst that has gripped the Redmond campus since Microsoft lost its sheen. Some fret that the fate of the entire Pacific Northwest is at stake.
All the instant millionaires in thermal shirts, droopy drawers and sandals with wool socks are suddenly Wondering If It's All Worth It. They have staggered out of the Seattle fog long enough to listen to their inner browsers.
This has been a rude shock to them because they honestly believed that our Washington was full of anti-business, careerist bureaucrats, and their Washington was full of imaginative idealists and entrepreneurs who buy and sell to the beat of a different drum. They didn't reckon smokestack laws could apply to high technology.
As Mr. Gates's lawyer, William Neukom, told Steve Lohr of The Times, "We sincerely believe that we are a force for good in the economy." Actually, Microsoft has been a force for greed in the economy, more brilliant at marketing and purloining and crushing than it has been at innovating. The company saw the fight with the Justice Department as a defense of its way of life. And that way was hardball on software; anything Microsoft decided was a core threat to it was sucked into the operating system.
These are Darwinian nerds. Besides, Microsoft couldn't even save the universe in "Independence Day." It took an Apple to do that.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Stocks Up in Japan, Helped by Wall Street's Gain

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Japanese stocks rose today for a sixth day, helped by Wall Street's gains and the possibility of additional measures to invigorate the domestic economy.
Elsewhere in Asia, South Korean stocks fell sharply. Other Asian markets were mixed. 
 Japan's benchmark Nikkei average of 225 issues closed up 317.89 points, or 1.94 percent, to 16,684.42.
Traders attributed the gain partly to a carry-over effect from the advances on Tuesday on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.5 percent and broader stock averages also strengthened.
Further helping the Japanese market were more hints the Government might issue another economic stimulus package.
Koichi Kato, secretary general of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, said on Tuesday that efforts to reduce the Government budget deficit should be delayed if the economy remained stagnant, the Nihon Keizai newspaper reported. He also said there was room to increase spending on public works.
In Seoul, stocks dropped 5.1 percent on profit-taking from the market's recent gains and the uncertainty regarding efforts to renegotiate the nation's short-term debt. A South Korean delegation was conferring with international bank representatives in New York today.
By late afternoon, the South Korean market's main index was down 27.40 points, to 506.15.
In other Asian markets, Indonesia's composite stock index rose 4.4 percent, largely on demand for shares of PT Telkom, which was viewed as an increasingly attractive investment because of the diminished value of the rupiah currency.
Stocks fell 2.64 percent in Hong Kong by midday, 1.42 percent in Singapore and 1.05 percent in the Philippines but were slightly higher in Thailand.

HEADLINE: Whitman Urges Funds for Cities And Open Land

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman pledged today in her second inaugural address to devote her next term to rebuilding neighborhoods in New Jersey's cities and protecting farmland and other open space from development.
Mrs. Whitman, taking the oath of office at the newly built New Jersey Performing Arts Center here, said: "I want to make our state more affordable, our schools stronger, and our communities safer. Ultimately, my mission is to make New Jersey more livable." 
 In the first inaugural since 1844 to be held outside Trenton, where the usual site is closed, Mrs. Whitman delivered a 22-minute address before 2,800 friends, supporters, lawmakers and state officials, emphasizing the importance of planning and controlling development in the nation's most densely populated state.
 She said the experience of driving around the state had given her a sense of urgency about the state's future. "I have a vision for that future," she said, "a vision for rebuilding our cities, preserving our open space, and enriching our sense of personal responsibility."
She said she would spend $400 million to help cities reclaim and develop abandoned properties. She vowed to stem suburban sprawl by giving municipalities the tools to stop development projects that overburden congested roadways and crowded schools. She also pledged to commit state dollars to preserve 300,000 acres of farmland in the next four years, with the ultimate goal of preserving one million acres in the next decade.
At the same time, she recommended giving developers incentives, like speedy state permit approvals, to build in areas that have already been targeted for development by the state.
"Every part of New Jersey suffers when we plan haphazardly," she said. "Sprawl eats up our open space. It creates traffic jams that boggle the mind and pollute the air. Sprawl can make one feel downright claustrophobic about our future."
Mrs. Whitman also called for increased state spending for community colleges to hold the line on tuition increases.
She pledged to give $5 million to help urban religious leaders and organizations support child care, job training and economic development projects in their communities.
And in other steps she said were intended to improve the quality of life, she proposed constructing 2,000 miles of hiking and bike paths over the next 10 years. She also said she would offer plans in the next two months to increase bus and train lines and improve safety on roadways.
Mrs. Whitman did not talk about some of the more immediate concerns of New Jerseyans that dominated last fall's gubernatorial race: the high cost of automobile insurance and property taxes. Nor did she propose any new tax cuts, a step that marked her first term and helped make her a national figure within the Republican Party.
But last week, during her annual address to the Legislature, she addressed the issue of property taxes and promised to be able to sign into law an auto insurance plan in March. She is expected to discuss her plans to control government spending when she unveils her new state budget next month.
The themes that Mrs. Whitman chose to emphasize in her inaugural address have been embraced by past New Jersey governors, Democrats and Republicans alike. In focusing on reviving cities and controlling development, Mrs. Whitman was tackling problems that have bedeviled other New Jersey politicians for years.
Her top aides said that despite the record of the past, she was determined that her final term would address development in the cities, which have not shared in the state's economic boom, and controlling development in the suburban and rural areas.
Her biggest challenge will be persuading some state and local officials to support her agenda for stemming suburban sprawl. Some municipal officials have embraced unplanned development of open space in the short term so they can hold down property taxes for current residents by increasing their property tax base. Mrs. Whitman said her administration intended to show municipal leaders that new development could often increase the local property tax burden in the long term by increasing the demand for local services.
She also faces difficulty persuading Republican legislators to pour state dollars into the cities. Since her narrow re-election victory last fall, Republican legislative leaders have hinted that they are prepared to set their own agenda for the state, and providing further state assistance to cities has never topped their priority list, because most of their constituents live in the suburban and rural areas.
Nevertheless, the state's Republican legislative leaders, Assembly Speaker Jack Collins and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, had only warm praise for Mrs. Whitman's speech.
"I think that she touched on the things that all New Jerseyans care about, some more than others," Mr. Collins said. "But everybody cares about the future of this state, the air we breathe, the water we drink, open space. I think she was really on target."
For the most part, Democrats offered milder remarks. "I don't think there was any meat on the bone," the Senate Minority Leader, Richard J. Codey, said.
But United States Senator Robert G. Torricelli, a Democrat, said he believed Democrats could embrace the goals Mrs. Whitman described. "It is a remarkably progressive agenda," Mr. Torricelli said. "She is likely to have more trouble from Republicans than Democrats. I admire Governor Whitman for taking on the fight. I hope that she has the strength to win."
Before arriving at her swearing-in ceremony, Mrs. Whitman attended an interfaith service at the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark. Outside the Roman Catholic church, about 150 opponents of abortion rights stood behind police barricades to protest Mrs. Whitman's decision to veto state legislation that would impose a ban on a type of late-term abortion.
The Performing Arts Center here, considered the cornerstone of the effort to revive the downtown of the state's largest city, was chosen as the site of the inaugural partly because the Trenton War Memorial, where inaugurations are usually held, has been closed for the last three years for renovations. But Mrs. Whitman also said the center represented the state's commitment to its cities. "Urban mayors, I give you my word," Mrs. Whitman said. "Together, we can pull down those boards. Together, we can raise up these neighborhoods."
Douglas Palmer, the Mayor of Trenton, said he was encouraged by Mrs. Whitman's pledge, particularly her proposal to give state assistance to religious leaders who are already working to help revive urban neighborhoods. "She is not giving lip service," Mr. Palmer said. "She is giving the tools that will help cities spur economic revitalization and growth."
State officials estimate that there are thousands of abandoned properties across the state that owe municipalities between $250 million and $300 million in back taxes. Since it is now time-consuming and costly for a municipality to acquire some abandoned properties, the state would speed up the process by covering the cost of a property owner's tax liens on those abandoned properties that have been designated for development.
The state would borrow up to $400 million through the state Economic Development Authority for the program. The debt would be paid back with proceeds from the sale and development of the properties, state officials said.
Mrs. Whitman closed her speech by talking about the importance of personal responsibility and challenging New Jerseyans to give an hour or two of their time to a cause that would help others.
She cited her own example by dedicating a few hours every month to reading for Recordings for the Blind and Dyslexic.
"As I make this commitment, I recognize that it's not much," she said. "But it's more than I am doing today. I challenge each of you to make the same kind of new start."

HEADLINE: Spending Rise Of 7% Sought In Pataki Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Reversing course from the austere program he brought to office three years ago, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed an election-year budget today that is 7.6 percent larger than the last, swelled by a major rise in school spending that was agreed to last year and new increases for education and health care.
The same Governor who, in his first two years, held spending flat proposed a $71.9 billion budget, up from $66.8 billion, the largest proportional increase since the heady days of the mid-1980's. Much of the rise in spending would go toward areas that Mr. Pataki fought to cut in previous years -- aid to schools and universities, health care for the poor -- and he also called for construction of a new maximum-security prison. 
 "Three years of conservative fiscal practices and smart economic policies have turned crisis into comeback," Mr. Pataki proclaimed in a 33-minute speech that was as long on politics as on numbers.
Last year, the Governor agreed to calls from Democratic legislators for a major increase in educational spending in each of the next four years, and the increase in his proposed budget for the fiscal year that begins on April 1 was, in part, a product of that deal.
But Mr. Pataki also proposed a range of new spending initiatives that sometimes sounded more like the work of a Democrat than a budget-cutting Republican: an English-immersion program for foreign-born students, a pilot after-school program in some schools, more money for child care for poor parents, more money for parks, and an expansion of health care for uninsured children through the age of 18.
And after three straight years of trying to make deep cuts in Medicaid, the state's costly health care program primarily for the poor that accounts for the biggest piece of the state budget -- 35 percent in the spending plan the Governor proposed today -- he proposed allowing it to grow by more than 5 percent.
As might have been predicted, reactions from the two legislative leaders whose support the Governor needs for his budget plan fell along partisan lines. Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, called it "a budget drawn to be an election-year budget." The Governor's budget plan, said Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, is meant to let Mr. Pataki "go out to all groups and say, 'Here's what I'm doing.' "
The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican from Rensselaer County, described it as "a great budget for the people of New York State."
While Mr. Pataki's turnabout may do him the political favor of softening his image as a fiscal conservative preaching sacrifice, it drew criticism from independent fiscal monitors. They had praised Mr. Pataki in the past for imposing discipline on the state's spending, but today they said they were disappointed that his latest plan not only increased spending but ialso ncluded another round of tax cuts.
The newly proposed tax cuts, not nearly on the scale of those he won in each of the three previous years, are mainly an acceleration of property tax cuts enacted last year.
His other proposed tax cuts include an expansion of tax credits for large businesses that locate in New York, and acceleration of New York City's income tax cut for some elderly city residents.
"We've made progress over time" in balancing the state's budget over the long run, said Andrew Rein, senior research associate at the Citizens Budget Commission, a private organization. "But this budget goes back on that progress." He noted that by the state's own projections, it will have a deficit of more than $4.5 billion in three years that will have to be closed with spending cuts, postponement of scheduled tax cuts or, perhaps, even tax increases.
Mr. Pataki, clearly anticipating the assertion that increasing spending while cutting taxes was risky, repeatedly insisted as he spoke in the auditorium of the state theater across from the Capitol that he remains a fiscal conservative. "We're restraining state spending like never before," he said.
And in a news conference later, he challenged reporters who questioned the prudence of the spending plan, waving copies of articles they had written that made the same criticism of his previous budget proposals. Events had proved them wrong, he said, commenting, "Why not just write the same articles you did last year and the year before?"
Since Mr. Pataki's election, the state has ridden an economic boom, driven largely by the boom on Wall Street, that has allowed New York to cut taxes and increase spending simultaneously. The Governor insisted that his fiscal plan did not rely on a continued bull market, but the plan also assumes that there will not be an economic downturn -- or even a serious slowdown in growth -- in the next several years.
In a budget address that rang with sound bites reminiscent of a campaign speech, Mr. Pataki ranged far afield from purely fiscal matters, repeating his call for an end to parole for violent felons and thanking people for the aid they have sent to victims of the recent ice storm in northern New York.
The budget presentation -- once a modest affair in the Governor's office -- has grown in recent years into a large, tightly choreographed event held in a theater and attended by hundreds of legislators, state officials and gubernatorial aides, with a corps of troopers and other state workers controlling the human traffic.
Historically, proposals by a Governor of either party have provided a floor for budget talks with the Legislature, and the budget that is finally enacted is invariably larger. In recent years, those negotiations have lasted longer and longer, often tying up the capital well into the summer.
But this year, as Mr. Pataki seeks a second term, there may be more common ground between the Governor and his legislative adversaries, since two areas that have historically been favorites of the Legislature -- education and health care -- account for most of the budget increase.
The proposed budget also contains a 4.7 percent increase in aid to school districts -- the second-largest part of the budget -- to $11.45 billion, a reflection of the multiyear agreement on education spending that was contained in last year's budget. That agreement provided an increase of $100 million in money for school construction and repair -- to $900 million -- and money for expanded pre-kindergarten programs and class-size reduction.
In addition, Mr. Pataki sought to double spending on construction for the State University of New York and City University systems, to $515 million, along with an increase in tuition assitance for students, which he tried to cut in previous years.
Mr. Pataki also proposed an expansion in state-subsidized child care for welfare recipients and the working poor, to 125,000 from 114,000.
Over all, the $71.9 billion proposed budget is nearly $5 billion larger than the one enacted last year but about one-third of that is Federal money for programs like Medicaid and welfare, which tend to increase regardless of state actions.
Still, the part of the budget that is generated by state taxes and fees, which Mr. Pataki held without an increase his first two years, would rise 8.5 percent next year under his plan, from $45 billion, to $48.8 billion.
Mr. Silver, the Assembly Speaker, said that "only in rhetoric" did the Governor's latest budget proposal and his first ones resemble each other. The Speaker said he would like to see an increase in basic school aid about $300 million larger than the one Mr. Pataki requested, and about $500 million more in school construction money than the Governor proposed.
Last year's budget agreement, if left untouched, would automatically mean $500 million in tax cuts during the fiscal year that begins on April 1. Mr. Pataki proposed raising that figure to $1.2 billion, mostly by accelerating cuts in property taxes and other levies that were to take place further in the future.
Last year, state lawmakers agreed to exempt clothing from the sales tax starting next year, and today the Governor called for including shoes in that exemption, a favorite request of New York City's Mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Mr. Giuliani said that he would have liked to see a greater commitment from Mr. Pataki to drug treatment but that "by and large, it's a positive budget from the point of view of the city."
The Governor's largess could avoid some of the nasty conflicts that have produced the four latest budgets in state history the last four years. But he made a few proposals that are guaranteed to turn into fights with the Democrats who control the Assembly.
Mr. Pataki asked for $180 million for a 1,500-bed, maximum-security prison, and the Assembly Democrats have generally resisted prison construction, instead calling, like Mr. Giuliani, for more treatment beds for drug abusers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. George E. Pataki, right, arriving to present the budget to the Legislature. From left, Senator Joseph L. Bruno, Assemblyman Thomas M. Reynolds, Speaker Sheldon Silver and Senator Martin Connor. (David Jennings for The New York Times)(pg. B6)
 
Chart: "HIGHLIGHTS: What Pataki's Budget Would Do"
The Governor's overall budget proposal of $71.9 billion -- which covers money from all sources, including the Federal Government -- would raise state spending by 7.6 percent. State spending alone would increase from the current $45 billion, to $48.8 billion, an 8.5 percent increase. Negotiations with the Legislature are almost certain to yield a final package that is larger on both accounts.
 
TAX CUTS
The budget proposes accelerating the school property tax cut for most elderly homeowners and an income tax reduction for seniors in New York City with low and moderate income, at a total cost of $500 million. It would also speed up the exemption of up to 250 acres of farmland from school property taxes ($71 million). It also proposes $45 million in tax cuts by extending to two the sales-tax-free weeks in January 1999 for all clothing and shoes costing less than $500; $50 million in tax savings through a 25 percent reduction in motor vehicle registration fees, and a state income tax exemption on all Holocaust reparation payments, the tax implications of which are not known at this point.
 
SCHOOL AID
Under the Governor's plan, state spending for secondary and elementary schools would increase by $518 million, bringing total spending for the year to $11.45 billion. Some of the new spending would go for charter schools, summer school for fourth graders, an English immersion program for children in kindergarten through second grade, full-day kindergarten, and expansion of the pre-kindergarten program.
 
HIGHER EDUCATION
The budget raises state aid to the State University of New York and the City University of New York to $2.58 billion, a 4.8 percent increase that should allow tuition to remain unchanged next year. Part of that increase is a doubling of spending on capital projects, to $515 million.
 
PRISONS
The Governor proposes spending $180 million for a new maximum-security state prison that would open in the 2000-2001 budget year.
 
ENVIRONMENT
The Governor recommended $125 million for the state's Environmental Protection Fund, a $25 million increase. (pg. B6)
