HEADLINE: Good-News Budget

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 20

 BODY:
In his first three years in office, Gov. George E. Pataki proposed some of the most contentious state budgets of the last 50 years: ideological cauldrons bubbling with demands for huge cuts in health care, welfare and education, along with tuition hikes at public universities and massive tax cuts.
The Republican Governor got some of what he wanted, but not all, and it came at the cost of extended public combat that undermined his relationship with the Legislature and hurt his reputation with the public. 
 But there was little talk of cuts or austerity in the budget Mr. Pataki offered today. Indeed, in Mr. Pataki's peppy budget presentation -- which had more of the trappings of a campaign kick-off than the annual gubernatorial accounting of the state's finances -- there was no mention of anything that might unsettle the Legislature, the lobbyists, the unions or the public at large.
And that was clearly how it was intended. The Governor's proposed budget, viewed in conjunction with his State of the State Message of two weeks ago, leaves little doubt that if Mr. Pataki has his way, 1998 will, in tone and ambition, be the opposite of his combative first three sessions in Albany. If his previous years here became often unruly attempts to impose the fiscally conservative political philosophy he had espoused throughout his career, the next 10 months are designed to be as placid as Mr. Pataki can manage.
In the view of many Democrats and Republicans here for the budget presentation, Mr. Pataki has replaced, at least for now, his philosophical designs on changing New York with a far more immediate objective: winning re-election later this year. And not simply winning (since Mr. Pataki's advisers are convinced that that will not be difficult), but defeating his Democratic rival with a large enough margin to establish himself as the dominant Republican from the Northeast, someone national Republicans will notice when the year 2000 rolls around.
That means, according to one of Mr. Pataki's political advisers, remaining fiscally responsible while coasting through this legislative session without the delays and often unseemly squabbling that marked his first three years here.
"The real Pataki is what we saw in the first couple of years," said State Senator Martin Connor, the Brooklyn Democrat and minority leader, after studying Mr. Pataki's latest budget plan. "This is the very pragmatic, get-me-re-elected Pataki."
"It's the old story in an election year," Mr. Connor continued, with a note of admiration. "He didn't leave the Democrats a lot of room to stand on. He's just captured so much of the middle."
In previous years, Democrats attacked Mr. Pataki's budgets as an assault on the poor and middle-class. Unions ran television advertisements depicting him as an enemy of the frail elderly; students shouted him down on state university campuses. The Legislature pounded him at every opportunity.
But today, Democrats were flummoxed to hear Mr. Pataki, who kept spending flat in his first two budgets and increased spending only moderately last year, calling for a 7.6 percent spending increase in a budget plan, chockablock with new spending. In one of more striking political role reversals of recent times, the conservative Republican Governor was attacked as reckless -- by a Democrat.
"George Pataki's proposed budget is the most fiscally irresponsible in history," said Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of New York City Council and one of the Democrats seeking to challenge the Governor.
At first glance, Mr. Pataki is doing what politicians commonly do: Pushing through their most controversial ideas as soon as possible, in the calculation that bad memories will fade from the public mind by election time. For Mr. Pataki, that meant advocating harsh cuts in Medicaid, welfare and education in 1995 and 1996 as he sought to erase a $5 billion state budget deficit, and changing fiscal practices he and his conservative allies labeled irresponsible.
The $5 billion budget deficit is indeed gone, replaced by a surplus -- due to Mr. Pataki's strategies and, even more importantly, say many economists, to Wall Street's good times. Hence, this year's good-news budget.
"This budget is meant to offset the damage that was done in 1995," said James L. Larocca, a former State Transportation Commissioner and another Democrat seeking to challenge Mr. Pataki. "But I think people will see through this as an election year budget."
But, in the end, there is a reason someone who was barely known beyond his home town of Peekskill four years ago seems headed for re-election today. Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, chuckled softly this afternoon when asked why the Medicaid cuts that had been central to Mr. Pataki's previous budgets were absent today. "He probably read the polls," Mr. Silver said.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Funds for Women's Group

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
The United States Small Business Administration has committed $750,000 over five years to establish the Women's Business Center in New York, an organization that will help women start their own businesses.
The new center, one of 10 such centers nationwide that the Federal agency has agreed to finance this year, joining 49 others, is to be administered by the Women's Venture Fund, a three-year-old nonprofit organization that gives loans to women in low-income communities in New York City to create a business. The Small Business Administration has required that its annual grants of $150,000 be matched, and the Women's Venture Fund is seeking corporate and private donations. 
 The Women's Business Center is to operate out of the Venture Fund's offices at 155 East 42d Street. A spokeswoman for the Venture Fund, Maria Semidei-Otero, said the new enterprise and grant money would provide technical assistance to women who are seeking commercial bank loans.
"The Women's Venture Fund has been very imaginative so far in their development of programs to assist women and have worked with very diverse populations," Thomas M. Bettridge, a regional administrator for the Small Business Administration responsible for New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, said yesterday. "We were glad they had a wide reach in terms of their activities." LISA W. FODERARO

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Overseas Crisis Takes a Toll On Earnings Of 3 Big Banks

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN

 BODY:
The crisis in overseas financial markets was again felt in the United States yesterday, as three of the nation's largest banks said fourth-quarter earnings were hurt by sharp economic downturns in Asia and Latin America.
J. P. Morgan & Company, which said profit in the quarter plunged 35.3 percent on lower trading and underwriting revenues, suffered the heaviest damage. Most glaringly, and perhaps a harbinger of further pain for banks in Asia, J. P. Morgan set aside $587 million to protect itself from potential losses on nonperforming transactions known as currency swaps, primarily involving South Korean, Thai and Indonesian companies. . 
 The Chase Manhattan Corporation's fourth-quarter earnings rose 5 percent and Citicorp's gained 7.4 percent, but both companies were battered abroad. Chase reported an overall trading loss of $78 million for the quarter, as losses on Latin American bonds outweighed strong foreign-exchange gains, and said it had less than $100 million in nonperforming Asian loans. Citicorp classified $281 million in emerging markets loans as nonperforming, of which $200 million was related to Asia, and said problems in Asia reduced pretax income by $250 million for the quarter.
Nonetheless, Chase and Citicorp turned in stronger performances on the whole than did J. P. Morgan, and the stock market recognized it. Chase's shares rose $1.6875 each, to $107.1875. Citicorp's shares fell 87.5 cents, to $119, and J. P. Morgan's share price dropped $1.625, to $105.25.
The earnings announcements preceded the arrival in New York today of a South Korean delegation to discuss the country's attempt to renegotiate at least $28 billion in short-term debt owed to international banks. J. P. Morgan, Chase and Citicorp have tried to convince South Korea to repackage a large portion of that debt as long-term bonds guaranteed by the Seoul Government, but the proposal has encountered strong antipathy from the South Koreans. Moreover, significant differences of opinion exist among American, Japanese and German banks about how to handle a debt repackaging -- further undermining the likelihood that the American proposal will be a blueprint for the negotiations.
Banks have agreed to extend payment on the loans, at least $6 billion of which are in technical default, until March 31.
Japanese and German banks are the two largest South Korean creditors and are interested in options that do not include enormous bond offerings by South Korea. The South Koreans themselves are concerned that using a big bond auction to repackage their debt could force them to pay punishing interest rates. But South Korea's pile of short-term loans has created a cash shortage that is strangling the local economy, and the country's negotiators do not have unlimited time.
As yet unspoken, but certainly a point of discussion, will be whether South Korea's creditors must swallow losses on loans in order to conclude an agreement and to deflate public criticism that aid to the country amounts to a bailout of lenders. In that regard, loans to Southeast Asia still haunt American banks, but much less so than their European and Japanese counterparts.
At the end of 1997, J. P. Morgan had $3.4 billion in combined loan, bond and derivatives exposure in South Korea; $1.1 billion in Thailand, and $900 million in Indonesia. Citicorp said it had $2.4 billion in South Korean loans, $500 million in Indonesia, $300 million in Thailand and $400 million in the Philippines at the end of 1997. Chase has yet to provide more detail about its Southeast Asian exposure, beyond saying it had $4 billion in South Korean loans at the end of last September.
J. P. Morgan reported fourth-quarter net income of $271 million, or $1.33 a diluted share, on revenue of $1.68 billion, compared with $419 million, or $2.04 a share, on revenue of $1.8 billion for the comparable period last year. Analysts had expected earnings of $1.57 a share, according to consensus estimates set by First Call, a company that tracks corporate earnings. For the year, the bank earned $1.465 billion on revenue of $7.22 billion, compared with $1.57 billion on revenue of $6.85 billion in 1996.
J. P. Morgan reported a $78 million drop in credit revenue for the quarter because of turmoil in Asia and a $54 million loss in its equities derivatives portfolio, which analysts said was unrelated to the bank's emerging markets business.
Citicorp had fourth-quarter profits of $1.06 billion, or $2.20 a share, on revenue of $6 billion, compared with $987 million, or $1.97 a share, on revenue of $5.74 billion, in last year's fourth quarter. Analysts had expected the bank to earn $2.18 a share. For the year, Citicorp earned $3.6 billion, or $7.33 a share, on revenue of $23.3 billion, compared with profits of $3.8 billion, or $7.43 a share, on revenue of $21.5 billion, in 1996.
Citicorp had an overall trading loss of $188 million in the quarter and classified $59 million in foreign currency derivatives as nonperforming. Citicorp also said profit from its consumer businesses in emerging markets was $107 million lower than a year earlier because of problems in Asia and Brazil. These problems were more than offset by gains in the company's other operations. Credit card profits worldwide were down, although that business appears to be stabilizing. Citicorp's chairman and chief executive, John S. Reed, said he was not currently interested in acquiring other American banks. The bank raised its dividend 5 cents a share.
While Citicorp does not break out earnings on a country-by-country basis, Mr. Reed said in an internal E-mail memo to employees that pretax earnings for Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines could be down considerably. Mr. Reed added that "it is not good news but it probably does not have serious long-term consequences."
Chase reported fourth-quarter profits of $874 million, or $1.89 a share, on revenue of $4.29 billion, compared with $836 million, or $1.88 a share, on revenue of $4.1 billion, in last year's quarter. Analysts expected earnings of $1.89 a share. For the year, Chase earned $3.53 billion, or $8.64 a share, on revenue of $17.67 billion, compared with profits of $2.24 billion, or $7.55 a share, on revenue of $16.43 billion in 1996.

HEADLINE: Turf;
The Perfect Doorman Is Made, Not Born

BYLINE: By Tracie Rozhon 

 BODY:
IT'S not easy being a doorman.
First, there are those pesky autograph seekers, trying to waylay a prestigious tenant as he makes his way through the throngs outside. 
 Then there is the workman having a heart attack on the lobby floor.
Then there is the pleasant but persistent visitor a tenant doesn't want to see -- whom the doorman has to get rid of, politely.
And there is a sleazy reporter, trying to trick the doorman into giving information on a tenant in the news.
Being a doorman is apparently such a tough and tricky job that the city's largest management company has produced a training video to help its workers learn to cope with these make-believe (but presumably realistic) challenges -- with poise, if, judging by the video, not always charm. (The company used real doormen, who are, if the truth be told, a bit wooden on camera but at least game.)
The video, matter-of-factly titled "Concierge and Doorman Training" and not for commercial release, was made by a security-video company on a modest budget: "low five figures," said Jim O'Connor, a senior vice president at the Insignia Residential Group, which produced the video.
Mr. O'Connor, who said he really "got a kick out of the whole thing," has shown the 20-minute video to doormen in all of Insignia's managed buildings in Manhattan, Westchester and New Jersey. The company's 2,000 doormen and concierges were also given a printed synopsis of the dos and don'ts of being a good doorman.
To complaints about autograph seekers, a doorman should nod his head sagely and say he'll try to stop them. For heart attacks and other maladies, he should dial 911. If unwanted visitors ask to wait in the lobby, he should just say no. With inquiring reporters, he should keep mum. (By the way, "doorman" is one of those titles that the gender police cannot fault; New York doormen are almost exclusively male.)
"You know, it's not the highest paid job in the world," Mr. O'Connor said, "and the labor pool is limited by economics. On top of that, you've got to have someone who's honest -- there are very thorough background checks -- and they also have to be congenial and intelligent."
It is a union job, and the turnover, especially among the younger doormen, is fairly high. "It's standing up for eight hours a day, dealing with all the action," Mr. O'Connor said. "Guests, deliveries, floods."
The video can be a revelation to watch, in that many New Yorkers have not observed their own doormen performing like the ones shown in it. Besides fending off autograph seekers (the elegant "actor" with a German accent is actually the board president of a building near the United Nations, Mr. O'Connor said), the video's doormen are eternally vigilant about taxis: the men run out of the building every time one pulls up. In this video, the doormen also wheel out elaborate brass clothing racks on which to hang their tenants' expensive leather suit carriers, as they alight from limousines.
"It's true -- we do have guys who do that," Mr. O'Connor said. "Not all of them do it, but they're supposed to. Now, at least they know they're supposed to."
Gus Bevona, the president of Local 32B-32JT of the Service Employees International Union -- which has 65,000 members, including doormen, janitors and maintenance men -- could not be reached for comment, despite several attempts.
But Steven Steinberg, the president of the co-op board at 60 Gramercy Park -- and not a customer of Insignia -- was outspoken about the need for doormen who do exactly what the video portrays them as doing.
"All buildings pay the same rate to doormen because they're in the union -- did you know that?" he asked. "What we're looking for, especially in Gramercy Park, since we have to compete against Park Avenue, is a Park Avenue-type of doorman: an old-fashioned kind of guy who can't wait to help."
"Somebody who leaps to hold the elevator door open for tenants," he continued, "and out of the corner of his eye sees a taxi pulling up with somebody with lots of packages. Someone who will leap -- leaping is part of the doorman Olympics -- to help."
Mr. Steinberg said his building had hired such a person about a year ago. "He's young," he said. "He's articulate. He wants to help. If I could clone him I would. I'd put him up against any doorman in the city."
The problem, he said, is keeping this paragon down on Gramercy Park.
"The downtown doormen may not get as many tips at Christmastime as the uptown doormen," he explained.
Then there is the problem of doormen at the other end of the scale, those who are not so great, and yet are extremely difficult to dismiss.
"If you have a real clunker, you're stuck with him forever," Mr. Steinberg said. He confided that he had visited a Greenwich Village apartment building and was shocked by the poor attitude of the doorman.
"He was indifferent," the board president said. "He's got his little dustpan out, and he didn't care less whether we're coming or going."
Mr. Steinberg called the doorman training video "a brilliant idea," and asked if it was available for viewing. Perhaps, he said, he would suggest his building's managing agent make its own instruction tape. "Or maybe we could ask somebody to pirate a copy," he added.
But Mr. O'Connor was incredulous. "Whattaya, kidding?" he asked. "This is not Blockbuster Video. We don't lend these things out. This is our secret weapon. This is war!"

HEADLINE: Trade Secrets;
The Private Life of Club Chairs

BYLINE: By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THINK of what Freud could have done with a leather club chair instead of a couch. People might have discovered they liked themselves. Had a drink or read a book instead of regressing. Sunk into something other than despair.
Because a leather club chair is like a memory -- a supple, not a suppressed one. It remembers everyone who's ever sat in it, in the lines of its face, the oils of its skin. No father figure like the sofa, the leather club chair is more like an uncle. Happy, a little worse for wear. The one who stays with you a lot. The kids love him. 
 So buying a leather club chair is more of a family matter. You are, if expensively, adopting it. And it is adopting you.
But like mixing friendship and money, it's not that simple. It may look all shrugs, like your first baseball glove, but a leather club chair is an adult luxury. Prices easily hit $2,000. Consumers seem increasingly game, and stores are obliging, with new models appearing in many collections.
"Leather is hot right now," said Kimberly Pfaff, the editor of High Points, a furniture trade magazine.
Mitchell Gold, whose company sold more than 5,000 leather club chairs over the last holiday season, said, "It's become one of the few impulse buys in the industry." The comfortable club chair has provided a sexier lounge-culture alternative to the lounger, especially for baby boomers who are aging but refuse to let recliners into the house.
The House & Home Section asked Tim Gleason, a decorative arts dealer and curator who is also a furniture maker and leather craftsman, to accompany us to a dozen stores in New York City that stock leather club chairs and to help get a good handle on the issues involved in buying one.
Mr. Gleason has 10 years' experience repairing and restoring furniture, especially Gustav Stickley pieces, many with leather upholstery; he also put in a brief stint at Hermes in New York.
What, in Mr. Gleason's opinion, should one look for? "The very first decision is esthetic -- what pulls you to the chair," he said. "A leather club chair should do a little more than just suit you -- it should be something you get a little excited about." And in fact at the end of the day's shopping, the most obvious lesson was this: Despite the leather club chair's familiarity in the mind, none of those seen were the same.
"Then the comfort," Mr. Gleason continued. "Those are the two most important things: does it look good and does it feel good?" Spend quality time with it, he advised, "because it's going to be around for a long time."
"The first thing you do when you get into a leather club chair -- you sit down and grab the arms, to feel the leather." he said. "Is there a nice spring and softness to it?"
Enjoy the touch of the skin. Then get under it. Mr. Gleason's quick all-points, primary-attack plan was illustrated in our first encounter at Portico Bed and Bath on Spring Street. After a leisurely professional sit, he got up and flipped the club chair over like a martial artist.
"From the bottom, you can see whether there are springs involved," Mr. Gleason said from underneath.
Ideally, a club chair's body will have some kind of padded spring construction, typically in the seat, more rarely in the back and arms. Traditional springs are upright coils, tied to provide a floating "ride" of independent but coordinated support. Horizontally spiraled coils that web the seat's frame, sometimes called sinuous or no-sag springs, are a newer, less expensive and less responsive alternative. The Portico club chair had sinuous springs.
Mr. Gleason righted the chair.
"The next thing is to pop the cushion up and see what's there," he said, reading a large white tag sewn to the seat that gives details of what the body and cushion are made of.
Body padding will usually be foam or a fiber fill. The best chairs employ horsehair or boar bristle, a stiffer, more durable batting. The seat cushion will be filled with foam, fiber, down or feathers.
The tags won't identify the frame's wood -- be sure to ask. The frame should be a hardwood, like ash or maple. With soft woods, joints will weaken quickly with use.
Mr. Gleason pushed on all crucial platforms of support -- the seat, the arms and the back -- to determine the construction. Typically for a midpriced chair, Portico's club chair had no springs in the back or arms. Also typical were the hardwood frame padded with foam wrapped in polyester fiber, and the foam seat cushion.
Because of its rounded, balloon-like shape, created largely with foam-padded framing, Mr. Gleason found it "fluffy," a comfortable but unsupportive sit. It is a style of seating preferred by some but a decision best made by the seat of your pants.
"I think a really good, comfortable chair that invites you to spend time in it is a combination of hard and soft," Mr. Gleason said.
Construction established, Mr. Gleason returned to the leather.
Depending on the hide's quality, processing and finishing, leather will have its original character -- or not. And it will be capable of aging -- or not. Regardless of grade or treatment, a chair's leather should be soft, silky and natural to the touch, with a good, clean leather smell.
Furniture sales tags will usually identify the upholstery as full-grain or top-grain leather. All upholstery leather is the top layer of a cowhide. Full-grain leather is the best quality. It is a skin used with its natural grain and it will display natural character in such things as pores and pocks, but not large imperfections like cattle brands. It is a connoisseur's leather. "The more they let you see, the better it is," Mr. Gleason said.
Next on the scale, top-grain leather is also the top of the hide, but not top of the line. Surface imperfections are corrected by sanding the hide and re-embossing a grain into it.
"When you think there's a beautiful grain pattern, 80 percent of the time it's been sanded and embossed to hide irregularities, so more of the hide can be used," Mr. Gleason said.
Industrial tanning methods that preserve and soften the hide -- now primarily the chromium salt process -- will produce a supple, durable leather from both grades. But be aware: The more perfect a leather looks, the more it may have been processed. Top-grain should be less expensive than full-grain leather, which is largely uncorrected.
Processing removes color, oils and moisture from the hide -- the leather's natural glow -- and these are replaced by dyeing and finishing. Some techniques encourage the look of age, some discourage it. This is where buyers' choices enter.
With each chair, Mr. Gleason employed two simple tests -- a pinch and a scratch -- to establish how each skin had been treated, and how it would show its wear.
Aniline dyeing creates uniform color through the hide. A small pinch of the skin won't produce a highlight that reads as a mark of age.
Modern club chair designs in solid colors, like Poltrona Frau's bright-red, Italian Art Deco-style Vanity Fair visited at its showroom on Wooster Street, benefit from this kind of insurance against time. Few love an old red chair.
But aniline dyeing seems less desirable for traditional brown-leather club chairs that may regret eternal youth: they will age like Dorian Gray, ever adolescent.
When age is a virtue, surface dyes help create it with a finish that will crease a lighter color. A pinch will prove this: the skin beneath will show white. Oil-treated hides, like the leather on the Biarritz chair at Wolfman, Gold and Good Company on Mercer Street, encourage this.
After the pinch test, Mr. Gleason lightly scratched each chair's leather with his finger, again demonstrating that the dye was on the surface. "You'll have a nice patina after a while, on the arms, the back," he said. "The oil will help it simulate an older chair more immediately."
Antiquing treatments are either machine-rubbed into the leather before upholstering or hand-rubbed into the chair afterward, which is preferable. In the William Alan club chair at ABC Carpet and Home, the chair's hand-rubbed antiquing looked integral to the piece, with the seams and piping a deeper shade.
The best leathers are vegetable-tanned in gentler oak-bark solutions then piece-rubbed with dye and oil. The result is a fine "hand," as leather workers like Mr. Gleason call it -- a touch that will develop character naturally with use over time. You'll also feel the rub in the price. Mr. Gleason found a good example in black leather at George Smith on Spring Street, at $5,130.
"It hasn't been embossed," Mr. Gleason said. "You're already seeing a natural cracking, which you wouldn't see with a chromium-tanned leather."
In some cases, design helped execute economy. Because large unblemished hides are relatively rare -- and correspondingly expensive -- leather piecework from less expensive hides cut costs in several chairs. The Pottery Barn Manhattan club chair and the Crate and Barrel Barclay club chair have backs made from three panels, rather than one.
Mr. Gleason advised considering preferences in style as decisions about comfort. Do you like the racing acceleration of a little club chair with a low rear, big fender arms and a throw-back tilt, like the small sporty chairs of the 1930's? Or do you like the lanky-legged tall parson's seat of the English club chair, with its confident spread-scroll arms?
The final decision will come down to the two of you. Measure your size against the chair, and measure the chair against your room. If you fall in love with your club chair it's not going to be living alone.
 
AN EXPERT SHOPS
A Guide to New York's Club Scene
 
If you're buying a leather club chair in the midrange -- $1,500 to $2,000 -- expect trade-offs between fine leather quality and great construction. But most of the chairs Tim Gleason appraised nicely balanced the two. Below, a sampling from stores around Manhattan.

Giving a Vintage Club Chair a 100,000-Mile Checkup
 STORES like ABC Carpet and Home stock old club chairs, usually French from the 1920's, 30's and 40's. A chair's condition can add or subtract $1,000 on the sales tag. But a cheaper chair in worse condition is not a clever economy. It can't be re-upholstered -- the hide is the point. And the leather can't be repaired. Search for good examples.
"If the leather tears on an old chair, you've got a very expensive frame," said Tim Gleason, a furniture maker and leather craftsman. The frame is usually impossible to fix, as well: you would need to remove the leather to get to it.
Mr. Gleason recommended giving a chair a point-by-point physical exam. "Grab the arms to see if they wobble away from the seat," he said. "Shake the back, too, to make sure there are no broken boards."
Flex the springs in the arms, back and seat, then study the leather inch by inch. "Look everywhere there is flexing -- anywhere you have movement you have cracks with age," Mr. Gleason added. Deep cracks are unrepairable. Examine the seams, too: remember, leather weakens around repairs.
Flaking means the hide is sheepskin (right above). "There is a layer of fat between the top and bottom of sheepskin," Mr. Gleason explained. "When it dries, the top flakes off." What remains is trouble: a weak, suedelike skin. Seat cushions are sometimes antiqued replacements, which Mr. Gleason considers an acceptable fix. A pull at newly antiqued piping (right) will reveal whiter leather underneath. WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Salmon eaters salute a victory against the protectionists.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THANKS to hard-charging Chilean exporters, fresh salmon -- in particular, the bone-free fillets ready for the broiler -- has become a major bargain. Check that: much of the thanks must go to lobbies for wholesale fish distributors and restaurants here in America.
For at considerable cost they have beaten back efforts by the domestic salmon industry to use the nation's trade laws to bar the foreign competition. Indeed, optimists in the free-trade crowd see a glimmer of hope that consumers will more routinely benefit from organized resistance to laws designed for protectionists. "We may be witnessing the emergence of an anti-anti-dumping coalition," suggested Greg Rushford, editor of The Rushford Report, a Washngton-based newsletter. 
 With the world's supplies of "free range" salmon badly depleted by overfishing, large-scale commercial salmon farming in tidal pools has come of age. Salmon are raised in, among other places, Norway, Scotland and America. But Chile is the market leader owing to a combination of ideal water conditions, low-cost labor and entrepreneurs quick to incorporate both new technology and modern advertising. Chilean exports to the United States skyrocketed from nearly nothing in the late 1980's to 70 million pounds in 1996 -- almost half the market for farmed salmon.
Not surprisingly, prices have fallen sharply, which accounts for the presence of salmon fillets in more supermarkets and on far more menus in midpriced restaurants. And while the domestic salmon industry, based in Maine and Washington, has remained profitable, it would be more profitable without all that low-cost Chilean fish flooding the market. So last year a coalition of eight American salmon farmers with a total of 440 employees hired Michael Coursey, the Washington-based lawyer who succeeded in knocking Norwegian salmon out of the market in 1990 by charging the Norwegians with selling below cost.
In light of the dreary history of both subsidy and dumping -- or selling below cost -- cases over the last two decades, it seemed the Chileans and those who enjoy their fish didn't have a prayer. "The trade laws are written to protect domestic producers," reminds Robert Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution. "Consumers' interests don't figure in the equation."
In fact, those $5.95-a-pound supermarket specials on salmon fillets are likely to be around a while longer. The subsidy charge has effectively been rejected and the preliminary anti-dumping duties assessed by the Commerce Department average just 5 percent -- a far cry from the 42 percent asked by the plaintiffs, and not nearly enough to send the Chileans packing.
It's possible that the Commerce Department simply overcame its loathing for everything imported and judged the Chilean case on the merits. But if you believe that, you might want to invest in Princess Di commemorative ceramics before the factory runs out of clay.
A more plausible explanation is that importers fought back with weapons that work. Atlas Air Inc., a cargo shipper that handles millions of pounds of Chilean salmon, hired Bob Dole's lobbying firm to make the case for importing tasty fish at reasonable prices. An alliance of importers in South Florida commissioned an economic consulting firm that came up with the preposterous (but eye-catching) estimate that 19,000 American jobs -- including 3,600 in Florida -- depended on easy Chilean access to the salmon market. And the National Restaurant Association weighed in with a shove at Congress and the Clinton Administration.
In a better world, Mr. Litan argues, there would be virtually no laws specifically aimed at regulating imports. The consumer-oriented antitrust laws, which prohibit restraint of trade and outlaw sales below cost with the intent of bankrupting competitors, would apply to foreign companies the way they now apply to domestic ones.
But foreigners don't vote in Congressional elections, and their efforts to buy favor with campaign contributions the way their American counterparts do is widely seen as a no-no. By the same token, large American exporters, who after World War II stood as a bulwark against protectionism, have lost their enthusiasm for open trade now that they have lost their commanding lead in technology. Many -- including Kodak and Boeing -- play both sides of the protectionist fence. And not surprisingly, "the Commerce Department views corporations that compete with imports as its real constituency," argued Ronald Cass, dean of the Boston University School of Law.
Hence from Mr. Cass's perspective, the best hope for consumers is a convergence of interest with businesses that depend on imports. To date, very few companies, with the notable exception of Caterpillar Industries, which lobbies hard for access to imported steel, have put in the political effort. But the success of the Salmon Trade Alliance (http://www.salmontrade.com) may just prove to be catching.

HEADLINE: $1.4 Billion Boeing Charge to Force First Yearly Loss Since '47

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company, compounding one of its worst annual financial performances in 50 years, said yesterday that it would take a $1.4 billion pretax charge against its earnings for the fourth quarter of 1997 related to its merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.
The charge, which was widely expected, was slightly higher than what was anticipated by investors and analysts and will result in Boeing's first annual loss since 1947. 
 Combined with $2.6 billion in charges announced by the company in October, Boeing has effectively written off about half of its shareholder equity, or assets minus liabilities, in the last three months as it has struggled with production problems in the manufacture of its flagship commercial jets.
But investors and analysts were optimistic in the wake of yesterday's announcement, saying they thought that Boeing was on the mend and that management was putting the worst behind it so that the company could improve its performance this year.
Indeed, Philip Condit, Boeing's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement yesterday that the company's fourth-quarter operating results would be in line with Wall Streets earnings estimates when the company reports them next week.
"The attitude that is emerging is: 'We know you are going to have a sloppy quarter, so make it as sloppy as you can so '98 will look better,' " said Byron K. Callan, an aerospace industry analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.
On a day when many large companies saw their share prices fall, Boeing's stock rose 50 cents yesterday, to $44, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Still, Boeing stock is trading well below its 52-week high of $60.50, set last July, when the company was basking in the success of record orders for its passenger jets. That performance turned bittersweet in the fall when the company was forced to shut down its 747 and 737 lines for a month because it could not handle the steep increase in production.
Analysts lowered their earnings estimates in October after Boeing announced that the production problems would cost the company $2.6 billion through the end of 1998. Estimates fell further more recently as fears have grown that airlines in Asia, which are some of Boeing's biggest customers, will cancel orders because of the economic turmoil there.
After completing its purchase of McDonnell Douglas for more than $16 billion last August, Boeing announced in November that it would stop making that company's MD-80 and MD-90 passenger jets after next year. Yesterday's charge reflected the costs and loss of value related to closing down the two production lines. Included are financial obligations Boeing owes McDonnell Douglas customers because the residual value of existing models of the two planes will decline once they are no longer in production.
Boeing has said that it will continue to produce McDonnell's three-engine MD-11 jet, marketing it mostly as a cargo plane, and the new 100-seat MD-95 regional jet, which it recently renamed the Boeing 717.
After taxes, the $1.4 billion charge will equal about 91 cents a share. On an operating basis, Boeing is expected to earn 32 cents a share for the quarter and 69 cents a share for the year, according to the average estimate of analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc., which tracks corporate earnings projections.

HEADLINE: Abortion Rights, 25 Years Later

 BODY:
A quarter-century after the Supreme Court's decision in Roe v. Wade, the right of women to control their reproductive lives remains central to their ability to participate fully in America's economic, social and cultural life. Yet a woman's right to choose abortion before a fetus becomes viable remains as embattled as ever. The current campaign in Congress and within the Republican Party against so-called partial birth abortions, most of which occur before viability, is only the latest blow against abortion rights. The past 25 years of litigation, clinic bombings and political struggle have taken a grievous toll.
Abortion opponents have made significant strides since 1973. For millions of women, particularly those who are poor or young or live in rural areas, the right to choose is increasingly hollow. Only 17 states have Medicaid-type funding for poor women seeking abortions in cases other than rape or incest or when the life of the woman is endangered. The 1992 Supreme Court decision in Planned Parenthood v. Casey, while reaffirming the general right to abortion under Roe, diminished the right by opening the door to greater government intrusion before fetal viability. Since then, dozens of states have passed laws creating waiting periods, requiring parental consent or notification, and banning certain types of abortion procedures. 
 These restrictions, coupled with anti-abortion violence and fewer doctors being trained and willing to provide abortions, have reduced access to the procedure everywhere. There is no abortion provider in 84 percent of counties in the country. Between 1982 and 1992 the number of providers dropped in 45 states. North and South Dakota have only one abortion provider each. If these trends continue, legal, safe abortion will cease to be available in some parts of the country. The nation may be headed back to pre-Roe times, when abortion access differed from state to state.
Despite efforts to dismantle Roe, most Americans support legalized abortion. In a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll, 60 percent of respondents said they believed that the Roe decision establishing a constitutional right to obtain a legal abortion is a good thing. Fifty-nine percent said government should stay out of abortion decisions, and 76 percent oppose a constitutional amendment to make abortions illegal. But the anti-abortion advocates are making inroads. The poll found that only 15 percent support legal abortion in the second trimester, part of the period protected by Roe.
The wisdom of Roe is that it placed the abortion decision in the hands of women and their doctors before viability. That remains a principle around which most Americans can rally. The challenge now is to defend that principle as a new generation comes of age that is too young to remember a time when women died or were maimed as a result of illegal abortions.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Gain, With 30-Year Bond Set to Yield 5.81

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices gained yesterday after a slumping stock market helped erase early losses.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 14/32, to 104 14/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.81 percent, from 5.84 percent on Tuesday. 
 Bonds fell early in the session after a Commerce Department report showed an unexpected shrinking of the United States trade deficit. The November trade gap fell to $8.037 billion from October's revised $9.091 billion. Falling oil prices and weaker demand for petroleum held down imports, offsetting a drop in exports to Asia. The data raised concerns in the bond market that the gross domestic product report may show the economy grew 4 percent in the fourth quarter, a figure that some feel would prevent the Federal Reserve from easing interest rates anytime soon.
Another report yesterday, a regional survey by the Fed known as the beige book, had little impact on the market.
Jack Ablin, president of Barnett Capital Advisors Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla., said the strength in the government bond market could be traced to the Asian market weakness and the Fed, which has effectively written off inflation this year.
"The stock market should be doing better, Mr. Ablin said, "but every time the Asian stories begin to percolate, the stock market takes a hit and bonds rally. I think the stock market should be doing better and bonds should be lower than they are today."
While the Treasury market drew buyers as stocks slumped, bond prices came under pressure as some market participants sold to hedge large issues of corporate and municipal debt being priced. Securities firms involved in such debt offerings typically sell Treasury securities as a hedge until the deals are done.
In the municipal market, the New York State Dormitory Authority tentatively priced the largest municipal bond deal of the new year, $718.3 million of mortgage hospital revenue bonds for Presbyterian Hospital through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The deal is priced with a maximum yield of 5.17 percent for a bond due in 2032. The bonds are insured by the Federal Housing Administration and Ambac Indemnity for a triple-A rating by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's. Presbyterian Hospital is Columbia University's teaching hospital.
Israel priced $1.4 billion of zero- coupon bonds yesterday through Lehman Brothers, which had won the deal in competitive bidding the day before.
The bonds, which mature semi-annually from 2002 to 2027, were issued through the United States Agency for International Development. Sold at discount, the zero-coupon bonds make no scheduled interest rate payments but if held to maturity will pay investors the full face value.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chip Maker's Operating Net Is Up Sharply

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Texas Instruments reported a healthy jump in operating earnings today despite fading orders at the end of the year resulting from Asia's economic turmoil. And despite predicting a slow first quarter, the company issued a bright outlook for the year.
For the fourth quarter, Texas Instruments, based here, reported operating earnings of $219 million, or 55 cents a diluted share, from continuing businesses, up sharply from $95 million, or 25 cents a diluted share, a year earlier. Analysts had expected 59 cents a share, and shares of Texas Instruments initially fell on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 The company, however, told analysts in a conference call that its sales of digital signal processors would grow more than 30 percent this year, and the shares rebounded to close up $1.75, or 3.8 percent, at $48. Digital signal processors, which are found in cellular telephones, modems, disk drives and other digital products, have specialized capabilities useful for communications.
After a number of one-time charges, Texas Instruments reported a loss of $285 million, or 73 cents a diluted share, compared with a loss of $29 million, or 8 cents a diluted share, a year earlier. The charges included a $461 million write-off in the acquisition of Amati Communications. Amati's technology allows modems containing the sorts of chips Texas Instruments makes to speed the transmission of data.
Many analysts came around to the view that the company's transformation from a maker of commodity memory chips and other low-margin goods into a producer of digital signal processors and other more specialized chips is on course. "Their outlook was O.K.," said Caroline Gangi, an analyst with Lehman Brothers. "More and more of their products are proprietary."
The company's quarterly revenue fell to slightly more than $2.4 billion, reflecting the sale of software and laptop computer businesses.
For the global chip industry, Texas Instruments predicted sales growth of 10 percent this year, tepid but still hotter than last year's 5 percent. The slow growth has been a result in large part of low prices for memory chips.
Thomas P. Kurlak, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, foresees industrywide gloom. "The company and the industry are slowing down," he said. "I don't see any momentum." At Texas Instruments, he said, low memory chip prices would hurt more than growing digital signal processor demand would help.
While low memory chip prices continue to afflict the company, by last year, digital signal processors and related devices accounted for 45 percent of its semiconductor sales. William A. Aylesworth, the company's chief financial officer, said that Texas Instruments would outstrip this year's expected 30 percent global sales growth in digital signal processors.
Texas Instruments saw some customers cut back orders as Asia's economic crisis spread, causing the company to remain cautious over the near term. But for the year as a whole, the company remains sufficiently optimistic to invest $1.3 billion, up from $1.1 billion, in research and development.

HEADLINE: Sybase Loss to Grow as Sales Are Disputed

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Sybase Inc. said today that it had discovered inappropriate accounting for sales by its Japanese subsidiary, forcing the company to postpone release of its fourth-quarter financial results for one week, and to revise results for the quarter and year.
Sybase, a provider of data-base management software, said the people responsible had either resigned or been dismissed. 
 Earlier this month, Sybase had cautioned analysts that results would fall below expectations, and that it anticipated a small net loss, which it attributed to poor performance in the North American market and economic weakness in Asia. The revision means that Sybase will report a much larger loss for the fourth quarter.
Sybase estimated that the amount of the disputed sales was $60 million to $65 million, and said the recent disclosure would require a restatement for the first three quarters. Earlier, the company, which is based in Emeryville, Calif., had said it expected fourth-quarter revenues of $245 million to $250 million, with earnings per share ranging from a loss of 7 cents to a profit of 2 cents.
"You're talking about more than 5 percent of their revenues going away, and a higher percentage of license fees," said Curt A. Monash, publisher of the Monash Software Letter. "This is a significant, but not crippling, loss of revenues."
Sybase made its announcement after the stock market closed. Earlier, Sybase shares closed at $9.6875, up 25 cents, in Nasdaq trading.
The announcement from Sybase, the second-largest data-base management software company, comes at a period of weakness in the market, with the market-leading Oracle Corporation reporting weaker-than-expected earnings and the Informix Corporation, No. 3 in the market, also facing financial difficulties. But analysts said Sybase's problems appeared to be primarily of the company's own making, and called into question the viability of the company's two-year-old turnaround effort.
"I keep thinking they're out of the woods, but then there's another setback," said James M. Pickrel, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. "This coming out, at a time when they were already perceived as weak, is just another wound inflicted. The restatement will take them to a substantial loss for 1997, and with the weakness in Japan and Asia, you have a dampening of the outlook for 1998."
Mitchell Kertzman, Sybase's chairman and chief executive, said the company's auditor, Ernst & Young, had found that the Japanese subsidiary, Sybase K. K., had closed some major sales by providing so-called side letters, which offered customers the ability to return software. Such provisions were in clear violation of the company's accounting standards, and had been covered up by the people responsible, including the Sybase K.K. president, Mr. Kertzman said. Names were not disclosed.
"There is zero chance they thought this was O.K.," Mr. Kertzman said. Though some percentage of the $60 to $65 million may be valid sales, there is no way to quantify that at this time, he said. "I think they thought the product would not come back, but they knew it was a violation of revenue recognition standards." Compounding the fraud, he added, was the fact that the executives did not disclose the existence of the side letters until they were confronted.
In the past, both Informix and Oracle have had to restate revenues to reflect questionable sales, and Sybase has indulged in some aggressive practices itself. But Mr. Kertzman said his company has tried hard to maintain more conservative standards since he took over as chief executive in 1996. "It's an industry that has been run much more on testosterone than on common sense," he said. "The thing that hurts me is we've been trying to put a stop to that for the last couple of years."

HEADLINE: Eastern Europeans Keep Ex-U.S. Spies in the Cold

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Jan. 17

 BODY:
Mihaly Bencsik had been on the inside of the Soviet Union's Communist Party apparatus, and by the time he walked into an apartment building near an American military base in Munich in 1981, he was ready to tell what he knew.
Mr. Bencsik (pronounced BEN-chick), then a disaffected 41-year-old Hungarian who had worked in Moscow as a trusted translator, told his American questioner how the Soviets sapped his country's economy and where troops were based near his home in eastern Hungary. 
 When he returned home after five weeks of meetings with "John," whom he understood to be a NATO officer and who American officials say was probably a member of the United States Army 69th Intelligence Unit, then based in Munich, Mr. Bencsik was arrested. He was convicted of espionage and sentenced to six years in prison.
Now, with Hungary expected to join NATO next year, Mr. Bencsik, 60, a polite but broken man, still lives under a cloud, his legal appeals for rehabilitation and a decent pension denied.
There are others like him -- in Hungary, and in Poland, which is also in line to join NATO -- who gave the United States information in its fight against Communism but who now find themselves out in the cold.
Their predicament is an unfinished piece of business as nations that were enemies become friends, and a philosophical quandary.
Some have argued, one diplomat said, that it was "not right" that people who helped in the American quest to undermine Communism remain slighted -- unable to vote, prevented from easily getting a job -- in their home countries.
But others argue, he said, that many Western countries would be as unforgiving toward spies, no matter how minor-league, as the new democracies in Central Europe are being. (Mr. Bencsik said he received 1,000 German marks in 1981.)
The anti-Communist governments that came to power in 1990 saw themselves as patriots first, and refused to pardon these spies.
In 1992 the right-of-center Government in Hungary passed a law that annulled all "political" crimes committed in the Communist era. But this law, according to Ferenc Koszeg, the chairman of the Helsinki Watch committee and a member of Parliament since 1990, specifically did not cover espionage.
Mr. Koszeg said he argued for pardons. But most anti-Communist members of Parliament believed that spying against Hungary during Communism was spying against the nation no matter what.
In Poland, the newly elected Government passed a law in 1990 that granted amnesties to those who were still in prison for espionage when the Communists fell. But the law did not cover those freed before 1990 after serving sentences for espionage, said Andrzej Rzeplinski, a law professor at Warsaw University. These people are "free but generally they are not rehabilitated," and retain criminal records for 10 years, he added.
In Poland, it took pressure from Washington for the Government to finally pardon last year the spy Ryszard Kuklinski, a Polish colonel who fled to Washington in 1981 with information about the plans for martial law. Colonel Kuklinski, who has remained in the United States, has been denied restitution of his property, as have several Polish diplomats who stayed in the West during the cold war.
For the small-time spies in Hungary -- they include a onetime disillusioned conscript and a former clerk in the Interior Ministry -- the spectacle of Hungary's joining NATO is bittersweet. They are dismayed, they say, that they remain shunned for having helped their country's new friends.
"Outwardly the Government is so enthusiastic about joining NATO, but domestically it is not clearing cases like mine," Mr. Bencsik, an elementary school teacher by training, said as he thumbed through a raft of court documents. Adding to Mr. Bencsik's sense of injustice is the fact that the current Government is led by former Communists, the very people who were in authority when he was jailed.
Three years ago Mr. Bencsik applied to Hungary's highest court to annul his sentence. The court turned him down. There is no appeal and no provision for a presidential pardon.
When he was released from prison in 1986 after serving a shortened sentence, Mr. Bencsik found it difficult to get a job because he was denied a "moral certificate" that former prisoners need in Hungary for their rights to be restored.
Returning to teaching was out of the question. He was able to wangle a laboring job at a granary after the foreman cleared it with the police. He will be allowed to vote in parliamentary elections for the first time this year.
But what is most at stake for Mr. Bencsik, whose early faith in Communism, his impeccable Russian and then his marriage to a Russian gave him extra access in Moscow, is a full pension and his honor.
Because of his criminal record, Mr. Bencsik said, he receives a pension of $100 a month instead of $300.
As for his honor, Mr. Bencsik said that when he came back from his short visit to West Germany in 1981 (he went to settle a financial matter with an acquaintance who had emigrated), he visited the head of the domestic intelligence agency in Budapest.
He had known the spy chief during his stint in Moscow and told his friend what he had told NATO.
"I was so honest because I was so sure the Soviet system was crumbling," Mr. Bencsik said. "I felt I had told how Hungary was suppressed. There couldn't even be a small arrangement in the Soviet Hungarian Peace Committee without its being approved by Moscow. I thought I was uncovering an injustice."
Soon after speaking to the spy chief, Mr. Bencsik was arrested in Nyiregyhaza, in eastern Hungary, where he lives. He was placed for four months in a solitary cell that was lighted around the clock, interrogated and convicted.
Mr. Koszeg, a former dissident, says that as a member of Parliament and lawyer, he is the last one to condone spying.
But in this situation, he said, perhaps the United States should ask the Hungarian Government as it enters NATO, "How is it possible you punish people who worked for us, while those of you who are in charge now worked against us?"

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Initially Backs Fidelity Plan to Insure Money Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
The Securities and Exchange Commission has given preliminary approval to a plan allowing Fidelity Investments, the giant mutual fund company, to establish a mutual insurance company to guarantee its money market funds against some losses.
Fidelity's proposal calls for its money funds to share the cost of insuring against annual losses up to $100 million that are caused by a default by the issuer of a security that some or all of the funds own. 
 But the S.E.C.'s preliminary ruling places limits on how a mutual fund can publicize its insured status, partly because the insurance is unlikely to cover all of the fund's assets.
To set up the insurance company, the Fidelity funds need an exemption from certain sections of the Investment Company Act of 1940, the statute governing mutual funds. On Tuesday, the S.E.C. decided to give other fund companies and insurers until Feb. 16 to comment on the insurance plan. The agency released a copy of its order late yesterday.
After the comment period ends, the agency will render a final decision. An endorsement, which is not guaranteed and which depends in part on any comments the agency receives, usually follows preliminary approval.
A spokeswoman for Fidelity, which is part of the FMR Corporation, declined to comment on the S.E.C.'s action, saying the company had not yet received notification of a decision.
The Fidelity plan attracted great attention in the mutual fund industry in August 1996, when the Internal Revenue Service issued a tax ruling that made the insurance plan feasible. Since then, several established insurance companies said they would plan to begin selling similar coverage to other money market funds if the S.E.C. approved Fidelity's application.
Among those expected to enter the field is Marsh & McLennan, the parent of Putnam Investments, Fidelity's crosstown rival in Boston.
The attraction of such insurance is simple for money market funds: It would allow them to assure shareholders that their investments were at least partly protected against losses if the issuer of a security defaulted. As proposed by Fidelity, the insurance would not cover losses caused by changes in interest rates.
By setting up its own insurance company, Fidelity gains an advantage over fund companies that might go to outside insurers for coverage. Because Fidelity can spread the costs of the insurance over three dozen money market funds, the expense is less likely to cut into the return of any individual fund.
Even such a relatively tiny expense means a lot among money market funds. Their annual investor returns rarely differ by more than few tenths of a percentage point.
Fidelity's initial application calls for only its United States money market funds to take part in the insurance venture. But according to the proposal, other, non-money market funds might participate in the future to insure any money market assets they hold if their boards approve the move.
In addition, while the S.E.C.'s preliminary approval allows a "a brief description of the nature and extent of the insurance coverage" in a fund's prospectus, the approval states that a fund's insured status "will not be used in connection with the marketing or the sale of shares of the funds, and thus will not be discussed in any marketing or sales literature" distributed to prospective investors.
Money market insurance sounds appealing, but it is not necessarily a good deal for fund investors, industry analysts say. A fund's manager is never obligated to repurchase securities from a fund. But a fund company, by insuring itself against losses up to a certain dollar amount, could be signaling that it will not step in to bail out the fund from greater losses.
Several fund companies have completed such bailouts in recent years. When interest rates shot up in 1994, some aggressive money market funds were caught with derivatives that lost value as interest rates rose.
In most cases, the fund companies stepped in and bought back the troubled securities in order to keep each fund's net asset value from falling below the $1-a-share level, which all money market funds strive to maintain.
And last year, the manager of the Strong money market funds, based in Milwaukee, repurchased some securities issued by Mercury Finance, which was about to default.
In a speech to industry executives last May, Barry Barbash, the director of the S.E.C.'s division of investment management, which regulates mutual funds, chastised the executives on their willingness to bail money funds out of bad investments.
"What I find disconcerting about bailouts is that we and fund shareholders have come to expect them," Mr. Barbash said. That tendency, he said, created the perception among investors in the funds that was "inconsistent with their basic design as an investment with some risk."

HEADLINE: End Video Poker Gambling, South Carolina Chief Urges

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 21

 BODY:
To hear the Governor tell it, the very soul of South Carolina is at risk in a high-stakes game of video poker, which has resulted in everything from rampant gambling addiction to the death of a child.
The Governor, David M. Beasley, said a proliferation of video poker machines in restaurants, bars and truck stops has caused a collective misery, spawned a new generation of addicted gamblers and destroyed families. 
 He formally appealed to the South Carolina Legislature today to join his crusade to completely do away with the $2-billion-a-year business.
"Routinely, we are asked to decide between right and wrong," the Governor said in his State of the State address tonight. "This is such a time."
Video poker in South Carolina, largely unregulated and rife with abuses, contributes only a sliver of the state taxes -- about $62 million has been projected for this year -- that lawmakers and experts on the industry say it should.
But instead of pushing for tougher regulation and higher taxes -- as much as $250 million in a state budget that is now $5.4 billion -- Governor Beasley wants it banned.
In his address, mostly a glowing speech in which he spoke of South Carolina's solid economy and scenic beauty, he asked the Legislature first for a strong bill to curb sexual predators -- "rapists and pedophiles have no place in this society except behind lock and key" -- before calling for a ban on video poker in the next breath.
"There is another force that has free reign over our state, and it's not a force for good," he said.
Opponents of video poker say they are locked in a battle with the machines for the state's very soul.
"It's in the Bible that it's wrong," said the Rev. Harold Park, a retired Lutheran pastor in Chapin, S.C.
Mr. Beasley often tells the story of a 26-year-old woman whose baby died from dehydration in a sweltering car while she played video poker in Jasper County last summer. She played for seven hours without checking on the infant.
The woman, Sgt. Gail Baker of the Army, has been charged with homicide by child abuse, but her husband -- and the Governor -- said it was her addiction that killed the baby.
"I do not hold her responsible for that," her husband, Staff Sgt. Julius Baker of the Army, said in a recent appeal to the Legislature to ban video poker. "She has an addiction."
Tonight, before a joint session of the State House of Representatives and the State Senate, Governor Beasley shared other stories. He told of a 52-year-old woman in Newberry who wrote him saying that suicide was "the only escape from her mounting gambling debts -- she said she'd be dead today if her husband hadn't saved her from a drug overdose."
Four years ago, Gamblers Anonymous had eight chapters in South Carolina. By 1997, that number had grown to 27.
"It is an industry focused to prey on those least able to care for themselves, the addicted and the poor," said the Rev. L. Wayne Bryant, executive minister of the Christian Action Council, which has battled video poker for years.
In the gas stations and roadside arcades where people play the game, away from politics and religion, the issue is discussed much less dramatically.
"My stepfather used to gamble away his paycheck," said Jessica Williams, 21, who works at a Columbia gas station with five video poker machines along a back wall. There, a single player sat feeding $1 bills into a machine, losing, mostly.
"Me, I put a few dollars in, and if I don't win my money back I quit," said Ms. Williams. "It all depends on the person. But it is right there, convenient for you. If you do have an addiction, it's there for you."
It is the only legal gambling, outside bingo, that this Bible Belt state allows, a small-stakes exemption to community morals hidden discreetly -- at least in the past -- in the back rooms of service stations and country stores.
In 1980, when video poker machines first appeared, they were little more than an amusement for truckers. But it has grown so much that a hand of video blackjack is only a few minutes drive away from most South Carolinians. There are now all-night arcades featuring the glowing, slot machine-like poker dealers. Almost every convenience store seems to have one.
Fred Collins, 62, is the industry's strongest force in South Carolina. He pioneered the industry here, and has made millions from it. He owns one in seven video poker licenses, and has the most to lose.
"People don't want morals legislated to them," he said. He points to a 1994 vote in which 58 percent of the voters said they wanted video poker left alone.
Store owners say they would have to close without the money generated by video poker players, who are enticed into the stores by the machines and often spend money on other goods and services.
Some members of the Legislature -- where there seems to be no clear majority on the issue, one way or another -- say it would be more prudent to harness the tax windfall that a properly regulated and taxed industry could provide.
Owners of arcades and roadside casinos circumvent existing restrictions by almost comical means. State law forbids more than five machines in one room. Some store owners just partition off rooms and file for a separate business license.
Governor Beasley and others say the industry is too far gone to restructure.
To underscore the Governor's call for a ban on machines, his proposed budget does not even include money from video poker. "Don't regulate it," he told the legislators. "Don't tighten it. Ban it -- once and for all."
Opponents of the ban say the Governor, a 40-year-old Democrat-turned-Republican, is just trying to shore up support among religious leaders and appear to be a strong leader, an image that some political experts say was tarnished when he tried unsuccessfully more than a year ago to have the Confederate battle flag removed from the state Capitol, a move that split the state's Republicans.
The most powerful man in keeping the video machines is Mr. Collins, who convinced many in the Legislature to create the existing laws that allow the existence of video poker.
"They need to regulate the industry," and he has even called for higher taxes himself, he said. "But they'd rather attack something than go on and fix it."

HEADLINE: THE POPE IN CUBA: THE IMPLICATIONS;
Castro's Spin: Pope Is on Our Side

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Jan. 21

 BODY:
To the rest of the world, the arrival of Pope John Paul II here today seems a direct challenge to Fidel Castro and everything he stands for. Inside Cuba, however, Mr. Castro is using every means at his disposal to convince his 11 million people that he and the beleaguered Cuban revolution he has led for nearly 40 years will be the ultimate beneficiaries of the visit.
Cubans have been told, for instance, that the Pope will vigorously condemn the American economic embargo -- but not that he will also speak out in support of human rights. The walls of many Government offices have been decorated with posters showing Mr. Castro and the Pope posed together at their meeting in Rome in 1996, accompanied by statements stressing their convergence of views on issues like the foreign debt, hunger, poverty and the environment. 
 "Holy Father, we feel the same way you do about many important issues of today's world," the Cuban leader said in his welcoming remarks at Jose Marti Airport this afternoon. "Another country will not be found better disposed to understand your felicitous idea -- as we understand it and so similar to what we preach -- that the equitable distribution of wealth and solidarity among men and peoples should be globalized."
In recent remarks, Mr. Castro has also characterized the Pope's visit as a triumph over efforts to isolate the only Communist Government in the Western Hemisphere and as a rare opportunity for Cuba to present itself in the best possible light to the international community.
"Billions of people around the world are going to be watching images of Cuba these days and reading news about Cuba," he told Cubans last weekend. "Nobody can change what is seen."
Conversely, Mr. Castro has argued that John Paul's visit constitutes a defeat for the United States. In his declarations on television on Friday night, which were reprinted in their entirety on Tuesday in Granma, the newspaper of the Cuban Communist Party, he contrasted the independent behavior of the Pope with that of other world leaders who, he maintained, have bowed to American pressure not to come to Cuba.
"They would like to have prohibited the visit of the Pope if they could," he said of Washington. "Because this Pope, with the cold war finally over, aware of the disaster that capitalism and the problems of corruption, pillaging and economic chaos have provoked in all those countries, based on the realities he has observed since then, has focused his efforts in another direction."
Anticipating just such a diplomatic offensive, the Clinton Administration took the unusual step of sending Michael E. Ranneberger, the State Department's coordinator of Cuban affairs, here and making him available to reporters. Peppered with questions about the morality and efficiency of the 37-year-old American economic embargo at a news conference this morning, Mr. Ranneberger repeatedly described the measure as only one element of a broader policy intended to induce "fundamental, systemic, democratic change in Cuba" and minimized the Vatican's opposition to economic sanctions as a disagreement between friends about means, not ends.
As always, Mr. Castro's actions have also sown division among his enemies among Cuban exiles in the United States. Fierce opposition to the papal visit among some exile groups in Miami led to the cancellation, on the grounds that the Pope's presence here would only legitimize Mr. Castro's dictatorship, of plans to sail a cruise ship full of Cuban-American pilgrims here for the visit. A burst of infighting over the issue is still going on among exiles.
By encouraging Cubans to turn out to see the Pope, and even authorizing days off with pay so they can do so, Mr. Castro has done more than just give his blessing to the visit. He also has created a situation, diplomats here pointed out, that allows him to take the credit if there is a huge turnout on Sunday at the Mass the Pope will celebrate at the Plaza of the Revolution, where Mr. Castro has over the years delivered speeches to crowds of a million people.
"Of course I'm going to attend," Ileana Acosta del Valle, a middle-aged store clerk here, responded today when asked about her plans for Sunday. "If the comandante is going to be there, why can't I also?"
Mr. Castro has been so adept in his efforts to co-opt the visit that it now appears to most Cubans almost as if he is sponsoring it. At a news conference here on Monday, Jaime Cardinal Ortega, who served a term in a labor camp in the mid 1960's, took pains to subtly remind journalists that the Pope was coming to Cuba at the behest of the Cuban church, not the state.
"The Pope has longed for this visit to Cuba," Cardinal Ortega said, adding that "in the end, that is what constitutes the purpose of the papal visit: to satisfy the invitation of the Cuban bishops" and also to meet the faithful of the church here so that he might "personally, in a direct manner, visit, animate and comfort them in their faith."
Mr. Castro's effort to stress similarities between his beliefs and those of the Catholic Church is not new, of course. "There is a great concurrence between Christianity's objectives and those we seek as Communists," he said in 1971 to a Christian group in Chile, "between the Christian teachings of humility, austerity, selflessness and loving thy neighbor and what we might call the content of a revolutionary's life and behavior."
Church officials predicted that Mr. Castro's efforts to identify himself with the Pope and his values will fail. The scars left by three decades of atheism as a policy of state, they said, and the persecution of Catholic clergy and lay people that followed from it, will not permit such a thing, they said.
"Fidel said that the Holy Father is someone who cannot be manipulated, and Fidel is right, as he will soon discover," a Bishop from a Latin American country who is here for the visit said today, adding:
"John Paul is going to deliver a very strong message about human liberty in all of its manifestations, just as he did when he went to Pinochet's Chile, Nicaragua under the Sandinistas or Brazil when it was ruled by the generals."

HEADLINE: Business Coalition to Fight Legislation Protecting Patients' Rights

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Lobbyists for big business, small business and health insurance companies today unveiled a $1 million campaign to block bipartisan legislation intended to protect the rights of patients.
The lobbyists said such legislation, far from protecting patients, would increase the cost of health care and health insurance, so that many employers would cut back coverage. 
 President Clinton and lawmakers from both parties, led by Representative Charlie Norwood, Republican of Georgia, have been pushing a variety of proposals to help patients and regulate health plans, especially health maintenance organizations.
Many politicians contend that such legislation will prove irresistible in this election year. But a coalition of business groups said today that they would fight back, in an effort to kill any new Federal requirements that guarantee patients a choice of doctors or other rights.
The coalition includes the National Federation of Independent Business and the Health Insurance Association of America, which led efforts to kill Mr. Clinton's proposal for universal health insurance in 1994.
The new coalition also includes the United States Chamber of Commerce, the National Association of Manufacturers, the Business Roundtable, which represents 200 of the nation's largest companies, and the American Association of Health Plans, which represents H.M.O.'s.
In a report today, the Congressional Budget Office predicted a resurgence of health care inflation, even without new requirements. And it said that "laws to protect health consumers could raise private premiums" even more, presumably by giving patients freer access to medical specialists and costly types of care.
Jack Faris, chief executive of the National Federation of Independent Business, said the coalition would spend at least $1 million on advertising in newspapers and magazines. One advertisement shows the head of Frankenstein's monster and admonishes Congress: "Be careful how you play doctor. You might mandate a monster." The coalition has no immediate plans to resurrect "Harry and Louise," the yuppie couple who starred in television advertisements lampooning the Clinton health plan in 1994.
In a new survey of public opinion, researchers from the Kaiser Family Foundation and Harvard University found that substantial majorities of Americans favored the patients' "bill of rights" proposed by the President and members of Congress. But fewer people said they would support such legislation if it caused increases in insurance premiums or prompted some employers to drop coverage.
Legislative proposals to regulate managed care have divided Republicans. More than 90 House Republicans support Mr. Norwood's bill, but Republican leaders like Representative Dick Armey of Texas and Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi oppose it.
In the last four years, the Congressional Budget Office said, "health spending has stabilized at about 13.5 percent of gross domestic product," or economic output. But it predicted that "the growth in health spending will soon accelerate," so that "national health expenditures will reach 15.5 percent of G.D.P. by 2008."
Health insurance premiums rose an average of 3.8 percent last year, the budget office said. It predicted that premiums would rise 5.5 percent this year, with similar annual increases in the coming decade.
The Federal Government spends more than $300 billion a year on Medicare and Medicaid, which together finance health care for more than 70 million people.
