HEADLINE: Our Towns;
A Neighbor Just Says No To Casinos

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
THE beginning of the very long day she had been waiting for started out quite productively for Lillian Bryant.
First thing in the morning, she gave a tour of her neighborhood to one very interested guest, an assistant to the National Gambling Impact Study Commission. Then, while the state and local politicians were in Room 302 of the new convention center, telling the panel all the great things gambling had done for Atlantic City, Ms. Bryant was outside with 300 kindred spirits, marching and picketing and being interviewed as to why she thinks the casino situation has gone completely wrong. 
 By midmorning, Ms. Bryant had gone back to her tidy split-level house on Horace J. Bryant Jr. Drive to sit tight. There was nothing to do now until 7 P.M., when she would get to line up to make her plea for her neighborhood during the commission's long-awaited public session. She had reams of documents in imposing stacks that she could study. But she has spent more than two years, after all, making a case against the leveling of her house for a tunnel project. She could recite her arguments by heart. "I know what I'm going to say," she said, giggly with anticipation.
She is one of hundreds of people with agendas who signed up to speak to the commission, which is in town for two days on its first field trip to examine the social and economic impact of gambling on society. The anti-gambling and pro-gambling forces have been jockeying for position for weeks: compulsive gamblers and clergy and advocates for the homeless lining up to say that casinos are wrecking lives, and casino workers and elected officials and some business owners ready to call gambling Atlantic City's salvation.
BUT Ms. Bryant, a former Atlantic County Freeholder whose street is named after her father, the state's first black cabinet member as Banking and Insurance Commissioner, knows her case is special. She and two neighbors are fighting to keep their houses from being razed for a $330 million tunnel and road that Steve Wynn insisted the state build before he agreed to develop a casino in the city's Marina district. The city uses eminent domain to condemn other private properties for casino expansions, but none would demolish an intact, thriving neighborhood like Ms. Bryant's.
While owners of six of the nine houses that must be torn down for the tunnel have agreed to move, several have said they did so reluctantly. And whether the owners are willing or not, the tunnel project cuts to the heart of the debate over whether Atlantic City's casinos prosper at the expense of city neighborhoods.
Foes of the tunnel project call it a present to Mr. Wynn, since the state, which gave him the land to build his mega-casino, is assuming at least $220 million of the cost of the roadway to the new casino. On Tuesday, to Ms. Bryant's delight, Mr. Wynn gave foes some ammunition whenMirage Resorts Inc., his company, announced it was canceling a deal with two partners so that it could expand its own project. "The announcement doesn't surprise me," Ms. Bryant said. "But the timing of the announcement while the commission is here is the surprising part."
SHE was sure the move would help a Federal civil rights case she and two other homeowners have filed to stop the tunnel project. "At least I hope we get to trial," she said.
Members of the Impact Study Commission were already aware of Ms. Bryant's situation before they arrived here. In August, she and her neighbors went to Washington to testify at the commission's first public hearing. "We invited them to come to Atlantic City and see things for themselves," she said. "Now, they're here and they're supposed to be getting a tour of the city. Well, I called them up and offered them a tour of my neighborhood."
"I've had so many newspeople come here, and they all react the same way," Ms. Bryant said. "They can't believe the city and state would destroy this neighborhood." She was feeling chipper since Tim Bidwell, the assistant to the commission, had visited. "He told me that our neighborhood was better than the one he lives in in Washington," she said.
Last night, Ms. Bryant was No. 50 of 102 people scheduled to speak in front of the nine-member commission. In two hours, the commission heard from casino employees, compulsive gamblers and most vocally, trade union members with jobs to protect who brpought a cheering section of more than 50 supporters in orange T-shirts. People droned on and on, so the session was over after speaker No. 40. Ms. Bryant was forced to wait until another night to tell her story.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Rubin Defends Asian Bailout and Asks Funds for I.M.F.

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Saying that the United States "cannot afford to stand back and gamble that the crisis will resolve itself," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin defended the Clinton Administration's efforts today to calm Asia's financial turmoil and called on Congress to help by providing more money to the International Monetary Fund.
Faced with mounting criticism from both parties on Capitol Hill that the bailouts of Thailand, South Korea and Indonesia cost too much and yielded too little, Mr. Rubin said that restoring stability to Asia was a matter critical to the economic and national security of the United States. 
 Mr. Rubin sought to counter complaints from both Republicans and Democrats about the American role in the international rescue plans, including the criticism that the bailouts are insulating investors and international banks from the losses they suffer from misjudging the financial risks in the region.
"I would not give one nickel to help any creditor or investor, and in fact vast numbers of investors and creditors have taken large losses in Asia," Mr. Rubin said. He noted the huge declines in stock and currency markets there and the earnings problems that have already hit banking companies like J. P. Morgan, Chase Manhattan and Citicorp.
Those banks said this week that their profits in the fourth quarter had been reduced by the problems in Asia, though at Chase and Citicorp, at least, the problems were not severe enough to prevent earnings from increasing over all. Other banks, too, have sought to play down the effects of the crisis.
Mr. Rubin, in a speech at Georgetown University, said there was no practical way to insure that all investors and banks pay for their investment mistakes.
"A byproduct of programs designed to restore stability and growth may be that some creditors will be protected from the full consequences of their actions," Mr. Rubin said.
Mr. Rubin's speech was an effort by the Administration to explain its role in assembling promises of more than $100 billion in international financial assistance for Asian nations and to shore up political support in Congress. And it suggested the Administration's difficulties in assembling a bipartisan coalition on Capitol Hill that is supportive of maintaining support for an activist American role in managing the global economy, a problem shown most clearly late last year when Congress blocked President Clinton's request for a renewal of broad "fast track" trade negotiating authority.
The Administration has already asked Congress for $3.5 billion to bolster the I.M.F., and it will seek $14 billion this year as part of a broader plan to strengthen the I.M.F.
Some members of Congress have attacked Mr. Rubin for promising $1.7 billion to South Korea from a separate $40 billion pool of money known as the Exchange Stabilization Fund that can be used at the Administration's discretion. Republicans are considering legislation to limit the President's use of the fund.
Some conservative Republicans have been arguing against further funds for the I.M.F., saying the bailouts of South Korea, Thailand and Indonesia have done little to restore the region's economic health. They say that the best strategy is to let the financial markets sort out the winners and losers in the global economy.
For their part, liberal Democrats have criticized the Administration for not linking financial assistance to improving human rights and working conditions and to protecting the environment. They say that the rescue plans developed by the Administration and the I.M.F. either prop up repressive governments, as in Indonesia, or unfairly inflict economic pain on the ordinary citizens of nations like South Korea who bear no responsibility for the crisis.
To the conservative argument Mr. Rubin replied, "There is simply too much risk that markets alone will not resolve these problems of financial instability, and therefore given our stakes in Asia we must try to help get these countries back on track."
To the liberal critique Mr. Rubin responded that human rights, workplace issues and the environment, while important, should be not be thrown into the maelstrom of bringing an international financial crisis under control. "To add these three objectives, however important, would vastly complicate this effort and greatly reduce its chances of success," Mr. Rubin said.
If Congress were to deny the additional funding to the I.M.F., it could "reduce our leverage in the I.M.F., and could shake confidence in American leadership in the global economy at a time when confidence is so important in re-establishing stability in Asia," Mr. Rubin said.
Mr. Rubin also offered a defense of the I.M.F. itself, saying it is "the right institution to be at the center of these support programs."
Mr. Rubin said the Asian crisis had its roots in "close links between governments, banks and corporations" in the region that led to "fundamentally unsound investments by corporations funded by unsound lending from banks." Further fueling the problem, he said, were foreign investors, who "injected an extraordinary amount of capital into these flawed systems without due weighting to the risks involved."
But the heart of his argument was that while the effects of the crisis on the United States have been relatively limited so far, the financial instability could spread to other nations and eventually derail the long economic expansion and stock market boom enjoyed by Americans.
"When we act to resolve the Asian crisis, we act to protect and benefit the American people," he said.
Mr. Rubin said the world's other big economic powers also have a responsibility to help avert a global downturn. Europe, he said, could do more to strengthen its tentative economic recovery. And he said it was "absolutely critical" that Japan strengthen its banking system, spur domestic demand and further open its market to foreign goods.
"A weak Japan is a source of weakness for the region," he said. "A strong Japan would be a source of strength for the region."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Trade Deficit Narrowed In November in Surprise Drop

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit unexpectedly narrowed in November, though analysts said it was likely to be only a brief respite before the Asian economic crisis leads to larger deficits this year.
The trade deficit shrank to $8.037 billion in November from a revised $9.091 billion in October, as both exports and imports declined, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Many economists had expected the deficit to rise. 
 The deficits with China, Japan and most Pacific Rim countries also narrowed in November, countering expectations that currency devaluations in Asia would increase United States imports by reducing the cost of foreign-made goods.
Still, despite the declines in the deficits with Japan and China in November, the gaps with those countries over the first 11 months of last year were up 16.7 percent and 24 percent, respectively.
And today, the Japanese Government reported further indications of the trend toward a rising imbalance in trade between the United States and that country. Japan's merchandise trade surplus rose in December by 40.9 percent from a year earlier, and the surplus with the United States rose by 25.4 percent.
For all of 1997, Japan's overall trade surplus expanded by 48.5 percent, the first annual rise in five years, the Ministry of Finance reported.
In a separate report yesterday, the Federal Reserve said that economic ripples from the Asian turmoil were felt in most regions of the United States in recent weeks. "Manufacturers and agricultural firms report weaker exports to Asia, and there was some evidence of increased competition from Asian products in U.S. markets," the Fed said in its regional survey, known as the beige book.
That has helped keep inflation absent from the American economy, the Fed said, noting that "prices were generally flat" in the period covered by the survey.
Analysts said the narrowing of the United States trade gap could be accounted for in part by problems with the way the Commerce Department computes the figures.
"We have been arguing for some time that the Government's seasonal adjustment procedure for the fourth quarter produces a narrowing of the deficit," said Anne Mills, an economist at Lehman Brothers in New York. "Today's numbers are a reflection of the seasonal adjustment, not the underlying data."
Lee Price, Acting Under Secretary for Economic Affairs, acknowledged that there were problems with the adjustment process, but added that the pattern did not show up consistently in every trade category and that Government economists were reluctant to force a general adjustment on the numbers only to try to correct the trend.
The trade figures could give a lift to the fourth quarter's gross domestic product, which economists had been forecasting to grow at about a 3.5 percent annual rate.
Economists said that the trade numbers for January or February should better reflect the actual trade situation and begin to show the effects of the Asian crisis. "It's the calm before the storm," Ms. Mills said.
The trade deficit for all of 1997 is on target to total $111 billion, matching last year's total, which was the largest since a $115 billion deficit in 1988.
"There isn't any doubt in anyone's mind where the trend is going on trade," said James Glassman, chief domestic economist at Chase Securities in New York. "It would defy logic for it to go the other way."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Samsung Will Sell Property And End a Skyscraper Plan

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, Jan. 22

 BODY:
The Samsung Group will sell a $300 million portfolio of global properties, get an $80 million cash infusion from its chairman and scrap plans for a Seoul skyscraper under a restructuring that the Korean conglomerate said was aimed at improving competitiveness.
The restructuring disclosed on Wednesday makes Samsung, one of South Korea's largest employers and the world's leading maker of computer memory chips, the third big corporation here to announce an overhaul this week, in response to President-elect Kim Dae Jung's plea for meaningful changes in business practices that are widely blamed for the country's economic crisis. 
 Samsung's plan would refocus the company on three or four businesses including the Samsung Electronics Company, the semiconductor maker that is its most valuable asset. The plan also appeared to go further than others by including a contribution of personal wealth from Lee Kun Hee, the conglomerate's chairman.
But the plan failed to answer a basic question: Will Mr. Lee abandon his pet project, a $2.5 billion automobile factory that would add another competitor to the overcrowded global car market? Instead, Samsung said it had canceled a 102-story office project in Seoul and would sell branch-office buildings in New York, London and Singapore, which it valued in all around $300 million.
Samsung's silence on cars coincided with a second appeal from President-elect Kim to the conglomerates to make sacrifices. "Large conglomerates, for both themselves and the country, must launch speedy and strong reforms," he said through a spokesman, adding that such changes "shouldn't be superficial."
Samsung said Mr. Lee would sell personal property valued at 128 billion won, now nearly $75 million, to help strengthen the finances of some affiliates. He also plans to donate 90 percent of the roughly $6 million he makes annually for the four or five years the company estimates it will take for the economy to recover. And he will withdraw bank deposits and sell part of his stock portfolio to raise about $6 million for a fund to help Samsung workers dismissed in the corporate revamping.
The President-elect was said to be dismayed that the chairmen of Hyundai and LG, the two other conglomerates that announced restructuring proposals, had not committed some of their own money.
Mr. Kim has emphasized a need for business and the Government to share the burden of extricating South Korea from its financial mess. Ordinary workers, who had little to do with the profligate corporate borrowing that helped cause the economic turmoil, are most likely to suffer unemployment.
In an interview on Wednesday, Kim Won Gil, chief policy maker for Mr. Kim's National Congress for New Politics, said many of the conglomerates, known as chaebol, were trying to pass off as reforms policies they will be forced to adopt by law -- such as consolidating financial statements and eliminating the practice of group affiliates guaranteeing each other's debts.
"The owner of a business group putting his own money in to contribute is a sort of gesture that he cares, and that's fine," he said. "But most importantly, the owners of the chaebols must seriously adjust their businesses to make them globally competitive."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Trade Deficit Drops, But Asia Impact Widens
The Commerce Department said the trade deficit declined in November, defying expectations of an increase tied to Asian currency devaluations that have made Asian exports cheaper in the United States. But economists called the drop a brief respite and repeated predictions that the deficit will surge in coming months.
Other economic data showed the impact of Asia's economic crisis is spreading throughout this country. A Federal Reserve report on regional economic activity said Asia-bound exports of American manufacturers and agricultural concerns had fallen, and there is evidence of increased competition with Asian products in domestic markets. Page D8. 

Indonesia Currency Plunges 23%
The Indonesian rupiah plunged 23 percent against the dollar early today, showing a growing lack of faith in the country by investors and suggesting that a recovery will be more difficult than previously seen. D8.
 
Fidelity Insurance Plan Advances
The S.E.C. has given preliminary approval to a plan that would allow Fidelity Investments to establish a mutual insurance company to guarantee its money market funds against some losses. Such a plan could give the leading mutual fund company an advantage in selling such funds. But the S.E.C.'s decision limits how a fund's insured status can be publicized. D4.
 
Hurdles to Giant Drug Deal
One of the chief obstacles to a possible deal between American Home Products and SmithKline Beecham appears to be American Home's legal liabilities from its two diet drugs, Redux and Pondimin, analysts say. The shares of both companies retreated yesterday, a day after the two confirmed that they were considering a merger. D5.
 
First Boeing Loss in 50 Years
Boeing said the cost of absorbing McDonnell Douglas would result in a $1.4 billion pretax charge against fourth-quarter earnings, more than expected. Coupled with $2.6 billion in previously announced charges for production problems, the charges mean Boeing will report its first annual loss since 1947 when results are announced next week. D5.
 
Accounting Trouble at Sybase
Sybase, a provider of data base software, discovered accounting irregularities at its Japanese subsidiary, forcing the company to postpone release of its financial results and to revise earlier reports. D7.
 
Texas Instruments Sees Gains
Texas Instruments showed a big rise in quarterly operating earnings and forecast a bright outlook for the year. After a number of one-time charges, however, the company had a loss of $285 million for the quarter. D4.
 
Exxon Earnings Up Slightly
Exxon reported a slight improvement in earnings, helped by strong gains in refining that more than offset a big drop in crude petroleum prices. D2.

Procter & Gamble dismissed Wells BDDP Inc., delivering a damaging blow to an agency already in turmoil. Advertising. D9.

Earnings at American, Delta and US Airways beat expectations, helped in part by higher fares and lower fuel prices. D7.
 
Mixed Results for 2 Big Banks
Earnings rose at BankAmerica despite volatile conditions in Asia, but they fell at First Union, mainly because of costs tied to its acquisition of Signet Banking. D6.
 
Bulls, Bears and Pigskin
The biggest bearish threat on the horizon? Asia? A decline in corporate earnings? No, the Denver Broncos. If they beat the Green Bay Packers in the Super Bowl, the stock market will fall -- at least, that is, if the Super Bowl indicator, a time-tested but very unscientific predictor of market performance, holds true. SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 8; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1397 words

HEADLINE: AT THE MOVIES;
Looking Back At 2 Classics

BYLINE: By Bernard Weinraub 

DATELINE: PARK CITY, Utah, Jan. 22

 BODY:
By the time he was 30, Paul Schrader (left) had written the screenplay for "Taxi Driver," which was directed by Martin Scorsese and starred Robert De Niro. Four years later, the three men teamed up again for "Raging Bull," the 1979 classic that, like "Taxi Driver," was arguably one of the most significant films made since World War II.
Was it, perhaps, a burden to write two great screenplays at such an early age and have everything that follows compared with them? 
 "Actually, a huge burden fell off my shoulders," said the bespectacled, ebullient 51-year-old writer and director, whose newest film, "Affliction," opened the other night here at the Sundance Film Festival, the nation's premier showcase for independent films.
"Having done fairly early on work that I thought was valuable and I thought would endure was an enormous relief," he said. "I knew that I had done something in life. I know people my age who still have not had that sense of personal artistic reward. And it gets to be a hard and bitter thing in your 50's and 60's, never to have had this sense of 'I did something.' And I got that in my 20's. And I was free. And it was a kind of liberation."
It has not been a particularly easy festival for Mr. Schrader because his film -- despite the presence of actors like Nick Nolte, Sissy Spacek, James Coburn and Willem Dafoe -- has not found a distributor to release it. Based on a Russell Banks novel, the movie is a harsh and intense drama about the lone police officer in an economically depressed town in New Hampshire who is struggling with personal demons. "The material is strong." Mr. Schrader said. "It's a marketing challenge."
He shrugged. "It's not that I've changed; in some ways, I've basically made the same film," he said. "I've always been drawn to men adrift, people with souls but without lives, guys who say, 'I'll find a life,' 'I'll find a wife,' 'Something will come together for me.' In many ways I'm the defender of a dying breed, the existential hero."
What's changed, Mr. Schrader said, is the Hollywood system: "The studios don't make these films anymore. They're not in that business." And the fact that he doesn't live in Los Angeles but on Riverside Drive in Manhattan doesn't help.
"It's a problem," he said. "If you live in New York long enough -- and I've lived there 14 years -- an entire new generation of executives and hustlers have come upon the scene in L.A. whom you've never met. I don't know those people."
Mr. Schrader left Los Angeles because, he said, his life was out of control. "It was '81, '82," he said. "The drug scene was wide open. Everyone was convinced it wasn't going to hurt you. And with drugs, and cocaine in particular, you can go on for a number of years and be in control of the drugs. And anybody who tells you those first couple of years of cocaine aren't fun is lying. But then all of a sudden you wake up and you are no longer doing the drug. The drug is doing you. And you're not in control."
At the time, he said, his relationship with a woman had collapsed. "I was agonizing day and night," Mr. Schrader said. "And when these women problems hit me, the drugs stepped in and said, 'I'll take care of that.' I got frightened. I left L.A. to get straight and change my life."
Mr. Schrader is married to the actress Mary Beth Hurt, who is also in "Affliction." They have two children. His professional life, he said, is divided. On one hand, he has focused his energies on directing films, including "The Comfort of Strangers," "Light Sleeper' and "Patty Hearst." He made his directorial debut in 1978 with "Blue Collar," starring Richard Pryor and Harvey Keitel.
On the other hand, he is also a screenwriter for hire, a job that pays the bills.
"I don't make a living directing films like 'Affliction,' " he said. "I don't send my kids to private school in New York on those salaries. Fortunately, I'm still able to turn a dollar as a writer, I still come up with one big writing gig a year to cover my expenses." He has films in development for Barry Levinson, Mr. Scorsese, Penny Marshall and Sharon Stone, among others.
Mr. Schrader, whose deeply religious Dutch Calvinist background informs a great deal of his work, admits that, like most writers, he gets anxious every now and then about his creativity. "You get flat for a day or a week and suddenly you start thinking it's for the rest of your life," he said. "It does get anxious. And there's the fact that artists tend to have short creative lives."
"Most artists have seven hot years," he said. "And then there are seven shadow years of the hot years. And the rest of their lives are living off of that. Except for some. Some rare artists are able to reinvent themselves with second lives."
 
A Career Picks Up
The queen of last year's Sundance festival was the New York-based actress Parker Posey, who was in at least three films at the time. This year, Ms. Posey is in one, a poorly received comedy, "The Misadventures of Margaret."
To his amazement, the New York-based actor Sam Rockwell (below) has been called this year's Parker Posey. The cheerful and friendly 29-year-old actor, who is also based in New York, is in three films here -- "Jerry and Tom," a Quentin Tarantino-like violent comedy about some hit men, directed by the actor Saul Rubinek; a screwball comedy, "Safe Men," directed by John Hamburg, and a drama, "Lawn Dogs," directed by John Duigan.
Mr. Rockwell said that he had been startled by the comparison to Ms. Posey -- "Well, oh yeah, I guess that's flattering" -- but that it was purely accidental that he had three films at Sundance. "A fluke," he said, eating breakfast at a hotel here hours after his arrival. "I lucked out. Actually, I made 'Lawn Dogs' about three years ago."
He's hardly complaining. Having struggled in New York for several years -- for a while he was a bus boy -- Mr. Rockwell is now in a position to pick and choose his roles in independent films.
Hollywood studios have expressed interest in Mr. Rockwell, but he has not been selected for any choice roles.
He flew to the festival during a brief break in the Off Broadway play "Goose-Pimples," a dark comedy in which he is appearing. He said his career breakthrough took place last year at Sundance when he co-starred with John Turturro in the comedy "Box of Moonlight," directed by Tom DeCillo.
The film was not a box-office success, but Mr. Rockwell's portrait of a whimsical Peter Pan figure led to many offers from directors. "That film was definitely a turning point, and I was sort of put on some independent film map after 10 years in New York," he said.
Of his roles, Mr. Rockwell said, "I'm getting kind of the goofball misfit right now."
Mr. Rockwell's parents, now divorced, were aspiring actors. He spent most of his childhood with his father, a printer and union organizer, in the San Francisco area. While a senior in high school, Mr. Rockwell appeared in an independent film and shortly after that moved to New York to act.
Mr. Rockwell said that for a while, like many actors in New York, he tried to be ethnic. "I was obsessed with De Niro," he said. "I tried to emulate him. I thought I was Italian at one point. Yeah, I know, it's a stretch. Actually, I have a pretty muddish look. I can go Polish, I can go half-Jewish and half-Irish." His television roles have included a policeman as well as a killer on "Law and Order" and a crack addict on "N.Y.P.D. Blue."
A few years ago, he tried living in Los Angeles but returned to New York.
"Being single there and not working every day is hard in L.A., much harder than New York, where you can walk the streets and get on a subway and do something," he said. "Being an unemployed actor in L.A. is very strange. It can mess your mind."
Being unemployed is not in the cards now. He's no longer interested in the low-low-budget independent films -- "You know, bring your own coffee" -- and now looks for good scripts and even an amenity or two.
"When I did 'Lawn Dogs' and 'Jerry and Tom,' I had a trailer and a refrigerator and a stereo and I got a decent paycheck, and I thought, 'I'm happy, what more do I want?' " he said. "I can make a living now, which is great."
Mr. Rockwell said that at Sundance he hoped to go to a party or two. "I'm hoping to meet girls when I'm here," he said.
That shouldn't be a problem.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 33; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1054 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE REVIEW;
Greening a South Bronx Brownfield

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
The Getty Center is finished, the Guggenheim Bilbao branch is done, the competition to design the Museum of Modern Art's expansion has ended with the choice of a graceful plan. After this cluster of high-profile projects, architecture deserves a breather. Here's a breath of fresh air: Maya Lin's design for the Bronx Community Paper Company. A scale model and drawing for this thoughtful, idealistic design are now on view at the Urban Center in a crisply installed show presented by the Municipal Art Society.
Low-rise, low-down, planned for a gritty, out-of-the-way location, this project may never earn a stellar place on the international circuit of must-see contemporary architectural attractions. That's fine. Ms. Lin probably got stardom out her system by the time she was 21, when she designed the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington, still one of the most visited places of our time. And her new project grapples with a more substantial set of issues than landmarks usually address: urban infrastructure, community rebuilding, the survival of the planet -- that sort of thing. 
 This project is a model exercise in cleaning up the rust belt. It is designed for a 26-acre tract of the Harlem River Rail Yards, a triangular plot of land at the southern tip of the Bronx. The Triborough Bridge slices through the site, which was abandoned in 1971. Planners use the dismal term brownfield to describe this type of site: a former industrial area, often with polluted ground.
Two agencies have collaborated to create the paper mill: the Natural Resources Defense Council, a nationwide environmental advocacy organization, and the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association, a group that promotes economic development in the South Bronx. Trees and money. Green and green. Often, the two forces are depicted as adversaries. This project seeks to ally them.
The plant would recycle almost 300,000 tons of wastepaper annually, roughly a quarter of that generated by New York City, producing more than 200,000 tons of newsprint for the city's publishers. It would create at least 400 permanent jobs and yield about $30 million in annual tax revenue. Trees, featured prominently in the landscaping around the plant, are intended to symbolize the 3.4 million trees spared by the recycling. Plainly visible from cars passing over the bridge, the trees would also signal the sprouting of economic growth in a notoriously depressed part of town.
Sponsors of the $370 million project are negotiating with potential investors. They hope to break ground this fall and complete construction in 2000.
Ms. Lin's design is visually spare, conceptually rich. Housed in a complex of four aluminum-clad sheds, two or three stories high, the plant is split in two at the point where the bridge crosses overhead. One section contains equipment for de-inking and pulping waste paper. The other, connected by a metal bridge, houses the paper mill, along with storage for finished rolls of newsprint.
The fanciest bit of design work occurs at the plant entrance, where Ms. Lin creates a de Stijl-like composition from roof planes of different dimensions and heights. This contains the plant's offices. An outdoor stair of concrete, unsupported from beneath, leads to the entrance and, up another flight, to offices on the second floor. Facing the stair is a wall of cascading water, similar to the waterfall at the rear of Paley Park on East 53d Street in Manhattan but enclosed behind glass. A tall exhaust stack, rising beyond, is also encased by glass.
These elements are at once formal, functional and symbolic. Air heated in the glass stack powers the building's cooling system. Cool air drawn from the water wall circulates in the offices. The water itself, treated gray water from the Wards Island sewage plant, is used in the recycling. Energy is also saved by the use of skylights and louvered clerestories, which admit natural light and ventilation throughout.
Ms. Lin, who studied architecture at Yale, has worked here with a firm of project architects, HLW International. She describes herself as a designer or an artist rather than an architect. Many of her works fall into the category of public art. Her design projects, for example her interior of the Museum for African Art in SoHo, tend to fall outside stylistic genres. Deliberately or not, however, her Bronx design recalls the work of Charles and Ray Eames, designers whose work also straddled disciplines.
Asked to define the boundaries of design, Charles Eames replied, "What are the boundaries of problems?" In the famous Case Study House they designed for themselves in Pacific Palisades, Calif., in 1949, the Eameses faced the problem of building low-cost housing for the postwar suburb. Their solution was a classic modern machine in the garden, a steel frame, inserted with panels of glass and wood, set in towering eucalyptus. To the eye, the house offered a happy reconciliation of nature and technology, achieved at one-fifteenth the cost of a traditional masonry house.
Nearly 50 years later, Ms. Lin's clients face a different set of problems. Suburbanization has drained parts of the city of people, jobs and stability. The Machine -- industrial production -- has been exported overseas. Landfills are full. Clean water and air turn out not to be limitless. Nature can no longer be treated simply as scenery.
Solutions to these problems do not reside within the realm of visual imagination. Without her clients' experience in economic and environmentally sustainable growth, Ms. Lin would be hard put to solve them. She operates, rather, at the place where visual metaphor and material reality intersect.
Ms. Lin wants the building to send the message that the forest is now urban. It's the newspaper you are reading, and millions like it, there for the harvesting each day. The trees planted outside the mill would be reflected in its aluminum walls, and echoed by the rhythm of the steel columns inside. Naturally, a forest should have a waterfall. And if that lovely cloud happened to come from a smokestack, at least this green machine would make it easier to breathe.
Maya Lin's design for the Bronx Community Paper Company will remain on view at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, near 50th Street, through Feb. 6.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A computer rendering of Maya Lin's design for the Bronx Community Paper Company paper-recycling mill. (HLW International LLP/IO Media)

HEADLINE: Housing Tax Credits

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A Jan. 18 editorial in support of tax credits to build low-income housing perpetuates a myth. The original Section 8 effort never achieved its goal of adding thousands of affordable housing units and instead became a costly program. Considering today's construction costs, the Clinton Administration's belief that tax credits will add 36,000 rental units extends this economic myth.
What we really need is a comprehensive program for affordable housing, making units available for low-, moderate- and middle-income people. We must also ask how we can help the millions of Americans who are already poorly housed or homeless.
 
MAURICE PAPRIN
New York, Jan. 20, 1998
 
The writer is chairman of the Business, Labor and Community Coalition of New York.

HEADLINE: Singapore's Softer Model

 BODY:

To the Editor:
William Safire (column, Jan. 19) blames the East Asian financial crisis on the "Singapore model, taken up throughout Asia," of social order taking precedence over individual freedom.
Singapore's authoritarianism has always been far softer than, say, the Korea of the 1980 Kwangju massacre, or the Taiwan that slaughtered 10,000 dissidents in 1948. The (nuanced) difference is Singapore's failure to evolve toward the lively political competition we see today in the other two countries. 
 Similarly, Mr. Safire implies that Singapore chauvinists ascribe the country's spectacular economic success to "state-controlled commerce" and covert dealings among "power elites." Hardly! Singapore has a high degree of financial transparency and relatively little "crony capitalism."
As a result, Singapore's case of financial Asian flu is relatively mild, due mostly to the troubles of its trading partners.
 
BRUCE L. REYNOLDS
Schenectady, N.Y., Jan. 20, 1998
 
Director, East Asian Studies
Union College

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Fiat Chief Wants G.E. Officer as Successor

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Jan. 22

 BODY:
The chairman of Fiat S.p.A., Italy's largest corporation, said today that he would step down in June and would recommend that Paolo Fresco, a vice chairman of the General Electric Company, take his place.
The chairman, Cesare Romiti, who took over in 1996 from Giovanni Agnelli, the grandson of the founder of the giant auto group, said on Italian television that he would propose Mr. Fresco as his successor when the Fiat board meets on Jan. 30. 
 A spokesman for the GE International unit of General Electric in Fairfield, Conn., said that Mr. Fresco, who turns 65 in July, had made it clear in the past that he intended to stay on at the company until late 1998. "If they can live with that, then he is available and would be flattered to accept," the spokesman, Jay Pomeroy, said.
The announcement from Fiat, which is based in Turin, was cheered by investors. Shares of Fiat rose 370 lire, or 6.5 percent, to 6,050 lire. In New York, American depository receipts of Fiat rose $1.125, to $17. Each A.D.R. represents five shares of the Italian auto maker.
Speculation as to who would succeed Mr. Romiti, who reaches the company's mandatory retirement age of 75 in June, quickened in December after the death from cancer of Mr. Agnelli's nephew, Giovanni Alberto Agnelli. But the younger Mr. Agnelli, who was 33, held no senior management jobs at Fiat. And friends of Mr. Fresco said today that the Agnellis, Fiat's largest shareholders, had offered Mr. Fresco the job at least six months ago.
A major task of Mr. Fresco would be to "make the transition from a family-run company to one run by someone from outside," said Daniel T. Jones, professor of auto industry management at the University of Cardiff in Wales. He described Mr. Romiti as a "loyal internal servant."
Mr. Fresco, a native of the north of Italy and a lawyer by training, joined General Electric in 1962. In his most recent job at General Electric, Mr. Fresco has been the righthand man of the chairman and chief executive, John F. Welch Jr., in casting the company's strategy for global expansion. Overseas revenue now accounts for about 40 percent of G.E.'s total, the company spokesman said.
As chairman of Fiat, Mr. Fresco would be responsible for plotting long-term strategy and appointing management. Daily operations are the job of the group's chief executive, Paolo Cantarella, 53, the former head of the automobile division who engineered Fiat's remarkable comeback from the recession of 1993, when an aging model line and weak markets in its major businesses pushed the group deeply into the red.
As Fiat chairman, Mr. Romiti has been one of the most prominent executives tarred by Italy's campaign against corruption. In 1997, he was convicted on charges of illegal payments to political parties for favors to Fiat and he was barred from holding corporate office in Italy. The sentence is not applicable pending an appeal. Earlier this month, he was ordered to stand trial again on similar charges. Fiat acknowledges that its officials paid bribes in the past, but it has always denied that Mr. Romiti was informed.
Though Fiat's core business is automobiles and commercial vehicles, the group's activities range from insurance and rail car manufacturing to publishing newspapers. Revenue in 1997 amounted to almost 90 trillion lire ($52 billion), and global auto sales totaled 2.7 million cars, making Fiat Europe's second-largest auto maker after Volkswagen.
The Agnelli family, which owns 33 percent of Fiat, effectively controls the group through a so-called syndicate pact with three other large shareholders -- Deutsche Bank of Germany, the Italian investment bank Mediobanca and Assicurazioni Generali, the insurance group. But the loose arrangement, common in Italian business, expires in 1999.
Mr. Jones of the University of Cardiff said Fiat's strategy of producing a world car, the Palio, was bearing rich fruit. In 1997, sales in Brazil, the launching pad for the Palio, totaled 508,000 cars, making Fiat the No. 1 manufacturer there, ahead of General Motors. Other world car plants are planned or under construction in places like India, Russia, South Africa and Turkey.
Fiat's main challenge in the medium term, Mr. Jones said, would be to "keep being nimble in its global strategy," notably in large but threatened Asian markets like China and India.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paolo Fresco, a G.E. vice chairman designated to head Fiat, is a native of the north of Italy. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Jack Lord, 77, Helped Direct And Starred In 'Hawaii Five-O'

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
Jack Lord, the deadpan star of "Hawaii Five-O" who made "Book him, Danno" a fixture of American slang, died Wednesday at his home in Honolulu.
He was 77 and died of congestive heart failure, said Carolyn Tanaka, a spokeswoman for Marie Lord, the actor's wife and only survivor. 
Playing the strait-laced, tight-lipped Detective Steve McGarrett, head of an elite state police investigative unit, Mr. Lord helped make "Hawaii Five-O" the longest running police drama in television history. It lasted 12 seasons on CBS, from 1968 to 1980, and was also seen in more than 80 other countries.
The phrase "Book him, Danno," used when the bad guy was captured, came from the name of Detective McGarrett's assistant, Detective Danny Williams, who was played until the show's penultimate season by James MacArthur.
Mr. Lord was not only the star; his contract gave him control over dramatic decisions on every episode, and it was he who insisted, against the network's wishes, that the show be shot entirely on location in Hawaii.
That decision enhanced not only the show's appeal, as viewers seemed as entranced by the idyllic island scenery as by the crime stories, but also the Hawaiian economy. The network's spending on the production and on staff members' living expenses was estimated at more than $100 million a year, and the show fostered what Hawaiian Government officials called significant increases in tourism.
"It was considered the ultimate travelogue for Hawaii," David F. Poltrack, executive vice president of research at CBS, said yesterday. "The ascent of Hawaii as a major tourist location coincided with the strong years of that program. It really hit a chord."
Mr. Lord helped shape the show with its creator and executive producer, the late Leonard Freeman. After Freeman's death in 1973, a succession of producers followed, but it was widely known that Mr. Lord controlled the show. He also directed several episodes.
"He was always a strict taskmaster, a perfectionist," said Kam Fong, an original cast member, who played Detective Chin Ho Kelly for 10 years. "When we were on the set, it was strictly business; he wouldn't stand for any horseplay. And he was not the sociable type. After work, he had nothing to do with us socially.
"But I learned quite a lot from him, and so did others," said Mr. Fong, who had acted on stage but never in films or television until "Hawaii Five-O." "We always had a lot of local actors on the show who were inexperienced, and he helped them a lot. He would yell at them, but always to help them learn."
Different biographies give varying birth dates for Mr. Lord, but Ms. Tanaka said the correct date was Dec. 30, 1920. He was born John Joseph Patrick Ryan, in Brooklyn, the son of a steamship company executive. As a youth, he served as a merchant marine officer, and pursued his first love, painting, while working on freighters around the world.
Returning to New York, he won a football scholarship to New York University, where he majored in fine arts.
Selling Cadillacs from a showroom at 57th and Broadway by day, Mr. Lord began studying acting with Sanford Meisner at the Neighborhood Playhouse by night. His first break was a role in the Ralph Bellamy television series "Man Against Crime," and he went on to play in numerous live television dramas in the early 1950's. He also appeared in four Broadway plays, including Elia Kazan's production of "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," in the role of Brick.
He later had roles in several movies, most notably "Dr. No," one of the early James Bond films.
Before "Hawaii Five-O," Mr. Lord won acclaim as the lead character, a rodeo rider, in "Stoney Burke," a 1962-63 series that lasted one season competing against "I Love Lucy" and "The Danny Thomas Show."
According to Mr. Fong and to other acquaintances quoted in Hawaiian newspaper accounts, Mr. Lord and his wife, a former fashion designer, were famously reclusive. In recent years, when Mr. Lord's health deteriorated, he was rarely seen.
The Lords, who moved to Hawaii from New York during the show's early seasons and never left, were married for more than 50 years, according to Ms. Tanaka, and had occupied themselves since 1980 with charitable work and relaxation.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jack Lord, left, and James MacArthur as the detectives Steve McGarrett and Danny Williams in "Hawaii Five-O," which ran for 12 seasons.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Town House Project Is Rising on Hudson Shore

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
The first town house project to be built along the resurgent Hudson River in a decade is rising at the water's edge in West New York, N.J.
K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, the largest home builder in New Jersey, has started construction on Jacob's Ferry, 258 two- and three-bedroom luxury town houses with garages, balconies and Manhattan views. It is the company's first development along the Hudson. 
 The town houses will rise on fallow industrial land at the water's edge in West New York, a Hudson County town of 39,000 atop the Palisade cliffs whose nearly one-mile-long waterfront, at the base of those cliffs, has sat idle since shipping and rail operations there ceased 25 years ago. Sale prices for the units are to start at $200,000 and go to $500,000 for homes directly on the water.
There will also be 33 more homes started later this year on land jutting out into the river. Those on the peninsula are expected to cost 30 to 70 percent more, said Robert D. Jackson, president of Hovnanian's metropolitan New York region.
Industry experts see the project as something of a barometer of demand for riverfront housing. In the two years since the real estate industry emerged from the recession, about 2,700 residences have been or are being built along the 18-mile shoreline once known as the Gold Coast, with most of them luxury rentals, according to RAD Consultants, a real estate services concern in Fairfield, N.J. Hundreds more are planned.
With Jacob's Ferry, which is across from midtown Manhattan at about 56th Street, the activity is slowly turning to condominiums, which dominated riverfront construction before the mid-1980's building boom deflated.
Other developers are expected to follow Hovnanian's lead. Among them is Applied Companies of Hoboken, N.J., which is reviving a 1,290-unit condo project in Jersey City and plans to start the initial phase this spring. Later this year, the company expects to add condominiums to a rental development under way in Hoboken. Together, they will produce about 298 condominiums.
Hovnanian also plans to start construction later this year on a second 154-unit town house project, to be called Bull's Ferry, on a site north of Jacob's Ferry, with 132 of the Bull's Ferry homes rising in neighboring Guttenberg in Hudson County.
James H. Robbins, managing director at RAD, said the rental vacancy rate was about 5 percent and rents have risen. His company put the average monthly rent for a two-bedroom apartment at $2,000, up from an average of $1,800 last year.
When the monthly cost of renting a unit is comparable to the cost of owning one, it starts to make sense for some people to buy, Mr. Robbins said. "The challenge has not been a lack of demand but a lack of financing" for the developers, he added.
With riverfront land a scarce commodity, the West New York site represents an opportunity, said Ara Hovnanian, president of K. Hovnanian Enterprises, which has been considering the waterfront market for 10 years. "There are not a lot of ownership opportunities now, the demand is huge and conditions that were great before are now superb."
The demand, Mr. Hovnanian said, is coming from professional couples working in northern New Jersey or Manhattan. He said he also expected to draw some people who are now living in Manhattan or elsewhere in New York City.
Hovnanian is tapping its own equity and bank credit to finance its riverfront projects, which are to rise on 20 acres. They will cost $100 million to build, including the price of the land, which has undergone an environmental cleanup.
Hovnanian bought the land from the Roseland Property Company of Roseland, N.J. It is part of a 98-acre tract, straddling West New York and Guttenberg, that Roseland purchased two years ago from Arthur E. Imperatore, who runs New York Waterway, the ferry service. The entire 98-acre tract, including land in both towns, is zoned to allow 4,360 housing units. Roseland has begun a 276-unit rental project on the part of the site that it has retained.
Mr. Imperatore, who still owns 150 adjacent acres in Weehawken, once envisioned building a Venetian-style city on the entire tract. While the Weehawken land became the base for his ferry service to Manhattan, which is being expanded, only a golf driving range took shape on the West New York portion.
For West New York, the projects "are not only the beginning of the renaissance of our waterfront but of the entire town," said Mayor Albio Sires. As one of the state's poorest and most densely populated municipalities, West New York needs the tax revenue, jobs and recreational space that waterfront development could bring. When completed, over the next decade, the waterfront developments are expected to generate $11 million to $12 million in taxes a year to the town, Mayor Sires said.
The brick and vinyl-sided town houses at Jacob's Ferry will have 1,200 to 2,333 square feet of living space. Those on the peninsula will be 3,800 to 4,200 square feet with lofts. All the units will be laid out over 10 acres interspersed with courtyards and open space, and nearly half will have clear river views, Mr. Hovnanian said.
Under a financial agreement with West New York, real estate taxes on the units will be kept lower than non-abated projects for the first six years, about $6,000 a year for the median-priced $300,000 home. Maintenance fees are expected to be no more than $200 a month.
Amenities will include two swimming pools, a clubhouse and a public riverfront walkway.
Mr. Hovnanian said sales were to start in the spring.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Oil Futures Plunge, Sending Stocks Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Two of three big American oil companies reporting quarterly earnings yesterday said their results were above expectations. But oil company stocks fell sharply as investors expected future results to suffer because of falling oil prices.
Chevron said its earnings roughly doubled, while Texaco's profit rose 22 percent. Amoco posted a 10 percent decline. But sales were lower at all three companies, causing concern that continued price softness would affect first-quarter earnings. 
 Crude oil futures plunged to their lowest prices in more than three years yesterday amid concern about sharply increased output from OPEC member countries, coupled with lighter demand from Asian nations because of economic turmoil.
On Wall Street, Amoco shares fell $2.4375, to $80.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Chevron shares fell $1.5625, to $75.4375, on the Big Board, while Texaco shares were down $1.125, to $52.875, also on the New York exchange.
Chevron, which is based in San Francisco, earned $929 million, or $1.41 a share on a diluted basis, in the fourth quarter, up from $464 million, or 71 cents a diluted share, a year earlier. Sales fell to $9.71 billion from $11.27 billion.
Texaco, which is based in White Plains, earned $623 million, or $1.12 a diluted share, in the fourth quarter, up from $509 million, or 93 cents a diluted share, a year earlier. Sales were $12.05 billion, a 6.4 percent decline from $12.87 billion a year earlier.
Amoco, which is based in Chicago, said net income fell to $789 million, or $1.62 a diluted share, in the fourth quarter, from $871 million, or $1.73 a diluted share, a year earlier.
Revenues fell 4 percent, to $9.69 billion from $10.12 billion.

LENGTH: 550 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Continues Its Retreat as Profit Hopes Grow Dimmer

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Another round of corporate earnings disappointments took its toll on stocks yesterday, dragging major indexes lower for a second consecutive day.
The latest quarterly earnings shortfalls -- from companies like Schlumberger, the oil driller; Sears, Roebuck, the retailer, and Altera and Sybase, both technology concerns -- heightened fears that the overriding trend for corporate profits in 1998 could be lower. 
 To be sure, a number of companies, including market bellwethers like Microsoft, have reported earnings that were higher than expected. But even the software giant warned that future results could be hurt by the economic turmoil in Asia.
And even some companies reporting favorable earnings have seen their stocks fall. Oil shares, for instance, were down sharply yesterday despite relatively strong earnings from Chevron and Texaco, and, the day before, from Exxon. The stocks were hit by concern over the falling price of crude oil, which dropped to the lowest price in more than three years yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 63.52 points, closing at 7,730.88. The Standard & Poor's 500 index slipped 7.74 points, to 963.04. The Nasdaq composite index fell 11.41 points, to 1,576.51.
The uncertainty about earnings reports has sent investors in search of places to limit their risk, rather than produce strong gains, said Thomas Galvin, chief equity strategist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
"There's no common theme that investors have uniformly grasped," Mr. Galvin said, adding that he believes that as prospects for revenue growth decline, more companies will seek to increase earnings by consolidating. And undervalued companies in sectors such as telecommunications, waste, water filtration, hotels and casinos, and utilities could be good candidates, he said.
But as investors search for opportunities, they will have to continue to sidestep unexpected pitfalls such as the Asian crisis.
And some investors said that the latest trouble to hit the Clinton Administration -- allegations that President Clinton had had an affair with a White House intern and then sought to cover it up -- contributed to the negative tone in the markets by creating more political uncertainty.
"It's another imponderable," Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed in Kansas City, Kan., said.
Investing in the stock market "is already difficult because of Asia, but you could see some negatives coming out of this that could impact the psychology of the market," he added.
Mr. Herrmann said he believed that bearish sentiment was fueled by investors' worries about the outcome of the investigation into whether Mr. Clinton obstructed justice. This may have contributed to the market's unenthusiastic response to those companies that managed to report on-target or better-than-expected earnings. "Very few stocks are making much progress on positive earnings surprises," he said.
Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Scudder Kemper Investments, said, "No one knows just what it means to the market," but added that the allegations were clearly on some investors minds. "I haven't had one question on Indonesia, Thailand or the Asian markets, but I've had about 100 on Bill Clinton and what it's going to mean to the market," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Currency Hits Record Low Vs. Dollar In Canada

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
A record number of American tourists are making overnight trips to Canada, and for good reason. The Canadian dollar has plunged 5 percent against the dollar since October and dropped to its lowest value ever yesterday, making trips north of the border much more affordable.
Despite intervention by the Bank of Canada to support the currency, the Canadian dollar fell to as low as 68.85 United States cents, or $1.4523 (Canadian) to the dollar. Its previous all-time low was 69.13 United States cents in February 1986. In late trading, the Canadian dollar rebounded a little, finishing at 69.22 United States cents, or $1.4445 (Canadian). 
 The swoon of the Canadian dollar comes despite a healthy Canadian economy, which is growing faster than the United States economy and has lower consumer inflation.
It reverses the business climate at the border from the beginning of the decade, when the Canadian currency reached a high of 89.26 United States cents and Canadians visited American shops and malls to buy brand names at bargain prices.
Now, said Mark Chandler, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company in Toronto, "Canadians taking a vacation are going to think twice about about going to Florida."
But some of the forces pushing the Canadian dollar lower are products of strong growth with low inflation.
Rising consumer spending means that Canadians have picked up their buying of imports. At the same time, the values of key Canadian commodity exports -- forest products, precious metals and energy -- have declined sharply because of a general fall in commodity prices accelerated by the economic collapse in Asia, where demand for such goods has plummeted.
Together, these trends have helped turn a $3.6 billion current account surplus for 1996 to a $25.6 billion deficit, at an annual rate, in the third quarter of 1997. This swift move to a deficit weakens the currency by sending too many Canadian dollars out of the country, which are, in turn, sold by the foreign companies that receive them for their home currencies.
"Until we get a better trade number, we will not see a definitive turnaround" for the Canadian dollar, Mr. Chandler said.
Asia has also contributed to the more immediate downward pressure on the Canadian dollar. Currency traders had been expecting the Canadian economy to grow at a similar pace this year, which meant that the Bank of Canada, the nation's central bank, would be likely to raise interest rates to slow growth and restrain inflation. The higher interest rates would attract more foreign investors to Canadian securities, making them buy Canadian dollars.
But the drag on growth now expected from Asia may slow the economy enough so that the central bank can stand pat or even reduce short-term interest rates.
Bernard Bonin, the deputy governor of the central bank, hinted at such an outcome in a speech on Wednesday that helped send the Canadian dollar down to just above its record low. This could leave Canadian short-term interest rates at their less attractive position of one percentage point below comparable United States rates.
The central bank's new leaning was given more emphasis yesterday when the Government reported that consumer inflation rose just seven-tenths of a percent in 1997, meaning inflation is not much of an immediate threat.

HEADLINE: Administration Proposes Moratorium on New Logging Roads

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration proposed a moratorium today on building new logging roads into millions of acres of national forest for the next year and a half, but it exempted large areas of Alaska and the Pacific Northwest from the moratorium.
Forest Service officials said the suspension would effectively preclude logging on about 33 million acres of roadless back country that is unprotected as wilderness, including about nine million acres where the agency had been likely to approve logging roads in the coming year. About 5 percent of the agency's timber sales in 1988 would have to be deferred, the officials said. 
 During the suspension of road building, the Forest Service said it would develop a new, permanent strategy governing the vast network of more than 400,000 miles of roads that crisscross the publicly owned forests, often fragmenting wildlife habitats, aggravating erosion and damaging streams.
This is certain to intensify the debate between conservationists and logging interests over the nation's long-term forest policy.
The Forest Service's new policy is intended to protect roadless areas from undue environmental damage, to maintain the logging roads that already exist and to close tens of thousands of miles of deteriorating roads that are no longer needed.
Such an approach, depending on how it is written, could fundamentally alter the economics and ecology of forest management, officials said.
"We intend to work with the American people, Congress and the scientific community to develop a science-based forest transportation system," said Mike Dombeck, chief of the Forest Service.
Both the proposed moratorium and the long-term plan are subject to public comment before they become final.
The immediate reaction to the Administration's plan, which had been expected, centered on the moratorium on road building.
The moratorium does not apply to forests in the Pacific Northwest that were covered by an earlier compromise governing logging in the habitat of the spotted owl, a threatened species. Nor does it apply to the Tongass National Forest in Alaska or to eight other, smaller forests where logging plans have been revised recently and are under appeal.
"Only Washington bureaucrats would develop a national policy to protect roadless areas that leaves out America's biggest and wildest national forest," said Matt Zencey, campaign manager of the Alaska Rainforest Campaign, which seeks more protection for the Tongass.
Senator Larry E. Craig, the Idaho Republican who is chairman of the Forests and Public Land Management Subcommittee of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, said the proposal would impose "horrendous economic costs" on people in his state, which has large areas of roadless national forest.
"You don't start a good-faith dialogue by first rolling a hand grenade under the door," Mr. Craig said.
Administration officials denied that the exemptions of a few forests were intended to satisfy Congressional critics, like the Alaskan delegation. Rather, they said, the recently written management plans for those forests are based on up-to-date science, and any additional protections for roadless areas there will be considered in the normal administrative appeals of those plans.

HEADLINE: THE POPE IN CUBA: IN THE COUNTRYSIDE;
Where's the Joy of Life? The Dirt Poor in Cuba Wonder

BYLINE: By MIRTA OJITO 

DATELINE: RANCHO VELOZ, Cuba, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Eight-year-old Yanela Nemer, who wants to be a ballerina, left her home before dawn today wearing her only pair of dressy shoes. The shoes, black patent with a bow, are reserved for special occasions like the trip to Santa Clara to see John Paul II today.
For everything else, from going to school to playing in the streets of this muddy speck of a town 55 miles north of Santa Clara in central Cuba, Yanela wears sneakers that were once navy blue. Now they are faded and stained, a result of too much wear and her mother's inability to find detergent. 
 "Detergent, real, real detergent, well I just can't remember how long it's been," said her mother, Elba Gonzalez, 36, who does remember the last time she ate steak. It was three years ago.
Ms. Gonzalez also knows, down to the last cent, how much she needs to buy all the things she cannot have: $2.85 for liquid soap, $2.30 for cooking oil and $10 to buy her daughter another pair of dressy shoes.
All these things are available in a store just a stone's throw from her spacious colonial home. Yet they are woefully out of reach because to buy them she needs dollars. And in the countryside of Cuba, in towns so remote that once the lights are out you cannot see your own hands, dollars are very hard to come by.
For people who live here and in the two other provinces where the Pope will hold Masses outside Havana, life is a grinding series of compromises, sacrifices and mind-bending transactions that leave many, like Ms. Gonzalez, with a permanent dull headache.
"We wake up in a bad mood and go to sleep in a bad mood," said Ms. Gonzalez, a mother of three who is married to a man who works selling fritters from a state-owned street car. She lives in the home of her father-in-law, a member of the Communist Party who defended Cuba during the Bay of Pigs invasion and against the rebels who sought to topple the Castro Government in the early years of the revolution.
"Sometimes," she said, "I wonder why I have this absence of joy, of happiness," adding as she pointed to her children's feet, "This is why." Her youngest son, Sandro, 7, has only one pair of shoes. Her daughter needs orthopedic shoes to correct a congenital malformation, but the family cannot afford them.
There are basically two ways to make a living here, as a campesino or in one of the few Government jobs available, selling bread in the store or teaching in the local schools. The campesinos work fields of their own or those owned by the Government, planting beans, rice, corn, sweet potato or sugar cane and tending cows and sheep.
Campesinos are thought to have a better life only because they have more access to food. And yet even they say that putting food on their tables every day is a constant struggle. Nature -- it rains too much or it does not rain at all -- and the almost total control the Government exerts over the land and the cattle conspire against them.
Antonio Veliz is 75 and goes to work every day on his finca, or farm, 49 acres he owns about an hour away from his home in Rancho Veloz. So calloused are his hands that his fingerprints have all but disappeared and his fingers are so cracked and mangled that it is difficult to shake hands with him.
He said the Government required that he dedicate about half of his land to sugar cane. He must prepare the fields, plant the cane, water it and fertilize it. When the cane is ready, the Government sends a brigade of men to cut it and haul it away. For his efforts, which take about a year, he was recently paid 266 pesos and 99 cents, about $12 at the current rate of exchange.
On the rest of the land Mr. Veliz can grow what he chooses and use it for his own consumption. Any products he has left over he can sell in a produce market, but he has to pay a tax to the Government. He has 20 cows, which he tends and milks every day. But he must sell the milk to the state, a liter daily per cow, at 36 cents per liter. If he is caught selling it to someone else, he can be fined, he said.
What bothers him the most, as a lifelong owner of land, is that he cannot kill his own cows, he said. If a cow dies or is killed by someone else, he must report it immediately to the Government. The cows are checked regularly by Government inspectors, who brand each of them with metal clips attached to the ears. The clips have numbers, which are recorded in government files.
Mr. Veliz can always raise and kill pigs, sheep and chickens. But that has become an expensive proposition. If he leaves them on his finca they will most likely be stolen by people even hungrier than he is. In the last years, he has lost 66 sheep, 36 turkeys and 12 pigs worth 50,000 pesos ($2,174).
Now he keeps his pigs in the homes of his children who have backyards. At night, though, they must take them inside and keep them in the bathroom for fear of theft. It takes about seven months of daily feedings and proper care to raise a pig succulent enough to eat.
"You see that there?" asked Mr. Veliz, pointing to a small, sickly looking pig his neighbor owns. "That is his only hope. But it will take a long time before he can put it on the table."
While the pigs fatten, most people survive on a diet of rice and beans, sweet potato and an occasional egg. Today, for a long day of work at his finca, Mr. Veliz packed a lunch of rice and black beans and two small sandwiches of green tomatoes.
The Cuban Government readily acknowledges that life here can be difficult. At a news conference in Havana this week, the Minister of the Economy, Jose Luis Rodriguez, said the difficulties should be attributed not only to the lack of dollars but also to the nature of life in the countryside. Historically, this has been especially difficult in Cuba.
"Lamentably, not all places have the same possibilities to attract tourism," Mr. Rodriguez said, adding that since the revolution the Government had invested heavily in the countryside to try to eradicate the abysmal differences between the provinces and the capital. "But like everything else, you have to give it time."
A study recently prepared by Cepal, an independent pan-American group that studies economies in Latin America, found that the provinces of Havana, Matanzas, Cienfuegos and Holguin had a "good" economic situation, while the provinces of Villa Clara, where this city is located, Sancti Spiritus, Ciego de Avila, Camaguey and Isla de la Juventud were in a "not so good situation." The rest of the provinces were in "adverse" situations.
But it is hard for the people of Rancho Veloz and a host of other small places bordering the north coast to imagine who can possibly be worse off than they are.
Madelyn Mazorra, a 26-year-old secretary, said it was impossible for her family to live off their salaries, totaling the equivalent of about $18 a month. To make ends meet, her mother, who works in a Government-owned bakery, must scurry around town on her day off buying items that she can later exchange for food. Because her mother does not smoke, once a week she exchanges two packs of cigarettes for six small fish in a fishing village about half an hour away.
Another woman, so thin that the joints in her arms were easily visible, said she made cheese at home (10 pesos per pound) from the milk produced by her husband's cows. She declined to give her name for fear of Government reprisal. Selling cheese to neighbors is a problem because doing so is a tip-off that the cows are producing more milk than the Government is aware of.
When she has enough pesos, she travels to a town where there is a money exchange and buys dollars. With the dollars she buys everything else her family needs, from toilet paper to deodorant.
It has been a while since she made a trip to the city. In her house there was no toilet paper, shampoo or soap. She washed a cup in hot water to offer coffee to a visitor. The water comes from a tank she keeps in the kitchen because for the last two days no water has flowed from the faucets.
The Rev. Raul Rodriguez, the priest who serves Rancho Veloz and three other towns in this region, said most of the people he tended to were very poor. He helps them with money he receives from the church in Cuba and from friends who live abroad. Once a year he travels to the United States to strengthen the ties between Cuban exiles and his people, but also, he admits, to seek donations.
"The spiritual side is my mission," said Father Rodriguez, 34, who travels 24 miles daily to visit his dispersed flock and 24 miles back to his home in Quemado de Guines. "But I also have to worry about the daily realities of life."
These days, he said, he has been busier than ever, coordinating the needs of 800 people who were to travel from his towns to see the Pope in Santa Clara.
Understanding that many people will not have enough to eat, the Communist Party here served breakfast at 3 A.M. before the buses left. They charged one peso per person, less than 5 cents.
The priest was happy with the arrangement and so were children like Yanela Nemer. With the breakfast, the Government promised sweet snacks. And it had been a long time since Yanela and his mother had such a treat.

HEADLINE: Comptroller Forecasts 2d Big Surplus

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
For the second year in a row, city auditors are projecting that the city will end its fiscal year with more than a $1 billion surplus, a larger-than-expected windfall being generated by factors ranging from rising tax collections to a drop in the number of people on welfare.
But City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, whose office issued a report yesterday announcing the surplus, tempered some of the glee in City Hall by warning that much of the extra money should be set aside to offset the $2.5 billion annual shortfall his office is predicting for the city by the millennium, when revenues from Wall Street and tourism may be less robust. 
 Nevertheless, city officials said that the projection of a $1.1 billion surplus reflected the continued strength of Wall Street and a rise in the city's real estate market, both of which increase city tax revenues.
And it came as welcome news to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who often grappled with the most basic of budgetary problems -- expenses exceeding revenues -- in the early years of his first administration.
Joseph J. Lhota, the Mayor's Budget Director, said that Mr. Hevesi's projection was "in the ball park" of the administration's own estimates, and he cited the surplus as the payoff for the Mayor's fiscal discipline.
Mr. Lhota said that the Mayor would explain next week how he planned to use the extra money when he announced his preliminary budget for the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1.
According to the Comptroller's office, most of the money is coming from the collection of taxes, which are $767.3 million higher than the amount projected in the city budget that was adopted last June. Much of that increase comes from rising property tax revenues.
But other sources, including those that might not be immediately obvious, contributed to the surplus. Some 29,000 fewer people are collecting welfare payments than expected, saving the city about $20 million.
The city is selling bonds at interest rates that are the lowest in decades. It collected $10 million more than expected in rent from Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports, $3.5 million more in parking-violation fines and $3.7 million more from parking meters.
Offsetting some of the surplus were disappointing returns in other areas.
For example, the city collected $6.9 million less than expected in moving-violation fines.
Still, the overall picture pleased many officials, including Thomas L. McMahon, the City Council's finance director. "The Comptroller's estimate is in line with our projections and reflects the relative strength of the city economy," he said.
He added that Peter F. Vallone, the Council Speaker, indicated in his state-of-the-city speech earlier this month that the Council would seek to spend most of the surplus on education and tax reductions.
Last year, officials say, the city used its $1.4 billion surplus to pay off principal and interest on the city's debt and to offset some of the revenue lost from tax cuts.
It still managed to have some money left over for various spending programs.
But, as is his custom as the city's financial watchdog, Mr. Hevesi issued a reminder that "this revenue source is temporary" and that most budget analysts remained concerned about the effect that any slowdown on Wall Street might have on the city.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
December Housing Starts Fell, But Were Strong for Full Year

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
Housing starts fell in December, the Commerce Department said today, but not enough to prevent 1997 from being a strong year for builders.
Housing starts slipped eight-tenths of a percent in December, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.52 million. For the year, builders began construction on 1.48 million units, just 1,100 short of the 1996 total, which marked an eight-year high. 
 As 1997 began, most analysts were looking for a slowdown in housing. But unexpectedly vigorous job growth, reducing the unemployment rate to a 24-year low, along with stock market gains gave Americans the wherewithal to buy homes. And lower mortgage rates, made home-buying more affordable.
Mortgage rates edged below 7 percent as 1998 began. They hit a four-year low of 6.89 percent last week and ticked up to 6.99 percent this week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. That has caused a record number of mortgage applications, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said. Applications last week were 277 percent higher than the corresponding week a year ago. Refinancings accounted for 69 percent of the total.
"We're getting off to a running start, but you can't sustain this type of pace forever," said David Lereah, an economist at the association.
On average, analysts are looking for a 3 percent drop in starts, to 1.44 million, in 1998.
The Labor Department said yesterday that first-time claims for unemployment benefits fell by 13,000, to 326,000 last week. But that followed three consecutive increases. And a four-week moving average of claims, which smooths weekly fluctuations, moved up to 329,000, a six-month high. Analysts believe this hints at softness.
