HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Microsoft Compromises, Avoiding Punishment
Microsoft agreed to separate its Web browser software from its Windows 95 computer operating system in a last-minute deal with the Justice Department that partly settles its antitrust battle and avoids a possible contempt-of-court citation.
 With the compromise, Microsoft retreated from its insistence that the browser and Windows were inseparable. Page A1.
 
Lincoln-Mercury Heads West
Ford said it would move the headquarters of its Lincoln-Mercury division to Southern California, to help it better understand that trend-setting market. The move is the first time that a division of one of the Big Three has left the Detroit area. D3. 

Asia Is Kinder to Bankers Trust
Bankers Trust reported a 12.5 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings, confounding expectations that Asia's economic crisis had sharply weakened the bank's performance. Though it suffered some damage, Bankers Trust fared better in Asia than several of its competitors did. D2.
 
Late Card Payments Hurting Sears
Sears said that its earnings dropped in the fourth quarter, and it warned that first-quarter profit would decline substantially, because more customers are falling behind on credit card payments. D3.
Canadian Dollar at All-Time Low
The Canadian dollar plunged as low as 68.85 cents, its weakest exchange value ever against the United States dollar. D7.
 
Profit Worries Drive Stocks Down
Earnings disappointments from companies like Sears contributed to a decline in stock prices, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down 63.52 points, to 7,730.88. D7.
 
Among the biggest decliners were oil stocks, which fell despite strong earnings at Chevron and Texaco. The drop was caused by concern over oil prices, which hit their lowest level in more than three years. D7.
 
Boom Year for Housing
Housing starts slipped eight-tenths of 1 percent last month, but that was less than expected, and the residential construction industry still had a strong year over all. In another sign of a strong economy, initial claims for unemployment benefits fell. D8.
 
Court Victory for Baby Bells
A Federal appeals court ordered the F.C.C. to stop circumventing a ruling by the court that leaves pricing decisions on local phone service to the states. The court said the F.C.C. cannot look at a Bell's prices when reviewing its application to sell long-distance. D8.
 
When Research Turns to Rah-Rah
Analysts are supposed to provide investors with insights to help determine a company's prospects, good or bad. But when analysts begin talking to companies they cover about possibly going to work for them, the credibility of their "buy" recommendations may be open to question. Market Place. D8.
 
Fiat Chairman to Retire
Fiat's chairman, Cesare Romiti, said he would step down in June, and he recommended that Paolo Fresco, a vice chairman of General Electric, take his place. D4.
 
Limitation on Some Fund Managers
Mutual fund managers who leave a fund company to set up their own shop will not be allowed to advertise the performance of the fund they managed at their previous employer, even though that information might be allowed in the prospectus of the new fund, according to new N.A.S.D. guidelines. D5.
 
Labor Chief Seeks Ties in Mexico
John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., began a trip to Mexico that he said was aimed at encouraging Mexican and American unions to cooperate. A3.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
It Could Be Very Last Super Bowl

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
STOCK up on your munchies and your drinks and gape at the Super Bowl on Sunday. We're going to miss it when it's gone.
I hear the animals outside in the back 40, lowing and mooing and pawing at the ground. They can feel the seismic plates grinding together deep under their feet. 
 We are about to suffer the Big One, caused by the new television deal that doubled the income of the National Football League through 2005. If there is a 2005.
The whole thing is going to blow. Escalating greed is going to take it all down, the leagues and the networks and the millionaire players.
Superficially, it would seem that the new $17.6 billion contract among four major networks would loosen up enough money for every football player in the land to be able to afford his next round of steroids as well as a new coat for the missus. But sports economy does not work that way. Probably no economy works that way.
Back when I was growing up in the picturesque coal valleys of central Queens, we used to say that the miners spent every pay raise twice -- once when it was announced, once when it actually appeared in his paycheck. It's human nature.
As far as I can see, when CBS splurged to get back into the football business, it raised the ante for three other networks, which included very ordinary football players' getting unbelievable raises, and a rookie broadcaster like Boomer Esiason finding networks fighting over him. (And don't think that players in other sports are not watching this madness; Bernie Williams's demands upon the Yankees probably went up another million because of the excesses of that other sport.)
This apocalyptic spiral can only get worse. Teams will be spending money to keep even with the other teams, the way paranoid linemen gobble down their steroids -- not only because they want to give themselves ludicrous bodies and hideous medical futures, but also because they are immediately afraid of the wild-eyed maniac on the opposite side of the line.
Even though the N.F.L. shares the swag evenly, and has implemented a cap to try to keep salaries down, every team will try to maintain its financial edge by putting in new luxury boxes.
Actually, with the proliferation of television timeouts, it makes no sense to sit in the stands. I went to a football game this season, and it was pouring in San Francisco as the fans huddled while the networks hawked high-octane pickup trucks designed to kill people in smaller gas-saving four-cylinder compacts. It would have been far better to be partying it up in a luxury box, ingesting the shrimp and the sushi and hitting on the white wine in the three or four minutes between snaps of the ball.
With luxury boxes de rigueur these days, municipalities will be under greater pressure to raise taxes or run a referendum to keep the team from bolting. At the same time, the friendly folks from the networks are not just tossing away money because they love pro football. In fact, their sponsors are going to raise the price on tooth-rotting colas, the stomach-curdling fast food, the intoxicating beers and the lethal pickups.
Who is actually paying for the awesome price increase the networks have been tossing out? Up to now, you are, dummy. And like my old buddies in the coal mines in central Queens, you are paying twice -- once as a consumer via higher prices, once as a fan via higher ticket prices.
A few years ago I used to think that sport was going down because low-rent teams like the Pittsburgh Pirates or Edmonton Oilers or New Jersey Nets could not afford the cost of being dreadful. But I've changed my mind. I now think the fans are the weak link.
In Madison Square Garden, the fans are already looking sullen if not rebellious. Part of it is the uninspired hockey and basketball being committed there, but more to the point are the ghastly prices being charged by whoever owns the Garden these days. At contemporary ticket prices, you need a Mookie at-bat every night, you need a Stanley Cup every night, you need an immaculate reception every game, you need Master Jordan thwacking somebody every night.
I see what my friends and the readers are paying for their tickets. I don't think they are going to support the next wave of price increases that the CBS gold rush will create.
The plates are rubbing together under the ground. The end is coming. Repent while there is time. The best way to repent is to not renew your season tickets.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 400 words

HEADLINE: The Wrong Place for Queen Catherine

 BODY:
There is no comprehensive Who's Who of those involved in the trans-Atlantic slave trade. But even if one existed, it is highly unlikely that Queen Catherine of Braganza, a Portuguese noblewoman who became the wife of England's Charles II, would merit a separate entry. As far as historians can tell, she played no active role but was a member of two royal families that chartered and sought to profit from companies involved in the slave trade.
The historians' verdict should help the Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman, settle the dispute over a plan to erect a statue of Queen Catherine facing the United Nations from the Queens waterfront. Proponents, who spent 10 years raising more than $1 million for the project, believe Catherine deserves a statue because Queens is named for her, among other reasons. The opponents, a diverse group led by blacks in Queens, believe that she is disqualified by her association, however tangential, with slavery. 
 But all this squabbling overlooks a larger question. Why award a prominent spot on New York's waterfront to a large memorial, one-third the height of the Statue of Liberty, to a monarch who is really only a footnote in borough history and the history of this democracy? Catherine herself, though a figure of prominence in Portugal's struggle to remain independent of Spain, and a Catholic who championed the interests of English Catholics during a time of great religious strife, played no role in the settlement of Queens.
It may be perfectly appropriate to display Queen Catherine in another location, public or private, assuming that Ms. Shulman can resolve the slavery argument. But before a valuable piece of New York's skyline is turned over to Catherine or anyone else, city and state officials ought to form a committee of prominent historians and others to see who most deserves the space. Surely the city's rich cultural, social and economic history could turn up someone more worthy of the honor.
Besides, this property does not technically belong to Queens. It belongs to the Port Authority, which is yet another argument for a broad committee of experts who can cast a wide net for possible candidates. The whole question of commemorative statuary -- who goes where, and why -- deserves the same rigorous intellectual review that New Yorkers routinely apply to their great museums and other cultural institutions.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Indonesia Currency Falls Hard, Clouding Recovery

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Friday, Jan. 23

 BODY:
A week after Indonesia agreed to stringent new austerity measures that increased hope somewhat for Asian economic stability, this country's currency plummeted Thursday and again this morning, to new lows that roiled other Asian markets and threw into question the prospects for Indonesian recovery.
The fall beyond all expectations of the currency, the rupiah, over the last week -- to about 20 percent of its value six months ago -- raised fears that a $40 billion rescue package organized by the International Monetary Fund would be inadequate. It kindled worries, as well, that a crushing burden of foreign debt could slow the economy to a standstill. 
 The damage to the Indonesian economy has heightened political and social tensions here, two months before President Suharto is expected to be named to a seventh term after 32 years in power.
At one point here on Thursday, the rupiah fell to a rate of 16,500 to the dollar before the central bank intervened to sell dollars, and the Indonesian currency recovered much of the loss, finishing the day at 12,000, compared with 11,550 on Wednesday.
This morning, stocks rose somewhat here, gaining 1.2 percent. But the rupiah was substantially lower -- losing nearly 14 percent of its value, to trade at a rate of 13,900 to the dollar.
In stark contrast, the Indonesian currency sold for 5,400 to the dollar as recently as the end of last month and 2,500 to the dollar in July. The rupiah's value was so far from its recent moorings that a local businessman dubbed it a "virtual currency," its value just a mirage.
The plunge in the rupiah means that Indonesia's $65 billion in private, dollar-denominated debt has swelled to exchange levels that borrowers cannot afford to repay, with far more rupiah required to buy dollars than before.
That has raised the possibility of mass bankruptcies or a possible moratorium from creditors on Indonesian debt payment. Some analysts here estimate that all but 22 of the nation's 228 publicly traded companies have liabilities that exceed assets.
The banking system is virtually paralyzed, and almost no loans are being granted.
Mr. Suharto, in a meeting on Thursday with Deputy Foreign Minister Masahiko Komura of Japan, repeated his ministers' assertion that the Government would not bail out debt-burdened companies.
But financial analysts said any agreement to reschedule such debts would be far more complicated than it has been in South Korea, where most debts are owed by a relatively small number of big banks.
By contrast, they said, the debt here is scattered among hundreds of corporations and is hard to tally because of weak financial-reporting requirements.
In Washington on Thursday, Clinton Administration officials declined to comment on the Indonesian currency's slide. But in recent days they have kept up gentle public pressure on Mr. Suharto to follow through on his commitments to the I.M.F., with Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin saying on Wednesday that "continued and sustained adherence" to the I.M.F. program would be necessary to restore stability.
Political uncertainty is the second major problem in restoring confidence in this country's economy. The fall of the rupiah was spurred this week by hints from Mr. Suharto that he would name a longtime aide, B. J. Habibie, as his Vice President at the electoral assembly in March.
Mr. Habibie is widely distrusted by investors because of his unorthodox economic views and record of fostering expensive and unrealistic projects, including a home-grown aircraft-assembly project that has been shelved under the new I.M.F. austerity measures.
Mr. Suharto, 76, said on Tuesday that he would accept another term, virtually insuring his re-election despite growing discontent with his rule. Because of his age and his refusal to establish a clear succession process, investors are increasingly wary of placing bets on the future stability of Indonesia, the world's fourth-most-populous nation.
"With Habibie as a possible successor, it is difficult to have any credibility in the I.M.F. package," said Neil Saker, an analyst with Societe Generale Crosby Securities in Singapore. "He has his own projects that the I.M.F. is attacking. Basically, he has reversed the I.M.F. euphoria. At this point, there's no reason to think the rupiah will strengthen. The risks are all on the downside."
Such sentiments can be heard these days from virtually any financial analyst. Nevertheless, a senior I.M.F. official said on Thursday that investors were overreacting. Stanley Fischer, the lending agency's deputy managing director, said in Washington that the rupiah and other Asian currencies had fallen "far more than is warranted or desirable."
A Japanese vice trade minister, Osamu Watanabe, also struck a note of cautious optimism on Thursday, telling reporters in Tokyo that the rupiah could recover if Indonesia strictly adhered to the conditions imposed by the I.M.F.
The Indoesian currency had been relatively stable, until a sharp decline in the Thai currency that started in July set off a chain reaction of devaluations through much of Asia.
When Indonesia, at the start of the year, announced a budget based on an exchange rate of 4,000 rupiah to the dollar, its forecasts were seen as wildly unrealistic. But when the I.M.F. negotiated a new exchange-rate projection with the Government last week, that estimate was set at a level that now seems mournfully inadequate: 5,000 to the dollar.
The troubles here have become a major concern for other Asian countries, where trade and investments have been wounded by the Indonesian slump and fears have grown of wider economic contagion.
The plunge in the rupiah helped drag down stock markets around Asia on Thursday, in what financial analysts described as widespread anxiety over Indonesia's unchecked slide.
But the rupiah's depreciation has not been accompanied by the panic buying that gripped Indonesia early this month when the currency first fell below 10,000 to the dollar, even though commercial banks in Jakarta have reported long lines of customers seeking to withdraw their money.
Security was tight on Thursday as the Jakarta police began deploying 14,000 more officers around the capital in advance of Id al-Fitr, the holiday next week that ends the Muslim fasting month, Ramadan. Most of Indonesia's 200 million people are Muslims.
At the personal level, the worsening economy has begun to bite in increasingly harsh ways -- with rising prices and increasing job losses that raise the risk of social unrest. Prices for rice, a staple, have doubled or tripled in some places.
The twin problems of the debt crisis and of political uncertainty were not addressed in the I.M.F. austerity package, which Mr. Suharto signed under intense international pressure and which are certain to intensify unemployment, inflation and bankruptcies.
But economists agree that the strictures are essential to bring some order to Indonesia's economy, which has been skewed by cronyism, corruption and monopolies, and by price supports.

HEADLINE: AT&T Chief Said to Plan Big Job Cuts

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Union leaders and senior executives at the AT&T Corporation, the nation's largest telecommunications carrier, said yesterday that they expected the company to announce on Monday that it intended to cut its work force by about 15,000 employees, or roughly 12 percent.
The job cuts would be the biggest step yet by AT&T's new chairman, C. Michael Armstrong, as he tries to remake the company into a slim, fast-moving operator after decades of relative sluggishness. 
 Mr. Armstrong has made no secret of his contempt for AT&T's traditionally flabby management structure and has said that he wants the company, whose stock is the most widely owned in the country, to have the lowest costs in the highly competitive telecommunications arena.
The wide job cuts may be accompanied by a shake-up of senior management. Yesterday Jeffrey Weitzen, head of AT&T's unit that serves business customers, announced that he would leave the company after 18 years to become president of Gateway 2000 Inc., the personal computer maker.
AT&T's previous chairman, Robert E. Allen, had pointed to Mr. Weitzen and to his counterpart in the consumer unit, Gail McGovern, as paragons of AT&T's management vigor. But both executives had seen their responsibilities curtailed recently as control over AT&T's network was shifted away from them and toward a separate network group, according to people close to the changes.
Ms. McGovern, who has a strong background in marketing, has been rumored to be considering a position with Pepsico Inc. AT&T has denied those reports.
AT&T spends more of its revenues on administrative costs than do most of its competitors. The telecommunications industry, one of the nation's largest, is being rocked by regulatory changes and waves of corporate takeovers. Amid the turmoil, AT&T wants to be able to spend more money on growth opportunities while being able to match the prices of its leaner competitors.
It was unclear yesterday whether most of the cuts would come through attrition, voluntary buyouts or layoffs. It was also unclear how many of the cuts would be made in New Jersey, where AT&T has its headquarters in Basking Ridge.
AT&T declined to comment officially yesterday. But senior executives said on condition of anonymity that they expected the company to announce job cuts on Monday. That day AT&T also plans to release its latest financial results and to stage a big meeting in New York City between top management, including Mr. Armstrong, and Wall Street analysts.
A spokeswoman for the Communications Workers of America, the union that represents about 40 percent of AT&T's 128,000 employees, said the union believed that the company would eliminate about 15,000 jobs, mostly in management.
Mr. Armstrong has said that he wants to reduce the company's annual selling, general and administrative costs by $4 billion to $5 billion, or down to about 20 percent of annual revenues. In 1996, the last full year for which AT&T has announced financial results, the company spent $14.8 billion, or 28.3 percent, of its $52.2 billion in revenues on selling, general and administrative costs.
In 1996 MCI Communications, the No. 2 long-distance carrier after AT&T, spent 27.2 percent of its revenues on those costs while the next-largest long-distance companies, Sprint and Worldcom, spent 22.5 percent and 18.5 percent, respectively.
Mr. Armstrong may like to reduce AT&T's administrative spending to Worldcom's range, but few analysts believe such hopes are realistic. That is because Worldcom, which serves business customers almost exclusively, does not have to employ the large customer service staff required by a company like AT&T, which makes most of its sales to residential consumers.
But most analysts agree that Mr. Armstrong can squeeze some savings out of the company he joined last fall, and that some of the juice will come in the form of lost jobs.
"You can't cut those kinds of dollars without cutting jobs," said Frank Governali, a telecommunications analyst for Credit Suisse First Boston. "It's really, really simple. Here's a company that's the largest operator in the long-distance industry by a factor of two and it's an industry that has a high level of operating leverage -- in other words, economies of scale. It just does not make any sense that AT&T has the most expensive cost structure."
First Boston advised AT&T during its $11.3 billion acquisition of Teleport Communications Group Inc. earlier this month.
Financial analysts estimate that each AT&T employee costs the company about $90,000 a year, so eliminating 15,000 jobs could save about $1.4 billion a year after one-time charges to cover the costs of the cuts.
But Wall Street is bound to take any job elimination announcement from AT&T with a grain of skepticism.
In January 1996, AT&T announced that it would cut 40,000 jobs over the next three years. Seventeen thousand of those cuts were to come in what would remain AT&T while 23,000 were scheduled for the company's equipment operation, which was spun off as Lucent Technologies Inc. later that year.
But two years after that announcement AT&T today has roughly 1,000 more employees than it had when the cuts were announced. While the company did go through with many of the planned reductions, it hired even more people to bolster AT&T in new areas like wireless communications and the Internet.
As AT&T seeks to build on its Teleport acquisition and expand into the local telephone market, the company could feel a similar countervailing pressure this year as well.
But yesterday that did not dampen the spirits of investors, who seized on rumors of the looming job cuts with hope that some of the savings would be passed on to them. Matching their highest closing price in a year, AT&T's shares rose 50 cents, to $68.625 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Fraying Alliance: Iraq Sees Sanction Backers Divided

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 22

 BODY:
In an orchestrated series of steps during the last week, President Saddam Hussein has sent the world an unmistakable message: Seven years after the Persian Gulf war, Iraq is going to extricate itself from economic sanctions, with or without permission from the United Nations Security Council.
The signals from Iraqi officials here are very clear. The next two or three months will be the most critical tests of American, British and United Nations resolve that Iraq has posed since it was put under international supervision for bad behavior in August 1990 after it invaded Kuwait. 
 On Friday, Richard Butler, the executive chairman of the United Nations Special Commission, which has been working since 1991 to rid Iraq of weapons of mass destruction, is to report to the Security Council on his visit to Baghdad this week.
The news will not be good, especially for the Clinton Administration, now in the throes of its most damaging domestic crisis. The opportunity of the moment is not lost on the Iraqi leadership.
Mr. Butler came here with what he called "blindingly obvious" news for the Iraqis. The Security Council had instructed him to demand unconditional access to any place in this country that weapons inspectors wanted to go.
The demand was simply brushed aside by Iraq. Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz told Mr. Butler that Iraq would no longer be willing to deal with "cops." Instead, Mr. Aziz gave Mr. Butler a definitive list of eight areas that were off limits, some of them huge.
Moreover, President Hussein declared that Iraq was in a state of jihad -- holy war -- with the United States, and ordered military training for a million citizens.
Mr. Aziz told Mr. Butler that there should be no more talk of access to presidential properties or other sites that the Iraqis have labeled "sensitive" -- and no more requests to inspect them -- until after three newly designated teams of United Nations technical experts weighed the file on Iraqi compliance on missile warheads, chemical weapons and germ warfare.
Iraq already considers the nuclear file effectively closed. All four areas must be declared disarmed by Mr. Butler's commission before sanctions can be lifted.
The technical teams are to begin meeting here on Feb. 1. They are expected to report to Mr. Butler a month later. He in turn is to tell the Security Council by early April how far Iraq has come in meeting the disarmament requirements. At that point the Council will decide whether to continue sanctions for another six months.
The Iraqis hope that this path will lead to their release from an embargo that has hurt many people -- including the leadership, which cannot expect to go on building itself magnificent palaces without a renewed oil income. Millions of other Iraqis no longer care who benefits from a release from sanctions as long as they can again eat and buy their children clothes and medicine.
Iraqi officials seem to believe that the United States has never been in a weaker position in the Security Council. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has been less aggressive in her approaches to the Iraqi problem than she was as the chief American delegate to the United Nations, when she could talk down and even ridicule many of Baghdad's ploys.
The United States would have a far more difficult time winning support for military attacks on Iraq, many diplomats say. Washington is crippling the United Nations financially by not paying its dues, a measure of the low priority the Clinton Administration has put on the need for international support there, many United Nations officials and diplomats say.
At the same time, some countries have big financial and commercial interests in an unfettered Iraq, especially France and Russia. Other diplomats are also jostling for attention here now, perhaps sensing that sanctions may crack.
Diplomats here and at the United Nations trace the shift on Iraq's part to early last fall, when President Hussein tried again -- and failed again -- to declare unilaterally that Iraq was free of prohibited weapons. American attempts to add new sanctions also failed, however, and that seems to have been seen as a green light in Baghdad.
The crisis over Iraq's decision to bar American arms inspectors followed in October, costing the United Nations Special Commission three weeks of lost work.
Although Russia eventually persuaded Iraq to back down, the scene had been set for further confrontations. To this day, diplomats say, they are not sure what Russia promised the Iraqis in return, but high among Baghdad's demands was a proportional reduction in American inspectors -- and a reduced role for the commission headed by Mr. Butler, an outspoken Australian disarmament expert.
The Iraqis persuaded Secretary General Kofi Annan to send a team of troubleshooters not drawn from the Security Council or its creation, the Special Commission, to discuss last fall's inspection crisis. Now Iraq has broadened the panel of technical experts who will examine the files on its weapons programs.
Instead of expert teams chosen by the Special Commission, there will be panels including Iraqis, commission members and nominees of six countries: Britain, China, France, Germany, Russia and the United States. What to an outsider might seem an insignificant change is to Iraqis a fundamental shift in principle.
When Mr. Butler was asked at a news conference here on Wednesday whether Iraq's demand for a freeze on access to suspect sites put it in clear violation of the Security Council resolution -- which in this case can be enforced militarily -- he explained why he could not even comment.
"This is a tough political environment right now," he said, "and that's a decision the Security Council will have to make."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Software Industry Growth

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
The software industry in the New York metropolitan region expects to post strong revenues during the next few years, according to a study released this week by KPMG Peat Marwick, an accounting firm.
In a survey of about 200 software companies, respondents said they were expecting revenue growth of 40 percent this year and 61 percent over the next two to three years. 
 "These software companies derive 60 percent of their revenue from the export of products and services outside the region," said Len Sturm, a partner at KPMG. "Consequently, they are bringing revenue back into the area, and this strengthens the local economy and creates the need for highly skilled, high-paying jobs."
About half, 54 percent, of the survey's respondents said they also believe that being in New York City gives them an edge over their competitors, citing the proximity to customers and major markets and the availability of qualified technical personnel. NICK RAVO

HEADLINE: The Budget's Best Friend

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your excellent Jan. 19 news article discussing credit for balancing the budget omits a crucial factor: Social Security. Since 1983 the program has rung up substantial surpluses, in recent years from $50 billion to $70 billion. Without Social Security's excess of collections over payout, the budget would not balance. 
 This development results from 1983 legislation based on recommendations of the National Commission on Social Security Reform, for which I was a consultant. Because of these surpluses, the United States borrows less, driving down interest rates for both government and private business, thereby encouraging more private investment. That feeds economic growth, generating more incometax revenue and enhancing the budget surplus.
 
MERTON C. BERNSTEIN
St. Louis, Jan. 21, 1998

HEADLINE: Science Confronts The Unknowable;
Less Is Known Than People Think

BYLINE: By SARAH BOXER 

 BODY:
Many scientists are not fond of the idea that there are things in the universe beyond their grasp. They do not even like the word unknowable and prefer to use the term intractable instead. They consider the idea of unknowability an admission of defeat or an invitation for an attack on science.
Recently, though, some scientists have made unknowability their business. Last summer the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation gave some $1.5 million in grants to researchers in different fields -- economics, oceanography, historical linguistics, computer science, population genetics, cell biology, anthropology and the history of science -- to take stock of what is known, unknown and unknowable. 
 "We are all taught what is known, but we rarely learn about what is not known, and we almost never learn about the unknowable," Ralph E. Gomory, the president of the Sloan Foundation, wrote in Scientific American in 1995. "Because of such lessons, we grow up thinking more is known than actually is," and we do not recognize the unknowables for what they are. That is why the average gambler always loses out to the average casino owner. "The gambler attempts to predict the individual and unpredictable spins of the roulette wheel," Mr. Gomory wrote, while "the owner concerns himself with the quite predictable average outcome."
This is not the first time the depths of unknowability have been plumbed. As John D. Barrow, an astronomy professor at the University of Sussex, writes in "Impossibility: The Limits of Science and the Science of Limits" (Oxford, coming in April), Heisenberg's uncertainty principle showed that you cannot simultaneously know the position and momentum of a subatomic particle. Einstein's cosmic speed limit put a cap on the transmission of information in the universe. And Godel's theorem proved that any mathematical system that is powerful enough to be interesting will contain statements that cannot be proved true or false inside that system.
More recently, chaos theorists have looked at phenomena like dripping faucets and long-term weather patterns, and showed how tiny inevitable fluctuations in those chaotic systems quickly snowball in unpredictable ways. Complexity theorists have shown that complicated systems, like embryos and economies, add up to more than the sum of their parts.
Now unknowability itself seems to be coming of age, or at least coming into some money.
So what is an example of something unknowable? Take the diet of a given person living in a French village in the year 1300. "You may know on average what his diet was," said Jesse Ausubel, the program officer of the Sloan Foundation. "But you cannot say what he ate on Dec. 15, 1300." The same goes for future climates. You may be able to say what the average temperature of the earth's atmosphere will be in 2030, but you cannot know what it will be in New York City.
The study of unknowability in each discipline offers a glimpse of how different scientists approach the boundaries of their own fields. In anthropology, the limits to knowledge can be determined by practical barriers. If a group of people refuses to perform a ritual while an outsider is watching, that ritual is, in a sense, unknowable. In the history of science, knowledge about a certain problem can be limited by illegible handwriting or some other fluke. No one will ever know, for example, exactly how Fermat proved his last theorem (that xn + yn = zn has no solution in which n is a positive whole number greater than 2) because, by his own admission, the margin of his page was "too narrow to contain" the solution.
In ecology, unknowability is a problem of scale. If, for example, one wants to see the effect of environmental changes on a forest, one literally has a choice between looking at the forest and looking at the trees.
Simon Levin, a biologist at Princeton University who has received part of the Sloan's unknowability grant, said that in looking at the climate's effect on the forest, "not every detail of every tree is important." What the study of unknowability can help reveal is how much detail you can leave out about individual trees without compromising your knowledge of the whole forest. Or, say you are starting with a single tree. As Dr. Levin points out, each tree will react differently to environmental changes and to other trees, and that tree's reaction in turn will have an effect on the climate. So, how much can you extrapolate from that one tree about the whole forest?
When it comes to unknowability in historical linguistics, time is the enemy. To name the unknowable is to name a date beyond which the past is irretrievably lost. According to Colin Renfrew, an archeologist at Cambridge University who is another recipient of a Sloan grant, the first direct evidence of language is from around 3000 B.C. because that's when writing began, in the Near East. So if you want to see what language was like before then, you run up against the boundary of what is knowable.
By comparing contemporary Indo-European languages (including English, Spanish, French and German), linguists have reconstructed what they call proto-Indo-European, a precursor to all Indo-European languages, Dr. Renfrew said. That takes us back to 5,000 years ago.
But pushing back the date further requires help from other fields. For example, Dr. Renfrew said, we know that languages spread when populations shift. That means archeology should say something about language. And DNA studies tell us a great deal about how populations are related, going back some 30,000 years. The problem is, "it is difficult to correlate data from different fields," Dr. Renfrew said. "There is always the possibility of dubious interpretations," which gets more and more likely the further back in time you go. That's why most linguists accept that we can see back at least 5,000 years, but few think we can detect the echoes of a hypothetical first language some 80,000 years ago.
In population genetics, unknowability is a matter of complexity. Say you know everything about the genetic makeup of a morning glory and everything about the behavior or ethology of its prime pollinator, the bumblebee. How much could you predict about the flower's evolution?
According to Mike Klegg, a population geneticist at the University of California at Riverside who is part of Sloan's unknowability project, we know the enzymatic reactions, the metabolic pathways that lead to the production of color in a flower. We know somewhat less about the genes involved in regulating those pathways. On the other end, we know something about how the bumblebee reacts to different colors: for example, it avoids albino morning glories. If we were to take the whole system apart we could potentially understand all the components, Dr. Klegg said, "but will that give us a complete picture of the flower's evolutionary future?" Probably not.
Because many of the unknowables are on the boundaries of each scientific discipline, scientists' ideas about unknowability have a lot to do with how optimistic those scientists are about bridging the gaps between different fields, in other words, how they feel about what the biologist E. O. Wilson calls consilience, the unity of knowledge.
In the current issue of "The Wilson Quarterly," Dr. Wilson declared that science is an interlocking system of fields. One day science will not only be able to give a complete picture of the flower's evolutionary prospects but will also be able to do the vastly more complex task of joining physics, chemistry and biology to the social sciences and humanities in one vast, unified web of knowledge. Ultimately, he suggests, there will be no boundary areas, no unknowables, between fields.
Responding to Dr. Wilson, the philosopher Richard Rorty argued that such a unified web of knowledge is not only unlikely but undesirable. Every one "of the various academic disciplines does its respective job," and their "vocabularies are irreducible to one another." What's more, "there can and should be thousands of ways of describing things and people," and there will always be boundaries, unknowables, at the edges of each discipline.
Others are willing to acknowledge boundaries but not unknowables. Michael Dummett, a philosopher at Oxford, said: "I don't actually believe one can identify something as absolutely unknowable. If a question makes clear sense, there's a possibility for an answer one way or another." The best one can do, he suggests, is hedge. Rather than talk about unknowables, why not just talk about the things that probably won't ever be known? You know?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Examples of unknowability have come up before, with Heisenberg's uncertainty principle and Einstein's cosmic speed limit on the transmission of information. Now unknowability itself is the focus. This picture of Einstein was taken in Princeton in 1951. (UPI/Corbis-Bettmann)(pg. B7)

HEADLINE: Raytheon Plans Deep Job Cuts And Closing Of 20 Plants

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Raytheon Company said today that it would cut 10 percent of its military-related work force, or about 8,700 people, in an effort to consolidate its operations after the recent acquisitions of Hughes Aircraft and the military businesses of Texas Instruments.
The job cutbacks -- more than half of which will be in California -- come as aerospace employment has in general leveled off after the steep decline of the early 1990's that resulted from the sharp reduction in Pentagon spending since the end of the cold war. 
 Raytheon also said that its engineering and construction division would cut 1,000 jobs, or about 6 percent. That business has slowed, in part because the financial turmoil in Asia has led to delays or cancellations in projects to build factories or infrastructure.
The company, based in Lexington, Mass., is expected to announce a charge against earnings of several hundred million dollars before taxes in connection with the cutbacks when it announces its latest quarterly results on Monday.
In addition to the job cutbacks, the military unit will shut 20 plants and parts of 6 others, reducing its total space by 20 percent.
Howard A. Rubel, aerospace analyst for Goldman, Sachs, said the size of the job reductions "catches your eye, but unfortunately I think we've become used to it."
Shares of Raytheon's class B shares fell 87.5 cents, to $50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Raytheon completed the $9.5 billion acquisition of the defense division of Hughes Electronics, a subsidiary of General Motors, in December. Earlier in 1997 it purchased the defense operations of Texas Instruments for $2.95 billion.
The acquisitions made it one of the Big Three of the newly consolidated aerospace industry, behind Boeing and Lockheed Martin. The new Raytheon has revenues of about $20 billion on a pro-forma basis, with $14.5 billion of that in defense.
But the acquisitions have also raised Raytheon's debt by about $7 billion, to an estimated $10 billion. And it has created much duplication, particularly in missiles, where both Raytheon and Hughes were strong.
Raytheon now has 120,000 employees, with about 85,000 in defense. The cutbacks will be accomplished through layoffs beginning in February and attrition over two years.
"The actions we've taken today are really bold," William H. Swanson, the chairman and chief executive of Raytheon's defense business, told reporters, saying the moves would insure a healthier future. "If we've done it right we're preparing for growth, not contraction."
Over all, aerospace employment in the United States fell from more than 1.3 million in 1989 to fewer than 786,000 in 1995, according to the Aerospace Industries Association. But since then it has been growing a bit, though that is a result of strong demand for commercial aircraft, not weapons.
Raytheon's moves show the changing nature of the aerospace employment, from metal bending to more high-tech pursuits like electronics.
Most of the cutbacks will be in manufacturing or in administrative and support positions. But 2,700 engineers who will be freed from their existing jobs by the consolidation will be redeployed, and the company continues to recruit new technical employees.
"We are crying for software engineers," said Ken Dahlberg, president and chief operating officer of the Raytheon Systems Company, the defense unit.
The company's plan also reflects political considerations.
The company's home state of Massachusetts, for example, will see a reduction of only 300 administrative and general positions out of a total of more than 15,000 employees.
Raytheon spearheaded a drive that won state tax cuts for manufacturers in 1996. It would have created a political uproar had the company announced huge job reductions in Massachusetts only two years later.
The production of the Amraam -- standing for advanced medium-range air-to-air missile -- will be moved out of the Andover, Mass., factory and consolidated in a Tucson, Ariz., factory acquired with Hughes. But Andover will be left with the Patriot and Hawk missiles and will become one of two factories making circuit boards for the entire company.
California, meanwhile, where Hughes was based, will be hit the hardest, with 5,200 jobs lost, representing nearly one-third of Raytheon's employees here.
This will be a new blow to Southern California, where a decline in aerospace employment devastated the economy earlier this decade but where industry employment had leveled off in the last two years.
"We had taken one step forward and now we've taken three-quarters of a step back," said Jack Kyser, director of economic information for the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corporation. California has high costs but also has many engineers, some of whom might leave if asked to transfer elsewhere.
Raytheon said it would seek to concentrate manufacturing and design of key technologies. The two circuit board manufacturing plants, for example, will replace 19 locations making circuit boards for individual programs or units.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
Steep Fall in Dollar Pulls Down Treasury Security Prices

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
A plunging dollar pulled bond prices sharply lower yesterday, sending the yield on the 30-year bond back near 6 percent. The dollar fell 1.5 percent against the German mark and 1.3 percent against the Japanese yen.
Just two weeks ago, the expectation of slower growth in the United States, the turmoil in Asia, the flight of foreign investors to American markets and low inflation had all combined to push the yield on the 30-year bond down to 5.69 percent, the lowest since the bond was first regularly issued in 1977. Other long-term yields also dropped to near 30-year lows, with the dollar rallying at the time. 
 But while the outlook for Indonesia is still very chancy, the outlook for other parts of Asia has improved, taking some pressure off the Japanese yen. Some investors seem to be counting on the promises of Japanese officials to offer a new economic program in February that will help the country's weakened banks and the economy. In addition, the outlook for South Korea seems to be improving.
These promises, traders said, have helped pull the value of the dollar down 4.8 percent against the yen in the last two weeks. The dollar has also dropped 2.4 percent against the German mark. And that, in turn, has led foreigners to sell the American currency and American securities to lock in profits before the dollar falls further and reduces their gains when they are translated back into their home currencies.
Some traders have also said that the dollar's downturn has been accelerated by accusations that President Clinton had a sexual affair with a young White House aide.
"I'm sure it didn't help," said Karen E. Parker, currency strategist at Chase Manhattan Bank. Traders on the floor, she said, "are talking about it all the time, so it must be having some impact."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 114/32 , to 10212/32 , pushing up its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, to 5.96 percent -- a three-week high. On Thursday, the yield was 5.86 percent. The decline yesterday finished erasing all the gains made in the 1998 rally that peaked Jan. 12.
In late trading in New York, the dollar was at 1.7774 marks, down from 1.8045 marks Thursday, and 125.57 yen, down from 127.23.
The selloff of dollars and bonds may also reflect the fact that both markets had rallied so strongly in the first week and a half of the year. Often, such a strong rally is followed by a correction that can be set off by the smallest of excuses.
"People who were long the dollar were a bit too long," said Audrey McNiff, a vice president in foreign exchange sales at Goldman, Sachs & Company.
David Shabelman, Treasury market analyst for Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, said: "The U.S. Government securities market has had a tremendous run-up in prices over the last few months because of the turmoil in the Asian financial markets.
"Now traders are trying to protect some of the profits they've made amid talk of the crisis in Washington. Adding to the urgency of the situation is talk of foreign-investor selling, all related to the dollar's decline, which, too, is related to Washington."
Barbara Kenworthy, portfolio manager at Prudential Mutual Funds, said that turmoil in the mortgage securities market might also be affecting the Treasury market. On Thursday, the Mortgage Bankers Association said that homeowners were applying to refinance their mortgages at a record pace, a situation that undermines the mortgage securities market.
In such circumstances, investors sell mortgage-backed securities and buy Treasury notes, usually 10-year notes, buying that probably helped the rally earlier this month. But she said there were signs that some investors who had rushed to make such trades may have reversed some of them yesterday because of the sharp fall in the bond market.
But she also said that the basic fundamentals supporting bonds were unchanged: inflation is expected to remain in check and the economic slowdown in Asia should curb growth in the United States.
Many investors, however, may have decided that they got a little ahead of the game because there are no significant signs yet that the economy is slowing. And that makes it more unlikely that the Federal Reserve, whose policy-making committee meets the first week of February, would consider any rate cut.
This change in attitude, plus the selling by foreign investors, is reflected in the fall in prices and rise in yields in shorter-term Treasury securities. For example, the yield on the two-year note jumped to 5.40 percent yesterday, from 5.30 Thursday and 5.02 on Jan. 12, the date of its recent intraday low.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Atmosphere of Uncertainty Leads to Continued Losses

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
After three years of spectacular returns, the stock market seems to have entered a period of uncertainty.
With corporate profits looking less robust these days, and the dollar and bond prices in at least a temporary descent, investors have become a little less optimistic about stocks. 
 As a result, the Dow Jones industrial average dropped another 30.14 points, to 7,700.74, yesterday, falling for the third consecutive session. For the week, the Dow lost 52.81 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent.
 Broader indexes also slid. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 5.45, to 957.59, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index fell slightly, dropping 0.58 point, to 1,575.93, extending a string of losses this week.
On the Big Board, trading was heavy at more than 635 million shares, as nearly two stocks fell for every one that rose.
Wall Street strategists said the losses were insignificant but that the larger pattern in 1998 was negative. Among the concerns are weakening profits, a festering crisis in Asia and a White House scandal, exactly the kind of uncertainty that can disrupt optimism among investors.
"The market doesn't like uncertainty, and that's what we've had," said Arthur Hogan, a stock trader at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover.
The events in Washington, however, were not front and center on Wall Street this week. The real concern has been the lackluster fourth-quarter earnings season.
"Earnings are not quite as good as they've been," said Hugh Johnson, an investment strategist at First Albany. "The market movers have been hurt. Not only have their fourth-quarter earnings been disappointing, but they've warned of more trouble in the first quarter."
Almost midway through the reporting season, corporate profits have come in just slightly ahead of the estimates put out by Wall Street analysts, estimates that had been sharply reduced in recent weeks.
But the profits, up about 9.2 percent from the period a year ago, were down sharply from 11 percent last quarter, according to First Call, which tracks earnings estimates. And that deceleration is expected to continue well into 1998.
"That 9 percent is not bad, but it's lower than what we've had in the last few quarters," said Charles Hill, research director at First Call. And more important, he said, are the revisions in first-quarter estimates..
"That number is dropping day by day," Mr. Hill added.
Among those warning of potential trouble in the first quarter were I.B.M., Intel, Microsoft, J. P. Morgan and Citicorp.
The great uncertainty is Asia. Economists and analysts have been trying to assess what kind of economic slowdown might be in store, but no consensus has developed.
Yet more and more strategists are warning investors to temper their expectations and be more careful about their stock selection. Although a broad array of stocks gained 20 percent last year, this year investors may not be so fortunate.
Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover, said that the market could gain sharply in the early part of the year but then fall sharply as the economy heats up.
"During the second half of the year, I expect traditional economic pressures to emerge," he said in a recent report. "By that time Asia should have begun to form a base, and the continuing U.S. expansion will result in rising wage pressures."
Instead of deflation and fierce price competition, which is a concern of many on Wall Street, Mr. Wien said that interest rates could begin to rise sharply near the end of the year, after it becomes clear that the American economy has not been harmed significantly by the crisis in Asia.
William L. Paternotte, an investment strategist at BT Alex. Brown, has a very different view. He said that he cannot imagine an outbreak of higher inflation anytime soon because corporations have little pricing power and Asia is weighing on the United States economy.
Yet, with the economy nearing full employment and wage pressures rising, there could be a counterbalance. "I can easily imagine a 1998 environment resembling a tug-of-war between the forces of deflation and reinflation," he said
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 383.42 points, or 2.34 percent, to 16,789.11.

HEADLINE: Union Hopes to Organize Workers at Tribe's Casino

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 23

 BODY:
In the last few days, billboards have sprung up here and in nearby towns warning of the "Foxwoods flu," a malady that has more to do with labor unrest than any virus.
The signs are an inkling of worker dissatisfaction at the nation's largest casino, Foxwoods Resort Casino, which is owned and operated by the Mashantucket Pequot Indians on their reservation in eastern Connecticut. 
 Just as Foxwoods capitalized on untapped gambling fever in New England, a major union is hoping to recruit the huge unorganized work force that the casino has spawned.
The Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union started to post 10 billboards on Tuesday that say, "Foxwoods Flu: Has it happened to you?" and list a phone number at the bottom.
The billboards are part of an effort to reach the 12,000 workers at the casino in Ledyard in what could become an unprecedented organizing drive. Never before has a union been established at an Indian casino, where tribal sovereignty often takes precedence over state and Federal labor laws.
It is difficult to gauge how workers feel about conditions at the casino. A union survey last year reportedly showed widespread dissatisfaction, but tribal officials insist that workers are happy.
In six phone interviews, some workers complained of recent cutbacks, while others said they were thankful to have a job with comprehensive health benefits and a year-end bonus.
"They do whatever they please," said Norman Andersen, 43, an electrician who makes $17.97 an hour and says he would support a union. "They expect you to abide by their rules, but they change them every day."
Mr. Andersen and other workers said that the casino had cut back on bonuses, decreased the size of raises, ended its annual Christmas party, introduced co-payments on the company health plan and even tried to limit the amount that employees can eat at the employee cafeteria.
Another worker, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, complained that the air quality in the casino was poor. When she saw a doctor because of a persistent cough, the first thing the physician asked was whether she worked at Foxwoods, she said. But she added that she felt lucky to have a job that paid for her to see a doctor and gave her any year-end bonus.
Mario Alvaran, 42, a blackjack dealer, said that he made $15 an hour, about $10 of it in tips, and that he felt lucky to have a job that paid that well.
Yet the billboards have clearly worried the tribe. Last week, before the ads were posted, Byron Quann, the tribe's chief communications officer, sent a letter to the union and local newspapers demanding that the union "stop this harmful public relations campaign." The letter expresses concern that the campaign will mislead employees and customers into believing that "Foxwoods operates its resort in an unsafe or unhealthy manner."
The casino has received calls from customers asking whether it is safe to gamble there because of the flu.
In his letter, Mr. Quann says that Foxwoods has a "computer-operated air quality control system" that insures that the air is healthy. Tribal officials have dismissed the idea that workers are dissatisfied.
"Foxwoods continually works to maintain an environment where its employees don't feel it is necessary to have a third party act as an intermediary," Jack Jones, the tribe's chief human resources officer, said in a statement released Thursday.
But the union has shown no signs of backing off. "The point of the billboards is to talk to current and former workers about conditions on the job," said Laura Moye, an organizer with the union, which began meeting with Foxwoods workers several years ago. "We want to hear about what's going on inside."
Ms. Moye said that the union did not know what was meant by the phrase "Foxwoods flu," but that it was mentioned by workers in a survey that the union commissioned last spring. That survey showed that workers were unhappy with conditions at the casino, The Hartford Courant has reported.
The 50,000-member union represents thousands of workers at Atlantic City and Las Vegas casinos, but an organizing drive at Foxwoods would face a different set of rules.
Nell Jessup Newton, a professor at the American University School of Law who specializes in Indian law, said the National Labor Relations Board ruled in 1976 that businesses operated by tribal governments are exempt from the Federal Labor Act. This means there would probably be no Federal protection of the union's efforts to organize at Foxwoods unless the board revisited the issue.
To organize the workers, the union would have to either apply economic pressure to Foxwoods or gain recognition under Pequot tribal law.
Although the tribe's law does not appear to have any specific rules regarding unions, it does not appear to bar them, said Jill Shibles, Chief Judge of the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Court. The tribal council could also pass laws spelling out a policy toward unions, she added.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Another Day, Another Indonesian Plunge

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund and the Clinton Administration worked today to complete a plan to prop up the rapidly deteriorating Indonesian banking system, diplomats and Government officials said.
Officials at the I.M.F. said they hoped to finish a plan by early next week under which the Indonesian Government would seize some ailing banks, provide them with new financing and then privatize them again, wiping out the holdings of existing shareholders in the process. 
 But it is unclear how much help the bank bailout would be in dealing with Indonesia's spreading problems. With the currency, the rupiah, plunging in value by the day, the financial system is starved for dollars that companies desperately need to repay loans, and some international banks have halted any new lending to creditors there. By some accounts the entire banking system is close to paralysis, raising the possibility of a cascade of defaults that could lead to widespread bankruptcies.
Bloomberg News reported from Jakarta today that Standard Chartered Bank, ABN-Amro Bank, Bank of America and Rabobank International are among banks no longer handling rupiah-denominated transactions in what is known as the interbank market, an international network that enables banks to lend each other money.
Officials from the United States and the I.M.F. pressed President Suharto last week to agree to a tough new package of economic changes intended to signal to bankers, investors and business executives that the nation would take whatever steps necessary to contain the turmoil.
But the financial markets have remained unconvinced, increasing the economic pressure on the country and raising fears about its social stability two months before President Suharto is expected to claim a seventh term in office after 32 years in power. There have already been instances of panic buying, and consumers face rapidly rising prices and the threat of surging unemployment in coming months.
In late trading in Asia the rupiah fell to 13,250 to the dollar, down from 12,000 a day earlier, when it had briefly traded as low as 16,500.
American officials were guarded in their comments, but gave no indication that the United States or other industrialized nations were preparing any big new financial bailouts for Indonesia, the world's fourth-most-populous country.
I.M.F. officials said Indonesia had $20 billion in foreign currency reserves, enough to keep the economy from collapsing in the short run though only a portion of the $65 billion in debts owed to foreign creditors by Indonesian companies.
There has been widespread speculation in the markets about a debt moratorium followed by an agreement between the banks and the companies on new terms for debt repayment. But there is little evidence any agreement is imminent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dollar Drop Roils Bonds, Sending Yields Up
The dollar declined abruptly in global foreign-exchange trading yesterday, pulling bond prices sharply lower and sending the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury surging toward 6 percent, only a few weeks after it had touched a record low of 5.69 percent. 
 Some traders attributed the dollar's drop to an improved outlook for much of Asia and political uncertainty created by President Clinton's preoccupation with a scandal over an alleged sexual affair. But others said the dollar and bonds were vulnerable to selloffs given their gains in recent weeks. Page D3.
 
Stocks fell for the third straight day in reaction to less-than-robust corporate earnings and the retreat in the dollar and bonds. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 30.14 points, to 7,700.74. For the week, the Dow lost 52.81 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent. D3.
 
Gold surpassed $300 an ounce for the first time in two months as the dollar weakened. In New York, gold for February delivery rose $9, to $300.30 an ounce. D3.
 
Indonesia Bank Bailout Seen
The International Monetary Fund and the Clinton Administration worked to complete a plan to prop up the rapidly deteriorating Indonesian banking system, diplomats and Government officials said. I.M.F. officials said they hoped to complete the bailout plan by early next week. B2.
 
Shares of Britain's EMI Group, one of the world's biggest music recording companies, fell sharply after it said economic setbacks in the Asia-Pacific region would hurt financial results. D2.
 
Xerox Profits Surge
Xerox said fourth-quarter profits rose 23 percent in a better-than-expected showing that reflected growth in the company's digital product sales. Xerox's stock rose 6.4 percent on the news. D11.
 
Handy & Harman Weighs Sale
A few days after spurning a takeover offer from WHX Corporation, Handy & Harman said it was considering other alternatives, including a sale of all or parts of the precious metals and auto-parts company. Handy & Harman stock rose nearly 8 percent. D3.
 
Surprise Pick to Run Silicon Graphics
Silicon Graphics recruited Richard E. Belluzzo, heir apparent at Hewlett-Packard, to be chairman and chief executive. News of the appointment surprised Silicon Valley and was viewed as a strong choice for the troubled computer company. Silicon Graphics shares rose 22 percent. D2.
 
Apple's Market Share Dwindles
Apple Computer said in a yearly financial filing that its market share fell sharply in the company's 1997 fiscal year, reflecting declines in the sale of Macintosh computers. Once the biggest maker of personal computers in the 1980's, Apple's market share and clout have been declining for years. D2.
 
Cost of Smoking Rises
The nation's largest tobacco companies will raise cigarette prices for the third time in a year, adding nearly 3 cents to every pack sold. The companies intend to use added sales revenue to help cover the costs of a $15.3 billion settlement between Texas and the tobacco industry reached earlier this week. D14.
 
DNA Plant Technology Corporation, a biotechnology company in California, pleaded guilty to a Federal conspiracy charge for growing high-nicotine tobacco secretly in foreign countries for an American tobacco company. A16.
 
MCI Changes Strategy
MCI Communications said it could not make money reselling local residential phone service and instead would focus on providing businesses local service through its own networks. D11.

HEADLINE: Illusions of a War Against Cocaine

 BODY:
Panama is debating whether to let Washington keep American troops there to combat drug trafficking after the 1999 pullout date set by the canal treaties. The proposal, called the Multinational Counternarcotics Center, is one of several efforts to broaden the role of Latin American militaries in fighting drugs. It is dismaying to see Congress and the Clinton Administration return to a strategy that has failed and could harm Latin democracies.
Washington is seeking to keep more than 2,000 soldiers in Panama for 12 years to continue coordinating radar searches for suspicious aircraft, a job that could be done from American soil. The troops would also train Latin American military and police forces in drug-fighting. The project needs the approval of Panama's Congress and its voters in a referendum. Some American officials say the proposal is a way for Washington to maintain ties and coordination with Latin militaries now that cold-war rationales have evaporated. 
 Military aid and sales to Colombia have also been resumed, and this year Congress approved a five-year project costing up to $100 million to train and equip the Colombian and Peruvian militaries to interdict drugs transported by river. Washington has periodically pushed the Mexican military to take on an anti-drug role, and since 1996 has provided training, intelligence and equipment.
Some cooperation with Latin American law enforcement is useful. Crop substitution programs, which give coca-growing peasants economic incentives to switch crops, deserve expansion. But no one should put too much store in efforts to stop the production of cocaine in Latin America. Past efforts have not reduced the flow of drugs to the United States. A Rand Corporation study showed that source-country control was by far the least cost-effective way of reducing cocaine use. Treatment for addicts, it found, could have the same impact at a 20th of the price.
Even effective military operations show this strategy's limits. The Peruvian Air Force has stopped many planes carrying coca paste to Colombia for processing. But that success, along with a fungus that has attacked Peru's coca plants, has simply pushed coca-growing into Colombia.
Military strategies are not only ineffective, they can be harmful. The virus of corruption contaminates everyone who comes near the drug war, as the wave of recent arrests of Mexican officers shows. There is evidence from several countries that militaries have used their American equipment and training to fight guerrillas or to abuse human rights. The counternarcotics relationship has also led some Clinton Administration officials to praise officers and strengthen militaries that threaten civilian rule. These are echoes of cold-war abuses that the Administration should heed.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT UNDER FIRE: THE DEFENDERS;
Clinton's Rapid-Response Squad Now Moves in Slow Motion

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 23

 BODY:
When Bill Clinton was running for President in 1992 and faced accusations of a 12-year extramarital affair with Gennifer Flowers, his aides corralled reporters to declare that Ms. Flowers was lying and had been paid by trashy tabloids.
His loyalists evolved into a legendary "rapid response" team to advance Mr. Clinton's case with each tick of the news cycle. The team has since been widely emulated but its effectiveness rarely equaled. 
 Now, with Mr. Clinton facing the biggest personal crisis of his Presidency, the old team is on the sidelines. Many of them have left Mr. Clinton's employ.
With the President's lawyers in control, hardly any other Democrats have stepped into the breach. Even Vice President Al Gore has commented on the situation only in a meeting in his office with a handful of newspaper columnists -- and no television cameras.
Oddly, some of the rapid-response team seem to be making things worse for their old boss..
George Stephanopoulos, a main campaign aide in 1992 and Mr. Clinton's senior adviser until after the 1996 election, was among the first to use the word "impeachment" over the allegations that Mr. Clinton was sexually involved with a 21-year-old intern and conspired to have her lie about it. Mr. Stephanopoulos now is a political analyst for ABC News.
Dee Dee Myers, Mr. Clinton's former press secretary and now an editor at Vanity Fair, said on NBC's "Today" show, "If he's not telling the truth, I think the consequences will be astronomical."
After five years of Washington political battles, the President has alienated many in his own party, particularly in Congress. And he has sent enough signals over the years so that some people find the charges against him at least plausible.
Jim Ruvolo, the former Democratic chairman in Ohio and now a political consultant, said people are outlining two scenarios: "If it's untrue, it's outrageous he has to put up with these charges, that this only gets worse and why would any good person get into this business? Others say if it's true, it's the death knell of his Presidency."
Geraldine Ferraro, the 1984 Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee and now a candidate for the Senate from New York, first told a New York One television interviewer that she thought the allegations, if true, constituted an impeachable offense.
"If indeed someone urges someone to perjure themselves, then absolutely, absolutely," Mrs. Ferraro said.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat and longtime Clinton supporter, spoke to reporters in a break in a hearing on Capitol Hill, saying, "If it's true, I think the President is in deep trouble."
In New Hampshire, Amanda Merrill, a Democrat and deputy minority leader in the state House, said: "We're not happy about it." She added: "This is not the sort of thing to have eating up people's time."
To be sure, there have been some gestures of support.
Mr. Gore gave a measured statement. "The President has denied the charges, and I believe it," he said.
And today, Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, which would conduct any impeachment hearings, volunteered a statement. Without defending the President, he questioned the evidence against him, saying the tapes could have been illegally recorded and might not be admissible as evidence.
Reporters for MSNBC caught up with Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, today in Cuba. Rather than insist on the President's innocence, Mr. Rangel attacked the credibility of Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating the charges. But, he added: "If indeed the President was guilty of obstruction of justice, I really would think that the word 'impeachment' would be one of the words to be used."
One measure of the lack of big guns to defend the President was the appearance on CNN today of a relatively unknown Democratic consultant, Jennifer Laszlo, as the counterpoint to Frank Luntz, a prominent Republican consultant and pollster. As Ms. Laszlo tried to change the subject to the healthy economy, Mr. Luntz gave her a backhanded compliment. "They're having a tough time in having the Democrats come forward," he said, "and there aren't many Democrats as loyal as you."
But Mr. Luntz himself had sent a memo to all Republican members of Congress telling them to keep mum on the subject. "The facts will speak far louder than any of your voices," he wrote. "If you comment, you will take a non-partisan, non-political situation and make it both partisan and political.
"Do not speculate. Do not hypothesize. Too many Americans justify the President's behavior because they dislike his accusers. Please don't add to that justification."
Charter members of Mr. Clinton's rapid-response team have been subdued in their limited appearances on television.
James Carville was perhaps the most vociferous of Mr. Clinton's defenders, screaming at reporters in 1992 for even bringing up Ms. Flowers and, as recently as Sunday, going on "Meet The Press" as part of his long campaign to discredit Paula Corbin Jones, who has accused Mr. Clinton of making crude sexual advances toward her.
This week Mr. Carville said on "Larry King Live" that the drill could get wearying.
"Having gone through the same thing any number of times, particularly during the campaign, they're more tired that anything," he said of White House aides. "Tired in terms of just dealing with it."
Another member of the rapid-response team was Mandy Grunwald, a media adviser in 1992 who made her name by aggressively challenging the legitimacy of Ted Koppel's "Nightline" report on Ms. Flowers.
But on "Larry King Live" Ms. Grunwald was more cautious Thursday night: "This is one of the really hard times when the best P.R. advice is not always the best legal advice."

HEADLINE: Consumers Play Role In Depleted Fish Stocks

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Senseless Killing in the Seas" (editorial, Jan. 20) is right that "America's fisheries are not in good shape," but the fishing industry and its methods deserve only a small portion of the blame. As we continue to fill wetlands, empty sewer overflows in estuaries and dump garbage in the ocean, we damage the ecosystem that feeds the fishery. Because of acid rain and the greenhouse effect, water temperatures have increased in fishing areas. 
 Consumers must take some responsibility, too. We have demanded white flaky fish, like cod and flounder, known as groundfish. Fifty years ago, groundfish significantly outnumbered their predators. Now the opposite is true.
Fishermen could help by catching more "underutilized" fish like mackerel and dogfish. In Gloucester, Mass., where I was economic development coordinator from 1993 to 1995, diversification has been slow to take effect because these fish are not desired by consumers. It's time we stop blaming the fisherman for a global problem.
 
GREGORY D. ATKINS
Brooklyn, Jan. 20, 1998
