HEADLINE: Mayor's Shopping Mission: Tax Free or Bust;
Trumpeting Cause to Lift Levy (and Picking Up Socks Along the Way)

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
A few days ago, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani found himself in a setting of Felliniesque design: surrounded by four sets of identically dressed identical twins, while a Giuliani impersonator belted out the lyrics to "New York, New York."
Perhaps only a late-night bowl of chili could conjure such a dreamlike scene. But this was all too real, coming as part of the Mayor's efforts to promote a weeklong suspension of the sales tax on clothing purchases under $500 in New York City stores. 
 The tax break ended at midnight last night, leaving mayoral aides to ponder whether it was enough to persuade state legislators to eliminate the clothing tax altogether, which in the city amounts to 8.25 percent. But there was no uncertainty over Mr. Giuliani's commitment to the cause, as he cut a swath through overstuffed clothes racks and perfume counters from Staten Island to the Bronx.
His critics might argue that the issue is hardly a political risk. Brave are the few who are for taxes. But those critics might take comfort in knowing that the Mayor still had to earn his good press, as evidenced the other day when he was ensconced in twins, smiling gamely, waiting for photographs to be snapped.
The issue is important to Mr. Giuliani, who maintains that eliminating the clothing sales tax would keep city consumers from straying to New Jersey, where there is no sales tax on clothes. He also says it would create as many as 20,000 jobs, a priority on the mayoral agenda.
The Mayor's aides say that the early returns in this week's promotion show there was a 50 percent jump in the sale of clothes and shoes, in a month when consumers, shellshocked from holiday shopping battles, tend not to spend. Those figures, slightly lower than those from a similar promotion last January, are generated from a daily survey of 150 stores citywide.
Mr. Giuliani's yearslong campaign has met with some success. Beginning in December 1999, a new state law will allow the city to eliminate taxes on clothes under $100. But Charles Millard, the Mayor's senior economic adviser, said that Mr. Giuliani's mission this week was "total elimination" of clothing taxes, a goal too ambitious even for Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, who has been fighting for a tax break of up to $500.
The Mayor's plan is not universally embraced by economists. "The decision to do this is powered by political ambition," said Bennett Harrison, an urban economist at the New School, "not by any systematic analysis that proves you'll change people's decisions on where to shop."
But the Mayor, emboldened by his staff's own economic research, disagrees, and is on a mission to prove the doubters wrong. For the last week, his voice, name and image have appeared in $400,000 worth of newspaper and radio advertisements promoting the campaign. And he himself set out to shop.
Two days before the "sales tax-free week" formally began, Mr. Giuliani left City Hall and walked across Chambers Street to Modell's Sporting Goods store, where a lectern bearing the city seal and placed amid racks of sweatshirts suggested that his visit was expected. Also in the store were four sets of adult identical twins and a Giuliani lookalike, all hired to promote the store's offer to clone its January tax discount in February.
After trumpeting the virtues of tax-free shopping, the Mayor tried to assume the role of the everyday shopper, albeit one being followed by a swarm of bodyguards and photographers. He rubbed the fabric of a Knicks warmup jacket between his fingers, he admired some baseball jerseys, and he bantered:
"I'm a traditionalist. I like old uniforms." "You don't have the new Mets stuff yet?" "Super Bowl hats? That's a strange-looking hat."
Then an aide said, "The twins are set up." The Mayor posed for photographs, then he completed his purchase at Modell's: the Knicks jacket, a New York Yankees shirt, a St. John's University basketball jersey and two Green Bay Packers shirts. He spent $71.46, and he saved about $6.50 in taxes.
He had only begun to shop.
Last Saturday, he bought three pairs of socks, two sweatshirts and a red sweater at an Old Navy store in the Bronx. But he had already wandered the aisles of a Caldor nearby, he admitted. "I'm not going to tell you what I bought because it's a little embarrassing. Some socks and a few other things, personal things."
A City Hall source said the Mayor had purchased underwear.
On Sunday, Mr. Giuliani led guards and reporters through another Caldor, this one on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn. Again, he headed to a display of socks. Holding up a pair decorated with small hearts, he asked a bodyguard, "A Valentine's Day gift for Randy Mastro?" in a joking reference to his trusted Deputy Mayor of Operations.
On Wednesday, the Mayor made one more venture into the world of consumerism, this time to the Staten Island Mall, where he was accompanied by the Borough President, Guy V. Molinari. They strolled past the Body Shop, Banana Republic, Bun 'n' Burger.
But shopping has a way of numbing the soul; even the most zealous of missionaries need a break. On this day, his last in promoting the tax-free week, Mr. Giuliani politely declined the offer of a makeover from a Sears beauty adviser. And he resisted the urge to buy socks.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 3; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1174 words

HEADLINE: SUPER BOWL XXXII;
It's Crazy, Lavish and Excessive, but Not Spontaneous

BYLINE: By BILL PENNINGTON

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 23

 BODY:
There was a two-page news release to announce the color, shape and design of the approximately two million pieces of confetti that will be shot from cannons at the end of Sunday's football game between the Green Bay Packers and the Denver Broncos.
There was a news conference to discuss the flipping of the pre-game coin. Another one to explain the singing of the national anthem. Another to announce that the 10,000 balloons to be released during the pre-game show are biodegradable. The Stealth bomber pilots doing the flyover at kickoff were made available. So was the pilot of the blimp. 
 A color psychologist was on hand to interpret the strengths and weaknesses portrayed within the teams' uniform designs.
And there was a large, well-attended reception to celebrate the Bud Bowl, the annual pretend playing of a game between two teams of beer bottles.
The buildup to the Super Bowl, the season-ending championship of the National Football League and a cultural winter landmark, has been called scripted insanity.
From mass interviews with the news media -- where 320-pound players are asked, "If you were a tree, what kind of tree would you be?" -- to parties for reporters at Sea World -- where the whales have been trained to mimic football moves -- the week preceding the Super Bowl is an annual testimony to simulated spontaneity.
The drumbeat that drives the week is a kind of choreographed excess.
"I was told the scene and all the planning at the Super Bowl was beyond anything else I had seen," said Smokey Robinson, the Motown singer and songwriter who will be a featured performer in the halftime show. "Now that I'm here, my impression is that they were right. This is a crazy week, man."
The headline in The San Diego Union-Tribune last Sunday read: S.D. Has S.B. Fever.
The next day, there was another headline across the newspaper's front page, shouting from newsstand boxes on street corners throughout the city: Is L.A. Envious?
By the time Super Bowl XXXII starts on Sunday at 6:18 P.M. Eastern time, 80,000 visitors will have descended upon San Diego. Previous Super Bowl host cities have estimated the economic windfall to be at least $100 million. The event is a source of pride, and every year, regardless of the city, the Super Bowl host committee is swamped with volunteers who just want to get close to the action.
What the volunteers see is a numbing procession of news conferences and shuttle-bus rides to and from the hotels that house the teams, monotonous rehearsals for Super Bowl celebrations and punctilious preparations to make the event efficient.
The fun stuff is out of bounds. The team practices are closed. At the hotels where the teams stay, the players are sequestered from the public, usually walking through separate corridors that are roped off to keep other guests of the hotel, or fans arriving to be a part of the scene, at a distance.
In fact, local residents wanting to feel a part of the Super Bowl festivities might be better off in the streets, away from the official league functions.
There have been special Super Bowl street parties, road-running races, golf tournaments, craft-making carnivals and harbor cruises, most of them unofficial.
The N.F.L. has found one runaway winner, the N.F.L. Experience, a football theme park that appeals to children and adults. It is a popular attraction drawing thousands across three days. Thursday's lines were 90 minutes long for one field-goal attempt.
But then, crowds are the backdrop to every facet of the event.
Tuesday, at the site of the game, Qualcomm Stadium, the league conducted its annual interview session. Thousands of members of the news media were herded like cattle through the gates.
Once inside, after the players were positioned at podiums and key locations in the grandstand, it was as if someone had fired a gun to begin a race. Reporters scurried, and the giant stadium clock at the far end of the facility began a countdown signaling how many minutes remained in the session, the numerals ticking off like a game in overtime.
Two minutes to go! Can you find one more lineman who can explain what victory will mean to him?
Similar packed interview sessions are repeated for three successive days. In the end, it is hard to know who is more fed up with whom. Are the players more tired of talking with the reporters, or vice versa?
Thursday, Packers defensive end Reggie White wore a T-shirt with one word on the front: why?
No one ventured an answer. It was hard enough to come up with a remotely original question.
Some of the more talkative players, like Green Bay safety Eugene Robinson, enjoyed holding the news media hostage.
"I was telling some friends just last night that I get to talk all I want and these poor guys have to listen to me," Robinson said. "Because you all got to write something. You have to listen to me whether you like it or not."
The N.F.L. schedules the interviews with the players and coaches each morning, feeds the reporters lunch, then whisks them off in a caravan of buses to the sprawling news media center downtown, where it deposits them content in the knowledge that the voracious god of Super Bowl hype will be nourished once again by nightfall.
Nothing at the Super Bowl, it seems, is left to chance, even the most chancy affair of all, the frenetic 10-minute halftime show.
Wednesday, beneath the Mission Valley Freeway, the performers in the halftime show -- 1,200 strong -- marched in a parking lot outside Qualcomm Stadium.
The outline of a simulated football field had been painted in the parking lot, with hash marks and yard markers, the rectangle illuminated by large, bright spotlights on a chilly evening four days before the game.
On command, with military-like precision, the cheerleaders, dancers and volunteers assembled from 47 California high schools and colleges paraded onto the fake field, finding coded locations that designated assigned places.
"Mark your spot," one of the show's directors shouted through a bullhorn. "Stay between the lines."
The show is a dizzying production that will include 20 Motown stars on a 32-ton portable stage, more than 5,000 props, 2,500 pyrotechnic explosions and as many stage cues as there are in the 90 minutes of Radio City Music Hall's Christmas extravaganza.
The Super Bowl halftime show is a tribute to some maniacally detailed choreography. And there is no small amount of symbolism that it will be performed right in the middle of the most choreographed sporting event.
"It's amazing, all the reporters, all the workers, all the volunteers, all the people," Smokey Robinson said, smiling and shaking his head as he waited in the parking lot outside the stadium for the rehearsal to wrap up. "What a spectacle. Look at us, we've got a thousand people and we're cramming them into a 10-minute show. Ten minutes, can you imagine that? The preparation is intense. Everything laid out to the last second.
"I look around and I just say, 'Thank God I'm not the choreographer.' "

HEADLINE: Chrysler Net Up But Higher Costs Raise Concerns

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 23

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation reported fourth-quarter earnings today that were better than expected, but the numbers, particularly a sharp increase in rebates and other incentives, set Wall Street to worrying about the auto industry's prospects for this year.
The cost of rebates and other incentives by Chrysler jumped 79.5 percent in the quarter, alarming analysts who expect other auto makers will also show increases in marketing costs. 
 Analysts are also concerned that Chrysler and the other Detroit giants -- the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company -- face a stagnant domestic market with falling prices and falling demand.
"When you have an industry that's flat and you've got excess capacity and everyone fighting for market share, it's going to be tough," said Wendy Beale Needham, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Chrysler shares fell 68.75 cents today, or 2 percent, to $33.50, amid an overall decline in the shares of auto makers.
"Chrysler's results could be a harbinger of tough things to come" for Detroit, said Jack V. Kirnan, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney. For Chrysler and the others, "1998 we think has to be considered a riskier year than 1997," he said.
Chrysler said it earned $852 million, or $1.28 a fully diluted share, in the fourth quarter, up 5.6 percent from $807 million, or $1.12 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Excluding a one-time gain from the initial public offering of the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, Chrysler earned $792 million, or $1.19 a share, down 27.3 percent from the $1.09 billion, or $1.51 a share, a year ago, also including special items.
Despite the fall in Chrysler's operating earnings, last year was a boom year for Detroit. G.M. is scheduled to release earnings Monday, while Ford's report is expected Tuesday.
The Big Three are expected to post combined 1997 profits of about $15.1 billion, well up from the 1994 record of $13.9 billion in combined earnings, with much of the profit coming from sales of high-margin sport utility vehicles and other trucks. Chrysler's earnings for the year were $2.81 billion, or $4.09 a share, down 20.5 percent from 1996. G.M. is expected to earn about $5.9 billion, or $7.84 a share, according to the consensus of analysts' estimates by First Call, a research firm. Ford is expected to earn $6.7 billion, or $5.41 a share, largely because its large sport utility vehicles have proved so popular.
While Chrysler's earnings held up fairly well last year and earnings this year are expected to come close to the record 1996 level, analysts said the company appeared to be near the top of its performance.
"Chrysler to a large extent is a victim of its own success," Mr. Kirnan of Salomon said. Because Chrysler has done so well in the last few years, "the question now is how much worse can things get."
The economic downturn in Asia crimped Chrysler's sales, but had little material effect on fourth-quarter earnings, said Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive. Chrysler has less exposure to Asia.than G.M. or Ford.
Mr. Eaton added that Chrysler, like General Motors and Ford, would consider taking advantage of the lower costs in dollar terms by expanding Asian operations. "If the right opportunity presents itself, we'll be there, " he said.
 Mr. Eaton also strongly defended sport utility vehicles against recent criticisms that the four-wheel-drive vehicles pose serious dangers for people in cars when there are collisions. Mr. Eaton noted that when small cars were introduced in the 1970's, some safety experts predicted that highway death rates would rise from collisions of the small cars with the much bigger, older cars that were built in the 1960's.
"You know what happened?" Mr. Eaton asked. "Deaths per 100 million miles, deaths per vehicle, deaths per mile, no matter what you look at, it didn't happen, it continued to drop. And believe me, that's exactly what I think will happen going forward."
But Donald W. Reinfurt, the deputy director of the Highway Safety Research Center at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, said the comparison with the 1970's was flawed. The spread of small cars coincided with a reduction in the national speed limit to 55 miles an hour, rising use of seat belts, a decline in drunken driving and stricter Federal safety standards for autos, he said.
There are few comparably big gains to be made now in automotive safety, while the mismatches in weight between cars and today's big sport utility vehicles are even larger than the mismatches between large and small cars in the 1970's, Mr. Reinfurt added.

HEADLINE: Sailing the High-End Seas;
Luxury Craft Are Back and Prices Are Bigger Than Ever

BYLINE: By JIM CARRIER 

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 20

 BODY:
Susan Puleo, an interior architect, mixes glass spiral staircases, leather floors, fiber optics and African rosewood to set off antiques in clients' salons. The stairs, entwining cockatoo cages, lead to master bedrooms with fireplaces and waterfront views, dance floors with smoke machines, hot tubs with wet bars, even to basketball courts that fold away when not in use.
Her creations also speed along at 20 knots, burn 400 gallons of fuel an hour, turn 1,200 gallons of sea water into fresh each day and spend the summer in the Mediterranean. 
 A new gilded age of yachting is dawning.
Five years after Congress repealed a 10 percent luxury tax on new boats costing more than $100,000 that had contributed to a plunge in sales, the boating industry is rebounding vigorously. Led by an appetite among the newly rich for extravagant boats -- costing $3 million to $30 million -- new yacht sales, both motor and sail, last year roughly matched the record $2 billion in purchases reached in 1988. While still much lower in inflation-adjusted dollars, the total today reflects a smaller number of much more expensive boats.
The boating revival is a visible measure of the wealth created by the stock market boom and yet another example of the widening gap between the rich and everybody else.
Sales of inboard cruisers, which are generally at least 35 feet in length, jumped 38 percent last year to $1.7 billion. Sales of sailboats over 35 feet long rose 40 percent, to $350 million.
For almost a decade, the boat industry was dead, leading to the closing and consolidation of several companies and a drop in employment from 600,000 to 400,000 jobs. Even today, with employment back up to about 650,000, sales of smaller motor yachts, 35 to 50 feet, have only partly recovered.
Whether the two-year luxury tax can be blamed for more than an worsening role still is debated. Signed by President George Bush along with a tax on expensive cars that was included in a deficit reduction bill, the luxury-boat tax went into effect in 1991. After an immense cry from marine communities, and little to show in higher tax revenues, the tax on boats was repealed in August 1993, retroactive to January.
The National Marine Manufacturers Association, representing inboard motor cruisers, argues that sales would be nearly double today if the tax had never been enacted.
But boating began to drop two years before the tax went into effect and remained battered by fallout from the 1987 stock market crash, the 1990-91 Persian Gulf war recession and the shock, however brief, of high interest rates and high oil prices. And for a while, the ostentation of the mid-1980's was passe.
Boating, once the favorite pastime of successful car dealers, lost allure -- plagued by high costs, poor quality and competition from golf and other leisure-time activities such as watching movies on elaborate home entertainment centers.
Shaken manufacturers, borrowing hard lessons from the auto industry, are only now beginning to stress better service, innovative financing and factory efficiency.
"We did blame the luxury tax," said Frank F. Herhold, executive director of the Marine Industries Association of South Florida. "But while many in the industry slept, our market share slipped away."
That was then. But now, here in America's Venice, with canals chock-a-block with 17,000 boats, dozens of brokers and a small army of marine craftsmen, the recession seems a distant memory. All boats appear to be rising with the tide of the stock market and the affluence of a maturing baby-boom generation. But as in Orwell's "Animal Farm," the biggest and most expensive are rising faster than others.
"It's on a real good upswing," said David Gennett, a sales executive with Allied Marine Group here. Florida leads the nation in marine expenditures at $3.4 billion last year.
Nationally, there is a backlog of factory orders, extending demand to used boats that sell for close to their original price.
"Since August we have taken in $90 million in net sales, as much as I took in in all of '96," said Bryant Phillips, senior vice president for sales and marketing of Hatteras Yachts in New Bern, N.C., which dominates the 39- to 70-foot motor yacht market. "It reminds us of the salad days of the late 80's."
Hatteras revenues fell in half the year after the tax was enacted. It cut 1,000 jobs from a work force of 1,800. Even with the closing of one of its two factories this winter to improve efficiency, the company has restored about 200 of the lost jobs. The growth at Hatteras now is in boats more than 50 feet, a trend evident throughout the industry.
At Broward Marine in Fort Lauderdale, six aluminum motor yachts -- stretching from 88 to 107 feet and selling from $5 million to $15 million -- are in various stages of construction. B. David Wiest, the controller, says the owners "are not too worried about the economy," adding, "They all pay cash."
"This will be a country kitchen," he said, ducking through a rough-cut door on an informal tour. "The entertainment center will be here. Watch your head. There may be a jet ski or two there." Broward's boats are considered starter mega-yachts.
"The top end of the market is just booming," said Mike Kelsey, chairman of Palmer Johnson, which employs 300 people in Sturgeon Bay, Wis., building six mega-yachts a year.
When the Robb Report, a catalogue of conspicuous consumption, called Mr. Kelsey for a contribution to its Christmas issue, he offered to showcase a 200-foot, $32 million motor yacht now under construction.
"I've gotten nine inquiries," Mr. Kelsey said. "It shows you sticker shock didn't deter them."
At the Fort Lauderdale boat show in November more than 20 boats, each costing $18 million to $20 million, sold in five days, according to Kaye Pearson, president of the show.
"You wouldn't think there would be impulse buys in that range, but there are," Mr. Pearson said.
Today, about 5,000 pleasure boats larger than 100 feet exist, double the number of a decade ago, said Jim Gilbert, who edits Showboats International magazine. Every year for the last three, 200 boats -- six miles of yachts -- have been under construction in boat yards around the world.
Nearly half of the orders are from Americans. Most come from the growing clan of self-made multimillionaires, flush from an public offering, a buyout or stock options, who have reached a financial zenith and want to repair to the ocean in safety and comfort.
Take Jim Mattei, 48, an investor and a builder of condominiums and shopping centers. "It's really the only passion I have," Mr. Mattei said in a telephone interview from his home in Charlotte, N.C. "I don't mind working 8 or 10 hours on the boat."
Like most owners of large yachts, Mr. Mattei moved up, from a 57-foot Chris Craft to a 90-footer to his present 120-foot Emerald K. He's building a 150-foot boat, which will also have satellite phones, three tenders, a crew of six and an art collection.
Why a bigger boat?
Family. "We look like Noah's ark when we arrive, my mother, who is 80, my son and all his friends," Mr. Mattei said. "We have five staterooms, and we were always full. It's nothing about egocentric rich guys with big toys. It's completely changed from the 80's."
Yes, the boats have become even more immense, with richer interiors, bigger engines and more water toys.
When a mega-yacht pulls into Fort Lauderdale, it's as if a tiny nation washed up, in terms of economic impact. If it docks at Pier 66, for example, the tie-up, complete with phone and room service, costs $450 a night, or $13,500 a month. Fuel can run several thousand dollars. And the marina could take in more big boats if it had the space.
"The business we turn away are the 120-footers." said James R. Allmand 3d, general manager of the Hyatt Regency Pier 66. "It gets frustrating."
A 150-foot motor craft can cost $1.5 million to run and maintain a year, said Bob Saxon, who manages 80 yachts for owners, chartering many to help defray expenses that typically include $500,000 for crew, $200,000 for fuel, $100,000 in insurance, $65,000 for food and liquor, and $225,000 for hauling the boat out of the water and normal repairs. A bottom paint job every four years costs $400,000.
When a large boat comes in, it is swarmed over by woodworkers, mechanics, electricians, carpet layers, you name it.
"I was on one that had 18 men working on it, all making $25 to $50 an hour," said Thomas J. Murray, an economist with the University of South Florida. "One boat can mean 50 jobs. So if 500 boats need refitting you're talking hundreds of millions expended."
Most large-boat owners register them offshore, usually in the Bahamas and the Cayman Islands, a practice that thrived during the luxury-tax years. By closing the deal in Nassau, they avoided not only the Federal tax, but also state sales tax.
Today, a $7,000 incorporation on a $5 million boat saves $525,000. Sailing under a foreign flag, they can also hire foreign crews and enter nations like Cuba. To enter American waters they need an annual cruising permit.
Whatever the cause of the downturn in the late 1980's and early 1990's, all involved now agree that the recession shook up an industry that had taken success for granted. Affluent consumers now rank boats No. 15 on their wish lists, down from No. 6 in 1984. Big screen television sets and home computers rank higher for this crucial group of would-be beginners who could become future yacht owners.
After a series of introspective studies the marine industry is considering certification of dealers to insure quality products and repairs, warranties on used boats and a self-imposed surcharge on sales to finance a national ad campaign.
Time sharing is also being tried, so people with incomes of, say, $200,000 a year can own a piece of an 80-foot yacht for $70,000 down, said Guy E. Veni, executive vice president of the sales financing division of CIT, a $1 billion underwriter of boat loans.
Still looming over the industry are environmental crackdowns on engine pollution and raw sewage discharge. "You can make it bigger, but I'm not seeing a lot of intelligence," said Ms. Puleo, the designer. "I'd like to hear about their nonpolluting systems."
Most owners spend a few weeks on their yachts and usually sell them in two years. At that rate, Capt. Michael Auer figures, a typical owner spends $2,000 for each hour of actual boat time.
The boat he runs, named Adler, is owned by a European businessman. It burns 500 gallons of diesel fuel an hour at top speed, at a cost of 72 cents a second.
But Adler does not cross the Atlantic on its own. The owner prefers to load the yacht into a huge open tanker to be carried to the Mediterranean, avoiding wear and tear on the engine and fittings. The cost? $225,000 round trip.
"I'd never own a boat," said Captain Auer said. "I know better."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Troubled Waters

BYLINE: By Thurston Clarke; Thurston Clarke is the author of "Equator," "California Fault" and the forthcoming "Searching for Crusoe: Around the World by Island."

 BODY:

SONG FOR THE
 BLUE OCEAN
 Encounters Along the World's Coasts and Beneath the Seas.
 By Carl Safina.
 458 pp. New York:
 Henry Holt & Company. $30. 
 Can you imagine trying to impress friends and business associates by ordering, say, breast of eagle in tarragon sauce, or tournedos of panda? But you would probably have no second thoughts about serving a platter of glistening bluefin tuna sashimi, and it is precisely this unwillingness to extend the sense of community to living things below the high-tide line that Carl Safina believes is the main reason some species of fish are threatened with extinction.
In "Song for the Blue Ocean," his engrossing and illuminating journey to the world's marine killing grounds stirs up typhoon-sized waves of bad news for almost anyone fond of eating, catching or admiring fish, including sushi lovers, backyard swordfish barbecuers, sport fishermen hoping for more than sunburn and a beer hangover from a day's charter, scuba divers lacking the time or money to search out reefs that dynamite and cyanide have not yet turned into underwater Hiroshimas, independent commercial fishermen and travelers expecting fishing boats and fishermen in coastal villages instead of boutiques.
Everywhere Safina goes he finds declining catches and threatened species. On the Eastern Seaboard of the United States, only eight yellowtail flounder out of 100 survive from one year to the next, and 40 miles of line and more than 1,000 hooks are required to catch what one man with a harpoon could land, within sight of land, in the 1960's. The legendary Grand Banks fisheries have become so barren that Newfoundland's unemployment rate is an astonishing 60 percent, and its yearly welfare budget stands at $2 billion. The bluefin tuna breeding population has fallen nearly 90 percent in 15 years, scientific reports put stocks of marlin and swordfish at their lowest levels in history, and 9 out of 10 swordfish harvested are juveniles who have never spawned. The charter fishing fleet of one Oregon town has shrunk from 300 to 20 in just five years, and the number of active salmon trolling licenses in Washington fallen from 2,300 to 600 in the last 20. Recreational salmon fishing has been closed between San Francisco and the Canadian border, and the Alaska halibut season is now reduced to 24 hours a year.
Some of these horror stories have been reported in environmental publications and the mainstream news media, but Safina, a research ecologist who founded the Living Oceans Program of the National Audubon Society, is the first to knit them together into a single passionate and enthralling narrative. This is not one of those environmental screeds that marshal the usual depressing statistics, excoriate the predictable villains and despair for the future. Instead, Safina takes us on a tour, not just to the most imperiled fishing grounds on earth, but also to Washington hearing rooms, pricey Asian restaurants, impoverished coastal villages and inland spawning grounds. He goes out with a Maine charter captain who compares the 1,000 trophy-sized fish he landed in previous years with the 60 he hopes to catch now. He flies over New England fishing grounds with a professional fish spotter who guides commercial fishermen to the giant tuna that command astronomical prices from the fish-mad Japanese. In Washington State, he joins a commercial fisherman who landed 400 fish in a single day in 1985 but is now lucky to catch four. This man is so heartbreakingly optimistic that he justifies his pointless fishing trips by arguing that although he's going broke, at least he's helping the community by buying fuel and paying dockage. On the Pacific island of Palau, where overfishing with dynamite has damaged reefs, he goes diving to tag fish for a census conducted by the Department of Natural Resources. In the Philippines he watches members of the Cyanide Reform Program attempt to persuade villagers to catch fish for aquariums without using reef-poisoning sodium cyanide. And, finally, in Hong Kong, he attends a lavish banquet where two-thirds of the seafood harvested at such cost is returned to the kitchen uneaten.
The villains include venal politicians and the timid government bureaucrats charged with setting and enforcing fishery regulations, timber companies whose irresponsible forestry practices are turning wild salmon into the bison of the Pacific Northwest, and greedy commercial fishermen whose giant nets and long lines cause such havoc among breeding populations. He is particularly scathing about the founder of the East Coast Tuna Association, who claims credit for first shipping bluefin to Japan, refuses to consider the mounting evidence it is endangered and, according to Safina, is "solemnly dedicated to making a dollar." Equally sharply criticized are the Army Corps of Engineers for closing a dam on the Columbia River before the fish ladders were ready so that it could be dedicated on schedule (causing 200,000 adult salmon to hurl themselves to death against its concrete), and Hong Kong glitterati who routinely pay hundreds of dollars for a prized and rare reef fish so they can announce, according to one of Safina's Chinese acquaintances, "I'm a very rich person, an affluent person."
One of the aspects of his story Safina finds most shocking is how much overfishing is prompted by considerations of status, and superstition. Sharks are killed in record numbers because their $200-per-pound dorsal fins add a questionable potency to herbal medicines and a still more questionable flavor to expensive soups. The Napoleon wrasse is taken live from Philippine reefs so businessmen can impress clients by ordering $250 platters of their lips. The bluefin is endangered because it is worth more than any large creature on earth -- more even than an elephant or a rhinoceros -- and worth its price to status-conscious Japanese executives. (But anyone tempted to conclude from this that contributing to ecological disasters for frivolous notions of status is confined to Asia might consider the upper-middle-class American families accomplishing their rounds of suburban errands in those greenhouse-gas-belching sport utility vehicles.)
Safina makes no attempt to disguise his convictions and agenda, and one would not expect him to have much sympathy for the timber companies, the Army Corps of Engineers or Blade Runner fishing fleets with their sea-floor charts, video sonar, airplanes and satellite-generated maps of sea-surface temperature patterns. But what elevates his book above the usual environmental tract and makes it so compelling and involving is that he is genuinely besotted by fish, and his enthusiasm is infectious. A giant bluefin tuna jumps 50 yards from his boat, and he sees "the largest and most magnificent of animals, hung suspended for a long riveting moment, emblazoned and backlit like a saber-finned warrior from another world." He perceives in the scales of a just-landed salmon "a miniature gallery of abstract paintings, like an exhibit of similar lacquered works by the same artist, gathered and brilliantly displayed side by side so that the slight variations among them set up a subtle shimmer."
In his cautiously optimistic epilogue Safina mentions encouraging developments such as the revitalized striped bass run in the Atlantic, the 1995 United Nations ban on drift nets, new regulations requiring United States fisheries managers to end overfishing for most species and rebuild depleted populations and the increased awareness of fishermen from New England to Micronesia that their future depends on curbing overfishing and maintaining harvests at sustainable levels. But after the horror stories that have gone before, one finishes "Song for the Blue Ocean" wondering how this can be enough. The world's oceans are notoriously difficult to police, and as long as certain species of fish command astronomical prices (one 300-pound tuna recently sold for $83,500), and technology makes it easy to catch fish faster than they can reproduce, overfishing will continue, although perhaps at less catastrophic levels.
The best hope may lie in curbing demand, in more people coming to share Safina's insistence that fish must be seen "as wild animals in their habitats." If this happens, if the "sea ethic" he advocates becomes accepted and more people feel a sense of community with marine creatures, if it becomes as shameful to dine on rare fish lips as filet of gorilla, and pilots flying down the east side of Cape Cod again see schools of mackerel as large as Buzzard's Bay and the waters from Provincetown to Nauset white with schools of fish, then credit must certainly go at least in part to Carl Safina's landmark book.

LENGTH: 1040 words

HEADLINE: Surviving Fiscal Ruin (and Disco)

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN; Clyde Haberman writes the NYC column for The New York Times.

 BODY:
IN THE 70's, New York hit bottom.
Not that it stayed there for long. The city has always been too skilled at reinventing itself not to bounce back from hard times. But by the mid-70's, only an irredeemable optimist could keep the gremlins at bay, the ones that stalked the soul in the dead of night. Could it be, they hissed, that New York had finally had it? 
 There were so many reasons to answer yes, none more compelling than the discovery in 1974 that the city was broke.
A history of fiscal irresponsibility had finally caught up with it -- decades of doing nothing to stop the mass exodus of middle-class taxpayers or the wild spending on social services that could not possibly be afforded or City Hall's addiction to dubious fiscal gimmicks to keep itself afloat.
In 1974, the house of cards collapsed when banks refused to lend New York any more money. Bankruptcy loomed. The city had no choice but to swallow its pride and ask the Federal Government for a bailout, only to suffer the humiliation of having President Gerald R. Ford tell it to take a hike.
Eventually, the White House came through with Federal loan guarantees that enabled New York to get past the immediate crisis. But the initial rejection still stung. It had been been seared into the municipal consciousness by a 1975 headline in The Daily News that became an instant classic:
 
Ford to City:
Drop Dead
Lamentably, in the eighth decade of a unified New York, the rot went well beyond the local treasury. It ate into the very fabric of city life. Sure, there were periods when crime rates were higher and decades, like the 30's, when unemployment was a plague. But it is hard to think of times when New Yorkers felt as bad about themselves as they did in the 70's.
This was a decade when they learned about systemic police corruption and when Frank Serpico became a household name. It was a heart-of-darkness decade, the decade of the deranged killer known as Son of Sam. Terrorist bombings spread death in Manhattan and at La Guardia Airport, endless fires consumed the Bronx, and widespread looting accompanied a 1977 blackout, erasing memories of the we're-all-brothers sweetness that had marked the last big power failure, in 1965.
Longtime New Yorkers sensed their beloved city spinning out of control. Crime soared, and every other week seemed to bring a municipal strike. Garbage collectors walked out. So did doctors at city hospitals. In January 1971, the police went on strike for a few days, an action that was unheard of, not to mention illegal. Fortunately, temperatures hovered near zero the whole time. Even the muggers stayed home -- that's how cold it was. Crime actually went down while the cops were out.
The collapse of the old order was already detectable in the late 60's, only it did not feel so ominous, despite destructive episodes like a 1968 student strike at Columbia University. Change was taking place at every level.
I will never forget my shock on returning to New York in 1970 after two years in the Army, mostly in Europe. The beards, long hair, flamboyant clothes and foul language that used to be associated primarily with hippies and leftist rebels had gone mainstream. Even stockbrokers were dressing and talking like that.
Though odd, these stylistic innovations were not threatening. Other breaks from the past were merely wacky or giddy. Some were even hopeful. The once-hapless Mets did not just have a good team in 1969, their eighth year of existence. They won the World Series. Impossible! As impossible as a man walking on the moon, which, of course, also occurred in 1969.
As for local politics, what could be more screwy than two big-time writers running for high office: Norman Mailer for mayor and Jimmy Breslin for City Council president. Sure, they lost, which was probably just as well. But how could you not like a political campaign that ended with a candidate, Mr. Breslin, apologizing for having taken an active part in a process that closed the bars for a day?
The problem was there was so much change. It came so fast and so hard. And a lot of it was ugly. Even a city with infinite endurance could buckle, which is exactly what happened as the 70's wore grimly on.
New York almost gave up on itself. Brigades of businesses fled to the suburbs or left the region entirely, turning their backs on the city that had nurtured them.
Nothing of consequence ever seemed to get built in those days, and existing structures were being defiled by graffiti vandals. True, the World Trade Center was completed in the early 70's. But it was hardly the city's most glorious skyscraper and, besides, it had been planned long before.
Everywhere you turned, naysayers abounded. A new road was needed to replace the crumbling West Side Highway. Not a chance. Environmentalists blocked the project at every turn. It was almost as if the city had lost the ability to dream grandly, a failing that went beyond architecture. We had gone from the Champagne sophistication of Cole Porter in grandfather's day to the disco exhortations of the Bee Gees: uh uh uh uh stayin' alive. This was progress?
Then again, staying alive was the most many New Yorkers could think about. Broadway acknowledged as much when it moved up the evening curtain by an hour, to 7:30, so that tourists and suburbanites could make a clean getaway before the night stalkers filled Times Square.
HAVING said all this, let's be careful not to paint too depressing a picture. The second half of the 70's brought glimmers of hope for a city destined to rebound. The Broadway musical, which was ready to receive last rites, got a reprieve with "A Chorus Line." The long-dormant Yankees roared back. Operation Sail, a bicentennial spectacle of tall ships, lifted New York spirits. And in 1977, a new mayor was elected, one Ed Koch. He was certainly not fault-free. But he brought pizazz to a City Hall that had limped along under the colorless Abe Beame.
Even better, New York had the last laugh on Washington. The Democrats held their 1976 national convention at Madison Square Garden and went from that New York springboard to the White House. In the end, it was President Ford who was told by the voters to drop dead.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 32; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2230 words

HEADLINE: Whatever Happened to Politics?;
When Naptime Is Over

BYLINE: By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich, professor of social and economic policy at Brandeis University, was Secretary of Labor during President Clinton's first term.

 BODY:
There's no longer any political news, a reporter friend confided recently, explaining why "human interest" stories were oozing like syrup across his newspaper's front pages. We're in the Bland Decade now, a time when citizens march on Washington not to affect politics but to vow they'll be better people and when politicians speak out mainly to urge niceness: volunteer your time, enter into dialogues on race, hire someone off welfare, please. Apparently we need little more than charity, moral uplift and perhaps a modest program or two. Politics is dead, or so it seems.
The easiest explanation for this torpor is that the nation is fat, like an overstuffed bear starting hibernation. It's no longer the economy, stupid. Six years ago, a prolonged recession hurt white-collar workers, giving some urgency to the politics of "change." Prosperity, though, is a powerful sedative. Forget politics for now, we seem to be saying. Let's compare stock portfolios, banter about culture and identity and tut-tut over problems decades hence, like an insolvent Social Security trust fund or excessive greenhouse gases. 
 The great economic contests have been won. Communism vanished before it was even vanquished. The Japanese competitive threat is now a sorry heap of bad debt. European welfare states heave under double-digit unemployment. And here in the land of plenty we've never had it so good. Wealth is exploding, unemployment is at a 24-year low, inflation is quiescent (the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, publicly raised concerns about deflation), the stock market is riding high. American capitalism is the envy of the world.
But look more closely and the easy explanation falls short. Most Americans don't have it so good. They have jobs, but most wages and benefits are stuck or continue to drop. Wealth has exploded at the top, but the wages of people in the bottom half are lower today in terms of purchasing power than they were in 1989, before the last recession. This is in sharp contrast to every previous recovery in the postwar period. Corporate downsizing and mass layoffs are still the order of the day, which partly explains why so few workers demand raises in this tight labor market. They'd rather keep their jobs.
The reality is that Wall Street's advance hasn't been widely shared. The richest 1 percent hold more than 35 percent of the nation's wealth. The typical middle-class family has no more than $7,000 in stocks and $12,500 in mutual funds, according to a 1995 survey by the Federal Reserve and the Treasury Department. Even the recent market surge isn't likely to have changed this very much, given what has happened to wages.
Whatever savings Americans do have are imperiled by hospital bills. A growing portion of the public lacks health insurance -- in 1989, 33 million Americans under age 65 were without it; by 1996, 41.3 million. (The President's proposal to extend Medicare coverage to early retirees and displaced workers as young as 55, which would be the largest expansion in 25 years, is expected to add only 300,000 to the rolls.)
Despite the boom, inequality has widened. The nation's poverty rate is slightly higher than it was before the last recession. In 1989, 12.6 million, or 19.6 percent, of the nation's children lived in poverty; now it's 14.5 million, or 20.5 percent. The Conference of Mayors reports rising demand for food and shelter among the homeless. And the successes of the civil rights movement notwithstanding, today's urban schools are more racially segregated than in the 1980's.
So why, then, the prevailing political somnolence? Traditional politics has been all about who's gaining and who's losing. Yet it has lately become unfashionable, indeed in poor taste, to notice such things. In the present upbeat climate, downbeat data are slightly subversive. It is necessary to minimize all worry about the economy lest the public lose confidence, a perfect tautology. Bankers and business leaders have become cheerleaders in the nationwide pep rally. Onward! Upward!
Recent polls show, accordingly, high rates of consumer confidence. A record 40 percent of consumers queried in the Conference Board's December survey called jobs "plentiful," although, tellingly, only 28 percent expected their own wages to rise. These are the ones who have heard the distant roar of surging wealth and assume that the rising tide will lift them, too -- which may explain the record level of consumer debt. Personal bankruptcies are also at a record high.
Will politics revive when the economic tide ebbs and hardships appear like shipwrecks on the tidal flats? Not necessarily. Even in 1992, with the nation mired in recession, political engagement was grudging. Americans wanted "change" to get the economy moving again. But there was no sense of moral urgency. It was simply time to replace old management with new. Most Americans had long before stopped believing in government as a force for much good in their lives.
Some people will say we don't need a vital politics to be a vital society. We can expand the circle of prosperity through grass-roots moral activism, spearheaded by community groups, socially responsible businesses, not-for-profits, religious organizations and compassionate individuals -- perhaps all deftly linked by fax and modem, a "virtual" social movement. Commentators rightly stress the importance of such civic engagement. But they make a serious mistake labeling it as an alternative to politics. Throughout our history, civic activism has been the precursor, and the propellant, of political movements.
Almost a century ago, American politics appeared similarly listless despite growing social problems. As today, the economy was booming, jobs were plentiful and vast fortunes were being accumulated. Yet real wages had stopped growing, and the gulf between rich and poor was widening into a chasm. New technologies (steam engines, railway locomotives, the telephone, steam turbines, electricity) were transforming the nation, pulling families off the farms and immigrants from abroad and depositing many into fetid slums. Wall Street magnates were consolidating their empires. Government was effectively bought by large corporations, and the broad public was deeply cynical. William McKinley won re-election -- legend has it, on a pledge to "stand pat" -- and as the century closed, the nation seemed politically comatose.
Within three years, however, there was an outburst of reform: muckrakers like Lincoln Steffens and Ida Tarbell exposed corruption, and the middle class demanded fundamental change; small businessmen railed at monopolies; Wisconsin's crusading Governor, Robert La Follette, enacted legislation regulating health and safety in factories; Oregon limited the hours of work for women (no more than 10 per day); Theodore Roosevelt, McKinley's energetic Vice President who took over after McKinley was assassinated, set out to bust the trusts; suffragists marched; campaigns were organized for pure food and drug laws, workers' compensation and a minimum wage. Politics gained new life and meaning.
What happened? Indignation, which had been rising steadily, suddenly burst out and flooded the country. Citizens were already active at the local level, as they are today. Common morality simply couldn't abide the way things were going. Yet instead of opting for revolution or radical change, Americans preferred to spread the benefits of the emerging industrial economy, thereby saving capitalism from its own excesses.
Another foreshadowing occurred in the placid Eisenhower era. The overall economy was doing nicely then as well, even though its benefits had not reached the rural poor, many of whom were black. Politics had grown inert. Ike golfed. In 1954, the Supreme Court decided that separate schools were not equal. In 1957, Eisenhower dispatched Federal troops to Little Rock's Central High School. But who could have predicted that within a few years the civil rights movement would have remolded American politics with the Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Voting Rights Act of 1965?
The next revival of American politics can be expected to follow a similar course. The current economic boom has bypassed too many; the gap between winners and losers has grown too wide. Fortunately, there is a common morality at the heart of this capitalist democracy that ultimately keeps us on track and keeps us together. Glimpses of it can be had even in these languid times. For example, a majority of Americans supported last year's increase in the minimum wage to $5.15, although only a tiny fraction stood to benefit. It was a matter of simple fairness. Or consider the broad-scale indignation stirred up by revelations of garment sweatshops.
We got another glimpse this summer, when a sudden groundswell of support forced a skinflint Congress to extend health care to millions of children. And a majority of Americans supported the United Parcel Service strikers, not because the public is particularly fond of organized labor but because it seemed unfair for U.P.S. to pay its part-time work force so little.
Recall also the firestorm when, almost exactly two years ago, AT&T announced it was firing some 40,000 employees and then gave the boss stock options that raised his total compensation to $16 million, from $6.7 million. Recall, by contrast, the celebration of Aaron Feuerstein, the owner of Malden Mills in Lawrence, Mass., who, after his synthetic-fleece business burned to the ground, assured his employees that he'd stick by them until the factory was rebuilt.
The pressure keeps rising. A final glimpse came just before the holidays, when the public signaled unease about giving the President "fast track" authority to whisk trade treaties through Congress without amendment and most members of the House of Representatives, including many Republicans, refused to support it. That may be a mistake. Trade is good for America. But the public's negative reaction shouldn't be seen as a repudiation of free trade. It was, at bottom, a matter of fairness: trade hurts some people, and we haven't made adequate provision for the losers.
Trade may, in fact, be the precipitating issue this time around. The economic implosion in East Asia will continue to reverberate here, as bahts, won, rupiahs, ringgit and yen drop in value relative to dollars -- one of the biggest price-cutting contests in world history. American consumers will have the benefit of bargain-basement sales, but the cheap imports will put additional downward pressure on the wages of lower-skilled Americans. The tumult also will crimp profits of American companies that export to the region, causing more layoffs here. If the Asian flu turns more deadly, the infection here will be all the worse. However resolved, the Asian crisis portends larger jolts, as the global economy absorbs the surging output of 1.2 billion Chinese -- more than a fifth of the world's population. When the current recovery ends, the underlying reality will be starkly evident and the political debate surrounding trade will intensify.
To an extent, that debate has already begun. The tension between economic nationalism and globalism is emerging as one of the most significant fissures in American politics, and it runs through both parties -- as shown by the current dispute over financing for the International Monetary Fund.
But it would be unfortunate indeed if the revival of American politics were to turn on the question of whether the nation should engage in more or less commerce with the rest of the world. The underlying choice is larger, more important and more subtle: ultimately, we must decide whether we want to slow the pace of globalization or else take bold steps to help today's losers share in the benefits of the new economy. I cannot predict the outcome of that great debate to come, but I can express a clear preference. It is that we expand the circle of prosperity and that we do so on a scale that matches the challenge.
A new nationalism founded on shared prosperity might, for example, support "re-employment insurance" that would enable people who lose their jobs to move to new ones with far less disruption and pain than is the norm today. (If the new job paid less, half the difference should be offset for a year by a wage subsidy.)
In that spirit, we could enlarge and expand the earned-income tax credit -- a reverse income tax that makes work pay if you're at or near the bottom. We could bring a larger portion of the next generation into the circle of prosperity by rebuilding decaying schools and helping states equalize spending between rich and poor school districts. And we would make sure that everyone has access to adequate health care and child care.
To finance all of this -- and move beyond the small, feel-good programs that lack adequate scale to make much of a difference -- we could simply reverse the current trend in public finance and adopt a truly progressive tax system (including payroll taxes).
None of this will come easily or without a fight. But in the end, the nation will be stronger and better for bringing everyone, or nearly everyone, along. Future historians looking back on the Bland Decade will conclude that, as before, American politics wasn't really dead. It was only caught napping.
