PUB-DATE: January 25, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 26; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 4723 words

HEADLINE: Whatever Happened to Politics?;
Washington Is Not Where It's At

BYLINE: By Garry Wills; Garry Wills wrote for The New York Times Magazine most recently about the revival of the classics.

 BODY:
Is Bill Clinton our first post-political President? It is hard to find, anywhere on the current scene, a politics of the sort once recognized as serious. There are no great debates on great issues. Party loyalty is down, voter apathy up. The vacuum in political interest is filled more and more by obsession with headline trials -- William Kennedy Smith, the Tonya Harding affair, the Menendez brothers, O. J. Simpson, Marv Albert, Louise Woodward, the Unabomber case. What still passes for politics will be absorbed into the vortex of trials when Paula Jones's suit against the President is brought into the courtroom.
Political problems continue to plague our world -- the gathering crisis in funds for entitlement programs like Social Security and Medicare is one of them -- but we seem to lack the political machinery or public engagement to do much, if anything, about them. The welfare problem was put off rather than solved by "devolution." Even the conservative William Bennett says that devolution "has often meant reducing the Federal Government's capacity to monitor and correct." But since many other conservatives do not want the Federal Government to have any regulatory powers, the shifting of the problem satisfies antigovernment ideologues. 
 The President's only foreign-policy initiatives of last year, NATO expansion and "fast track" negotiating authority on trade, did not stir the public except (in the latter case) to opposition. Republicans in Congress were deserted even more spectacularly by their followers than were the Democrats on fast track by the labor unions. When Congress tried to implement the Gingrich "revolution" of 1995, it found that Congressional popularity ratings "fell like a rock" (in Bennett's phrase). Both the President and Congress seem like sailors in a dead calm. They work the rudder back and forth but nothing happens to make the boat respond. One needs at least some slight breeze of public opinion. But public engagement in politics has been so veering and contradictory as only to flap the sail sluggishly.
Without a stable structure of political debate, the electorate shows mood swings rather than a "climate of opinion." In 1994, Republicans interpreted some sour growling as a deep disgust with government. But by 1996, the swing toward complacency made Clinton so scandalproof that Bennett asked, "Have we lost our capacity for justified outrage?" The current prosperity cannot explain a falling off of political debate that precedes it. Whether the public is disaffected or complacent, the result seems the same -- stasis and dead air.
Perhaps we are not finding political life around us because we are looking for it in the wrong places. We may have to redefine politics, not confining it to high policy in foreign and economic affairs. Certainly the old party lines do not give us much guidance. In fact the parties have been changing places in a weird dos-a-dos. It was a Democratic President who said that "the era of big government is over" -- only to see a whole string of Republicans argue the need for strong central government. William Kristol, Eliot A. Cohen, David Brooks and John DiIulio have joined Bennett in saying that national greatness depends more on the approach of Alexander Hamilton and Theodore Roosevelt than on Reagan's maxim that government is the problem, not the solution. Faced with such role shifts, the public has a right to be puzzled, to say what the detective Philip Marlowe does when challenged to say whose side he is on. He just shrugs, "I don't even know who's playing today."
Confused or fading loyalty to the political parties made the commentator David Broder, long a champion of measures to strengthen the two-party system, give up on his efforts in 1996, when he wrote that Ross Perot was the one figure addressing new realities. I asked him about that at the 1996 California convention of Perot's political party, United We Stand America. He responded with a gesture at the proceedings, "This is the future." Well, it was yesterday's future. Futures, like everything else in today's politics, have a brief shelf life.
The emptiness of modern politics has come home with special force to conservatives, who feel they have won victory after victory with little to show for it. What does victory mean in a political vacuum? That is a question many conservatives are asking. Their discomfort has led to anguished symposiums on the possibility of a "conservative crackup." Contributors to one such discussion, in The Weekly Standard, had various explanations of the crisis. Some claimed that in a political situation where little if anything is firmly nailed down, Bill Clinton simply filched the conservatives' slogans and agenda, moving their accomplishments over into his win column.
Others, writing in the religious journal First Things, decided that in the absence of electoral impact, the Supreme Court is ruling the nation, unconstitutionally; so conservatives should consider going outside a political system that has no legitimacy. That is a measure of the desperation that can be caused by a "failure of politics."
Pat Buchanan has for a long time been saying that conservatives have won the political war but lost the cultural war. Politics with no cultural impact is a feckless exercise. Neoconservatives agree with that point, if not with other Buchananisms. And the neoconservatives' foe, R. Emmett Tyrell, who started the talk about a "conservative crackup" in an article 10 years ago and wrote a book by that title in 1992, traces the conservatives' feeble cultural impact to a lack of respected elders who could legitimize authentically conservative positions while marginalizing kooks and opportunists:
"There was a hierarchy of conservatives, but it was not acting as a hierarchy. It was not analyzing the younger conservatives' work. It was not pointing to new areas for conservative endeavors. It failed to recognize the charlatans among the younger conservatives and the bright fellows among the dolts. . . .It did not scotch the proliferation of fly-by-night organizations that were draining off the movement's precious funds."
Tyrell said the conservatives needed their own "wise men," who could do for them what Bernard Baruch or Clark Clifford had done for the liberals.
David Gelernter, the computer specialist, has tried to spell out the content of a cultural offensive of the sort Buchanan and Tyrell call for. He says conservatives must erect a counter-Establishment, complete with new universities that will be "apolitical," concentrating on the cultural arena previously abandoned to liberals: "I would put aside politics for a while and plant bushes, attempt to stabilize the culture."
The odd thing is that conservatives are calling for their own Establishment when what used to be called the Establishment has disappeared. It is quite true that there used to be an agenda-setting elite that informally decreed what political positions were serious, marginalizing all others. The tip of this Establishment iceberg was the "wise men," that body of elite corporate lawyers or investment bankers called in, when crises arose, to authenticate the needed policies. These men -- John J. McCloy, Robert Lovett, Dean Acheson, Chip Bohlen, Clark Clifford, George Kennan, Averell Harriman, Douglas Dillon and others -- were turned to by Republican as well as Democratic Presidents. Lovett, for instance, was favored for almost any position by Eisenhower and Kennedy. Kennedy called on the wise men for help in the Cuban crisis, and Johnson for his efforts to get out of Vietnam. (Getting in he had handled on his own.)
The wise men had high standards of public service, but their power did not come simply from their own integrity or charm. They had ties to the best universities and law firms, to philanthropic foundations and think tanks, to Wall Street, to the world of international finance, to "responsible" journalists like Walter Lippmann and James Reston. They embodied the shared ideals of these interlocking institutions and radiated their own authority back through what was taught, financed or published as politically serieux.
This Establishment was not liberal but centrist. That was its warrant for bipartisan consensus on the mixed economy (neither socialist nor unbridled laissez-faire) and on the international order (anti-Communist, nonisolationist, Eurotropic). From this assurance of centrality the Establishment could marginalize "extremists" -- a Joseph McCarthy on the right, a Henry Wallace on the left. Even in the narrow spectrum of Presidential politics, noncentrists could be marginalized -- Barry Goldwater on the right, George McGovern on the left. So powerful was this ideal of "mainstream" politics that historians at the peak of the wise men's influence read their ideals back through our national life to create the "consensus school" of American historiography. Talk of the "bland" Eisenhower era was a less flattering way to describe the same state of affairs.
This solid center of agreement underwent fission in the late 1960's. Walter Isaacson and Evan Thomas, who described the Establishment's 50-year reign in their book "The Wise Men" (1986), said that disagreement over the Vietnam War divided the wise men and their cognate academics -- a split made highly visible in the disagreement of Establishment journalists Lippmann (against the war) and Joseph Alsop (for the war).
I.M. Destler, Leslie Gelb and Anthony Lake, writing two years earlier in "Our Own Worst Enemy," thought the whole structure topped by the wise men was coming apart even before Vietnam. The wise men were the best representatives of a privileged elite with paternalistic motives of public service. After World War II, a meritocratic professionalism entered the governmental recruiting process. It allowed non-WASP, nonprivileged, nonamateur meritocrats -- Henry Kissinger, Stanley Hoffmann, Edward Luttwak, Walter Laqueur, Zbigniew Brzezinski -- to achieve an influence that would have been exercised earlier by heirs to a familial and legal "old boy" network. These new professionals did not have the assumed power of people whose careers rested on status and its presuppositions. Their rank depended on up-to-the-minute information, policy expertise and ambitious maneuvering.
I think one can go deeper, in 1997, than did those books of the 80's. The extraordinary authority of the wise-men structure arose in part from its ability to focus narrowly on what was circumscribed as "politics." Roughly, this amounted to high policy (foreign and economic) and its relation to national elections. Local police matters were not high politics as the wise men understood that. Averell Harriman was looked at askance by his peers when he ran for governor of New York -- which was more akin to garbage collecting than to wise-man policy-making.
Other parts of life were not directly political, because they defined themselves as subsidiary to the "real" issues. Religion was a private matter except when seen as a prop for the Establishment. Women, too, were not serious in political terms unless they rose by virtue of their association with Establishment men -- married to them like Eleanor Roosevelt or Lindy Boggs, dispensing their wealth to philanthropic and charity events or educating their daughters at finishing schools and Seven Sisters colleges. Though some of the wise men were notable womanizers, they disapproved when Nelson Rockefeller went beyond affairs to get a divorce. The family, like religion, was a civil institution making for stability.
Some of the wise men were racists -- not that it mattered, since racial relations were not a part of politics as they defined the subject. Such relations were adverted to mainly to keep them out of the sphere of high politics. George Kennan once wrote that the Founding Fathers would "turn over in their graves at the mere thought of the democratic principle being applied to a population containing over 10 million Negroes." In 1965, Kennan said, "I have a soft spot in my heart for apartheid," and he greeted racial unrest in 1968 by saying it is unrealistic "to suppose that the American Negro is going to find his dignity and comfort of body and mind by the effort to participate and to compete as an individual in a political and social system he neither understands nor respects and for which he is ill prepared."
I do not mean to castigate Kennan individually. He was voicing some of the maxims of his time and upbringing. Most of the wise men were born around the beginning of the century, and they reached their days of glory when they were already becoming anachronisms. But it is important to remember that an earlier form of "political correctness" let elite institutions deal with religion, women and blacks in demeaning ways.
David Gelernter, speaking for the conservative counterculturalists, agrees with the professionalization thesis to explain the downfall of the Establishment. He calls the professionals "intellectuals" and says the social elite committed suicide by admitting the intellectuals into positions of privilege. "Nothing compelled the Harvards and the Yales to change their ways. They did it by volunteering to make room for a new elite." In that sense, the fall of the Establishment was "a bloodless coup inside the generals' tent within the tiny upper stratum that calls the shots and sets the tone."
This view of elite-only actors is "top down" history with a vengeance. Actually, of course, many forces were in play -- demography, education, technology, the ideological aftermath of World War II. The work force was altered during that war by women's entry into it and by huge influxes of black labor moving up from the south (1.5 million people in the 1940's). American attacks on Hitler's "racism" (the word was invented during his rise) combined with the morale-boosting egalitarianism professed in the military to stir awareness of our own racial problems. Blacks, pressing for integration of the military under Truman, found it hard, on leaving the military base, to plunge back into segregation in the South.
The business side of the Establishment was, meanwhile, creating the affluence and technology that would erode its own connections with authority. Television brought alternate life styles into every living room. A youth culture grew up from the sale of music, movies, clothes and vehicles aimed at the teen-age market. College students now brought a whole culture of their own onto the campus, eroding the colleges' paternalistic (in loco parentis) role. Students did not go straight from their parents' house to an in-loco college, as before. They passed through an intermediary arena of rock music, youth-culture heroes and -- increasingly -- drugs.
In the 60's, this culture almost declared its independence from the earlier socialization processes for the young. Radicals were, by their own self-definition, not merely marginal to "the system" but opposed to it -- antipolitical in that sense. Hippies were hedonists not to be taken seriously except as symptoms of cultural decay. Yippies said hedonism could be a political act -- and they were right. The time of the radicals passed, but hippie culture, through all its manifold echoes, helped along the sexual revolution, the women's movement and changes in the context of marriage.
Conservatives like to treat the 60's as the end of civilization as we knew it, but the right, too, had a role in bringing a "marginal" cultural activity -- religion -- into politics. If abortion is murder, political opposition to it (or even more direct action) must be promoted. Operation Rescue deliberately imitated the civil rights movement's tactics, with Randall Terry delighting in "street theater." Fundamentalists, neglected by the Establishment (which only had eyes, occasionally, for "mainline" religion), gave up their former passivity to turn electoral politics toward things like school prayer, opposition to sex education and the distribution of condoms or the denial of rights to homosexuals.
The old Establishment quietly assumed that separation of church from state entailed a separation of religion from politics. But the First Amendment, which forbids the state from establishing a church, also provides for free exercise of religion and of speech, meaning that one can vote and argue from one's religiously formed conscience. There were many "walls of separation" in the old definition of politics. Each of these walls has been swept away in the last three decades. The citadel was not, as Gelernter argues, surrendered. It was engulfed.
The restriction of politics to "the system," which meant primarily the electoral system, can no longer be enforced. The women's movement did not score great electoral victories -- in fact, it lost the vote on the Equal Rights Amendment to Phyllis Schlafly's expertly organized opposition. But women's status changed, more than ever in human history, over the last three decades. This is a perfect example of what the conservatives call winning the political war and losing the cultural war. But it no longer makes sense to distinguish the two. Politics in the old sense has been emptied out. The fall of the Soviet Union shattered the cold-war consensus on foreign policy. The paralysis of economic initiatives -- temporarily by the deficit, in the longer range by growing entitlement spending -- has made "Establishment" domestic policy nonexistent. Real change -- sweeping, unprecedented change -- has not been taking place because of the electoral system. The electoral system is, instead, a lagging and imperfect indicator of such changes.
Right-wingers call it illegitimate for blacks or women or homosexuals to seek rights in the courts rather than by voting for candidates who agree with them. "Rights" has become a swear word on the right: we are too concerned with rights. We should go back to just counting votes. Republicans, not Democrats, are our new superdemocrats, the defenders of elections as the sole arbiters of political life. Everything else is "culture," and decadent -- feminism, affirmative action, gay rights, rock music, drugs, the whole evil catalogue.
The absurdity of trying to separate our current politics from culture is seen in Gelernter's proposal for counter-Establishment colleges and other institutions.
"The new institutions I have in mind would have no political agenda," he writes. "They would merely promote cant-free history, apolitical art, nonfeminist news reporting for the masses, the teaching of technique and not self-esteem, moral seriousness, ideology-free language -- items that today's elite despises and is attempting to destroy."
He advocates ideology-free language in ideology-laden language. Nonfeminism is, for him, "apolitical." "Cant-free history" is the old Establishment history, with George Kennan's politically correct views on women, blacks and religion. Gelernter is admirably candid about wanting to imitate the old Establishment, the one that was destroyed (he believes) by meritocratic "intellectuals." But that Establishment was built up on structures of privilege -- the right prep schools and colleges, the right clubs and relatives and law firms, the long experience derived from a semi-monopoly of prestigious positions. These things were not created overnight, and even they had to crumble in a vast sea of social change.
Gelernter cannot build on the kind of silent assumptions that were only "nonpolitical" because they were not, for a long time, challenged. He can find no Burkean subsoil from which to grow his institutions. They would have to be formed from raw and immediate attack on the "culture" he dislikes -- formed, in fact, with right-wing money coaxed from "nonintellectual" corporations and foundations on the promise of creating a nonintellectual elite, a new order of right-wing "wise men." Gelernter, to reach his goal, would have to give ideological preference to his weird form of "apolitical" students, just as the old Establishment favored its own kind, excluding Jews or blacks or Catholics or Asians.
It is interesting that conservatives, in order to wrest short-term gains against affirmative action, have become strict meritocrats themselves, considering only the individual's performance in deciding who gets into the right colleges or the right law firms. These superdemocrats ignore the way privilege was indulged in at most of our higher institutions of learning through most of their history. That privilege was justified as socially useful because it built up the shared experience and cumulative wisdom needed to guide the nation's economic and policy-making elite. It produced men like the wise men. If a quota kept out all but a few Jews, that was the price of training wise men.
The "culture" both Gelernter and his conservative fellows despise argues in the same way for socially useful preferences, but to serve egalitarian rather than elite values. It values sexual and ethnic diversity, and hopes to provide stimuli for the economically disadvantaged (as the old system provided cushions for the less-bright boys -- but not girls -- in the right families). Now goals are set for purposes of inclusion, not exclusion, to bring in more Americans, not to exclude one specific body. The comparison of affirmative action with old Ivy League quotas for Jews is disingenuous. White males are not targets for exclusion under affirmative action. They still make up the vast majority of people in colleges, law firms and corporations. What bothers some is that white males are not given the assured entry that upper-class WASP's used to have to "their" schools.
If culture is no longer neatly walled off from politics, does that mean that a flood of barbarism has inundated our institutions, as Allan Bloom and Robert Bork contend? Is right order falling victim to a "rights" culture? That is one (apoplectic) way of looking at our recent history.
Another way is to see the half-century of the Establishment as a deviation, one caused by the need to respond to a long-continuing crisis (Depression, World War, cold war), in which elites were given emergency powers. The longer-run progress of the nation was interrupted by this arrangement, delaying certain developments that rushed onto the scene when that interruption ended -- long-delayed business dealing with women's rights, with race relations, with child-rearing ideals.
The brightest side of American history has been the slow but persistent spread of egalitarianism. That ideal was there, though still nugatory, when Jefferson wrote that all men are created equal. By the 1820's, egalitarianism was pronounced enough for Tocqueville to find in it one of our definitive features -- even though slavery still existed in the 1820's, women could not vote and workers had few guaranteed rights. The rest of the 19th century saw the spread of equality. In the struggle over slavery, Lincoln encouraged us to read the Constitution, which lacks the words "all men are created equal," in light of that ideal (to the horror of a constitutional fundamentalist like Robert Bork). Freed blacks and voting women and children protected by child-labor laws still had a long way to go. It took the martyrdom of civil rights leaders to inch us on again in the unending war on racism. Women and homosexuals were pilloried for advancing their rights.
Some think that attention to different groups' rights is divisive, productive of social "balkanization." But these critics are the ones who speak as if attention to Martin Luther King in history books were a sop to blacks rather than a matter of pride for all Americans. The civil rights movement is our modern epic, the great social achievement of our time. Not to celebrate it is not to be truly alive to our own achievements. The current changes in women's status, unparalleled in the past, recognize the talents and dignity of more than half the human race, a momentous activity that goes to the inmost nexus of society, affecting the relations of wives to husbands, daughters to fathers, sisters to brothers, mothers to daughters. It is one of the most exciting breakthroughs in all of human history. Yet the "non-divisive" and "apolitical" Gelernter wants to set up new institutions to oppose this development by ignoring it, to achieve "nonfeminist" news reporting. Not reporting the advances of feminism now would be like not reporting the Civil War in the 1860's because ending slavery had its unpleasantnesses.
The egalitarianism of our culture affects everyone today, even the right-wingers who deplore many of its aspects. Advanced interactive communication -- call-in radio and television programs, the Internet, cellular phones -- all these encourage each person to have an equal say in things, to be his or her own expert; and no one has leapt at this opportunity more than conservatives. These right-wingers have taken up Tom Hayden's old concept of "participatory democracy." They won't let the powers that be tell them what to think. Such conservatives are rights-oriented. They think rights are being taken from them by the courts, by affirmative action, by religious discrimination. They propel the culture even as they denounce it.
I go back to my beginning. Is Bill Clinton our first post-political President? If we take "politics" in the old Establishment sense -- international and economic policy, along with the electoral system -- then he definitely is. The proof is here: his early priorities on taking office were "rights issues" -- recognizing gay rights in the military and working for greater participation of women in the Government. Those who judge politics by the old standards said that these actions showed he was not a "serious" politician but a marginalized one, an extremist. Well, perhaps he was premature, and certainly he was not deft in his handling of either issue. But he, not his critics, was recognizing the real world we live in. This, Mr. Broder, and not Ross Perot, "is the future."
Many people continue, if only subconsciously, to treat cultural questions -- "rights" issues, "identity politics," "multiculturalism" -- as intrusions into "real" politics. They act as if these were fads of the 60's, bits of hedonism or "self-expression" that will pass away when Americans become adults again. But coping with the vast culture of change now at work will provide the challenge of coming years. What is America as a social entity going to make of itself?
The explosion of ethnic diversity guarantees that affirmative action of some sort will be needed so that everyone feels a stake in a country that is literally changing complexion every day: whites will be a minority by early in the next century. What does that imply about the education, cultural heritage and social values of a community also undergoing technological changes of a dizzying sort? Panicky clampdowns on immigration will not put off the basic change in the makeup of our population.
Women will keep changing the shape of family life. Businesses will continue to use affirmative action, to the disgust of many conservatives, to accommodate diversity of customers and workers. (Right- wingers deplore the open recognition of homosexuals, but businesses know that gay and lesbian buying power, at an estimated $100 billion a year, is greater than that of, for instance, far more numerous blacks.)
People who deplore "rights politics" ain't seen nothin' yet. Rights to privacy, access and inclusion will be in play and in question at every level of our changing society and will spill over from the schools, the churches, the courts and the media into electoral politics.
John Kennedy said that a generation tempered by World War II was equipped to handle the cold war. He was describing, though he did not know it, the peak time and the passing of the old politics of the Establishment. Now a generation that experienced the deep social re-evaluations of the 60's is the one that can cope with the ongoing consequences of that reorientation. Politics in this new sense is alive and well -- indeed too lively for some people's nerves. And there are no wise men around to salve things for us. We may have to rely on wise women.

HEADLINE: Masks and More: Art Objects of Oceania

BYLINE: By BESS LIEBENSON 

 BODY:
VIEWERS may be transported to the other side of the world, to the Sepik River region of New Guinea, considered the most important art center in the region known as Oceania. In "Spirit Images: The Lidz Collection of Southwest Pacific Art," an exhibition at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History in New Haven through Sept. 27, themes include the separation of sexes and relationship of the dead to the living.
The exhibition is drawn from the private collection of Theodore and Ruth Wilmanns Lidz, psychiatrists who, in the early 1970's collected extensively in Melanesia. Their acquisitions, donated to the Peabody Museum in 1986, document the culture of Zanuatu and parts of Papua New Guinea, just as those areas were beginning to experience extensive contact with other cultures. 
 New Guinea is divided into two culturally contrasting areas. "The people of the central highlands place importance on individual economic success, experience minimum cult life and religious ceremonies, do not venerate war heroes and conspicuously lack art, except in forms of singing and bodily decoration," said Leopold J. Pospisil, Peabody curator emeritus and professor emeritus of anthropology, who spent three years (beginning in 1954) as the first white man to enter and research the unmapped highlands of New Guinea.
In contrast, Mr. Pospisil said, "the lowland people emphasize ceremonial warfare, sometimes combined with cannibalism, are preoccupied with religious ritual and cult life and are unusually gifted in wood carving." The most intricate wood carvings spring from areas of the middle and lower Sepik River and its tributaries, the Yuat and Keram. Since prehistoric times the river has been the artery along which aboriginal traders transported and sold carvings for use in secret rites and elaborate public ceremonies. The Sepik peoples produced objects like suspension hooks, canoe prow figures, flute stoppers, masks, plaques, shields and chair-shaped lecterns.
Entry to the Peabody exhibition is through a permanent exhibition in the hall of Native American cultures. Swathed in red, it becomes a promenade and prologue to the exhibition of the moment. Songs and chants from the interior of New Guinea, recorded by Mr. Pospisil, add a compelling quality to an exotic setting: floors shimmering black, walls shaded in blue and painted with tropical foliage. And by a mechanical trick, shadows, clouds, even forest vapors appear to roll by.
The exhibition opens with an ornately carved canoe, its prow sculptured into stylized hornbill birds, set in an improvised sea. A carved head on the wall represents a human skull. "They originally used real skulls that they pasted over and painted," Mr. Pospisil noted. Multilevel cubes zig-zag in a circle heralding objects: lime containers, headdresses, beak-like masks inlaid with shells and a sacred flute stopper. Individual flutes played during male adult-initiation ceremonies were believed to emit voices of the spirits.
Men were initiated by elaborate rituals into graded societies, during their lives progressing through the ranks. A highlight display is of a men's house, used for secret rites, a storehouse and center of ceremonial life. Thatched with palm leaves, the tall facade reveals an interior of vividly painted bark clothes and masks. Outside, a stool, carved from a single piece of wood, depicts a male ancestral figure supporting a seat on his shoulders. Speakers, emphasizing a motion, beat the seat with palm leaves.
"Collections like this are invaluable, not only because they cannot be duplicated," said Richard L. Burger, director of the Peabody Museum, "but also because they exemplify the critical stages a culture has gone through as it transforms itself over time."
"Colonialism destroyed their art," Mr. Pospisil added. "In the lower Sepik River, the people are now resurrecting their lost art, copying the art of their ancestors from museums in the West."
The Peabody Museum of Natural History (170 Whitney Avenue, New Haven) is open Monday-Saturday 10 A.M.-5 P.M., Sunday noon-5 P.M.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Wooden suspension hook with crocodiles flanking male figure. From upper Sepik, New Guinea, a wooden board mask with stylized face carved in relief (eyes and nose cut out) and painted. At the Peabody: Painted wooden debating stool, left, from the middle Sepik River region of New Guinea and, above, carved standing palm figure from Atchin Island, Vanuatu, New Guinea.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1957 words

HEADLINE: Retirees, Refusing to Stand Pat, Infuse Communities

BYLINE: By JOY ALTER HUBEL

 BODY:
WHOEVER said there's no future in retirement should meet Marvin Levine. Since resigning from the Psychology Department of the State University at Stony Brook six years ago, he has been writing and publishing poetry, playing in an orchestra and giving lectures on the psychology of Buddhism.
"The thought of retiring to Florida to be in summer camp the rest of my life just didn't interest me," said Mr. Levine. 
 Many Long Islanders share his view, and are discovering a rich variety of pleasures and possibilities in the region, experts say.
Rene Iacona, Commissioner of Nassau County Department of Senior Citizen Affairs, noted that many people now reaching their 60's were healthy, well educated and eager to continue contributing meaningfully to their communities.
"They want to stay near their families, or are being asked to help with their grandchildren," she said. "Long Island has a lot to offer these older adults. We have great health care, great parks, lots of culture and a low crime rate."
Prof. Christopher Hayes, director of the Gerontology Center at Long Island University's Southampton campus, agrees that Southern migration among the retired has slowed, and adds that many older adults were becoming influenced by their children's progressive ideas on retirement.
"There is an anti-aging rebellion going on in some groups of the retirement population," he said. "You are seeing an intergenerational exchange of concepts in which older generations are looking at younger generations and attempting to have the kind of free-spirited retirement their children aspire to."
This intergenerational exchange is producing a curious reversal in which the parents have become the social radicals and their children the economic conservatives, said Rhoda Spinner, a retired teacher and the event coordinator of Stony Brook's Round Table, an educational cooperative run by and for retired adults.
While baby boomers, the original practitioners of the alternative life style, are working the 10-hour-day treadmill, Ms. Spinner indicated, their parents, former bulwarks of conformity, are traveling, fulfilling their artistic longings and lobbying for social change.
Louis Boroson, a retired high school teacher from Stony Brook, became a volunteer for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. last year, and spent last summer in New York City, picketing with striking steel workers and petitioning against sweat shops.
Mickey and Arthur Meyer of Stony Brook worked on the restoration of a pueblo church in New Mexico.
Robert and Irma Mandel, retired teachers from Huntington Station, have spent parts of their retirement trekking through the Himalayas, snorkeling in Belize, teaching English in Japan and backpacking in Australia. The Mandels are leading a life style more like college students than retired teachers.
"We took early retirement 10 years ago when we were 55, and we haven't regretted it for a minute," Mr. Mandel said. "But we lived very frugally, at least for the first few years, and had to do some careful financial planning to make it possible."
At the start of their retirement, they moved to Japan, where they subsisted on the local economy while teaching English. After three months of living in an apartment the size of a futon, they saved enough for a trip around the world. Since then, they have crisscrossed the globe several times, stopping in Laos, Nepal, China, Thailand, Australia, Bali and Tibet. Last year, the Mandels canceled a planned trip to Syria when the country announced a cholera outbreak, but barring plague and pestilence, nothing much stops them.
Whenever they return from foreign trekking, the Mandels take their travel slides on the road to libraries and schools throughout Long Island. Their photographs form the core of a program in which they chronicle the various countries they visit, using, as props regional artifacts and dress.
"We show slides that portray the country," said Ms. Mandel. "Our photos of Laos capture the real country. Most Laotians, for example, live in straw shacks that have been built on stilts to protect against monsoons. Their villages have neither electricity nor plumbing. They bathe in the Mekong Delta and feed their livestock from the shell casings left from the Vietnam War."
Ms. Mandel said that she and her husband tried to convey the material poverty as well as the cultural richness of these countries.
"We American's don't realize how many comforts we have, and how well we live compared to the rest of the world," she said.
The Mandels say that their programs are particularly popular among the elderly, who attend the travelogues to satisfy their own world curiosity, without having to leave town themselves.
For those less itinerant retirees on the Island, there are ample avenues of enrichment right off the Long Island Expressway. Of growing popularity are the university-sponsored Learning in Retirement programs, where seniors can embark on the self-exploration that was once the specialty of their college-bound children 30 years ago.
Five Learning in Retirement programs exist in the region, including Stony Brook's Round Table, the Center for Creative Retirement at Long Island University's Southampton campus, the Professional and Executive's Retirement Center at Hofstra, the Institute for Life Long Learning at Molloy College and the Institute for Learning and Retirement at SUNY Farmingdale.
Though each program has its own personality, they function in much the same style. For a yearly fee of about $200, the retirees can take a variety of peer-taught courses, ranging from the academic to the practical. At Hofstra, for example, "The Byzantine Dynasty" is offered along with "Introduction to Computers."
For the price of enrollment, program members have access to many of the sponsoring university's offerings, including gym, library, cultural events, classroom space and auditing privileges.
They also enjoy unique social advantages. "People form relationships not on the basis of age, but on the basis of common interests," said Carl Siegel, president of the Round Table.
Many of the learning centers also encourage their members to do volunteer work on campus, as a way of giving back to the community that supports them. The Round Table, for example, surveys the skills of its enrollees and places them in volunteer roles within the university.
"We have members who are career counseling, tutoring and mentoring students throughout the campus," said Mr. Siegel.
Most learning in retirement programs operate like co-ops, with members both creating and consuming the principal commodity, which is knowledge. Those who take courses also give back, through teaching or volunteering. Program instructors have creative leeway in presenting their subjects. They can invite guest lecturers from within the university, have students attend cultural events on campus or plan outside trips.
"At first, we started planning day trips," said Ms. Spinner. "We've been to Harlem, to the Monet exhibit at the Brooklyn Museum, to the city for operas and plays. These trips worked so well that we got a bit braver and started planning weekend jaunts to places like Tanglewood and Philadelphia. Now 60 of us are going to Turkey in the spring."
Some speculate that Long Island colleges, so effective at addressing the social and intellectual needs of the retirees, might be on the verge of doing something about their housing too. Mr. Siegel and Ms. Spinner said that developers were considering building a retirement community to be affiliated with Stony Brook University, on adjacent property.
This college-retirement connection is not as much of a stretch as it seems, at least in other parts of the country. Many universities, including Duke, Yale, Cornell and the University of Virginia, are medically or financially affiliated with retirement communities
In part, the growth of continuing care communities across the country is reinforcing the college-retirement connection.
A continuing care community is a one-site-fits-all retirement complex. It provides a mix of independent housing, assisted living and nursing-home care on one campus. Residents move through these graduated levels of care on an as-needed basis. Many continuing care communities are being built in college towns to take advantage of the health care services and enriched cultural life the universities provide.
Though popular in other states, continuing care communities have been slow to develop in New York. The state's restrictive legislation prevented their development. New legislation, passed last September, reverses many of those restrictions and gives potential continuing care community sponsors a wide range of financing and contracting options.
Residents can either purchase continuing care units as a source of equity or rent them. Additional entrance and monthly fees pay for maintenance and health care costs over the life of the tenant.
Peconic Landing in Southold, which is based on the equity model, will be Long Island's first continuing care community. U.S. Retirement Communities Inc., a Pennsylvania-based builder of retirement complexes in Arizona and Pennsylvania, is developing it. .
Peconic Landing will begin construction in the fall of 1998, but has already begun marketing its 250 independent units. The units, to be built on waterfront property, will sell for $200,000 to $450,000. There will also be assisted living quarters and nursing beds. Its list of amenities reads like the contents of a resort brochure, and includes pools, tennis courts, library, barbershop and beauty salon, auditorium, recreational programs, maid service and dining. Continuing care communities like Peconic Landing appeal mostly to upper-income retirees. They do little to alleviate the housing shortage many middle and lower income retirees face.
By the year 2000 more than 20 percent of Long Island's population will be over 60. This demographic tilt, which will become even more pronounced when baby boomers begin turning 60 in another decade, has made housing a particularly visible target of change, said Lee Koppelman, director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board.
"Once upon a time, Long Island towns refused to zone for adult condominiums and apartment-style residences," he said. "They were afraid it would impoverish schools, reduce tax bases and destroy the suburban landscape. But now many of the people who opposed these residences 20 years ago are the ones who need them most."
Commissioner Iacona already sees a concerted effort on the part of developers to meet the housing needs of the aging. And because Suffolk Country has more space, and lower property taxes than neighboring Nassau, it is likely to be the recipient of much of that development.
Suffolk County, and particularly the East End, has already become a retirement mecca. Approximately 27 percent of the population in eastern Suffok is 60 years and older. This trend is fueled, in part, by many empty-nest couples, who are transforming their summer cottages into year-round retirement homes. With its natural beauty, convenient transportation into New York City and innumerable cultural resources, an East End retirement appeals to many who would ordinarily be lured south.
Fran Kelly, a librarian at Suffolk Community College and a former resident of Smithtown, recently bought a home in Southampton. "The towns out here are small, intimate and picturesque," she said. "It's next to impossible to find this kind of small town life style in other suburban areas of Long Island. And then of course, there's the beach," which, Ms. Kelly said, is as beautiful as anything Florida has to offer.

HEADLINE: Q&A: David Lerner;
Advocating a 'Safe' Route in Investment

BYLINE: By SUSAN KONIG

 BODY:
"THE tree doesn't grow to the sky," said David Lerner, referring to recent record highs set by the stock market. As chief executive officer of the Syosset-based David Lerner Associates, one of the nation's largest regional dealers of municipal bonds, Mr. Lerner recommends that investors put just a small portion of their investable assets into the stock market, with the remainder in "safe" investments like tax-free and zero coupon bonds.
His message is conveyed often through his regular seminars and well-known radio ad campaign, in which he asks listeners to "Take a tip from Poppy." His company, which has five locations including Wall Street, Teaneck, N.J., and Coral Springs, Fla., helps investors create retirement portfolios consisting mainly of conservative, fixed-income vehicles. Mr. Lerner is a graduate of the City University of New York, where he also earned a master's degree. He was a history and economics teacher in the South Bronx, then at Bayside High School in Queens -- until 1976, when he entered the financial services industry full-time. 
 Mr. Lerner lives in Jericho with his wife, Lois. They have two children and three grandchildren.
Q. How did you go from school teacher to running your own brokerage?
A. It's something I never expected to do. In 1960, I took a part-time job selling mutual funds to help make ends meet. But, it couldn't have been more out of character for me. I was a teacher -- the scholarly type -- and my views at the time weren't very business-like. Politically, I was very liberal -- you might even say I was a Socialist. My credo was, "Man doesn't live by bread alone."
But I got into the business because I believed I could apply the skills I used as a teacher, like communication and organization, to "educate" clients -- make them familiar with all different types of conservative investments. The approach worked. In 1976, I started David Lerner Associates, and it's been my life ever since. We're still very educational. We put concepts into understandable language so that everyone can see how investments work. My seminars are very much like being in a classroom. I think what I've really done is just continued my teaching career.
Q. You favor the heavy use of fixed-income vehicles and are rather leery of the stock market?
A. From the very start, we've focused on investments with relatively little risk so that our clients would know what they'd be getting in returns. They knew there was a guaranteed maturity date, etc. Our main focus in the early years -- and to a large degree today -- is tax-free municipal bonds. The attraction is a very high historical degree of safety, the fact that you have these significant tax advantages and that you know you're going to get 100 cents on the dollar at maturity. Your interest rate won't go up or down; it's a fixed rate of return. And this is a liquid investment.
Q. Why do you take such a conservative approach?
A. We believe that sharp declines in the stock market should make for interesting dinner conversation, but they shouldn't be a matter of life and death. If they are, you've made some very bad investment decisions. For almost all people, at least 80 percent of your assets should be in predictable investments that are out of harm's way. Once you've built a firm foundation, if you have other moneys which, if you lose, your world won't change, then you can afford to be speculative. Then, stocks and growth mutual funds may make good sense for you.
Q. What do you say to people who've seen considerable success in the stock market?
A. The stock market is not a panacea; it's a very fickle lady. We've been around long enough to know this. Tell this to people who've done well in it, and they may say, "That's great advice; let's give it to someone else." But, in my mind, it's not much different from meeting someone in a gambling casino who just won a great deal of money and telling him: "Be careful. You should stay away from this casino." If his pockets are full of money, the message isn't going to fall on fertile ears. But I'm telling you that if he continues to go, he'll give that money back and then some. We find that, when people need their money the most, that's usually when the stock market's taking it on the chin. So, if you make money with stock investments, my advice is to take most of it off the table and put it into safer vehicles.
Q. What is the appeal of zero coupon bonds?
A. You can buy them very deeply discounted. Let's say you buy $10,000 bonds for $3,000 each. Fifteen years from now, they're guaranteed for the full face value of $10,000. In the meantime, if it's a municipal bond, you don't pay any taxes. These are long-term investments, and they're ideal for financing college educations. When a child is born, a lot of grandparents buy zero coupon bonds as gifts. If they invest $30,000, for example, 18 years later, when the child is ready for college, they'll be worth $100,000. This is incredibly important, because the cost of private schools has skyrocketed. When my daughter was in college 10 years ago, I paid $60,000 for her tuition, and I thought that was astronomical. Today, that same education costs $125,000.
Q. Are conservative investors at risk of not keeping up with inflation?
A. We believe that, for the last 15 years, there's been almost no inflation. And interest rates have been declining. Not in a straight line, of course, but the trends have been lower. We don't believe inflation will be a major issue in the foreseeable future.
I think, as the economy becomes more global, competition from all over the world tends to keep prices down and put a lid on inflation. Some of the leading economists are talking about deflation. None of what's developing in the global or domestic economies looks to me like it's inflationary. In fact, it's quite the contrary.
Q. What about younger investors? Should a 35-year-old be as conservative as, say, a 55-year-old?
A. No. But by the same token, we'd still counsel him to build a strong base, have a significant amount of assets in investments where he won't have to worry about his money declining or vanishing overnight. I recommend this for people of all ages -- with no equivocation.
Q. Are people planning for retirement early enough?
A. It's very difficult for young people, given the nature of their life styles, to accumulate assets. They want two and three cars, vacations, etc. They live well, but I think many live from paycheck to paycheck.
It's hard to start planning early, yet I feel you should make every effort to. A good rule of thumb is, if you're making a dollar, live on 90 cents, and put away a dime. With personal bankruptcy and credit card delinquencies at an all-time high, I suspect a lot of people aren't doing this. But they should be.
Q. In 1993, you added real-estate investment trusts (REITs) to the list of products you market. What are they, and why do you like them?
A. They're basically companies or trusts that gather capital from investors to buy various forms of real estate, like homes, malls or offices. Investors get dividend income from the tenants who rent space in the properties. We felt that, as a result of the real estate debacle of the late 1980's and early 1990's, the market was quite ripe for REITs. We got together with a property manager in Richmond, Va., who'd spent 20 years buying and managing residential properties in the southeast. He approached me in 1992 with the concept that we could buy residential properties rather cheaply, because they were in a depressed situation, and we'd do it all for cash.
In 1993, we began the Cornerstone REIT. We added it to our product menu because we felt it had many of the same characteristics as the products we'd always favored. It was a high-income type of product with relatively little risk, and we'd list it on the stock market so it would be liquid. Today, it's worth more than $500 million and is the widest-held REIT in the world.
Q. You have a REIT in Dallas-Fort Worth. How important is location?
A. Well, we think we've hit a gold mine. The Dallas-Fort Worth area is one of the most rapidly growing areas in the country. We're buying residential apartments there for cash. So many young people are migrating into the area because of the growth of all kinds of business opportunities. It's become a premier hi-tech state, which creates ideal circumstances for a REIT.
Q. How would you advise people to create investment portfolios?
A. First, start saving money, because there's no magic formula for accumulating assets. Then, you should build up things you can depend on. There should be money in the bank and in money market accounts. As it builds, begin to buy tax-free bonds, if you're able to. REITS, which aren't leveraged, are great for young people. Mortgages are what bring real estate down, so you're giving yourself the chance to participate in the real-estate market without having to take a huge risk. The bottom line is, if you build your life around the belief that a certain stock or mutual fund is going to go crazy, you're in for a serious letdown.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Lerner, chief of David Lerner Associates, one of the largest regional dealers of municipal bonds. (Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: He Did It His Way, Or Else

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS; Sam Roberts is the deputy editor of the New York Times's Week in Review section.

 BODY:
MOSES is immortalized all over New York City -- but it's the guy who parted the Red Sea, not his namesake. He was the Moses who parted East Tremont by gouging out the Cross-Bronx Expressway and linking the suburbs with the city via bridges, expressways and parkways to deliver commuters to their promised land.
For reshaping the cityscape, all Robert Moses got were plaques on the fence of a First Avenue playground , at a plaza on the West Side campus at Fordham University and on a drab administration building on Randalls Island. 
 By 1981, when he died at age 92, few if any municipal officials had chosen to honor Moses, as his acolytes had done outside the city, by naming giant power plants and beaches and highways after him. By then, his very name had become a synonym for imperiousness. Nearly a decade earlier, Robert A. Caro's biography, "The Power Broker," monumental in its own right, had brutally punctured the Moses myth, depicting him as an arrogant genius whose ruthlessness spawned a backlash of decentralization and community vetoes that would hobble his possible successors.
Arrogant or not, Moses was a genius.
As head of a dozen city and state authorities and commissions, he wrapped New York in 627 miles of expressways and parkways, expanded its parks by 20,000 acres, built 658 playgrounds and filled in so much shoreline that its land area grew by 15,000 acres -- the equivalent of another Manhattan. He oversaw construction of public-housing projects for 555,000 people, about the same number he evicted. "I raise my stein," he wrote, "to the builder who can remove ghettos without moving people, as I hail the chef who can make omelets without breaking eggs."
MOSES began his rise by insinuating himself with Gov. Al Smith as a young idealist; he then parlayed his power by generously dispensing legal graft. Before Moses was even old enough to vote, Andrew H. Green, the father of New York's consolidation, had united disparate cities and towns into the critical mass that would make it Greater New York. Other visionaries invested in a subway system, which forged a single city from Green's blueprint. But, more than any other person, Moses shaped the city's physical face, and much of its social destiny, for very nearly half the 100 years that it rose and stumbled and rose again.
Would the city have been better off without him? Even Mr. Caro wrote that "Robert Moses may have bent the democratic processes of the city to his own ends to build public works; left to themselves, these processes proved unequal to the building required." Moses and the expansionist era he typified are easier to judge in hindsight. Headlines nowadays resonate with the unresolved conflicts that he personified: between urban development and democracy and between mass transit and motorists.
Moses' distrust of democracy might have been rooted in personal experience (he offered himself for mayor in 1933 and governor in 1934 and was soundly rejected), but he insisted that most people benefited from his public projects. He never lost the illusion that if New Yorkers knew what good was, they would embrace his brand of benevolent despotism.
Moses' favorite aphorism was, "If the ends don't justify the means, what does?"
He would be remembered for both.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
8 New Start-Up Incubators for Business Proposed

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
SINCE its purchase in 1996 of a 240,000-square-foot office building in Bethpage from Northrop Grumman, Briarcliffe College has refurbished half the structure for its academic needs and leased out 104,000 square feet to others.
But Briarcliffe's Board of Trustees also has another enterprise in mind. With the nonprofit Briarcliffe Foundation as the sponsor it hopes to turn the remaining 22,000 square feet on the building's second floor into an "incubator" to nurture start-up companies involved with software development. 
 Two companies, Valid Data, which develops software for the furniture industry, and Current Legal Resources, which collects and publishes legal information, have moved into a total of 2,000 square feet. But the incubator is not yet in operation since more than $500,000 is needed to divide the space for an anticipated total of up to 19 companies and provide high-speed data lines and other services.
"We feel that the computer software industry should be supported and what we are hoping to do is develop companies that eventually will provide work opportunities for all Long Island," said Richard B. Turan, president of the college, which specializes in business and technology.
New York State has 38 incubators, but only one -- the Long Island High Technology Incubator on the campus of the State University of New York at Stony Brook -- is on Long Island. Now there are proposals under way to add eight including the one at Briarcliffe. The proposals depend on the availability of public funds to help with construction, but thereafter incubators would be self-sustaining, according to their proponents.
A pilot program has been started at another of the proposed locations, the State University of New York at Farmingdale. The nonprofit Long Island Forum for Technology now has a 6,000-square-foot incubator there, but is working with the university and others on the design of an incubator with as much as 40,000 square feet of space.
"You need incubators to support companies in their formative stages, otherwise the companies go elsewhere," said Peter S. Goldsmith, director of economic development for the Long Island Association in Commack.
The business group started a program called Project Long Island three years ago to keep high technology manufacturing jobs in the region following job losses in military contracts.
The electronics, printing, medical imaging and health information systems, biotechnology and computer software industries are key to providing those jobs and must be nurtured, Mr. Goldsmith said.
Business incubators are becoming increasingly popular economic development tools throughout the country, growing from only 12 such programs as recently as 1980, to almost 600 today. In addition to providing inexpensive space, their value lies in giving start-up companies access to other ongoing research because they are usually situated in an academic setting.
A RECENTLY completed study conducted by the University of Michigan, the National Business Incubation Association and Ohio University in Athens and the Southern Technology Council in Research Triangle Park in North Carolina found that entrepreneurial companies that graduate from incubators have an 87 percent survival rate and that 84 percent remain in their communities. In 1996, such companies created an average of 468 direct jobs and 234 spinoff jobs.
"I am a firm believer in the ability of incubators to support a spawning stream of high technology, particularly on Long Island," said James Hayward, co-chairman of the Long Island Regional Incubator Task Force. The group was formed two years ago by Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's economic development and job creation agency.
The purpose of the task force, whose other chairman is Thomas F. Gallagher, is to assess the need for incubators on Long Island and recommend ways to implement them. Dr. Hayward is president of the Collaborative Group of East Setauket, a biotechnology company. Mr. Gallagher is the director of manufacturing business development for Empire State.
The task force received 27 incubator proposals. It combined them into eight, "ruling out none," Dr.Hayward said. "The eight could provide in excess of 10,000 new jobs over the course of a decade," he added.
In addition to Briarcliffe and Farmingdale, proposed sites include North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, Dowling College in Oakdale, Freeport, Calverton and additional space at SUNY Stony Brook. The task force is recommending a five-year program involving both new construction and adaptations of space in existing buildings.
The projected cost of the eight proposals would be $95.4 million of which New York State's share would be $30 million, according to a letter supporting the incubator proposals that was sent to Gov. George E. Pataki by 19 of 22 of Long Island's Assembly membersmen. The remaining cost would be paid out of Federal matching grants and private loans and investment.
Computer Associates International of Islandia, another leading software company, already announced earlier this month that it would help finance a separate 6,000-square-foot software incubator at the Stony Brook campus, with the university also picking up some of the cost. Computer Associates will contribute several hundred thousand dollars over three years, said Marc S. Sokol, the company's senior vice president of advanced technology.
Stony Brook's existing incubator has attracted mainly biotechnology companies."There is enough biomedical research being done between New York City and Long Island to generate enough technology to spawn hundreds of new companies," said Francis P. Hession, the president and managing director of the incubator.
"Unfortunately, there has been a tremendous loss of both brainpower and economic viability as these companies go elsewhere," he said. "But by having incubators as a structured way to transfer technology to private industry, we can attract venture capital, which now goes from New York to California."
SUNY at Stony Brook had housed start-up companies in various campus buildings until 1992 when the state provided a $1.2 million grant to build the 42,000-square-foot incubator. The building offers both office and laboratory space along with support services. Loans, which provided the remaining $5.9 million needed for construction, are being paid off out of rents paid by its 30 tenants.
IN 1994, 30,000 square feet more were added with the help of a $3.6 million state grant. The incubator has already graduated 20 companies that now employ 900 people and generate $75 million in revenues annually, Mr. Hession said.
One graduate is Dr. Hayward's company, the Collaborative Group, which among other ventures is the world's largest manufacturer of liposomes -- artificial structures similar to a human cell that are used in gene therapy and in cosmetics and in skin care.
The company, started in 1990, has grown from 500 square feet it occupied at the Stony Brook incubator into a 150,000-square-foot enterprise employing 200 people.
One of its four subsidiaries, Collaborative BioAlliance, operates a 30,000-square-foot contract research and contract manufacturing complex at the Stony Brook incubator, where it is the anchor tenant. The facility, which has Food and Drug Administration approval, makes it possible for biotechnology companies to bring products to clinical trials without making a major investment in their own plants and equipment.
Merrill Garnett, a cancer researcher since 1959, has worked for the last five years in a 500-square-foot laboratory at the Stony Brook incubator. His company, Garnett McKeen Lab, will submit its new oral chemotherapy to clinical trials this spring. Dr. Garnett, the primary inventor of the chemotherapy agent, called Palladium Complex, developed it for the treatment of brain tumors, lymphoma, lung and kidney cancers and a variety of other tumors. It also benefits patients when used in conjunction with other chemotherapy treatments, he said. So-called compassionate trials conducted in Canada and Mexico on patients with glioblastoma, a lethal brain tumor, brought about long-lasting improvement on some advanced cases within days, Dr. Garnett said.
Other advances growing out of Stony Brook include a device resembling a series of pressure cuffs that is used for a painless, noninvasive treatment of angina pectoris -- a chest pain caused by coronary artery disease. The device, applied to the lower extremities, reduces angina by using a technology called enhanced external counterpulsation to increase coronary artery blood flow. The device is marketed by Vasomedical, a Westbury company, to medical centers around the world.
Patients are treated an hour a day for a total of 35 days over seven weeks. John C. K. Hui and Harry S. Soroff brought the device, which was refined in China, to Stony Brook in 1989 for its first clinical trials.

HEADLINE: On Staten Island, a Buried Treasure

BYLINE: By FRANK McCOURT; Frank McCourt is the author of "Angela's Ashes" (Scribner).

 BODY:
THE school page of The New York World-Telegram and Sun carried lists of jobs available for teachers around the city. In March 1958, there was a vacancy for an English teacher at McKee Vocational and Technical High School, St. Mark's Place and Wall Street. There was a phone number and when I called, a lady said, "Come right over." I lived, then, near Borough Hall in Brooklyn, and I was pleased at how convenient it would be to travel such a short distance to my first teaching job.
I wandered up and down Wall Street looking for the school. No one had ever heard of it. A police officer shook his head. "Nah, no schools on Wall Street." 
 "What about St. Mark's Place?"
"There's no St. Mark's Place around here."
"But it's right here in the paper."
"I don't care what's in the paper. This is my beat."
I called the number again. (In those days there were no area codes in the city.) When I told the lady her school didn't exist in the Wall Street area, she sighed: "We have that trouble all the time. You gotta take the ferry to St. George and walk up the hill. You can't miss McKee. You'll see kids."
"Where is St. George?"
The sigh now was impatient. "Staten Island! Staten Island!"
The ferry fare was a nickel and it took a half-hour to cross the harbor to St. George. It was not a straight, clear run. The bay was alive with vessels: liners, freighters, tankers, barges, tugboats, other ferries to Governors Island, the Statue of Liberty, New Jersey. The Manhattan skyline was seductive but then lacked the World Trade Center and the buildings that later sprang up throughout the island.
The view out along the Narrows was open: the Verrazano bridge had not yet been built. Ellis Island was a desolation. It saddened me to see an abandoned ferry sinking in the water. My father might have stood on the deck of that ferry, excited, as I was, over the city's towers.
At St. George, I climbed the hill to McKee Vocational and Technical High School and the lady was right: there were kids -- hundreds of them swarming outside the school. Some cruised by in convertibles, and when they approached the school, revved up and roared away to the cheers of their friends. It was a scene from an early 50's, teen-age gang movie, and I felt trapped. I had never been able to deal with these alien creatures -- the boys with their duck-tail haircuts, girls with their hair piled up beehive style. I could walk away now, back down the hill to the ferry. After all, friends had told me: "Don't go near vocational high schools. The kids there will kill you."
No. I'd try it. How could I pass up that daily ferry ride, that skyline, that great sweep of harbor, the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island -- a daily reminder of the thousands who had passed through?
The assistant principal, Miss Seested, checked my teaching license and took me to the office of the principal, Moses Sorola. He grunted when I told him I had no teaching experience, and he wanted to know why I talked like that. "What is this accent?"
"Irish."
"Oh."
He said he really didn't have a complete English program for me, that I would have three classes in a social-studies course, "Economic Citizenship," and two sophomore classes in English, and could I handle that? I said I knew nothing about "Economic Citizenship," and he said there was a textbook, just stay a few pages ahead of the kids. The textbook was "Your World and You," and he smiled and said that should cover just about everything. He took me to the teacher I was replacing, Miss Mudd, who sat at her desk ignoring the bedlam in her classroom. Bits of chalk flew through the air, blackboard erasers, scraps of sandwiches. Boys leaned out the windows, calling to girls across the yard.
But when Mr. Sorola appeared, everything stopped. He called two boys to the front of the room, told me that Miss Mudd would tell me everything I needed to know and marched the boys to his office. Miss Mudd hardly looked at me, bleated that she was swamped with paper work, that these kids were driving her crazy, that I would be crazy, too, after 32 years in a vocational high school, that if I looked out the window next week I would see an ocean liner sailing by with her waving goodbye and that when she returned from her retirement cruise, there were two things she never wanted to see again in her life: kids and Staten Island.
Her end was my beginning -- and nearly my end. In Room 104 that last week in March 1958, I struggled with five classes of students from various shops: auto mechanics, sheet metal, printing, machine shop, woodworking, cosmetology.
THEY didn't want to sit in English classes. Why couldn't they watch movies instead of reading these stupid books, "Giants in the Earth" and "Silas Marner"? Why did they have to read about people all gloomy on the prairie or about a dirty old man in England? The "Economic Citizenship" kids didn't want to know about the stock market. They wanted to know if I was sorry James Dean was dead. I shook my head: I didn't know. Didn't I think Elvis was the greatest singer the world had ever seen? I preferred Bing Crosby. They frowned. They threw chalk and sandwiches at one another. I was losing them.
I was saved by Miss Mudd. She had left closets packed with old grammar textbooks, newspapers, Regents exams and hundreds of pages of uncorrected student compositions going back to 1942. The boys yearned to fight, to avenge the deaths of brothers, friends, neighbors. ("I'm gonna kill five Japs for every one they killed from my neighborhood.") And the girls would wait. ("When Joey comes home, we're gonna get married and move to Jersey and get away from his crazy mother.")
I piled the crumbling compositions on my desk and began reading some to my classes. They sat up. There were familiar names. "Hey, that was my father. He was wounded in Africa." "That was my uncle. Killed in Guam." There were tears: strong, young men ran suddenly to the toilets and returned red-eyed. The girls wept openly and consoled one another.
We worried that these brittle papers would fall apart and, since there were no sophisticated duplicating machines in the school, we agreed that we would have to copy the old papers by hand.
Mr. Sorola looked in a few times and said nothing: I think he was grateful for a quiet classroom. We continued after the Easter break and when exam time rolled around in June, I passed everyone.
The teacher had learned more than anyone in that classroom on Staten Island.

HEADLINE: The Ultimate Takeover

BYLINE: By RON CHERNOW; Ron Chernow is the author of "The House of Morgan" (Touchstone) and "The Warburgs" (Vintage). His biography of John D. Rockefeller Sr. is to be published in May by Random House.

 BODY:
SHORTLY after noon on Oct. 19, 1987, as the giant plunge on Wall Street gathered force, I boarded the downtown Seventh Avenue IRT in search of high drama. Newly embarked on "The House of Morgan," I wanted to stand at the corner of Broad and Wall Streets and savor the full thrill of financial disaster. My mind teemed with grainy black-and-white images of ashen-faced investors thronging the sidewalks during the 1907 panic and the 1929 crash. Yet when I emerged from the subway that day, I found, to my great dismay, no ranks of grim, ruined speculators, no stockbrokers sailing from upper-story windows. The famous corner, if not quite as calm as a country crossroads, gave no hint that $500 billion of shareholder value was being erased behind the Corinthian columns of the New York Stock Exchange.
Though I felt robbed of a certain voyeuristic titillation -- I read once that messengers, unlike their bosses, had found the 1929 crash exhilarating -- I realized that the empty, placid street disclosed a larger truth. A century ago, Wall Street denoted a specific piece of real estate in lower Manhattan, plus an industry crowded within its borders. Nowadays, Wall Street is a free-floating state of mind, an electronic universe enlisting the avid attention of tens of millions of small investors. Where the old Wall Street had been aloof and aristocratic, snob heaven, the new Wall Street, with its computer screens, discount brokers and trading on the Internet, is as blandly democratic as a shopping mall. 
 Back in 1898, Wall Street was the preserve of high finance, catering to governments, corporations and rich individuals. Denizens of the Street spent a lifetime avoiding contact with unfortunate mortals worth less than seven figures. Because it harbored the nation's creditor class, the financial district inevitability bred mistrust in a small-town, agrarian America populated by millions of debtors. It seemed poetically apt that Wall Street occupied the tip of an island, overlooking a great port. Closeness to the sea was the very essence of this cosmopolitan place.
Thriving on its overseas connections, Wall Street channeled capital from abroad to American railways and industry and embodied a truth unpalatable to most Americans: a proudly isolationist republic, conceived in a struggle against European despotism, still relied on foreigners for money.
The portly, top-hatted bankers in lower Manhattan reflected the values of those distant creditors, especially their preference for hard currency, low inflation and fiscal discipline. Not surprisingly, they often seemed spoilsports in an America yearning for cheap money and rip-roaring growth.
A century ago, Main Street dreaded Wall Street for another reason. As thousands of regional companies were amalgamated into national trusts, New York bankers engineered many of the deals. To a worried Main Street, it seemed that Wall Street was stealing its local companies. Small-town banks, with limited capital, were hopelessly inadequate before the scale of the emerging new economy; only Manhattan bankers had the large capital pools to effect these mergers. As a result, the new monopolies were often based in Manhattan, their boards stuffed with fancy bankers and lawyers. The Wall Street tycoons were instrumental in making New York a managerial city, the nation's business address.
AS THE 20th century progressed, Wall Street banks grew larger as they tried to keep pace with their expanding multinational clients. But the bankers themselves grew smaller and less lordly, trapped in large conglomerates and overshadowed by their corporate customers.
After World War II, real estate on Wall Street stagnated as many investment houses migrated to midtown, humbly trailing these clients. Why this sudden demotion in power? As large companies raised money directly from stock and bond markets, turned to foreign bankers or developed their own financial subsidiaries, the Street surrendered its historic monopoly on capital, knowledge and expertise.
Deserted by their blue-chip clients, Wall Street has submitted in recent years to the ultimate indignity: it has embraced Main Street as its salvation. The most blue-blooded houses are scrambling to buy retail brokers, forge links with mutual fund groups or manage 401(k) plans for middle-income investors. They have traded the discretion of deal makers for the robust salesmanship of asset managers. Power in the financial world now flows from the bottom up, not the top down. In the 1920's, when only 1.5 million Americans played the stock market, Wall Street thought it unseemly to recognize them. Now that more than 60 million Americans own mutual funds, Wall Street has developed profound esteem for the small investor. In the process, it has sacrificed its proud heritage as a conspiracy against the public, becoming instead the nerve center for a national brokerage network.
The revolution has been two-sided; small investors in the heartland -- once the seedbed of populism -- now find wisdom in the pronouncements of Wall Street financiers. They accept stock-market pundits, brokerage house analysts and billionaire investors as oracles on topical issues and role models in daily life. With the current vogue for stock investing, the distinctive psychology of the creditor permeates American politics and culture. Ordinary citizens fret about inflation, worry about excess growth and betray a touching concern for corporate earnings. Once poised on the rim of the continent, like an enemy beachhead, Wall Street has marched across the country and occupied it from coast to coast. It has stooped to conquer the American masses, and the conquest has been all but complete.
