HEADLINE: Disabled, He Helps Others Beat Handicaps

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER

 BODY:
THE real issue for people with disabilities is their abilities. In an ideal world, people with disabilities will live simply as people, with the same opportunities as everyone else.
Making their abilities, not their disabilities, count, has been a lifelong mission for 85-year-old Henry Viscardi Jr. Born without legs, he spent the first six years of his life as a charity patient in a hospital ward for crippled children. An adviser to presidents, author of eight books and holder of 23 honorary doctorates, this Long Island legend founded the internationally recognized National Center for Disability Services, a multi-faceted, state-of-the art-educational training and research institution in Albertson. 
 The center is the fruition of Abilities Inc., a venture Dr. Viscardi started 45 years ago out of a West Hempstead garage with eight handicapped adults -- legless, armless, blind and paralyzed -- who were considered unemployable by traditional standards. Ten years later, Abilities, a competitive not-for-profit enterprise, had 475 employees building electronic components.
"It survived 30 years, but as the economy on Long Island changed we began to see we had new and greater responsibilities in our school, adult training program and research," Dr. Viscardi said. "The opposition didn't really change."
In 1962, he founded the Human Resources School, which was renamed in his honor six years ago, educating severely disabled children who otherwise would have to study at home or from a hospital bed. The Henry Viscardi School has 220 pupils in pre-kindergarten through high school, 40 percent of whom come from New York City. Others commute from Westchester and Rockland Counties.
While Dr. Viscardi retired as chief executive officer in 1981, it was his vision that enabled the center to be a model program. New technologies, long-distance learning capabilities and a website are allowing the trendsetting work there to be shared with the disabled all over the globe.
Educating and training thousands of people with disabilities, and inspiring them to lead active, fulfilling lives, Dr. Viscardi's work continues to have an impact on the lives of Long Islanders and their families. Last year, almost 300 people with disabilities were placed into employment on Long Island and an additional 327 found employment elsewhere with the center's help.
Last November, the center received $6.6 million in Federal grants for programs that will train and find jobs for more than 5,200 people with disabilities in eight states, including New York, over the next five years. The school is mostly financed by the state.
"Continuing to serve this cause as long as I can is the fulfillment of what I consider to be my destiny," said Dr. Viscardi, who was fitted with artificial limbs at age 27. "We changed thousands of lives.I think it's a better world now than when it began. Far more disabled people are given the opportunity to be educated and to work."
Dr. Viscardi and his wife, Lucile, have lived their married life of 52 years in a converted garage overlooking the Sound in Kings Point. The Viscardis have four daughters, nine grandchildren and became great-grandparents of twins last week.
During World War II, as part of the Red Cross, he worked with amputees at Walter Reed Hospital in Washington. He helped pay part of his way through college by refereeing basketball games on his stumps, standing three feet, eight inches high in orthopedic boots. He attended law school and worked as a tax auditor, in broadcasting and as personnel director of a large corporation before taking on JOB, Just One Break, a project finding jobs for rehabilitated men and women.
Dr. Viscardi, an avid sailor whose office at the seven-acre complex on Searingtown Road is a museum of photographs, mementos and diplomas chronicling his life's work, still swims with the children at the school's specially-equipped indoor pool every day. The campus includes an independent learning house for senior high school students to practice living on their own and preparing their own meals before graduation.
"We keep saying to these kids, "There's a place for you out in that world. It's not going to come easy. You have to sacrifice and work hard. Prepare yourselves. Be prepared for rejection,' " said Dr. Viscardi, who continues to give lectures and presentations.
Videoconferencing capabilities, a fully accessible television studio and conference area in the adjacent 7,560-square-foot Smeal Learning Center, which opened in September, allows the center to share its research and training techniques with universities and other institutions. The learning center, built on Abilities' former site, was conceptualized by Dr. Viscardi in 1952. The campus also includes St. Charles Hospital at the Dolan Rehabilitation Center, which provides medical rehabilitation services including physical, occupational and speech therapies, neuropsychological evaluations and counseling services.
"The center originally started as a place that was attempting to help people with disabilities get out of situations in which they were either isolated at home, or children who should have been in school were being kept at home because the education system wasn't working for them," said Edmund L. Cortez, president and chief executive officer of the national center. "People who should have had jobs weren't working and were staying at home because employment opportunities didn't exist for them. The center created a kind of isolated haven for these individuals to go to school and get training to go to work with the eventual goal that these individuals would would become integrated within the community."
Dr. Viscardi's program was created to prove that people with disabilities could work like everybody else at a time when institutions and separate schools were being built to isolate the handicapped.
"It was Hank Viscardi who said, 'But I can demonstrate that these people can work, can compete, can be part of the mainstream,' " Mr. Cortez said. "Throughout our history we have been committed to that original idea, that people with disabilities are simply people like everybody else. They have the same ambitions, the same dreams, the same feelings as everybody else. And on top of that they are people that we know personally. People with disabilities are our parents and our children and our friends. If a person, because they're getting older and can't walk as well as they used to, or hear as well as they used to or can't hold things as well as they used to because of arthritis, those are disabilities."
In most ways, the Viscardi school is an educational institution like any other. Children chatter noisily in the cafeteria at lunchtime. Down the hall in a second-grade classroom, youngsters are studying the forests and working on their writing skills. Kindergartners play at the sand table in their classroom. The children have art, music, gym and computer. There is a black rabbit named Cocoa in the preschool classroom.
But there are standers stacked in the hallways, wooden boards for children who need the opportunity to be in upright positions during the day, a large red buggy to transport six nonambulatory preschoolers through the hallways and a wheelchair accessible playground outside the kindergarten door.
In the $600,000 technology suite, which was built with private donor funds and opened in October, 24 computer stations adapt to individual needs. Desk tops and monitors adjust to accommodate different-sized wheelchairs at the input of a special code, specialty keyboards come split in sections, tilt in any direction for a youngster with very short arms and come in smaller sizes to accommodate students without a large range of motion. There are trackballs instead of mice, pressure-sensitive keyboards and one designed for a student who manipulates it with his feet.
"In a lot of ways we are like every other school," said Dr. Ellen Bergman, superintendent of the school. "Same types of books, same types of posters. We run readings, participation events." It is technology, she said, that has made a tremendous difference.
"Technology enables them to compete in the world on a level playing field," she said. "Thanks to assistive technology, equipment that makes access to computers available to almost all of us and the actual use of technology, which allows you to travel the world without ever leaving your actual environment, our students for the first time are able to adapt to the demands of society and compensate for their disabilities on a very even playing field. They can use their intelligence, their talents, their creativity and it is quite remarkable, all thanks to technology."
Children in the Viscardi school primarily have physical or medically related disabilities, such as cerebral palsy that leaves them little control over their muscles. Many have been in car accidents or broken their necks jumping into swimming pools. Six children at the center must use ventilators because of spinal cord injuries and have no control of anything below their necks, yet attend class and learn with their ventilator systems strapped to their wheelchairs. Many of the children with degenerative diseases need regular medical care through the day.
Eight-year-old Brandon Wolfbiss of Syosset, who has severe cerebral palsy, takes second-grade spelling and math tests with his eyes, using special visual boards, and practices navigating a power wheelchair operated with a chin switch down the school's long corridors.
Alan Muir, a vice president at Chase Bank's Long Island headquarters in Melville, graduated from the school as valedictorian in 1978. A dwarf who has some difficulty walking because of congenital hip and back deformities, he played hockey, baseball and football and was team manager at the then Human Resources School, none of which would have been possible in a public high school.
"The overall atmosphere gave you a better sense of yourself and self confidence," said Mr. Muir. He followed the Regents curriculum and went on to Adelphi University. "Dr. Viscardi is probably one of the most genuinely compassionate and passionate people that I have ever met," Mr. Muir said. "He is very determined, very upfront about a lot of situations. He tells you exactly what the situation is. He doesn't sugarcoat anything."
Adults in the vocational rehabilitation program, most of whom come from Nassau and Suffolk Counties, have disabilities that interfere with their ability to work.
"We will have people with developmental delays, emotional disabilities, an inability to cope with stress, depression, those kinds of issues to the extent where it keeps the person from keeping a job," Mr. Cortez said. "We train them to cope with some of those issues and at the same time to work despite those disabilities."
The center's National Business and Disability Council program is designed to provide support to employers so they understand what they need to do to hire and effectively employ people with disabilities. The employment program offers training for laboratory assistants and in basic accounting skills, word processing, filing and retail skills.
"We try to pave the way for them so that they can hire that person," Mr. Cortez said. "Once that person is hired, we try to help them make reasonable accommodations in a cost-effective manner. Very often, the employer thinks he has to spend thousands of dollars to accommodate this environment. Often the answer is you don't have to spend very much money at all. There are some very easy solutions if you just understand how to approach the problem."
Despite the lowest unemployment rate in 28 years, Mr. Cortez said that close to 70 percent of people with disabilities of working age who wanted to work and had the capability of working did not have jobs. Eighty-five percent of the people who go to the center's training program get jobs, he said.
"That's an extraordinary record," Mr. Cortez said. "It's unique. If you go to most training programs, you won't find statistics like that. What we're talking about is isolated to Long Island and to the places where we have programs. There are 49 million people with disabilities in this country. We're just touching not even the tip of the iceberg. Employers are hiring unqualified people to fill jobs because they can't find qualified people. Yet there's this pool of millions of people with disabilities who are looking for work who can't get jobs. What we need to do is figure out how to put the two together. They're looking for each other. They just can't find each other.".
Despite the center's technological savvy, Dr. Viscardi is personally glad the computer age has passed him by. He doesn't even have a telephone answering machine at home.
"The computer age is pushing the horizons of total helplessness further and further back," Dr. Viscardi said. "With the computer, you have so much potential to close the gap between the capacities of the individual and the demands of the job to be done. We're physically disabled because the doctors can define that. When it comes to occupational disability, as long as our physical capacities can meet the demands of the job to be done, we are not occupationally disabled. Both can be changed. I'm one thing without my artificial limbs. I'm quite another with them."

HEADLINE: HIGH-TECH RECORDINGS;
Music in Color

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Paul Griffiths's article "Callas Sings Bob Dylan? Could Be" Jan. 11 overlooked two important companion technologies to the recording of classical music. The first is television and videocassettes. The VCR has become almost as ubiquitous as the television set. As consumers upgrade the quality of their "home theater" equipment, these technologies come remarkably close to a live performance. 
 I disagree with Mr. Griffiths's assertion that seeing is unnecessary and a redundant part of classical-music enjoyment. Seeing has to be one of the reasons people go to a live performance of a symphony orchestra. Television and videocassettes offer this opportunity to virtually all Americans at economical prices, even if their local areas do not have live performances.
The second technology is video distribution, with its enormous expansion of channels through cable and satellites, which is increased even more by bandwidth compression. It is only a matter of time until more of these channels will be used for niche audiences rather than movies. Classical music is a natural for this new opportunity. Ovation Channel is trying to do just this for all the arts.
The future of technology and classical music is indeed bright, even if fundamental audio recording and editing are going in the wrong direction with their ability to create artificial perfection and maybe even deception as Mr. Griffiths seems to suggest.
 
HARLAN E. ANDERSON
New Canaan, Conn.

LENGTH: 1565 words

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Kent, N.Y.;
Rustic, Rugged Yet A Workable Commute

BYLINE: By LISA PREVOST 

 BODY:
WHEN Anne Ladau talks about the Town of Kent in northern Putnam County, she often jokingly refers to it as "L. L. Bean country."
"You know, warm fires and wet dogs -- perfect for a log cabin or a chalet," said Ms. Ladau, an associate broker with Houlihan/ Lawrence. 
 Indeed, a trip up the Taconic State Parkway through the town's rugged northwestern edge, which hooks around the northern tip of the rugged terrain of Clarence Fahnestock Memorial State Park, confirms that assessment. Elsewhere in Kent, thousands of acres of preservation land and more than a dozen pristine lakes and ponds give residents the illusion of living upstate, though they are only about 65 miles from New York City.
While several recreation-oriented developments have grown up around golf clubs and lakes here, Kent does not have the feel of an upscale resort area. Most homeowners are year-round residents, many in modest ranches or Cape Cods clustered near lakes. And because it is accessible by both the Taconic and Interstates 684 and 84, Kent is becoming increasingly attractive to commuters looking for rural surroundings at affordable prices.
Carol Luiken, a costume designer, said she can make it to New York City from her house in western Kent in an hour. That was one of the criteria she laid down when she and her husband, Charles Clute, a personal-fitness trainer, set out to buy a house in 1984. They wanted a historic home, but thought Westchester County was too expensive. They found their ideal right off the Taconic -- a 200-year-old refinished barn with big, exposed beams inside and "breathtaking" surroundings.
"We just have an acre of land, but it seems like we have forever," Ms. Luiken said. "We're just about on the corner of Fahnestock."
The town has no main street -- Route 52 serves as the main business road, where shopping includes such basics a small grocery, a drugstore and a hardware store. The nearest shopping hub is the huge Danbury Fair complex, a 10- to 15-minute drive away in Danbury, Conn. But Ms. Luiken said she's learned to adjust: "I go to Sam's Club and buy enough toilet paper for a year."
The town is often considered part of Carmel and the confusion is understandable. Until recently, addresses in Kent were lumped in with Carmel -- there are two Kents in New York State, so this Kent had to use the Carmel zip code and post office. About a year ago, Kent got its own postal designation as Kent Lakes, but the town still shares Carmel's post office and zip code.
BUT Kent may soon establish a name for itself as a regional shopping destination. F.A.C. Realty Trust, of Cary, N.C, has proposed a 450,000-square-foot factory outlet center on 100 acres just off Interstate 84 where it crosses Route 311 at Exit 18. If the developer obtains the necessary approvals, construction will begin in early spring, said Edward Heelan, owner of Heelan Realty and Development in Brewster, the broker for the project.
"There's no question the revenue is needed, said Joseph L. Belvedere, who recently concluded eight years as Town Supervisor. "As it is now, we penny-pinch -- we have to," he said. The property tax rate in Kent went up 35 cents to about $7.19 per $1,000 this year, the first increase in almost three years.
But "future development in Kent is environmentally limited," said Matthew D. Rudikoff, the Town Planner. One natural limitation is its steep, rocky terrain, which makes large-scale subdivisions a near impossibility. Kent issued an average of just 16 residential building permits annually from 1991 through 1996. Moreover, the town is almost entirely within the New York City watershed, which is regulated by the city's Department of Environmental Protection.
The city already owns 840 acres in Kent, but through the D.E.P.'s new Land Acquisition and Stewardship Program, they are now offering landowners fair-market value for vacant land to protect it from development. So far, landowners in Kent have contracted to sell an additional 2,266 acres to the city, according to Dave Tobias, the program director.
 NEW YORK CITY'S claim to Putnam County water -- there are 11 city reservoirs in the county, 2 of them in Kent -- dates back to the 1860's, when the city began acquiring land for the Croton Aqueduct Water Works and built the 70-foot-tall Boyd's Dam in Kent on the Croton River. The clear and plentiful water that was so valuable to parched city dwellers was also the economic lifeblood of a thriving mill community in Kent.
The settlement, called Farmers Mills, was strung along a small stream at the outlet of White Pond. It produced flour, wood, leather, barrel hoops, wool, charcoal and dairy products for surrounding towns. At one time, said Richard Muscarella, the county historian, some 500 families lived there.
But when the Harlem and the Hudson Railroads came through in the mid-19th century, Mr. Muscarella said, the population center moved south to the Village of Brewster, cutting off Farmers Mills from the new paths of commerce. Though little remains of the settlement, its history is depicted in a diorama in front of a one-room schoolhouse on Farmers Mills Road.
Farmers Mills was one of the earliest settlements in Kent, which was known as Frederick until 1817 when it was renamed for a family of prominent settlers. Another one-time mill community is the hamlet of Ludingtonville, once the home of Sybil Ludington, a Revolutionary War heroine. On the night of April 26, 1777, the 16-year-old Miss Ludington, the daughter of Col. Henry Ludington, rode 40 miles through the countryside to alert militiamen that the British were burning Danbury. A statue commemorating her ride stands in Carmel on the shore of Lake Gleneida.
By the turn of the century, Kent began to receive an influx of wealthy vacationers from the city. Country clubs and camps, some complete with manmade lakes, sprang up to meet the demand. One of the earliest of these was Hill and Dale Country Club, constructed in 1928 with a private lake and 18-hole golf course.
Most of the homes in this private community are now occupied year-round; prices range from $165,000 a 2-bedroom ranch to $265,000 for a 3-bedroom log chalet. Up the road are two town-house condominium complexes, one of which, the 116-unit Sparrow Ridge, is still under construction. Prices there start at about $152,000 for a 2-bedroom unit. A 2-bedroom town house at the 100-unit Fairways complex was recently listed at a resale price of $180,000.
Development is most dense around Lake Carmel, a manmade lake created in the early 30's as part of a low-priced housing development marketed to blue-collar workers. The Cape Cods and raised ranches set closely together on small lots around the lake range in price from about $130,000 to $160,000.
The few dozen ranches and raised ranches in Kentwood Lake Estates, built in the 70's, tend to sell for slightly more. The houses are on half-acre lots near a lake with a sandy beach and walking trails.
Between such developments, the woods can stretch for several miles without interruption. Then a few houses might appear, set back in the trees or high on a ledge. There are relatively few historic homes in Kent, but a little bit of everything else.
Vacation homes tend to be in the Sedgewood Club, Gipsy Trail Club and Lake Sagamore areas. Homes in Sedgewood, a golf club also established in the 1920's where Itzhak Perlman, the concert violinist, once owned a residence, can cost close to $1 million for a spacious log and stone lakefront retreat. The Gipsy Trail Club caters to active families -- the mandatory club membership provides access to swimming, sailing, tennis, horseback riding and dining. Lake Sagamore, once the site of a Wappinger Indian village, offers properties with beautiful lakefront views, but the "oldish ranches" often require some remodeling, said Ms. Ladau, the broker. Second-home prices in Kent average between $300,000 and $400,000, she said.
KENT is part of the Carmel Central School District. Children attend elementary school in Kent through the fourth grade, then attend middle school and high school in Carmel. The music program in the Carmel schools is "one of the most extensive in the area," said Dr. Thomas P. Higgins Jr., the schools superintendent, who noted that almost 90 percent of the students in fifth grade were "involved in some way in music."
Carmel High School offers 11 advanced placement courses. S.A.T. averages for 1997 were 519 in verbal and 507 in math; the state averages for the same period were 495 in verbal and 502 in math. Mr. Higgins said that over the last two years 85 percent of the graduating classes went on to higher education.
 The Roman Catholic St. James the Apostle school in Carmel offers a full-day kindergarten program and classes through the eighth grade. Annual tuition is $1,490, with a $250 surcharge for kindergarten students, said the principal, Daisy Abruzzo.
Recreational opportunities abound at the many state and county-owned parks in Kent. Fahnestock Park, which covers 6,800 acres, entices fishermen to its three ponds and two lakes. A nature center offers various family-oriented activities during the summer. The 1,000-acre Ninham Mountain State Forest, named for a Wappinger sachem who fought in both the French and Indian and Revolutionary Wars, offers fishing, hiking, camping, cross-country skiing and hunting.

BUDDHIST MONASTERY: The Chuang Yen Monastery celebrated its opening in Kent last May with a visit from the exiled Dalai Lama. An estimated 7,000 people flocked to the $6 million Center for Enlightenment during four days of ceremonies and lectures. Situated on 225 wooded acres donated by Dr. Chia Teng Shen, a cofounder of the Buddhist Association of the United States, the complex includes a large library, residence halls, a small lake and a granite terrace reserved for religious ceremonies. The main attraction is the 37-foot-tall Buddha statue, which Hans Hallundbaek, the monastery's spokesman, calls the largest such statue in the Western Hemisphere. Situated within the massive Great Buddha Hall, the statue is encircled by 10,000 smaller versions. The monastery, which is off Route 301 about 1.7 miles east of its junction with the Taconic State Parkway, welcomes visitors between 9 A.M. and 5 P.M. daily. A vegetarian lunch is served on Sundays between noon and 1 P.M. (suggested donation: $5).

HEADLINE: Knick Player Reaches for More Time on Court

BYLINE: By DAN MARKOWITZ 

 BODY:
WHEN Chris Dudley, the New York Knick center and Rye resident, turned down a four-year, $13 million deal with the Detroit Pistons to play for the Knicks for $272,000, the league minimum, he expected to receive regular playing time on a championship-caliber team. Instead, Patrick Ewing's season-ending wrist injury actually decreased Dudley's playing time, and although the Knicks have played well during Ewing's absence, making the playoffs and possibly winning one round is a more realistic Knick goal than a championship. 
 But Dudley, who will turn 33 next month, is no stranger to adversity. This season, he has already suffered through a bout with the flu, a strained lower back and a broken nose. When he was 16, he was diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes. The 6-foot-11 Dudley remembers asking his father, "Will I still be able to play basketball?" He could, but as a Division 1 recruit, Dudley chose Yale, not a basketball titan, from which his father, uncle and grandfather, Guilford Dudley, who served as Ambassador to Denmark, all graduated.
It was not until the summer after his sophomore season at Yale, while working as a counselor at Dean Smith's basketball camp at the University of North Carolina, where he played pick-up games against all the former Carolina players-turned-pro, that Dudley thought he had pro potential. When he graduated from Yale with a degree in economics, Dudley was the 75th pick in the 1987 National Basketball Association draft.
Now he is entering his 12th season in the N.B.A. The Knicks are his fourth team after stints in Cleveland, New Jersey and Portland. Dudley, along with Matt Maloney of the Houston Rockets and formerly of the University of Pennsylvania, is the only Ivy League graduate playing in the N.B.A. The league tried to block the Knicks' acquiring Dudley this summer and signing him for a one-year deal at far less than his market value. N.B.A. lawyers contended in a case that was ruled on in favor of the Knicks by an arbitrator that a secret deal had already illegally been brokered by the Knicks and Dudley, which would circumvent league salary-cap restrictions.
Dudley's name has been mentioned in a couple of possible trade rumors recently, but he hopes to play four more years in the N.B.A., and the team he likes to play for is the Knicks.
"I like New York," said Dudley, who said he wants to work on Wall Street or in real estate after his playing career. "I like Rye. It's extremely pretty and convenient to Purchase College, where we practice, Westchester Airport, where the team flies out of, and the city."
On his longevity in the N.B.A,, Dudley said:
"To stay in the league for a while you have to do one thing real well, and mine has been rebounding. A lot of it is effort and simply going after missed shots. For my size, I always had quick jumps and quick pursuit to the ball."
Dudley was named the winner of the J. Walter Kennedy N.B.A. Citizenship Award in 1996 for his work with young diabetics. His basketball camp in Veronia, Ore., admitted 70 diabetic children from around the country last summer.
"It's a lot of work getting it all in place," Dudley said, explaining why the camp will remain in Oregon this summer instead of moving with Dudley to New York. "You need the doctors, nurses and donations from medical companies."
Dudley said that he has not had time to look for a charity to support in the Westchester-New York City area but that he and the Knicks are searching for an appropriate organization. Dudley appeared at the Dunleavy-Millbank Center, an after-school children's recreation site in Harlem earlier in this season for the N.B.A.'s Teamup program, a leaguewide event in which players work in the community.
Even as the diabetes has made his own life more difficult, Dudley said dealing with the disease on a daily basis is a mixed blessing. "The biggest thing was I had something I had to be aware of at all times," he said. "But it made me more disciplined, more regimented. I think that has helped me in my overall life."
As an athlete, Dudley said: "I don't eat things with a lot of sugar. I'll have a Diet Coke instead of a Coke. I test my blood sugar levels and take my shots before meals."
Dudley makes a habit of signing autographs. At a recent game against the Nets in New Jersey two days after he broke his nose in Orlando, for example, he left the locker room 90 minutes early for shooting practice and signed many for fans calling to him.
"New Haven says hello," said one fan, and Dudley replied about the city of his alma mater, "Oh yeah, how's New Haven?"
With a plastic mask covering his nose and eyes, Dudley began his warm-up ritual of receiving passes from a Knick assistant coach and shooting little hooks, jump shots and dunks around the basket. Then he moved to the free-throw line -- where he holds the dubious distinction of holding one of the worst career percentages (46 percent) -- and rolled off a number of shots. He grabbed a basketball and dribbled it the length of the floor one way with his right hand and back again with his left. Afterward, he sprawled out at midcourt and manipulated his lanky body in different directions while stretching.
Dudley began the game on the bench -- as he has done throughout most of his career -- and remained there for the entire game. In the Knicks' first 38 games this season, Dudley only averaged about 14 minutes a game and was not called upon at all in three games. By comparison, throughout 643 games he played before this season, Dudley averaged nearly 21 minutes a game.
Jeff Van Gundy, the Knicks' coach, said Dudley's reduced playing time is the result of the Knicks' needing more scoring production because of Ewing's absence. He also said opponents are fielding smaller and quicker squads.
Dudley has played more minutes recently against teams with bigger players like the Chicago Bulls, the Seattle Supersonics and the Boston Celtics, and he has been effective. While he said he can understand Van Gundy's reasoning, he does not always agree with it. "That has never been something that has kept me out of a game in the past," he said. "I think that works two ways, when you're big and stronger, you out-rebound them and pound them inside against a quicker, smaller team. When I'm playing the way I'm capable, then everything else should shake out."
Dudley said he senses a silver lining in the current season: "Sometimes, at the end of the year, when you turn things around for the better, you look back and it makes it that much more rewarding. I hope that's how it's going to work out here."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: A Site That Crunches Numbers;
Refinancing On the Web

 BODY:
With mortgage rates low, many homeowners are wondering whether they should refinance. To help provide answers, Intuit Inc., the Mountain View, Calif., company that markets Quicken financial software, opened an electronic Refinance Center last week on its Quicken Mortgage Web site -- a cybershopping center for mortgages that the company started last November.
The center (www.quicken.com/mortgage) allows mortgage shoppers to provide information about their mortgage, such as the interest rate they are paying, the amount of the mortgage and the number of years and months remaining on it, and then quickly receive an assessment of the costs and benefits of refinancing. The assessment includes the size of the new monthly payment at current rates, and the number of years and months it would take before refinancing, net of the costs of taking out a new loan, would be profitable for the homeowner. 
 "The object is to get a quick feel for whether it makes sense to refinance," said Carl Reese, vice president of Intuit's Quicken Mortgage. He said the assessment was based on interest rates charged by the company's six participating lenders. Homeowners can obtain more information and determine whether they qualify for a particular mortgage by providing more data. Those who find an offer they like, Mr. Reese said, can instantly transfer their data to a participating lender, who will then contact the customer. "Information in our database is only sent to a lender at the customer's request," he said.

HEADLINE: Theater Air Rights Plan Awaits Reviews

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
LIKE the characters in "The Sunshine Boys," whose set they used for the announcement, city officials and leaders of the theater industry have reached entente after years of estrangement.
From the stage of the Lyceum Theater last month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a proposal in which more than two million square feet of air rights from 25 Broadway theaters, most of them landmarks, could be transferred easily throughout the Theater District and up to the edge of Clinton. 
 Developers could use the air rights, without going through public review, to increase the floor area of new towers by 20 percent. With a review and special permit, they could increase the floor area in towers on Broadway, Seventh Avenue and 42d Street by up to 40 percent. On Eighth Avenue, air rights could be used to increase floor area by up to 44 percent, although the resulting buildings would still be much smaller than those on Times Square.
Any theater from which air rights were transferred would have to be maintained as a legitimate Broadway playhouse. And with a special permit, builders of mixed-use developments on Broadway, Seventh Avenue and 42d Street would be granted extra floor area to accommodate new Broadway playhouses.
Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, promised from the stage of the Lyceum that under the proposal, real estate pressures would no longer "suffocate the theaters or be a threat but will actually nurture and support the future of the Broadway theater."
This was just Act I, however. The proposal has to go through public review in coming months. Critical questions are already in the air:
Would the zoning induce so much development along Eighth Avenue that it would displace low- and middle-income Clinton residents? Would it spread air rights over too wide an area with too little discretionary control? And why create incentives for a district in which private development is already under way? Would this be a precedent for other parts of the city?
Conversely, would there be a strong enough market for so many air rights, or would the size of the pool diminish their value? Would sales of air rights benefit the whole theater industry or merely developers and theater owners? Are theaters sufficiently protected over the long run? And is zoning the appropriate way to solve an economic problem?
These are some of the issues facing Community Board 4 in Clinton and Community Board 5 in midtown, the first stops in the review procedure. At the end, the proposal is subject to approval by the City Planning Commission and City Council. Speaker Peter F. Vallone was on stage at the Lyceum, but his aides said later he was there more to show support for the general goal of aiding Broadway theaters than to endorse the specific text of the zoning measures.
The Giuliani administration is convinced that exploitation of the real estate market is the key to bolstering Broadway's bottom line, increasing theatrical employment and preserving landmark playhouses.
Ten dollars a square foot from the sale of air rights (currently valued at about $50 a square foot) would go into a fund to benefit a nonprofit group called the Broadway Initiative, which seeks to cultivate new audiences and develop new plays and musicals.
"By allowing the transfer of air rights," Mayor Giuliani said, "it will produce needed capital and dollars for modernizing theaters, for building some new ones. And also the establishment of the fund -- which will involve actors, producers, people involved in the creative arts, as well as people in government and in the unions -- will allow us to support small musicals, allow us to support experimental works. And it will also insure that these buildings remain theaters."
ALTHOUGH air rights from several Broadway theaters have already been used in nearby developments, Mr. Rose said generally that "the ways they can recoup their value as development sites don't work."
Air rights, also known as unused development rights, represent the difference between the size of an existing building and the maximum that zoning rules would allow on the lot. Because theaters are not tall, they tend to have ample air rights. But transfer opportunities are generally limited under zoning laws to sites that are adjacent, across the street, cater-corner or linked by common ownership.
If air rights could easily float between Eighth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, 40th and 57th Streets, planners and owners believe development pressure would shift away from the mid-block areas where most theaters are found.
Moreover, Mr. Rose said, the proposal would guide development on Eighth Avenue by requiring that new buildings have a strong "street wall"; that is, a fairly uniform and relatively low-rise frontage, more in keeping with the tenement scale of Clinton than the skyscrapers of Times Square.
But neighborhood leaders worry that the proposal may wind up hurting Clinton residents, including actors, musicians, ushers and stagehands who have benefited from the relatively lower rents in the area.
"The issues that haven't been discussed are the effects on the Clinton community and what it means for a city -- not just a cityscape," said Pamela Frederick, chairwoman of Community Board 4. "They act as if zoning doesn't affect people."
"The actors said they're going to be out in Hoboken before they know it," Ms. Frederick said. Clinton residents see the proposal as a "threat to their homes," she said, and are "really galvanizing against this thing."
While neither Board 4 nor Board 5 has taken a formal position, the chairwomen of both said they would almost certainly oppose the inclusion of the west side of Eighth Avenue in the district to which theater air rights can be transferred.
The Municipal Art Society takes much the same position, said its president, Brendan Sexton. It is also concerned that the theater preservation guarantee runs unequivocally for only 25 years, after which an owner could apply for a permit to convert the playhouse to another use.
Without trying to predict the future, city planners identified 22 potential sites where air rights would theoretically be most likely to land, based on ownership patterns, current use and density. Eleven of these hypothetical sites are on Eighth Avenue, while nine are on Broadway or Seventh Avenue.
"I think in two cycles you'll see the majority of these development rights move to the avenues," said Rebecca Robertson, vice president of real estate at the Shubert Organization and former president of the 42d Street Development Project, a state agency.
SHUBERT is by far the largest of the theater owners. Twelve of its houses, with 1.1 million square feet of air rights, would be affected by the new zoning.
Ms. Robertson said revenues from the sale of air rights, plus the construction incentive, might propel Shubert to build a theater with 1,800 seats or more. "It would be a fabulous thing to build a true state-of-the-art musical house," she said. "We think we'd be a great partner for a hotel developer in particular but we'd be a good partner for anybody." She would not elaborate any more than to say that Shubert might be a tenant in a mixed-use project or own the theater as a condominium unit.
Ms. Robertson said the sale of air rights would provide a vital source of income to help existing theaters through long periods when nothing is playing.
One possible transfer would be from Shubert's Winter Garden at Broadway and 50th Street (which has 285,000 square feet of air rights) to the Rockefeller Plaza West project on Seventh Avenue, between 49th and 50th Streets (which might be allowed under the new rules to grow from 1 million to 1.3 million square feet through the use of theater air rights). Neither Ms. Robertson nor executives of the Rockefeller Group Development Corporation would comment.
Another big site affected by the zoning proposal is on the Avenue of the Americas, between 42d and 43d Streets. It is largely controlled by the Durst Organization, which is building the Four Times Square tower on the west end of the block. Douglas Durst, the company's president, said the new zoning "could be very helpful," particularly the theater construction incentive.
Robert E. Nederlander, president of the Nederlander Organization, which owns four affected theaters, also said the proposal would be "helpful" but added that any owner would "have to weigh the benefits and burdens" before deciding to transfer air rights under its restrictions.
For example, air rights from the Nederlander Theater, 208 West 41st Street, might be worth $6.5 million. (The building has 24,975 square feet of floor area where zoning rules would permit 155,800, leaving 130,825 square feet of unused rights.) But maintenance costs are about $250,000 a year, whether the theater is used or not. And until "Rent," the Nederlander had not housed a hit in 15 years.
What would happen if buyers were not found? That was a question raised by a member of the City Planning Commission, Brenda Levin, as the land-use review began earlier this month. Although she said she shared the belief that the city ought to help the theater industry, Ms. Levin wondered whether that goal was best served by an unpredictable real estate market.
Looking at the question from a different angle, another commission member, Amanda M. Burden, raised questions at the hearing about the overall impact of the proposal if all the air rights were exploited, particularly since many transfers could occur without public review.
Mr. Rose said that ultimately there would be only a "marginal increase in density," and that the proposal would distribute development potential more evenly throughout the theater district.
BUT critics argue that by making air rights easier to use, planners invite the construction of additional floor space that would probably not otherwise be built -- thus practically raising density, even if not technically doing so.
"All New Yorkers are going to have to live with bigger buildings in mid-Manhattan in order for the theater industry to prosper," said Kevin A. Finnegan, chairman of the Eighth Avenue rezoning task force of Community Board 5. "I have to question whether zoning is the proper mechanism for assisting the theater industry."
There are two other zoning districts, around Grand Central Terminal and the South Street Seaport, where a more liberal transfer of air rights are allowed. They have scarcely proliferated over the years and city planners believe each district has a distinct rationale.
That does not stop some local leaders from wondering whether the Giuliani administration will use this zoning approach elsewhere. Lola Finkelstein, chairwoman of Community Board 5, said, "We are concerned that the wider transfer of development rights can be a precedent that would be upsetting to the whole planning process in New York."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Through the Windshield, A Vision for the State

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
When Governor Whitman announced four years ago that she would not use the state helicopter to get to most of her official events, she saved the state $7 million -- and earned some political points.
But perhaps the biggest gain for New Jersey from her decision to be driven around the state is what she saw from her car window. 
 As governor, you get to every corner of the state. And from her car, Mrs. Whitman could not help but see the impact of years of poor land-use planning. The abandoned buildings in once-thriving urban neighborhoods. Suburban sprawl clogging already congested roadways. Unbridled development on farmland in communities that do not have the infrastructure and other resources to support it.
"Spending so much time in a car seeing New Jersey roll by has given me a sense of urgency about our state's future," Mrs. Whitman said during her second inaugural address last week. "I have a vision for that future -- a vision for rebuilding our cities, preserving our open space and enriching our sense of personal responsibility."
It was a bold, ambitious agenda, one that insures Mrs. Whitman a legacy as one of the state's most visionary and important governors -- if she succeeds in making it a reality.
Even Democrats, who have been quick to criticize Mrs. Whitman for not offering a vision beyond cutting taxes, offered warm praise for her ideas.
"She set forth a strong, clear vision for an activist government," said James E. McGreevey, the Democrat who nearly defeated Mrs. Whitman last fall. "It was a progressive agenda that Democrats and Republicans alike ought to support."
Senator Robert G. Torricelli, also a Democrat, said: "I admire Governor Whitman for taking on the fight. I hope that she has the strength to win."
Mrs. Whitman may face opposition from her own party within the Republican-controlled Legislature for some of her plans. Builders and developers have been longtime contributors to the state's Republican Party, and they can be expected to put up a strong fight.
Also, most land-use decisions are made by local officials. Over the years, many local officials have embraced new development because of the prospect of expanding the property tax base. But many towns are now struggling with the high cost of expanding services. Persuading some municipalities to consider the cost of new development over the long run will not be easy.
Then there is the state government bureaucracy. State officials have virtually ignored New Jersey's five-year-old master plan, which has determined what areas of the state should accommodate further development.
Mrs. Whitman said she has directed her administration to use the state plan as a "fundamental guide" in making permit and financing decisions. She promises swift state approval for development projects that are consistent with the state plan's goals.
She also proposes preserving 300,000 more acres during her next term, with an ultimate goal of protecting 1 million acres over the next decade. What she did not spell out last week, however, is where she would get the money. In the past, New Jerseyans have regularly supported bond issues to preserve open space. But they may not be so quick to support a tax increase.
For the nation's cities, Mrs. Whitman proposes spending $400 million to help mayors reclaim abandoned buildings and turn them into affordable housing. In the past, Republican lawmakers have demonstrated their reluctance to pour more state dollars into urban areas, since most of their constituents do not live in them.
Also, it will take much more than turning vacant buildings into affordable housing to revive cities.
Although Mrs. Whitman has repeatedly emphasized the importance of creating jobs in New Jersey, she did not offer any new programs to spur economic development in urban areas. The cities have not shared in the recent economic boom. Cities need jobs and affordable housing. More jobs in cities also means fewer people willing to move far away from them.
Mrs. Whitman has taken some positive steps in this direction. She recently signed legislation aimed at making abandoned factories and vacant land in cities more attractive to developers. In her first term, she also expanded programs to lure businesses and commercial development to cities, like enterprise zones that offer tax breaks to companies.
But is the Whitman administration prepared to move even more aggressively to direct companies to locate in urban areas? Will state-financed incentives continue to be offered to companies that want to locate in suburban office parks that planners say often contribute to suburban sprawl?
Mrs. Whitman demonstrated that she has a vision to take on the most important problems facing New Jersey. She has vowed to tackle problems that have defied solution, not only in New Jersey but across the country.
The first measure of her commitment will come next month, when she unveils her new state budget and shows how she will back up her pledges with state dollars. The next measure will be her efforts to persuade reluctant state lawmakers to support her plan and bureaucrats to carry it out.
The changes, if they come, will not be hard to see. Just look out your car window.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
A Mortgage Broker Fee on the Ropes

BYLINE: By CAROL MARIE CROPPER 

 BODY:
THE battle between home buyers and the mortgage industry intensified recently when a Federal appeals court ruled that certain fees banks pay to mortgage brokers were little more than kickbacks.
At issue is an estimated $7 billion annually in "yield spread premiums," the fees the mortgage lenders pay the brokers for sending customers to them for their loans. They are paid when the mortgage broker gets the home buyer to pay an interest rate higher than he could otherwise get at the same bank. 
 Consumer advocates say banning the fees will mean lower interest rates for home buyers using brokers.
But the banking industry says that the premium is an accepted way to compensate brokers who generate loans for them, and that it cuts a buyer's closing costs by shifting part of the broker's fee, otherwise paid by the borrower, to the lender.
Still, in a growing number of lawsuits around the country, home buyers and consumer advocates say the fee is little more than an inducement for a broker to misrepresent the lowest available mortgage rates.
Earlier this month, the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit in Atlanta ruled in Culpepper v. Inland Mortgage that the $1,263 yield spread premium paid by Inland to a broker was a violation of the Federal Real Estate Settlement Procedure Act's rule against kickbacks.
It was the first decision on the issue by an appellate court and it overturned a summary judgment by the Federal District Court in Birmingham, Ala., that the fee was permissible. Unless reversed, the appellate ruling will govern cases brought in the circuit, which includes Alabama, Florida and Georgia. Lower courts in other jurisdictions could also look to it as a precedent.
The decision came in a 1996 suit against the Inland Mortgage Corporation, now known as the Irwin Mortgage Corporation, based in Indianapolis. A Birmingham couple, John and Patricia Culpepper, sued after taking out a $76,000 home loan in 1995.
They contended that, while they had paid Premiere Mortgage, the broker that prepared their loan papers, a $760 origination fee, Inland had paid the additional premium because Premiere wrote the loan at an interest rate of 7.5 percent rather than the 7.25 percent they could have qualified for at Inland.
"It is undisputed that the payment of the yield spread premium was not tied to the quantity or quality of the services that Premiere provided," the court ruled. "Rather, the sole determinant of whether a yield spread premium would be paid was the interest rate on the loan."
The Mortgage Bankers Association of America, in a friend-of-the-court brief supporting Inland's position, estimated that lenders paid brokers, who now arrange more than half of all mortgage loans, $7 billion in such fees in 1996.
David Donaldson, the Culpeppers' lawyer, called the ruling "a landmark decision that protects consumers against these abusive practices."
"Unless the mortgage banking industry wants to violate the law, they're going to have to change," he said.
Lawyers for the industry, though, said the ruling might not be that big a victory for home buyers, since it did not address whether the case, which was sent back to the District Court for final disposition, would become a class action.
A class-action lawsuit would be a major headache for the industry, said William Cumberland, general counsel for the Mortgage Bankers Association. "Class actions don't go to trial," he said. "The threat of loss is so great that you've got to settle."
Even when there is no class-action threat, the industry has been settling some cases. Last year, for example, a Federal district judge in Virginia found against the practice of yield spread premiums. But the case was settled after the judge denied the motion for class-action certification.
Robert Platte, a lawyer for Irwin Mortgage, argued that it was also unclear whether the ruling calling the fee a violation of the real estate act is open for reconsideration when the case goes back to the lower court. Irwin has not decided whether it will ask the appeals court to reconsider its opinion, Mr. Platte said.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 15; Column 5; Sports Desk

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
Saving Salmon In the Atlantic Makes Sense

BYLINE: By Nelson Bryant 

 BODY:
A few days ago, I thawed out a small Atlantic salmon that I caught in Caribou Pool on the Upsalquitch River in Canada last summer, and poached it for supper.
Handsomely bedecked with sliced cucumbers, sliced hard-boiled eggs and served cold with a fresh dill, lemon juice, caper and sour cream sauce, it received the reverential treatment Ruth and I always accord one of its kind. 
 There was poignancy in our traditional "thanks to salmon and the gods of the chase" invocation because it was, I had resolved, the last Atlantic salmon I would kill until I am persuaded that the species is well on the road to recovery.
Atlantic salmon populations of North American origin -- the only ones for which I fish -- are at their lowest points in history. This situation developed after nearly three decades of conservation efforts that until about three years ago seemed to be working. Those efforts included severely curtailing the daily and seasonal bag limits for recreational anglers, ending most netting of the species off Canada, and establishing, through an international organization, quotas for salmon fisheries off Greenland and the Faeroe Islands, locations to which the salmon travel while at sea.
My decision not to kill salmon was triggered by a November 1997 resolution of the Atlantic Salmon Federation that asked anglers to release all of the salmon they catch, even if keeping them is legal. The World Wildlife Fund and the Salmon Trust of Scotland have endorsed this proposal. Even if anglers agree to this, it isn't very likely that the salmon's plunge toward erasure will be halted, but it is one way to immediately reduce the attrition on this glorious fish.
Some anglers are already releasing all or most of the salmon they catch. And even now in eastern Canada, which accounts for almost all the wild salmon of North American origin, Quebec and Labrador are the only places where anglers may keep a large salmon, one that has been at sea for more than one year and produces more eggs than a grilse, a salmon that returns to its natal stream to spawn after only a year in the ocean.
Elsewhere in Canada, only grilse may be kept -- no more than seven of them at the most -- during an entire season. Salmon conservationists have also successfully promoted salmon farming. Today more than 95 percent of the salmon sold in the world market are farmed fish.
There is a twist to this success story, however. Farmed salmon that escape from their cages are mating with wild salmon and producing strains with inferior spawning capabilities.
Why, given the plight of the salmon, would reasonable anglers be reluctant to release all of the salmon that they catch? Some might reason that commercial fishermen, American Indians under special dispensation and many recreational anglers are killing salmon, so why shouldn't we? Still others, and I was one of them until recently, are enmeshed in a food-gathering mystique that, in the case of salmon or any other similarly threatened species, cannot be justified.
As one whose childhood was spent in rural surroundings in the late 1920's and early 30's, fishing -- whether for trout, perch, striped bass or bluefish -- was fun, but it was also for food. For me, cleaning, cooking and eating the catch brought the endeavor full circle, and lifted it beyond the mere pursuit of recreation. For decades I felt that luring, hooking, playing and releasing all fish, presumably to demonstrate one's skill and to observe and experience the quarry's antics, was silly.
Today I no longer feel this way and realize that I was carrying old attitudes into a new era, an era in which there are too many of us pursuing too few fish. I was failing to comprehend that angling without food in mind can be both honorable and pleasurable. If a species of fish is in deep trouble and laws do not provide for its adequate protection, why shouldn't thinking anglers impose a no-kill restriction on themselves and hope that others will emulate them?
Studies have shown that, if warming water has not placed them under stress, nearly all salmon survive the trauma of catch and release if brought to shore as swiftly as possible and handled properly during release.
Thus it would be possible to sustain the thriving sport fishing industry for salmon in Canada without a single fish being killed intentionally, an all-important consideration for a country that is plagued by unemployment.
The greatest threat to the salmon is commercial fishing in salt water for mixed stocks of the species. Such salmon could be from several rivers, and there is no way for the fishermen to identify their origin as they tumble on board.
There are other problems: proliferation of salmon-eating seals; the degradation of salmon rivers by bad logging practices and acid rain, and the disruption of the oceanic food chain by overfishing. A bizarre example of a potential disruption is the Danes' fishery for sand eels in the North Sea. These ubiquitous little forage fish, which are near the bottom of the food chain, are being processed for use, among other things, as fuel oil.
So to the salmon angler I say go forth and hone your skills, return your precious quarry to the water, and perhaps there will come a time when -- with a clear conscience -- you can bear a wild fish to the table triumphantly.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A fisherman putting back a grilse into the Upsalquitch River. (Richard Franklin)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2324 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Farewell to Arms, Hello to Doubts

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ON Mark Hoye's desk in the brand-new suburban offices of the mortgage company where he works are a few reminders of his former life as a Navy aviator -- a model of the P3 Orion submarine tracker he navigated in the Persian Gulf and the plaque they gave him after he came home.
He unconsciously hugs the plaque to his chest as he tells about the time he and his crew spotted some Iraqis rolling free-floating mines off a speedboat. Using radar to "paint" the surface of the ocean, his team marked them for destruction by smart bomb. He got a nice letter from the high command for that one, he says. 
 And about two years later, in the huge downsizing that shrank the ranks of the United States military to 1.4 million from 2.1 million over the last decade, he was pushed into early retirement at age 33.
Like many others who left the military in the years after the cold war, Mr. Hoye eventually found a good job in a good economy. He bought a house in Virginia and has gotten to know his children in a way that he says would never have been possible in the military.
Still, the transition has been bewildering.
He knew he could fly a plane from Japan to a dot in the Indian Ocean and not get lost; he did not know how to steer clear of office politics. He knew he could be locked in a small, dark space and keep his cool; he did not know how to handle the everyday domestic stresses that go with being a husband and father who is around more.
After leaving the Navy nearly five years ago, at the height of the reductions in force, Mr. Hoye worked for two different start-up satellite communications companies that eventually went under. He also went to graduate school to study international business -- "a waste of money," he says -- before finding his current position, as a loan officer, nine months ago.
Along the way, he struggled with depression, new strains on his marriage and the strange feeling that he had almost been relocated to some alien planet.
"We crushed the Iraqis and had a feeling of accomplishment, and the drawdown hit us hard," said Mr. Hoye, now 37, whose neat pinstripes and perfectly shined shoes set him apart in a dressed-down office. "We didn't understand, and none of us wanted to go. I'm starting to do better, but there have been some rough periods."
In the military, he said, "what I did mattered."
"What I was doing was on the front page of all the world's newspapers," he said. "To be yanked out of that in midcareer -- I have not stopped grieving. I try to keep myself entertained. I have season tickets to the Orioles. But there's just as much stress now, where you just want to choke somebody on the phone. And I felt safer in my P3 Orion than driving on I-95 every day."
Of course, some former soldiers and sailors have always found civilian life more daunting than war. And while no one has gathered data on the more than 700,000 men and women who have left the military since the late 1980's, it is clear that many of every rank go on to do extremely well.
But many who were pushed out of the military say they remain traumatized by the experience, whether they were literally asked to leave, were offered early retirement, were denied a promotion in a force with fewer opportunities or decided for other reasons not to stay in a smaller military.
Many had never received a negative job evaluation, so they were both hurt and uncomprehending: What had they done wrong? And what of the job security they had counted on? Some said they felt even more betrayed than private-sector employees in similar situations because there are no other jobs in their field, strictly speaking; you cannot apply to the Navy when the Air Force does not want you anymore.
Sam Martin, a public-affairs officer who was asked to leave the Air Force in 1992 after almost 26 years of steady advancement, said he found the change stimulating -- once he got over the initial shock.
Today, teaching civics to eighth graders at Rocky Run Middle School in Chantilly, Va., Mr. Martin, 55, says he is completely engaged in his new work. "The kids do not snap to attention," he laughed. "But they're good kids; they keep you in stitches. I equate the military officer and the teacher trying to do so much for the nation."
Others, however, remain deeply resentful, feeling that their sacrifices were repaid with ingratitude. And not one of the several dozen former military men and women interviewed for this article said the shift had been painless.
They have gone from a highly structured life to winging it, from knowing years in advance what their next move would be to the uncertainty of the private sector, from being part of a community to standing alone. Some said that they felt uncertain for a while about their clothes, hair and other matters of personal style, and that they had to work on their manner of speech, too, turning "0900 hours" back into "9 o'clock."
One former officer had never had a business lunch until a couple of years ago and was unsure how to behave. Another found it strange that in his new job, nobody knew how much money anyone else was making. Several said that they were initially too trusting of employers and colleagues and too-good-to-be-true job offers. You have to trust the guy in the next foxhole, they concluded, but the guy in the next cubicle may be a different story.
"I have business associates now, as opposed to people you work with who are truly your friends," said Nadine R. Kokolis, 30, of Chantilly. Ms. Kokolis said she liked her new life but missed the camaraderie in the Army Corps of Engineers.
More than a few veteran officers lamented their skimpy business experience, even when they had shouldered considerable responsibility in the military. Some said they felt misled about how much their management skills would help in the private sector.
And despite a variety of career transition programs, some said they came out of the service without much of a plan for the future, because military culture has traditionally frowned on those who spend much time preparing for their next job, instead of focusing 100 percent on the mission at hand. There is a sneering term for that: retired on active duty.
So, several former officers said, they worked hard until the end of their last day, and then figured the rest out later.
"It's like dying," said Steve Strobridge, a retired Air Force colonel who works for the Retired Officers Association in Alexandria, Va. "It sneaks up on you."
MOST of those who were actually asked to leave the military already had 20 years of service and were eligible for pensions. And those who were within a few years of qualifying for a pension were offered early retirement on a case-by-case basis, receiving a choice of a lump sum or monthly payments based on the number of years they had served. The monthly payments ranged from $471 for the lowest-ranking enlisted person to $2,349 for commissioned officers. The lump sums were about $12,000 to almost $150,000, based on pay grade and years of service.
Others with less experience were told that they had little chance of promotion in a shrinking military, and while they were not literally dismissed, they were encouraged to look for other work. And most of those who left under those circumstances got no severance package.
There are roughly 90,000 former military men and women in the Washington area, many of them drawn here by military industry and Government jobs. But a number of those have recently been forced back into the job market for a second and even a third time because both of those sectors are shrinking, too.
Because many military officers were given considerable responsibility at a younger age than would generally be possible in the private sector, most do very well in their new fields, said H. W. Buse 3d, a former Marine colonel who runs a job placement service at the Retired Officers Association. Mr. Buse said his clients usually found other jobs in one to three months -- though the average was closer to six months at the height of the downsizing.
Stephen Wright, an official of the regional blood bank operations affiliated with the American Red Cross, has hired several former military officers in the last year and is so impressed that he now looks for them when there are openings.
"I find them to be good hires for managers' jobs because military people tend to be very disciplined, focused and very flexible, which in our operation is a real asset," said Mr. Wright, who said he had no military background beyond the Reserve Officers Training Corps in school. "A lot of them have had some medical training, too, so their learning curve tends to be shorter."
Of course, while officers with such technical skills are usually snapped up right away, military generalists -- infantry soldiers, for example -- often find it more difficult to find the right job. And even if they do find a comparable position, they may not find it as satisfying. In the Army, a clerk is not only a clerk but a soldier who happens to be a clerk, a part of the team.
On a recent morning, about 40 former military men and women who were looking for work gathered at the Army-Navy Club in downtown Washington for a monthly breakfast organized by Peter McCarthy, who runs a career counseling and outplacement service, McCarthy & Company. When he retired from the Marines and took a job in investment banking 18 years ago, he said, he felt like "a giant tuna swimming in the Baltimore aquarium with a bunch of piranha."
This morning, as he he surveys the crowd lining up for eggs and sausage, he talks about why he feels a little protective of them.
"I don't want them to jump into something entrepreneurial too quickly," he says. "They may be too trusting of somebody saying, 'Invest in this business.' They have no real-world experience."
Across a room full of people with excellent posture, nice manners and the unmistakable look of apprehension that says, "How did it ever come to this?" Mr. McCarthy spies one of the success stories he has invited here to give a little pep talk, and he motions him over. Al Ross, a former Navy captain who retired in 1993 after 26 years, says he now has a healthy business in international marketing consulting -- despite having come out of the service with little idea of how to proceed.
"My business has evolved, but not as the result of any master plan," Mr. Ross says, laughing. "Networking in the military is kind of distasteful. That would be getting ahead not on merit but on who you know."
After breakfast, Mr. McCarthy gets up and asks everyone to take a turn giving "a 30-second commercial on yourself."
"And remember the golden rule. What's that, gentlemen?" he says, putting a hand to his ear. "I can't hear you! It's "No acronyms!' " They're lost, he said, on people in the private sector.
At Mr. McCarthy's table, one man calls him "sir" and gets a reprimand. "You drop that," Mr. McCarthy tells him, "or you're going to intimidate the hell out of people."
The man, Neil Nelson, still in Army uniform, is a colonel who plans to retire next October. He starts again: "Sir, I -- oh, I apologize, I'll get used to it. It's been 32 years."
Another man at the table, Joel Keefer, who left the Navy in 1993 after 22 years, says he is seeking work again, in public relations. He had worked for a health care telecommunications company that later folded.
The loyalty and can-do attitude that served so well in the military have not been much help in civilian life so far, he says, seeming a little embarrassed that he stuck with the company to the end.
He stayed on even after the company stopped paying him, though he eventually got a check, and he still says "us" when he refers to the business. "I knew the end was coming, but my approach was, 'Stay with it and we can make this work,' " says Mr. Keefer, 48, who lives in Vienna, Va. "I don't want to say I had blind faith, but I trusted the situation. If I had shifted my attention to getting another position, it wouldn't have been so stressful."
Even those who have found good jobs quickly say they have found some aspects of civilian life confounding.
After six promotions in three years at two different companies, Marty Keeley, 46, a former Marine infantry officer, is now president and chief executive of Ingram Library Services, a unit of Ingram Industries, a book distributor based near Nashville. Even so, he says, he has faced "a vertical learning curve" during the last few years in bridging the cultural divide between military and civilian life.
He found that even socializing was a new experience outside the military, without the framework of strict rules about fraternization. And especially among people his own age, he has felt he had to overcome certain stereotypes about the military. "Some you have to win them over, like, 'Hey, I'm not a baby killer,' " Mr. Keeley said.
Still, he said, he would never have done as well without his experience in the military. "I'm not using the survival skills I learned as an infantry officer; I haven't rappelled since I left," he explained. "But I use the persuasive skills every day."
WHATEVER the challenges, few veteran officers are openly critical of their treatment, either by the military or civilian employers. "You do what you've got to do and let everyone else whine and complain," said a former Air Force captain, one of many who says he has a "consulting business" but means he is mostly looking for work. "I'm looking," he said, "but I've succeeded in everything I've done, and I make no excuses for myself."
And many retain such great affection for the military that they would return to the fold tomorrow, if they could. Mr. Hoye, who misses his days as a Naval officer, knows there's no going back but hopes that his sons, Tyler, now 3, and Matthew, 6, will someday pick up where he left off.
"My dream for them," he said, "is the Naval Academy."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Scandals Can Hurt Bulls and Presidents

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Scandal engulfed Washington. A recession arrived. Stock prices plunged. The Vice President replaced the President.
That describes the situation 25 years ago, when the Watergate scandal dominated the news. And it describes what happened 50 years earlier, in the Teapot Dome scandal. 
 A new scandal is engrossing the country. And though it is premature to talk of the end of Bill Clinton's Presidency, that did not stop Wall Street traders last week, some of whom saw signs of his demise in everything from rising gold prices to a declining dollar. Falling tobacco stocks, they said, showed that investors feared that a President Al Gore would be even tougher on cigarettes.
Even allowing for Wall Street's tendency to leap to conclusions, there are parallels to be pondered. In 1923, a scandal broke about corrupt leases of Government oilfields known as Teapot Dome. It might have led to the impeachment of President Warren G. Harding had he not died before the news came out. A recession arrived, perhaps exacerbated by currency collapse in Germany and an earthquake that devastated Japan.
The stock market outlook appeared to be bright as 1923 began, and when the Dow Jones industrial average peaked in March, it was up 62 percent in less than two years. By late October, with the recession on, the Dow had lost 19 percent of its value. Not, as bear markets go, a severe one, but one that alarmed a lot of investors.
In January 1973, a quarter of a century ago, the Dow peaked at a record 1,051.69, up 67 percent in less than three years. It had been merely the most recent leg of a long bull market, which had seen the index leap more than 1,000 percent in just over 30 years, beginning on an April day in 1942 when World War II news was dismaying.
From early 1973 to late 1974, as the Presidency of Richard M. Nixon fell apart and as that of his successor began, the Dow fell 45 percent. A Mideast war brought on an oil price shock and a severe recession.
Some people date the current bull market to that day in December 1974 when share prices bottomed amid worries that the United States could not compete in a world of soaring commodity prices. From then until the Dow's peak last summer, a span of more than 23 years, the Dow was up more than 1,300 percent.
The 1923-24 recession was a mild one, and the bear market of 1923 was soon forgotten as share prices recovered and then went on a wild upward ride that ended with the 1929 crash. After 1973, by contrast, the stock market did not recover for nearly a decade, as investors became thoroughly disenchanted.
Consider the changing nature of scandals: Early in this century, it was politicians going after money. In the Nixon years, it was a search for power, and a desire to destroy political opponents, that brought down a Presidency. Now the allegations concern sex. This does not sound like progress.
In 1923, and 1973, disturbing overseas events came along as Washington was preoccupied with its own problems. Would the foreign problems have had less impact and been dealt with better had scandal not consumed the capital? There is no way to tell.
Now, with Asia in crisis, Congress appears to be more interested in whether the President lied about his sexual conduct than it is in coming up with the money needed to bolster the International Monetary Fund.
Investors should hope that this scandal quickly fades away. When scandals dominate Washington, bulls rarely dominate Wall Street.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk
